title: Review: Evan Thomass Being Nixon: A Man Divided, a Glossy Biography
description: Evan Thomass introduction to his glossy, armchair-ready biography, Being Nixon, explains this undertaking as an effort to understand what it was like to actually be Nixon. This explanation sounds clear, even in a world already filled with efforts to nail, defend, rehabilitate, shrink and compartmentalize parts or all of that disgraced president and his life.

description: THE last time a boat sailed into New York Harbor bearing the Marquis de Lafayette, the arrival touched off a frenzy that would put Beatlemania to shame.

title: Donna Karans Fans and Friends Discuss Her Legacy
description: On Tuesday, Donna Karan stepped down from her namesake company after more than 30 years in business. In that time she became one of the most famous designers in America, started an enormously successful bridge line, sold her company to LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and was an icon for working women.

title: Stephen Colbert Interviews Eminem on Michigan Public Access
description: Stephen Colbert doesnt have his own television show yet, but he continues to find unexpected (and increasingly esoteric) ways to remind people that he will soon be returning to the airwaves.

At 90 Smith Street, Brooklyn.

Smith, former majority leader of the New York State Senate, to seven years in prison for consenting to the payment of tens of thousands of dollars to Republican Party leaders to permit him, as a registered Queens Democrat, to run for mayor in 2013 on their partys line.

description: ATHENS  This is what it looks like when a country goes bankrupt.

description: Nicholas Winton, who died Wednesday at 106, went 50 years without telling anyone about how he had rescued 669 children from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia.

title: The Difference Between Listening Up and Tuning Out
description: RIDE the subway, sit in a coffee shop or just walk down the street and youll see people wearing earphones. They are everywhere. In some settings, youre the odd man out if you dont have wires dangling from your ears.

title: Charles Harbutt: Photographer, Teacher, Mentor
description: Charles Harbutt, a former president of Magnum Photos, died overnight Monday in Monteagle, Tenn., where he was conducting a photography workshop. He was 79 and had been suffering from emphysema, his wife, the photographer Joan Liftin, said.

title: Russia Sees a Threat in Its Converts to Islam
description: ERZURUM, Turkey   As a teenager in St. Petersburg, Maksim Baidak hung out with neo-Nazis and right-wing nationalists, but the Russian security services mostly left him alone.

title: Puerto Rico Needs Debt Relief
description: Puerto Ricos governor has bluntly declared that the commonwealths $72 billion debt is unpayable. The issue now is how to come up with a credible plan to put the islands finances and economy on sound footing.

title: Tanning Bed Use Falls
description: Use of tanning beds declined to 4.2 percent of American adults in 2013, down from 5.5 percent in 2010, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The findings, published in a report in JAMA Dermatology, showed broad declines in the practice of indoor tanning by young people. Just 8.6 percent of Americans ages 18 to 29 tanned indoors in 2013, down from 11.3 percent in 2010. The reports authors attributed the change to more awareness of the risks posed by indoor tanning, a shift that was aided by new laws to limit use of tanning beds by minors.

title: Report Concludes Police Shooting Victim in Washington State Probably Had a Rock
description: SEATTLE  A man who was shot by the police in February in Pasco, Wash., was likely in possession of a rock when a second hail of bullets fired by the officers killed him, according to an investigative report released Wednesday by prosecutors.

title: An Architects Vision in the Desert
description: Donald Wexler created steel houses in the Desert Modern style that helped make Palm Springs a showcase for midcentury modernism.

title: Donald Wexler, Architect Who Gave Shape to Palm Springs, Dies at 89
description: Donald Wexler, an architect whose innovative steel houses and soaring glass-fronted terminal at the Palm Springs International Airport helped make Palm Springs, Calif., a showcase for midcentury modernism, died on Friday at his home in Palm Desert. He was 89.

title: File Is Said to Confirm N.S.A. Spied on Merkel
description: BERLIN  More than three years ago, Chancellor Angela Merkel professed to be at a loss over the option of debt relief that would best stem the crisis in Greece. Yet even then, she feared that no amount of coaching from visiting experts would resolve the problems in Athens.

title: Kathryn Barnard, Innovator in Care and Development of Newborns, Dies at 77
description: Kathryn Barnard, a professor of nursing whose expertise in the social and emotional development of very young children led her to develop innovative techniques for better parenting of infants, died on Saturday at her home in Seattle. She was 77.

title: New York Comptroller Faults Payment System in 39 City Agencies
description: City Comptroller Scott M. Stringer sent letters to 39 city agencies on Wednesday over what he called a misuse of a payment system, suggesting that swaths of municipal spending had not received proper oversight.

title: A Call to Revise How Chicago Funds Teacher Pensions
description: CHICAGO  As public school officials here announced $200 million in budget cuts and outlined plans to eliminate about 1,400 jobs, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday called for a broad rethinking of how teacher pensions in Illinois are funded.

title: Rule From S.E.C. Would Allow Companies to Take Back Executive Bonuses

title: Delays, Migration Problems and Blame Stretch Across English Channel
description: PARIS  On both sides of the English Channel, thousands of longhaul trucks have come to a halt, the lines stretching into the flat green countryside of France and England on Wednesday as the trucks sat idled by the third day of a strike by ferry workers.

And Bill Levin, who was introduced as the Grand Poobah of this new church, finished the gathering with a simple message: Light up, folks!

The embrace of statistical analysis in baseball has led to shifting dynamics in many organizations, with the manager no longer considered the primary decision maker on all matters concerning the 25 players who play for him. Instead, he is increasingly regarded as a steward whose job is to carry out upper managements vision, which is dictated by data rather than gut feelings.

title: Father of Erebus and Nyx

A lot of tricky stuff has to happen to get your puzzles to you, including getting them past the EMUs in one piece, so its not that far-fetched to think that my brain might worry about what might happen if, say, parts of the clues suddenly disappeared.

He was 91.

Afterward, as he was being examined in the trainers room, he looked as if he could not bend the knee.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 4:30 P.M. (E!) MAGIC MIKE (2012) In a role inspired by his stint as a stripper in Florida, Channing Tatum stars as the gyrating main attraction at Xquisite, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called Steven Soderberghs funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream. Alex Pettyfer is Adam, a college dropout who is pushed onstage. At first hes resistant. Then Madonnas Like a Virgin begins to throb. The collaboration between Mr. Soderbergh and the relatively untested Mr. Tatum is itself a gamble, one that has brought out the best in each, Ms. Dargis said.

description: With his previous film Senna, the director Asif Kapadia weaved together existing footage to tell the story of the Brazilian Formula One driver Ayrton Senna. He revisits that technique for the documentary Amy, an intimate look at the life and premature death of the British pop singer Amy Winehouse.

title: South Korean Ex-Premier Indicted on Charge of Taking Illegal Donation
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A former prime minister of South Korea and a provincial governor were indicted on Thursday on charges of receiving illegal political funds from a businessman who recently committed suicide, prosecutors said.

title: An Upper East Side Apartment Hunt Goes Full Circle
description: As a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, Callia Hargrove tried living at home with her parents in Rockland County, N.Y.

title: U.S. Economy Adds 223,000 Jobs; Unemployment at 5.3%
description: Not too hot, not too cold. But not, alas, just right.

title: Greek Referendum on Offer That Is Off the Table Baffles Voters
description: ATHENS  Imagine the fate of your country hangs on a yes-or-no question. The question is drafted in cryptic, bureaucratic language and asks you to decide on an economic program that no longer exists. Leaders in neighboring countries are begging you to vote yes. Your government is begging you to vote no.

title: Review: Amy, an Intimate Diary of Amy Winehouses Rise and Destruction
description: In The Dogs Are Eating Your Mother, a poem that Ted Hughes addressed to his children and, by extension, critics and fans, he writes of a kind of hyena tearing at the body of his dead wife, Sylvia Plath. They dug her out. Now they batten/On the cornucopia/Of her body. In Amy, a shattering biographical portrait of the British singer and songwriter Amy Winehouse, you catch sight of some other hyenas every time the paparazzi go in for the kill. The photographers shove their cameras toward her haunted face and ravaged body, ripping at her with each new shot.

title: Scott Walkers Hard Right Turn in Iowa May Hurt Him Elsewhere
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spent months persuading influential Republicans that he alone had the impressive conservative achievements and mainstream American appeal needed to not only win the partys nomination but also recapture the White House.

title: Weak Power Grids in Africa Stunt Economies and Fire Up Tempers
description: JOHANNESBURG  In the darkened and chilly parking lot of a mall, a suburban family huddling around a shopping cart shared a snack on a Friday evening out. After finding their favorite restaurant closed because of a blackout, Buhle Ngwenya, with her two sons and two nephews, settled for meat pies from one of the few stores open in the mall.

title: News Qs | Misty Copeland Is Promoted to Principal Dancer at American Ballet Theater
description: Note: Were experimenting with a new format for this feature, including a new name. Tell us what you think!

title: Parker Poseys Offbeat Glamour
description: Parker Posey emerged from her downtown Manhattan lobby in a zip-up black jumpsuit streaked with white, her newly blond hair in a cotton candy nimbus. She could have passed for Daryl Hannah in Blade Runner were it not for the fluffy white Bichon-Maltese poodle at her feet.

title: Ferry Capsizes Off Philippines, Leaving Dozens Dead
description: MANILA  A wooden ferry that was heavily loaded with passengers and cargo sank in stormy weather in the central Philippines on Thursday, killing at least 36 people, officials said.

title: R.B.S. to Reduce Cash Management Operations Outside Britain and Ireland
description: LONDON  The reshaping of Royal Bank of Scotland continued on Thursday as the lender announced plans to significantly reduce its cash management services outside Britain and Ireland.

title: Jitters in Tech World Over New Chinese Security Law
description: HONG KONG  When a draft of Chinas new national security law was made public in May, critics argued that it was too broad and left much open to interpretation.

title: Hotel Review: The Godolphin Arms in Cornwall, England
description: From 150, or $230 at $1.55 to the pound.

title: A Disney World Vacation in One Day
description: Orlando: So much excitement, so little time.

title: Thursdays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Times Readers in Europe React to Debt and Deals in Greece
description: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Cambrian Explosions Strange-Looking Poster Child
description: The animal kingdom got off to a slow start. Studies on DNA indicate that the first animals evolved more than 750 million years ago, but for well over 200 million years, they left a meager mark on the fossil record. As best as paleontologists can tell, the animal kingdom during that time consisted of little more than sponges and other creatures rooted to the ocean floor.

title: Transgender Rights, Bangladesh Style
description: On March 30, Labannya Hijra became a Bangladeshi hero. Witnessing the murder by Islamist radicals of the secular blogger Oyasiqur Rhaman on a street in Dhaka, she grabbed at the fleeing assailants. Her courageous intervention led to the arrest of two men, who later confessed to the killing.

title: New York Today: A Revolution, Relearned
description: Good morning on this gleaming Thursday.

title: A Quick Puzzle to Test Your Problem Solving
description: A short game sheds light on government policy, corporate America, and why no one likes to be wrong.

title: The 6.21.15 Issue
description: RE: JUDGES

title: How to Sell the Most Cookies
description: Smile. No one wants to buy from a person who is frowning, says Katie Francis, 13, who sold 22,200 boxes of Girl Scout cookies this year, breaking the world record she set last year. Look and act like a professional, even if youre just a child. When making the rounds in Oklahoma City, Francis wears her troop uniform and passes out business cards. Dont waste time trying to convince naysayers; instead, move on and find the yesses. On school days, Francis works past dark, and she logs 12- to 13-hour days on the weekends.

title: The Word That Is a Prayer
description: What I like best about poems, beyond their sheer aesthetic pleasures, is the way that the intimacy of a single voice speaking across time and space can become a call to empathy. In this poem, the close and particular focus invites a kind of mindfulness  a way to recognize ourselves in others, linked by our common need.

title: Revisiting The Americans
description: Selections from Robert Franks midcentury classic, one of the most influential photography books of all time.

title: Divided Sky
description: Had I known I would spend so much time thinking about the southern Syrian city of Daraa, I would have paid more attention when I drove through it in 2009. I was a young teacher then, living in Jordan and en route to Damascus for a short holiday. Im certain I didnt even bother to remember the name at the time, much less notice any of the details. But two years later, Daraa was where the crisis in Syria would begin, with the bloody suppression of a protest against Bashar al-Assad. Today, opposition and regime forces are still battling to control the symbolic city; more than half its population has been displaced, and many of its buildings have been destroyed.

title: Restaurant Report: Edwins Leadership & Restaurant Institute in Cleveland
description: It is easy to root for Edwins Leadership & Restaurant Institute  and part of its likability comes from the slightly uneasy experience of anticipating the meal.

title: Letter of Recommendation: The Oxford English Dictionary
description: Until the appearance of the Oxford English Dictionary in 1928, Samuel Johnsons 1755 Dictionary of the English Language was the pre-eminent authority on spelling and usage. Titanic an achievement as it was  Johnson wrote it largely on his own, with the help of a few assistants  it contained only those words the great lexicographer thought worth knowing. Richard Chenevix Trench, dean of Westminster and an early champion of the project that would result in the O.E.D., opposed the very idea of curation, as he explained to the Philological Society in London in November 1857.

title: Dinesh DSouza Isnt the Real Criminal
description: After your conviction for violating campaign-finance law, you served an eight-month sentence, spending nights in a confinement center. Irving Kristol once said that a neoconservative is a liberal who has been mugged by reality. So whats a conservative whose reality is being surrounded by muggers? Unlike white-collar prisons, the confinement center has the full gamut of criminals  armed robbers, rapists, murderers. I thought of myself as an anthropologist with a rare opportunity to, you might say, study the natives.

title: The Man Who Saw America
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Today in Politics: A Backlash Costs Donald Trump, and Possibly Republicans
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington. As we head into the holiday, the campaign trail is crowded in Iowa, and Hillary Rodham Clinton released a large fund-raising figure as her emails while secretary of state continue to be parsed. And with news of another business partner deserting Donald J. Trump, he has put Republicans in a delicate spot, even as he finds some success in the polls.

title: Understanding the Incomprehensible With Music
description: I arrived home from the Shepherd Center in Atlanta  a catastrophic care hospital  debilitated by grief. I had many questions stemming from our familys new reality, but only one that I would work to answer: What should I include on a soundtrack for recovery for my formerly active and able-bodied 23-year-old nephew who had just become a quadriplegic? I sifted through my iTunes and the pile of neglected CDs shoved to the back of my closet with a clarity of purpose and swollen eyes. There wasnt much else I could do.

title: Looking White In the Face
description: This is the 13th in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with John D. Caputo, who is the Thomas J. Watson professor of religion emeritus at Syracuse University and David R. Cook professor of philosophy emeritus at Villanova University. He is the author of numerous books, including The Insistence of God: A Theology of Perhaps and Truth. His next book, Hoping Against Hope, will appear this fall.  George Yancy

title: Ferry Capsizes in Philippines
description: A vessel carrying 173 people sank off the Philippine coast on Thursday, leaving dozens dead and others missing, Coast Guard officials said.

title: The Relentless Pursuit of Happiness
Morning Agenda: Mixed Messages and Paralysis in Greek Crisis
description: MIXED MESSAGES AND PARALYSIS IN GREEK CRISIS | In a day of twists and turns, Greeks could be forgiven for wondering who was in charge,  Andrew Higgins writes in The New York Times. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece said he would be willing to accept many of the bailout terms set by Greeces creditors, only to go on television in the afternoon to urge Greeks to vote no on Sundays referendum on the bailout,  Suzanne Daley and Kiki Kitsantonis write in The New York Times. Then theres the question of what Greeks would be voting on: The referendum pertains to the terms offered by creditors last week, an offer that in effect expired with the existing bailout package on Tuesday night. On Thursday, Yanis Varoufakis, Greeces finance minister,  told Bloomberg Television that he would resign if Greek voters accepted the bailout.

title: I.M.F. Agrees With Athens That Greece Needs Debt Relief
description: ATHENS  The International Monetary Fund, a big Greek creditor, conceded a point on Thursday that the Athens government has long been making: Without some reduction in the countrys staggering debt load, Greece has little hope of a sustained economic recovery.

title: France Arrests 2 Soldiers Accused of Sexual Abuse in Burkina Faso
description: LONDON  Two French soldiers accused of sexually abusing two young girls in Burkina Faso have been repatriated to France and arrested, French prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: The Declaration | Ashley Smith
description: To celebrate July 4th, the model recites sections of this most cherished symbol of liberty in a character driven screen test.

title: German Luxury Car Brands Dominate and Look to Extend Their Lead
description: LIKE an arrogant sports dynasty, Germanys luxury car brands have long dominated the competition  and when rivals get too close, the champs load up and zoom ahead again.

title: Anthony Doerr: By the Book
description: The author of All the Light We Cannot See read The Sheltering Sky when he was 11 or 12. I was incredibly blessed, because neither my mother nor the local librarians ever said: This is outside your age range, Tony. You cant handle this.

title: Heading Off the Grid, and Escaping Guacamole Protests
description: Much as I hate to leave the reader email influx, Im taking a few days to go analog. (Although I doubt that I will be able or willing to do so entirely.)

title: Ashley Smith Declares Independence
description: As a model and muse for Sports Illustrated and Agent Provocateur, among others, Ashley Smith is no stranger to self-transformation. For a new short film project directed by the photographer Marissa Kaiser, with creative direction by the hair colorist Aura Friedman, Smith plays five distinct characters, intercut reading the same monologue  its a meditation on identity and style that is also, thanks to her natural charisma, quite funny. The full video will premiere on Nowness tomorrow; in the meantime, heres a patriotic teaser that finds Smiths five very different women brought together by Americas founding document. Happy Fourth!

title: A Movie Scene About Abortion, With a Message for Mother and Daughter
description: My daughter and I are snuggled up in the big bed watching a movie. Perched side-by-side, my laptop propped against our knees, we are as cozy as we once were a dozen years ago in this very same bed, when we would take naps together. After a romp at the playground, wed come home to a little mac and cheese, an episode of The Wiggles, and then wed settle down for a snooze. Shed stick her chilly bare feet between my knees (cozy toes, we called this maneuver) and her eyelids would flutter a little as her breathing grew deep, nearly as close to me as a baby in the womb.

title: Univision Intends to Pursue I.P.O. in U.S.
description: After nearly a decade of private ownership, Univision  which modestly considers itself the gateway to Hispanic America  is preparing to rejoin the public stock markets.

title: 8 Are Arrested in Connection With Tunisia Attack
description: TUNIS  The Tunisian authorities said on Thursday that eight people had been arrested in connection with the massacre of 38 foreign tourists at the beachside resort of Sousse last Friday.

title: The Glass God
description: Dear Diary:

title: Tom, Jerry and Valerie and Her Week of Wonders: Cat, Mouse and Head Trip
description: A visual rondo of free-floating symbols, shape-shifting vampires and erotic high jinks, set in the fertile imagination of a newly nubile teenager, Jaromil Jiress phantasmagoric Valerie and Her Week of Wonders (1970) may be the most exotic flower to bloom on the grave of the Prague Spring, but its one with deep roots in 20th-century Czech culture.

title: Daily Report: As More Tech Start-Ups Stay Private, So Does the Money
description: Not long ago, if you were a young, brash technologist with a world-conquering start-up idea, there was a good chance you spent much of your waking life working toward a single business milestone: taking your company public, Farhad Manjoo writes.

title: Centene to Acquire Its Managed Care Rival Health Net for $6.8 Billion
description: The Centene Corporation, a managed health care company, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire its rival Health Net in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $6.8 billion, including the assumption of debt.

title: Afghanistan Said to Overturn Death Sentences in Womans Lynching
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Afghan court has overturned the death sentences of four men convicted in the lynching of a woman who had been falsely accused of burning the Quran, a lawyer connected to the case and a politician said on Thursday.

title: Police Find No Signs of Shooting After Washington Navy Yard Lockdown
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators scouring the Washington Navy Yard on Thursday found no evidence that a shooting had occurred at the facility, federal and city officials said, after a report of gunshots prompted a lockdown.

title: Englands Own Goal at Womens World Cup Brings Sympathy, Not Scorn
description: It was a soccer players worst nightmare. With seconds left in a World Cup semifinal on Wednesday, Laura Bassett of England lunged for the ball and accidentally kicked it into her own net.

title: BP to Pay $18.7 Billion for Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill
description: NEW ORLEANS  An $18.7 billion settlement announced Thursday of all federal, state and local claims against the oil giant BP arising from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill would be the largest environmental settlement  and the largest civil settlement with any single entity  in the nations history, officials said Thursday.

title: The Truth and Other Lies, by Sascha Arango
description: You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style, says Humbert Humbert in Lolita. Humbert is a pedophile and a murderer. Henry Hayden (another H.H.), the protagonist of The Truth and Other Lies, by Sascha Arango, is merely a murderer, though, like Humbert, a man of discernment. Hes a world-famous, best-selling novelist, with millions of copies sold around the world, a winner of awards and a recipient of honorary degrees. He drives a Maserati, wears expensive suits and lives in splendor in a coastal town in, apparently, Germany.

title: Book of Numbers, by Joshua Cohen
description: For last years words belong to last years language, T.S. Eliot wrote, and next years words await another voice. It would be hard to find a more apt description of Joshua Cohen and his brilliantly exhausting fourth novel, Book of Numbers. On its surface, the book is about a struggling New York novelist hired as an Internet billionaires ghostwriter  but its breadth, the ambition of its ideas and devices, confounds standard book review responses. Trying to approach this demanding, overstuffed novel is a bit like hyperlinking ones way around the Internet: Its bigger, wilder and fuller than you imagined, and theres always more where that came from.

title: Joan of Arc: A History, by Helen Castor
description: Fame is like a parasite. It feeds off its host  infecting, extracting, consuming its victim until theres nothing left but an empty husk. For the lucky (or unlucky, depending on your point of view), with the emptiness comes the possibility of a long afterlife as one of the blowup dolls of history.

title: The New Jobs Numbers Are Weaker Than They Look
description: There is nothing in the June jobs numbers, released Thursday morning, that signals economic catastrophe. But the closer you look, the more reason there is to feel just a little glum.

title: Search for Prison Escapees in Northern New York Became Boon for Regions Economy
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y.  On the main street of this small town, business has always been brisk at Stewarts, the convenience store and gas station near the high-walled state prison. After all, it is among the few places where residents can fill up their tanks, pick up something to eat or slip into a booth to sip coffee and catch up on gossip without having to drive miles away.

title: A Beautiful Game Far Afield
description: To participate in the Nunavut soccer tournament, players traveled at great expense to Iqaluit, where they slept on classroom floors and played by futsal rules in a hockey rink outfitted with turf.

title: Thriving in a Barren Land
description: IQALUIT, Nunavut  The boys soccer team from Clyde River arrived hours before the most important tournament of the year in the Canadian Arctic. At the airport, the players climbed into taxis and pickup trucks, their luggage piled like rocks on the surrounding tundra.

title: Search Results
description: Douglas Coupland, the novelist credited with naming Generation X, recently took part in a very millennial experience, as an artist in residence at the Google Cultural Institute in Paris.

title: Valley Fever, by Katherine Taylor
description: Romantic breakups are never fun, but the Devil is in the details. It is better, for example, not to be caught completely off guard. Ideally, one should also not hear the phrase I think I only love you when Im drunk. No such luck for Ingrid Palamede, the heroine of Katherine Taylors second novel, Valley Fever. After uprooting her life in New York to live with her boyfriend in Los Angeles, she discovers, nearly a year in, that he doesnt love her. Ingrid is becoming a connoisseur of sudden, devastating breakups in exotic locales, but this one leaves her homeless and unmoored. The book begins with her crying in an airport, calling her big sister to pick her up.

title: Life #6, by Diana Wagman
description: If every stage of growth proceeds from a sort of metaphorical death, how many times in life does one person die? We cycle through our grand repertory of possible selves, striving in adolescence and adulthood for reinvention, yet our most enduring feature never recedes: We are always dying.

title: Nathaniel Poppers Digital Gold Looks at Bitcoin
description: If you wanted to create an entirely new world, like that in Star Wars, or in Neal Stephensons Cryptonomicon, you would certainly need an entirely new form of money. As Nathaniel Popper points out in his new book, Digital Gold, which tracks the roller-coaster ride of the digital currency called Bitcoin, its not surprising that part of its appeal to its devotees is that it could enable the creation of that new world, a libertarian utopia. Bitcoins  which are created, or mined, via complex computer algorithms, and are stored in digital wallets  offer privacy: Although every transaction is recorded, the users are identified only by wallet IDs, which are difficult, if not impossible, to track back to their owners. Theoretically, Bitcoins also allow users to avoid any fees or meddling by a middleman like a bank, because buyers and sellers can deal directly with one another. At its grandest, Bitcoin promises freedom from the clunkiness of cash, from the dominance of central banks and from technology that allows us to be tracked, even by our own governments. On a more prosaic level, why shouldnt money be as vulnerable to technological disruption as, say, music?

title: A Lady of Good Family, by Jeanne Mackin
description: Toward the beginning of The Beautiful American, Jeanne Mackins absorbing 2014 novel of American expats in France from the 1920s through World War II, her heroine asks, Do they matter, simple facts? She could be summing up the dilemma of the historical novelist: How closely must fiction inspired by real people and events  as Mackins novels have been  hew to the bones of the historical record? How much can the writer invent without betraying the readers trust? And, conversely, how much must the writer invent in order to transform history, in all its messiness, into fiction with a satisfying narrative arc and fully developed characters?

title: The Body Where I Was Born, by Guadalupe Nettel
description: The girl at the heart of Guadalupe Nettels novel has a peculiar problem. She is a cockroach. At least her mother refers to her this way, as when she castigates her posture: Cucaracha! she yells. Stand up straight! Adding insult to insecthood, a birthmark on the childs right cornea limits her vision. In order to strengthen the extraocular muscles, she must wear a flesh-hued cloth over her good eye. She resists putting it on each morning, but once it is secured, she submits to being a patched child until 5 oclock, when she is allowed to remove it.

title: Joseph Luzzis In a Dark Wood
description: Beatrice Portinari died at age 24 on June 8, 1290, and dozens of other figures in the Commedia were dead by the week in 1300 when Dante, poet and protagonist, crossed over to the other side. The Divine Comedy is a long poem about a lot of dead people, and Dante, no halfway believer in the hereafter, used his gifts  for speech, for the strong image, for extravagant simile  to bring them to life in words.

title: Etgar Kerets The Seven Good Years: A Memoir
description: Etgar Kerets story collections are like good punk rock records: fast, fun and cultishly admired. And yet despite the inclusion of a few foundation-rattling standouts, even the best punk records ultimately leave the listener under the spell of undiminishing sameness. The same goes for Kerets collections. Not that Keret is completely to blame; his genre is the parable, and if it werent for the demands of the market, these stories would be individually packaged rather than bound in books. The best of Kerets stories, Surprise Egg, say, from his 2006 collection The Nimrod Flipout, explode with distortion. In the case of that particular story, theres also an actual explosion  a suicide bomb  and the storys power lies in the immediacy of its ending: a bomb-widowed husband dreams of the foot of his dead wife slowly stroking his face. Keret forgoes easy moralizing and refuses to politicize the personal or to offer an obvious message. When Keret, who is Israeli and writes in Hebrew, first appeared in English, he was hailed as a savior of short stories from the dour realism of Raymond Carver, and a liberator of Israeli fiction from the big-picture density of writers like David Grossman. His stories were unapologetically absurd and libidinous, and if they werent all winners, then at least there was something refreshing in Kerets imaginative conceits.

title: Irrepressible: The Jazz Age Life of Henrietta Bingham, by Emily Bingham
description: Its hard to resist a biography with a preface that features the discovery of attic trunks filled with nearly 200 beribboned love letters, a first edition of Virginia Woolfs The Years and a court ensemble once owned by the 1930s shorts-wearing rebel tennis star Helen Jacobs.

title: Independence Lost, by Kathleen DuVal
description: Paint yourself a mental picture of the American War of Independence. If all you see are British redcoats battling minutemen and Continentals, Kathleen DuVals Independence Lost will knock your socks off.

title: The Sleuth Next Door
description: THE NEW NEIGHBOR (Touchstone, $24.99) opens with an image of such overwhelming loneliness that it lingers all the way to the last page. In simple, elegant language, Leah Stewart draws us to a little pond hidden away in the mountains of Tennessee. On one side of the pond is a modest house with a small deck, and on the other is a similarly modest house, also with a small deck.

title: Bernie Sanders Gaining on Hillary Clinton in Iowa, Poll Shows
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton might want to watch her back in Iowa.

title: Americana
description: EMPIRE OF DECEPTIONThe Incredible Story of a Master Swindler Who Seduced a City and Captivated the NationBy Dean Jobb336 pp. Algonquin, $27.95.

title: The Cast of Amazing Grace Grapples With Slavery
description: One by one, they passed into the stone monument, a dark chamber meant to evoke a ships hold, and turned tear-streaked faces toward the shaft of sunlight.

title: Montauks Least Popular Fish for Dinner
description: The fashion photographer and farmer Greg Kessler teams up with New York chefs to trace the trajectory of seasonal food, from its original source to a place on your table. This edition: chef Joseph Realmuto (Nick & Tonis in East Hampton).

title: Russia to Boycott Meeting of Security Body, Diplomats Say
description: VIENNA  Russia will boycott a meeting of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe because of Ukraine-related sanctions that bar a prominent Russian lawmaker from attending, diplomats said on Thursday.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOW TO TELL TOLEDO FROM THE NIGHT SKY, by Lydia Netzer. (St. Martins Griffin, $15.99.) Parallel universes and cosmic visions co-exist in the story of George and Irene, both astronomers whose mothers, unbeknown to their children, conspired for them to fall in love. The book continues Netzers exploration of science, destiny and love, which began in her first novel, Shine Shine Shine.

title: Denis Leary Finds His Inner Washed-Up Singer in Sex&Drugs&Rock&Roll
description: Denis Leary has always been a music guy.

title: Editors Choice
description: DESTRUCTION WAS MY BEATRICE: Dada and the Unmaking of the Twentieth Century, by Jed Rasula. (Basic Books, $29.99.) A professor uncovers why Dada didnt expire along with all the artistic isms it either spawned or incorporated.

title: An Architects Vision in the Desert
description: Donald Wexler created steel houses in the Desert Modern style that helped make Palm Springs a showcase for midcentury modernism.

title: Inside the List
description: Here Bunny, Bunny: Holly Madison, the former Playboy Playmate and star of the E! reality show The Girls Next Door, about life at the Playboy Mansion, hits the hardcover nonfiction list this week with a tell-all memoir, Down the Rabbit Hole, new at No. 2. The book paints a fairly tawdry picture of Madisons years as Hugh Hefners girlfriend  or, more accurately, as the No.1 girlfriend in a volatile harem rife with infighting, sexual competition and petty jealousies over money and favors. (I told you it was tawdry.) Hef has accused Madison of rewriting history, a claim she shrugged off in a recent interview with The Associated Press: He doesnt have any mental or emotional power over me anymore, she said. Hes somebody that I look back on as somebody who treated me really poorly, who I tried to convince myself was a great person but I dont think is. And I dont want negative, toxic people in my life anymore. All of this is a good excuse, if you needed one, to dig up a copy of Gloria Steinems 1963 expos of the Playboy Club in New York City, where she briefly assumed a false name and went undercover in the standard satin costume, complete with ears and a rabbit tail. A middle-aged man in a private guards uniform grinned and beckoned, Steinem wrote. Here bunny, bunny, bunny, he said, and jerked his thumb toward the glass door on the left. Interviews downstairs in the Playmate Bar. Madison might recognize the world Steinem was writing about, even if it had less silicone than shes used to; evidently, the bunnies of Steinems era padded their bosoms with plastic dry-cleaning bags.

title: Lifetimes UnReal Recycles a Producers Dark Experiences
description: After six seasons of working as a producer on The Bachelor, Sarah Gertrude Shapiro was facing a breakdown. I wasnt thinking suicide, but I was close, she said. I wanted to burn my whole life down. Ms. Shapiro, an avowed feminist, had somehow become an expert at manipulating female contestants behind the scenes to get good television for the reality dating show.

title: A Joint Appearance for a Bush and a Clinton
description: Newsflash: Bush and Clinton will share a stage next week. But not that Bush or that Clinton.

title: Pea GuacamoleDefenders Step Up
description: The Times on Wednesday posted to Twitter a pea-laden guacamole recipe that enraged the Internet, generated countless pea puns and drew the criticism of a sitting president.

title: Scott Walker Moves Toward a Presidential Run
description: At last, Scott Walker is taking concrete steps toward his presidential candidacy.

title: Sonia Manzano, Maria on Sesame Street, to Retire After 44 Years
description: The neighborhood will have one less person when Sesame Street begins its 46th season this fall. Sonia Manzano, who has played Maria on the PBS show for more than four decades, said Monday that she is retiring. Ms. Manzano, 65, made the announcement  during a speech at the annual conference of the American Library Association.

title: Reelz to Show Donald Trumps Miss USA Pageant
description: A new television station has stepped in to broadcast Donald Trumps Miss USA beauty pageant: Reelz.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: The Upshot staff found several interesting items elsewhere on the web this week:

title: 12 Die in Pakistan as Train Carrying Soldiers Falls Into Canal
description: ISLAMABAD  At least 12 people were killed Thursday when four cars of a train carrying soldiers fell into a canal in eastern Pakistan, military and government officials said. Rescue work was underway by the army and others, according to a military spokesman.

title: Tsipras Assures No Defense Cuts Expected
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece said on Thursday there will not be cuts in defense spending despite current financial trouble and urged citizens to maintain a core of national sovereignty.

title: Super PAC Raises $15.6 Million for Hillary Clinton Campaign
description: The super PAC supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton will report that it has raised $15.6 million when it files its disclosure statements, officials with the group said Thursday morning, with donations from big names like George Soros, the liberal philanthropist, and the Hollywood moguls Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something to do this weekend, before or after the fireworks?

title: A Former Wedding Photographer Finds His Focus as a Crooner
description: Music is a very visual thing for me, says the Nigerian-born singer-songwriter Vicktor Taiwo. I dont mean I see green or something when I make music, but when I start making a song, it looks like a real, physical thing to me. That the 24-year-old Londoner views music as a multisensory enterprise is little surprise. As a teenager, Taiwo fell deeply in love with photography after playing with the aperture on his mothers camera. I realized it could be pitch-black, and I could change a knob and it would be bright, he says. It blew my mind. By 15, he was a working photographer, toting his own DSLR to weddings and parties around Britain. He was paid for his work, but the high-pressure gigs overwhelmed him. I hated photography after that, he says.

title: I.M.F. Says Greece Needs Debt Relief, but Blames Government Lapses
description: FRANKFURT  Greece will need more help from eurozone countries to manage its debt because the countrys finances and economic performance have deteriorated since a new government took office, the International Monetary Fund said in a report on Thursday that is likely to further heighten tensions between Athens and its creditors.

title: 1915: Belgian Pacifist Preaches War
description: M. Henri Lafontaine, president of the International Peace and Arbitration Association, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1913 and is a member of the Belgian Senate, has just left France for the United States, where he intends to conduct a campaign against the propaganda of certain American pacifists in favor of stopping the war. In conversation with a correspondent of the Herald, M. Lafontaine said that he proposes to preach throughout the United States that nothing could be more disastrous to the cause of civilization and justice than the conclusion of a premature peace.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 3, 1915

title: Security Law Suggests a Broadening of Chinas Core Interests
description: BEIJING  After China enacted a sweeping national security law this week, one official said the measure was intended to safeguard the countrys core interests. President Xi Jinping has repeatedly used the same term in speeches at international forums, inside and outside China.

title: 1890: Crimean Heroes Celebrated
description: A grand fte for the benefit of the surviving heroes of the Crimea war opened this afternoon at Olympia with a large and varied programme. The veterans, about sixty in number, including thirty- eight survivors of the famous charge of the Light Brigade, mustered at Addison road station, and marched to Olympia, where they were received at the main entrance by a large crowd and greeted with repeated bursts of cheers. Among the items on the programme was the recitation of The Charge of the Light Brigade, by W.H. Pennington, one of the survivors.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 3, 1890

title: U.S.-China Adventure Film Already Creating Buzz
description: Hordes of young female fans gripping camera phones were camped out in the lobby of the Park Hyatt in Beijing on Thursday afternoon, hoping to catch a glimpse of Lu Han, formerly of the South Korean boy band EXO, who was appearing there with a clutch of other stars to discuss their participation in the renowned director Zhang Yimous latest film, a fantasy adventure epic called The Great Wall.

title: Gift Ideas for an Outdoor Summer Feast
description: Wedding gifts that help a couple set a chic table or picnic blanket.

title: The Happiest Hour
description: Cocktails and Cali-style burgers in Greenwich Village.

title: At the Happiest Hour, a Cheeseburger Does a Star Turn
description: When I first heard about the burger at the Happiest Hour, a cocktail bar in Greenwich Village where the dcor is heavy on the palm fronds and the soundtrack is heavy on Tom Petty, it dislodged a memory.

title: Should Swimmers Worry About Sharks?
description: Seven swimmers have been bitten by sharks in North Carolina in less than a month. In the most recent attack, on Wednesday, authorities said the victim was swimming in front of a lifeguard stand when a gray shark, as large as seven feet long, pulled him under the water and bit him on the rib cage, hip, lower leg and both hands.

title: Brookfield Makes Offer for Ports and Rail Business
description: Sydney, AUSTRALIA  Brookfield Infrastructure Partners, the acquisitive Canadian infrastructure investor, said Wednesday that it had made a $6.8 billion takeover offer for Asciano, an owner of ports and rail assets in Australia and New Zealand.

title: Knicks to Sign Arron Afflalo; Greg Monroe Heads to Bucks
description: The Knicks on Thursday agreed to a deal with Arron Afflalo, a 6-foot-5 shooting guard who should help bolster the teams depleted backcourt. The Knicks frontcourt remained a concern, as meetings came and went without commitments from the front offices top targets.

title: A $50 Day in Knoxville, Tennessee
description: Knoxville, Tenn., may or may not be a great place to live, or to spend a month or a week or a couple of days. I have no idea. Should the need arise, however, I can say its the perfect place to spend 18 hours.

title: Train Carrying Toxic Substance Derails in Tennessee
description: About 5,000 people were evacuated from a town in eastern Tennessee after a train car carrying a flammable toxic substance derailed and burst into flames late Wednesday evening.

title: Barnes & Noble Names Ronald Boire of Sears Canada as C.E.O.
description: Barnes & Noble, the countrys largest bookstore chain, announced on Thursday that it had appointed a new chief executive, Ronald D. Boire.

title: A Spiked Punch to Perk Up a Summer Dinner
description: From the Bedrock Fizzs tower of pink foam to the Bastions carved lime wedge, drinks by Kelvin Uffre  the head barman at the Eddy in the East Village  are known for their special flourishes. But his 7th Regiment Punch, made from brandy, wine and raspberries, is particularly opulent: Its served in a scalloped black-and-white teacup reminiscent of Alice in Wonderland and comes over hand-cracked ice. The drink has quite a pedigree: Its mentioned by the legendary bartender Jerry Thomas in his 1862 handbook The Bon Vivants Companion, and was originally created by the sons of the Vanderbilts, Van Rensselaers and Livingstons who made up the ranks of New Yorks Silk Stocking regiment.

title: National Ballet of China Conveys Its History at Lincoln Center Festival
description: Our aim in the cultural sphere is to build a new Chinese national culture, Mao wrote in 1940, more than two decades before the start of the Cultural Revolution. Since then, China has undergone a series of profound cultural shifts, many of which Mao could never have predicted. Change has come to every sphere, including ballet, a relatively recent import that has nonetheless played a role in the countrys re-evaluation of its performance traditions and aesthetic ideals. New Yorkers will have the chance to view part of that trajectory next week when the National Ballet of China comes to the Koch Theater as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. Later the company will travel to Wolf Trap in Vienna, Va., and Saratoga, N.Y.

title: Prince Removes Music From Most Subscription Streaming Services
description: The latest move in the developing chess game of streaming music has been made by the musician Prince.

title: Trumps Golf Course, a Lesson in Inequality
description: If the thought of Donald Trump has been lodged in your head of late, exclusively as a Republican presidential candidate, defamer of immigrants and thrice-wed champion of traditional marriage, then it may have escaped your attention that a lush and extravagant municipal golf course bearing his name  Trump Golf Links at Ferry Point  opened this spring on the southeastern shoreline of the Bronx. Paid for by New York City, to the sum of $127 million, and maintained by the Trump organization, the course offers the kind of visual lessons in inequality that make statistics and editorials and Thomas Piketty seem ponderously inefficient.

title: Andrew Essex Is Leaving Droga5 Ad Agency
description: Andrew Essex, a founding member and vice chairman of Droga5, is leaving the independent advertising agency. Mr. Essex, who has also served as chief executive of the agency, will move into an advisory role.

title: Per Se Violated Labor Law With Service Charge, Inquiry Finds
description: A private event at Per Se, a restaurant with prices to match its opulent confines at the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, near the luxury skyscrapers often called Billionaires Row, is yet another level of exclusivity in a dining experience where Nova Scotia lobster coddled in butter joins a menu where foie gras is followed by caviar and truffles.

title: And Now, What Mexico Thinks of Donald Trump
description: MEXICO CITY  It is the kind of publicity money cannot buy  front-page coverage, segments on the nightly news, the attention of political heavyweights and a stream of commentary  burning a hole in the web.

title: Why BP Is Paying $18.7 Billion
description: Background on the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill and the largest environmental settlement in American history.

title: Morton Salt Owner K&S Rejects Takeover Bid From Potash Corporation
description: The German potash and salt mining company that owns Morton Salt, K&S, said on Thursday that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover bid from a Canadian rival, the Potash Corporation, because the offer of 7.8 billion euros, or about $8.6 billion, undervalued the company.

title: In a Brutal Gun Case, a Win for the Common Good
description: It has been 12 years since Russell Graham, a convicted felon, shot and killed his eight-year-old son, Zeus, and then himself in Cherokee County, Kansas.

title: Review: JakeGyllenhaal Sings in Little Shop of Horrors
description: If you were in the vicinity of Seventh Avenue and West 55th Street at about 7:40 p.m. on Wednesday, you may have been alarmed by the sight of a really big Moorish dome sailing into the air. That would have been the roof of City Center, which was blown right off the building when Ellen Greene made her entrance in the blissed-out, two-nights-only concert production of Little Shop of Horrors.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Poison Fish, Fitness Age and Guinea Pigs
description: Take the Quiz

title: Egypt, Stunned by Sinai Assault, Vows to Erase Terrorist Dens
description: CAIRO  Egypts military killed 23 militants in the northern Sinai Peninsula early Thursday, a senior security official said, as the government sought to reassert control and eradicate what it called the areas terrorist dens after the largest assault there by jihadists affiliated with the Islamic State.

title: Bernie Sanders Raises $15 Million From a Wide Donor Base
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, the liberal Vermont senator who has been rising in recent polls in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, raised $15 million in the last two months, his aides said.

title: Harper Lees Go Set a Watchman May Have Been Found Earlier Than Thought
description: On the eve of the most anticipated publishing event in years  the release of Harper Lees novel Go Set a Watchman  there is yet another strange twist to the tale of how the book made its way to publication, a development that further clouds the story of serendipitous discovery that generated  both excitement and skepticism in February.

title: Exclusive | 440 West 22nd Street
description: A 25-foot-wide, 4-story townhouse on one of Chelseas most historic blocks is about to enter the market.

title: Jeb Bush Tax Returns Recall Old Days of Shelters
description: Jeb Bushs tax returns take us back to the time when it was a point of pride for high-income earners to buy a piece of a Panamanian gold mine, a Hollywood movie, a Texas oil well or a California alpaca farm. The point was not to make money but to use the artificial tax losses from a partnership to shelter ones true salary from tax.

title: President Obama: Talk to Black America, Not at Us
description: Is President Obama the scold of black America or its empathetic prophet?

title: Salons Editorial Staff Plans to Unionize
description: The editorial staff of the online magazine Salon plans to unionize, according to a letter posted on a union website on Thursday, the second major web publication to do so in recent weeks.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Limping Along Solved!
description: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 2-year-old boy who stopped walking just months after he learned how. Maybe this case was too easy because one in four of you got it right  at least by my last count.

title: Orkambi, a New Cystic Fibrosis Drug, Wins F.D.A. Approval
description: A new drug for people with the most common genetic type of cystic fibrosis won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday.

title: Indonesia Plane Crash Caused by Engine Failure, Air Force Chief Says
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An engine malfunction was the reason an Indonesian military aircraft crashed into an urban neighborhood, the chief of the air force said on Thursday, offering the first official explanation of the disaster two days ago.

title: Britain Hints It May Join U.S. Campaign Against ISIS in Syria
description: LONDON  Jolted by the deaths of 30 British tourists in Tunisia at the hands of a gunman professing allegiance to the Islamic State, Prime Minister David Cameron is considering joining the United States in bombing the groups forces in Syria.

title: Clint Dempsey Replaced as U.S. National Team Captain
description: Michael Bradley will be the United States national soccer teams captain during the Concacaf Gold Cup this month, taking over the role from Clint Dempsey in further fallout from Dempseys confrontation with a referee last month.

title: Cava Sparkles on Its Own Merits
description: Briskly uncork a bottle of cava, the sparkling wine of Spain, and you will hear the festive pop so dear to revelers around the globe. Ease it open ever so slowly, and instead youll hear the soft, contented sigh that may signal an evening of sparkling romance.

title: Pakistan Train Plunges Into Canal
description: Rescuers at work in Gujranwala District, Punjab Province, after a section of a railway bridge collapsed. The derailment sent four cars carrying soldiers into the water and left at least 12 people dead. The authorities denied reports that the bridge was dilapidated and said they were looking into the possibility of sabotage.

title: Obama and Scott Walker Set Aside Political Tensions on the Tarmac
description: LA CROSSE, Wis.  Its a conundrum that could stump Miss Manners: The most powerful man on earth flies into the state where you are the governor, but you want to take his job, house and plane and overturn every law he holds dear.

title: When Youre So Skinny! Isnt Quite a Compliment
description: I am a very skinny woman. I have always been thin, but over the last few years, I have lost a great deal of weight because of depression and stress. I am now on the mend and slowly putting weight back on, but I am frightfully self-conscious about my appearance. The problem: When I run into people I know, they say, Youre so skinny! Even people I dont know make remarks like, I hate skinny women. What can I do?

title: Opting Out of Automatic Portraits in Sony Cameras
description: Q. My Sony camera sometimes produces two versions of each photo I take, one the way I originally framed it and one a weird close-up of someone in the shot. It seems to happen randomly. What is this? I end up deleting a lot of pictures I didnt really take and dont want.

title: Into Wimbledons Third Round, James Ward Gains a Victory, and Maybe Some Slack
description: WIMBLEDON, England  When Andy Murray ended the great title drought for British men at Wimbledon in 2013, the pressure on British players supposedly eased. But it never disappeared.

title: The Times Responds to Peacamole Tweets
description: The Timess food editor, Sam Sifton, reads a selection of Twitter responses to a recipe for guacamole with peas, including one from President Obama.

title: Chiefs of T-Mobile and Sprint Spar on Twitter
description: In speeches and on social media, John Legere, the chief executive of T-Mobile, has built a reputation of emphatically, if sometimes profanely, promoting T-Mobiles services, often at the expense of the competition.

title: Minions and Its Influences: A Goggle-Eyed View
description: Pierre Coffin and Kyle Balda put a lot of film history into their conception of the third installment in a successful animated franchise.

title: On Centre Court, Paths Increasingly Diverge for Federer and Nadal
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Long after they finish whipping topspin forehands for an excellent living, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal will share a link to Centre Court.

title: Jim Webb Announces Democratic Bid for Presidency
description: Jim Webb, a former Virginia senator and Reagan-era secretary of the Navy, announced his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination on Thursday, bringing his antiwar credentials to the field in what many consider a long-shot campaign for the presidency.

title: After Settlement, Relief at a Diminished BP
description: LONDON  BPs future no longer has a giant cloud ahead. But it will take years, if not decades, for the company to approach its size of five years ago, before the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig.

title: Your Next Lesson: Santorini Assyrtiko
description: Of all the fascinating regions that have emerged in the global wine economy over the last 20 years, Ive become especially enamored of Santorini, the Greek island in the Cyclades, which produces some of the most distinctive white wines around.

title: Benjamin Lawskys Legacy
description: After four years on the job, Benjamin Lawsky, New Yorks top financial regulator, stepped down in June. His legacyincludes important protections against abusive debt collectors and usurious payday lenders, as well as aggressive enforcement actions against banks and financial firms for money laundering, currency manipulation, interest rate rigging, foreclosure abuses and insurance scams.

title: When Food is the Food of Love
description: Jennifer Beck did not know the man she would eventually fall for, but she knew precisely what sort of engagement ring she wanted, and no other ring would do.

title: Jennifer Beck and Brian Goldblatt: He Can Stand the Heat in the Kitchen
description: Jennifer Beck is someone who enjoys perfect outcomes, and she will do whatever it takes to make them happen. When cooking, she uses an array of implements and a meticulous approach that might put a biochemist to shame.

title: Reaction to Smells May Help Diagnose Autism, Study Suggests
description: It may be possible to diagnose autism by giving children a sniff test, a new study suggests.

title: Bangladesh Police Arrest 12 Men Suspected of Qaeda Ties
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Twelve men suspected of membership in Al Qaedas branch in the Indian subcontinent have been arrested in three separate raids in the capital, Dhaka, an elite police unit said on Thursday.

title: As Bar Codes Replace Tickets, Something Is Lost Before the First Pitch
description: After San Francisco Giants pitcher Chris Heston threw a no-hitter at Citi Field in June, his family members and his girlfriend gave him their tickets from the game as keepsakes.

title: D.C. Mayor on Navy Yard Shooting Reports
description: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington said on Tuesday that there was no evidence of any gunman at the United States Navy Yard.

title: Asexual and Happy
description: They were words I didnt expect to hear from my therapist: I dont believe a person could possibly be asexual.

title: BBC to Cut 1,000 Jobs as License Revenue Falls Short
description: LONDON  The BBC said Thursday that it was cutting 1,000 jobs to help plug a budget gap of 150 million pounds caused by a larger decline than expected in the number of households owning televisions, as viewers increasingly choose to watch content free online.

title: The Polaroid Swinger: Changing the Market in an Instant
description: Fifty years ago this month, Polaroid introduced the first low-priced, mass-market instant camera, the Swinger. Its almost alive! went the catchy jingle in the TV spot starring the then-unknown Ali MacGraw. Its only nineteen dollars and ninety-five.

title: Jim Webb Candidacy Assures Another Antiwar Voice Against Hillary Clinton
description: The entry of former Senator Jim Webb of Virginia into the field of Democrats running for president makes it certain that Hillary Rodham Clinton will have to defend her support for the Iraq war, just as she did when she ran for president eight years ago.

title: Make-Ahead Fried Chicken
description: Melissa Clark makes crispy fried chicken that is best eaten cold.

title: Fried Chicken Stars in This Make-Ahead Meal
description: Every cook knows the formula for a winter make-ahead dinner party: stew some short ribs, braise a chicken or layer together a lasagna a few days before, reheat to serve. The flavors are better for having had a chance to meld, and the cook feels better for having a chance to clean the kitchen and take a shower before the doorbell rings.

title: Bill Cunningham | Casual Cool
description: The Fourth of July brings out signatures of American fashion: simplicity, comfort and function.

title: Bill Cunningham | Casual Cool
description: The Fourth of July brings out signatures of American fashion: simplicity, comfort and function. The shirtdress has many variations, from T-shirts to, new this year, sleeping shirts that recall the late 19th century. Shown as nonfitted nightshirts in Paris, these are belted by American women.

title: 1970s | Reining In a Racial Slur in The Times
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: On the Organ Trail in Manhattan
description: The trickiest part is turning it on, Paul Jacobs said one night recently as he took his seat at the console of the organ at St. Patricks Cathedral for the first time. Ah, the plight of the itinerant organist. Where, amid the myriad buttons and knobs and levers and (literal) bells and whistles, was the on-off switch?

title: Jacob deGrom Pitches In, but Mets Offense Remains in Slump
description: During another listless loss on Thursday, Mets Manager Terry Collins posed a question to Michael Cuddyer, a veteran outfielder sitting out with a knee injury.

title: Train Derails in Tennessee
description: A CSX train car carrying a flammable toxic substance derailed near Maryville in eastern Tennessee and burst into flames Wednesday, forcing the evacuation of about 5,000 people.

title: Review: Roger Brown, Political Paintings and Virtual Still Life
description: Roger Brown (1941-1997) was one of the best of the Chicago Imagists who emerged in the 1960s. In a cartoon style reminiscent of the comics and graphic design of the 1930s and 40s, he painted city and rural scenes populated by tiny, silhouetted figures of people, under glowing skies filled with puffy clouds in gridded patterns.

title: Comic-Con International to Stay in San Diego Through 2018
description: The Comic-Con International fan convention will remain in San Diego through at least 2018 under a deal reached with the events operators, the citys mayor announced on Thursday.

title: Searching for Children Rescued by Nicholas Winton
description: Do you know someone who was saved by Nicholas Winton? The New York Times would like to hear from you.

title: Rene James, President of Intel, Is Leaving the Company
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The president of Intel is moving on, and the chief executive appears to be using the occasion for a sweeping reorganization of his company, the worlds largest maker of semiconductors.

title: Anonymous Donors Give Over $3 Million for Charleston Scholarship Fund
description: Anonymous donors have given more than $3 million to establish a scholarship fund for people affiliated with the church in Charleston, S.C., where nine people were killed last month, city officials said on Thursday.

title: Obama Announces Job-Growth Record
description: President Obama on Thursday said that the United States has entered its 64th consecutive month of private sector job growth, a new record.

title: Evening Hours | Sargent and Sunshine
description: An exhibition preview, the Gay Pride Parade and more.

title: Mennonites and Episcopalians Say No, for Now, to Israel Divestment
description: Two American Christian church denominations dealt a setback Thursday to a pro-Palestinian economic campaign against Israel, with one defeating a resolution calling for divestment and boycott and the other delaying a vote for two years.

title: Supreme Court Ruling on Health Care Bolsters Deal-Making
description: Health care deal-making is ramping up after a booster shot from the Affordable Care Act. The Supreme Courts decision last week to uphold President Obamas landmark reform signaled the official start of a race to consolidate. Centenes $6.3 billion purchase of Health Net gives the insurers an early lead, but bigger rivals like Cigna and Anthem may soon catch up.

title: Finding the Right Types in August Sanders Germany
description: As a recent acquisition by the Museum of Modern Art shows, August Sanders desire to produce a complete survey of German society led to a lifelong, and unfinished, endeavor.

title: Germany, Again, Calls on U.S. to Answer Spying Accusations
description: BERLIN  This time, the Germans were more polite about wanting a word with the United States ambassador over accusations of American spying on top members of the government here.

title: What I Love | Ron Wendt
description: The party designers weekend house in Bridgehampton, N.Y., includes a lavish garden.

title: Santander Consumer USA C.E.O. Thomas Dundon Steps Down
description: The chief executive and chairman of Santander Consumer USA, one of the nations largest subprime auto lenders, resigned on Thursday amid regulatory issues and a broad overhaul by the companys Spanish parent of its United States operations.

title: Summer Love
description: Some of the stories will have happy endings. Others will merely end. Love, after all, is complicated, in any season. Articles in this series explore summer love stories in New York City.

title: Obama, in Wisconsin, Takes On Scott Walker
description: LA CROSSE, Wis.  President Obama came to this city on the Mississippi on Thursday and launched a frontal assault on Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who filed papers earlier in the day that moved him closer to joining a crowded Republican presidential field.

title: The Dominican Time Bomb
description: In early 2006, my first long-term overseas posting as a journalist took me to the Dominican Republic. From my new home in Santo Domingo, I planned to write about tourism, baseball, corruption and drug trafficking, while working on my Spanish. If things went well, I figured, I might even get to cross the island of Hispaniolas international border, into Haiti, whose chronic crises  including a recent coup dtat that had overthrown the president  drew more international interest.

title: White House Orders Review of Rules for Genetically Modified Crops
description: The Obama administration said on Thursday that it would update the way the government regulated genetically modified crops and some other biotechnology products, saying that the nearly 30-year-old system had become outdated and confusing and did not foster public confidence.

title: Review: Ruth Root, Minimal and Opulent, at Andrew Kreps Gallery
description: In a gesture of extraordinary generosity and transparency, the artist Ruth Root once made a news release with dozens of thumbnail images of phenomena that had inspired her work: everything from paintings by Peter Feeley, Mary Heilmann, Ellsworth Kelly and Josef Albers to shaped bathmats, ghosts and multicolored ski socks. From the looks of her current show, Ms. Root has stayed close to these origins  yet also strayed very far away.

title: Review: Susan Cianciolo Lets Others Pick Through Fragments of Her Life
description: The kind of visual and tactile magic that makes you remember why you loved art in the first place  way back, as a kid  is hard to find. But its there in Susan Cianciolos enchanting solo exhibition, her first New York gallery show in over a decade.

title: Review: Zoe Leonards Analogue Shows the Human Toll of Globalization
description: Zoe Leonards Analogue, a vast suite of photographs installed across three walls of the Museum of Modern Arts atrium, is an affectingly plangent update of Social Realist photography. Produced between 1998 and 2009, its 412 images  342 color, 70 black and white  show examples of low-end commerce from New York to Africa, indirectly but evocatively representing the human toll of corporate globalization.

title: Forget Fireworks: A Couch Potatos TV Lineup
description: Forget fireworks; the real purpose of holiday-week down time is to catch up on overlooked small-screen offerings. Yet that means different things to different people.

title: An Artist on the Margins Is Rescued From Obscurity
description: A career sidelined by greed inspired the HBO documentary Packed in a Trunk: The Lost Art of Edith Lake Wilkinson, which will be shown on July 20. The film resulted from decades of legwork by the writer and director Jane Anderson, Wilkinsons great-niece. Her family inherited about 120 artworks and related documents from Wilkinson, a West Virginia native who had trained at the Art Students League of New York in the 1880s and befriended modernist painters, including Blanche Lazzell.

title: An Immigrants Story, Discovered in Discarded Papers
description: A stack of notebooks and letters were recently salvaged from a Los Angeles trash heap by a man who stumbled upon them. He was immediately drawn to the intricate electrical drawings among the materials, and said he wondered if the owner was a famous inventor.

title: Jim Webb: Warrior, Novelist, Senator
description: Former Senator Jim Webb of Virginia kept a relatively low profile before announcing his presidential candidacy, and while his poll numbers barely register in many surveys, he brings a diverse background that could appeal to Democratic voters looking for a candidate who is more than a career politician.

title: Review: Elmer Bischoff, Figurative Paintings
description: During Abstract Expressionisms heyday in the 1950s, three artists in San Francisco turned away from abstraction and back to representational painting, founding a movement that came to be known as Bay Area Figuration. They were David Park, Richard Diebenkorn and the subject of this stirring exhibition at the George Adams Gallery, Elmer Bischoff (1916-1991).

title: Paneras Mission to Be Anything but Artificial
description: Dan Kish grew up visiting his grandparents farm in northwest Pennsylvania. During long summer days, he would can vegetables and shuck thousands of ears of corn. His grandfather would squirt cows milk straight from the udder into his mouth. His grandmother taught him how to cook on a white enamel Westinghouse gas stove.

title: Review: A History of the Silhouette, From Corsets to Spanx
description: Our bodies are not always ourselves. Like identity, the human form can be a cultural construct. For centuries  especially among elites  it has been shaped, modified and augmented according to the styles and mores of the day.

title: Potential Holiday Threats Assessed With Focus on Lone Wolf Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  Since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, American counterterrorism officials have increased security at national landmarks and large public events ahead of major holidays or significant anniversaries, and issued bulletins calling for increased vigilance by the public.

title: Closets Carrie Would Love
description: Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Brodericks 25-foot-wide townhouse at 20 East 10th Street was the sale of the week.

title: Donald Trumps Lousy Week (Except for the Polling)
description: Donald Trump has had a bad week.

title: 2 Nuns, a Developer andKaty Perry Walk Into a Real Estate Deal
description: LOS ANGELES  God moves in mysterious ways  particularly when it comes to Los Angeles real estate.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Dollar Tree and Family Dollar Will Sell 330 Stores to Seal Merger Deal
description: Dollar Tree and Family Dollar have agreed to sell 330 Family Dollar stores to settle a complaint that their proposed merger would probably be anticompetitive, the Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday.

title: Merci, Lafayette
description: This is how George Washington got some really good news 235 years ago.

title: Review: Sargents Intimate Portraits of Friends at the Metropolitan Museum
description: Despite a career as a society portraitist, John Singer Sargent was, by many accounts, a shy man, given to halting speech or silence except among people he knew well and liked. He was not ever, though, a shy painter. Few artists in any era have had as extroverted a hand as his, and as keen an instinct for visual theater. And when his sitters were people he cared for, something extra came into the work, a relaxed recklessness of a kind that scintillates and sluices through the 90 paintings and drawings in Sargent: Portraits of Artists and Friends at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Highlights From 'Sargent: Portraits of Artists and Friends' at the Met
description: John Singer Sargent is best known for his portraits of society figures, but he also painted a number of lesser-known people, including friends and fellow artists.

title: Capri Social Club in Brooklyn Is a Bar So Ordinary, Its a Star
description: The regulars do not gravitate there for its glamorous decorations or its trendy ambience. There are basic tables and chairs and a bar so old that drinkers can feel the contours in the wood from cigarette burns decades old.

title: Review: In Cartel Land Documentary, Vigilantes Wage Drug Wars
description: The director Matthew Heineman has a terrific eye. And, to judge from Cartel Land, his immersive documentary about American and Mexican vigilante groups, he also has guts and nerves of steel. Serving as the primary cinematographer, he employs a run-and-gun style for much of the movie, using a lightweight digital camera that at times lurches so dramatically that you can visualize the body attached to it. Considering that Mr. Heineman landed in a few shootouts while making this documentary, both his camera moves and its pictorial quality are striking.

title: Ernest Hemingway: Between Two Wars Arriving at Morgan Library
description: Ernest Hemingway was a maker of lists and a collector of his lifes ephemera. For the first time, some of the objects that this American writer gathered during his long career  bullfighting stubs from Pamplona in Spain, boastful fishing logs from expeditions off the Cuban coast, coy letters to a mistress, penciled drafts of stories  will be on display in an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum from Sept. 25 through Jan. 31.

title: Drought Pushes Nevada Ranchers to Take On Washington
description: BATTLE MOUNTAIN, Nev.  Around here they call it going Bundy: allowing cattle to graze illegally on federally owned land. For months, ranching families in this tiny community have itched to do it  both because of the relentless drought, which has left their own land dry and their animals hungry, and because of the anti-Washington streak that runs deep in this part of the rural West, where people fervently believe that the government owns too much land.

title: This Weeks Movies | July 3, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Magic Mike XXL, Terminator: Genisys and Cartel Land.

title: Theater Listings for July 3-9
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for July 3-9
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Stray Dog Documents a Complex Veteran
description: A young boy at a picnic asks Ron Hall about the medals and badges that decorate his leather motorcycle vest. Its a way of telling people who you are, Mr. Hall explains. Stray Dog, Debra Graniks new documentary, is all about who this man is. Mr. Hall, whose nickname gives the film its title, is a Vietnam veteran, a biker, the manager of a trailer park in southern Missouri, the patriarch of a multicultural family and much more. Hes a complicated American, and Ms. Granik honors that complexity.

title: Jazz Listings for July 3-9
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for July 3-9
description: Classical

title: Comedy Listings for July 3-9
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for July 3-9
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Review: In Jackie & Ryan, a Handsome Drifter Guides the Way
description: Ogden, a small city in northern Utah at the western edge of the Rocky Mountains, is the bleak, snowy setting of Ami Canaan Manns third feature, Jackie & Ryan.
