Ogden is the hometown of Jackie Laurel (Katherine Heigl), a struggling country-folk singer who finds herself at a personal crossroads. Years ago, she fled Ogden, determined never to return. In her one shot at a big-time music career, she made enough money to buy a condominium in New York City, but it is her only asset.

title: Employers Have Greater Leeway on Unpaid Internships, Court Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Employers have considerable leeway to use unpaid interns legally when the work serves an educational purpose, a federal appeals court ruled on Thursday, setting aside a lower court decision that the movie studio Fox Searchlight Pictures had improperly classified former workers as unpaid interns rather than employees.

title: Dance Listings for July 3-9
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jim Webb on the Issues
description: Jim Webb, a Virginia Democrat who was elected to the Senate in 2006 and served a single term, announced on Thursday that he is running for president. Mr. Webb, a Vietnam veteran and former Navy secretary under President Ronald Reagan, has policy positions do not fall neatly along party lines. Here is where he stands on the issues.

title: Of Drought and Man in the West
description: With the continuing drought in the West, an investigation by ProPublica and Matter looks at mans role in exacerbating the crisis.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 3-9
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Burundi, Pakistan, the Philippines and Greece.

title: July 2, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Burundi, Pakistan, Philippines and Greece.

title: Review: Jimmys Hall Pits the Church Against a Populist Gathering Place
description: One of the pleasures of Jimmys Hall, a likable period piece directed by the social-realist British filmmaker Ken Loach, is its unswerving belief in old-fashioned populist heroes. Such a hero is Jimmy Gralton (Barry Ward), a real-life Irish firebrand portrayed as an articulate, courageous natural leader without a shred of grandiosity. Jimmy is a man of the people whose defiance of the powers that be eventually lands him in deep trouble.

title: Spare Times for July 3-9
description: Macys Fourth of July Fireworks (Saturday) This corporate-sponsored display of patriotism sparkles above the East River for a second year since its return from the Hudson. It begins around 9:20 p.m., with fireworks barges set up at the Brooklyn Bridge and between 23rd and 34th Streets in Manhattan.

title: Spare Times for Children for July 3-9
description: Bug Week

title: Review: Closer to God Offers a Modern-Day Frankenstein Tale
description: Billy Seneses suspense movie Closer to God would like you to know the weightiness of its Frankenstein-like themes of scientific irresponsibility. So it hammers them home again and again: in staged TV news reports, in scenes of public protest, in conversations between its main character, Dr. Victor Reed (Jeremy Childs), and his wife, Claire (Shannon Hoppe). Victor has produced what he says is the first human clone, an infant named Elizabeth, and taken her home for observation. But Elizabeth isnt as problematic as Ethan, a previous child experiment raised secretly in a separate house on Victors estate. Ethan tends to be manic and homicidal.

title: Liberia Reports New Cases of Ebola
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Three new cases of Ebola have emerged in Liberia since the country was declared free of the virus on May 9, highlighting the continuing threat of viral outbreaks in West Africa. The Liberian government said it was tracing scores of people who had recent contact with the three patients.

title: Prison Escapee Was Killed After He Aimed Gun at Agent, Officials Say
description: Cornered in the woods three weeks after his extraordinary escape from prison, Richard W. Matt aimed his 20-gauge shotgun at an armed federal agent late last week but was shot and killed before he could pull the trigger, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Review: In Zarafa, a Giraffe Journeys in a Hot-Air Balloon
description: Pro-giraffe and antislavery, the animated feature Zarafa follows an African boy, Maki, on his trek across deserts, oceans and the city of Paris to save a friend. Set in the early 1820s, when the pasha of Egypt famously gave a giraffe to King Charles X of France, this hand-drawn French adventure is a childrens story in the routine template of many friends-and-villains quests, but with a fresh historical setting and a serenely subdued look.

title: Bidens to Lead U.S. World Cup Delegation
description: The United States womens soccer team will have some high-profile fans in the stands on Sunday as it faces Japan in the World Cup final.

title: A Mission to Catalog Hidden Life in Central Park
description: Daniel Atha put on his waders and ventured slowly into the Pool, near West 103rd Street, one of several bodies of water in Central Park. He was after a broad-leaved yellow pond lily and an iris of indeterminate species.

title: Review: Stung Stars Giant Wasps That Attack the Rich
description: For sheer gustatory delight, you cant beat outdoor summer dining: barbecue, lemonade, cold beer on a humid evening. But watch out for wasps, especially any that have been feeding on growth-hormone-infused plant fertilizer. Even industrial DEET is no match for the seven-foot-tall winged predators that make the lives of the caterers Julia (Jessica Cook) and Paul (Matt OLeary) so stressful in Benni Diezs comic gorefest, Stung.

title: Danny Elfman Brings Music From Tim Burtons Films to Lincoln Center
description: IM a mole, Danny Elfman said, putting on a pair of shaded glasses as he sat in a bright restaurant at Lincoln Center recently. Mr. Elfman, the versatile composer who has scored nearly 100 movies, ranging from Good Will Hunting to Avengers: Age of Ultron, as well as writing the enduring theme to The Simpsons, was talking about his proclivity for the nighttime. I lived at the beach for five years, and they called me Nosferatu on the Beach, he said. As soon as the sun got big and red and was going down, I would come out. He works nocturnally, too, moving among three studios he owns around Los Angeles, soundtracking into the wee hours.

title: Val Doonican, Top-Selling Irish Singer and TV Host, Dies at 88
description: Val Doonican, an Irish crooner whose gentle, humorous way with a song and a story on television made him so popular in Britain in the 1960s and 70s that he once dislodged the Beatles from the top of the album charts there, died on Wednesday in Buckinghamshire, England. He was 88.

title: Review: Cartel Land
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Cartel Land.

title: Review: Terminator Genisys
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Terminator: Genisys.

title: Review: Magic Mike XXL
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Magic Mike XXL.

title: Sprawling Estate With an Unknown Future
description: An eight-acre complex is at the center of a disagreement between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles and a group of nuns over who should be able to buy the estate.

title: Led by Pirates, Iceland Legalizes Blasphemy
description: Less than a week after Icelands prime minister contended that his nations fundamental values would be at risk should the insurgent Pirate Party ever come to power, the group celebrated its first legislative success on Thursday, the decriminalization of blasphemy.

title: Review: Shania Twain in Concert Recalls Glory Days
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Everything shone brightly when Shania Twain performed at Nassau Coliseum here on Wednesday night. After a long residency in Las Vegas, she is back on the road for her first tour in over a decade  one that she has said will be her last. She brought Las Vegas with her. She had blond hair, sequined minidresses, thigh-high boots, banks of lasers, tall video screens and bursts of fireworks. For Up!, the title song of her blockbuster 2002 album, she was literally back in the saddle, one that was mounted on a cherry picker to lift her up and closer to the audience.

title: For Two Final Weeks, Playing in, and Cheering On, the Band
description: In the last two weeks, the Grateful Dead played five final Fare Thee Well shows in Santa Clara, Calif., and Chicago to celebrate the bands 50th anniversary.

title: As Grateful Dead Exit, a Debate Will Not Fade Away
description: ALAN MANDE calls his first experience with the Grateful Dead, in 1969, a portal to a spiritual awakening. Since then, hes attended more than 400 shows and traded bootlegs with untold Deadheads, all while philosophizing on the nature of such devoted fandom.

title: The Hunger Games: The Exhibition Allows Kids to Express Their Inner Katniss
description: REBELLION? Awesome. Romance? Not so much.

title: Review: Multitudinous Heart, Newly Translated Poetry by Carlos Drummond de Andrade
description: Carlos Drummond de Andrade (1902-1987) is widely considered the greatest poet in the history of Brazil, a country where poets are taken seriously. One of his poems, Cano Amiga (Friendly Song), was once printed on the 50 cruzados bill.

title: Ada/Ava and Preludes Are Shows to See in a Relatively Empty City
description: Stuck in the city this holiday weekend? As your neighbors load their cars, stuff themselves onto trains and push their way to the bridges and tunnels, the Miser suggests you wave goodbye with a smile  your piece of the Big Apple just got that much bigger.

title: Sheldon Richardson of Jets Is Among Four Suspended for Drugs
description: Sheldon Richardson, a stalwart of the Jets defensive line, will miss the first four games of the season for violating the N.F.L.s substance-abuse policy and program.

title: Remembering the Phonograph
description: 127 YEARS AGO

title: A Ford Recall for Engines That Might Not Turn Off
description: Ford is recalling about 433,000 of its newest cars and sport utilities  including almost 375,000 in the United States  because drivers may not be able to shut off the engine, even after pressing the stop engine button, the automaker said on Thursday. The problem with the 2015 Focus, C-MAX and Escape models is a computer malfunction. When I tried to shut the engine, it didnt, the owner of a 2015 Escape wrote to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in May. The motor was still running when it was being towed. Ford said it was not aware of any accidents or injuries.

title: Boko Haram Militants Suspected in Attacks at Mosques in Nigeria
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Gunmen thought to be members of the Islamist sect Boko Haram rounded up scores of men in mosques in northeast Nigeria on Wednesday evening and began shooting indiscriminately, witnesses said.

title: Nascar Asks Fans to Put Away Confederate Flags
description: Confederate battle flags have been common at Nascar racetracks for decades, with fans often flying them above their motor homes along with American flags and banners of their favorite drivers. Nascar, with its predominantly white Southern fan base, has always tolerated the presence of the flag at its races even after banning it from official use.

title: Opening-Round 66 Leaves Tiger Woods Buoyed
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va.  The only other time Tiger Woods appeared in the Greenbrier Classic, he was coming off his third victory of the 2012 season and had not posted a score higher than 75 all year. He carded a 71 and a 69 on the par-70 Old White TPC course and did not make the cut.

title: Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas May Face Securities-Fraud Indictment
description: HOUSTON  Evidence that Ken Paxton, the attorney general of Texas, committed securities fraud before he became the states top lawyer will soon be presented to a grand jury, a special prosecutor said this week.

title: Miss USA Pageant Finds a Televised Venue
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  The symbolism wasnt lost on the organizers and contestants of the 2015 Miss USA pageant Wednesday evening as thunderstorms drenched the public sports park where their first official media event was scheduled to take place.

title: Bratton Tells Police Academy Graduates They Face a Time of Change
description: It was nine days after two police officers were killed in December when a class of recruits last graduated from the New York Police Academy.

title: Cardinals Fire Rising Front-Office Star Amid Hacking Investigation
description: As the F.B.I. continues its investigation into a breach of the Houston Astros database, the St. Louis Cardinals have fired their scouting director, Chris Correa, who once worked under Jeff Luhnow before Luhnow left the Cardinals to be Houstons general manager.

title: Fiat Chrysler Accused of Neglect in 23 Recalls
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators on Thursday accused Fiat Chrysler Automobiles of putting lives at risk by repeatedly failing to perform timely vehicle recalls and inform consumers of dangerous defects.

title: Aetna Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Humana for $34 Billion
description: Aetna is near an agreement to buy its smaller rival Humana for about $34 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday, in what could be the first in a series of mergers among the countrys big health insurers.

title: Jihadist From Tunisia Died in Strike in Libya, U.S. Official Says
description: TUNIS  Tunisias most wanted jihadist, who masterminded a campaign of assassinations and terrorist attacks, including one against the United States Embassy in Tunis, was killed in an American airstrike in Libya in mid-June that had targeted another Al Qaeda leader, a senior United States official said on Thursday.

title: Air Passengers Applaud a Justice Dept. Collusion Case
description: As the manager of her husbands rock band, Jill Meniketti has booked many flights over the past 12 years.

title: Business Ties Made by Jeb Bush as Florida Governor Turned Lucrative When He Left Office
description: In his final year as governor, Jeb Bush led a campaign to persuade an Italian military contractor and its partners to build a plant in Florida, meeting with the companys chief executive, offering financial incentives and appearing at an event celebrating the project.

title: Dustin Brown, Ranked 102nd, Seems to Have Rafael Nadals Number
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Dustin Brown stands 6 feet 5 inches, with dreadlocks about half that long, and is listed at a lithe 172 pounds. He has a large tattoo of his father over his left rib cage, has rings in his ears and speaks English with a German-Caribbean accent.

title: Yemen Expects a Pause in Fighting for Aid Deliveries
description: UNITED NATIONS  Under mounting pressure from United Nations officials who warn of the risk of an imminent famine, the Saudi-backed Yemeni government said it expected a pause in the fighting to be declared to allow for the delivery of humanitarian aid, a government minister said Thursday.

title: Hopeful Start to Greek Debt Negotiations Quickly Soured
description: ATHENS  Last Friday morning, the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, gathered his closest advisers in a Brussels hotel room for a meeting that was meant to be secret. All the participants had to leave their phones outside the door to prevent leaks.

title: Republican Governors Signal Their Intent to Thwart Obamas Climate Rules
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to complete sweeping regulations aimed at tackling climate change, at least five Republican governors, including two presidential hopefuls, say they may refuse to carry out the rules in their states.

title: From Bats to Trades, All Is Quiet for the Mets
description: Baseball is so crazy that the Mets, who have scored one run in their last three games, will probably blitz Clayton Kershaw in Los Angeles on Friday night, and then do the same to Zack Greinke on Saturday. Perhaps the Mets have the Dodgers aces right where they want them.

title: Glenn Ford, Death Row Prisoner Freed After 29 Years, Dies at 65
description: Glenn Ford, who spent nearly 30 years on death row in Louisiana for a murder he almost certainly did not commit, died on Monday in New Orleans, less than 16 months after his conviction and death sentence were vacated and he was released. He was 65.

title: Letter Accompanying Sin
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  A very fresh and snappy puzzle by Brandon I Make My Own Ice Cream From Scratch Hensley. Mr. Hensley, who has yet to offer me any of his delicious RUM RAISIN ice cream, or even his lavender honeycomb flavor (which sounds fabulous), wondered if I was going to begin my post about his puzzle with the word Ew, like I did with his debut puzzle. I was actually responding to the grotesque rural legend that his theme described, and not his construction, because its impossible for me to think about what that legend described and not respond with an Ew.

title: South Sudan: 2 Sanctioned by U.S.
description: Two commanders leading the opposing sides in the civil war convulsing South Sudan were sanctioned by the Treasury Department on Thursday for fomenting the conflict. The action against the two, Gabriel Jok Riak and Simon Gatwech Dual, freezes any assets they have under American jurisdiction and bars them from transactions with Americans. The Treasury said the two were responsible for perpetrating violence and breaching cease-fire agreements. The United Nations Security Council has imposed sanctions on them and four others.

title: Signs of a Compromise Over Inspections in Iran Nuclear Talks
description: VIENNA  An Iranian official signaled Thursday that Tehran was trying to bridge the gap between Western demands for inspections of any suspected nuclear-related facility and a declaration by Irans supreme leader that foreigners could not enter military sites or interview Iranian scientists.

title: Charles Harbutt, Photojournalist With an Eye for Art, Dies at 79
description: Charles Harbutt, a photojournalist who infused his work with evocative imagery and an art photographer who transformed conventional scenes into surreal metaphors, died late Monday or early Tuesday in Monteagle, Tenn., near Chattanooga, where he was teaching. He was 79.

title: Alexis Tsiprass Enemies in Europe See Their Chance in Vote on Greeces Bailout Terms
description: ATHENS  Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras says the referendum in Greece on Sunday is simply about whether to agree to what he sees as a bad deal from the countrys creditors. Many of his opponents say it is actually about whether Greece wants to stay with the euro.

title: Man Accused in Killing Is Indicted on Terrorism Charges, a First for New Jersey
description: A Seattle man accused of killing a New Jersey man as an act of revenge for United States military action overseas was indicted on terrorism charges on Thursday, the first time in New Jersey that a defendant has faced a state-level terror charge in a murder case.

title: Unlikely Journey of Martin St. Louis, Spanning 391 Goals and a Stanley Cup, Comes to Its End
description: Martin St. Louis, an undersized right winger who went from being an undrafted free agent to having an N.H.L. career that will likely put him in the Hall of Fame, announced his retirement Thursday.

title: Near Citi Field, Plans for Willets West Are Ruled Illegal
description: A state court ruled Thursday that a development group that includes the owners of the Mets cannot build a mall and movie theater on acreage next to Citi Field because it is parkland legally designated only for use as a stadium. The proposed construction of Willets West  on the parking lot where Shea Stadium once stood  is part of a long-planned project to redevelop the larger Willets Point area.

title: William Anderson Said to Be Leaving Goldman Sachs for Evercore
description: One of the most prominent advisers to companies besieged by activist investors is preparing to leave his perch at Goldman Sachs.

title: Mayor de Blasio and Governor Cuomo Point Fingers, but Theres Enough Blame for Both
description: Just before the shooting war between the mayor and the governor broke into the open this week, a series of guerrilla strikes promised the first signs of life in Albany for months. Other than the two most powerful legislators being arrested, nothing much had happened since January, although all kinds of laws needed to be fixed or extended.

title: When a Chic Italian Interiors Magazine Curates a Pop-Up Bazaar
description: The year-old Italian interiors magazine Cabana is dedicated to the principle of gemtlich, a German term referring to an intimate, comfortable feeling. That word summons this vision, says Cabanas editor in chief, Martina Mondadori. Not only big and grand rooms, but that corner, that detail, that object that makes a room feel unique and yet personal. Next week, fans of the publication will have the chance to bring its eclectic sensibility home when the magazine debuts its first-ever pop-up store at the entrance of the MiArt fair taking place in Milan during Salone del Mobile, and an online companion sale at 1stdibs.com. Mondadori hand-selected each of the antique and contemporary objects on offer, including gilded decorative panels by Tennant and Tennant (Stella Tennants design project with her sister Isabel); antique decanters similar to a set found at Marella Agnellis house in Marrakesh; and ikat cushions by Rifat Ozbek. The assortment is somewhere between a Middle Eastern bazaar and a cabinet of curiosities, Mondadori says. These are ultimately the elements that can make a house truly unique and inspiring.

title: Word of the Day | underscore
description: Please Note: Because The Learning Network is on hiatus for July, this is our last installment of Word of the Day until Aug. 3.

title: Pete Rose Declines to Respond to ESPN Report on Betting
description: In an appearance on Fox Sports 1 on Thursday, Pete Rose declined to respond to a report on ESPN last month that he bet on baseball while playing for the Cincinnati Reds in 1986.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (2014) A motley crew of baddies, led by the armed professional scavenger Peter Quill (Chris Pratt, above), joins forces to stop a crazed warrior from taking over the universe in James Gunns interstellar western, based on the Marvel Comics characters. The cast includes Zoe Saldana as Gamora, a green, mean killing machine; Dave Bautista as the brute Drax; Glenn Close as a space-age Hillary Rodham Clinton; Bradley Cooper as the voice of the raccoon Rocket; and Vin Diesel as a gorgeous tree called Groot, who nibbles his own tender sprouts. Oh, yes  and a blue orb that has incited the mayhem in the first place. That theres a palpable directorial sensibility in Guardians of the Galaxy, along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats. She added: The story may be confusing and generic by turns, but if you shake off the bonds of narrative coherency its liberating letting the weird words  Yondu, Necrocraft, Sakkaran  just slide right past you, much like the zigzagging, exploding 3-D spaceships. What sticks are the fantastical landscapes, the beautiful creature designs and the actors delivering lively performances, even with strata of makeup and digital wizardry.

title: Corrections: July 3, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This tsunami is coming.

title: Wild in the Streets: A 24-Hour Field Guide to New York City
description: In the citys urban jungle, the natural world still thrives around the clock. Meet the ctenophores and helleborines next door.

title: A Plan to Resettle Hong Kongers in Northern Ireland? Surely You Jest
description: British officials discussed a plan in the early 1980s to resettle the population of Hong Kong, then still a British colony but facing a 1997 deadline for return to China, to Northern Ireland.

title: How Bobbi Brown Spends Her Sundays
description: As the head of her own cosmetics company and the editor in chief of Yahoo Beauty, Bobbi Brown is busier than ever, she said. The makeup artist turned entrepreneur first peddled her wares in 1991, when she introduced a line of lipsticks at Bergdorf Goodman. Four years later, her company was acquired by Este Lauder Companies. Ms. Brown, 58, spends her Sundays walking, shopping and socializing with family in Manhattan. She lives with her husband of 27 years, Steven Plofker, also 58, in the 20s near the High Line, with a view of the Hudson River and of New Jersey, where I came from.

title: Happiness in a Cone
description: The Original Chinatown Ice Cream Factory, located on Bayard Street, has been a neighborhood favorite since 1977.

title: Chinatown Ice Cream Factory, Where a Scoop of Durian Is Plain Vanilla
description: On the first June day to cross the 75-degree mark, the line at Chinatown Ice Cream Factory snaked out the door and under the bright yellow awning with a dragon eating ice cream on it. Groups of customers ate from cups and cones nearby, blocking sections of Bayard Street in Manhattan.

title: An App to Aid the Visually Impaired
description: When Dr. Howard Kaplan first started using a Kindle, he had a flash of insight. Dr. Kaplan is an ophthalmologist and retina surgeon with a practice in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. His patients often suffer from macular degeneration and retinitis pigmentosa, diseases that severely degrade their vision. Even after successful surgeries, many remain unable to read print.

title: The Surfboard Doctor to See in the Rockaways
description: Fernando Pires, dusty and tired, was headed for a hammock on the porch of his Hawaiian-style bungalow on Beach 91st Street in the Rockaways, when suddenly there came a cry for help.

title: Chefs Club Draws Out-of-Town Crowd Downtown
description: Summer is when the city empties of New Yorkers and fills up with their stand-ins, tourists from near and far who arrive by the plane-, train- and busload. Like the rising temperatures, they slow the citys pace, as they take the time to marvel at the things that residents rush past. One record of these out-of-towners discoveries is the travel website TripAdvisor, with its catalog of traveler recommendations, and its listings could teach New Yorkers a few things about their city.

title: Bob Dylans Quiet Debut in New York City
description: Q. When and where did Bob Dylan make his debut in New York?

title: A Hybrid of Nature and the Man-Made
description: The photographer, Miska Draskoczy, found life abounding near the Gowanus Canal.

title: A Photographer Finds Abundant Life in and Around the Gowanus Canal
description: A tree grows in Brooklyn, a rose grows in Spanish Harlem, a developer follows with seven-figure condos  are there any forces in New York more eternally indestructible than nature and gentrification? The photographer Miska Draskoczy became fascinated with this cycle of destruction and rebirth after moving near the Gowanus Canal in 2008, two years before the canal was named a Superfund site, requiring $506 million to clean up. Wandering the neighborhood at night, when the streets emptied of people, he found life abounding: green plants pushing up through broken pavement, vines reclaiming graffiti-marked walls, trees throwing bucolic shade over drive-by garbage heaps. One night, pushing through dense foliage at the dead end of Huntington Street, he spied a snowy egret perched on a branch, staring out over a motionless canal.

title: He Saved Jewish Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges and Creativity
description: To the Editor:

title: Tired of All Those TV Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Christian Conservatives vs. Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Europes Many Economic Disasters
description: Its depressing thinking about Greece these days, so lets talk about something else, O.K.? Lets talk, for starters, about Finland, which couldnt be more different from that corrupt, irresponsible country to the south. Finland is a model European citizen; it has honest government, sound finances and a solid credit rating, which lets it borrow money at incredibly low interest rates.

title: Interns, Victimized Yet Again
description: JULY is to internships what March is to college basketball. Tens of thousands of interns have descended on New York, Washington, Los Angeles and other internship capitals with the hope of showing off the talent needed to land a job  and in some fields, ones chances are about as high as getting picked in the N.B.A. draft.

title: What Do Iranian-Americans Think of the Nuclear Deal?
description: LOS ANGELES  MY family left Tehran in 1979, in the aftermath of the revolution that created the Islamic Republic of Iran. We arrived in the United States with nothing but a single suitcase each, assuming this would be only temporary. Once things settled down, we would surely be returning to our lives back in Iran.

title: Medicare and Medicaid at 50
description: Medicare and Medicaid, the two mainstays of government health insurance, turn 50 this month, having made it possible for most Americans in poverty and old age to get medical care. While the Affordable Care Act fills the gap for people who dont qualify for help from those two programs, there are important improvements still needed in both Medicare and Medicaid.

title: A Sensible Question for Gun Owners
description: California has some of the nations strongest gun safety laws, but one that requires citizens to supply a good cause for why they should be granted a license to carry concealed weapons in public is under challenge.

title: After a Historic Week, Reflections on How the Supreme Court Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Could You Block Your Mobile Phone?
description: A spa hotel in Baden-Baden, Germany, thinks it has come up with the ultimate in de luxe recreation with a silvery bedside switch that allows a guest to disconnect from the digital world entirely. Turning the switch off obstructs all electronic signals with the help of copper plates embedded in the walls that guard against leakage from neighboring rooms and the Great Out There.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, July 4 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 4 to 11, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 4 to 11, 2015

title: Review: Red 36 in Mystic
description: Sometimes a restaurants style is so crucial to the places success, it should be on the menu. Set in a marina, Red 36 in Mystic juts out over the water, and with sunlight streaming through huge windows, timber rafters overhead and an outdoor dining deck, the place feels like a big boat. (The name refers to the numbering of channel markers in the harbor.)

title: A Review of Casa dItalia in Harrison
description: Lucy and Steve Selvaggio grew up on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx, where Ms. Selvaggio loved each and every deli, each and every bakery  I must have worked at all the bakeries down there.

title: Review: Biddy OMalleys in Northvale
description: Pubs in Ireland are practically a cultural institution. Traditionally, they are neighborhood watering holes where locals gather for a pint and maybe a bite. Lately gastropubs, which stand out for serving high-quality food, have become trendy there.

title: An Upscale Seafood Shack
description: It is just around this time that tensions on the East End of Long Island begin to rise along with the temperature. Droves of vacationers have paid extravagant amounts to be there and are anxious to relax, but often discover an infrastructure ill-equipped to accommodate them. Parking, they find, is in short supply. Roads are insufficient. Foodstuffs run out quickly. If you sleep until 10 a.m. on Sunday, finding a copy of The New York Times becomes an Easter egg hunt.

title: Aetna Agrees to Acquire Humana for $37 Billion in Cash and Stock
description: The health insurer Aetna said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire its smaller rival Humana for $37 billion in cash and stock, signaling the start of what may become a flurry of consolidation in the sector.

title: Five Ways to Escape Your Renovation
description: Need someplace to live during your renovation?

title: Home Renovation: Time for a Hotel?
description: Sometimes, creating the home youve always desired requires living like a nomad. While many people spend months plotting a renovation, down to the choice of bathroom faucet and finish of hardwood floors, fewer spend that sort of time thinking about where theyre going to live when the demolition crew arrives.

title: New York Butcher Is Named as Real Live Uncle Sam
description: In parades across the country on Saturday, lanky men on stilts sporting red and white striped pants, star-spangled top hats and gray goatees will pretend to be Uncle Sam. In Conway, Ark., James Black would perform that role after he retired as a cattle hauler and bus driver until he died in 2009 at 76.

title: Potash Corporation Still Interested in K&S After $8.6 Billion Offer Is Rejected
description: LONDON  The Potash Corporation said on Friday that it was still interested in acquiring K&S, the German potash and salt mining company that owns Morton Salt, despite a rejection of its unsolicited takeover bid.

description: Please Note: Because The Learning Network is on hiatus for July, this is our last installment of News Qs until Aug. 3. We are also experimenting with this feature, so please let us know what you think about the changes.

title: Shinzo Abe Faces Growing Wrath of Okinawans Over U.S. Base
description: HENOKO, Japan  Orange buoys surround a wide swath of clear blue sea off the coast of Okinawa where the United States Marine Corps has long sought to build a new airfield on landfill. For more than two decades, plans for this base have gone nowhere, stymied by fierce local opposition and politicians in Tokyo without the clout or determination to overcome it.

title: 2012 | Life, Liberty and Legibility
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: More Caregivers Are No Spring Chickens Themselves
description: Gail Schwartz wants to keep her 85-year-old husband out of a nursing home as long as she can, but it isnt easy.

title: Teenagers in The Times | June 2015
description: Video from The Roller Coaster Couple, part of the Timess Summer Love project  to which you can contribute.

title: Take the Hamptons Helicopter; Get the Tamara Mellon Outfit?
description: Q. When is an airplane aisle not just an airplane aisle?

title: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian Teenager in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian teenager in the occupied West Bank on Friday as he and others hurled stones and rocks at their army vehicle, the Israeli military said, while Palestinian Authority security forces in the West Bank arrested more than 100 members of its rival group Hamas in the biggest such roundup in years.

title: Putting Fewer Innocents Behind Bars
description: Kalief Browder hanged himself last month. He was 22.You may well know of him; he was 16 when he was arrested in the Bronx for allegedly stealing a backpack. Three years later, the charges were dropped for lack of evidence, but Browder spent those three years in Rikers Island jail, two of them in solitary confinement.

title: Greeces Sorry Reckoning
description: FALIRON BAY, Greece  THE sea, as I look from my office window, is calm. Little white sailboats glide over silver waters in the Saronic Gulf. A picture of peace, but the scene of countless battles. In these waters, at Salamis, an alliance of free Greek states under Athenss leadership defeated the Persian navy in 480 B.C., giving democracy room to develop. In 1941, as German forces swept into the country, a handful of allied airmen tried to stop black waves of enemy planes, with many pilots plunging to their deaths in the bay one April day.

title: 1915: Sinking Provokes Italians
description: ROME  The news of the sinking of the Italian barque Sardomene by a German submarine, off the south-east coast of Ireland, near Bantry Bay, has aroused deep indignation among all classes throughout Italy. Everyone is asking whether this is intended as a means of provoking the declaration of war that Germany refuses to make, while all the time she is transferring Bavarian troops to the Italian frontier and keeping the Swiss frontiers closed, in order to conceal these movements. If destruction of the Sardomene is really meant to goad Italy into declaring war, Germany could not have chosen anything better calculated to move Italian public opinion. Among the harrowing details of the sinking of this ship without notice, is the fact that two seamen were shot by the crew of the submarine as they were attempting to swim ashore. The New York Herald, European Edition, July 4, 1915

title: Seattle on the Mediterranean
description: Oh, the ceaseless Seattle sun. June just set another record  the hottest ever recorded in this city, closing out the warmest first half of a year.

title: Where Perfect Tranquillity Reigns
description: The poet and writer, shellshocked after World War I, found a place to write in a village on the northern coast of the Spanish island.

title: The Arts Find a Home in the Upper Florida Keys
description: More than an hours drive south of Miami, Islamorada in the Upper Florida Keys has a history of reinventing itself. Practically annihilated by the 1935 Labor Day hurricane (still considered the strongest to reach landfall in the United States), this Village of Islands became known for quality sport fishing, attracting professional and amateur anglers from around the world.

title: Robert Graves Found Perfect Tranquillity in Majorca
description: The Serra de Tramunta rose behind me, a towering limestone mountain covered in wild olive trees, pines and rosemary. Below, a valley filled with ancient olive groves plunged to the Mediterranean.

title: Fur Is Back in Fashion and Debate
description: Even by the standards of Fendi, the Roman house that once sent mink coats glistening with 24-karat gold down the runways, its upcoming haute fourrure show on Wednesday counts as a statement: the first fur-only extravaganza by a major design label during the Paris haute couture shows.

title: Robert Frank on a Vanished Friend and Collaborator
description: By the time the photographer Robert Franks masterpiece, The Americans, was published in the United States in 1959, he was starting the next phase of his career: filmmaker. Over the next 50 years, Frank made many films, but perhaps his most notable was a documentary few have ever seen. [expletive] Blues got its start in 1972, when the Rolling Stones asked Frank, who had photographed them for their album Exile on Main Street, to go on tour with them. Franks only condition was that he could bring along a friend: the young photographer Danny Seymour.

title: The Long Decline of Trust in Government, and Why That Can Be Patriotic
description: How often do you trust the government in Washington to do what is right? That question has been put to thousands of Americans over the decades by multiple survey research firms.

title: In Machu Picchus Shadow, Perus Lake Titicaca Offers Natural Beauty
description: The fuchsia roses and yellow daisies that frame trails across Suasi Island were always meant to be here. So were the alpacas and vicuas whose silhouettes occasionally interrupt the deep orange sunsets that reflect off the calm waters of Lake Titicaca.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 4 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its fourth week. To participate, just post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 10 and answer the question What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: Alibabas Financial Affiliate Is Said to Close Private Placement of Shares
description: SHANGHAI  The financial services affiliate of the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group closed a private placement of shares on Friday that the company said values it at more than $45 billion and makes the Chinese government a stakeholder, according to people familiar with the transaction.

title: Bernie Sanderss Revolutionary Roots Were Nurtured in 60s Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  When he came to Vermont in the late 1960s to help plan the upending of the old social order, the future presidential candidate Bernie Sanders brought with him the belief that the United States was starkly divided into two groups: the establishment and the revolutionaries. He was a revolutionary.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Adelaide, Australia

description: Dear Diary:

title: 1965: Algerian Leader to Form Government
description: ALGIERS  Algerian strongman Col. Houari Boumedienne today [July 4] reluctantly agreed to take over the task of forming a new government. He did so after apparently giving up his attempt to get another prominent figure to take over the job of president, which has been vacant since the Boumedienne-led coup ousted President Ahmed Ben Bella two weeks ago. An Information Ministry announcement said Col. Boumedienne would make an important address to the nation tomorrow  his first since the military coup. Tomorrow is the third anniversary of Algerias independence of France. It has been widely reported that he was engaged in talks with two of Mr. Ben Bellas political opponents, Ferhat Abbas and Rabah Bitat, to serve in the presidency to a figurehead capacity, leaving him free to run the government from his old post as defense minister. These talks apparently collapsed. Meanwhile the council banned all independence anniversary parades and mass meetings tomorrow, apparently to guard against any possible demonstrations in favor of Mr. Ben Bella. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 4, 1965

title: My Sons Flag Is Not My Familiar Stars and Stripes
description: What does it mean to be from somewhere? How much a part of your identity is the place you grow up  the town, the state, the country? How important is it that your children share that identity?

title: Effective Concussion Treatment Remains Frustratingly Elusive, Despite a Booming Industry
description: In a small brick building across the street from a Taco Bell in Marrero, La., patients enter a clear plastic capsule and breathe pure oxygen.

title: Home Tours Take Mary McBride Band to Zones of Conflict and Calamity
description: On a dusty stage at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan, the Mary McBride Band was playing one of its signature songs, Do I Ever Cross Your Mind? Ms. McBride, 45, the groups founder and lead singer, cleared her throat and launched into the lyrics, as the guitarist Paul Carbonara, the keyboardist Jon Spurney, and the rhythm section of bassist Greg Beshers and drummer Mark Stepro found a groove. American soldiers in the country to fight the Taliban swayed and sang along, for once not weighed down by their 45-pound bulletproof jackets.

title: Donatella Versace on Her Responsibility as a Designer, the Ultimate Luxury and Exercising Restraint
description: Asked what she is looking forward to most this summer, Donatella Versace said recently, Absolute peace, absolute privacy and absolute pleasure with my family and friends. But the Italian designer is in Paris this weekend to present her fall 2015 couture collection where she is sure to experience the opposite of rest and relaxation with loved ones. When I am in Paris for Atelier Versace, she says, life is a whirlwind. There is so much to perfect, and ensure that every single detail is how I want it to be. In the days leading up to her runway show, Versace took a quiet moment to share with T her own fashionrules, beauty secrets and the responsibility she feels as a designer.

title: Check Insurance Coverage When Renting a Car
description: BEFORE heading out on summer vacation in a rental car, its a good idea to check what insurance coverage you already have before opting to buy expensive protection at the car rental counter.

title: Greenlands Iceberg Factory  Where the Empire State Building is Too Short a Yardstick
description: Its worth being reminded occasionally of the stunning scale of the worlds great ice sheets and the glaciers that connect them with faraway coasts when cleaved icebergs (and flowing meltwater) outweigh the gain of mass from snowfall in the frigid interior, contributing to sea-level rise.

title: Video Reviews of Magic Mike XXL, Terminator Genisys and Cartel Land
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Magic Mike XXL, Terminator Genisys and Cartel Land. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Heroines Triumph at Box Office, but Has Anything Changed in Hollywood?
description: Has feminism conquered Hollywood? Has Hollywood co-opted feminism? Some recent female-driven hits and some vocal critics suggest that the entertainment industrys status quo is under attack, at least in some quarters. While the Sony hacking scandal last year revealed what certain power players really think about women, more and more women and men in the industry  from Kathryn Bigelow to Mark Ruffalo and Margaret Cho  are speaking out against discrimination. Whether emboldened by the hacking, by exasperated fans, media attention, legal threats or just one another, these critics  and the box office  may signal that real change is upon us, even during that seasonal playground for boys and men called summer.

title: The Art of Thinking Inside the Box
description: In his minds eye, the American artist Joseph Cornell traveled the European continent without ever leaving his Queens apartment. He was an armchair voyager, says Sarah Lea, the curator of a major survey of his work, Joseph Cornell: Wanderlust, opening at the Royal Academy in London tomorrow. Europe was not just a source of inspiration for him, it was a long-distance love affair that sparked a wanderlust of the mind. The former textile salesmans imaginary travels began in Manhattan junk stores, where he amassed the vintage maps, travel guides, toys and ephemera that were the building blocks of his surrealist assemblages. Cornells found-object aesthetic  which pays tribute to his many interests, from vaudeville to Renaissance art to his beloved prima ballerinas  remains influential. Here, we round up three contemporary box artists whose work, like Cornells, is the product of a life of collecting.

title: Sarah Jessica Parkers House Sells for $18.25 Million
description: A 25-foot-wide Greek Revival-style townhouse on a prime tree-lined street in Greenwich Village that Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick bought, refurbished and promptly returned to the market, sold for $18,250,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: No Felony Charges for Sean Combs, Says Los Angeles County District Attorneys Office
description: The Los Angeles County District Attorneys Office declined on Thursday to bring felony charges against Sean Combs, the music mogul known as Diddy, following an incident last month at the University of California, Los Angeles, where his son is a member of the football team.

title: Aleppo Fighting Flares as Syria Insurgents Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The fiercest fighting in months raged in the divided Syrian city of Aleppo on Friday, as newly reorganized insurgents carried out a new offensive on government-held areas.

title: At the 2015 Tour de France, the Route Could Favor the Home Team
description: Although the organizers of the Tour de France do not acknowledge it, French riders strengths sometimes factor into the annual route planning.

description: AMMAN, Jordan  HER FATHER wanted to marry her off by the time she was 12. Her mother most definitely did not, and for this conviction, she paid dearly.

title: Savage Beauty at V&A Museum to Open Continuously for Last 2 Weekends
description: LONDON  For the first time in its history, the Victoria and Albert Museum will stay open around the clock for the final two weekends of the exhibition Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty, which closes on Aug. 2.

title: Partnerships Opening Number: A Day of Jazz
description: When Jeffrey P. Haydon took over as the chief executive of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah almost three years ago, favorable attendance at its jazz concerts was a hit-or-miss proposition. So he began networking, eventually approaching Jazz at Lincoln Center about forming a programming relationship.

title: In Greek Referendum Campaign, a Barrage of Doomsday Ads
description: ATHENS  The ads come close to suggesting that the apocalypse could be just around the corner if Greeks make the wrong choice in a referendum on Sunday.

title: Technicolor at 100: Saturation and Subtlety in Filmmaking
description: By the time Dorothy opened a door onto Oz in 1939, Technicolor  the company that let viewers see the yellow in the yellow-brick road  was already almost a quarter-century old.

title: Mitt Romney Invites Marco Rubio and Chris Christie to Holiday Sleepover at New Hampshire Vacation Home
description: Mitt Romney is having a slumber party this weekend at his New Hampshire compound with some very interesting guests: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, along with their families.

title: Japan Cuts Film Festival at Japan Society Emphasizes the Eccentric
description: The annual cinematic cornucopia known as Japan Cuts  the largest festival of Japanese film in the United States  has previously been presented in association with the even larger New York Asian Film Festival. This year, its ninth, Japan Cuts is going it alone as it presents 28 features and a program of experimental shorts beginning Thursday through July 19 at Japan Society in Manhattan.

title: Review of Five Presidents at the Bay Street Theater
description: Turning politics into entertainment is a specialty for Rick Cleveland, who has written for The West Wing and House of Cards. In Five Presidents, Mr. Clevelands new play at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, he demonstrates that he can make government leaders engaging on the stage, too. His 85-minute imagining of what the five presidents (four former, one current) who paid their respects at Richard Nixons funeral in 1994 might have chatted about when they were alone is at times as smart and funny as a high-grade dramedy.

title: Review of Loves Labours Lost by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey
description: Go ahead guys, blather on about your brains. Soon enough, your hearts will show you whos boss. This idea is made wonderfully clear in an exceptional production of Loves Labours Lost by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey.

title: Hartford Police Officers Rap With Youths to Erode Stereotypes
description: The two Hartford police officers were sitting in their cruiser recently when a couple of Hispanic boys leaving middle school waved at them, and said Hey, Hiram, Teddy, as they walked by.

title: Uber Suspends UberPop in France and Awaits Court Ruling
description: PARIS  Uber, the American ride-hailing company, agreed to suspend its lowest-cost service in France starting Friday evening, bowing to strikes last week in which taxi drivers blocked roads, burned tires and in some cases attacked drivers who they thought were working for Uber.

description: There will be no treble, no bass and no concerts for fans of Meghan Trainor for at least a few days this summer: the pop singer said she has been instructed by her doctors to postpone two coming shows and take a complete vocal rest after having a hemorrhage on her vocal cords.

title: A Chelsea Townhouse, Mansion-Ready
description: A stately four-story townhouse on a historic Chelsea block is about to enter the market for the first time in more than two decades; the listing price for 440 West 22nd Street, nestled midway between Ninth and 10th Avenues, is $17.95 million.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan military commandos raided and searched a Doctors Without Borders hospital in the north of the country, firing several shots in the air and threatening the staff, the humanitarian group said Friday.

description: Young adults stuck in expensive rentals may be tempted to pool resources with friends to buy a shared home.

description: Nearly four decades after a murder he had long since confessed to, the prisoner sat for yet another round of questions.

title: United States vs. Japan: A Rivalry Renewed
description: Sundays Womens World Cup final will be the third straight major final contested by the United States and Japan. A look back at the previous two games shows just how tight the formerly one-sided rivalry has become.

title: Building Amenities: Flashy Is Nice, but So Is Mundane
description: New York plays by its own rules, as most anyone who lives here knows. What constitutes a status symbol might seem confusing or even commonplace elsewhere, like having a fourth child (the nanny bills! the school tuition!) or a car ($600 a month for a space in a parking garage!).

title: What Jim Webb Would Need to Do to Win
description: Former Senator Jim Webb of Virginia on Thursday entered the race for the Democratic nomination for president. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.

description: Ice cream still needs scooping, beaches still need guarding and campers still need counseling. But now, there are way fewer teenagers doing it all this summer.

title: Driving the Souths Flag Divide
description: Controversy over the Confederate battle flag has escalated across Southern states in the wake of the racially motivated killings at Emanuel A.M.E. Church in June.

title: Views Clash Where Confederate Flags Fly
description: South Carolinas legislature is expected to vote next week on whether to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House in Columbia.

title: Serena Williams Avoids Upset at Wimbledon for Rare Matchup of Sisters
description: WIMBLEDON, England  They were once awkward occasions met with an ambivalent mix of curiosity and sympathy. But it has been so long since tennis had an all-Williams match for high stakes that perhaps the sport and maybe even the sisters are finally ready to embrace the prospect instead of keeping it at long arms length.

title: A Hamptons Event Planner on How to Design Your Garden
description: When mapping out the gardens at his weekend house in Bridgehampton, N.Y., the party designer Ron Wendt followed one of his cardinal rules for staging weddings, charity galas and other events for clients like Cartier, Chanel and Louis Vuitton.

title: Marco Rubios Donor Obstacles: A Limited Base and Another Floridian
description: WASHINGTON  In the nearly three months since he announced that he was running for president, Senator Marco Rubio has been enjoying his moment. Republicans have talked up his potential. Democrats have called him a threat. He has been in the top tier of many polls.

title: Advanced Soccer Statistic Shows Better Team Doesnt Always Win
description: The scoreboard showed that Japan beat England, 2-1, in their Womens World Cup semifinal on Wednesday, and it is Japan that will play in the final against the United States on Sunday.

title: Two Deals for Alex Rodriguez: One for Ball, One for Bonus
description: Alex Rodriguez had his own personal doubleheader Friday, first with an agreement that gave him possession of the baseball he smacked for his 3,000th hit and then with a deal that resolved his longstanding dispute with the Yankees over a $6 million home run bonus. In both cases, the biggest beneficiaries will be designated charities.

description: FOR Phyllis Edelman, 61, dog-walking was the answer.

description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Robin Lopez and Knicks Agree to a Four-Year Deal
description: The Knicks priority entering free agency was to add size. Phil Jackson, the team president, said he needed post players and noted that the team did not have a center on the roster.

title: Logistics and Lizards Disrupt Chevrons Project Off Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Getting anything to Chevrons gas-processing plant on Barrow Island is a bit of a trick.

title: Bubba Watson Will Paint Over Confederate Flag on Dukes of Hazzard Car
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va.  Bubba Watson considers his orange 1969 Dodge Charger a trophy, a symbol of his success on the PGA Tour. Before he won his first Tour event, much less the first of his two Masters green jackets, Watson exacted a promise from his wife, Angie, that he could buy the car featured in the 1970s television show The Dukes of Hazzard.

title: Party Planners Take It From Good to Great, and Free the Host to Make Merry
description: HAVING a party for friends is supposed to be fun. But that may not necessarily be true for the hosts, who do the planning and then often feel that they must make sure everyone is having a good time.

title: Review: Bilal Brings Far-Out Viewpoint to This Life and His Show
description: For an awkward few moments at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night, Bilal seemed at risk of losing his audience. Not literally, as in walkouts, but conceptually, as in What is going on here? He had decided to preface a song with a rambling hypothetical  Can you imagine if God was, like, an alien from some other time? it began  and the more he talked, the more fraught and antsy the resulting laughter sounded.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) MACYS 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR Willie Geist and Tamron Hall host this 39th-annual pyrotechnic extravaganza, featuring performances by Dierks Bentley, above; Kelly Clarkson; Brad Paisley; Flo Rida; and Ed Sheeran. The fireworks  about 2,000 a minute, in 22 colors and in the shapes of ghosts, octopuses, moons, stars, dragons and banshees  will be fired from barges on the East River.

title: As Referendum Looms, Greeces Tourism Industry Holds Its Breath
description: ATHENS  Charles and Liz Lee and their three children had come to see the sights in Athens for their vacation. But it may not be the Acropolis they will remember as much as something else unexpectedly exhilarating, something they had never seen before: demonstrators carrying Communist flags.

title: First Draft Focus: Hello, New Hampshire
Health Insurance Companies Seek Big Rate Increases for 2016
description: WASHINGTON  Health insurance companies around the country are seeking rate increases of 20 percent to 40 percent or more, saying their new customers under the Affordable Care Act turned out to be sicker than expected. Federal officials say they are determined to see that the requests are scaled back.

title: Chris Christie on Donald Trump: Hes a Good Guy
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Donald J. Trump, a friend of 13 years, about whether the fellow presidential candidates comments about Mexicansare bad for Republicans.

title: French President Denies Julian Assanges Request for Protection
description: PARIS  The French president on Friday rejected an appeal for protection from Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks co-founder, who has spent three years under political asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.

title: The Hand That Feeds You, a Thriller Written as an Act of Love for Its Originator
description: Several years ago, the writer Katherine Russell Rich made an alarming discovery about a man she had fallen in love with. She grew suspicious when, after they had been dating for a while and he had proposed marriage, he said that he couldnt spend the holidays with her, so she paid a hacker to get into his email. His messages revealed a shadow life, refracted through layers of deception. He was living with another woman and seeing several others on the side.

title: Despair and Anger as Puerto Ricans Cope With Debt Crisis
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Its the lunch hour at Bakers Bakery, a fixture in Ro Piedras, one of Puerto Ricos oldest neighborhoods, but the bustle at the counter is long gone. The front door opens and shuts only a few times an hour as customers, holding tighter than ever to their money, judiciously pick up some sugar-sprinkled pastries and a caf con leche.

title: Review: Un Break  Mozart Sails Onstage, Along With the Dash Ensemble
description: Just as the Hermione, a replica of the Marquis de Lafayettes ship, sailed into South Street Seaport for the Fourth of July weekend, a group of stalwart hip-hop dancers from France whirled their way around an outdoor stage to Mozart.

title: How Iceland Emerged From Its Deep Freeze
description: When the financial crisis hit Iceland seven years ago, Gudmundur Kristjansson, a 55-year-old fisherman with a wide smile, weathered face and mischievous eyes, almost lost his business. Interest payments on his loans soared 300 percent. He had to sell his two fish factories and two of his five fishing boats. We didnt invest for many years, he said, because we were only paying interest.

title: Farm Activism
description: Innovative movements are sprouting across the country to improve wages and working conditions for Americas more than two million farm workers.

title: Farm Labor Groups Make Progress on Wages and Working Conditions
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  It was an unlikely place for a labor protest: 120 migrant workers, students and clergy members were shouting outside the flagship store of Ben & Jerrys, which displayed a Peace, Love and Ice Cream sign on its facade.

title: What Did Lincoln Really Think of Jefferson?
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  Lincoln hated Thomas Jefferson. That is not exactly what we expect to hear about the president who spoke of malice toward none, referring to the president who wrote that all men are created equal.

title: Pegasus, a Tugboat and Floating Museum, Hits Rough Waters
description: Pamela Hepburn walked on the steel decks of the Pegasus, in the shadow of its big black, stately stacks.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: Ballet Theaters Met Season, a Mix of Sparkling Moments and Familiar War Horses
description: In a magnificent malapropism, a woman of my acquaintance once described a mans wife as a lodestone round his neck. And thats what the Metropolitan Opera House is to American Ballet Theater: a draw that drags the company down.

title: Operation Wild and Dr. Jeff Show Two Approaches to Veterinary TV
description: Was that venerable PBS venturing into the lowbrow world of veterinary television this week? Yes, it was, and Dr. Jeff should take a lesson.

title: A Long Flight Powered by Sunlight
description: The Solar Impulse 2 aircraft landed in Hawaii on Friday. It set the records for the longest solar-powered airplane flights, for both distance and time.

title: The Science of Inside Out
description: FIVE years ago, the writer and director Pete Docter of Pixar reached out to us to talk over an idea for a film, one that would portray how emotions work inside a persons head and at the same time shape a persons outer life with other people. He wanted to do this all in the mind of an 11-year-old girl as she navigated a few difficult days in her life.

title: ISIS Destroys More Artifacts in Syria and Iraq
description: Islamic State militants indulged in new public displays of artifact destruction this week, sledgehammering a half-dozen statues said to have been stolen from the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra.

title: Hillary Clinton Warns That a Republican President Would Repeal the Health Law
description: HANOVER, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton has steadfastly ignored Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator who is also vying for the Democratic presidential nomination, even as he has surged in the polls. But she sent a clear signal on Friday that she was not planning to cede any ground to her liberal rival.

title: Universals Back Lot Tour Adds a Bigger Dose of Movie Fantasy
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  When Universal Studios opened its back lot to tourists in 1964, it was one of Hollywoods biggest wows. For the first time, swarms of everyday people, riding in candy-striped GlamorTrams, could come face to face with filmmaking.

title: Obamas Eulogy, Which Found Its Place in History
description: Barack Obamas eulogy for the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., was remarkable not only because the president sang the opening refrain of Amazing Grace on live television, and not only because of his eloquence in memorializing the pastor and eight other parishioners killed by a white gunman. It was also remarkable because the eulogy drew on all of Mr. Obamas gifts of language and empathy and searching intellect  first glimpsed in Dreams From My Father, his deeply felt 1995 memoir about identity and family. And because it used those gifts to talk about the complexities of race and justice, situating them within an echoing continuum in time that reflected both Mr. Obamas own long view of history, and the panoramic vision of America, shared by Abraham Lincoln and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as a country in the process of perfecting itself.

title: Charleston Suspect Was in Contact With Supremacists, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Federal and local authorities have found that the man charged in the shooting deaths of nine black people in a South Carolina church last month had been in contact with white supremacists online, although it does not appear they encouraged him to carry out the massacre, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Thoreau, the First Declutterer
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  WITH household decluttering now a national obsession, maybe Americans should pause this Fourth of July and remember the nations original domestic minimalist, Henry David Thoreau.

title: Our National Parks: Make Upkeep a Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Training Police in Social and Communication Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: Escapees Prison Art
description: To the Editor:

title: An Insult to Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Protected Consumer Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Love Among the Fireworks
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  Fireworks have always reminded me of falling in love and the fear that someone will get hurt.

title: ReBar, Once a Brooklyn Wedding Destination, Is Now a Neighborhood Blight
description: The Manhattan Bridge casts a deep shadow on 147 Front Street, where today a sandwich shop operates at street level, and upstairs a real estate sign offers space  bar, lounge, seating area  for rent, both hourly and monthly.

title: Collecting Paradise at the Rubin: A Curious Case of Divergence
description: When art exhibitions travel from one museum to another, as they often do, their main themes usually dont change very much. A show might be tweaked by different institutions, but the core set of objects and ideas put together by the originating curators ordinarily remains the same. Collecting Paradise: Buddhist Art of Kashmir and Its Legacies, a show at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, is a curious case of divergence from that custom, and its one that hinges on some currently momentous issues for museums and their holdings.

title: Mindful of Greece, Ukraine Is in a Rush to Line Up Debt Relief
description: MOSCOW  Nobody knows how the endless dispute will play out between Athens and the European leaders who hold its purse strings. But in Kiev, another European capital in the grip of debt talks, one thing is certain: The Ukrainian government does not want to end up like Greece, squabbling with creditors for years.

title: Calls to Oust Ecuadors President Flare Before Visit by the Pope
description: QUITO, Ecuador  Protesters calling for the ouster of President Rafael Correa have filled the streets of Ecuadors largest cities in recent weeks in some of the largest antigovernment demonstrations here in years, creating tensions on the eve of a visit by Pope Francis.

title: Liberia: 200 Reportedly Had Contact With Ebola Victim
description: The World Health Organization reported Friday that nearly 200 people had been in contact with a 17-year-old in Liberia who was confirmed to have died of Ebola on June 28, the countrys first Ebola case since May 9, when it had been officially declared free of the highly contagious disease. In an assessment posted on its website, the W.H.O. said that all of the contacts of the teenager were being closely monitored and that two of them had already tested positive for the virus, confirming what the Liberian health authorities had reported this week. The organization also said it was dispatching epidemiologists and other specialists to ensure that the victims hometown is fully involved in identifying contacts and preventing any further disease spread.

title: An American Tip to German Spies Points to a More Complex Relationship
description: BERLIN  In the summer of 2011, American intelligence agencies spied on a senior German official who they concluded had been the likely source of classified information being leaked to the news media.

title: Romneys Said to Meet With Jeb Bush in Maine Next Week
description: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, will travel to the Bush family compound in Kennebunkport, Me., early next week for a private lunch meeting with Jeb Bush, according to a person briefed on the plans who was not authorized to discuss the meeting.

title: John Whitman, Investment Banker and Husband of Governor, Dies at 71
description: John R. Whitman, an investment banker and the husband of former Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey, died on Thursday in Morristown, N.J. He was 71.

title: Medical Mysteries of the Heart
description: Scientists have made enormous gains in reducing deaths from coronary heart disease, the leading cause of heart attacks, but it is astonishing how much they still dont know. That leaves patients and their doctors uncertain about the best way to fight a disease that is still the leading cause of death for both men and women in the United States.

title: Jeb Bush Needs Some New Economic Advice
description: Jeb Bush is said to have brought on Glenn Hubbard as an economic adviser  the dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business and a prominent conservative who served as President George W. Bushs chief economist and was an architect of the big tax cuts in 2001, which favored the wealthy. He can be expected to weigh in on wage stagnation and income inequality, campaign issues that all the candidates, including Mr. Bush, have said they will address.

title: Lawrence Herkimer, Grandfather of Modern Cheerleading, Dies at 89
description: Lawrence R. Herkimer, who elevated cheerleading into an aspirational goal for generations of youths and a highly successful business for himself, organizing camps for would-be cheerleaders and selling the clothing and gear they would need, died on Wednesday in Dallas. He was 89.

title: Survivor of 05 London Subway Attack Is on Antiterror Mission
description: LONDON  For a moment, after a suicide bomb ripped off both her legs, Gill Hicks thought she had died. It took an hour for emergency medical workers to make it to the deepest tunnel of the London subway, and she drifted in and out of consciousness. But she remembers vividly finding a label on her wrist in the hospital: One unknown, estimated female.

title: Billionaires to the Barricades
description: EARLIER this month, when the billionaire merchandising mogul Johann Rupert gave a speech at The Financial Timess luxury summit in Monaco, he sounded more like a Marxist theoretician than someone who made his fortune selling Cartier diamonds and Montblanc pens. Appearing before a crowd of executives from Fendi and Ferrari, Mr. Rupert argued that it wasnt right  or even good business  for the 0.1 percent of the 0.1 percent to raid the worlds spoils. Its unfair and it is not sustainable, he said.

title: Saving the Palisades
description: More than four years ago, LG Electronics USA released plans to build a new headquarters that would have marred the natural vistas along New Jerseys Palisades Park, which runs along the west side of the Hudson River just across from New York City.

title: Why Puerto Ricos Debt Is So Big
More Gains at Wimbledon for Americans on a Day With Some Upsets
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Just outside the grounds of the All England Club stands a giant blue hydraulic lift that supports a camera to capture a birds-eye view of the grounds. That may have been the only way to fully appreciate the compelling action that took place Friday from high noon until darkness fell.

title: Man Accused of Robbing Queens Bank in a Wheelchair
description: The man in the gray hooded sweatshirt rolled into a bank in Queens at midday on Monday, and handed the teller a note demanding cash.

title: Town That Chased Away Starbucks Sees Its Identity Being Endangered Again
description: KATONAH, N.Y  A hamlet that looks as though it would fit neatly into a model-train layout at Christmastime is battling once again to sustain its small-town character against the relentless march of the large chain stores.

title: Charlie Sanders, Hall of Fame Tight End With Lions, Dies at 68
description: Charlie Sanders, a tight end for the Detroit Lions from 1968 to 1977 whose sticky fingers, fleet feet and shifty elusiveness helped redefine a position that had traditionally been reserved for stolid blockers, died on Thursday in Royal Oak, Mich., near Detroit. He was 68.

title: Helping Immigrant Farmers Sow Seeds From Home on American Soil
description: UNION, N.J.  On a verdant farm five miles from Newark Liberty International Airport, Jacob Okam struggled to push a shiny, new garden tiller over the bumpy soil last month. His black jersey was already drenched in the noonday sun as he cut a lonesome, but winsome, figure in the field  at one with the land that is both his heritage and his hope.

title: Obama Plans Broader Use of Clemency to Free Nonviolent Drug Offenders
description: WASHINGTON  Sometime in the next few weeks, aides expect President Obama to issue orders freeing dozens of federal prisoners locked up on nonviolent drug offenses. With the stroke of his pen, he will probably commute more sentences at one time than any president has in nearly half a century.

title: Character-Building Event
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Happy Independence Day to our American readers! Youre probably wondering where your Fourth of July-themed puzzle is. Sorry, the closest we will get to things that light up in todays puzzle is the entry GLOW-IN-THE-DARK, but thats O.K. Youve got real fireworks to watch, and I have something else to discuss with you.

title: California Drought Takes Some Sparkle Out of Fireworks Displays
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  The annual Fourth of July fireworks extravaganza here has survived municipal economic crises and fire marshal warnings about exploding shells over this hot and dry landlocked community. But this year, patriotism might have finally met its match: the California drought.

title: Heather Watsons Memorable Defeat at Wimbledon Packs a Sting
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Heather Watson put aside her childhood idolization of Serena Williams on Friday and stared down the best female player in the world on Centre Court.

title: French Honors for an American Veteran of the Monuments Men
description: It was 1945 when Harry L. Ettlinger, a Jewish-American soldier, escorted two German miners down a 12-foot-high aisle of a deep underground salt mine. They kept passing sealed doors.

title: Wimbledon Players Who Are Mothers Welcome Change in Focus
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Of the 32 women who advanced to the third round of Wimbledon, Casey Dellacqua may have been the only one to spend time this week sleeping on the floor.

title: Status of David Wrights Rehab Is Still Hanging Over Mets
description: LOS ANGELES  On Mondays, David Wright typically meets with Dr. Robert Watkins, a back surgeon, and undergoes a series of tests for his spinal stenosis. Wright has not yet passed Watkinss tests.

title: Brian McCanns Three-Run Homer in 12th Helps Yankees Walk Off With a Victory
description: No fireworks show was planned at Yankee Stadium this weekend, so Brian McCann and Mark Teixeira provided their own.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: So many people are leaving you cant even find suitcases.

title: Corrections: July 4, 2015
description: NEW YORK

title: Mets Noah Syndergaard Stares Down Clayton Kershaw and the Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES  Noah Syndergaard took the moundFridayfor his 10th career start, facing Clayton Kershaw, arguably the best pitcher in baseball, and a Dodgers lineup featuring five former All-Stars, in front of more than 50,000 fans at historic Dodgers Stadium. And just before his first pitch, he took a breath so deep his cheeks puffed out like a blowfish.

title: Afghan Forces Battle Taliban as Lawmakers Reject Defense Minister
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan security forces battling the Taliban about 30 miles west of Kabul have sustained heavy casualties, officials said Saturday, as senior members of the government criticized the response to the assault as slow and ineffective.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from the steps of the U.S. Capitol to a brutal, centuries-old competition in Florence, Italy.

title: Perks at Smaller Hotels Mimic Luxury Brands
description: Luxury hotels arent the only ones with free attractive amenities. More wallet-friendly properties are also giving their guests some freebies.

title: Grateful Dead Fare Thee Well Tour Gets Down to the Music
description: CHICAGOFriday night was the beginning of the end: the first of the Grateful Deads final three concerts at Soldier Field, for 70,764 people here and untold numbers more at theater simulcasts, pay-per-view web streams and the free concert replay immediately after the show by WXRT. Even with a handful of the Deads inevitable stumbles, the music was strong.

title: The Inevitable, Indispensable Property Tax
description: If youre a homeowner, you probably dont like paying property taxes. But economists like property taxes for the same reason taxpayers hate them: Theyre hard to avoid.

title: Syria Forces and Hezbollah Attack Insurgents Near Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces and their allies in the Lebanese Shiite group Hezbollah started a new offensive Saturday against insurgents in Zabadani, a mountain town near the border with Lebanon that was one of the first to be wrested by rebels four years ago.

title: China Moves to Stabilize Stock Markets; Initial Offerings Halted
