description: Greeks delivered a rebuff to Europes leaders, rejecting a deal offered by the countrys creditors.

title: Screen Addiction Is Taking a Toll on Children
description: Excessive use of computer games among young people in China appears to be taking an alarming turn and may have particular relevance for American parents whose children spend many hours a day focused on electronic screens. The documentary Web Junkie, to be shown next Monday on PBS, highlights the tragic effects on teenagers who become hooked on video games, playing for dozens of hours at a time often without breaks to eat, sleep or even use the bathroom. Many come to view the real world as fake.

title: New York Today: Back to Reality
description: Good morning on this fair Monday.

title: Metrosophy: Philosophy and the City
description: Where is philosophy? This is not a typo. What is philosophy is a common question. But rarely do we wonder where it is, physically speaking. Imagine a philosopher at work. Where does this scene take place?

title: Today in Politics: Gaps Remain as Deadline Nears on Iran Deal
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where candidates are recovering from a working weekend of holiday parades and rope lines. Financial disclosures continue to trickle in amid a focus on outside fund-raising groups, but the trail gives way this week to Vienna, where negotiators report progress but also great distance over crucial elements of a deal to curtail Irans nuclear program.

title: Greek Exit Isnt Automatic, France Says
description: The French finance minister, Michel Sapin, said on Monday that negotiations now depended on Greece, and that the countrys exit from the eurozone was not guaranteed.

title: Paying People to Be Healthy Usually Works, if the Public Can Stomach It
description: Few people seem comfortable with the idea of paying patients to do what we want them to do.

title: Grocery Delivery Service Instacart Adds Zabars
description: Instacart, the Web service that employs personal shoppers to fulfill grocery orders, has added Zabars to its growing list of partners. The Upper West Side specialty food store has been available to subscribers in Instacarts Upper Manhattan delivery zone on a limited basis, in beta mode, for several weeks. On Monday the partnership was made official, though delivery will remain uptown for now.

title: How to Undo the Damage in Greece
description: ATHENS  Today Greece faces calamity. Banks have been closed for more than a week and the economy is deteriorating at an accelerating rate. Citizens and businesses cant easily carry on with their normal lives; the tourism industry is plagued by cancellations; companies are postponing paying their workers. Yet the infusion of cash from the European Central Bank that is desperately needed to resuscitate the Greek banking system and jump-start the economy is missing. It will arrive only after Greeks and their lenders come to a final agreement on the details of a new assistance program.

title: What It Means to Be Single
Schiaparelli: Fall 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: Morning Agenda: Greece Votes No
description: GREECE VOTES NO |  Greeks celebrated Sunday night as the results of the referendum on the now-defunct bailout offer showed that more than 60 percent of voters rejected the European creditors terms,  Suzanne Daley of The New York Times writes. The rest of the world was wary, unsure of what came next, but no panic was seen in the markets. Stocks in Asia and Europe fell on Monday, as did the euro, but the losses were moderate,  Keith Bradsher and David Jolly write in The New York Times. The yield on Spanish, Italian and Portuguese bonds rose, but, as  Mr. Jolly noted in a tweet, there was no blowout.

title: Concacaf Details Plans for Reforms After Scandal
description: For those who have followed the recent corruption allegations lingering over global soccer, it most likely required little more than a glance at the list of officials implicated in the United States Justice Departments investigation to notice a pattern: Most of the executives have, or had, connections to Concacaf, the regional governing body that oversees soccer in North America, Central America and the Caribbean.

title: Will the Burqa Be Banned in Berlin?
description: BERLIN  IN the last few weeks, many Germans have come to know a young Muslim blogger in Berlin named Betul Ulusoy. Having obtained a law degree, Ms. Ulusoy applied for several jobs in Berlins city administration as a trainee, and was hired for a post in the city district of Neuklln.

title: From the Archives: Dalai Lamas Accession to Throne and Flight to India
description: As the Dalai Lama celebrates his 80th birthday on Monday, here is a look at how The New York Times covered his early years as the spiritual leader of Tibet, a time whenrare glimpses into the Himalayan territorys politics came mostly from radio broadcasts from India andafewtravelers and missionaries from war-torn China.

title: The Scale of Things (Personal and Trivial)
description: On Friday I drove from Vermont to New York, but as usual avoided driving into Manhattan  I parked at Secaucus Junction, a quick train ride in and a good jumping-off point for the drive to Princeton today.

title: ComiXology Expands Digital Library With French Titles
description: ComiXology, an online streaming service for the comic book industry, will be expanding its international digital library. The company announced a partnership on Monday with Delcourt Group, the largest independent comic book publisher in France. The deal will make available for purchase English-language versions of more than 150 French series and graphic novels. (In France, comics are called bandes dessines  drawn strips.) Three monthly series will have their premiere on Monday: Promethe, a science fiction tale about strange phenomena that occurs daily for 13 days at 1:13 p.m.; Spin Angels, about a special-ops group with ties to the Roman Catholic Church; and The Curse of the Wendigo, about opposing soldiers during World War I who must temporarily unite against an evil creature. Prices for the Delcourt Group titles begin at $2.99 for stand-alone issues.

title: Q. and A.: Xie Shi on the Brotherhood of Skateboarding in Chinas Far West
description: In the ethnically mixed region of Xinjiang, in Chinas far west, tensions run high, and the government-promoted slogan that Uighurs and Han are all one family is not embraced by everyone.

title: Daily Report: Getting to Buy, With a Button on Mobile
description: Denise Chapman, a director at a San Diego advertising agency, is afraid to count how many hours of each day she spends on her mobile phone, browsing for clothes or gifts. But when it comes time to actually buy something, instead of using her iPhone, she fires up an aging Dell computer that sits on a desk in her familys kitchen.

title: Scattered Notes on the Euro
description: Wolfgang Munchau has a perceptive analysis of the utter disaster of the Yes campaign in Greece, in which he says

title: Friendly Reminder: Were On Partial Hiatus Until Aug. 3
description: For the next four weeks, well be working busily behind the scenes, tweaking old features and inventing new ones, to get ready for the 2015-16 school year.

title: Delusions of Control
description: David Keohane has an informative post on the China stock crash, which is among other things revealing that the Chinese government has much less ability to control events than legend has it. And that brings back memories.

title: Times Critics Guide: What to Do This Week
description: Need to break out of a cultural rut?

title: 1940: Children Come From England
description: Seventy-one calm and self-contained Britain children arrived here yesterday afternoon aboard the Cunard White Star liner Scythia, bringing with them cricket bats, governesses, flannel shorts and a restrained curiosity about that unbelievable place, America. They were the first large group of thousands of English children who will be brought to Canada and the United States for the duration of the war. The children in this group were not refugees in the grimmer sense of the word. Almost all of them were sons and daughters of well-to-do English families and were on their way to the homes of friends or relatives in this country.  New York Herald Tribune, July 7, 1940

title: Lone Star Bailout
description: Jared Bernstein weighs in on the big No, hopes that it leads to a change in Europes approach, but acknowledges the political difficulties:

title: Leaving Salt in the Shaker
description: Q. If I stop adding salt to my food and consume only what is already in it, would there be negative effects?

title: Conviction of Former Goldman Sachs Programmer Is Overturned
description: Kevin H. Marino pumped his fist in the air in celebration. Then Mr. Marino, a New Jersey lawyer with a linebackers build, turned to his longtime client, Sergey Aleynikov, and gave Mr. Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, a bear hug and a hearty pat on the back.

title: Euro Sign in Frankfurt Is Dismantled
description: Workers in Frankfurt on Monday dismantled the statue in front of the former headquarters of the European Central Bank  not as a reaction to the Greek referendum, but to polish it.

title: 1965: Place a Man Can Call His Own
description: JOHNSON CITY, Texas  When Lyndon B. Johnson goes boating in Texas it is on Lake Lyndon B. Johnson. Lake Lyndon B. Johnson is 35 miles north of the LBJ Ranch, which is 15 miles east of Johnson City, which has a big sign at its town limits which says Johnson City, home of Lyndon B. Johnson. Its young people attend Lyndon B. Johnson High School. All these names have led some Texas critics of the president to joke that the state is in a process of being monogrammed. There was, in fact, a movement afoot down here recently to rename the presidents alma mater, Southwest Texas State College, as Lyndon B. Johnson College.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 7, 1965

title: Pope Francis Focuses on Family in Ecuador Mass
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador  Standing above a huge dirt field engulfed by hundreds of thousands of followers, Pope Francis on Monday used the first full day of his Latin American trip to ruminate on the anguish and joy of family life, alluding to the broader debate among many Catholic prelates about whether church teachings should be changed regarding gay people and the divorced.

title: Bruno Frisonis Paris Short List: Where to Sit, Eat, Drink and Party
description: Roger Viviers creative director Bruno Frisoni, who presented the labels architectural and buckle-heavy footwear for fall earlier this year in Paris (shoes were hanging from the chandelier!), returns to the City of Light on Tuesday to showhis couture designs for the same season. If you like fashion, its simply the best for your eyes, he says about couture week.

title: Both Sides of Sunset
description: Contributors to Both Sides of Sunset, a new photography book that captures Los Angeles in all its gritty grandeur, explain why their images encapsulate the magic of the city.

title: Serena and Venus Williams Are Siblings Forever, but Rivals for Not Much Longer
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Time! the chair umpire kept saying on Monday, the customary reminder to resume play after a changeover.

title: U.S. Team Reacts After World Cup Win
description: The U.S. womens soccer team spoke on Sunday after defeating Japan 5-2 to win their first World Cup championship since 1999.

title: New York City Takes Steps to Increase the Safety of Employees at Homeless Shelters
description: The huge, turreted castle that looms over Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn is the first stopover for many of New York Citys homeless men. Some call it Castle Grayskull after the forbidding fortress in the Masters of the Universe stories.

title: Scenes of Pope Francis in Ecuador
description: Pope Francis spoke in Quito, Ecuador, on Sunday after arriving for an eight-day tour of South America that will take him to some of the poorest countries of his home continent.

title: G.O.P. Sees Opportunity in Harry Reids Nevada Senate Seat
description: The race to replace Senator Harry Reid in Nevada is getting serious with the announcement on Monday that Representative Joe Heck will look to flip the seat to the Republican side.

title: An Ode to Runny Eggs
description: This week Martha Rose Shulman celebrates a classic recipe  Egg-in-a-Hole.

title: Lawyer Comments on Bloggers Release
description: Alfred Dodwell, a lawyer for the Singaporean blogger Amos Yee, spoke on Monday as Mr. Yee was released after four weeks in detention for criticizing Lee Kuan Yew on YouTube.

title: Boko Harams Civilian Attacks in Nigeria Intensify
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The violent campaign by the Boko Haram militant group against Nigerian civilians appeared to intensify late on Sunday with two deadly attacks in Jos, a city in central Nigeria, underscoring the challenge the countrys new president faces in trying to suppress the group.

title: Chris Christie Accuses Rand Paul of Politicizing National Security
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has kicked off his presidential campaign with some harsh words for Senator Rand Paul, his Republican rival for the nomination.

title: Keeping Blood Pressure Low in Those Under 50
description: Higher blood pressure in young adulthood increases the risk for coronary heart disease, a new study found.

title: With Subtle Signals, Supreme Court Justices Request the Cases They Want to Hear
description: WASHINGTON  Supreme Court justices like to say that they have no agenda. Cases come to them unbidden. They decide the ones that need deciding.

title: The Scene
description: Atelier Versace at Paris Couture Week.

title: Photo Diary: Atelier Versace Fall/Winter 2015 Couture
description: Scenes from Paris Couture Week, captured by Schohaja.

title: Ruling on Ex-Goldman Programmer
description: A court has again overturned the conviction of Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer charged with stealing computer code for high-speed trading.

title: Rory McIlroy Is Hurt Playing Soccer and May Miss British Open
description: The highly anticipated showdown between Rory McIlroy and Jordan Spieth at next weeks British Open is in doubt after McIlroy injured his left ankle over the weekend while playing soccer.

title: The Scene
description: Schiaparelli at Paris Couture Week.

title: Photo Diary: Schiaparelli Fall/Winter 2015 Couture
description: Scenes from Paris Couture Week, captured by Sarah Aubel.

title: An Innovative Library Lifts the Fortunes of a Chinese Town
description: JIAOJIEHE, China  Nestled among the shimmering chestnut, walnut and peach trees of a deep valley surrounded by craggy hills, the tiny village of Jiaojiehe suffers from being close to the nations capital. The young flee easily to the big city, leaving the elderly behind, lonely and poor.

title: Cherry Bombes Claudia Wu and Her Trusty Ice-Cream Maker
description: When Claudia Wu wants to make ice cream, she retreats to her closet. There she pours chilled custard into a machine wedged between a laundry bin and a pair of vintage Ferragamo boots.

title: The Problem With Change
description: This weeks puzzle is an original suggested by LAN, a regular Numberplay contributor who in his non-Numberplay life applies computational and statistical approaches to problems in science and academia.

title: Ava DuVernay Wont Direct Marvels Black Panther Film
description: With a nod to the Fourth of July, Ava DuVernay announced over the long weekend that she would not be directing the action film Black Panther, telling Essence magazine: I guess Ill declare my independence from this rumor.

title: Versace, Dior and the Reality Gap
description: PARIS  As couture week dawned on Sunday, Greek citizens went to the polls for their austerity referendum and the fashion flock drove off to Asnires-sur-Seine, a suburb of Paris, for a garden party celebrating the opening of Louis Vuittons La Galerie. It made for a strange, bifurcated reality.

title: Chinese Stocks Still Look Overvalued
description: For all the Chinese authorities increasingly overt meddling in the market, Chinese shares are still looking expensive. Even after the countrys main market indexes plunged roughly 30 percent in three weeks, on any fundamental analysis, they have further to fall.

title: Alison Mosshart of the Kills Makes Jarring Paintings
description: There was something grotesque if not downright alarming about the portraits on the wall. Strangers encountered during concert tours, they glared glassy-eyed from the canvas, grinning with stained teeth as crumbly and neglected as a tumbledown fence.

title: Even as Museum Piece, Confederate Flag Is in Dispute
description: RICHMOND, Va.  One floor below street level in the Museum of the Confederacy here, at the end of a cinder-block hallway behind two sets of locked double doors, a climate-controlled vault contains the worlds largest collection of some of the most revered and reviled objects in American history: Confederate-era flags.

title: Eric Holder Returns to Covington & Burling
description: After stepping down as United States attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr.s return to private practice will be to a familiar place.

title: Summery Rice Noodles With Coconut Milk, Curry and Shrimp
description: Summer cooking at its best is a streamlined affair. Nothing too complicated. A sliced melon or a chilled tomato soup. Something tasty on the grill, like a steak for slicing, some sausages or some vegetable kebabs. Or a giant colorful salad. The goal is a meal that is light, bright, refreshing and restorative.

title: South Carolinas Senators Take Step to Remove the Confederate Flag
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  With protesters outside and the desk of a slain member draped in black, the South Carolina Senate voted overwhelmingly on Monday to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House.

title: Boys in Pink
description: The seasons mens wear shows a softer side.

title: Review: Reaching Down the Rabbit Hole
description: An extraterrestrial dropping into a modern-day hospital might be forgiven for thinking it was run by machines.

title: Damon Albarn Concert in Denmark Ends Abruptly When a Security Guard Carries Him Offstage
description: Damon Albarn, the frontman for Blur, was carried away from a concert at the Roskilde Festival in Denmark early Sunday morning after playing a set that lasted for five hours and then refusing to leave the stage.

title: Grapes of Wrath
description: OK, is Eric Asimov doing international finance now (and scooping the rest of us, too)? His wine of the month is from the Greek island of Santorini, which is the remnant of a bigger island destroyed by a huge volcanic explosion. This explosion seems to have played a central role in the collapse of Minoan civilization, and may have given rise to the legend of Atlantis.

title: Craft Atlantic Puts Modesty on Display, With Surprises
description: The re-emphasis on basics in mens wear over the last couple of years has often felt like the culmination of some elaborate prank. We may be in the middle of fashion season, when designers put their most elaborate fantasies on the runways, but for every designer who traffics in excess and drama and challenge, there are several who prefer their vision tunneled, and basic.

title: Review: No Song Left Unsung, Grateful Dead Plays Its Last
description: CHICAGO  The last song the Grateful Dead performed here on Sunday night at Soldier Field  the bands farewell, 50 years after it was founded  was Attics of My Life. Its a close-harmony song of thankfulness to a soul, a muse, perhaps an audience. It professes, I have spent my life/ Seeking all thats still unsung and concludes, When there was no dream of mine/ You dreamed of me.

title: Review: Aziz Ansaris Modern Romance Explores Dating in the Digital Age
description: Everyone with a cellphone and a romantic life knows how swiftly and viciously the phone can turn against you. One minute, its a blameless communication device; the next, its a toxic incubator of second-guessing and self-loathing. You think youre a reasonable person; suddenly, youre obsessing over how to respond properly to a 2 a.m. text from a crush whose only communication after three days of silence reads, in its entirety, wsup.

title: Why the Greeks Said No to Bailout Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael B. Orens Ally: My Journey Across the American-Israeli Divide
description: When Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited Washington in July 2010, he met with representatives of the National Jewish Democratic Council and the Republican Jewish Coalition at Blair House. After the two delegations quietly entered the dimly lit brocaded dining room, they sat down at a large elliptical table, the Democrats to Netanyahus left and the Republicans to his right. But the calm was shattered as the Democrats and Republicans began shouting at each other and pounding the table until they were told to cool it. The chastised representatives fell silent and finally acknowledged Netanyahus presence, but their near brawl demonstrated that Washingtons political schizophrenia also split American Jews  or so the former Israeli ambassador to the United States and current Knesset member Michael B. Oren reports in his remarkably frank new memoir, Ally.

title: Theyve Said Too Much
description: Mom, is a memoir true?

title: Arms Embargo Takes on Larger Meaning as Iran Nuclear Talks Enter Endgame
description: VIENNA  With foreign ministers from around the world arriving here in hopes that the negotiations over Irans nuclear program are entering their final hours, a senior Iranian official said on Monday that Tehran was demanding that all United Nations sanctions against his country  including the ban on the import or export of conventional arms  be lifted as part of any deal.

title: The Making Of
description: A behind-the-scenes look at Mansur Gavriels window installation at Colette.

title: Hillary Clintons Team Is Wary as Bernie Sanders Finds Footing in Iowa
description: The ample crowds and unexpectedly strong showing garnered by Senator Bernie Sanders are setting off worry among advisers and allies of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who believe the Vermont senator could overtake her in Iowa polls by the fall and even defeat her in the nations first nominating contest there.

title: The Snow Buildup  and Meltdown
description: Sara Norrman, the team operations manager at Oasys Water Inc. in Boston, photographed the rise and fall of the snow farm across the street from her office.

title: Remnant of Bostons Brutal Winter Threatens to Outlast Summer
description: BOSTON  Now that it is July, it is easy to think of Bostons record snowfall last winter as a bad dream.

title: Angela Merkel Faces Monumental Test of Leadership After Greek Vote
description: BERLIN  As chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel leads a nation that prizes fiscal rectitude and adherence to the rules, and, after pledging tens of billions in bailout programs for five years, has expressed scant sympathy for Greeces demand for more financial help.

title: From the Farmers Market to the Freezer
description: When the Manhattan chef Marc Meyer opened Rosies in the East Village in April, reports focused on the Mexican restaurants upscale tortilla-making station in the middle of the dining room.

title: Freezing Food: Tips From Chefs
description: Invest in a vacuum sealer, which removes air from special freezer bags to prevent freezer burn and keeps food tasting fresher for longer. It also saves space.

title: About Last Night
description: A photo diary of Miu Mius party to celebrate its new fragrance (and recent resort collection) on Saturday night.

title: Shark Week Gets Real
description: Shark Week is trying to shape up. The famous Discovery Channel extravaganza, criticized by scientists in the past, will be more science-focused than in previous years, according to N.P.R.

title: Nonprofit Group Tied to Marco Rubio Raises Millions While Shielding Donors
description: A tax-exempt group formed by allies of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said on Monday that it was preparing to spend upward of $20 million on issue advertising, money whose source the group is not required to disclose.

title: South Carolina Lawmakers on the Confederate Flag
description: Selected remarks by state senators engaged in Mondays discussion continue to reflect deep divisions.

title: Mystery of the Lizards That Know the Way Home
description: Call it the case of the homing lizards.

title: The Making of the Largest Mansur Gavriel Bag Standing
description: In the annals of It bags with epic wait lists, theres the iconic (the Birkin) and the more emergent, like the Bucket Bag from Mansur Gavriel, the accessories label launched by the designer friends Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel in 2013. The duos short-order success instantly caught the attention of the fashion worlds most discerning members and saw them bestowed with the Swarovski Award for Accessory Design at the 2015 CFDA Fashion Awards last month. Beginning today, they introduce a new collaboration with Colette  a limited-edition of their bestselling Bucket Bag in pony-hair saffiano leather and iridescent blue, the Parisian concept stores iconic color, handmade in the Italian region of Veneto  with a special window installation featuring an oversized Bucket Bag crafted entirely from paper and brimming with large, red graphic representations of anemone flowers.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 534 sub
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 534 sub

title: Reddits Chief Apologizes After Employees Dismissal
description: After widespread user outrage over an abrupt employee dismissal at Reddit last week, Ellen Pao, chief executive of the online message board, apologized to the sites members for what she characterized as a history of broken promises and poor communication.

title: Merkel and Hollande Comment on Greece
description: In a joint appearance, the German chancellor Angela Merkel and the French president Franois Hollande said they respected the results of the Greek referendum.

title: For Europes Sake, Keep Greece in the Eurozone
description: The resounding victory for the no vote in Greeces referendum has left European leaders like Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany with a stark and clear choice. Only they have the power to decide what happens next  whether to shove Greece out of the eurozone or offer some path forward for the Greek economy, starting by writing down its huge and unpayable debts.

title: The Scene
description: Christian Dior at Paris Couture Week.

title: Swearing. Smashing. Fines. Boos. Hugs. Richard Gasquet-Nick Kyrgios Match Has It All.
description: WIMBLEDON, England  With rackets flying and crashing into bits, swear words screeching out, and players hugging each other and ball boys, too, it was difficult to pinpoint the exact nature of the match between Nick Kyrgios and Richard Gasquet, other than to say it was lively.

title: The Universal Uniform
description: The polo shirt has found favor with everyone from Wimbledon champions to British punks.

title: Photo Diary: Christian Dior Fall/Winter 2015 Couture
description: Scenes from Paris Couture Week, captured by Schohaja.

title: How to Make Sense of Chinas Plummeting Stock Market
description: While the eyes of the world have been on the crisis in Greece, China, a country with 123 times its population, has faced financial troubles of its own. A free fall in the Chinese stock market could threaten the prosperity of the worlds second-largest economy and have long-term effects of its own.

title: 8 Ways Pope Francis Is Changing the Direction of the Catholic Church
description: Francis has differed significantly from his predecessors with his outspoken style and his approach to leading the church. Here is a look at some of his comments on poverty, church reform, climate change and divorce.

title: Guide to Chinas Market Turmoil
description: The Chinese stock market rout has prompted the countrys government to act aggressively to stop the slide.

title: Cakes, Fools and Fruit Puddings
description: Inspired by Womans Institute Library of Cookery, published by International Textbook Company, Scranton, Pa., 1929.

title: Helping Prisoners Voices Be Heard By Their Children
description: Im not even going to say goodbye. I dont want her to freak out, I called to my husband as I gathered my bags and kissed my 5-year-old son on the head. My 16-month-old daughter Darcy would certainly demand release from her highchair captivity if I revealed myself. But after my husband reminded me that I would be gone all day  a goodbye was necessary  I risked it. She fussed; I left anyway.

title: Giambattista Valli: Fall 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: With its First Sneaker, Adieu Toughens Up the Classic PF Flyer
description: For its first sneaker collection, Adieu  the Parisian shoe company known for its unisex creeper and Chelsea boot styles inspired by the British Teddy-Boy and punk scenes  looks with nostalgia across the Atlantic: to America in the 1960s, when practically every boy wore PF Flyers. Inspired by that timeless shoe  immortalized in the millennial-favorite 1993 film The Sandlot, about a group of scrappy suburban boys playing baseball in the summer of 1962  the Adieu Walk Over sneaker toughens up the PF Flyers classic shape with a chunkier sole and more pronounced notches.

title: Reaching Pluto, and the End of an Era of Planetary Exploration
description: When I was a kid, before I wanted to be Einstein and before I wanted to play second base for the Yankees, I wanted to be a cowboy. Specifically, I wanted to ride a horse over the hills and mountains of the West that we always passed by on car trips and see what was on the other side.

title: Fast and Light to Pluto
description: On July 14, 2015, the New Horizons spacecraft will zip past Pluto and its five known moons. Nobody really knows what it will find.

title: Almost Time for Plutos Close-Up
description: The pictures coming back from Pluto are still a bit fuzzy. But just wait.

title: Unesco Remembers the Alamo
description: The Alamo has received the sought-after designation of being a world heritage site from the United Nations cultural body, Unesco.

title: Review: Seven Year Switch Re-Pairs Couples for Marriage Repair
description: FYI, the network formerly known as the Biography Channel, has lately become laser-focused on couples who meet cute or strange. Since its rebranding last year, its offered Married at First Sight, in which experts pair couples who first meet at the altar, and are then documented in their early weeks of marriage; the docu-series Arranged, about arranged marriages in various cultures; and Find My First Love, in which a lovelorn woman consents to be dragged to unlikely places to reconnect with the one that got away.

title: Broadway Box Office Feels the Fizzle on Fourth of July Weekend
description: There were few fireworks for several Broadway shows over the Fourth of July week, according to box office data released on Monday.

title: Womens World Cup Final Was Most-Watched Soccer Game in United States History
description: The United States 5-2 victory over Japan in the Womens World Cup final on Sunday was seen by 25.4 million viewers on Fox  a record for any soccer game, mens or womens, shown on English-language television in this country.

title: Condiments Galore at New Yorks Fancy Food Show
description: Condiments, notably those that are Asian and fueled with searing heat, continue to ride high in the specialty food business, as showcased at last weeks Fancy Food Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York. Some newcomers in the category included charred sriracha from Nathan Meshberg and Jessica Fox of Ft. Greene Farms; a hot chile and a milder lime leaf sambal from Auria Abraham of Aurias Malaysian Kitchen; and sriracha tweaked to make a hot sauce called Veracha, from Kevin Powell of True Made Foods. There were new imports of gochujang, the thick, spicy Korean sauce. And ketchup was not left in the dust; several came with gochujang and sriracha profiles. Popcorn, especially with smaller kernels like Pipcorn, and variations on corn nuts were also a big presence: Specialty Food Association, specialtyfood.com.

title: Shopping for Homegrown Wares in Zagreb
description: Croatias capital isnt typically thought of as a shoppers paradise, but the Lower Town of Zagreb is a favorite destination of in-the-know locals.

title: When the President Decided to Sing Amazing Grace
description: President Obamas decision to sing Amazing Grace at the end of his eulogy for the Rev. Clementa Pinckney, a black pastor who was killed with eight others during Bible study in a Charleston, S.C., church last month, became one of the more memorable moments of his second term. But the idea raised at least some eyebrows when he first broached it with his closest confidants.

title: Sparse Schedule for Obama as He Awaits News on Iran Talks
description: Take a glance at President Obamas public schedule for the next few days, and it may appear the leader of the free world is indulging in a week of summer vacation.

title: Jeb Bush Dines With Mitt Romney in Maine
description: Mitt Romneys seemingly nonstop hospitality tour of the 2016 presidential field took him to Maine on Monday.

title: Stephen Cutler, JPMorgans General Counsel, to Become Vice Chairman
description: After helping JPMorgan Chase negotiate multiple billion-dollar settlements with regulators, the banks general counsel, Stephen M. Cutler, is taking on a new job as vice chairman.

title: A White House Invitation for Senate Democrats
description: The White House evidently wants to get on the same page as Senate Democrats as lawmakers return for July. The Obama administration has invited all Senate Democrats to visit after casting votes Tuesday evening.

title: Google to Test Carpooling Service in Israel
description: Google said on Monday that it would start testing a carpooling service in Tel Aviv through Waze, the Israeli social mapping start-up that the company bought in 2013 for $1 billion.

title: Texas Scientist With a Thing for Longhorns
description: Deep in the heart of Texas, cows with fearsome horns are everywhere  on bumper stickers and T-shirts, on the signs of auto dealerships and chain restaurants, grazing in broad pastures. The ubiquitousness of the longhorn, a symbol of the state and its flagship universitys mascot, might lead one to wonder: How did this animal get horns that can exceed seven feet across?

title: Brooklyn Apartment Fire Leaves One Man Dead and Another Injured
description: With fire raging just outside their bedrooms and blocking their escape, two men stood at the windows of a third-floor apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, early on Monday, contemplating the distance to the pavement.

title: Chinese Investors Who Borrowed Are Hit Hard by Market Turn
description: SHANGHAI  With his stock market riches, Gong Yifeng bought a riverfront apartment here for his son and daughter-in-law. He can eat well and travel abroad. He can also afford to pay for his granddaughters education.

title: Study Shows Diseases Like Plague Can Perilously Evolve
description: Contrary to what was previously believed, the bacterium responsible for the Black Death probably caused small outbreaks of lung disease for many years before it evolved its better-known bubonic form, according to a new genetic study.

title: A Trip Into Miu Mius Wild Parisian Night Club
description: When it came time to launch her debut fragrance for Miu Miu, Miuccia Prada looked to Parisian nightlife, and places like Les Folies Bergres and the jazz bars of Montmartre. So it came as no surprise that the launch party for the new scent, held in Paris Palais dIna on Saturday night, felt like a trip into an especially fashionable (and sweet-smelling) Parisian mega-club. The space (where Miu Miu regularly holds its shows) was transformed with neon signs and white banquettes, and editors and celebrities including Kate Moss, Dianna Agron and Maggie Gyllenhaal sat at bottle-service tables watching Miu Mius 2016 resort collection come down the runway. The collection reflected the rooms clubby feel, with an eclectic mix of prints and silhouettes from past Miu Miu collections (kitty-cat prints, anyone?) updated in a new way.

title: 6 maneras en las que el Papa Francisco ha cambiado el curso de la Iglesia
description: Seis artculos reflejan las prioridades del papa desde que fue electo.

title: The Forgotten Man Behind William Carlos Williamss Red Wheelbarrow
description: For decades, much has depended on his red wheelbarrow, streaked with rain, next to some white chickens, even if no one has known  or perhaps even wondered  exactly who he was.

description: Giambattista Valli at Paris Couture Week.

description: Scenes from Paris Couture Week, captured by Sarah Aubel.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Next Up for the Womens World Cup Champions: Some Tough Choices
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  From the day she became the coach of the United States womens national team in 2014, Jill Ellis has told her players, We cant sit still. A team that sits still, she said, will get run over.

title: South Carolina Debates Confederate Flag
description: The South Carolina Senate voted Monday to remove the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House.

title: Forget What I Said. That Scott Walker Call? Never Happened
description: Last Wednesday, Stephen Moore, a scholar at the Heritage Foundation who is an outspoken supporter of an immigration overhaul, described a recent telephone call with Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, in which he said Mr. Walker had assured him he had not completely renounced his earlier support for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
description: United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Hillary Clinton Chides Israel Boycott Effort in Letter to Supporters
description: In a letter to prominent Jewish leaders, Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed her alarm over calls to boycott Israeli products to push Israel to improve its dealings with the Palestinians.

title: July 6, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from United States, Spain, Nepal and Bolivia.

title: Goldman Restructures Its Activism Defense Team
description: Goldman Sachs has reshaped its activism defense practice, days after the senior banker who led the team, William Anderson, defected to the boutique investment bank Evercore Partners.

title: Why a Meaningful Boost for Those at the Bottom Requires Help From the Top
description: Just about every high-profile politician in the country today says income inequality is a problem. And while those from the center-left to the far right differ on how they would reduce inequality, they tend to agree on one thing: We can do it without affecting the rich.

title: Obama Says ISIS Can Be Defeated
description: In remarks made during a visit to the Pentagon on Monday, President Obama said that despite recent gains by ISIS, it can be pushed back, but the process will not be quick.

title: John Weinberg, Scion of Goldman, Is Retiring
description: John S. Weinberg, a banker whose father and grandfather led Goldman Sachs for decades, is retiring after his own 32-year career at the firm.

title: Strangers No More in An Adopted Family
description: Stranger Than Family is Matthew Avignones take on growing up in a family of adopted children in a small Midwest town.

title: Threat of Pay Clawbacks May Be as Powerful as Recoveries
description: One of the challenges after the financial crisis has been figuring out how to hold corporate officials accountable when their companies engage in risky activities and even misconduct. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Bank of England have taken steps to ratchet up the cost to executives by aiming at an area they are likely to notice: their wallets.

title: Pluto, From Ninth Planet to Dwarf Planet
description: When Pluto was the ninth planet, and when it became a dwarf planet.

title: March 30, 1930: Pluto Is Discovered
description: On the front page on March 14, 1930, The New York Times announced, with a flourish, the discovery of Pluto: In the little cluster of orbs which scampers across the sidereal abyss under the name of the solar system there are, be it known, nine instead of a mere eight, worlds.

title: Orson Welless Last Film Hits a Bump in Production, but Project Continues
description: LOS ANGELES  The producers behind an effort to finish The Other Side of the Wind, the incomplete final film of Orson Welles, are moving on to Plan C after coming up short on an Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign.

title: Bloombergs Granddaughter Gets a Hybrid Surname
description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is known for affixing his name to concert halls, corporate towers, glossy magazines and computer terminals, ensuring that his surname will endure for generations.

title: Review: John Zorn Brings Avant-Garde Style to the Stone
description: While in French and German, bagatelle means a trifle, when Beethoven titled three published volumes of solo piano pieces bagatelles he was being rather coy. The word suggests that these were little diversions. But many of them, however short, are amazing pieces, especially the cosmic, quirky, deceptively beguiling ones he wrote during his late years.

title: Montpellier Danse Offers Globe-Trotting Via Choreography
description: MONTPELLIER, France  Oh, youre in town for the festival, said a shop assistant, proceeding to detail favorite dance shows seen over the years. There are other festivals here in the summer, but Montpellier Danse is the festival in this city of winding medieval passages and centuries-old buildings in the Languedoc-Roussillon region of southern France.

title: Review: Legacy, an Uneasy Comedy of Morals at Williamstown Festival
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Lifetime movies and Philip Roth dont usually pop up in the same frame of reference. Yet its hard to avoid thinking of both those sudsy topical television films and the author of Portnoys Complaint as you watch Legacy, Daniel Goldfarbs uneasy comedy of morals at the Williamstown Theater Festival here.

title: Carly Fiorina Reports Raising $1.4 Million for Campaign
description: Carly Fiorinas presidential campaign said on Monday that she raised more than $1.4 million since she announced her bid for the White House two months ago.

title: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Ecuador
description: The pope spoke in Guayaquil, Ecuador, during an eight-day tour of South America that will take him to some of the poorest countries of his home continent

title: As Israelis Are Tried in a Palestinians Murder, Agonizing Intimacy in Court
description: JERUSALEM  The slightly plump Israeli teenager on the witness stand insisted that he had not known the plan was to kill, and had never dreamed it would end that way.

title: Sheryl Sandberg Joins SurveyMonkeys Board
description: Sheryl Sandberg is taking a seat on the board of SurveyMonkey, her late husbands online survey and polling company.

title: For Start-Ups, How Many Angels Is Too Many?
description: Shortly after presenting her start-up to potential investors at a conference, Nancy Hua was bombarded by eager suitors. A little more than 48 hours later, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur had amassed about $2 million from wealthy individuals known as angel investors.

title: Global Poverty Drops Sharply, With China Making Big Strides, U.N. Report Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  Dire poverty has dropped sharply, and just as many girls as boys are now enrolled in primary schools around the world. Simple measures like installing bed nets have prevented some six million deaths from malaria. But nearly one billion people still defecate in the open, endangering the health of many others.

title: Silvercup StudiosIs Turning a Bronx Warehouse Into Its 3rd Production Complex
description: The borough known as the birthplace of hip-hop will soon be expanding its entertainment credentials.

title: Music Publishing Deal Driven by Shift From Sales to Streaming
description: In the latest change to the rapidly evolving business of music publishing, Sesac, a boutique rights group backed by private equity, has agreed to buy the Harry Fox Agency, a major clearinghouse of songwriting rights, the two groups plan to announce on Tuesday.

title: Greek No May Have Its Roots in Heroic Myths and Real Resistance
description: ATHENS  In the early 1800s, Greek fighters rebelled against their Ottoman overlord by blowing themselves up instead of submitting to captivity. In the mountains of Zalongo, by legend, women flung their children off a cliff and then danced off after them rather than be sold as slaves.

title: Burt Shavitz, Scruffy Face of Burts Bees, Dies at 80
description: Burt Shavitz, a rural beekeeper whose homespun marketing for natural personal care products transformed him from an unknown recluse into the familiar scruffy face of a line of balms that healed a million lips, died on Sunday in Bangor, Me. He was 80.

title: The Civil War Is Winding Down
description: The members of the South Carolina Senate began their business on Monday morning by bowing to pray. O God, and the pressures on this body today are considerable, the chaplain said. Strengthen them and fill their hearts with a determination to, as the psalmist puts it, to maintain justice and to do what is right.

title: Toll Rises as Saudi Coalition Steps Up Airstrikes in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  About a hundred people have been killed by airstrikes across Yemen in the past three days as warring parties have haggled over the terms of a humanitarian cease-fire, health workers and security officials said.

title: Pacific Trade Deal Negotiators See a Wrap in Late July
description: WASHINGTON  With a final accord in sight, the 12 nations negotiating a trans-Pacific trade agreement linking 40 percent of the global economy have set a last round of talks for late July on the remaining issues on the most ambitious trade deal in a generation.

title: A Wimbledon Cliffhanger Leaves Novak Djokovic Dangling
description: WIMBLEDON, England  A bid for a shocking upset at Wimbledon, or perhaps a remarkable recovery, was interrupted Monday when darkness interceded to produce a tennis cliffhanger.

title: New Trial Requested for Boston Marathon Bomber

title: Alex Rodriguez Is Passed Over for American League All-Star Bench
description: Alex Rodriguez, baseballs repentant soul and restored slugger, quipped recently that he would walk to Cincinnati if that were the requirement for him to get to the All-Star Game next week.

title: John A. Williams, 89, Dies; Underrated Novelist Wrote About Black Identity
description: John A. Williams, a writer whose exploration of black identity, notably in the 1967 novel The Man Who Cried I Am, established him as one of the bright lights in what he liked to call the second Harlem Renaissance, and who caused a furor with an unflattering biography of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Friday in a veterans home in Paramus, N.J. He was 89.

title: Gambling Board Gets a Single Casino Proposal After Reopening Bidding

description: UNITED NATIONS  For more than 50 years, the death of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations has been shrouded in mystery and a fair bit of conspiracy theory.

title: Iraqi Forces Plan Offensive to Retake Ramadi From ISIS

He was 77.

He did not pace or fret or review his game plan one last time. He had an unusual request for his coaches, though: He wanted to take some swings in the cage.

description: WASHINGTON  Sixty-six percent of states that elect prosecutors have no blacks in those offices, a new study has found, highlighting the lack of diversity in the ranks of those entrusted to bring criminal charges and negotiate prison sentences.

description: Youre stuck at the office working late, but your dog is stuck at home and getting pretty desperate to take care of some business of his own. What to do?

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN AMERICA (2003) With their entire lives packed into a groaning station wagon, Johnny (Paddy Considine), an Irish actor, and his wife, Sarah (Samantha Morton), enter the United States from Canada illegally and try to start over in a battered walk-up apartment in New York after the death of their young son. Djimon Hounsou is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS, who is befriended one Halloween by Johnny and Sarahs daughters. The director Jim Sheridan (My Left Foot) wrote this film with his two daughters, Naomi and Kirsten Sheridan. This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridans other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.

title: Womens Draw Presents Obstacles for Stars but Chances for Hopefuls
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Though the Wimbledon womens singles draw is intended to be as symmetrical as possible, the players in the top half have an obstacle-riddled road ahead that barely resembles the smoothly paved path the bottom half has become.

title: Jon Niese Throws a Gem as the Mets Blank the Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Chris Heston turned and watched the ball Ruben Tejada had just stroked into the outfield, and then Heston turned and watched Tejada round first base, as if he needed further confirmation about what he had just seen.

title: Corrections: July 7, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Strangers No More in An Adopted Family
description: When the Avignone brood goes out, people rubberneck at the sight of the older white couple with five Korean and Indian children. For a while, it bothered Matthew Avignone that he did not have a normal family  but who among us does? In his case, his parents adopted five children  four with special needs  creating a family by choice, not chance.

description: To the Editor:

Making Police Use of Chokeholds a Crime

title: As Yemen Collapses
description: Yemen has now been added to the United Nations list of most severe humanitarian emergencies, along with South Sudan, Syria and Iraq. It is a tragic distinction, highlighting the peril to 80 percent of the countrys 25 million citizens. The international community, including the United States, is not doing enough to push for an immediate cease-fire in the war that is ravaging the country to make it possible to deliver aid.

title: When Therapists Grieve
description: To the Editor:

title: The Courage of Small Things
description: I thought I knew the basic life story of my friend Clemantine Wamariya. She was born in Rwanda 27 years ago. When she was 6  though she didnt understand it  the genocide began and her world started shrinking. Her father stopped going to work after dark. Her family ate dinner with the lights off.

title: The Good Jobs Strategy
description: At the Aspen Ideas Festival  an annual summer gabfest that presents all sorts of interesting ideas, from the improbable to the important  one of the big themes this year was jobs. How will America close the skills gap? Where will the good middle-class jobs of the future come from? I heard pleas for infrastructure spending as a job strategy, and creating jobs by unleashing our energy resources. There were speakers who believed that innovation would bring good jobs, and speakers who feared that some of those innovations  in robotics, for instance  would destroy good jobs.

title: A Knockout Blow for American Fish Stocks
description: BOSTON  NEW ENGLAND has long been synonymous with cod fishing. Since the 1600s, cod have been central to the regions development, even giving Massachusetts famous cape its name. The fish were once so abundant, according to a local anecdote, that you could almost walk across the ocean on their backs.

title: Somali Militants Carry Out Deadly Attack in Northeast Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Shabab militants killed 14 people and wounded 11 in the northeastern Kenyan town of Mandera on Tuesday, a government official said, the latest attack in the region by the Somali Islamist group.

title: KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps, by Nikolaus Wachsmann
description: Of an estimated 2.3 million prisoners who entered the hell of the Nazi concentration camps, over 1.7 million were killed, whether gassed or worked to their skeletal ends. Many went straight to their deaths, including about 870,000 Jews murdered on arrival and without registration at Auschwitz; others endured a slower annihilation, reduced to what Hannah Arendt called ghastly marionettes with human faces. Millions more were killed in other ways, but there were also survivors, and at the end of KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps, his monumental study of the SS camps, Nikolaus Wachsmann focuses on one. His name is Moritz Choinowski, a Polish-born Jew detained by the Gestapo in 1939 in the German town of Magdeburg. By the time of his liberation on April 29, 1945, Choinowski has survived Buchenwald, Auschwitz, a slowly growing German camp called Gross-Rosen and finally Dachau, as well as the nightmarish forms of transportation between them. Is this possible? he sobs in the Dachau infirmary. It was, just.

title: Among the Ten Thousand Things, by Julia Pierpont
description: In some cases, the key to the success of a longstanding marriage may not be in its well-kept secrets but in its tacit agreements. Many a promiscuous spouse has been allowed room to roam as long as his or her dalliances arent flaunted. I remember reading an interview with Magic Johnsons wife, Cookie, in this very newspaper in May 1996, five years after he was told he had been infected with H.I.V. When she came to Los Angeles to visit, he always respected me, she said. Its not that I thought he was a saint. But I didnt know what was happening, and I preferred it that way. If a marriage is sufficiently loving (as the Johnsons apparently still is) or satisfying or economically advantageous, maybe it isnt worth blowing up if the person being betrayed is given the opportunity to turn a blind eye.

title: Complicated Support for Confederate Flag in White South
description: BUCHANAN, Ga.  Brandon Heath, Haralson Countys chief magistrate judge, flies the Confederate battle flag on his property. A version of it adorns the front bumper of his cherry-red Chevrolet pickup. It is painted on the wall of the gymnasium of his alma mater, Haralson County High School, where the sports teams are called the Rebels and Rebelettes.

title: Is the Death Penalty Unconstitutional?
description: CHICAGO  On the heels of major decisions about same-sex marriage and health care, the Supreme Court closed the term that ended last week with one more extremely contentious case, Glossip v. Gross, which was about the death penalty. The narrow issue in the case was the legality of Oklahomas most recent method of lethal injection, using a drug called midazolam. The court upheld that execution method in a 5-to-4 ruling, concluding that the challengers had not done enough to show that it was riskier than the alternatives. But the extensive opinions in the case confronted fundamental questions about the place of the death penalty in our constitutional system.

title: Is the Supreme Court Too Powerful?
What a Travel Adviser Can Offer That the Internet Cant
description: When it comes to planning his trips, whether for business or pleasure, Matthew D. Upchurch, 52, is old-fashioned. While the Internet might be a mainstay today for making flight and hotel reservations, Mr. Upchurch, the chairman and chief executive of Virtuoso, a global luxury network of travel advisers and more than 1,700 hotels, cruise lines and tour operators, says he believes there is nothing like the human touch. To that end, he encourages travelers to develop a relationship with one of the brands 9,000 advisers and rely on that person to create and manage their itineraries.

title: What Are the Limits of Religious Liberty?
description: I cant. Its against my religion. Americans tend to handle religious objections with care, personally and politically. When a guest says, for example, that he cant eat the food being served because its not kosher or halal, the host usually hastens to find an alternative. And when people resist following a law on the basis of faith, the government and the courts may try to accommodate them. Its an American legacy that dates back to before the founding, when some of the original colonies were set up as havens for religious dissenters. Under the banner of belief, Quakers and Mennonites in the 18th century won the right not to join state militias. The first conscientious objectors were religious objectors, and from there, the category expanded to include moral opponents of war. The same pattern holds for home-schoolers. It was an Amish father, not a hippie mother, who first got the Supreme Courts permission to take his children out of school in 1972, based on his religious commitment to life aloof from the world, as the justices respectfully put it.

title: Unstarched Shirt
description: In 1925, when Ren Lacoste won both the French Championships and Wimbledon, he wore a starched white shirt with buttons extending all the way down the front and sleeves reaching to the wrists. In 1926, he won the United States National Championship wearing the same shirt but with its sleeves cut short: a daring evolutionary step toward an archetype of sportswear. In 1933, Lacoste went into business with a knitwear manufacturer to mass-produce la chemise Lacoste, a short-sleeved pullover with a turndown collar, three buttons on its placket and a breathable piqu-cotton body. Ads extolled its suitability not just for le tennis and le golf but also for la plage (the beach): not just for athletic exertion but for general leisure. The shirt was not rigid, but there was a rectitude to it. It promoted physical comfort while adhering to social strictures. The line from there to casual Friday runs fairly straight.

title: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Opens a Previously Guarded Door
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where Congress returns from its Fourth of July holiday to find education bills, highway funding and potential Iran nuclear deals waiting for it. But as the activity on the trail slows a little, Hillary Rodham Clinton seems ready to enter another stage of her campaign.

title: Morning Agenda: Cracks Appear in Europes Stance on Greece
description: CRACKS APPEAR IN EUROPES STANCE ON GREECE | A day after Greek voters rejected the bailout terms set by creditors, a rift emerged among European leaders as Germany maintained its hard line with Athens while other officials signaled a willingness to look for a compromise,  Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing write in The New York Times. In France, the finance minister, Michel Sapin, told French radio on Monday that France could support debt relief for Greece should the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, put forth a proposal containing serious terms for a new bailout package. And in Brussels, the European Commissions vice president for euro affairs, Valdis Dombrovskis, said, If all sides are working seriously, its possible to find a solution, even in this very complicated situation.

description: HONG KONG  Officials in Malaysia said on Tuesday that they had frozen bank accounts as part of an investigation into the countrys troubled development investment fund and accusations that hundreds of millions of dollars from the fund had been transferred to Prime Minister Najib Razak.

title: Its Time for Greece to Leave the Euro
description: HAMBURG, Germany  DOES democracy trump debt? Of course not, not even in Europe. No bank clerk here would be impressed if a family told her that they had voted to have the terms of their housing loan renegotiated  thats not how loans, either personal or international, work. Yet leaders are gathering for a special summit meeting in Brussels on Tuesday because the Greeks have done exactly that: voted against the conditions the eurozone demands for a third bailout program for their country.

title: At Wimbledon, Most of the Serving Is Done Behind the Scenes

But while all eyes are on the action, behind the swish of the rackets, the popping of champagne corks and the ripples of applause that characterize the Wimbledon experience, a well-oiled operation swings into action: the small army of stewards, officials, attendants and other workers who ensure that the tournament runs smoothly.

Breyer laid out the problems, as he saw them, with the death penalty. Among them was arbitrariness in application, including how simple geography can determine whether someone convicted of murder would be sentenced to death.

title: A Royal Escape
description: While splashy business hotels continue to sprout up around Kyotos bustling core, a low-slung gem on the citys western outskirts transports guests to a time when samurai, not suits, roamed the town. Built on the site of a 13th-century imperial villa and designed in the style of the Edo era, the newly opened Suiran abuts a historic Zen temple, and offers access to the areas sprawling bamboo grove. The inn has 39 opulent rooms  nearly half of them with private outdoor hot-spring baths  and a pair of restaurants serving fresh, local seafood.

After five years, debt was  177 percent of GDP.
