title: Weighing the Fallout of a Greek Exit From the Euro
description: FRANKFURT  Bare store shelves and empty gas tanks. Hyperinflation. Riots in the streets.

title: Uber Files Motion Opposing Driver Class-Action Suit
description: In a counteroffensive filled with driver testimonials, expert witnesses and a highly produced video, Uber on Thursday filed a motion in a California court to oppose the certification of a class-action lawsuit that spotlights the work status of drivers for the ride-hailing service.

title: When Algorithms Discriminate
description: The online world is shaped by forces beyond our control, determining the stories we read on Facebook, the people we meet on OkCupid and the search results we see on Google. Big data is used to make decisions about health care, employment, housing, education and policing.

title: Womens Pro League Seeks a Bump From U.S. World Cup Success
description: The United States womens soccer team won the World Cup on Sunday before 53,000 fans in Vancouver, British Columbia, and a domestic television audience of 26.7 million people. On Friday, the players will be celebrated in a ticker-tape parade down the Canyon of Heroes in Lower Manhattan, as the Yankees, the Mets and John Glenn were before them. And next month the team will begin a 10-game victory tour with an exhibition against Costa Rica at Heinz Field in Pittsburgh, home to the N.F.L.s Steelers.

title: Aaron Tveit To Star in TV Production of Grease
description: Aaron Tveit is the one that they want.

title: Austrian Rieslings Set a High, Dry Standard
description: Riesling nowadays comes from all corners of the wine-producing earth. And happily, unlike grapes that have achieved international popularity, like sauvignon blanc, chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon, riesling has rarely been criticized for generic homogeneity.

title: In an Indifferent Toronto, the Pan-Am Games Land With a Thud
description: TORONTO  The new mayor is excited about his citys big moment in the spotlight, but hardly anyone else seems to be.

title: Calling Off the Credit-Card Debt Collectors
description: For years, consumer advocates have warned of abuse, deception and unfairness in credit-card debt collections by banks and third-party debt collectors.

title: Review: In Between the World and Me, Ta-Nehisi Coates Delivers a Searing Dispatch to His Son
description: Inspired by James Baldwins 1963 classic The Fire Next Time, Ta-Nehisi Coatess new book, Between the World and Me, is a searing meditation on what it means to be black in America today. It takes the form of a letter from Mr. Coates to his 14-year-old son, Samori, and speaks of the perils of living in a country where unarmed black men and boys  Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Eric Garner, Walter L. Scott, Freddie Gray  are dying at the hands of police officers, an America where just last month nine black worshipers were shot and killed in a Charleston, S.C., church by a young white man with apparent links to white supremacist groups online.

title: China Institute Moving to Larger Home in Lower Manhattan
description: The China Institute  which calls itself the nations oldest educational institution devoted solely to Chinese culture  is moving to Lower Manhattan from the Upper East Side.

title: Chinas Stock Crash Raises New Fears
description: The stock market crash in China is  a test of President Xi Jinpings stated goal of reducing the governments dominant role in the economy. So far, his government has reverted to its traditional command-and-control approach to financial matters.

title: Presidential Fine China, With Patterns Reflecting America
description: American presidents have had such varied tastes in dinnerware that many have discarded their predecessors china in favor of their own commissions. Historians and collectors are painstakingly reuniting sets and unearthing provenance and design paperwork.

title: House Democrats Debate Flag Bill
description: On Thursday, Democrats in the House of Representatives debated an amendment to a bill that would have allowed the Confederate battle flag in certain cemeteries. The vote was then cancelled.

title: Hacking of Government Computers Exposed 21.5 Million People
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday revealed that 21.5 million people were swept up in a colossal breach of government computer systems that was far more damaging than initially thought, resulting in the theft of a vast trove of personal information, including Social Security numbers and some fingerprints.

title: Review: In Tribute to Eva Cassidy, Rebekah Lowin Gives New Personality to Standards
description: A sad, preternatural wisdom emanated from the singer Eva Cassidy, who was only 33 when she died in 1996 from complications of melanoma. And on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, the 23-year-old Rebekah Lowin, who paid Cassidy tribute in her show I Know You By Heart: the Songs of Eva Cassidy, projected a similar aura of bittersweet, farsighted resignation.

title: With CarPlay, Apple Looks to Upend Tradition
description: APPLES widely anticipated CarPlay software is making its mainstream debut this summer in models from Hyundai and Chevrolet, but Apple is already looking ahead to leverage its potential in a way that could turn the automotive industrys current approach to connected cars on its head.

title: Behind a Watchs Elegant Face, Some Valuable Mechanisms
description: In 2012, a new IWC Portuguese Chronograph in stainless steel retailed for $7,990. A year later, a very similar looking Portugieser Chronograph Classic was $12,700.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 133 YEARS AGO

title: The Best Days of Our Lives
description: We danced at midnight in Venice, motored through Tuscany and made memories. Just as newlyweds should.

title: Review: Paris Is Reborn in Gustave Caillebotte: The Painters Eye
description: WASHINGTON  Flash on French Impressionism and youre likely to see gauzy noon landscapes, or a steam-choked Gare Saint-Lazare, or just clouds of flickering paint strokes like molecules flying apart. Yet if you visited the Impressionist show in Paris in 1877, you would have found a few things that countered such expectations: realistic paintings of a new Paris of luxury high-rises as blank as mausoleums and of ruler-straight boulevards running back into infinite space.

title: Celebrate Bastille Day: Take to the Streets Like Its 1789
description: One summer day in 1789 nearly a thousand Parisians stormed a fortress and sparked a messy revolution that eventually brought us modern France  and Bastille Day.

title: Ignoring Protests, Thailand Deports About 100 Uighurs Back to China
description: BEIJING  Thailand has sent about 100 ethnic Uighurs back to China, the country they fled, a Thai government spokesman said on Thursday. Thailand acted despite international warnings that the Uighurs could face harsh treatment in China and pleas that they be allowed to resettle elsewhere.

title: Janis and Gueorgui Pastujov: Togetherness Is a Balancing Act
description: When they were married on April 8, 1994, Janis Tardy and Gueorgui Pastujov (who appeared in a Vows column) were members of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus and living in a 6-foot by 6-foot compartment on the mile-long circus train. Their bed doubled as the dining room table and every other piece of furniture, too.

title: Increasingly Visible, Cubas Elin Gonzlez Champions Islands Government
description: His rescue by fishermen off the coast of Fort Lauderdale nearly 16 years ago touched off a custody battle that ensnarled the Clinton White House in the intense acrimony between Cuban exiles and the islands Communist leaders.

title: Yankees Brett Gardner Plays Like an All-Star, Then Learns He Is One
description: The Yankees had scored two runs in the fourth inning to pull ahead of the Oakland Athletics, 4-2, on Thursday, and now the sun was starting to burst through the clouds in the top of the fifth, illuminating the grass at Yankee Stadium on which left fielder Brett Gardner stood, and hinting at more good news to come.

title: Chinese Employee of German Weekly Is Freed After 9-Month Detention
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese news assistant for the influential German weekly Die Zeit was freed on Thursday, her lawyer said, nine months after the police in Beijing detained her after she had returned from helping to report on pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

title: Perella Weinberg Hires a Senior Goldman Sachs Executive
description: As Perella Weinberg Partners restocks its corporate bankruptcy advisory practice, the boutique investment bank has poached a senior executive from one of its larger rivals.

title: Age Bias? Tell Us About It
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: In a Theater, or Under a Tent
description: The evangelical movement in New York is driven, in large part, by immigrant-led churches that have proliferated outside Manhattan.

title: An Evangelical Revival in the Heart of New York
description: The sky-blue walls of the former Vaudeville theater thundered with faith on Sunday morning in Corona, Queens. Some 600 worshipers rose to join the Latino band in song, shaking their tambourines, heads and hands in electric rapture.

title: South Carolina Governor Signs Flag Bill
description: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed a bill into law on Thursday that orders the removal of the Confederate battle flag from the Capitol grounds.

title: Carnegie Museum to Open a Survey of the Designer Peter Muller-Munk
description: His Normandie pitcher is one of the prime examples of Art Deco streamlining, sleek as a funnel on that great steamliner and elegant as one of its staterooms. And yet Peter Muller-Munk himself, who designed it in 1935, has passed largely from view.

title: Art Thats Made Not to Last
description: In an era when art is toppling gold and joining high-end real estate as a preferred instrument for storing wealth, ephemeral works tend to flummox the system. A piece that burns bright for a few weeks or months and then exists only in memory, or photographs?

title: New Museum Names Triennial Curators
description: The New Museums triennial, which began in 2009 and wrapped up its third iteration in May, has established itself as a kind of energetically internationalist, youth-oriented answer to the Whitney Biennial  the triennials first show was made up of artists 33 or younger. For its next installation, the museum has chosen two curators (one of whom is over that age) who have become well known in the art world for covering a lot of ground in a short time. Gary Carrion-Murayari, 34, who has been a curator at the New Museum since 2010 and was co-curator of the Whitney Biennial that same year, will join Alex Gartenfeld, 28, the founding deputy director and chief curator at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Miami, to curate the show, which will open in 2018.

title: Hold the Phone, Its Patti LuPone
description: For Patti LuPone, it was the day from hell, all day.

title: Thompson Family Foundation to Give Park Avenue Armory $65 Million
description: The New York City cultural landscape is mapped by the surnames of great patronage: Guggenheim, Whitney, Morgan, Frick, Cooper Hewitt and, more recently, Geffen, Koch and Bloomberg. Now the name of another donor seems likely to enter the lexicon: Wade Thompson. Mr. Thompson, who died in 2009, made his money by reviving the Airstream brand of shiny aluminum trailers, and in the 1990s, he began devoting a sizable amount of his fortune to reviving the grand but crumbling Park Avenue Armory, at 66th Street, which has transformed itself into a hangar-size stage for art, music and performance.

title: Superheroes, Just for Each Other
description: The first time I lifted her up and carried her away, I was acting on a whim, seeking an exit from a stupid but dangerous argument. Though we lived in the glittering center of Shanghai, we couldnt agree on where to go for dinner.

title: Why Chinas Stock Market Bailout Just Might Work
description: Outside of China, the consensus among economists is overwhelming: The countrys efforts to prop up its plunging stock markets are doomed, the financial equivalent of King Canute trying to halt the incoming tide. But this being China, the conventional wisdom may turn out to be wrong.

title: British Tourists Should Leave Tunisia, London Says
description: LONDON  All British travelers should leave Tunisia, the British government said Thursday, because a terrorist attack there is highly likely.

title: When a Son Says I Do, and the Parents Say They Dont
description: Our son started dating a college classmate three years ago. They are graduating in December and told us they will marry in May. Neither has a job, and we pay all of our sons tuition and living expenses. We told him that we are happy he found that special person, but that they should be more practical: find jobs, save money, then get married. My husband reached out to the womans parents, who were horrified by our attitude. Still, we told our son we cannot give him our blessing and will not attend his wedding. Now, no one is speaking with us. Thoughts?

title: Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, Quiet Force in Middle East, Dies at 75
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Prince Saud al-Faisal, the urbane diplomat who used quiet diplomacy to maintain Saudi Arabias regional influence and alliance with the United States during his four decades as foreign minister, died on Thursday, according to Saudi officials and state news media. He was 75.

title: Theodore Roosevelts Sagamore Hill Home Cries Bully!
description: COVE NECK, N.Y.  The big house has been a pretty lonely place for a while now. It has been three and a half years since the public has been able to walk through Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelts sprawling family home near Oyster Bay on the North Shore of Long Island. In December 2011 the doors closed, most of the artifacts were shipped out and crews of workers moved in for a $10 million restoration. Strollers on the grounds have been able to sit on its big front porch or press their noses to the windows, but the house itself has been locked up tight.

title: Review: National Ballet of China Brings Peony Pavilion to Lincoln Center
description: At the center of the Ming dynasty play The Peony Pavilion is a love story that advances through dreams and visions and across the boundaries between life and death. Thats a feature it has in common with Romantic ballets. On this commonality rests the hopes of the National Ballet of Chinas 2008 production of Peony Pavilion, which itself seeks to fulfill a dream: to create a Western ballet with Chinese characteristics.

title: Review: Losing Tom Pecinka Challenges Audience to Get the Message
description: The real Tom Pecinka didnt die. He left for drama school. Still, loss is loss, and the handsome ghost who addresses the audience at the start of Morgan Goulds Losing Tom Pecinka in the New Ohio Theaters Ice Factory festival wears a Yale T-shirt, an emblem of that abandonment.

title: High-Flying Fashion
description: The airport as runway.

title: Valentino: Fall 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: Review: Alan Smithee Directed This Play, at Jacobs Pillow, Blends Three Films in Dance
description: BECKET, Mass.  In the 83rd season of Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival, Big Dance Theaters magnetic and enigmatic Alan Smithee Directed This Play: Triple Feature is something of an anomaly. While dance at the Pillow tends toward the ultra-dancey  strenuously physical stuff  Big Dance, directed by Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar, traffics in many media, in text, sound and video as much as movement.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 537  541
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 537  541

title: The Scene
description: Valentino at Couture Week.

title: Photo Diary: Valentino Fall/Winter 2015 Couture
description: Scenes from Couture Week, captured by Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: HBOs 7 Days in Hell, a Tennis Mockumentary Timed to Wimbledon
description: Golf has its Caddyshack. Baseball has its Major League. And now tennis, another sport that some people find boring and that sometimes comes off as a wee bit pretentious, has 7 Days in Hell. Center Court may never be the same.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bosnia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, London, Pakistan and elsewhere.

title: Bonard Fowler, Alabama Officer in Shooting That Led to Selma March, Dies at 81
description: Jimmie Lee Jackson, a 26-year-old laborer and church deacon, was shot to death in Macks Cafe in Marion, Ala., on the night of Feb. 18, 1965, and the killing proved historic: It provoked the fateful voting-rights march from Selma to Montgomery, turning the tide for the civil rights movement.

title: July 9, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Bosnia, England, Pakistan and Greece.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, July 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Greece Official on Reform Proposal
description: Panos Kammenos, the Greek defense minister, told reporters that Greece was on track for a deal with creditors.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Petra Cortrights Desktop Dolls
description: The artist Petra Cortright has always committed her work to screens  shes best known for her short webcam videos, which meld selfie technique with performance art, and for her digital paintings (on aluminum) and animations  and the screens keep getting bigger. The Santa Barbara, Calif.-born artist now shares a studio building in El Sereno (the easternmost neighborhood of Los Angeles) with her husband, Marc Horowitz, and Parker Ito. But regardless of where she plugs in her computer, shes at home: Cortright has been making and showing work on the Internet since 2007, years before it was a medium comprehensible to many aficionados of analog art.

title: Review: Do I Sound Gay? Examines a Manner of Speaking
description: David Thorpes engaging personal documentary, Do I Sound Gay?, tiptoes into treacherous waters, where it stirs up a few ripples before gracefully backing out. Not so long ago, mockery of the sissy queen stereotype, with a limp wrist, a mincing gait and a lisp was a surefire laugh getter for comedians like Bob Hope, who made cruel sport of perceived effeminacy.

title: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Bolivia
description: Pope Francis celebrated mass in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, on Thursday during his tour of south America.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review:Art Carved From Inequality by James Son Ford Thomas
description: James Son Ford Thomas: The Devil and His Blues at New York Universitys 80WSE Gallery is an inspirational show about the perseverance of art, and the tragedy of inequality. But it is also a thing of joy: It brings the work of a wonderful and underappreciated artist to the fore.

title: Review: Positions Wanted by Minions Experienced at Serving Evildoers
description: Its fitting that the little yellow critters scampering through Minions look as identical as genetically modified corn kernels, save for a googly eyeball or two. Franchises operate on an axis of sameness and difference, so its amusing that one incorporates that truism into its actual character design. And while Minions explores nominally new narrative ground, it folds neatly into a series that now includes two features (Despicable Me and Despicable Me 2), various shorts, books, video games, sheet music and a theme park attraction. So, you know, different but also the same.

title: No Need for DeAndre Jordan to Apologize
description: A conflicted young man with a major career decision reneged on a handshake agreement to leave the nest because what he wanted most from his newfound leverage was love and attention from the most popular guys at the home office.

title: Circus Cats Are Lions of Their Profession, but Domestic at Heart
description: TO train a cat to balance on a ball and walk it forward, you will need a weighted ball, a track to place it on, a hand-held clicker and lots of kitty treats. Each time the cat masters part of the process  standing on the ball, say, or learning to walk backward to make the ball advance  you make a clicking noise while delivering a treat. It takes time, patience and a willing cat.

title: On Location | Nockamixon, Pa.
description: Lori and Leonard Bruno, owners of three Ligne Roset showrooms, reclaimed an old Pennsylvania barn and turned it into their home.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: How Can I Get Crisp Fish Skin? Sam Sifton Answers This and Other Questions for the Home Cook
description: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? Thats what Im here for! Write me at foodeditor@nytimes.com and ask away. Ill answer your queries herewith.

title: Jeb Bush Outstrips Rivals in Fund-Raising as Super PACs Swell Candidates Coffers
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me.  Jeb Bush and his allies announced on Thursday that they had amassed more than $114 million in campaign cash over the last six months, dwarfing the combined fund-raising of his Republican rivals for the partys presidential nomination.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, July 12 to 18, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Tap Forward Showcases Contemporary Tap
description: This week, Tony Waag, the perpetually cheerful director of the American Tap Dance Foundation, presides over Tap City, a festival now in its 15th year. On Wednesday in Tap Forward, a program highlighting contemporary tappers at the intimate Duke on 42nd Street, there was even a flash from the past: The veteran Brenda Bufalino showed off her polished finish as she quietly blended in and out of a groove in Strayhorn Medley.

title: Review: In Self/less, Immortality at a Cost
description: At the start of Self/less, Damian Hale, a ruthless New York real estate magnate, is played by Ben Kingsley, who seems to have fired his dialect coach halfway to mastering what is apparently supposed to be a Brooklyn accent. No matter. Damian, who has a terminal illness, has purchased immortality  or at least extended life on his original warranty  from a smooth and shady British scientist named Albright (Matthew Goode). After his death, Damians unique cognitive software, his reservoir of memories and feelings and thoughts, is uploaded into the body and brain of Ryan Reynolds. So is the job of carrying this entirely preposterous, not entirely unenjoyable movie.

title: Brooklyn Expats Come Home
description: The average person will move 11.7 times in his or her lifetime, census data shows. Of these homes, many will be fondly remembered, but once the tape is sealed on the last moving box, rarely do people continue to regularly visit their old stamping grounds. That is, unless the last place they lived was Brooklyn.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: July 10
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a tugboat captain and the Police Departments graduating class.

title: Todd Snyder, a Designer Raised in Iowa, Is Big in Japan
description: Fashion could use a little Iowa. Thats what stylish Japanese men think, and since when has Japan ever been late to a trend?

title: Letters: Jacob Lawrences Champion
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislator During Debate Over Rebel Flag
description: State Representative Michael A. Pitts spoke this week during a debate at the South Carolina House.

title: Spare Times for July 10-16
description: A Night at Niblos Garden

title: Spare Times for Children for July 10-16
description: Viva la Frida!

title: Review: Tangerine, a Madcap Buddy Picture About Transgender Prostitutes
description: Little is as it seems in Tangerine, a fast, raucously funny comedy about love and other misadventures. Thats true of its main attractions, a pair of transgender lookers with motormouths and killer gams, as well as the nominally straight men occupying their hearts and minds. Appearances both deceive and delight in this tough yet tender, gritty yet gorgeous movie, which was made with ingenious skill and what would count as chump change at the big studios. Shot along a grubby stretch of Los Angeles, it takes place in the looming shadow of the Hollywood sign, but as far from industrial cinema as another galaxy.

title: New York Attorney GeneralCreatesSpecial Unit on Killings by the Police
description: The New York attorney general, prompted by an executive order from the governor, announced on Thursday the formation of a special unit to investigate cases in which people killed by the police are unarmed or serious doubts exist about whether they were armed and dangerous.

title: Anatomy | The Stanford Prison Experiment
description: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Kyle Patrick Alvarez narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Citi Bike Workers in New York Get Union Contract
description: Less than a year after Citi Bike employees in New York City joined a union, they became the first bike-share workers in the country to reach an agreement for a union contract.

title: The Stanford Prison Experiment (With Movie Trailer): Kyle Patrick Alvarez Narrates a Scene
description: In 1971, the psychologist Philip G. Zimbardo assembled a group of young male volunteers and paid them to participate in a project that would recreate a prison environment.

title: Crowning Glory
description: The Milliners Guild arose to help professional hat makers deal with the dwindling number of suppliers in the once-thriving hat district in Manhattans West 30s.

title: Pete Rose Says He Is Among Four Reds to Be Honored at All-Star Game
description: Pete Rose, who is on baseballs permanently ineligible list, will be on the field before the All-Star Game in Cincinnati on Tuesday as one of the four most influential players in Reds history, selected by fans votes.

title: Review: Stations of the Cross, a Portrait of Religious Fervor
description: There are three ways to look at the German director Dietrich Brggemanns Stations of the Cross, an austere, beautifully filmed and powerfully acted portrait of extreme religious fervor that slyly flirts with comedy.

title: Theater Listings for July 10-16
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: In 10.000 km, Lovers an Ocean Apart Struggle to Connect
description: The opening scene of 10.000 km, which is more than 20 minutes, follows Alex and Sergi through the intimate rituals of a Sunday morning: making love, making breakfast, brushing their teeth, imagining the baby they are thinking about having.

title: Changes to New York Police Practices and Policies
description: A federal monitor filed his first review of how the New York Police Department is complying with court orders to outfit officers with body cameras, provide new training on the laws surrounding street stops and develop policies that guide those tactics.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for July 10-16
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for July 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New York Swaps State Test-Makers Amid Strife Over Exams
description: A new company has been chosen to develop the assessments for New York State students in third through eighth grades, a contentious group of tests that spawned a backlash in recent years.

title: This Weeks Movies | July 10, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Minions, Self/less and Tangerine.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for July 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for July 10-16
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for July 10-16
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Dance Listings for July 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 10-16
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: July 4 Terror Plots Foiled, F.B.I. Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said on Thursday that counterterrorism authorities had thwarted multiple attacks being plotted for July 4 by the Islamic State and its sympathizers in the United States.

title: Review: The Gallows Somehow Finds More Horror Footage
description: The horror movie The Gallows starts with a decent if improbable premise, and it ends with a pretty good jolt. But in between, the film sure wears out the already tired found-footage device.

title: New Jersey Man Charged With Killing 7 People Over 2 Months
description: A 22-year-old man has been charged with fatally shooting seven people and wounding an eighth in a seven-week span that spread from New Jersey to Pennsylvania, punctuated by bursts of violence that left multiple people dead within several hours.

title: Lionsgate Takes Fresh Approach to Promote The Hunger Games at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO  Trot some stars onto a stage. Get a gushy blogger or aspiring comedian to ask canned questions. Dim the lights and show footage.

title: Review: In Mad Women, a Small-Town Political Family With Issues
description: Jeff Lipsky has made a new film, which means more domestic turbulence and stripped-bare (often figuratively, occasionally literally) characters for his fans. The movie is Mad Women, and this time Mr. Lipsky, who wrote and directed, throws in a political side plot that gives these sometimes satirical proceedings a skewed topicality.

title: A Prayer Sung by a Long-Lost Son
description: Cantor David Rosenberg chanting in Hebrew.

title: Review: Meet Me in Montenegro, Romance for Ex-Lovers
description: Based on a true love story  the filmmakers  Meet Me in Montenegro stars its directors, Alex Holdridge and Linnea Saasen, as former lovers who reconnect in Berlin years after a romantic jaunt in the Balkans. Hes Anderson, a stagnating independent filmmaker; shes Lina, the Norwegian dancer who broke his heart. Like Mr. Holdridges previous film, In Search of a Midnight Kiss, this story has echoes of a Richard Linklater story, but peters out early on and an interminable voice-over grinds every other dramatic moment into dust.

title: Dark Cloud Lifts Over Denver, but Experts Warn of More to Come
description: DENVER  An ugly and ominous dark cloud that has enveloped this city and much of eastern Colorado this week finally dissipated on Thursday, prompting public health officials to lift a warning against spending too much time outside, particularly for young children, old people and people with lung problems.

title: Review: SlingShot Documentary Pitches Solution to Global Water Crisis
description: According to the documentary SlingShot, the Slingshot  a purification device known as a vapor compression distiller  can make polluted water drinkable. If brought to impoverished communities, the machine, were told, would have vast implications for global health.

title: F.D.A. Is Set to Toughen Nonaspirin Warnings
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration is strengthening warnings on painkillers like ibuprofen to say that they cause an increased risk of heart attack and stroke. The over-the-counter forms include Advil, Motrin IB and Aleve.

title: Review: In Strangerland, Relocating Does Little to Ease a Familys Strains
description: Strangerland centers on a family of new arrivals in an Australian desert town. Whether the title refers to their presence  or whether they are, perhaps, more alien to one another than to those around them  is a question left unresolved by this well-acted fiction feature debut from Kim Farrant.

title: Review: Tap World Documentary Features a Variety of Quick-Stepping Dancers
description: Tap World is a pleasant documentary full of tap dancers proclaiming their love of the form and showing off their skills. It would be better if it had a bit less proclaiming and a bit more nuts-and-bolts information, but still, its refreshing to see people bubbling over with enthusiasm for an art that is somewhat out of the mainstream.

title: Florida Court Finds Politics Determined District Lines
description: MIAMI  The Florida Supreme Court on Thursday rejected political gerrymandering by state legislators and ordered eight congressional districts redrawn within 100 days, a decision likely to complicate preparations for next years elections.

title: With Flag Gone, South Carolina May Host College Playoffs
description: Minutes after Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed a law Thursday afternoon removing the Confederate battle flag from the grounds of the State House, the N.C.A.A. announced that the states colleges may once again bid to host championships.

title: Facebook Said to Seek Music Video Licensing Deals
description: Over the last few years, Facebook has slowly encroached on YouTubes territory as a go-to outlet for online video, showing popular content from publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice and a growing number of user-loaded clips. Now Facebook is considering going after another piece of YouTubes signature turf: music videos.

title: Review: What We Did on Our Holiday Transfers Sitcom Formula to the Big Screen
description: A family of bickering, broken adults has its priorities realigned by three children and a terminally ill grandpa in What We Did on Our Holiday, a damp-eyed comedy whose banal title isnt the only thing needing improvement.

title: Myanmar Signs Treaty on Chemical Weapons
description: Myanmar, a former pariah state in Southeast Asia once run by a military junta that has gradually embraced some democratic changes and reintegration with the world, has become the 191st country to sign the treaty that bans chemical weapons, the international body that monitors that accord said Thursday.

title: Movie Review: Minions
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Minions.

title: India Inquiry Into Scandal Over Testing Set to Expand
description: GWALIOR, India  The Supreme Court of India on Thursday ordered federal investigators to take over from a state police force in a sprawling testing scandal that has involved about 2,000 arrests and at least 23 deaths, some of them possibly suspicious.

title: Movie Review: Tangerine
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Tangerine.

title: Movie Review: Self/Less
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Self/Less.

title: In Bolivia, Pope Francis Apologizes for Churchs Grave Sins
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia  Pope Francis offered a direct apology on Thursday for the complicity of the Roman Catholic Church in the oppression of Latin America during the colonial era, even as he called for a global social movement to shatter a new colonialism that has fostered inequality, materialism and the exploitation of the poor.

title: An Uber I.P.O. Looms, and Suddenly Bankers Are Using Uber. Coincidence?
description: Wall Street banks can be hidebound in their ways: insisting on suits and ties and handing out BlackBerries after everyone else has moved on to the iPhone. But if there is one thing that can push even the most conservative bank into the future, it is the prospect of business.

title: Catholics Defy Boston Archdiocese With 11-Year Vigil to Keep Church
description: SCITUATE, Mass.  It was a bright Sunday morning at St. Frances Xavier Cabrini Church, and the buildings stained glass windows cast a jewel-colored glow over the service. An elegant 81-year-old woman led a few dozen congregants in Catholic prayer. A single flutist accompanied the hymns.

title: Surge of Ebola in Liberia May Be Linked to a Survivor
description: A resurgence of Ebola in the last week in Liberia, which had been declared free of the disease, may have originated with a survivor still carrying the virus, according to scientists who analyzed the genetic sequence of the virus from the body of a 17-year-old Liberian boy who died of Ebola last week.

title: Can the U.S. and China Get Along?
description: FOR longtime observers of China, the last two years have been unsettling. Under Xi Jinping the Chinese Communist Party has made it more difficult than ever to hope that the Peoples Republic is still dedicated to the agenda of reform and opening up that was the mantra of the Deng Xiaoping era. Instead, Beijing has served up a neo-Maoist cocktail of autocracy within and truculence without.

title: Wimbledon 2015: Garbie Muguruza Realizes a Dream, but Faces Nightmarish Odds
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The only way to know how you will handle a first Grand Slam final is to wake up in the morning, feel the hope and tension rise, walk onto the court with the cameras clicking and the crowd buzzing, and actually play that first Grand Slam final.

title: Takata Says No to Fund for Victims of Defective Airbag
description: As the recall of defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata has mushroomed and the death and injury toll has mounted, the company has come under increasing pressure to take more responsibility for its faulty products.

title: Unharmed by a Gas Explosion, but Choked by the Red Tape That Followed
description: To begin with, although the B&H Dairy Restaurant on Second Avenue in Manhattan now hangs by a thread, no one was hurt there on March 26, the day that three buildings on the same block were leveled by a gas explosion. Two men were killed in a sushi restaurant two doors away. Dozens of people lost their homes.

title: James Marcus, Opera Benefactor and Ex-Goldman Partner, Dies at 85
description: James S. Marcus, who fell in love with opera at a student performance of Wagners fairy tale Lohengrin when he was 9 and who went on to become a board chairman and benefactor of the Metropolitan Opera, died on July 5 in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: A Bush and a Clinton Side by Side on Stage, and Not a Political Zinger Between Them
description: DALLAS  The last names Clinton and Bush typically mean political combat of the past, present and potential future. But on Thursday, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush were all charm as they took the stage together here in a bipartisan love fest to promote a joint scholarship program.

title: Giants Jason Pierre-Paul Should Be Able to Overcome Loss of Finger, Former Players Say
description: Jason Pierre-Paul was viewed as a high-risk, high-reward prospect when he was drafted higher than projected, going to the Giants 15th over all in 2011. He had played only one season at the major college level after transferring to South Florida as a defensive end following stints at two junior colleges.

title: Federal Monitor Proposes Larger Trial of Body Cameras for New York Police
description: New Yorkers would be more likely to encounter a police officer wearing a body camera under a vast new trial program recommended by the federal monitor for the Police Department.

title: A Photographer Takes the Road West
description: The New York Times staff photographer Ruth Fremson is driving toward Seattle, posting photos to Instagram along the way.

title: Eisenhower Memorial Design Approved
description: Frank Gehrys design for the National Eisenhower Memorial received final approval on Thursday from the National Capital Planning Commission, completing the federal approval process for the design. The action is the last federal approval required for the memorial, planned for the National Mall in Washington; the United States Commission of Fine Arts also recently gave approval. This is an important day for those of us who are committed to memorializing Dwight D. Eisenhower, a brilliant military strategist, a visionary world leader, a man who saved Western democracy, and a proud Kansan, said Senator Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Eisenhower Memorial Commission. Its my belief we can finish a memorial that is fitting for a man who has given so much to our freedom. The project has been plagued by conflict, since Eisenhower family members have objected to the design and Congress has not funded construction. Representative Mike Thompson, a California Democrat, added: Its time to put aside the squabbling and attacks and move forward to give to the American people, to Ikes remaining troops, and to the world, a great memorial to a great man.

title: From the First Round to a Last Chance for Thomas Robinson
description: While N.B.A. fans heatedly debated DeAndre Jordans decision to spurn the Dallas Mavericks and remain with the Los Angeles Clippers, the Nets introduced their free-agent signings on Thursday in a subdued atmosphere at Barclays Center.

title: The National Youth Orchestras Moment in the Sun
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  Ah, the great indoors!

title: Friend, on Stand, Recalls Losing His Job After Doing Brooklyn Senator a Favor
description: Sam Noel called State Senator John L. Sampson John-O. Mr. Sampson called him N.O. They were high school friends, and Mr. Noel was a groomsman in Mr. Sampsons wedding, the godfather to his daughter. He stood by the bedside of Mr. Sampsons mother as she died of cancer.

title: Masabumi Kikuchi, Jazz Pianist Who Embraced Individualism, Dies at 75
description: Masabumi Kikuchi, a Japanese jazz pianist known to New York audiences in his final decades for his highly idiosyncratic approach, often heard in his work with the drummer Paul Motian, died on Monday at a hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Review: In The Weir, Things Go Bump in the Night, at the Pub
description: The Irish Repertory Theaters superb revival of The Weir, Conor McPhersons haunting drama about strange occurrences and the comfort of sharing them with strangers, has returned for a summer run at the DR2 Theater, while the companys home base undergoes renovation.

title: Review: Sayonara Reimagines a Story of Cross-Cultural Love
description: Its 1952 in Kobe, Japan, and the American airmen stationed there must confront an unfamiliar culture with its strange rituals and customs. Even the booze is perplexing. This is the first rice I ever drank, says Maj. Ace Gruver, tasting sake. Back home we make pudding out of rice.

title: Built to Commemorate Triumph
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  This was an odd solving experience for me. I started out, happy as a clam, in the northwest and then came to a dead halt. Not that theres anything wrong with that.

title: Is Greece Worse Off Than the U.S. During the Great Depression?
description: The economy has been in disarray. People have been out of work for years. The banks have been running out of money. It sounds a lot like the Great Depression in the United States. But it is Greece  and in some ways, the situation is worse.

title: Steve Reich, Game Designer
description: Forget Angry Birds, or 2048. The latest star of a maddeningly addictive iPhone game is the composer Steve Reich.

title: Review: Anthems for the Mother Earth Goddess
description: ANTHEMS FOR THE MOTHER EARTH GODDESS

title: Three Men Charged in Fatal Shooting of Manhattan Shopkeeper
description: Three men were charged on Thursday in connection with the murder of a shopkeeper, who was fatally shot last month and found by a customer behind the register of his familys odd-and-ends store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: In Impassioned Debate on South Carolina Confederate Flag, Three Voices Emerge
description: As South Carolina lawmakers delivered impassioned speeches for and against taking down the Confederate battle flag, three distinctive voices emerged.

title: Settlement Over Anti-Semitic Bullying at Pine Bush Central Schools Is Approved
description: WHITE PLAINS  The two 17-year-old girls told of repeated acts of anti-Semitic bullying  one girl had money shoved into her mouth, another kept seeing swastikas pervasively in school hallways and lockers  yet school officials in the largely rural Pine Bush Central School District made only feeble efforts to combat the abuse.

title: Carlos Martinez Leads Cardinals Past Pirates
description: Carlos Martinez made his case on Thursday for being included on the National League All-Star team by pitching seven and one-third scoreless innings, and the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1, in a matchup between the teams with the best records in the major leagues.

title: De Blasio Stands by His Criticism of Cuomo
description: When Mayor Bill de Blasio launched a startling broadside last week at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, accusing his fellow Democrat of moral and political malpractice, he threw back the curtains on one of the more rancorous disputes between a mayor and a governor in decades.

title: Kristaps Porzingis, Knicks Top Draft Pick, Is Set for Summer League Debut
description: LAS VEGAS  Kristaps Porzingis, two weeks into his tenure with the Knicks, said he was looking forward to making his summer league debut here on Saturday against the San Antonio Spurs. After straining his hip in a predraft workout, Porzingis said he felt healthy. But he was still grappling with unknowns.

title: North Korea: Pesticide Factory May Have Sinister Purpose, Report Says
description: A pesticide factory recently visited by the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un may be used to produce biological weapons, like anthrax, according to an online report posted Thursday. On June 6, the state-run North Korean news media reported that when Mr. Kim visited the Pyongyang Biotechnical Institute, he was so happy with scientists work there in developing insecticides that he wanted to carry them on his back. But 38 North, a website run by Johns Hopkins Universitys U.S.-Korea Institute, said photographs North Korean media released with the reports of Mr. Kims visit showed that North Korea has been importing dual-use equipment. It is hard to avoid the conclusion that the institute is intended to produce military-size batches of anthrax, it said. Regardless of whether the equipment is being used to produce anthrax today, it could in the near future.

title: Italian Farm to Table
description: Why do the simplest Italian ingredients  ripe tomatoes, sharp pecorino, a splash of fruity olive oil  taste so sublime? It has something to do with where youre eating them, but mostly its the location where theyre made. Until recently, savoring the spoils grown and prepared at Fattoria La Vialla meant having to make a trip to the 3,000-acre organic, biodynamic family farm and winery in Tuscany, where visitors can buy from the shop or stay in one of the 23 rental villas and dine al fresco under the olive trees. But now, all that deliciously authentic cheese and fresh pasta can be delivered directly to customers in the U.S. and Europe  so that you can think globally, and eat locally.

title: How to Throw a Clambake Like Youre From Rhode Island
description: In Newport, R. I., the clambake is more than just a way to pass a summer afternoon; its a beloved New England tradition that locals take very seriously. Castle Hill Inns summer clambakes, overseen by the chef Karsten Hart (the director of restaurants at Newport Harbor Corporations), have been voted the states best by Rhode Island Monthly. Theyre inspired, Hart explains, by the Wampanoag and Narragansett tribes centuries-old customs  but presented with some modern twists.

title: Mets Steven Matz Is Out for at Least a Month With a Torn Muscle
description: When Steven Matz made his major league debut for the Mets on June 28, everything went right. He dominated the Cincinnati Reds hitters, he went three for three at the plate with four R.B.I. and he reinvigorated a Mets season that had begun to flatten out from lack of hitting and too much shaky defense in the infield.

title: Ken Stabler, Quarterback Who Led Raiders to Title, Dies at 69
description: Ken Stabler, a precision passer who was famously cool under pressure in becoming one of pro footballs leading quarterbacks of the 1970s and engineering the Oakland Raiders first Super Bowl victory, died on Wednesday in Gulfport, Miss. He was 69.

title: U.S. Womens Open: Marina Alex and Karrie Webb Are Tied for Lead
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  After a 66 in the first round of the United States Womens Open on Thursday, a quick television interview, a news conference, another television interview and a bite to eat, Marina Alex was finally able to find some peace and quiet. The demands of being a co-leader of the Open can be burdensome, especially if you have never been in that position.

title: After Week of Turmoil, Chinese Stocks Post Further Gains
description: HONG KONG  A week of volatility in Chinas stock markets ended on a better note than many investors expected, as government policies to prop up shares seemed to have muted some of the panic among sellers.

title: Kenneth G. Lieberthal on the Political Effects of Chinas Stock Market Plunge
description: Chinas stock market is in crisis. By Wednesday, the main Shanghai stock index had plummeted an astounding 32 percent since its peak on June 12 of 5,166 points. The Shenzhen index suffered a similar plunge. Chinese leaders have been rolling out a range of policies to try to halt the slides and restore investor confidence. Some may be working, if haltingly  the Shanghai index on Thursday closed 28 percent down from the peak. But the efforts could forestall what many analysts say is a necessary market correction.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) HARPER LEE: AMERICAN MASTERS In honor of the release of Ms. Lees novel Go Set a Watchman on Tuesday, Mary McDonagh Murphy  who was able to read an advance copy  has updated her 2011 documentary, Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and To Kill a Mockingbird. (Above, Ms. Lee with Gregory Peck at the movies premiere in 1962.) Ms. Murphy will also post on Twitter (#HarperLeePBS) during the broadcast. It gives the fascinating history of how the book came to be, which involved Truman Capote, a perceptive editor and an act of generosity that helped give Ms. Lee, the novels author, the time she needed to write, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times of the original documentary, adding that the best moments come from other authors, who read passages and talk about the books impact on their work. But just when this is beginning to seem like pandering, he added, Oprah Winfrey gives the most eloquent reading of all, of the scene in which Atticus leaves the courtroom after the pivotal verdict. The broadcast is part of Thirteen Days of Harper Lee, an event featuring videos, book discussions and a link to Essential Longform: The Best Harper Lee Reads, assembled by the New York Public Library. (thirteen.org)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Youve got to keep him in the tent. He just wreaks havoc, and every vote he takes comes out of our hide.

title: Corrections: July 10, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: In First Chapter of Harper Lees Go Set a Watchman, Sprouts With Deep Roots
description: She had turned from an overalled, fractious, gun-slinging creature into a reasonable facsimile of a human being.

title: Crowning Glory
description: For centuries, no self-respecting woman was considered fully dressed without a hat; no outfit was complete if your head was bare. Today, alas, the hat has been reduced to a novelty item. So once a month, a group calling itself the Milliners Guild meets with a singular purpose: to restore the well-made hat to its rightful place on top of the fashion world.

title: Senator Jon Tester, on a Conservation Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., on Mercury in Vaccines
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dominican Ambassador, on Deportation of Haitians
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Penalty Motive: Revenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Illegal Defiance on Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Supreme Court could not have been clearer when it ruled late last month that states may not refuse to marry same-sex couples.

title: Greeces Economy Is a Lesson for Republicans in the U.S.
description: Greece is a faraway country with an economy roughly the size of greater Miami, so America has very little direct stake in its ongoing disaster. To the extent that Greece matters to us, its mainly about geopolitics: By poisoning relations among Europes democracies, the Greek crisis risks depriving the United States of crucial allies.

title: Trapped by New Yorks Bail System
description: Imagine, for a moment, that you are accused of a misdemeanor or even a nonviolent felony in New York. The judge sets a low bail, maybe $500, but even that is too much for you or your family. So you sweat it out in New York Citys hellhole of a jail on Rikers Island, waiting for a trial months, even years away. Plead guilty and the terrors of Rikers are behind you. But now you have a criminal record, which could damage your future.

title: Obesity Clinics and the Health Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryanair Says Itll Accept I.A.G.s Takeover Bid for Its Aer Lingus Stake
description: PARIS  Ryanair said on Friday that it would accept a takeover bid for its 29.8 percent stake in the Irish flag carrier, Aer Lingus, from the parent company of British Airways, removing the final hurdle to a combination that analysts say will bolster Irelands position as hub for trans-Atlantic travel.

title: Greece and Creditors Move Toward Deal, and Investor Optimism Surges
description: ATHENS  Optimism rose on Friday over the prospects of an accord between Greece and its international creditors, as the two sides weighed the latest measures from Athens aimed at overhauling its economy and securing its place in the euro currency bloc.

title: Bostons 2024 Olympic Bid Faces Skepticism Despite New Proposal, Poll Finds
description: Statewide support in Massachusetts for holding the 2024 Summer Olympics in Boston appears to have inched up slightly since organizers proposed a new plan last month, but it remains tepid, and more voters still oppose the move than support it.

title: Cuomo Is Put on Defensive by Fellow Democrats Over His Style
description: It was a moment for reflection and, perhaps, reconciliation with fellow Democrats who had grown exasperated with what they said were Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos tactics of bullying and intimidation. But he was having none of that.

title: Era Ends as South Carolina Lowers Confederate Flag
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  They pooled by the thousands in the scorching July heat  white and black, old and young, civil rights veterans and everyday Southerners who grew up with the symbols and assumptions of the racial order of the South. They waited quietly at first, but eventually erupted into spontaneous chants of Take it down!

title: In North Korea, Fears of Extreme Drought Ease
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Fears of a severe drought in impoverished North Korea have eased after a partial rebound in rainfall in recent weeks, the South Korean government said on Friday.

title: Fridays Travel News and Tips
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Runway Fantasies and the Regular Guy
description: PARIS  The young guy by the exit of the Mtro station a few blocks from the Muse du Quai Branly seemed nervous.

title: A Honeymoon Through Italy
description: The trip began years before we met, when Sara wrote a short story about the perfect marriage. It started like this: ____ and I are moving to Europe to paint and make love, right after he finishes his diamond floor. We will live in a gigantic home filled with magic and passion. One of our favorite things to do in the summer will be to drive our 68 Ferrari to the end of Italy and take a boat to a tiny island with nothing on it. There, we will have a picnic at sunset, fall asleep with blankets and small furs and wake up in the morning and go home.

title: Naps May Improve Our Frustration Tolerance
description: A short nap could reduce impulsive behavior and improve the ability to withstand frustration, a small study suggests.

title: 1965 | Heres the Pope. Wheres the Paper?
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: Keeping a Tugboat Afloat
description: Good morning on this ticker-tapey Friday.

title: Google Search Chief Amit Singhal Talks Searching Apps
description: Amit Singhal, Googles search chief, has spent the past 15 years creating the miracle that is the Google search box. Now, as he and his team face a shifting landscape in which phones and apps are starting to rival computers and websites, he is in a race to make Google the Google of Apps.

title: BritainsDangerous New Tribalism
description: LONDON  This past week marked the 10th anniversary of the 7/7 attacks in London. On July 7, 2005, 52 people were killed when four suicide bombers detonated explosive devices on subways and buses. There were commemorations across the nation to honor the victims, including a ceremony of remembrance at the 7/7 memorial in Hyde Park and a service at St. Pauls Cathedral.

title: Stampede inBangladesh Kills at Least 23 at Clothing Handout
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  At least 23 people, all women and children, were killed in a stampede Friday morning in a district north of here, after a large crowd gathered for clothes that were being donated during the month of Ramadan, the police said.

title: Today in Politics: Presidential Race Takes Shape and Offers Hints of Things to Come
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where Congress took up the debate over the Confederate battle flag and where former President Jimmy Carter can still draw a crowd in the rain. While the summer election cycle has seemed to be mostly about adding a new candidate every few days, this week offered a look at some story lines that are bound to endure.

title: The 6.28.15 Issue
description: RE: PSYCHOANALYSIS

title: After a New Moon
description: In troubled times, poems can offer a kind of solace. Reading this one, I am reminded that even the darkness of difficult knowledge is a shared experience, that we are not alone in joy or in despair.

title: The Bicycle Thief
description: Ive been living in Japan for two years, and I pretty much know all the rules. Laws, customs, etiquette, that kind of thing. I never blow my nose in public, and I always remember to take off my shoes, though at first I would forget. That felt really embarrassing, so I learned quickly.

title: Tenniss Top Women Balance Body Image With Ambition
description: WIMBLEDON, England  While most celebrities go incognito behind a hat and sunglasses, Serena Williams uses a different tactic to blend into a crowd: long sleeves.

title: Not Like Us
description: They were criminals  thugs and thieves  a single ethnic group that filled the jails of big cities. Scum unloaded on American wharves, one speaker in Philadelphia said of them. Dirty, filthy, foreign. As for their children, they were utterly ignorant of a place such as school, The New York Herald reported.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Hangovers
description: I used to loathe hangovers. I used to keep my bedside table stacked with bananas, Pedialyte, do-it-yourself guides to bootleg saline. Home from nights out, I used to dis- and replace fluids with the verve of an undertaker. I tried every which way to delay the inevitable. Still I woke up hung over, of course. Blanched in the a.m. sun, feeling like death, I used to offer up that childish, transactional petition: I promise Ill never do this again if you just make it hurt less.

title: How to Conduct an Auction
description: Its the sound that sells, says Brandon Neely, describing an auctioneers hard-driving patter. Strive for a melodic chant that lulls your audience, even as it pushes them into fast-paced bidding wars. Potential buyers should be able to sit and listen to you all day without getting agitated, says Neely, 29, of Southside, Ala., who auctions cattle, vehicles and farm equipment and was recently named this years winner at the World Livestock Auctioneer Championship in Clifton, Tex.

title: How Does Paul Rudd Work?
description: On a Friday night in May, I met Paul Rudd to see a play on Broadway. In advancing the task of examining his fundamental Ruddness, I thought a shared activity would provide us something to talk about beyond the mandatory promotional patter. (Which is this: He is starring in the newest Marvel movie, Ant-Man, out July 17.) Rudd suggested Fun Home, the musical based on a graphic memoir by Alison Bechdel, which deals with topics like parenting, queer theory and Chippendale furniture.

title: A Living Wage for Caregivers
description: Marlene Juarez worked as a nanny for a family near Boston, taking care of four children ranging in age from 6 months to 6 years old; she organized play dates, cooked, did laundry and cleaned a large house. Both parents worked full time and in some weeks asked Juarez to work as many as 60 or 70 hours. Juarez had recently emigrated from Honduras, and was afraid to complain. She couldnt afford to lose her job. But, once, she requested a few hours off to deal with a personal matter  and in response, her employers docked her pay.

title: Going Off the Grid on a Swedish Island
description: I needed a break.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 5 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its fifth week. To participate, just post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 17 and answer the question What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: An Iraq Veterans Homecoming, With Arias
description: Early in the opera adaptation of The Long Walk, Brian Castners dark memoir of his tour as a bomb-disposal officer in Iraq and his struggles with anxiety and brain injury after returning home, the performance signals that it will build on the original accounts claustrophobic exploration of what its protagonist calls, with a convincing mix of detail and bluntness, his Crazy.

title: Greeces Latest Proposal
description: This is the text of the proposed actions that Greece submitted to its European creditors on Thursday. It lists a series of measures that the nation would undertake in exchange for a new bailout plan.

title: Morning Agenda: Greece Accepts Austerity Measures
description: GREECE ACCEPTS AUSTERITY MEASURES | European markets rallied again on Friday after Greece submitted proposals that appeared to accept the austerity measures that its creditors wanted,  David Jolly and Liz Alderman write in The New York Times. On Thursday, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece sought a three-year bailout loan totaling 53.5 billion euros, or about $59 billion, and asked for the countrys European creditors to commit to a discussion about debt relief, which has been a major sticking point in the bailout talks,  Ms. Alderman and James Kanter write in The New York Times. Germanys finance minister, Wolfgang Schuble, finally softened his stance on that issue on Thursday, admitting that debt sustainability is not feasible without a haircut, although he then appeared to backtrack.

title: Hollande Supports Greeces Proposals
description: President Franois Hollande of France hailed the offer of the Greek prime minister Alexis Tsipras on Friday, calling it serious and credible.

title: Mitch McConnells Commitment to Civil Rights Sets Him Apart
description: WASHINGTON  Last spring, Marc H. Morial, the president of the National Urban League, found himself in a place he has come to know well over the years, across a desk from Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, talking about public policy.

title: An Adult Stepson Moves In, and a Solid Family Wobbles
description: Mom, can I have some money to go out? asked my 21-year-old-son, Tracey, after our first family dinner together in four years. My husband gave me a look that said, You dont have the money to give him. We just fed him out of a budget hes not in yet.

title: A Son Given Up for Adoption Is Found After Half a Century, and Then Lost Again
description: On a rainy spring evening last year, Margaret Erle Katz noticed a voice mail from an unfamiliar area code and dismissed it as a message from a telemarketer. A day later, though, she listened. And listened, and listened.

title: Charles Johnson Discusses Middle Passage at 25
description: What Charles Johnson has  and can do with it  is much easier to say than to replicate or imitate. Thats Stanley Crouch in his introduction to the recently published 25th-anniversary edition of Middle Passage, the novel for which Mr. Johnson won the National Book Award in 1990.

title: Putin Calls for End to Use of Sanctions and Criticizes U.S. in Afghanistan
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on Friday for an end to the use of punitive financial and economic sanctions around the world, saying they should be excluded from the international economic vocabulary.

title: Valentinos Roman Legion
description: ROME  Coutures grand tour came to an end Thursday night in Rome, after having landmark-hopped through Paris: the Bourse, the Muse Rodin, the Thtre des Champs-lyses and various parts of the Grand Palais (to name a few of the venues).

title: John Berry to Step Down as Artistic Director of English National Opera
description: John Berry, the artistic director of the English National Opera, one of Londons two major opera companies, will leave after 20 years at the organization, it was announced on Friday.

title: Video Reviews of Minions, Self/less and Tangerine
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Minions, Self/less and Tangerine. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: At Coney Island With Grandma
description: Dear Diary:

title: Obamacare Flexes Muscles With New Medicare Payment Plans
description: For the first time, the Obama administration has deployed an important new power it has under the Affordable Care Act: proposing to pay doctors and hospitals based on the quality of care they provide, regardless of whether they want to be paid that way.

title: Are the Lessons of Srebrenica Being Forgotten?
description: WASHINGTON  AMIRS voice, patched through to the United Nations base in Tuzla from the eastern Bosnian enclave in Srebrenica, was faint, but his fear came through in nauseating clarity. It was July 1995, and the Dutch battalion sent to protect the United Nations-designated safe area around Srebrenica had collapsed after United Nations officials refused to call for concerted NATO airstrikes.

title: Jeb Bush Draws on Family Dynasty for Fund-Raising Efforts
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me.  Maybe it was the sunset selfies on the lawn at Walkers Point, the family compound, with the state flags of Texas and Maine fluttering in the salty breeze.

title: Living in a Barn, Without the Hay
description: What do you do when you find yourself envying your horses? You go out and get a barn of your own.

title: Chinese Authorities Appear to Detain 4 Human Rights Lawyers
description: HONG KONG  The police detained one of Chinas most prominent human rights lawyers in Beijing on Friday, after three other rights lawyers who worked together disappeared in the capital within 24 hours, apparently caught in an expanding investigation focused on their firm, their colleagues and family members said.

title: U.N., Warning of Migrant Crisis in Greece, Urges Europe to Act
description: GENEVA  The United Nations warned on Friday that Greece and its Balkan neighbors were being overwhelmed by the flood of migrants arriving from Syria and other areas of conflict, and it urged European countries to step forward with aid to avert a looming humanitarian crisis.

title: Building Attention Span
description: If youre like most of us, youre wondering what the Internet is doing to your attention span. You toggle over to check your phone during even the smallest pause in real life. You feel those phantom vibrations even when no one is texting you. You have trouble concentrating for long periods.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Said to Seek Licensing Deals for Music Videos
description: Over the last few years, Facebook has slowly encroached on YouTubes territory as a go-to outlet for online video, showing popular content from publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice and a growing number of user-loaded clips. Now Facebook is considering going after another piece of YouTubes signature turf: music videos, Mike Isaac and Ben Sisario report.

title: Chris Christies First Television Ad Goes Up for New Hampshire Viewers
description: Gov. Chris Christie will be showing his first television ad of the cycle in the same place he spent his first week as a candidate: New Hampshire.

title: Austerity and the Greek Depression
description: Olivier Blanchard offers a defense of the IMFs role in the Greek crisis. Basically, he argues that given the political realities, there was no alternative to requiring that Greece move into primary budget surplus, whatever the cost. This is surely true.

title: Readers on Donald Trump: Bigot, Patriot, or Frankensteins Monster?
description: Donald Trump, many readers say, has exposed a Republican id of racism and xenophobia that has long succeeded for the party as an implied message.

title: George W. Bush Recalls Putins My Dog Is Stronger Style of Diplomacy
description: George W. Bush may have famously said that he got a sense of Vladimir Putins soul, but he also got a sense of his pooch.

title: The Moment the Confederate Flag Was Lowered in South Carolina
description: On June 17, a white man entered a church in Charleston, S.C., and killed nine black people during a prayer meeting.

title: 1915: Mexican War Carried to Paris
description: The Herald has lately published communications from the representatives in Paris of General Villa and General Carranza, respectively, which indicate some of the difficulties which the present tangled situation in Mexico presents for foreigners. The representative of General Villa raised the question by issuing a note to the press in which he assailed Senor Isidro Fabela, General Carranzas agent for occupying without right the Mexican Legation in Paris and calling himself the Mexican Minister.

title: Web Chief Joshua Topolsky to Leave Bloomberg as Staff Tensions Surface
description: Earlier this year, after Michael Bloomberg reasserted control over the company he founded and began to scrutinize its online operations, he suggested in a meeting that perhaps Bloomberg  which makes the overwhelming majority of its money from desk terminals that provide financial data  did not need to have a website.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Southwold, England

title: American Mens Wear, Dizzyingly Reimagined
description: In honor of the inaugural New York Fashion Week: Mens, which begins Monday, the photographer Erik Madigan Heck has created a whimsical series around 16 of the designers showing there. His exhibition of explosively colorful photographs  featuring pieces by John Varvatos, Calvin Klein Collection and Ovadia & Sons  will open at Amazon Fashions studio in Williamsburg on Monday, before it moves to the fashion-week hub at Skylight Clarkson Square later in the week. I felt I had a responsibility to create a fresh work that really celebrates each designers distinct point of view, regardless of my own personal taste, says Heck. In the end, I think that makes the work more interesting  to show whatever detail was most important, even if its only a seam.

title: Upgrading a Deck to Avoid Headaches and Bump Up Home Value
description: AT its most basic, a deck is an extension of your house. You open your door, walk outside and there you are in what feels like an outdoor room.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: South Carolina Removes Confederate Flag
description: Watch the scene in Columbia, S.C., as the Confederate battle flag was removed from the State House grounds on Friday.

title: Hip-Hops Silent Majority
description: Hip-hops mainstream can often be confused with prosperity gospel, so its striking that in 2015, at least a couple of the genres biggest selling stars want nothing to do with such narratives.

title: Japans New Satellite Captures an Image of Earth Every 10 Minutes
description: Images from the Himawari-8 weather satellites first official day paint a living portrait of Earth.

title: The Appeal of Credit Union Mortgages
description: More than 100 million Americans are members of credit unions, and not just because they want inexpensive checking. These nonprofit lenders are increasingly winning over borrowers with low-cost mortgages and programs aimed at first-time home buyers.

title: Omar Sharif, 83, a Star in Lawrence of Arabia and Doctor Zhivago, Dies
description: Omar Sharif, the Egyptian actor who rode out of the desert in the 1962 screen epic Lawrence of Arabia into a glamorous if brief reign as an international star in films like Doctor Zhivago and The Night of the Generals, died on Friday in Cairo. He was 83.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Screen Addiction, Bullies and Love Life
description: Take the Quiz

title: Photo Firehose: World Cup Parade
description: A real-time stream of images from the parade in New York City to honor the United States womens soccer team by photographers for The New York Times and spectators at the parade.

title: Student Loan Co-Signers Face a Tangled Path to a Release
description: Most students who take out private educational loans for college end up with a co-signer to help assure the lender that the loan will be paid if the borrower runs into financial trouble. But having the co-signer removed later can be a challenge.

title: Masters of Sex Returns for Season 3, Children in Tow
description: Lets be honest: Kids ruin everything. And there are alarming signs in the early going of Season 3 that they might ruin Masters of Sex.

title: A Star Trek Future Might Be Closer Than We Think
description: Set against some of the biggest sci-fi franchises of the last five years, many of which imagine the future as a wreckage in which the strong prey relentlessly upon the weak, Star Trek can seem kind of quaint. After all, the show, especially in its second and strongest incarnation, The Next Generation, takes place in a time when, essentially, everything has worked out.

title: Back on the Grid, and Sorting Through Reader Complaints
description: Updated July 10, 2015, 6 p.m.

title: Making Decisions on Elder Housing May Take a Team Effort
description: AFTER her husbands death in 2007, Mary Jane Renninger, a retired nurse, began having occasional dizzy spells and even passed out on one occasion as she was painting her patio. She was not found until 12 hours later.

title: The Inconceivable Success of Obamacare
description: Yesterday, for my sins, I went to Freedomfest, the libertarian conclave in Las Vegas, to debate Stephen Moore of the Heritage Foundation. It went pretty much as you might expect: evidence, evidence, evidence versus Reagan, Reagan, Reagan. But in a way the most interesting thing was the audience reaction when I described Obamacare as a major success story so far: boos and hissing.

title: Stories
description: MAKING NICEBy Matt Sumell223 pp. Holt, $25.

title: Middle Passage at 25
description: What Charles Johnson has  and can do with it  is much easier to say than to replicate or imitate. Thats Stanley Crouch in his introduction to the recently published 25th-anniversary edition of Middle Passage, the novel for which Johnson won the National Book Award in 1990.

title: Immunity, by Taylor Antrim
description: What is it about shiny, clean, contemporary New York that inspires writers to evoke it wrecked, dangerous and falling apart? Does a certain sickness settle in at the sight of another branch bank? An anomie at the word artisanal or the discovery of an undercover J. Crew? Gotham is expensive, clean, incredibly safe and full of Chipotles. Without anyone quite catching the switch  heres the fear  rock n roll has become middle management.

title: Midnights Furies, by Nisid Hajari
description: Few books need more urgently to be written than a definitive oral history of the 1947 partition of India. The partition, even by the standards of a bloody century, was hideous; it left between one and two million people dead and displaced 15 million others; it caused the dismemberment of a syncretic society and led to the largest forced migration in the history of humanity. The generation that lived through that terrible time is on its way out, taking its unrecorded memories.

title: Kevin Kwans China Rich Girlfriend
description: Proudhon said, Property is theft; Balzac said, Behind great fortunes without apparent cause lies a crime forgotten.

title: Circling the Square: Stories From the Egyptian Revolution, by Wendell Steavenson
description: In early 2011, Egypt seemed to be on the verge of a radical transformation. A popular uprising brought down the president and turned Cairos Tahrir Square into a ramshackle utopia, a fairground of poetry recitations, Muslim-Christian solidarity and volunteer sanitation workers. The protesters were brave, idealistic, unarmed and media-savvy. Many were young and beautiful. But they werent experienced in practical politics. After their chief demand  Hosni Mubaraks removal from power  was met, they had few plans for what came next.

title: Summerlong, by Dean Bakopoulos
description: Sex. In fiction, as in life, it is a great catalyst, setting knickers and plots atwist.
