Also as in life, the sex in fiction, especially that had by adults behaving badly, is often far less interesting than the underlying tensions and motives that led to the bad behavior in the first place.

title: A Dog Day, Ask Me and Sidewalk Flowers
description: Grown-ups may need occasional reminders, but children know that any journey can be as exciting as its destination. In three new picture books, even a casual stroll brings a world of unexpected pleasures, providing ample time for playing, bonding and spontaneous acts of generosity.

title: Fort and The Secrets of Blueberries, Brothers, Moose & Me
description: For many children, the itchy summertime pleasures of the outdoors have been replaced by air-conditioned hours in front of a screen. But two new middle-grade novels offer young readers a sampling of classic summer adventure  and may even tempt them to leave the house and find excitement out in the natural world.

title: Nimona, by Noelle Stevenson
description: In an unnamed fantasy kingdom, the villain in residence is Ballister Blackheart, formerly a good knight in training, who lost his arm in an accident. Heroes dont have mechanical prosthetics, so Ballister decides to do the logical thing and become a villain. And what villain doesnt benefit from a sidekick? Unannounced, Nimona arrives, a helpful, motivated shapeshifting girl who wants nothing more than to see Ballisters evil plans succeed.

title: Shadowshaper, by Daniel Jos Older
description: In the best urban fantasy, the city is not just a backdrop, but functions as a character in its own right, offering up parallels between personal histories and histories of place. That is certainly true in Daniel Jos Olders magnificent Shadowshaper, which gives us a Brooklyn that is vital, authentic and under attack.

title: 3 New National Monuments Are Established by Obama
description: President Obama announced on Friday that he was designating new national monuments covering more than a million acres in California, Texas and Nevada, his latest use of executive power to preserve public land.

title: Event for Donald Trump in Phoenix Will Draw Thousands
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate mogul who has tied Republicans in knots in recent weeks with his comments on immigration, will roll into Phoenix on Saturday to address the issue again, just after the head of the Republican Party supposedly asked him to tone down his words on the issue.

title: Goldman Names Roopesh Shah to Lead Restructuring Group
description: Goldman Sachs has appointed a new leader of its restructuring practice after one of the teams top bankers left for a rival investment bank.

title: Lets Have a Parade
description: Spectators take up position to watch New Yorks first ticker-tape parade for a womens sports team.

title: John LeFevres Memoir of Banking Debauchery Elicits Mostly Yawns
description: It turned out that John LeFevre was not only never a Goldman Sachs employee, he didnt work at any investment bank when he started the notorious anonymous Twitter account @GSElevator  which stands for Goldman Sachs elevator  in 2011. Whats more, he had not worked in New York at all for almost a decade, although he previously worked his way up to a midlevel position on the Citigroup debt syndicate desk. For all but a brief period after his analyst training program, Mr. LeFevre was relegated to a series of international Citigroup outposts. So when his identity was revealed, it surprised no one that his lucrative book contract was canceled.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHISKEY TANGO FOXTROT, by David Shafer. (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $16.) Vivid, witty prose animates this thriller, which explores the uneasy links between government surveillance and personal privacy. Shafers characters confront a shadowy cabal of powerful media magnates seeking control of the worlds data.

title: Pozole Verde for a Fresh Summertime Meal
description: If you happen to be in a Mexican town on a warm summer night, head for the spot where street vendors set up for the evening and let your nose guide you past the tacos and empanadas and tamales to the fragrant steaming pozole stand.

title: Wimbledon 2015: Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer Set Up Rematch in Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  With each gorgeous passing shot and fist pump from Andy Murray, the noise and energy at Centre Court surged. Murray was engaged in a critical fight to stay alive in the second set of his match with Roger Federer, and he was producing the daring, line-kissing shots to do it.

title: The Dream World of the Southern Republicans
description: UNLIKE previous Alabama governors, Robert J. Bentley is not a fount of oratory. Nor is he a champion of kinder and gentler. His dyspeptic refusal to accept federal funds for Medicaid expansion, in a state where more than one million of 4.8 million residents depend on the program, betokens a stunning indifference to the Hippocratic oath. (The governor is a dermatologist.) Yet Mr. Bentley recently took a page from the Obama playbook and used a surprise executive order to remove four Confederate flags from the Alabama Capitol grounds, not far from the very spot where Jefferson Davis was sworn in as president of the Confederacy.

title: Inside the List
description: Best Regards: The German novelist Nina George is prolific: In the 22 years since she started her career at age 19, she has written almost 30 books, including mysteries, relationship guides and steamy romances. (Americans get all finicky when it comes to the graphic nature of my erotic scenes, she has said. They prefer to leave a lot of it up to the imagination: more Barbie doll sexlessness, less Anas Nin eroticism.) But with The Little Paris Bookshop, new at No. 16 on the hardcover fiction list, George has her first bona fide international hit, the tale of a lovelorn bookseller who peddles his wares from a barge on the Seine and sees his calling as one part matchmaker, one part witch doctor. There are books that are suitable for a million people, others for only a hundred, he explains. There are even remedies  I mean books  that were written for one person only. The novels success has introduced George, happily, to the world of international publishing, as she describes at some length on her website: The captains and navigators in publishing are women! From agents to list managers, women negotiate with other women on everything from money and content to sales, she writes. The agents and publishers always sign their first names to their emails: Vanessa, Cecile, Mirjam. From New York to Paris, they write: Best regards/Yours, Christine, Rowan, Anna, Hedda, Elise. They discuss money with the cold clarity of a glass of vodka. No dancing around the issue as is so often the case in Germany. Whats even more cathartic, though, is the praise Ive received from Cecile, Rowan, Anna, Hedda and Christine. No praise for my work has ever been as profuse and sincere as the compliments Ive received from these foreign publishers in Paris, New York, Rome, Amsterdam and Riga. First they bought my book, then they wrote me long letters explaining what they liked about it. I suspect the reluctance to compliment authors and their novels is a typically German phenomenon. What if it makes the author too expensive? Or if the accolades go to her head? Or if she becomes, somehow, too difficult to work with? Nonsense! Bring on the praise, my dear German book people! It is pure joy.

title: George W. Bush Hopes Jeb Bush and Hillary Clinton Elevate the Discourse
description: In his appearance in Texas with Bill Clinton on Thursday, George W. Bush called for an elevated political discourse in the 2016 presidential campaign, defended his difficult wartime decisions, and said he did not plan to campaign for his brother Jeb Bush.

title: Editors Choice
description: SOMETHING MUST BE DONE ABOUT PRINCE EDWARD COUNTY: A Family, a Virginia Town, a Civil Rights Battle, by Kristen Green. (Harper, $25.99.) Avoiding integration in 1959: private schools for whites, no school at all for blacks.

title: Bipartisan Partnership Produces a Health Bill That Passes the House
description: WASHINGTON  By the standards of the modern Congress, Representatives Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, and Diana DeGette, Democrat of Colorado, have no business writing health care legislation together.

title: Why a Teenage Bank Teller May Have the Best Summer Job
description: Everyone should work as a bank teller at least once in their lives.

title: Finding Slight Suburbia in Stamford, Conn.
description: Unlike many of her friends, Bridget Biederman doesnt commute to an office. As a saleswoman for a biotech company, she uses her car as her office. And when she isnt on the road, she works from home.

title: The Boston Symphony and Steven Beck Entice Concertgoers
description: When the weather cooperates, the free Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park draw overflow crowds, for both the outdoor ambience and fresh programming. Next, the acclaimed Boston Symphony Chamber Players perform Mozarts Oboe Quartet, Carl Nielsens Wind Quintet and a novelty: Brahmss Serenade No. 1 for Winds and Strings (best known as his First Serenade for Orchestra, presented in Alan Bousteads 1988 reconstruction of an earlier chamber version). With seats set up for 1,000 early arrivers, the Naumburg Bandshell makes an inviting concert space. (7:30 p.m., Tuesday, Central Park, naumburgconcerts.org.)

title: The Amazing Acro-Cats Visit New York
description: George Balanchine used to say that in Mourka, his beloved white-and-orange alley cat, he had a body worth choreographing for. (As documented in Tanaquil Le Clercqs book featuring Martha Swopes photographs of the feline charmer, Mourka did possess delightful ballon.) In The Amazing Acro-Cats, a troupe of rescues and strays led by the Chicago animal trainer Samantha Martin roll on balls, soar through the air in long and high jumps, push shopping carts, and leap through hoops. The finale is a six-cat band, better known as the Rock Cats; Tuna, on cowbell, is the shows star. Acro-Cats, which makes its New York debut, was first presented in an art gallery in 2006.

title: Kelly Clarkson Takes Her Tour to Holmdel, N.J., and Radio City Music Hall
description: The next season of American Idol, its 15th, will also be its last. Naturally, that will occasion all sorts of think pieces about the shows success stories, its influence and its staying power. All of those pieces can pre-emptively be replaced with just two words: Kelly Clarkson. She was the winner of the shows first season, in 2002, but more important, she was a transcendently good and totally unknown singer: the proof of concept Idol needed to continue bushwhacking through the country for more than a decade trying to recapture that first high. That model has collapsed, for now, but Ms. Clarkson remains  not quite the reliable hitmaker she was five or 10 years ago, but still one of the most technically precise executors in pop. Shes lasted this long because Idol couldnt have predicted the sort of pop star she would become: bombastic, demure, aggrieved, flamboyantly talented but awww-shucks modest. (Tuesday, PNC Bank Arts Center, Holmdel, N.J.; Thursday and Friday, Radio City Music Hall.)

title: Sex&Drugs&Rock&Roll Begins on FX
description: When we first meet Johnny Rock (Denis Leary), he has just mistaken dishwashing detergent for cocaine. Never mind: Hes on a perpetual high as the frontman for the Heathens, a 90s band set for stardom with its debut album. But on the day of its release, the band breaks up. Something about Johnnys having sex with the wife of the lead guitarist, Flash (John Corbett).

title: Peter Jacksons Heavenly Creatures at Film Forum
description: In 1994, after his indulgent splatterfest Dead Alive and long before he became the auteur of Middle-earth, Peter Jackson recounted a case of matricide in the 1950s in Christchurch, New Zealand. That film, Heavenly Creatures  playing Friday in Film Forums True Crime series  offered the feature debuts of Kate Winslet and the indie stalwart Melanie Lynskey and earned Mr. Jackson and his wife, Fran Walsh, Oscar nominations for their poignant script.

title: The Problem With a Euro Fix: Whats in It for the Dutch?
description: Economists agree: If the eurozone does not break up, it will have to move closer together. Theyre right. But its easy to understand why Europeans are not eager to heed their advice.

title: Levine Withdraws From Verbier Festival
description: James Levine has canceled his planned return to Europe after several years in which ill health kept him away, withdrawing from the opening concert of the Verbier Festival in Switzerland next week due to what festival officials described Friday as a serious ear infection which prevents him from flying.

title: Popcast: Hip-Hops Silent Majority
description: Hip-hops mainstream can often be confused with prosperity gospel, so its striking that in 2015, at least a couple of the genres biggest selling stars  Kendrick Lamar and J. Cole  want nothing to do with such narratives.

title: Omar Sharifs Best-Known Roles
description: The Egyptian-born actor Omar Sharif died on Friday at the age of 83. He is best known for his roles in the films Lawrence of Arabia and Doctor Zhivago.

title: As Superheroes Go, Ant-Man Was Always a Wimp
description: In the Marvel Comics big bang of the early 1960s that brought forth memorable characters like the Fantastic Four, the Amazing Spider-Man and the Mighty Thor, Ant-Man always seemed like a mortified orphan. Thor was an Asgardian god; Ant-Man had the strength of a regular joe. Spidey reveled in snappy repartee; Ant-Man cooed to ants. The Things catch phrase was Its clobberin time! Ant-Man was never known to shriek, Its shrinkin time!

title: Katherine Archuleta, Director of Personnel Agency, Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  Katherine Archuleta, the director of the Office of Personnel Management, resigned under pressure on Friday, one day after the government revealed that two sweeping cyberintrusions at the agency had resulted in the theft of the personal information of more than 22 million people, including those who had applied for sensitive security clearances.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include East Village and Crown Heights condos, and a co-op in Inwood.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Bookshelf: All in the Family
description: New picture books include One Family and My Family Tree and Me.

title: Yellen Expects Fed to Raise Rates This Year
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that she expected the Fed to raise its benchmark interest rate this year as the domestic economy continued to gain strength.

title: Omar Sharif, the Star of Doctor Zhivago, Dies at 83
description: Born in Egypt, Mr. Sharif earned an Oscar nomination in his first English-language film, Lawrence of Arabia.

title: Migrants Flood Greek Island of Lesbos
description: Thousands of migrants came ashore this summer on the Greek island of Lesbos, a popular tourist destination. Some of them had to walk more than 40 miles to get to the main port of Mytilene.

title: Dish Suit Shows Close Ties Between Executive and Board Members
description: Cozy corporate boards, populated by a chief executives pals, are an all-too-common hazard of investing in a publicly owned company. But rarely do stockholders get an inside look at the ties between board members and the chief executives they are supposed to supervise.

title: Statehood Is the Only Antidote for What Ails Puerto Rico
description: WASHINGTON  PUERTO RICOS governor recently claimed that the island could not pay all its debts. In the media, comparisons to Greece abound. But if Puerto Rico were a patient, then most commentators would have been misdiagnosing its illness and recommending improper treatment. A dose of reality is in order.

title: Witness Describes Stampede in Bangladesh
description: At least 23 people were killed in a stampede Friday morning during a clothing giveaway in central Bangladesh.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: A Fruit Salad Both Sweet and Spicy
description: Fruit salad may not seem like the kind of dish that warrants a recipe, since a perfectly fine one can be made by chopping up whatever ripe fruit youve got and mixing it in a bowl.

title: Pete Rose at the Corn Crib: Next Stop, the All-Star Game
description: NORMAL, Ill.  Of all the promotional events this year at the Corn Crib, the ballpark for the Normal CornBelters of central Illinois, nothing could match Thursday nights draw: the banished first child of Major League Baseball.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Michael B. Orens Ally
description: This week, Jacob Heilbrunn discusses Michael B. Orens Ally; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Julia Pierpont talks about her debut novel, Among the Ten Thousand Things; questions from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Trying On, Selling and Stealing Sneakers, One Shoe at a Time
description: Never has buying, selling or stealing a pair of sneakers in Brooklyn been this complicated.

title: For Jim Gaffigan and TV Land, Home Is Where the Har-Har Is
description: Jim Gaffigan was tired, and for good reason. This is a picture I took at 3:30 this morning, he said as he slumped across a couch during a break in filming his new TV Land show on a soundstage near Madison Square Garden. He pushed his phone forward and showed a picture of himself and his wife, Jeannie, in bed, trying to sleep, despite having three of their five young children draped all over them. The seven Gaffigans share a two-bedroom apartment on the Lower East Side. Its a scenario tailor-made for a sitcom.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a four-bedroom house with a pool in Plandome, N.Y., and a three-bedroom ranch in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Paul Rudds Scientific-Sounding Guide to Ants
description: Mr. Rudd is playing one of the tiniest superheroes ever seen on screen, but hes impressed by ants skills and variety.

title: Background Check Flaw Let Dylann Roof Buy Gun, F.B.I. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The man accused of killing nine people in a historically black church in South Carolina last month was able to buy the gun used in the attack because of a breakdown in the federal gun background check system, the F.B.I. said Friday.

title: Greeces Parliament Approves Prime Ministers Bailout Plan
description: ATHENS  Setting the stage for a pivotal deal with Europe, the Greek Parliament early Saturday approved Prime Minister Alexis Tsiprass proposal for a three-year, $59 billion rescue package with harsh austerity terms that was remarkably similar to the one Greek voters rejected in a referendum less than a week ago.

title: A Photographer Finds Symmetry in Gardens and Galaxies
description: MEXICO CITY  Facing the entrance, an unmarked metal door, of Anonymous Gallery are two photographic prints by Todd Eberle, each big, brilliantly colored and symmetrical  somewhere between a Rorschach image and the view inside a kaleidoscope.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Michael B. Orens Ally
description: This week, Jacob Heilbrunn and Julia Pierpont.

title: Donna Karan Departs, Matt Damon May or May Not Need a Haircut and the Ladies Love Soccer
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: 1940: Pots and Pans for Defense
description: The British government requests that women contribute to the nations defense by collecting salvage in 1940. The video has no sound. (britishpathe.com).

title: Interim Agreement With Iran Is Extended as Negotiations Continue
description: VIENNA  An interim nuclear agreement between Iran and six major world powers has been extended through Monday so that negotiators have more time to pursue a final accord, the State Department announced on Friday.

title: Turkey Arrests 21 Suspected ISIS Members
description: Turkish police on Friday arrested 21 suspected Islamic State operatives.

title: Unplugged in a Swedish Hermit Hut
description: Gotland, a remote island in the Baltic Sea, provides an exotic escape from the digital world.

title: A Shattered Adam Statue Comes to Life at the Met
description: What if Adam could talk? Not just any Adam, but the 15th-century marble statue that crashed to the floor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art  all 6 feet 3 inches of him  one dismal October evening in 2002. The Adam that was recently, after a 12-year restoration project, installed in a special gallery for Venetian sculpture of the Renaissance. What might he say?

title: Simon Armitage, Oxford Poetry Professor, Finds Inspiration in the Mundane
description: WAKEFIELD, England  POUNDLAND is a low-end variety store chain in Britain, sort of like a dollar store in the United States. It is also the title of a poem Simon Armitage published last year, a contemporary take on The Odyssey.

title: How to Throw a Clambake
description: Chef Karsten Hart of Castle Hill Inn in Rhode Island shares tips and a recipe.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: More Greeks Looking to Work Abroad, Search Engines Suggest
description: Whatever is decided during this weekends negotiations between Greece and its creditors, Greek workers are planning their own kind of exit. At least, thats the message that comes from analyzing their online job search behavior.

title: Omar Sharif, Star of Doctor Zhivago, Dies at 83
description: An Egyptian actor with a commanding presence on screen, Mr. Sharif starred in films such as Lawrence of Arabia and Dr. Zhivago.

title: Bronx Museum Showcases (and Helps) Emerging Artists
description: For more than 30 years, the Bronx Museum of the Arts Artist in the Marketplace program has presented the work of emerging artists and provided them with professional-development guidance. Now the museum is showcasing their work in the third biennial of its kind. Titled Bronx Calling, the exhibition features sculpture, photography, installations, prints, collage, painting, performance, drawing, video and animation. Of the 72 artists participating this year, five  Nicholas Fraser, Sharon Ma, Rob Swainston, Rica Takashima and David Wilson  will also be developing site-specific artworks for FLOW.15, an outdoor art exhibition on Randalls Island aimed at fostering appreciation of the shoreline.

title: Book Review Podcast: Michael B. Orens Ally
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jacob Heilbrunn reviews Ally: My Journey Across the American-Israeli Divide, a remarkably frank memoir by Michael B. Oren, the former Israeli ambassador to the United States and current Knesset member. Mr. Heilbrunn writes:

title: Iran Opens Campaign to Lay Blame on U.S. if Nuclear Talks Fail
description: TEHRAN  As nuclear negotiations in Vienna grind on through deadline after deadline, Iranian officials have begun a public campaign to blame the United States in the event that the talks fail.

title: PartnerRe and Axis Capital Delay Shareholder Meetings on Merger
description: LONDON  The Bermuda insurance companies PartnerRe and Axis Capital said on Friday that they would delay for two weeks shareholder meetings to approve their merger so they could explore enhancing their agreement to combine in a so-called merger of equals.

title: Prison Investments That Can Help Society
description: Columbia Universitys prison break frees it to make a difference. Divesting from private jail companies could actually strengthen the Ivy League schools influence over a bloated American penal system. Alternative investments that pay off if inmate populations drop rather than rise can prompt fundamental change, with returns to society that are priceless.

title: U.S. Team Is Still on a Roll
description: A 360-degree view of the New York City parade honoring the United States womens soccer team.

title: Banks Living Wills Are Murky Guides
description: The big banks have filed another round of resolution plans for winding themselves down in a controlled fashion if they run into serious trouble, or so-called living wills. Only small pieces of the overall plans are available, but this bit is intended to give the general public some idea of the progress that has been made toward preventing banks from being too big to fail.

title: Republican Candidates Appeal to Anti-Abortion Groups
description: A half-dozen Republican candidates for president reassured members of one of the most influential anti-abortion groups on Friday that they favored further regulation and restriction of the procedure and that, if elected, they would be strong leaders on the issue.

title: Bill Clintons Candid Views of the Political Press
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons relations with the political news media had been tense long before she declared her candidacy in April, and her campaigns efforts to try and improve those relations have backfired at times.

title: At Tour de France, Mark Cavendish Sprints to Stage 7 Win
description: FOUGRES, France  Andr Greipel and Mark Cavendish, two of the leading sprinters at the Tour de France, began Fridays stage with the same problem. The crashes that have marred the opening week of the race had depleted the numbers of their teammates, whom they rely upon to wind up the pace before their final sprints.

title: New Walking Tours Explore Nashvilles Food Scene
description: Nashville is famous for its country music. But its food scene is hopping, too. The company Walk Eat Nashville offers tours of the city, with a new expansion exploring the restaurants and artisan food shops in the Midtown/Vanderbilt area, near Music Row, of Nashville. The neighborhood is known as the place where the citys culinary roots took hold, and includes upscale dining and down-home cooking, said Karen-Lee Ryan, the Walk Eat Nashville founder. Tastings at each location include discussions with chefs, owners and managers. I want people to connect to the food and the people who make it possible, she said.

title: Brooklyn Libraries, Development and Misdirected Fear
description: One day this month, various politicians and officials convened outside the Sunset Park Library on Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn to announce an affordable housing initiative, the cornerstone of which would seem to be any progressives cotton candy and rainbow vision. To accommodate the neighborhoods growing and largely immigrant population, the library would expand to nearly twice its current size as part of a project orchestrated by a nonprofit developer, the Fifth Avenue Committee, which would put 49 units of housing on top.

title: Debate Over Greek Debt Relief Begins With the Definition
description: FRANKFURT  Debt relief has emerged as a major sticking point in last-ditch negotiations to keep Greece from leaving the eurozone.

title: New Yorks Ticker-Tape Parade
description: Fans cheered the U.S. womens national soccer team in a parade through New Yorks Canyon of Heroes on Friday.

title: Its Not the Hours We Work, but the Energy We Put Into Them
description: I was in the middle of writing a column on Thursday about workaholism and overwork when Jeb Bush serendipitously appeared to set me straight. Americans dont work too much or too compulsively, he told The New Hampshire Union Leader. Rather, they dont work enough.

title: How Reshma Saujani, Founder of Girls Who Code, Spends Her Sundays
description: If Reshma Saujani had been elected New York City public advocate in 2013 (she ran in the Democratic primary), its unlikely that 1,200 rising high school juniors and seniors would be learning computer science this summer through the organization she founded, Girls Who Code. We scaled enormously since 2013 because I came back here and I gave this organization my 1,000 percent attention every day, said Ms. Saujani, 39, who lives in Chelsea with her husband, the 37-year-old tech entrepreneur Nihal Mehta, and their son, Shaan, born in February. This year the seven-week summer-intensive program is operating in nine cities, including New York, where about 250 girls will participate.

title: A Bold Proposal to Offer Greece Some Financial Relief
description: MUNICH  With time running short for Greece to meet a deadline to stay in the eurozone, a small but influential circle of debt experts are putting forward a provocative plan to persuade foreign investors to lend Greece the money it needs to survive.

title: An Art Collection Gathered From the Street and the Laundry
description: Madame Lint pulled out dozens of little plastic boxes stuffed with delicate, fuzzy accumulations that haphazardly formed into patterns not unlike Chinese dumplings.

title: Greg Hardys N.F.L. Suspension Is Reduced to 4 Games From 10
description: Dallas Cowboys defensive end Greg Hardy, who had to sit out almost all of last season because of a domestic violence conviction that was later overturned, will return to the field sooner than anticipated.

title: Nicky Hilton and James Rothschild: Designing a Lasting Partnership
description: Nicholai Olivia Hilton and James Amschel Victor Rothschild were married Friday on the grounds of Kensington Palace in London. The ceremony took place at the Orangery, a structure originally built in 1704 for Queen Anne as a greenhouse in the style of a palace to protect citrus trees from harsh winters.

title: The Top 10 Moments From Couture Week
description: Ts market director rounds up the most memorable things  from fur protests to a Lauryn Hill concert  that happened during the fall/winter 2015 shows.

title: Health Laws Contraceptive Rule Eased for Businesses With Religious Objections
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued new rules on Friday that allow closely held for-profit corporations like Hobby Lobby Stores to opt out of providing women with insurance coverage for contraceptives if the companies have religious objections.

title: Alexis Tsiprass Aggressive Game of Poker Pays Off, for Now
description: I have played poker with Alexis Tsipras.

title: Psychologists and Enhanced Interrogation
description: A 542-page report concludes that prominent psychologists worked closely with the C.I.A. to blunt dissent inside the agency over an interrogation program that is now known to have included torture. It also finds that officials at the American Psychological Association colluded with the Pentagon to make sure the associations ethics policies did not hinder the ability of psychologists to be involved in the interrogation program.

title: Outside Psychologists Shielded U.S. Torture Program, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agencys health professionals repeatedly criticized the agencys post-Sept. 11 interrogation program, but their protests were rebuffed by prominent outside psychologists who lent credibility to the program, according to a new report.

title: In Athens, Greeks Wonder Whether Tsipras Folded or Restored Dignity
description: ATHENS  Did Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras betray his principles and cave in to Greeces creditors? Or did he fight valiantly and succeed in establishing that his nations debt load is not sustainable and has to be reduced?

title: White House Healthy Lunchtime Challenge
description: Young chefs are treated to a state dinner at the White House with Michelle Obama.

title: White House Lunch Features Healthy Recipes by Young Chefs
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, a longtime food editor hatched an idea she thought might catch the fancy of Michelle Obama, the nations nutritionist in chief, who has spent a good deal of her tenure as first lady trying to encourage American children to improve their diets.

title: Fight Breaks Out During Mexican Congress
description: An altercation broke out between lawmakers during the middle of a session of Congress on Thursday in the southern Mexican state of Oaxaca. Fire extinguishers were used to break up the fight.

title: Yellen on Raising Interest Rates
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, in a speech on Friday in Cleveland, said the recovery remained incomplete.

title: A Final Hurdle in Iran Talks Deals With Conventional, Not Nuclear, Arms
description: VIENNA  One of the last major obstacles to concluding a historic nuclear deal with Iran is a dispute over a set of United Nations sanctions that appeared to be resolved months ago and only peripherally has to do with nuclear weapons.

title: Exclusive | 920 Fifth Avenue
description: The spacious co-op enters the market for the first time since 1985. The price is $12 million.

title: Why Are Our Parks So White?
description: SEATTLE  MOUNT RAINIER stands sentry over Seattle. On clear days, the mountain is the dominant backdrop, particularly in the citys southeast, where its most racially diverse neighborhoods embrace their majestic setting with names like Rainier Valley and Rainier Beach.

title: Fifth Avenue Duplex With a Touch of French Country
description: A spacious duplex co-op on the top residential floor of 920 Fifth Avenue, a 1922 James E .R. Carpenter-designed building with its entrance tucked away at 2 East 73rd Street, is about to enter the market for the first time since 1985, when the comedian Robert Klein chose to part with it. The asking price is $12 million.

title: New York City Salutes U.S. Womens Team
description: Images from Fridays ticker-tape parade and City Hall ceremony in Lower Manhattan, a first for a womens team in New York City.

title: New Names Join Familiar Faces on Academys Board of Governors
description: Four new members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, nine incumbents and three past members returning after a hiatus came up winners, as the Academy announced the results Friday of annual elections to its board of governors.

title: Big Ticket | Two Levels of Elegance
description: A residence at the landmark Plaza, with its own street-level entrance and private elevator, was the sale of the week.

title: Last Stop on the L Train: Detroit
description: Detroit, Just West of Bushwick, read the first billboard that popped up in Bushwick, Brooklyn, this spring, with a working class scene from one of Diego Riveras Detroit Industry murals. Detroit, Be Left Alone, a second one preached soon after, again in Bushwick. And then a third sign appeared, in two locations in Brooklyn and two in Manhattan  Detroit: Now Hiring.

title: Maisonette at the Plaza for $17.25 Million
description: An elegantly redesigned, two-level maisonette at the landmark Plaza, a short stroll from Central Park, with its own street-level entrance and private elevator, was sold by a Mexican businessman for $17,250,000 in an all-cash deal and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Setting Out on a Laughter-Filled Life
description: The wedding of the composer and writer Christopher Cerf and the writer Katherine Vaz at their Manhattan townhouse was the natural outcome of a relationship filled with fun.

title: Katherine Vaz and Christopher Cerf: Kermit Will Attend
description: The bride wore white. The groom wore Kermit the Frog.

title: Review: Ballet NY Presents a Premiere, Medhi Bahiris What Ever
description: One mission of Ballet NY is to support emerging choreographers. Yet this season, 18 years after its founding, this intimate company of seven hedges its bets on a more established crew. On Thursday at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, Ballet NY offered a premiere by Medhi Bahiri, who directs the company with Judith Fugate, and dances by William Forsythe, John Butler and Stanton Welch.

title: Empathy Is Actually a Choice
description: ONE death is a tragedy. One million is a statistic.

title: Review: A Young Cast for the Young Lovers of Madama Butterfly
description: At her wedding, early in Puccinis Madama Butterfly, Cio-Cio-San coyly answers a question from Sharpless, the American consul in Nagasaki, about her age. She is 15, she says, adding, Im already old.

title: Review: Todd Reynolds, Live and Recorded, at the Jewish Museum
description: Technically speaking, Thursdays performance by the violinist Todd Reynolds at the Jewish Museum was a solo recital. After all, there were no other performers, unless you count the video artist Luke Dubois, who created expressive projections, live, for some of the pieces. And yet what Mr. Reynolds conjured with the help of his violin, an array of electronic equipment and, occasionally, a foot-pedal-operated drum, sounded very much like chamber music. Call it echo-chamber music, if you like.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: What I Love | Jane Green
description: The British-born author shares her Westport, Conn., home with her husband, four of their combined six children, five cats and two dogs.

title: Jane Greens Creaky Cottage
description: Welcome to the creaky cottage on the creek. Our happy home.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: Bill Cunningham | Male Look
description: The tailored jacket remains the backbone.

title: Pictures of the Week: The Fourth of July and More
description: Some recent photographs.

title: Bill Cunningham | Male Look
description: Manufacturers and designers of mens wear are re-establishing a New York Mens Fashion Week, similar to Europes or what New York had decades ago. A clear picture of mens style shows up on New Yorks streets and at evening events. The tailored jacket remains the backbone. Any novelty is found in evening jacket fabrics and dashes of color. The no-sock idea has spread to red-carpet evenings.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Review: Thelonious is a Tap Tribute to a Musician
description: In Thelonious, written, directed, and choreographed by Sarah Petronio, friends gather in a Parisian apartment to listen to a radio program about the jazz pianist Thelonious Monk. Since they are tap dancers, they tap dance to the music. But they also sing along, like ordinary people who sort of know the words. Its a casual, low-key affair, and as performed at the Duke on 42nd Street on Thursday, during the American Tap Dance Foundations 15th annual Tap City festival, it was a simmering party that never came to a boil.

title: Ludovic Morlot Extends Contract With Seattle Symphony
description: The dynamic French conductor Ludovic Morlot has extended his contract as music director of the Seattle Symphony for two more years through August 2019, the orchestra announced Friday.

title: Sheriff in San Francisco Faults Federal Authorities After Killing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The sheriff of San Francisco, Ross Mirkarimi, is a political veteran who was once a rising star in the citys most liberal circles, a critic of many tough-on-crime policies who was admired by many of the citys immigrant-rights activists.

title: The Sport That Makes the Flag (and the Confetti) Fly
description: The championship women of United States soccer were showered with confetti and streamers and outright love on Friday as they became the first team of female athletes to be honored with a ticker-tape parade in the Canyon of Heroes in Lower Manhattan.

title: Comic-Con 2015: Why the Convention Stayed in San Diego
description: SAN DIEGO  With a sigh of relief and expressions of joy, San Diego Mayor Kevin L. Faulconer last week announced that Comic-Con International would remain in this city until at least 2018.

title: Court Observers Learn Stories Behind New Yorks Jaywalkers and Subway Scufflers
description: When Michael Gayed, a street vendor, appeared in Manhattan criminal court last month accused of violating Subsection 1-05(b) of Section 56 of the Rules of New York City, the person who spoke with him in most detail about the charges he was facing was not the judge, the prosecutor or even his own lawyer. It was a tall, bald man named Robert Gangi, who at the conclusion of the hearing followed Mr. Gayed from the dreary room at 111 Centre Street and approached him in a hallway.

title: Ojais Magnetic Pull
description: People, particularly people belonging to Generations X or Y, are responding to Ojai as a whole with a collective barbaric yawp.

title: Its Silicon Valley 2, Ellen Pao 0: Fighter of Sexism Is Out at Reddit
description: Ellen Pao became a hero to many when she took on the entrenched male-dominated culture of Silicon Valley. But sentiment is a fickle thing. Late Friday she fell victim to a crowd demanding her ouster as chief executive of the popular social media site Reddit.

title: Evening Hours | Summer Fireworks
description: Celebrating Independence Day, music, ballet and more.

title: Pictures of the Day: the United States and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the United States, Iran, Bolivia and elsewhere.

title: Battery-Powered Aviation
description: A first, twice.

title: July 10, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Iran, Bolivia and China.

title: Turkey Arrests 21 Suspected of Ties to ISIS
description: ISTANBUL  Under pressure from its Western allies to do more to combat Islamist extremists, the Turkish authorities arrested 21 suspected Islamic State members on Friday, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported.

title: Review: Harper Lees Go Set a Watchman Gives Atticus Finch a Dark Side
description: We remember Atticus Finch in Harper Lees 1960 classic, To Kill a Mockingbird, as that novels moral conscience: kind, wise, honorable, an avatar of integrity who used his gifts as a lawyer to defend a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman in a small Alabama town filled with prejudice and hatred in the 1930s. As indelibly played by Gregory Peck in the 1962 movie, he was the perfect man  the ideal father and a principled idealist, an enlightened, almost saintly believer in justice and fairness. In real life, people named their children after Atticus. People went to law school and became lawyers because of Atticus.

title: Times Readers React to Citi Bikes Gender Gap
description: Men may outnumber women on Citi Bike, but many of the women who use the bike-share system say it is their favorite way to get around New York City.

title: Protesters Gather in Athens
description: Several thousand demonstrators rallied in front of the Parliament building, awaiting word on new bailout terms.

title: Comic-Con 2015:  Star Wars, as Told by Steampunk Fans
description: SAN DIEGO  The super fans were out in force at a Friday afternoon panel here titled Star Wars Goes Steampunk. What that means was abundantly clear with one glance at a young woman in line. She was done up as a 19th-century Princess Leia, with big, dark buns tucked under a stovepipe hat.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Signs of a Growing Hush in Chinas Economy
description: HONG KONG  As Chinas stock market tumbled over the last month, some wealthy apartment owners began trying to sell. Shopping malls became quieter. And customers at automobile dealerships across the country asked to defer delivery and payment for previously ordered cars.

title: Friday Night Music: Could I Leave You?
description: Yes, talk of Grexit made me think about this. But Sondheim doesnt need a reason. And the lyrics are awesome:

title: Five Steps to Secure Personal Data After a Breach
description: Consumers can take some steps to make it harder  albeit not impossible  for hackers to exploit their data.

title: Movies With Art Deco Charm
description: Alpine Cinema in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, which opened in 1921, provides a low-budget movie option for families and frugal couples.

title: Wednesday Night Fever in Bay Ridge
description: As dusk fell on a recent balmy Wednesday, it was still bright underneath the arched marquee of the Alpine Cinema. Young families, groups of students finally free for the summer and older couples milled around in the amber light, sidestepping piles of shoes spilling out of the neighboring Islamic Society of Bay Ridge, which was packed for Ramadan services. The line snaked past a shuttered comic-book store and was joined by people exiting Middle Eastern sweets shops, queuing up to watch dinosaurs maul one another in Jurassic World.

title: At Comic-Con, It Feels Like the Year of the Woman
description: SAN DIEGO  This year at Comic-Con International, the gathering of genre-geek tribes that takes over the convention center and surrounding neighborhoods here for four days every July, you could see a lot of Sadness, a few examples of Disgust, but, at least so far, no Joy.

title: Belgian Liberal Basks in Viral Fame for Scolding Greek Prime Minister
description: While the Greek debt crisis remains unresolved, and the countrys prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, finds himself derided by even members of his own party, at least one European politician clearly seems to be enjoying himself.

title: Standards Board Struggles With Pension Quagmire
description: A standards board for actuaries that is seeking ways to defuse a public pension crisis heard on Thursday about two changes that seemingly everyone could agree on, but many more where there was no consensus at all.

title: Sam Roberts on Books About the New York Public Library, Washington Heights and the Citys First Black Police Officer
description: New York Citys public library system, recently rescued by a much-deserved infusion of money from Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council, traces its roots to 1754 when the New York Society Library was established. That librarys earliest surviving catalog includes only one novel, Don Quixote.

title: Senate Subcommittee Preparing to Question U.S. Soccer Official Next Week
description: The United States Soccer Federation is expected to face aggressive scrutiny on Wednesday at a Senate subcommittee hearing related to charges of widespread corruption among leaders of FIFA, the sports global governing body.

title: Liquid Assets and a Pipe Dream
description: There is nothing more American than making money off the needs of others.

title: Theaters Struggle With Patrons Phone Use During Shows
description: Patti LuPones quick snatching of an audience members cellphone on Wednesday made her a vigilante heroine to those frustrated by breaches of theater etiquette. But the incident, at an evening performance of Shows for Days at Lincoln Center, also highlighted a seemingly intractable problem: What to do about people who think a darkened theater is a great place to check Facebook?

title: Mockingbird Reviews From 1960
description: Michiko Kakutanis review of Harper Lees Go Set a Watchman comes to us 55 years (in one case, to the day) after The Times offered its opinions of Ms. Lees iconic debut, To Kill a Mockingbird.

title: Shabab Militants Strike 2 Hotels in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Militants attacked two hotels in Mogadishu, Somalias capital, with grenades, bombs and heavy gunfire on Friday in what appeared to have been coordinated attacks, witnesses and officials said. At least 18 of the attackers were killed and at least six civilians were wounded, officials said.

title: Gray Squirrels, New Yorks Furry Cache Machines
description: The gray squirrel is very adaptable and easily finds a home in and around human-altered environs. But this familiarity breeds a certain amount of contempt. There isnt a bird-feeding New Yorker who hasnt gradually upgraded to increasingly squirrel-proof feeding stations in an escalating battle to keep these bushy-tailed mammals at bay.

title: The Strain Rolls Out Season 2 of Its Vampire Invasion Tale
description: Brooklyn becomes the epicenter of the fight against the vampire invasion in Season 2 of FXs highly enjoyable horror series The Strain, beginning on Sunday night. Most of the action in the first season took place in Manhattan and Queens, but now the shows fearless vamp hunters are ensconced in an abandoned pathology lab on Smith Street and a warehouse in nearby Red Hook, where the smiling exterminator Vasiliy Fet (Kevin Durand) engages in a Falluja-like house-by-house campaign to eradicate the bloodsuckers. And you thought hipsters were a problem.

title: Review: Lianne La Havas Sings of Love and Identity
description: In the songs of Lianne La Havas intricate cross-currents are something to sail above. There are cross-currents of rhythm and harmony, of melancholy and bliss, of romance and self-determination, of playfulness and purpose. But what comes across first is the sheer grace of her voice. It can be a breathy purr, a lilting tease, a liquid confession or a torchy declaration. She often introduces a melody by landing firmly on each note, then returns to toy with it in sliding, fluttering phrases, not for vocal display but to convey a sense of freedom.

title: Tattooing Embraced Long Ago by New Yorkers
description: Q. Now that summer is here and people are wearing less clothing, the number of people sporting multiple tattoos you see on city streets is really amazing. Does tattooing have a particularly colorful history in New York?

title: Putting the Public Back in Public Finance
description: It all came down to the penguins.

title: Small-Cap and Growth Stock Funds Are Bright Spots
description: In the second quarter, the eurozone quivered, as Greece sparred with its creditors. In China, the stock market sank. Yet markets in the United States managed to chug along without much damage from Europe or China, with small-cap and growth stocks, in particular, showing gains and propelling mutual funds that focus on them.

title: Did Scott Walkers Twitter Account Get Ahead of His Campaign?
description: In what appears to be either a premature presidential announcement or a tease of one to get attention, the Twitter account of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin sent word on Friday afternoon that he was seeking the 2016 Republican nomination for president.

title: Slow-Motion Events in Greece and Washington Sway Markets
description: Stocks traded in an extremely tight range for nearly all of the second quarter as the world awaited two drawn-out events that seemed increasingly likely to occur: the first Federal Reserve interest rate increase in nearly a decade and a full-fledged Greek debt default.

title: Srebrenica Revisited
description: Twenty years on, those who died trying to escape the killing fields in Bosnia are remembered.

title: Jackson, Hamilton and the Plan to Add a Woman on Our Currency
description: To the Editor:

title: When Bond Yields Rise, Go Long. Also Short.
description: Sudden leaps in bond yields during the second quarter caused prices to experience scary downdrafts. That may lead investors to wonder whether this is a time for buying or selling. The answer for some managers is: Yes.

title: A Mischievous Thorn in the Side of Conservative Christianity
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.  It is hard to know what to hope for when meeting a couple of Satanists. Horns? Sulfurous fumes? Faint strains of organ music? But when they sit down in an organic food cafe and order plates of fettuccini Alfredo, its hard to take them seriously as worshipers of the Dark Lord of the Underworld.

title: South Sudan Enemies Find Uneasy Refuge Together at a U.N. Base
description: UNMISS BASE, MALAKAL, South Sudan  The trial started at dawn.

title: A Summer Road Trip With Ruth Fremson
description: As Ms. Fremson drove cross-country, she developed a new appreciation for the United States, finding different ways to look at familiar sights.

title: Small, but Still Strong
description: In an aging bull market, when investors worry that a downturn may be near, safety often trumps speculation.

title: Review Reveals a New Atticus Finch, and Readers Arent Happy
description: The Timess Michiko Kakutani revealed the literary surprise of the year in her review of Harper Lees second novel, Go Set a Watchman, on Friday: Atticus Finch, a protagonist of both the book and its iconic companion, To Kill a Mockingbird, has gone from a champion of social justice to an outright racist.

title: Dalvin Cook of F.S.U. Will Face a Charge of Battery
description: Dalvin Cook, Florida States top running back, will be charged with misdemeanor battery after being accused of punching a woman, the latest of several recent criminal accusations against Seminoles football players.

title: Malaysias Critics Fear U.S. May Ease Stance on Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, and human rights advocates expressed alarm on Friday over a report that the State Department might declare that Malaysias record on human trafficking had improved since last year, even though, they say, the record has not.

title: Roger Federer Turns Back the Clock, and Finds Novak Djokovic Once Again
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Many of Roger Federers former rivals and opponents now have different roles in tennis.

title: Obama Plan for Immigration Action Gets a Cold Reception at Appeals Court
description: NEW ORLEANS  Government lawyers labored on Friday to persuade federal appeals court judges here to allow President Obama to move ahead with sweeping initiatives to protect immigrants in the country illegally. But the judges questions seemed to make it ever more unlikely that the presidents programs, which he has hoped would be a central piece of his legacy, would start any time before the last months of his term, if at all.

title: Plan to Require Background Checks for Ammunition Sales Is Suspended in New York
description: The administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo agreed on Friday to suspend a plan to require background checks on ammunition sales, putting in doubt part of the gun control law that he considers one of his proudest legacies.

title: What Its Like to Face a 150 M.P.H. Tennis Serve
description: Watch this video and see how it feels to stand across the court from the fastest serves in tennis.

title: Exchange-Traded Funds for the Active-Minded
description: With the growing popularity of exchange-traded funds, the industry is churning out new products targeted at investors needs, fears and greed.

title: Amtrak Will Not Fight Suits Filed in Wreck
description: WASHINGTON  Amtrak said in a court filing on Friday that the railway would not contest lawsuits seeking compensation for damages caused by the May 12 derailment of its passenger train that crashed shortly after leaving 30th Street Station in Philadelphia, killing eight and injuring more than 200.

title: James Tate, Prolific Pulitzer-Winning Poet, Dies at 71
description: James Tate, a poet whose offhand style, ingenious wordplay and wild flights of surrealism won him a devoted following, a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, died on Wednesday in Springfield, Mass. He was 71.

title: Son of Mezz Mezzrow Finds His Fathers Legacy Lives in a Jazz Club in the Village
description: Spike Wilner stepped in front of the crowd at Mezzrow, a Greenwich Village jazz club he opened in September, and introduced a bearded man sitting against the wall as the son of the jazz clarinetist Mezz Mezzrow, for whom Mr. Wilner named the club.

title: Houlihan Lokey, Boutique Investment Bank, Files for an I.P.O.
description: More than a few boutique investment banks have gone public over the last decade. Now Houlihan Lokey, one of the oldest, is planning to take that step.

title: Promoters of Coming Star Wars Film Have a Delicate Dance at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO  As the Comic-Con International fan convention opened here this week, one of the most anticipated movies of the decade, Star Wars: The Force Awakens, was strangely invisible.

title: A Game for Cats
description: SATURDAY POST Cat owners, did you remember to feed your pet today? Theres little chance youll forget if you solve todays crossword puzzle, constructed by Joe DiPietro, because it contains several references to both cats and cat food.

title: Court Rules Against Developer in Battle Over Upstate New York Casino
description: ALBANY  A group fighting a casino proposal in a rural upstate town won a legal victory on Friday when an appellate court ruled that the town board had violated the procedures of a state environmental law.

title: When Obama Speaks to Black America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voter's Question to Jeb Bush: Would You Carpet-Bomb ISIS?
description: Mr. Bush faced a tough questioner, and a complex question, on the campaign trail, focused on the best strategy for taking on the Islamic State.

title: Marco Rubio and Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Chamber of Commerce: We Dont Support Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Requires Restaurants to Freeze Raw Fish Before Serving
description: For years, many New York sushi restaurants have lured gourmands by boasting of the freshest fish in the city. But soon, those claims may call for an asterisk.

title: Women on Bikes, With Helmets
description: To the Editor:

title: A Modern-Day Greek Drama: The Next Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowd Asks for More on Game of Thrones, but Cast Says No
description: SAN DIEGO  Sooner or later, Game of Thrones is going to need its own Con.

title: Nurturing Afghan Peace Talks
description: The Afghan government and the Taliban held their first official meeting  this week, a significant step beyond an informal gathering that took place in May. The recent talks, held in Pakistan, reportedly were positive, and at the end, participants were hugging each other, a senior Pakistan official told The Times.

title: Psychologists Who Greenlighted Torture
description: The first detailed accounts of the brutal interrogation program the Central Intelligence Agency established after the Sept. 11 attacks noted that psychologists and other medical professionals played key roles in abetting the torture of terrorism suspects. However, much about their role and their degree of responsibility in one of the most macabre and shameful chapters of American history has remained shrouded in secrecy.

title: Memorandum on New York Ammunition Checks
description: The background checks were part of the Safe Act, the set of tough gun control measures passed in January 2013.

title: Rand Pauls Fake Flat Tax
description: Every four years, Republican candidates for the White House denounce the federal tax system  often advocating replacing it with a supposedly more equitable single tax rate  and this year is no exception. Senator Rand Paul has already come up with a flat-tax reform plan, and it shows clearly, once again, that this is a fundamentally flawed idea.

title: Deron Williams Is Said to Be Leaving Nets for Dallas
description: Once regarded as the centerpiece of the Nets efforts on the court and in their marketing department, point guard Deron Williams unceremoniously parted ways with the team on Friday when he agreed to a buyout of the remaining two years of his contract, according to two people with knowledge of the situation.

title: What BP Taught Takata
description: On Thursday, the office of Senator Richard Blumenthal, a Connecticut Democrat, released a letter from Kevin M. Kennedy, an executive vice president at Takata, the company whose defective airbags have killed at least eight people and wounded more than 100.

title: New Knicks Meet the Press, After Meeting the Triangle
description: LAS VEGAS  Phil Jackson was consistent in his approach to free agency. When Jackson, the president of the Knicks, sat down last week with Arron Afflalo and Robin Lopez in separate meetings, it did not take long for Jackson to set up his laptop so Afflalo and Lopez could watch film of the triangle offense.

title: Brett Gardner Helps Set Pace as Yankees Deal a Blow to the Red Sox
description: BOSTON  Brett Gardner hopped up from the ground, dirt on the front of his jersey, and pounded his hands together.

title: Noah Syndergaard Strikes Out 13 to Lift Mets Past Diamondbacks
description: Noah Syndergaard struck out a career-high 13, and the Mets offense stirred to life  albeit briefly  to earn the teams fourth win in the past five games, beating the Arizona Diamondbacks, 4-2, at Citi Field on Friday.

title: Torn Muscle in His Back Lands Steven Matz on the D.L.
description: The question was posed to Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson midway through his somber news conference Friday afternoon. Why, he was asked, did the Mets not give Steven Matz a magnetic resonance imaging exam after he told the team about a tugging sensation near his left armpit in the wake of his rousing major league debut?

title: Startling Fall for Former No. 1 Yani Tseng Continues at U.S. Womens Open
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  Yani Tseng had just watched another putt go where it was not supposed to.

title: U.S. Team Loves New York; Its Mutual
description: First they conquered the world. And then on Friday, the members of the United States womens soccer team took over Manhattan.

title: At Gold Cup, Indignation at Donald Trumps Words on Mexico
description: CHICAGO  It is not often that rhetoric from a political candidate finds its way into the sporting arena, but the recent remarks about immigration by the presidential candidate Donald Trump have caused the P.G.A. of America to remove a tournament from one of the golf courses he operates and prompted ESPN and Nascar to remove award events from Trumps properties.

title: Corrections: July 11, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We are all sickthis happened. Wewish we could turn back time. From this vantage point, everything seems obvious.

title: Frank Lampard Sidelined With Calf Injury
description: Frank Lampard will not play his first game for New York City F.C. as planned on Sunday after he sustained a calf injury in practice, the club announced. Lampard, 37, was expected to be back at full speed by next week.

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO) 7 DAYS IN HELL (2015) Andy Samberg, below, stars as Aaron Williams, the brother of Serena with the behavior of John McEnroe and the hair of Andre Agassi, and Kit Harington is Charles Poole, a British prodigy bred to play tennis, in this satire about the longest match in Wimbledon history and the people who overinflate the importance of athletic events. Ms. Williams, Chris Evert, Jim Lampley, Soledad OBrien and Queen Elizabeth (or is it?) play themselves; Lena Dunham, Fred Armisen, Mary Steenburgen, Will Forte and Michael Sheen also find their way into the story, which features revealing mens underwear, a prison orgy and performance-enhancing cocaine. If raunchy isnt your thing, skip 7 Days and watch the real Wimbledon, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. But if youve always wanted to chase down the anonymous tennis tournament official who intones Quiet, please before a serve and smack him or her upside the head for the crimes of affectedness and self-importance, 7 Days in Hell is made for you. Bonus points if you recognize the well-disguised Howie Mandel.

title: The Hit King at the Corn Crib
description: Pete Rose, who continues to seek redemption more than 25 years after his banishment from Major League Baseball, was honored by the Normal CornBelters, a minor league team in Illinois.

title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Blast at Italian Consulate in Cairo
description: CAIRO  The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for a powerful explosion outside the Italian Consulates compound in downtown Cairo early Saturday that killed one person and was the first major bombing of a foreign diplomatic mission since the start of an insurgency here nearly two years ago.

title: Why Investing Is So Complicated, and How to Make It Simpler
description: I finally faced up to something I had been dreading.

title: How CVS Quit Smoking and Grew Into a Health Care Giant
description: Michael Gaffneys throat was scratchy for days, and lemon tea was not helping. So he dropped into a MinuteClinic above a CVS store in Midtown Manhattan on a lunch break. Within minutes, a nurse practitioner tested him for strep throat (negative), suggested lozenges and a regimen (ample fluids, no spicy food), collected a co-payment ($25 cash) and sent him on his way.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from the All England Club to Thayet Oak, a Rohingya village in Myanmar.

title: A Eulogy for the Long, Intimate Email
description: When I started college in 1997, I got my first email account, as did most of my peers. Over the next four years, I sent and received countless rambling letters to friends, both off and on campus, a habit that persisted for a decade or so after graduation.

title: Walking Tours That Help Hotel Guests Discover Nearby Nature
description: To help guests better appreciate local wildlife, a number of hotels have naturalists to give guided walks and eco-tours, many of them free.

title: Class or Ideology? My Conversation With Bernie Sanders
description: Everything Im telling you may end up being wrong, Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator seeking the Democratic nomination for president, said early in our conversation on Thursday.

title: Ojais Golden Hour
description: OJAI, Calif.  On a recent Sunday morning the sidewalk in front of Porch Gallery Ojai buzzed with shoppers toting organic grocery bags to and from the nearby farmers market. Every now and then someone  a surfer dude with a blond topknot, a couple pushing a tricycle stroller  peeled off to snap a picture of Before I Die, an interactive installation outside the gallery in which viewers are invited to complete the sentence Before I die I want to . on a large chalkboard mounted under an incense cedar. (One not atypical contribution: Sound my barbaric yawp.)

title: Meeting on Greece Debt Breaks Up With No Deal
description: BRUSSELS  A meeting of European finance ministers broke up late Saturday with no agreement on whether Greece should be granted its third bailout since 2010, reflecting deep divides over whether the Athens government can be trusted to repay huge new loans and leaving the Continent hours from what could be a historic rupture.

title: Greece Financial Crisis Hits Poorest and Hungriest the Hardest
description: ATHENS  Behind the lace curtains of a soup kitchen run by a parish in the humble Athens neighborhood of Kerameikos, the needy and hungry sit down to a plate of sliced cucumbers, three hunks of bread, a shallow china bowl of chickpea soup and often a piece of meat. Sometimes there is even ice cream, a special treat.

title: 1904 | The Evil That Is Ticker Tape
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Neighbors and Property Lines
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Sex Abuse Trial of Ex-Vatican Envoy Is Delayed
description: VATICAN CITY  The trial of a former Vatican ambassador accused of sexually abusing boys while stationed in the Dominican Republic and of possessing child pornography was adjourned indefinitely on Saturday after he fell ill and was hospitalized.

title: Mass Evacuation in China as Typhoon Chan-Hom Hits Coast
description: HONG KONG  A typhoon swept along the coast of eastern China on Saturday, whipping up high waves, intense winds and rain that forced the crowded commercial region to suspend flights and evacuate hundreds of thousands of residents.

title: U.S. Strike Is Said to Kill Senior ISIS Militant in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A senior Pakistani militant leading the Afghanistan and Pakistan chapter of the Islamic State was killed in an airstrike by United States forces in eastern Afghanistan on Friday, Afghan officials said on Saturday.

title: Wimbledon 2015: Serena Williams Defeats Garbie Muguruza and Closes In on Grand Slam
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Three years had passed since the Wimbledon champions trophy was last in her possession, so Serena Williams had some fun with it.

title: Comic-Con Is All About the Eyes
description: SAN DIEGO  The weird thing about Comic-Conwell, one of the weird thingsis that you cant really hear it. Walk the halls for an hour, and youll pick up nothing but the low, anonymous murmur of people who are mostly looking at, not listening to, each other.

title: Jeb and the Nation of Takers
description: Maybe we were unfair to Mitt Romney; Jeb people should work longer hours Bush is making him look like a model of empathy for the less fortunate. All the obvious points apply: longer hours would mean more GDP (if and when the economy ever gets back to full employment), but not necessarily better lives, especially if the increase in GDP doesnt trickle down.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks Still Face Difficult Issues, Kerry Says
description: VIENNA  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Saturday that there were still difficult issues to resolve before a landmark nuclear accord with Iran could be completed.

title: Variety: A Poetic Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE What makes a poet unique? That is the question addressed in todays acrostic.

title: Writing Books Very Few Will Read
description: Authors are often asked where they get their ideas. As a writer for hire, my answer owes something to the songwriter Sammy Cahn. Asked which came first, the music or the lyrics, he said: The phone call.

title: Stewart Butterfield of Slack: Is Empathy on Your Rsum?
description: This interview with Stewart Butterfield, the co-founder and chief executive of Slack, a communication service for businesses, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: The Real Threat Posed by Powerful Computers
description: In October, Elon Musk called artificial intelligence our greatest existential threat, and equated making machines that think with summoning the demon. In December, Stephen Hawking said full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race. And this year, Bill Gates said he was concerned about super intelligence, which he appeared to think was just a few decades away.

title: At the British Open, Where the Path to a Grand Slam Has Been Lost
description: The footprints were there for Jordan Spieth to follow  the footprints of Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods in their pursuit of golfs most elusive prize, a calendar-year Grand Slam. Spieth has followed those footprints through the towering pines of the Masters and the tangled rough of the United States Open at Chambers Bay to the British Open, which starts Thursday on the Old Course at St. Andrews in Scotland.

title: In Paris, Scientists Chart Varied Paths to a Sustainable Human Relationship With Earths Climate
description: A richlyvariegated four-day climate change conference, concluding yesterdayin Paris, provided a sobering look at the mix of environmental, social and technological trends that have created humanitys planet-size challenge  fitting seemingly infinite aspirations safely in a climate system that is showing signs of disruptive human-driven change.

title: Shaping a Campaign Against Hillary Clinton
description: American Crossroads, a Republican super PAC, conducted two four-hour focus groups in Florida to test a series of attack ads against Mrs. Clinton. Here are descriptions of some ads, along with some reactions from the participants.

title: The Best Way to Vilify HillaryClinton? G.O.P. Spends Heavily to Test It
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Inside an office park here, about a dozen women gathered to watch a 30-second television spot that opened with Hillary Rodham Clinton looking well-coiffed and aristocratic, toasting champagne with her tuxedoed husband, the former president, against a golden-hued backdrop.

title: While Some Are Shocked by Go Set a Watchman, Others Find Nuance in a Bigoted Atticus Finch
description: With all the debate brewing over the origins of Harper Lees novel Go Set a Watchman, the biggest bombshell turned out to be an explosive plot twist that no one saw coming.

title: In Fiery Speeches, Francis Excoriates Global Capitalism
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  His speeches can blend biblical fury with apocalyptic doom. Pope Francis does not just criticize the excesses of global capitalism. He compares them to the dung of the devil. He does not simply argue that systemic greed for money is a bad thing. He calls it a subtle dictatorship that condemns and enslaves men and women.

title: Why Employee Ranking Can Backfire
description: Big Data has made it possible to measure employee performance more thoroughly than ever. But two recent studies offer a warning: Be careful about how you deploy that data.

title: Hillary Clinton Will Call for Economic Policy Changes to Lift Middle-Class Wages
description: A major teachers union voted on Saturday to give Hillary Rodham Clinton an early endorsement for president, a boost to her pro-labor credentials as she prepares to outline in more detail an economic vision focused on lifting middle-class incomes and tries to fend off a stronger-than-expected challenge from the left.

title: Abigael Hoeschler: A Real Balancing Act
description: Abigael A. Hoeschler, 28, is a logrolling teacher in Minneapolis.

title: Greek Debt Crisis Pits Greeks Against Germans
description: BERLIN  If the scramble to hold together Europes single currency has highlighted one thing, it is that national mind-sets can be more stubborn than the 60-year-old mantra of the Continents ever closer union once supposed. And no national psyche is more important to the outcome at this moment than Germanys.

title: Rays Center Fielder No. 941 in Draft, No. 1 in Defense
description: Kevin Kiermaier will always remember the number 941. That was his overall draft position in the 31stround in 2010. Essentially, 30 teams passed on him 30 times before the Tampa Bay Rays gave him a chance to play in the pros.

title: Player Ratings: United States (1) vs. Haiti (0)
description: After yet another poor start, the United States mens national team improved in the second half and defeated a Haiti team that was unlucky not to earn a result in the game. For the first 30 minutes, Haiti was by far the better team, and the United States was on its heels.

title: With Greeks Now Ready to Make a Deal, What Can We Expect?
description: Q. Now that the Greek Parliament has approved a package of pension cuts, tax increases and other changes along the lines of what the countrys creditors have been demanding as a condition for more bailout money, what happens next?

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 3 to July 9.

title: Mike Giannattasio of Montblanc North America: Finding Tranquility in an Urban Jungle
description: Mike Giannattasio is the chief executive and president of Montblanc North America in New York.

title: Money, Sex and Las Vegas Pool Parties
description: Las Vegas  IMAGINE this: Before a job interview, you wait five hours in a room with your competition, but instead of business attire, youre in bikinis and swimsuits, and prep with self-tanning lotion rather than hypothetical interview questions. When your turn comes to stand before the hiring panel, they ask you to walk, turn around, strike a pose for the camera. If youre lucky, they might also ask about your past work experience. In the span of one minute, your interview is over. Exit stage right.

title: My Mother, Lost and Found
description: DENVER  CAN you make sure it has lots of stuff? my mom regularly asked the server at her favorite Italian restaurant. Apparently, the minestrone soup was mostly broth with just a couple of noodles, which was unacceptable. Really scoop it up, she instructed, adding her nervous, friendly laugh. With her salmon, she demanded all sauces on the side, and an additional plate of lemon slices. Sometimes she brought her own dessert from the place she liked down the street. Her fastidiousness made me want to shrink into the jar of Parmesan cheese, but what could I do? That was my mom.

title: D.I.Y. Education Before YouTube
description: EACH summer, when school ends, education mostly stops short, too. But it hasnt always been that way. For the striving youths of 19th-century America, learning was often a self-driven, year-round process. Devouring books by candlelight and debating issues by bonfire, the young men and women of the so-called go-ahead generation worked to educate themselves into a better life.

title: Addicted to Your Phone? Theres Help for That
description: LIKE pretty much everyone these days, Susan Butler stares at her smartphone too much. Unlike most everyone, she took action, buying a $195 ring from a company called Ringly, which promises to let you put your phone away and your mind at ease.

title: What Type of Nostalgic 90s TV Fan Are You? (The Wrong Kind)
description: WE held the meeting on the floor of my childhood bedroom, where centerfolds torn from Bop magazine and Teen Beat were stuck to the walls with Fun-Tak that looked like wads of chewed up Bubblicious. Ricky Schroder and Kirk Cameron smiled down on us as my neighbor Rebecca took minutes with a multicolored click-pen.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: A Lost Boy Battles AK-47s With Education
description: MARIAL BAI, South Sudan  If theres a world center of despair, it may be South Sudan, enveloped in an increasingly brutal war in which children are raped and then burned alive. But against that grim backdrop, one local man has undertaken a journey that is an affirmation of hope, inspiration and the transformative power of education.

title: The Bernie Sanders Moment
description: THE white-haired politician stands before 10,000 cheering supporters in Madison, Wis., and calls for political revolution, denouncing a rigged economy that produces a grotesque level of inequality, returning to a theme that 60s radicals have long been trumpeting.

title: Sam Altman
description: Sam Altman is a serial technology entrepreneur and president of Y Combinator, a venture capital firm in Mountain View, Calif., that has funded and nurtured a number of technology start-ups, including Airbnb and Dropbox.

title: The New Child Abuse Panic
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  FEW things are tougher for a parent than dealing with a childs serious medical condition, particularly if it is complicated and hard to diagnose. The parent has to make hard choices about treatment, navigating conflicting advice from doctors or even rejecting one doctors opinion and seeking another.

title: Aid-in-Dying Laws Are Just a Start
description: One cold March day, when she was 84 and suffering from congestive heart failure, my beautiful mother went to the garage and measured her Camrys tailpipe, planning to buy a hose to fit it. She was grieving my fathers recent death, living alone in Connecticut with occasional visits from her three grown children in California, and suffering too much chest pain and breathlessness to weed her beloved garden.
