There is a possibility for a timely escape, she wrote in the journal I discovered after her death. And I will take it.

title: When This Man Is Irked, He Might Just File a Suit
description: You should be ashamed of yourself!

title: Review: Closure at the New Jersey Repertory Company
description: When my mother would scold me as a child, shed often add a compliment to soften the sting. That is not a bad strategy for critics, either. So many people in the theater work so hard that even a tedious show deserves some recognition for all the effort involved.

title: The End of Federally Financed Ghettos
description: The Supreme Court issued an important ruling last month when it reminded state and local governments that the Fair Housing Act of 1968 bars them from spending federal housing money in a manner that perpetuates racial segregation.

title: Baseball Intermission Report
description: Assessing the best and the worst of baseball at the midway point of the season.

title: Stateless in the Dominican Republic
description: In 2013, the Dominican Republics highest court issued an unconscionable ruling that rendered tens of thousands of Dominican-born people of Haitian descent effectively stateless. Last year, the Dominican government, responding to international criticism, established a process that ostensibly offered them a path to be recognized as citizens. But because the application process was so onerous and poorly administered, tens of thousands of people remain in limbo, shunned in their homeland and unwelcome in neighboring Haiti.

title: A Battle Over Eisenhower in Washington
description: After a steady siege of Washington infighting and aesthetic backbiting, the plan to build a national memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th president and five-star military leader of World War II, has run into its toughest hurdle yet  growing congressional resistance to financing the project and even calls to reset the planning process from scratch.

title: Medicare and Medicaid: Successes and Drawbacks
description: Readers discuss the impact of Medicare and Medicaid at 50 and offer their suggestions.

title: What Youll Be Remembered For
description: LANE TEBBETT, the actor, 83, died at home in Brooklyn on May 11. His death was announced by his wife of 52 years, the former Elaine Gaspar. Mr. Tebbett, a graduate of the Actors Studio and a longtime fixture on the Off Broadway stage, was perhaps best known for originating the part of Bishop Stansfield in the 1956 tragicomedy Mrs. Peltons Purses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Review of Punctuating Space: The Prints and Multiples of Richard Artschwager at Vassar College
description: Richard Artschwager made ordinary things extraordinary. In fact, much of his remarkable career soared on an unremarkable black dot. Artschwager, who died in 2013, elongated it into a lozenge shape, called it a blp (pronounced blip), then stenciled or attached his sundry creatures throughout a city or in oddball museum locations.

title: Baltimore Mayors Challenge: Fighting Crime While Reining In Police
description: BALTIMORE  On the day after Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake fired her police commissioner last week, a man was doing a brisk business selling DVDs from a folding table in front of a Baptist church in West Baltimore. A block away, a CVS Pharmacy stood as a reminder of riots in April, its windows still boarded with plywood, its red brick stained by black smoke.

title: A Makeover for the Mother of Parliaments
description: LONDON  LONDON BRIDGE is not falling down, but the Houses of Parliament and Buckingham Palace are. In recent weeks, each building has been declared unfit for habitation, with the prospect of members of Parliament, as well as the monarch, moving out during renovations that may take decades to complete.

title: Review: The Nuns Are Back in Sister Act at the Gateway Playhouse
description: Light entertainment is the hallmark of summer theaters, and that is just what the Gateway Playhouse is serving up nicely with its current staging of Sister Act. Situated on about seven acres of greenery in Bellport, the Gateway has a red clapboard exterior offering visitors a picture-perfect vision of those classic barn theaters of yesteryear.

title: Roger Rees, Actor Who Won Tony as Nicholas Nickleby, Dies at 71
description: Roger Rees, the handsome Welsh-born actor and director who rose to fame as the title character in The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby, for which he won a Tony Award, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: At Tour de France, Riders From Eritrea Hope to Blaze a Grueling Trail for a Continent
description: MR-DE-BRETAGNE, France  All manner of flags are waved at the Tour de France. But at the start in Rennes on Saturday there were a few dozen examples of one that had probably not made an appearance: the red, blue and green of Eritrea.

title: In Tourist Destinations, a Picture of Excess
description: MAGALUF, Majorca  For a holiday photograph from this resort town on the island of Majorca, two tourists wiped a drunken friends face clean with a crumpled flier advertising a deal for all-you-can-drink cocktails. Then they hoisted his sagging body upright between them while another buddy clicked away with a smartphone.

title: Chinese Authorities Detain and Denounce Rights Lawyers
description: HONG KONG  At least five Chinese lawyers from a firm that specialized in rights cases have been detained by the police in Beijing and accused of running a criminal syndicate to smear the Communist Party and create social chaos through their litigation, state-run news media said on Saturday.

title: For Boston Sports Fans, Its All About Rallying Cries
description: BOSTON  Around the corner from venerable Fenway Park, in the vending hustle of Kenmore Square, outnumbering and outselling the T-shirts mocking the Yankees for making a familiarly unflattering slurping sound were relatively new ones defending Tom Brady from the arbitrary justice of Roger Goodell.

title: Hillary Clinton Picks Up Teachers Union Endorsement
description: A major teachers union on Saturday voted to make an early endorsement of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a lift to her presidential campaign as she tries to fend off a stronger-than-expected challenge from the left.

title: Unlikely Targets in Cross Hairs as Russia Aims to Expose Foreign Influence
description: MOSCOW  Dmitry Zimin, the telecommunications billionaire and benefactor of a foundation known as the Dynasty Fund, was not calling for revolution or election monitors. His efforts were elsewhere: awarding grants to young Russian researchers and financing high school science camps.

title: Chinese Officials to Restructure Beijing to Ease Strains on City Center
description: Beijing will undertake a major restructuring of the capital government as part of a broader plan to create a giant urban corridor in northern China, officials said Saturday.

title: Spanish Look to Havana to Repay an Old Debt
description: MADRID  Though it was more than half a century ago, Carmen Gmez lvarez-Varccel, now 90, vividly remembers her last hour on Cuban soil.

title: U.N. Cease-Fire Fails to Take Hold in Yemen
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  A cease-fire brokered by the United Nations that was intended to allow the delivery of relief supplies failed to take hold in Yemen on Saturday, as a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia carried out airstrikes, and fighting continued between the Houthis rebels and rival militias in several cities.

title: Art and Its Inspiration, Side by Side, at the Aldrich
description: Stepping into the Leir Atrium at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, visitors encounter a motley group of objects arranged on a wall and an adjacent platform. There are photographs, a massive cluster of handmade rope and an anthropomorphized banjo with spiky hair. Nearby are a woven basket, a Victorian vase and a yellow plastic toy telephone. Interspersed throughout are Nancy Shavers quirky quiltlike assemblages of fabric-wrapped wooden blocks, some mounted on the wall, others perched on metal rods and one attached to a tree stump.

title: China Fences In Its Nomads, and an Ancient Life Withers
description: MADOI, China  If modern material comforts are the measure of success, then Gere, a 59-year-old former yak-and-sheep herder in Chinas western Qinghai Province, should be a happy man.

title: Restaurant Review: Great Necks Lola Reopens, With a Middle Eastern Flair
description: When Michael Ginor opened Lola in Great Neck in 2009, Spanish tapas were featured. By the time I visited, about a year later, the restaurant was serving New American cuisine. In May, Lola closed briefly and reopened with a Mediterranean menu that focuses on Middle Eastern and North African dishes.

title: Restaurant Review: Fairy-Tale Touches at Richard Geres Barn at the Bedford Post Inn
description: The swell little bar at the Barn at the Bedford Post Inn has a row of tractor-seat stools that descend in height from left to right, like a scene from Goldilocks and the Three Bears. Even the famously fussy heroine might settle happily here in one of the iron seats  they can be raised or lowered to suit  and eat the fluke crudo (so much better than porridge!).

title: Review: Tikkaway Grill in New Haven
description: In 2008, when the restaurateur Gopi Nair was working as managing partner for Fairfield Countys Coromandel group of Indian eateries, he had what he calls a 2 a.m. eureka! moment.

title: Review: Saddle River Inn in Saddle River
description: One of the toughest places to score a table in New York City right now is the Polo Bar, Ralph Laurens latest venture. The reservationist will politely tell you that the dining room is booked a month ahead. And forget trying to walk in, because an employee guards the entrance, iPad in hand.

title: Start Again
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE If you look forward to Sunday puzzles constructed by Patrick Berry, then youre IN LUCK.

title: William Conrad Gibbons, Dogged Writer About Vietnam War, Dies at 88
description: William Conrad Gibbons, a foreign policy expert at the Library of Congress whose multivolume account of the relationship between Congress and the executive branch during the Vietnam War has served as a cornerstone of historical writing on the war ever since its first volume was published in 1984, died on July 4 at his farm in Monroe, Va. He was 88.

title: U.S. Screening on Foreign Projects Roils Aid Groups
description: WASHINGTON  A new federal screening program designed to ferret out terrorists working for government-backed nonprofit organizations is drawing sharp criticism from groups that say the vetting is overly intrusive, undermines their mission, and may endanger the lives of their employees.

title: Obituaries Shed Euphemisms to Chronicle Toll of Heroin
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  When George P. Gauthier died of an opiate overdose in May at 44, his sister, Cindy Gauthier-Rivera, wrote an obituary that was more like a cry from the heart.

title: Blaine Gibson, Sculptor of Figures in Disney Parks, Dies at 97
description: Blaine Gibson, whose sculptures of pirates and presidents, boys and ghouls, are bedrock features of Walt Disneys theme parks and resorts around the world, died on July 5 at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 97.

title: Paying It Forward
description: Nicholas Kristof travels to South Sudan to revisit Valentino Deng, a Lost Boy of Sudan who runs a remarkable school amid civil war.

title: Paul Lioy, Scientist Who Analyzed 9/11 Dust and Its Health Effects, Dies at 68
description: Paul J. Lioy, an environmental scientist widely known for his analysis of the dust spawned by the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and for his studies of its health effects over time, died on Wednesday after collapsing at Newark Liberty International Airport. He was 68.

title: U Turn
description: Skipping the stampede.

title: Discussions Shift to Endgames as Nuclear Negotiations Drag On
description: VIENNA  Absent real pronouncements 11 days after the hard-and-fast deadline for a nuclear deal with Iran, people have begun looking to the balconies to determine if a deal is imminent. Well, one balcony: Mohammad Javad Zarifs, Irans foreign minister, who on Saturday spent a lot of time in the sun.

title: As Latin Tour Nears End, Pope Travels to Paraguay
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  Pope Francis on Saturday highlighted two crucial periods in Paraguays history as a way to emphasize the importance of resilience in one of Latin Americas poorest countries.

title: Donald Trump Defiantly Rallies a New Silent Majority in a Visit to Arizona
description: PHOENIX  Donald Trump, the real estate mogul and reality television star who has taken center stage in the race for the Republican presidential nomination this week, delivered a rambling monologue on Saturday, dismissing a long list of critics  including Jeb Bush, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Macys  while rallying what he termed a new silent majority of voters.

title: Trump Takes His Message to Arizona
description: Donald Trump, the real estate mogul and Republican presidential candidate, spoke at an event in Phoenix hosted by the Republican Party of Maricopa County.

title: The New Reddit C.E.O.s Many Challenges
description: Steve Huffman has just walked into what may be one of the most difficult jobs in Silicon Valley.

title: Martina Hingis Returns to Top of Wimbledon, With Help From a Breakthrough
description: WIMBLEDON, England  For Martina Hingis, it was a return. For Sania Mirza, it was a breakthrough.

title: After Slow Rise, Wimbledon Mens Doubles Champions Are Advised to Party Hard
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Andy Murray had a tough couple of days at his local tennis club. On Friday he lost in a semifinal in mens singles to Roger Federer on Wimbledons Centre Court, and on Saturday he watched from the seats of the same court as his older brother, Jamie, lost in the doubles final.

title: Was That Piazza at the Plate? No, It Was a Pitcher
description: With a familiar tomahawk chop of a swing and a back-smacking, two-handed follow-through, it looked for a moment as if Mike Piazza had stepped out of retirement to deliver a two-run homer to left field.

title: Modern Doctors House Calls: Skype Chat and Fast Diagnosis
description: TACOMA, Wash.  One night, when her face turned puffy and painful from what she thought was a sinus infection, Jessica DeVisser briefly considered going to an urgent care clinic, but then decided to try something kind of sci-fi.

title: Stacy Lewis Keeps Falling Short as Amy Yang Maintains Lead at U.S. Womens Open
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  Stacy Lewis did not want to come up short again. She stood in the middle of the 18th fairway, staring down the final green of the day, knowing she needed to put the ball close to the hole to give herself a chance at one last birdie.

title: Voting Rights Legacy of the 60s Heads to Court as North Carolina Law Is Tested
description: Days after South Carolina confronted its past and lowered the Confederate battle flag, North Carolina will grapple with its present-day rules that determine access to the voting booth.

title: Bernie Sanders Courts Marthas Vineyard Donors
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has risen in the polls thanks in part to his denunciations of the forces of concentrated wealth, drawing thousands of liberals to hear his jeremiads against corporate power in early nominating states and liberal hubs such as Madison, Wis.

title: Knicks Kristaps Porzingis Puts His Promise on Display
description: LAS VEGAS  Kristaps Porzingis said he felt a little nervous on the bus ride over to Thomas & Mack Center on Saturday afternoon. He was set to make his debut for the Knicks in the N.B.A. summer league, and if he was anxious, it was understandable.

title: The Faithful Celebrate in Central Park
description: Thousands went to the Great Lawn in Central Park Saturday afternoon for the largest evangelical Christian gathering in New York City since 2005.

title: Rob Refsnyder Makes Composed Debut as the Yankees Lose to the Red Sox
description: BOSTON  When Rob Refsnyder, a celebrated and self-effacing Yankees prospect, studied the lineup before the Yankees game against the Red Sox on Saturday, he found his name  at the bottom of the order.

title: Thousands Gather at Evangelical Event in Central Park
description: The sun bore down on Barbara Harrison as she dabbed at the sweat on her forehead. She then waved an arm in the air, eyes closed, while a singer performed on a stage lit as if for a rock concert.

title: Comic-Con 2015: Big-Name Stars and Glimpse of Suicide Squad Wow Crowd
description: SAN DIEGO  When you spend like Warner Bros. spends, it is relatively easy to leave Comic-Con attendees with pinwheels in their eyes.

title: Comic-Con 2015: Tarantino Rails Against Digital Film Technology
description: SAN DIEGO  Only Comic-Con could veer from Quentin Tarantino and a period Western to the computer-generated Orcs of Warcraft.

title: Elizabeth Giardina, Darius Daftary
description: Elizabeth Marie Giardina and Darius Alexander Daftary were married Saturday by Lawrence Grecco, a Zen Buddhist monk at Stone Park, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Jessie duPont,  James McDonald
description: Jessie Greenwood duPont, a daughter of Jill G. duPont and Augustus I. duPont of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday at Chickemmoo Farm in West Tisbury, Mass., to James Patrick McDonald, a son of Kathleen M. McDonald and William R. McDonald of Denver. Leading the ceremony was Richard H. Brodhead, president of Duke University, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Sally Myers,  Jorey Ramer
description: Sally Joy Myers and Jorey Evan Ramer were married Saturday. Rabbi Nadia Gold performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Kristin Farley, Wai Wong
description: Kristin Leigh Farley, a daughter of Barbara A. Farley and Dennis T. Farley of Annadale, Staten Island, was married Saturday to Robert Wai Wong, the son of M. Luanne Wong and Dr. George S. Wong of Virginia Beach. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Keever performed the ceremony at Bayside Presbyterian Church in Virginia Beach.

title: Molly Ford,  Collin Beck
description: Molly Elizabeth Ford and Collin Mitchell Beck were married Friday in New York. The Rev. Dr. Patrick S. Cheng performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, where he is an associate priest.

title: Elizabeth Trongone and Evan Layne
description: Elizabeth Christine Trongone and Evan Alexander Layne were married Saturday evening at the New York Yacht Club in Newport, R.I. Jacob D. Loup, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Sarah Curtis and Benjamin Grant
description: Sarah Esther Curtis and Benjamin Boyd Grant were married Saturday at the Wainwright House, an events space in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret S. Koeniger, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Claire Benjamin, Andrew DiMattina
description: Claire Rose Benjamin and Andrew John DiMattina were married Saturday in Warren, Vt. William E. Ritch-Smith, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Vermont secretary of state to solemnize the marriage, officiated at Sugarbush, the ski resort.

title: Ashley Silvers and Steven Shur
description: Ashley Danielle Silvers, the daughter of Robin D. Silvers and Dr. Lawrence W. Silvers of Toms River, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Steven Lawrence Shur, the son of Ellen P. Shur and Paul H. Shur of East Brunswick, N.J. Cantor Claire Franco officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Arta Lahiji,  Emmanuel Fordjour
description: Dr. Arta Lahiji and Emmanuel Fordjour were married Saturday. The Rev. George A. Gregory, a minister of Every Nation Church, performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. Later that day, Nilou Nouri, who is affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, led a Persian ceremony at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: Adrian Heinzelman,  Ryan Dismukes
description: Adrian Odell Heinzelman and Ryan Tyler Dismukes were married Saturday at the Buttermilk Falls Inn in Milton, N.Y. The officiant was Barbara J. Magid, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Nathan Bowen and Christiaan James
description: Nathan Gregory Bowen and Christiaan Klee James were married Friday at the H. Carl Moultrie Courthouse in Washington. Paul A. Trudeau, with the District of Columbia Superior Court, officiated.

title: Stacy Schuster,  David Tukey
description: Stacy Marie Schuster and David Stanley Tukey were married Saturday at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Brian Woodrow, a Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Beverly Baker and Thomas Jackson
description: Beverly Ann Baker and Thomas Matthew Jackson were married Saturday at the Rainbow Room in New York. The Rev. James W. Warnake, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Kimberly Kolker, Daniel Kasten
description: Kimberly Anne Kolker and Daniel Aaron Kasten were married Saturday at the Museum of Biblical Art in Dallas. The Rev. Buster Noah, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Olga Urbieta,  Chad Di Stefano
description: Olga Marie Urbieta and Chad Woodruff Di Stefano were married Thursday at St. Patricks Catholic Church in Telluride, Colo. Michael Doehrman, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Hannah Buchsbaum, Joseph Lambert
description: Hannah Eliot Buchsbaum, the daughter of Suzanne R. Buchsbaum and Andrew D. Buchsbaum of Bennington, Vt., was married Saturday to Joseph Michael Lambert, a son of Janet M. Lambert and J. Kevin Lambert of Brightwaters, N.Y. Susan E. Beal, a Vermont justice of the peace, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Alice Kenney and Gregory Johnston
description: Alice Anderson Kenney, a daughter of Pamela K. Kenney and David A. Kenney of New York, was married Saturday to Gregory Bruce Johnston, the son of Deborah E. Johnston of Winchester, Mass., and A. Bruce Johnston of Boston. The Rev. Luther Zeigler, the Episcopal chaplain at Harvard, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Jelena Djordjevic,  Alexander Wooten
Sarah Thompson, Jonathan Shugar
description: Sarah Nicole Thompson, a daughter of Sherrie B. Thompson and William R. Thompson of Manhattan, was married Saturday to Jonathan Harry Shugar, the son of Gerald R. Shugar of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Lois R. Shugar, who lived in Manhattan. Cantor Bruce Ruben officiated at Guastavinos, an events space in Manhattan.

title: Diana Peters, Jonathan Crowder
description: Diana Elyssa Peters, the daughter of Nancy Freedman Peters and Steven M. Peters of Riverside, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Michael Crowder, the son of Karen Morris Crowder and Kevin F. Crowder of Dallas. Eric A. Gordon, a secular Jewish marriage officiant who was certified by the New York City clerks office, officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Hal Brewster and Geoffrey Wetrosky: United by Their Love of Politics
description: Henry James Brewster and Geoffrey Clinton Wetrosky were married Saturday evening at the York Harbor Reading Room, a private club and event space in York Harbor, Me. Mr. Brewsters father, the Rev. William Brewster Jr., a retired Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Jessica Green,  Craig Wilson
description: Jessica Lauren Green and Craig Lawrence Wilson were married Saturday evening at 26 Bridge, an event space in Brooklyn. Cantor Deborah Katchko-Gray, a cousin of the groom, officiated.

title: Jillian Swencionis,  Daniel Licata
description: Jillian Kendra Swencionis and Daniel Richard Licata were married Saturday at the Inn at Middletown, a hotel and restaurant in Middletown, Conn. Sal J. Fiore, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Michele Callari,  Paul Antunes
description: Michele Lyn Callari, the daughter of Priscilla Callari and Richard Callari of Farmingdale, N.J., was married Saturday to Paul Matthew Antunes, the son of Clarinda Antunes and Americo S. Antunes of Smithfield, R.I. The Rev. Austin Litke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Josephs Church in New York.

title: Grace Boone,  Kenneth Louis
description: Grace Marie Boone and Kenneth Calam Louis were married Saturday at Piedmont Community Church in Piedmont, Calif. The Rev. Dr. William McNabb, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Erica Ferrari, Scudder Fowler
Thas Miller, Chad Fusco
description: Thas Helene Miller, the daughter of Mona D. Miller and Steven J. Miller of Los Angeles, is to be married Sunday in Malibu, Calif., to Chad Robert Fusco, a son of Lori A. Fusco and Robert J. Fusco of Canfield, Ohio. Rabbi Allen Freehling is to officiate at the Malibu West Beach Club.

title: Alyson Kolberg,  David Wurtzbacher
description: Alyson Bailey Kolberg and David Alan Wurtzbacher were married Saturday in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Logan Michael Gentry, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Reveille United Methodist Church.

title: April McHugh, Philip Arnold
description: April Rose McHugh, a daughter of Mary McHugh and Neil McHugh of Falmouth, Mass., was married Saturday to Philip Warren Arnold, a son of Jane R. Arnold and A. Alexander Arnold III of New York. The Rev. Andrew Stoessel, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michaels Church in Marblehead, Mass.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Hope you are having a great Sunday. Here are the weeks top stories.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We used to carry knives. Now we have to carry keys.

title: Corrections: July 12, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: With Ban on Exports Lifted, Japan Arms Makers Cautiously Market Wares Abroad
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  Some of Japans biggest companies, best known for motorcycles, washing machines and laptop computers, are pitching a new line of global products: military hardware.

title: Scott Walker, Viewed as Authentic, Aims for Smart in the 2016 Race
description: After listening to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin as he has traveled the country preparing his campaign for president, which officially begins on Monday, admiring voters most often describe him as authentic, real and approachable, Mr. Walkers advisers say.

title: Leaders From Eurozone Work Into Morning on Greek Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  Haggling through the night into Monday morning over a deal to calm Greeces debt crisis, European leaders demanded that Athens make new concessions and quickly adopt a host of economic policy changes as they worked to overcome deep divisions and avert a historic fracture in the Continents common currency.

title: New Culinary-Cycling Options Abroad
description: On a new mountain-bike tour offered by H &I Adventures, riders can enjoy meals in three countries all in one day, with breakfast in Slovenia, lunch in Austria and afternoon coffee in Italy. The trip explores the cultural differences in each of the neighboring European countries, taking travelers from the Julian Alps to the Adriatic Sea. The weeklong tour ends with a seafood meal in the coastal town of Piran, Slovenia, one of the best-preserved historical towns on the Adriatic. Rates start at $2,448 a person based on double occupancy. Departure dates in 2015 include Aug. 22, Sept. 6 and Sept. 20, with more in 2016.

title: Daniel Tiger Becomes a Boy With Autisms Guide to Social Life
description: Weve spent thousands of dollars on therapies, countless hours at trial-and-error play dates. In spite of all that, I know just where the credit lies for my high-functioning autistic sons new-found ability to connect with others: Daniel Tiger.

title: Disaster In Europe
description: Obviously the news from Europe is terrible, with much confusion about exactly what is happening. Heres what I think is the story, although I havent done any independent reporting.

title: 1915: Austrian Retreat Also Forces Germans to Retire in Poland
description: LONDON  The outlook for the Russians is still very encouraging in South Poland. For more than a week the Austro-German forces between the Vistula and the Bug have been unable to make any progress in their advance toward Lublin and Kholm. The Russians maintain all the advantages won by their crushing blow against the Austrian army under Archduke Joseph near Krasnik, on the road to Lublin.

title: Mexican Drug Kingpin, El Chapo, Escapes Prison Through Tunnel
description: Shortly before 9 p.m. on Saturday, Joaqun Guzmn Loera, the Mexican drug kingpin whose capture last year had been trumpeted by his countrys government as a crucial victory in its bloody campaign against the narcotics trade, stepped into the shower in his cell in the most secure wing of the most secure prison in Mexico.

title: On Chinas Stock Market
description: Its going to be a bumpy ride.

title: Man Charged With Abandoning Daughter, 3, at a Sandwich Shop in Harlem
description: Crying out Daddy, Daddy, Daddy, the 3-year-old girl walked toward the door of a Subway shop in Harlem, holding a turkey sandwich.

title: Jon Vickers, Opera Star Known for His Raw Power and Intensity, Dies at 88
description: The Canadian tenor Jon Vickers, who brought a colossal voice and raw dramatic intensity to everything he sang, including legendary portrayals of Wagners Tristan, Verdis Otello, Beethovens Florestan and Brittens Peter Grimes, died on Friday in Ontario, Canada. He was 88.

title: New York States Paleontologist Seeks to Bring Prehistoric Era to Life
description: Long before skyscrapers stretched toward the stars, before men in pinstripes swung bats in the Bronx, before settlers populated New Amsterdam, before there were people   any people  trilobites flourished in the warm tidal waters that submerged most of what we now call the state of New York.

title: 1940: Childrens Departure Postponed by British
description: LONDON  The British government announced today [July 12] that its scheme to send thousands of Great Britains children to safety in the Dominions and the United States had been postponed for the present. The move came as a severe blow to the parents of at least 100,000 children already registered for transportation to new homes overseas. Although it was said authoritatively that there was ample shipping space to carry the children  and that the stumbling block was the lack of sufficient naval vessels for convoy duty  it was understood from other reliable quarters that the shipping problem was one by no means easily solved. In fact it was reported there are thousands of children whose parents want to send them abroad privately who are unable to get accommodations on British liners.  New York Herald Tribune, July 13, 1940

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 5 P.M. (Hallmark) PAW STAR GAME Whitey Furred, Mike Troutbreath, Derek Cheetah, Carlton Frisky, Jose Catseco and other all-stars sponsored by North Shore Animal League America and Last Hope Animal Rescue and Rehabilitation swat balls and catch line drives in this kitten baseball game. Beth Stern hosts this inaugural competition; the Yankees radio announcer John Sterling and the sports analyst Mary Carillo call the play-by-play; and celebrities including Ed Asner, Maria Menounos, Mario Lopez and Al Roker cheer on the teams.

title: Why the Greece Deal Matters
description: A visual guide to why a deal with Greece is so critical to Europe.

title: Wimbledon Crowd Resists a Novak Djokovic Title. Its Futile.
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It is hard enough to win a Wimbledon final in normal circumstances. Novak Djokovic has had to play his finals against great players on the road.

title: Universal Adds Yet Another Box-Office Hit With Minions
description: LOS ANGELES  Universal Pictures just keeps hitting home runs: The studios Minions took in about $115.2 million at the North American box office over the weekend, one of the biggest openings on record for an animated movie.

title: David Letterman Goes Top 10 on Donald Trump
description: As a late-night entertainer, David Letterman endured for more than 30 years. As a retiree, he lasted about two months.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks Are Nearing a Deal With Fewer Obstacles
description: VIENNA  Negotiators from Iran and six world powers are down to a small number of remaining disputes for a historic deal that would limit Tehrans nuclear ability for more than a decade in return for sanctions relief, diplomats said on Sunday.

title: Hamilton Heads to Broadway in a Hip-Hop Retelling
description: The Broadway musical can seem as oldfangled as the founding fathers. But an audacious hip-hop retelling of the life of the nations first Treasury secretary lands on Broadway on Monday poised to become the rarest of theatrical phenomena: not only a hit, but a turning point for the art form and a cultural conversation piece.

title: Previous Prison Escapes in Mexico
description: The drug lord Joaqun Guzmn Loeras escape from a maximum-security prison on Saturday using a well-constructed tunnel is the latest in a string of brazen escapes from Mexican penitentiaries over the years.

title: Deadpool, an Extra Witty Superhero, Has Comic-Con on Its Feet
description: SAN DIEGO  In the end, it was not even close: Deadpool from 20th Century Fox won Comic-Con  and one reason behind its success here should make studios nervous.

title: Actresses in Hamilton Take a Trip to a Family Home for a History Lesson
description: These should be very familiar to you, the docent in a skirt that billowed at the hips told one of the wide-eyed visitors, taking a dinner plate from a corner cupboard in the dining room. These were your dishes.

title: The Bonfire of the Vanities Gets Opera Adaptation
description: The Bonfire of the Vanities, Tom Wolfes iconic debut novel about the cutthroat socioeconomic world of 1980s New York City, will arrive on the Upper East Side in opera form in October. El Museo del Barrio will host the novels first stage adaptation on Oct. 9 and 10, with music by Stefania de Kenessey and libretto and direction by Michael Bergmann.

title: Talk Show Roundup: Lindsey Graham Calls Donald Trump a Threat to Republicans Moral Authority
description: Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, Scott Walker and the Obama administrations negotiations with Iran for a nuclear containment deal dominated the Sunday news shows.

title: Sundar Pichai of Google Talks About Phone Intrusion
description: Americans spend about three hours each day staring at their mobile phones. Thats a lot, but is it too much? As an article this weekend notes, several new companies betting that consumers crave less phone time are offering products like apps that filter messages and jewelry that buzzes only when the most important messages arrive.

title: Tour de France 2015: Team Time Trial Win Bolsters Americans Shot at Podium
description: PLUMELEC, France  BMC, the American team that includes the winner of the opening time trial of this years Tour de France, followed up by winning Sundays team event against the clock.

title: At Comic-Con, Faith-Based Entertainment Stays in the Shadows
description: SAN DIEGO  What would Jesus do at Comic-Con?

title: Killing the European Project
description: Suppose you consider Tsipras an incompetent twerp. Suppose you dearly want to see Syriza out of power. Suppose, even, that you welcome the prospect of pushing those annoying Greeks out of the euro.

title: Growth in the Gig Economy Fuels Work Force Anxieties
description: When the California Labor Commissioners Office ruled last month that an Uber driver was an employee deserving of a variety of workplace protections  and was not, as the company maintained, an independent contractor  it highlighted the divided feelings many Americans have about what is increasingly being called the gig economy.

title: Another Boys Title Signals a Bright Future for American Tennis
description: WIMBLEDON, England  After years of waiting for a mens champion, American tennis suddenly has a glut of promising rsums piling up.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 13
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: 25 Killed in Suicide Bombing Outside U.S. Base in Afghanistan
description: KHOST, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomber killed at least 25 people and wounded 15 on Sunday outside a United States base in Afghanistans southeastern province of Khost, the site of a suicide attack in 2009 that left seven C.I.A. operatives dead.

title: Le Corbusiers Architecture and His Politics Are Revisited
description: PARIS  Was the paradigm-changing architect known as Le Corbusier a fascist-leaning ideologue whose plans for garden cities were inspired by totalitarian ideals, or a humanist who wanted to improve peoples living conditions  a political naf who, like many architects, was eager to work with almost any regime that would let him build?

title: Mets Kirk Nieuwenhuis Hits Three Homers Against Diamondbacks
description: The first run the Mets scored Sunday came as a pleasant surprise for them. Kirk Nieuwenhuis sliced a line drive down the left-field line that kept carrying, and the crowd watched intently, erupting when the ball ricocheted off the padding at the top of the wall. As Nieuwenhuis rounded second base, he paused, too, looking back at the umpire for confirmation. The umpires even consulted the replay for 46 seconds, just to be sure.

title: Review: Skippyjon Jones Snow What Continues Tale of a Conflicted Cat
description: Skippyjon Jones is a Siamese cat who believes hes a Chihuahua. You might think hed require a veterinary psychologist or at least a visit from Jackson Galaxy, Animal Planets punked-out cat whisperer. But Theatreworks USA has a better idea: Just put the conflicted kitty onstage and let him act out his fantasies.

title: Review: Whelan/Watson: Other Stories Pairs Stars of Ballet
description: LONDON  The names in the title Whelan/Watson: Other Stories are those of Wendy Whelan, an American, and Edward Watson, a Brit. She retired from New York City Ballet in October after 23 years as principal; he has been a principal of the Royal Ballet for 10 years. They hold the attention throughout Other Stories, a 70-minute show in which theyre the only dancers. I saw it on Friday at Covent Gardens Linbury Studio Theater; it closed Sunday. Next spring, it is scheduled to play at New York City Center.

title: Greeks Anticipation Turns to Anxiety, Then Frustration in Weekend on Edge
description: ATHENS  Many Greeks went to bed on Friday thinking that their government and its creditors had all but completed a deal that would keep the country in the eurozone and was acceptable all around, even though it contained another raft of austerity measures.

title: Review: Arabella Brings Intrigue to the Munich Opera Festival
description: MUNICH  Richard Strausss Arabella, which had its premiere in 1933, is an enigma. You could see it as a shallow work, a story of a rich girl from an aristocratic but debt-ridden family, looking for love. Or, more harshly, it might be seen as a prissy update of Der Rosenkavalier that would have benefited from some redrafting prevented by the death of its librettist, Hugo von Hofmannsthal.

title: Festival dAix-en-Provence Includes A Midsummer Nights Dream Revival
description: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France  The venerable Festival dAix-en-Provence, founded in 1948 to enhance the natural beauties of southern France, is renowned especially for the quality and variety of its opera program, with Mozart as a staple. So it seemed sensible to begin a first return after some four decades with a tasting menu of old, new and indefinably in between.

title: Review: Owen Sheerss I Saw a Man Examines Grief and Responsibility
description: Something very bad has happened, we learn in the first sentence of Owen Sheerss new novel, I Saw a Man, something that changed all of their lives. (We are not yet sure whose lives these are.) It happened because one day, during a wiltingly steamy heat wave in London, a man named Michael Turner stepped through the open back door of his neighbors apparently empty house.

title: Julie Klausner Happily Channels Restlessness Into a Podcast, a TV Show and Cabaret
description: You could say its all because of Cats. Julie Klausner was a child when she came into New York City from upstate to see the musical with her parents in the early 1980s. And it probably ruined me for life, she said.

title: Review: National Youth Orchestra Impresses With Symphonie Fantastique at Carnegie Hall
description: The Swiss-born conductor Charles Dutoit, a major maestro with a special affinity for French repertory, has conducted Berliozs Symphonie Fantastique with many of the worlds great orchestras. But its hard to imagine he has ever worked with more eager, attentive players as he had on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall when he concluded a concert by the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America with a colorful, probing account of that demanding staple.

title: A City Turns to Face Indonesias Murderous Past
description: PALU, Indonesia  A half-century after the massacre of hundreds of thousands of suspected Communists and sympathizers, Indonesia has shown little interest in reckoning with the event.

title: The Invisible Hand Behind Harper Lees To Kill a Mockingbird
description: In the spring of 1957, a 31-year-old aspiring novelist named Harper Lee  everyone called her Nelle  delivered the manuscript for Go Set a Watchman to her agent to send out to publishers, including the now-defunct J. B. Lippincott Company, which eventually bought it.

title: Review: My Depression (The Up and Down and Up of It) Offers Hope to Others
description: As a theater artist, the versatile Elizabeth Swados often works on the fringes, writing, directing or providing music for pieces that bend forms and challenge audiences. But she is completely accessible in an animated film on Monday night on HBO. The subject is one she no doubt wants everyone to understand.The movie is My Depression (The Up and Down and Up of It), and its about her struggle with that condition. The film is adapted from her 2005 picture book  the screenplay is credited to Ms. Swados, David Wachtenheim and Robert Marianetti (the three also directed the film)  and its as charming and whimsical a discussion of depression as youre likely to find. And as musical. Yes, the song Suicide Mobile (sung by Steve Buscemi) may be a little dark for some tastes, but, like the rest of this film, its honest and forthright as it talks about a condition often misunderstood and misrepresented.

title: A Social Monday
description: MONDAY PUZZLE You dont need to be a social media whiz to pick up on the theme of todays puzzle, but a familiarity with some of the more popular terms will probably help you determine the answers a little quicker.

title: Ritchie Coster on Playing the Drunk Mayor on True Detective
description: Ritchie Coster is just as much in the dark about True Detective as the rest of us. Even though he plays Austin Chessani, the corrupt, often-inebriated mayor of Vinci, Calif., in HBOs hard-boiled drama, the 48-year-old London-born actor was given only the first three scripts when he signed on for the series. Beyond that, he saw only the scenes in which his character appears. A lot about it was a mystery, Mr. Coster said. I dont want to say they were being obtuse, but it was the most secrecy Ive ever encountered.

title: Alex Rodriguez and Rob Refsnyder Send Yankees Into All-Star Break on a High
description: BOSTON  Manager Joe Girardi, carrying a black plastic plate piled with Italian food, approached Mark Teixeira and wished him luck, presumably for Teixeiras appearance in the All-Star Game on Tuesday.

title: Roger Federers Loss at Wimbledon Is Disappointing, but Not Devastating
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Just as Roger Federer was handed the one object he did not want to touch  the Wimbledon runner-up trophy  his wife, Mirka, held up her cellphone from her seat in the family box, capturing the presentation.

title: World War II History, Captured in a Privates Letters to His Wife
description: For years the letter lay in a box in the attic. It was postmarked in April 1945, just before the Nazis surrender in World War II. It was just one letter among many letters, and the box was just one box among many boxes.

title: Luc Besson Talks About a Risky New Film, Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets, at Comic-Con
description: SAN DIEGO  Sometimes movies stand out at Comic-Con by delivering the unexpected in splashy fashion (Deadpool). Sometimes they win attention through sheer star power (X-Men: Apocalypse). Sometimes they blast their way into the conversation with booming bass and pure spectacle (Warcraft).

title: At St. Andrews, Renee Powell Rises Above Prejudices to Become a Pioneer
description: An unexpected gift arrived last December at the public golf course that Renee Powells father carved out of an old dairy farm in East Canton, Ohio. Interspersed with holiday mail was an envelope with a Scotland postmark. Inside was a letter of invitation for Powell to become one of the first seven female members of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club in St. Andrews, known as the home of golf.

title: Influential Site Inhabits Fringe of an Electronic Dance Music Culture
description: The electronic dance music craze has spawned hit singles, drawn corporate sponsors and fueled the growth of outdoor festivals  all part of a worldwide business estimated to be worth $6.9 billion a year.

title: At Least 2 Are Killed in Collapse at Russian Barracks
description: MOSCOW  A concrete military barracks partly collapsed on Sunday, killing at least two people at a training center in south-central Russia and trapping more than two dozen others in rubble, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Roy C. Bennett, Part of Midcentury Songwriting Duo, Dies at 96
description: Roy C. Bennett, who with his partner, Sid Tepper, wrote songs that were recorded by a wide roster of midcentury pop singers, including the titles Red Roses for a Blue Lady, Kiss of Fire and The Naughty Lady of Shady Lane, died on July 2 in Queens. He was 96.

title: The Shadow of Waco
description: In 1993, federal agents raided the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., and generated a legacy of fear that continues to shape antigovernment groups today.

title: Memories of Waco Siege Continue to Fuel Far-Right Groups
description: On Wednesday, the Army is scheduled to begin two months of training exercises across the American Southwest. If the past is a reasonable guide, some on the outer reaches of the far right are bound to recycle warnings that martial law is at hand. Conspiracy theorists were singularly imaginative after these war games, code-named Jade Helm 15, were announced.

title: Cameron Urges British Military to Spend More to Tackle ISIS
description: LONDON  After his government promised last week to hit NATO spending targets, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said on Sunday that he wanted more of the military budget to be spent on tackling Islamic extremism, citing special forces, spy planes and drones as probable priorities.

title: Time Check at the Terminal
description: Dear Diary:

title: Asian Tech Start-Ups Quietly Earn Backing
description: HONG KONG  The rise of a mobile software company from nothing to a $1 billion valuation in just over a year from its first product release would typically draw rapt attention, and jealousy, inside Silicon Valley.

title: Chinas Incendiary Market Is Fanned by Borrowers and Manipulation
description: SHANGHAI  At the height of the frenzy for Chinese stocks, just about every company was a winner.

title: Nuclear Plant Closing Reflects Overhaul of German Energy Production
description: GRAFENRHEINFELD, Germany  In one of this countrys most popular novels for young readers, the nuclear reactor on the edge of this Bavarian town melts down, spewing a radioactive cloud that threatens all of Germany and robs a 14-year-old girl of her family and her hope for the future.

title: Kosovo Charges 5 People in Plot to Poison Water
description: WARSAW  Five people were in custody in Kosovo on Sunday, suspected of a terrorist plot to contaminate the water supply in the capital, Pristina, after exhortations on recent videos released by the Islamic State to poison the countrys food and water supplies.

title: Grieving Joe Biden Focuses on the Job He Has Now, Not the Next One
description: WASHINGTON  Hosting a rockfish and crab lunch for a visiting Vietnamese leader, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. seemed subdued as he talked of a painful history and a promising future between the United States and Vietnam. He ad-libbed some remarks, made a few mild jokes and stared straight ahead when his guest spoke.

title: Site Devoted to Education Overhaul Is to Hold Presidential Forums
description: An education-focused news outlet run by the journalist-turned-advocate Campbell Brown plans to host presidential forums for both parties, with the first one held in New Hampshire.

title: Police in Western Ukraine Clash With Paramilitary Group; 7 Are Hurt
description: KIEV, Ukraine  In the worst breach yet between Ukrainian authorities and one of the pro-government right-wing paramilitary groups, at least seven people were wounded in a gun battle over the weekend in usually peaceful western Ukraine.

title: Creaky but Poised for a Run, for Old Times Sake
description: BOSTON  In the late-morning pregame hours, the scent of downtime in the air of the Yankees cramped Fenway Park redoubt, a handful of players were glued to a television as Roger Federer tried to turn back the championship clock.

title: Parsing the Popes Words (and Silences) to Hear His Messages in South America
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  In Ecuador, government supporters and opponents both seized on the same papal utterance as evidence that Pope Francis had taken their side during his historic visit last week. In Bolivia, people celebrated the popes reference to a thorny regional dispute that made officials in neighboring Chile cringe.

title: Marine Commanders Firing Stirs Debate on Integration of Women in Corps
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  When Lt. Col. Kate Germano took command of the Marine Corps all-women boot camp, the failure rate of female recruits at the rifle range was about three times higher than that of their male counterparts, and she said there was no plan to try to improve it. The thinking was girls cant shoot, so why bother, she said in an interview.

title: Trial to Begin for Thomas Libous, New York Senator Whose Son Was Convicted
description: When Senator Thomas W. Libous returned to Albany in June, shortly before this years legislative session concluded, his colleagues greeted him with a lengthy ovation.

title: Michael Conforto Finds Road to Promise in More Than One Sport
description: CINCINNATI  The Futures Game is the last of the showcase events for players on the rise. Most of them are used to the attention, being veterans of the prospect scene, and the setting  a major league park  is nothing new to many elite young players, who often play only baseball as amateurs.

title: Stakes High, Scott Walker Signs Wisconsin Budget
description: Gov. Scott Walker signed Wisconsins budget on Sunday afternoon, more than a week after the new budget year began and only hours before he was to announce his presidential campaign.

title: Charles Winick, Author Who Challenged Views on Drugs and Gender, Dies at 92
description: Charles Winick, a professor of anthropology and sociology who wrote a book bemoaning the blurring of lines between the sexes and who challenged prevailing views about the dangers of drug abuse, died on July 4 in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: New Hearing for Jason Rezaian Held in Iran
description: The third hearing in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been imprisoned in Iran for nearly a year, will be held on Monday in Tehran, Mr. Rezaians brother said on Sunday night.

title: Youth Programs Imperiled After New York Changes How Grants Are Awarded
description: For 30 years, Mount Sinai Adolescent Health Center has counseled teenagers in the Bronx and Manhattan on avoiding the trappings of drugs.

title: Brooklyn Law School Offers a Safety Net for New Students
description: Shelley Friedman, 21, who recently started a two-year program at Brooklyn Law School, is not too concerned about how she will fare in the job market after she earns her degree  and not just because she wont begin looking for work until she approaches graduation in May 2017. She is simply confident about her prospects.

title: Courts Support Obamas Contraceptive Policy, but Challenges Remain
description: WASHINGTON  Four federal appeals courts have upheld efforts by the Obama administration to guarantee access to free birth control for women, suggesting that the government may have found a way to circumvent religious organizations that refuse to provide coverage for some or all forms of contraception.

title: Jordan Spieth Heads to British Open With Grand Slam in His Sights
description: A target that Jordan Spieth thought, at the start of the year, was well out of his range suddenly seems as accessible as a drivable par 4. Spieth won his second consecutive start and his fourth title of 2015 on Sunday at the John Deere Classic to inch closer to golfs summit.

title: Puerto Ricos Meeting With Creditors, Janet Yellens Testimony and Googles Earnings
description: Monday afternoon, Puerto Ricos creditors are invited to meet at Citigroups Park Avenue office for a presentation by the Commonwealths top financial official and a former chief economist at the World Bank. The meeting, which will be streamed online to the public, is being billed as the first face-to-face meeting between Puerto Rico and its creditors since the governor declared that the islands debts were not payable. Michael Corkery

title: A Pursuit That Drained In Gee Chuns Family Produces a U.S. Womens Open Victory
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  In Gee Chun, carrying a big silver trophy after winning the 70th United States Womens Open on Sunday, suddenly had an entourage. After a photography session in front of the scoreboard with her name at the top, she was surrounded by nearly a dozen police officers and straggling fans seeking autographs.

title: Andrea Bargnani Agrees to a Two-Year Deal With the Nets
description: LAS VEGAS  After two unproductive, injury-marred seasons with the Knicks, Andrea Bargnani has found a new home in New York. On Sunday, Bargnani agreed to sign with the Nets, who are hoping that Bargnani, a former No. 1 overall draft pick, can somehow resuscitate his N.B.A. career in Brooklyn.

title: Review: Penn & Teller on Broadway Explores the Illusions of Technology
description: Though its been four decades since they first teamed up, Penn and Teller are looking terribly of-the-moment these days. Never mind that their latest entertaining exercise in populist hocus-pocus  Penn & Teller on Broadway, which opened on Sunday night at the Marquis Theater  includes some of the oldest tricks in any conjurers book, including the extraction of a rabbit from a top hat and sawing a woman in half.

title: Fighting to Bring Women in History to Central Park
description: Coline Jenkins is on a campaign to overthrow what she portrays as the bronze patriarchy in Central Park.

title: Poldark Episode 4 Recap: Ignominy vs. Constancy
description: Season 1, Episode 4

title: Comcast Offers Its Alternative to Cable TV, Using the Web
description: Comcast, the countrys largest cable operator, is responding to the rush of new streaming television alternatives with the start of its own web-based offering that includes a bundle of broadcast networks and the premium cable network HBO.

title: Pride in the Streets
description: New York Citys first Disability Pride Parade celebrated the 25th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act on Sunday.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: In the Season 3 Premiere, All Is Anger and Cruelty
description: Season 3, Episode 1, Untitled

title: Outdoor Pillows (With Shades of Blue)
description: Nice enough for indoors but able to stand up to the vagaries of summer.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Errol Morris and Parker Posey
description: Errol Morris and Parker Posey sip yogi tequila while sizing up 3D wallpaper and Yoko Onos set of sad saucers.

title: Time Inc. to Move Test Kitchens to Alabama
description: Time Inc., the nations largest magazine publisher, is moving almost all its recipe testing and other food editorial production for its 29 domestic magazines and websites to Birmingham, Ala., where it is building a food studio with 28 test kitchens, a dozen photography studios and a private dining room.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 1:20 P.M. (HBO2) THE FAULT IN OUR STARS (2014) Two teenage cancer kids  Hazel Grace Lancaster (Shailene Woodley), who expects to die soon from the thyroid cancer that has plagued her since childhood, and Augustus Waters (Ansel Elgort, above with Ms. Woodley), known as Gus, who lost part of his leg to cancer but has been healthy since  fall in love while trying to lead extraordinary lives in Josh Boones adaptation of the young-adult novel by John Green. Willem Dafoe plays Peter Van Houten, the misanthropic author of Hazels favorite cancer story, who lectures the couple on the difference between fiction and reality; Sam Trammell and Laura Dern are Hazels stricken parents; and Nat Wolff is Guss slightly goofy wingman. Though it is a tragic love story, it is also a perfect and irresistible fantasy, A. O. Scott wrote of the film in The New York Times. Hazel and Gus possess an absolute moral authority, an ability to assert the truth of their experience that few can share and many might covet. He added, The loudest weeping you hear  including your own  may arise not from grief or admiration, but from envy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I am so sick and tired of all this. Its such crazy theater. GIORGOS PAPADOPOULOS, a taxi driver, on talks between Greece and its creditors.

title: 2 Teenagers Shot at Festival in Brooklyn Park, Police Say
description: Two teenagers were shot during a West Indian music festival in Mount Prospect Park in Brooklynon Sundaynight, according to witnesses and the police, who said the boys were taken to a nearby hospital.

title: True Detective Recap: Big Auras and Slow S.U.V.s
description: This post contains spoilers for Sundays episode of True Detective.

title: Satoru Iwata, Nintendo Chief Executive, Dies at 55
description: Satoru Iwata, who as chief executive of Nintendo oversaw the introduction of gaming systems such as the Nintendo DS and the Wii, died on Saturday in Kyoto, Japan. He was 55.

title: Corrections: July 13, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Summer Road Trip With Ruth Fremson
description: Ruth Fremson is no stranger to America. Over the years, she has visited every state, often on assignment for The New York Times, where she has been a staff photographer since 2000.

title: Starbucks and Other Corporations to Announce Plan to Curb Unemployment of Young People
description: Spearheaded by Starbucks and its chief executive, Howard Schultz, nearly 20 big American corporations will unveil a plan on Monday to find jobs for 100,000 unemployed young people over the next three years.

title: Tsinghua Business Graduates Scrap Market-Oriented Slogan
description: Following one of the most turbulent weeks for Chinas stock markets, some of the countrys brightest young business majors assembled for their graduation from prestigious Tsinghua University in Beijing on Sunday.

title: Premier of Greece, Alexis Tsipras, Accepts Creditors Austerity Deal
description: ATHENS  Forced by his nations creditors into broad new concessions to avert financial collapse, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece returned home on Monday with just days to sell the deal to fractured lawmakers and a dazed electorate.

title: Bakeries and Same-Sex Marriage: Wedding Cakes for All
description: To the Editor:

title: The Truth About Gluten
description: To the Editor:

title: Contraband and Prison Security in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Statutory Rape Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecting Young People With Jobs
description: SEATTLE  IN one of the few photos she has of her mother, Carmen Williams is a pigtailed toddler and her moms arms are wrapped around her and her brother. This is the only time I remember her holding us, she said earlier this summer, after we met her during a tour of a charter school in inner-city Philadelphia. For me growing up, I had a different definition of normal.

title: The Laziness Dogma
description: Americans work longer hours than their counterparts in just about every other wealthy country; we are known, among those who study such things, as the no-vacation nation. According to a 2009 study, full-time U.S. workers put in almost 30 percent more hours over the course of a year than their German counterparts, largely because they had only half as many weeks of paid leave. Not surprisingly, work-life balance is a big problem for many people.

title: Lost in the Immigration Frenzy
description: Kathryn Steinle was killed on a pier in San Francisco on July 1, allegedly by a troubled immigrant who had a stolen gun and a long criminal history and had been deported five times. The shooting was inexplicable, yet Ms. Steinles family and friends have been shunning talk of politics and vengeance, while expressing the hope that some good might emerge from this tragedy.

title: Jefferson Davis on Fire
description: THE president of the Confederate States of America still watches over much of the nation he hoped to destroy. Statues, memorials or roadside markers in honor of Jefferson Davis stand in a dozen states; his bronze presence in the United States Capitol is a public relations coup unmatched in American history; and last weeks conflict in Congress over rebel flags on federal property made his ghost difficult to ignore.

title: Lowering the Teenage Birthrate
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Contraception for Young Women
description: Colorado has achieved remarkable reductions in the rate of teenage pregnancy in recent years by giving young women free, long-acting contraceptives that protect them for several years. The birthrate among teenagers in the state plummeted by 40 percent from 2009 to 2013 and teenage abortions dropped by 42 percent largely as a result of this initiative.

title: A Bias More Than Skin Deep
description: I will never forget the October 2013 feature on National Geographics website:

title: Californias Tough Vaccination Law
description: California sets a smart example for the nation by passing tough new laws that will require the vast majority of children in day care or kindergarten to be vaccinated against a slew of infectious diseases next year. The state will no longer grant exemptions based on a parents religious convictions or personal belief that vaccines might be harmful. It will only allow exemptions for children with medical conditions that make vaccination unsafe. This public health policy ought to be adopted by all states.

title: Hearing Without an Ending in Rezaian Spy Case in Iran
description: TEHRAN  A third hearing in the espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been imprisoned in Iran for nearly a year, was held on Monday, ending without a conclusion or any indication of a resumption date.

title: I.M.F Chief Announces Greece Agreement
description: Christine Lagarde said the deal rebuilt confidence and had to be followed by Greeces putting in place the commitments it made during the talks.

title: Text of the Euro Summit Statement on Greece
description: The text of the final conclusions from the summit of 19 eurozone leaders that began on Sunday afternoon and ended on Monday morning with a deal on Greeces debt crisis.

title: Platform Specialty Products to Acquire Alent for $2.1 Billion
description: LONDON  The American chemical company Platform Specialty Products Corporation said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the British maker of chemicals and materials Alent for 1.35 billion pounds, or about $2.1 billion.

title: Big Science, by Michael Hiltzik
description: Modern scientific machinery is increasingly international and astronomically expensive. The Thirty Meter Telescope (T.M.T.) taking shape atop Mauna Kea in Hawaii costs $1.4 billion, will be 18 stories high and is under construction in partnership with Japan and other countries. ITER, a $21 billion, 24-story-high project to explore nuclear fusion, is being built in France by seven international partners, including the European Union, Russia, China and the United States. The Large Hadron Collider (L.H.C.), which produced the Higgs boson three years ago, cost $10 billion, is 17 miles in circumference and straddles two nations.

title: The Weather Experiment, by Peter Moore
description: On the 25th of October in 1859, the steam clipper Royal Charter rounded the island of Anglesey off the coast of Wales on what was supposed to be the celebratory last evening of its two-month journey from Melbourne to Liverpool. Some 500 men, women and children were nearly home, many feeling blessed with fortunes worked from Australias Ballarat goldfields. Gold bullion and specie were crammed into pockets, hidden in money belts and locked up in the strongroom.

title: In Search of Sir Thomas Browne, by Hugh Aldersey-Williams
description: The history of English prose can be seen as a dialectical struggle between two tendencies: plain versus grand. The plain style aims at ease and lucidity. It favors simply structured sentences, short words of Saxon origin and a conversational tone. It runs the risk of being flat. By contrast, the grand style  also called (by Cyril Connolly) mandarin  aims at rhetorical luxuriance. It is characterized by rolling periods decked with balanced subordinate clauses, a polysyllabic Latinate vocabulary, elaborate rhythms, stately epithets, sumptuous metaphors, learned allusions and fanciful turns of phrase. It runs the risk of being ridiculous.

title: At Extended-Stay Hotels, a Sense of Home (or a Party)
description: Mike Jones spends about 100 days a year on the road in his work as an executive at a chemical company. Traveling from his home in North Carolina to as far as Malaysia and Thailand, he prefers extended-stay hotels.

title: An Altar to Donald Trump Swallows Up Public Space in Manhattan
description: For anyone in New York shopping for a Trump Collection silk tie and matching shirt, or Empire and Success colognes, about the only place left to find such billionaire memorabilia is on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Not in a department store, though, but in the lobby of Trump Tower.

title: Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, Tibetan Religious Leader, Dies in Chinese Custody
description: HONG KONG  One of the most prominent Tibetan religious leaders in Chinese custody has died, a family member and a Tibetan exile group said on Monday.

title: Mondays Travel News: A Broadway Tour; Caribbean Hotel Deals
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Into the Wild With Sarah Ryhanen
description: The imaginative Brooklyn florist wanted to grow flowers on her own terms. Long winters, lost crops and a creaky old house aside, its worked out perfectly.

title: Russia Says 23 Are Now Dead After Collapse of Barracks
description: MOSCOW  A late-night barracks collapse killed 23 people and wounded at least 22 others in south-central Russia, as soldiers at a training center for airborne forces were crushed in their beds by a cascade of concrete and metal, the Russian Defense Ministry said on Monday.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: ScienceTake | How to Read Octopus
description: One octopus may signal its intent to fight with changes in color and posture.

title: How to Cut Childrens Screen Time? Say No to Yourself First.
description: Parents are often at fault, directly or indirectly, when children and teenagers become hooked on electronic media, playing video games or sending texts many hours a day instead of interacting with the real world and the people in it. And as discussed in last weeks column, digital overload can impair a childs social, emotional and intellectual growth.

title: Solitary Octopuses Strong Statements
description: Some animals just arent that social. Like octopuses. They dont live in groups. They dont have big chatterfests like prairie dogs. They dont write, they dont call.

title: Ask Well: Muscle Knots
description: Question:

title: Pluto Comes Into Focus
description: LAKE TEKAPO, New Zealand  TWENTY-FOUR hours before showtime our prospects looked bleak. Halfway around the world from our homes in Massachusetts, our team of astronomers had traveled to this lakes barren shores for a two-minute encounter with Pluto. But the wind was at gale force, so we werent even allowed to open the telescope dome.

title: New York Today: Unearthing the Regions Hidden Skeletons
description: Good morning on this toothy Monday.

title: Peoples Daily Details Allegations Against Lawyers Detained in China
description: The police in China have detained dozens of lawyers in recent days, dealing a bruising blow to the rights defense movement that has sought to expand civic rights through litigation and publicity.

title: Can Moral Disputes Be Resolved?
description: Moral disputes seem intractable  more intractable than other disputes. Take an example of a moral position that most of us would consider obvious: Honor killing is wrong. But honor killing has its supporters. Anyone who suggests that we can compromise with its supporters on the matter misunderstands the nature of this type of disagreement. Its absolute. One party has to be right. Us. So why cant we convince those who hold the opposite view?

title: Scott Walker Enters 2016 Presidential Race, Pledging Conservative Agenda
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker, who built a national conservative following by crippling public employee unions and then defeating an effort to recall him, announced on Monday that he was running for president as a Washington outsider who would reduce taxes, challenge Iran and Russia, and cut the size of the federal government.

title: Why Hillary Clinton Wants to Remember Your Birthday
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she always remembers a birthday. So shes asking supporters of her presidential candidacy to tell her theirs so she can send a personalized card.

title: Today in Politics: A Perceived Front-Runner Joins the Race
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where negotiators have expressed optimism over a nuclear deal with Iran, and where Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is taking it a day at a time after the death of his son Beau. But the campaign trail is preparing for another Republican candidate as Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, fresh off signing a contentious state budget, makes an announcement.

title: Scott Walker on the Issues
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday. A fiscal conservative who has taken on Wisconsins public-sector unions, Mr. Walker has also promoted his adherence to socially conservative values like opposition to same-sex marriage. Here are his stances on important issues.

title: Things You May Not Know About Scott Walker
description: He is well known to Wisconsin voters, widely reviled by many union leaders and admired by a healthy segment of the Republican primary electorate. But there is much voters can still learn about Gov. Scott Walker, who announced his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday. Here are some things you may not know about him.

title: Birth Control on Demand
Merkel Outlines Next Steps on Greece
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said the deal on Greeces debt announced on Monday would be debated in the German Parliament.

title: What Scott Walker Would Need to Do to Win
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has announced he is joining the race for the Republican presidential nomination. Here is a look at what he will need to do to win.

title: Hillary Clinton Speech Is Not Expected to Dwell on Wall Street
description: In a speech in Lower Manhattan during the 2008 Democratic primaries, Hillary Rodham Clinton assailed Wall Street for its role in a subprime mortgage crisis that was months away from becoming the worst financial meltdown since the Great Depression.

title: Morning Agenda: A Deal for Greece
description: A DEAL FOR GREECE | Grexit has been averted and a deal has been done. After haggling through the night, past the midnight deadline and into the morning, European leaders have agreed on Greeces third bailout package in five years,  write James Kanter and Andrew Higgins in The New York Times. It includes a complete overhaul of the pension system, changes to the labor market and privatization plans.

title: Scott Walker Had a Great Starting Position but Not a Great Start
description: Scott Walkers rapid but unsurprising rise to the top of the Republican pack was perhaps the clearest example during the first half of the primary season of the importance of fundamentals: factors that shape the outcome of the race from the very start, like the amount of support from party elites and the potential to build a broad coalition. His ability to appeal to conservatives  thanks to his high-profile fight against organized labor in Wisconsin  without alienating the rest of the party instantly made him a formidable contender.

title: How an Insomnia Therapy Can Help With Other Illnesses
description: Its a Catch-22 that even those with a common cold experience: Illness disrupts sleep. Poor sleep makes the symptoms of the illness worse.

title: Microsoft Strikes New Tone for Windows 10 Release
description: SEATTLE  Almost 20 years ago, Microsoft licensed the Rolling Stones song Start Me Up to add a dash of rock n roll to the release of Windows 95, the product that catapulted the company to a high-water mark of influence in the tech industry.

title: CrowdStrike, Cybersecurity Services Provider, Raises $100 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the wake of computer attacks on the government and other prominent targets, investor interest in cybersecurity is unsurprisingly high.

title: Pipeline Operator MPLX to Buy MarkWest Energy Partners
description: The pipeline operator MPLX said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire MarkWest Energy Partners, in a deal that values the company at about $20 billion, including debt.

title: Malaysia Investigates Leaks Claiming to Show Transfers to Najib Razak
description: BANGKOK  The Malaysian police said on Monday that they were opening an investigation into whether government officials, including central bank personnel, were the source of leaked documents purporting to show the transfer of hundreds of millions of dollars into the bank accounts of Prime Minister Najib Razak and his wife.

title: Romanian Prime Minister, Accused of Graft, Is Indicted
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Prosecutors in Romania temporarily seized the assets of Prime Minister Victor Ponta on Monday after indicting him in a corruption investigation, accusing him of forgery, money laundering and tax evasion before his ascension to power.

title: Latest Count Has Marco Rubio Near Top of G.O.P. Fund-Raisers
description: Senator Marco Rubio has started his presidential campaign on strong financial footing, raising about $12 million since announcing his run in April.

title: Daily Report: The New Technology to Save Us From Technology
description: Smartphones have invaded our lives so quickly and thoroughly, its easy to forget that they are still a relatively new technology, Conor Dougherty writes.

title: Jarden to Acquire Waddington Group for $1.35 Billion
description: The consumer products company Jarden Corporation said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the disposable dinnerware maker Waddington Group for about $1.35 billion.

title: Protest on Runway Over Heathrow Airport Expansion Disrupts Flights
description: LONDON  More than 20 flights were canceled on Monday at Heathrow Airport here in London after members of an environmental group cut through a perimeter fence and chained themselves to one another on a runway to protest against the possible expansion of the airport.

title: Deal on Greek Debt Crisis Exposes Europes Deepening Fissures
description: LONDON  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said about Greece on Sunday that the most important currency has been lost: that is trust and reliability. But many Germans think the most important currency that has been lost is the deutsche mark, the symbol of rectitude and confidence that embodied West Germanys ascent from the ashes of World War II.

title: Greek Merchants Fear a Way of Life Is Disappearing
description: ATHENS  Fifteen years ago, Spyros Kyriakopoulos and his partner took over a small pastry shop on a side street near downtown Athens and began selling the braided loaves called tsourekia and traditional Greek dipping cookies.

title: Tsipras Hopes Exit Is Thing of Past
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece said that the deal the country reached with its creditors offered possibilities for recovery, but that putting it in place could prove to be difficult.

title: Times Critics Guide: What to Do This Week
description: Looking to break out of a cultural rut?

title: Pope Francis Says Hes Overlooked the Worlds Middle Class
description: ABOARD THE PAPAL AIRPLANE  Pope Francis has dedicated his papacy to the plight of the poor and delivered severe critiques of economic systems that benefit the rich. But flying back to Rome from his eight-day visit to Latin America, Francis admitted he had overlooked a group.

title: Scott Walkers Announcement Video
description: In a video posted online Monday, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin announced he was joining the Republican field in the 2016 race for president of the United States.

title: Iraq Begins Military Operation to Drive ISIS From Anbar Province
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government declared on Monday that it was beginning a major military operation to retake the western province of Anbar from the Islamic State, which occupies much of the area including its major cities, Ramadi and Falluja.

title: A Lot of Big Toes Arent the Biggest
description: Since summer is sandal-wearing season, its the time of year for seeing just how many people have Mortons toe, with the second toe being the longest.

title: Baseballs Over- and Underachievers at the All-Star Break
description: The All-Star break is a good time to take stock. A little more than half the baseball season is over. Enough time has passed for unsustainable hot streaks to cool and early strugglers to find their form. It is a little late for most excuses.

title: Review: DruidShakespeare: The History Plays Is Complete With a Crown Fit for Many Kings
