description: For someone who first conquered Broadway as the most wholesome kid on the block, Sutton Foster dirties up real nice. Playing a jaded jazz baby in Andrew Lippas The Wild Party, which has been given a glossy concert revival by the Encores! Off-Center summer series, the actress who made her name being perky in musicals like Thoroughly Modern Millie and Little Women looks deliciously louche and lowdown.

title: Scott Walker Walks a Conservative Tightrope in New Hampshire
description: AMHERST, N.H.  Is Scott Walker too conservative to win the New Hampshire primary?

title: Chinese Cremate Body of Revered Tibetan Monk, Ignoring Pleas
description: BEIJING  The authorities in southwest China on Thursday cremated the body of a prominent Tibetan monk who died in prison last week, ignoring the pleas of relatives, religious leaders and thousands of supporters who had demanded that they be allowed to carry out funeral rites integral to Tibetan Buddhism.

title: A New L.A. Lifestyle Shop With a Bodega Sensibility
description: Sean Knibb has emerged as a key stakeholder in the Los Angeles design scene for his quirky, slightly surreal elevation of everyday materials, both indoors and out. Now, fans of his environmental design work  which includes, most famously, the industrial-chic Line hotel in Koreatown  can take home a piece of his sensibility at Knibbs first retail space, Flowerboy Project, opening Saturday adjacent to the Knibb Design studio in Venice, Calif. Like many lifestyle stores in the neighborhood, the space includes a selection of design, fashion and beauty goods  but is anchored by a daily selection of fresh-cut blooms (bouquets come prearranged in jars in sizes small, medium and large).

title: When Cries of Rape Are Heard in Opera Halls
description: At the beginning of Don Giovanni, a masked man breaks into a womans room in the middle of the night. Later in the opera, the woman  Donna Anna  describes the encounter to her fianc as an attempted rape. Do we believe her? While we can sift through Mozarts harmonies for proof, we always return to Annas words: The man wanted to embrace me. As I tried to free myself, he held me even tighter.

title: The Boos in the Balcony, and Their Targets
description: The uproar at the Royal Opera over its new production of Rossinis Guillaume Tell is part of a venerable operatic tradition. Such fury can surprise the uninitiated, who mistakenly think of opera as safe, effete entertainment  and not as the blood sport that aficionados know, love and, sometimes, love to hate. Booing, like opera, can be divided into several genres.

title: Gibney Dance to Continue Work With Domestic Violence Victims
description: The fall season of Gibney Dance will include performances at its new space in Lower Manhattan, a continuation of its work with victims of domestic violence and a new round of residencies for 10 choreographers based in New York City, the company announced.

title: Merkel Comforts Palestinian Girl
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany told a Palestinian teenager who said she was in danger of deportation that Germany cannot allow all refugees to stay, then attempted to comfort her.

title: Orley: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Kikis
description: A Greek tavern in Chinatown.

title: Kikis Greek Tavern Needs No Translation
description: Division Street is short-lived: It starts off under the watchful eyes of the Confucius statue at Bowerys southern end, ducks under the Manhattan Bridge, and dies out at Canal Street, less than a third of a mile later.

title: Gose Is a Beer That Keeps Summer Cool
description: It was just a month ago that I found what I now consider my official summer beer of 2015. I was in Austin, Tex., in mid-June, not technically summer yet but hot enough under the Texas sun to qualify as a dog day.

title: Art Matters
description: Raybon Pettibone, Richard Prince and more at auction.

title: Gunman Kills 4 Marines at Military Site in Chattanooga
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  A 24-year-old Kuwaiti-born gunman opened fire on a military recruiting station on Thursday, then raced to a second military site where he killed four United States Marines, prompting a federal domestic terrorism investigation. Three other people, including a Marine Corps recruiter and a police officer, were wounded, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Collection of Silhouette Portraits Is to Be Auctioned
description: Meticulous notes about provenance trails are scrawled on the backs of about 100 silhouette portraits that Willis Henry Auctions  will offer on Aug. 2 in Manchester, N.H. The collection belonged to the folk-art historian Howard Fertig, who died in 2012, at 85, and his wife, Florence, a retired antiques dealer.

title: As Four
description: Schohaja, a photographer and T contributor, shares her personal snapshots of the once design collective, taken in 2002 and 2003.

title: Verbatim: Rick Perry Lashes Out at Donald Trump
description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, in a statement posted to his campaigns website criticizing Donald J. Trumps border security comments.

title: Emmy Awards 2015: Winners and Nominees
description: Winners are in bold. (The full list of nominees and winners is available at the Emmys website.)

title: Perry Ellis: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Jeb Bushs Uber Ride: A Journey and an Economic Message
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Jeb Bush summoned a car from Uber on Thursday morning, using the ride-hailing app to take him to Thumbtack, a consumer-service technology company, more than a dozen reporters packed around as he exited the vehicle.

title: Michael Kors: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Op-Photo: Protesters Wave Confederate Flags at President Obama
description: As President Obama arrived in Oklahoma City on Wednesday, some protesters waved the flag he has called a reminder of systemic oppression and racial subjugation.

title: Polar Bears Dont Go Into Hibernation-Like State in Summer, Researchers Say
description: Scientists have long considered the possibility that polar bears enter a kind of walking hibernation to cut down their energy demands during the summer, when food on land is scarce.

title: Dollhouse Appraised at $8.5 Million Is to Tour
description: A dollhouse with 29 rooms, stacked nine feet tall inside papier-mch turrets, will hit the road as a fund-raising attraction.

title: F.C.C. Votes to Limit Discounts in Airwaves Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved plans to prevent large businesses from gaining access to small-business discounts in a much-anticipated auction of airwaves expected early next year.

title: Review: Design and Violence, Online at MoMA
description: Described on the Museum of Modern Arts website as a curatorial experiment, Design and Violence was and is  its presence in time and space is part of the experiment  an exhibition that exists almost entirely on the Internet.

title: Jeffrey Webb, Top FIFA Official, Said to Be in U.S. After Agreeing to Extradition
description: United States prosecutors have extradited a top FIFA executive arrested in Switzerland as part of their investigation of corruption in world soccer, and on Thursday they revealed that they had been engaged in plea negotiations with another defendant charged in the case.

title: BBC, a Target of Conservatives, Faces a Review of Its Mission
description: LONDON  The Conservative government in Britain has set its sights on remaking the BBC, the broadcaster supported by a national license fee, after a political campaign in which the Conservatives complained that the BBCs news coverage has a left-wing bias.

title: Lance Armstrong Bikes Along the Fringe of the Tour, to the Chagrin of Many
description: PLATEAU DE BEILLE, France  It was only the Tour de France by association, and it was not even a race. But Lance Armstrong was indeed back riding his bike on French roads Thursday.

title: Review: Facing East Examines Chinese Influence on African Cities
description: In 2009, two Dutch compatriots  Michiel Hulshof, a journalist covering China, and Daan Roggeveen, an architect working there  met in Shanghai and discovered they had a mutual fascination with urbanization in China. They were particularly intrigued by developments in secondary cities like Taiyuan, Hohhot and Lanzhou, which were largely off the Wests radar.

title: Civilians Killed in Disputed Kashmir Region Between India and Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD  Tensions erupted into violence on Thursday between the estranged, nuclear-armed neighbors Pakistan and India, as both sides made competing claims of violations by security forces along a de facto border in the disputed Kashmir region.

title: Dylann Storm Roof Court Appearance
description: Dylann Storm Roof, 21, charged with killing nine black parishioners in a Charleston, S.C., church last month, appeared in a South Carolina court on Thursday.

title: British Open 2015: Tom Watson Isnt Happy About How He Looks on Course, or on Fans Masks
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  For the most part, Tom Watson appreciated all the support he received from the fans at the Old Course on Thursday as he began what he said would be his final British Open. There was a small group of spectators, however, with whom Watson, 65, took issue: the ones wearing Tom Watson masks.

title: The Wedding Toast Ill Never Give
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Kathryn Hahn in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below or subscribe on iTunes or Google Play Music.

title: Review: Kate Newby and Helen Johnson at Laurel Gitlen
description: Each of these side-by-side solos introduces an extremely promising artist: one with a full-fledged New York gallery debut, and the other with three paintings that feel more like a trailer for a debut.

title: Bigger Might Have Been Better for Goldman
description: Goldman Sachss second-quarter showing may for once leave it wishing it was a sprawling mega-bank.

title: Twitters Communications Chief Leaves as It Seeks New Message
description: Gabriel Stricker, the chief communications officer of Twitter, left the company Thursday  the first high-level management change under Jack Dorsey, the Twitter co-founder who stepped in on July 1 to run the troubled company temporarily while the board searches for a permanent chief executive to replace Dick Costolo.

title: Senate Approves a Bill to Revamp No Child Left Behind
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in 14 years, the Senate on Thursday approved a revised version of No Child Left Behind, the signature Bush-era education law that ushered in an era of broadly reviled, high-stakes standardized testing.

title: Britains Liberal Democrats Pick Tim Farron as Leader
description: LONDON  Seeking to revive their partys fortunes after its worst elections ever, Britains Liberal Democrats on Thursday chose as their leader Tim Farron, a member of Parliament who has signaled a return to the left with plans to focus on human rights, the environment and social inequality.

title: Guilty Verdict forJames Holmes in Aurora Attack
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  Inside Courtroom 201, the families of the dead and wounded watched in taut silence on Thursday afternoon as the judge shuffled through a stack of verdict forms containing the fate of James E. Holmes, the gunman who slipped into a Colorado movie theater in 2012 and opened fire on their sons and daughters, friends and loved ones.

title: Vermont Furniture, Experimental and Elegant at the Shelburne Museum
description: Connoisseurs of Vermont antiques have long sought to dispel notions that the furniture is rustic, and that the makers were eccentrics living on the edges of the wilderness. In the last few decades, historians and collectors have unearthed evidence that the states early woodworkers, even those farming in remote spots, kept up with trends in design, materials and tools. An exhibition surveying these sophisticated pieces, Rich and Tasty: Vermont Furniture to 1850, opens on July 25 at the Shelburne Museum in Vermont.

title: Cuomo Signs Nail Salon Bill
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, a Democrat, signed into a law on Thursday a measure that overhauls licensing practices in the industry.

title: Bakers Reason for Withholding a Cake Is Crummy
description: I was asked to make a wedding cake for the daughter of a friend I havent been in touch with for a few years. (I used to bake cakes professionally.) The problem is, I was widowed three years ago, and this friend never sent a condolence card or contacted me, even though she knew my husband had died. I declined to bake the cake. But she is not giving up easily. I want to express how hurtful this is without being judgmental. Can I make this a lesson for her?

title: Jury Instructions in the Trial of James E. Holmes
description: Jurors considered these counts in the trial of Mr. Holmes, accused of being the gunman in the July 2012 movie theater shooting in Aurora, Colo., in which 12 people died.

title: Santa Fe Opera Adds Performance of Cold Mountain
description: The strong interest in next months world premiere of Cold Mountain, an opera by Jennifer Higdon based on the novel by Charles Frazier, has led the Santa Fe Opera to add an extra performance and make plans to release a recording of it, the company announced on Thursday.

title: Obama Urges Criminal Justice Overhaul
description: President Obama spoke on Thursday after visiting a federal prison in Oklahoma. There but for the grace of God, Mr. Obama said. And that is something we all have to think about.

title: Review: The Guardsman, at the Shakespeare Theater, Pricks the Heart While Eliciting Laughs
description: The green-eyed monster of jealousy rears its head at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison, but not, as might be expected, in Othello. Instead, prepare to meet The Guardsman, a 1910 comedy that successfully seizes the potentially tragic theme of marital mistrust and twists it into mirth.

title: Angela Merkels Encounter With a Teary Young Refugee Draws Mixed Reactions
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels response to a tearful Palestinian girl who pleaded for her family to be allowed to stay in Germany drew both praise and criticism on Thursday, as a video of the encounter spread across the Internet.

title: Image Object at City Hall Park in Manhattan
description: This exhibition looks at the two-way relationship between image and object.

title: Review: Image Object Looks at the Relationship Between the Virtual and the Physical
description: When contemporary art ventures into the public realm, outside the protective walls of galleries and museums, the question arises, Who is this for? Its potential audience is no longer viewers who are already interested; now it includes passers-by of many dispositions, not all of whom have the time or the inclination to reflect on the aesthetics and knotty ideas that artworks may put in their paths.

title: Reddit Changes Content Rules as Steve Huffman Takes Charge
description: The return of a founder to a company is a well-worn story line in Silicon Valley.

title: At Studio Museum in Harlem, a Social and Arty Evening
description: While Harlems restaurant renaissance is still buzzworthy, its the neighborhoods growing art scene that has been making headlines lately. In addition to an anticipated move by Gavin Browns Enterprise from the West Village to a former brewery on West 126th Street in September, the Studio Museum in Harlem is planning a $122 million new home on West 125th Street.

title: 1943 | In Tehran, The Timess International Edition Is Born
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Google Revenues Up 11% as Earnings Surpass Forecast
description: Investors have spent the last year telling Google to stop opening its wallet so much. On Thursday, they got their wish.

title: The Greece Deal Pleases No One
description: The ink isnt even dry on the eurozones latest agreement with Greece but many of the main players who negotiated it are publicly expressing skepticism. They all take a slightly different view of whats wrong with the deal, but the central thread tying them together is the fact that it will not help reduce Greeces mountain of unpayable debt.

title: Congressmen Propose Antidoping Agency for Horse Racing
description: It took 37 years and a singular horse named American Pharoah to deliver horse racing its 12th Triple Crown winner at Belmont Park in June. On Thursday, a coalition of horse breeders, owners and animal lovers turned to Congress with the hope of ending another long-running drama in thoroughbred racing: its drug problem.

title: Bucky Loves Selma
description: It all began when he was 15 and she was 13.

title: It Began With Secret Pickles, and Survived a War
description: Bucky Bachner was one of the boys on the roof.

title: Chattanooga Officials Discuss Shooting
description: Mayor Andy Berke of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Bill Killian, a United States attorney in Tennessee, spoke on Thursday after a gunman opened fire at two military centers, killing at least four Marines.

title: Reading and Writing the Waves
description: William Finnegan has spent nearly three decades as a staff writer for The New Yorker, reporting on civil war in Sudan, drug cartels in Mexico and global sex trafficking, among other subjects.

title: Feeling the Pain and Sweat of the Ring in Southpaw
description: The director and cameramen discuss how they filmed the visceral fight scenes in the boxing drama.

title: Masks, Sweat and Mosh Pits
description: The crowd at a fashion week party at Church Street Boxing Gym was as rowdy as the wrestlers in the ring.

title: Concert Marking Anniversary of Eric Garners Death Set for Friday
description: The killing of Eric Garner by a police officer using a chokehold last year sparked protests around the country and led rappers to hold memorial concerts in Staten Island, where he was killed, and as far away as Oakland, Calif. A concert being held Friday night to mark the first anniversary of his death will have a similar message but a different sound: it will be orchestral.

title: Review: Yarn/Wire Mesmerizes at Lincoln Center Festival
description: Over the course of music history composers have emphasized different aspects of music: melody, for instance, or harmony or timbre. On Wednesday evening, the Lincoln Center Festival offered a mesmerizing concert of new music that explored resonance as a central expressive device. The concert, at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse, featured Yarn/Wire, an ensemble made up of two percussionists and two pianists. They presented three world premieres by Tristan Murail, Misato Mochizuki and Raphal Cendo, who all found different ways to luxuriate in the sound-clouds this combination of instruments can produce.

title: Review: At Asbury Festhalle & Biergarten, Authentic Beer Garden Meets Jersey Shore
description: When I walked into the Asbury Festhalle & Biergarten for the first time, I was told that my friend and I could sit anywhere we wanted. But where?

title: France Detains 3 Men in Alleged Plot to Attack Military Base
description: PARIS  France has foiled a terrorist plot and detained three men who are accused of plotting to enter a military base, stage an attack there and film it, according to the Interior Ministry.

title: Review: Foo Fighters Bring a Little of Everything to the Stage, Including a Broken Leg
description: Dave Grohl had an accident last month, two songs into a Foo Fighters concert in Sweden. He stumbled and fell off the stage, breaking the fibula in his right leg and dislocating his ankle. He appeared to go into warrior mentality very quickly. He insisted that he be carried back onstage on a stretcher so that he could keep performing, seated with his leg up, while a medic prepared him a splint.

title: Hillary Clinton Proposes Tax Credit for Businesses That Share Profits
description: Granting tax incentives to persuade corporations to share more of their profits with employees is one of the key ideas to emerge from Hillary Rodham Clintons recently announced economic agenda, which relies mostly on standard Democratic proposals to address stagnant middle-class wages and the overwhelming concentration of wealth among the richest Americans.

title: Hans H. Angermueller, 90, Dies; Banker Helped Free U.S. Hostages in Iran
description: Hans H. Angermueller, a runner-up for the top job at Citicorp in the 1980s who helped devise a financial deal to free American hostages in Iran, died on July 11 in Westerly, R.I. He was 90.

title: Letters: Revolutionary Roads
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu May Turn Iran Defeat to His Favor
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli commentators have described this weeks Iran nuclear deal as a personal failure, a stinging failure, and a colossal failure for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Yair Lapid, a rival who heads an opposition faction in Israels Parliament, called it the greatest failure in foreign policy of any Israeli prime minister since the states establishment and demanded his ouster.

title: Review: Joachim Wtewaels Provocative and Puzzling Paintings at the National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON  How can you maintain fame if people cant say your name? This is one question that might have occurred to the 16th-century Dutch artist Joachim Wtewael if he had cared about lasting fame, which, apparently, he only sometimes did. Over the span of his well-cushioned life in Utrecht, Wtewael  pronounced, approximately, oo-tuh-vawl (even the Dutch have a hard time with it)  seems to have paid more attention to selling flax and buying stocks than he did to making art, even though art was his first calling and did bring him local renown.

title: Review: In Daphne, the Cleveland Orchestra Takes on a Difficult Strauss Opera
description: Though Richard Strauss thought highly of his one-act 1938 opera Daphne, a bucolic tragedy, as he and the librettist Joseph Gregor called it, posterity has not agreed. Even many Strauss-lovers feel that the score, while sumptuous and beguiling, is not top-tier Strauss, until the final scene of this mythological fantasy, when Daphne, a nature girl who longs to bond with the woods and meadows, is transformed by the gods into a tree. Here at last in this intricate, slightly strange music is Strauss at his most ingenious.

title: The Marine Corps Command Investigation Into Alleged Abuse of Authority by Lt. Col. Kate Germano
description: This investigation, initiated by the commander of the Marine Corps Training Depot at Parris Island, found that Colonel Germano, the commander of the womens training battalion, created a hostile, repressive, and unprofessional command climate.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, July 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: New Review Ordered Into Israels Gaza Flotilla Raid
description: PARIS  Judges of the International Criminal Court presented a new challenge to Israel on Thursday, asking the courts chief prosecutor to review her decision not to investigate a deadly Israeli commando raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla of aid ships in 2010. Israel denounced the move.

title: Review: In Pretty Is, Grown Friends Recall Being Kidnapped
description: People looking for tips on how to mount a successful kidnapping-and-torture operation could easily find help from the large body of literature on the subject. In Thomas Harriss Silence of the Lambs, for example, the villain stashes his victims in a fetid pit before killing them and using their skin for his freaky sewing project. The protagonist of John Fowless creepfest The Collector imprisons a woman in a custom-built underground bunker and waits for her to fall in love with him. (She doesnt.)

title: Former U.S. Diplomats Praise Iran Deal
description: More than 100 former American ambassadors wrote to President Obama on Thursday praising the nuclear deal reached with Iran this week as a landmark agreement that could be effective in halting Tehrans development of a nuclear weapon, and urging Congress to support it.

title: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: What I Read and What I Didnt, Summer 2015 (Part 1)
description: Am I the only person who puts things on her Kindle app and then completely forgets about them? I kept thinking, as I wrote last months edition of this column, I really thought I bought some other books. But I turned over all the piles of books and found no new books, so I just thought I must be wrong  until I opened the Kindle app on my iPad: and there were Dietland, The Knockoff and Picnic in Provence. Ive even been known to start a book on Kindle and then forget about it (or roam the house saying things like: I know I started a book. Where is it?).

title: Mothers Helping Mothers to Live With H.I.V.
description: When Teresa Njeri got pregnant in 2001 in Kiambu, a suburb of Nairobi, it was the end of the world. She was joyous about the pregnancy  but an AIDS test showed she was H.I.V.-positive. A clinician told her: Make sure your husband comes in for testing  and dont sleep with him.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Theater Listings for July 17-23
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Greek Debt Crisis Highlights Fractures in European Union
description: LONDON  For the European Union, the thrill is gone.

title: Robert Rymans Work Will Travel to Dia
description: One of the most important spaces for the permanent exhibition of artists from the Minimalist generation  the Hallen fr Neue Kunst (or Halls for New Art), in Schaffhausen, Switzerland  was forced to close last year, the victim of a protracted lawsuit that depleted its modest resources. But at least for a while, Europes loss will be New Yorks gain. The Dia Art Foundation, whose focus on the artists of the 1960s and 70s made it a kind of American sister to the Schaffhausen institution, announced that it would mount the first American survey in more than 20 years of the work of Robert Ryman, whose austere white-on-white paintings are among the most important of the postwar period and who long had a sizable body of work on display in Schaffhausen.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for July 17-23
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Umbrella House
description: The East Village co-op has come a long way since the 1980s, when squatters occupied what was then an abandoned city-owned tenement.

title: Trying to Win the Publics Trust With Autonomous Cars, at 120 M.P.H.
description: SONOMA, Calif.  Markus Hoffmann, an engineer at Audi, prepared himself for a high-speed run around the Sonoma Raceway here in Northern California.

title: Hermitage Museum to Open a Contemporary Outpost in Moscow
description: Add the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, to a growing list of museums, including the Guggenheim and the Louvre, that are launching new satellites from the mother ship. Late last month, during 250th-anniversary celebrations of the Hermitages founding by Catherine the Great, the New York architects Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture of Asymptote Architecture signed a contract to design the Hermitage Modern Contemporary, an outpost in Moscow that will draw on the Hermitages rich 20th-century art collections and also display new work. With the Garage, by Rem Koolhaas, which opened a month ago, and other new contemporary museums popping up, Moscow is signaling an ambition to become a New York-style art powerhouse.

title: An Art Collective Takes Over Stedelijks Instagram Feed
description: On Wednesday at 4 a.m. Eastern Daylight Time (10 a.m. in Amsterdam), a small band of invaders took control of the Instagram channel of the Stedelijk Museum, posting a 15-second video for the institutions 12,500 followers. It wasnt a hacking incident, but rather a planned 24-hour social media takeover by Tromarama, a three-member art collective from Indonesia with a concurrent exhibition inside the brick-and-mortar walls of the Stedelijk, the Netherlands leading museum for Modern and contemporary art and design.

title: Jazz Listings for July 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Unemployment Rates in New York City and State Fall to Seven-Year Lows
description: The unemployment rates in New York City and New York State fell to their lowest levels in nearly seven years as the long, steady improvement of New Yorks economy continued in June, according to State Labor Department figures released on Thursday.

title: Review: Richard Duponts Sobriquets, the Human Form From Scan to 3-D
description: Richard Dupont probably wont make it into the pantheon of figurative sculpture, alongside Praxiteles, the Italians (Donatello, Michelangelo and Bernini) or Rodin. But every era needs its representations of the human figure, and Mr. Duponts sculptures aptly demonstrate how scanning, surveillance and imaging technology shape our conceptions of humanity today.

title: Classical Music Listings for July 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Woody Allens Irrational Man Explores Lifes Randomness
description: In Woody Allens 1987 drama September, a writer and a physicist walk into a room (well, really, theyre playing pool) when the writer asks the physicist, Is there anything more terrifying than the destruction of the world? The physicist, sunk deep in gloomy shadow, answers, Yeah, the knowledge that it doesnt matter one way or the other  that its all random, radiating aimlessly out of nothing and eventually vanishing forever. The physicist says that hes not talking about the world. Im talking about the universe, adding, all space, all time, just a temporary convulsion.

title: Comedy Listings for July 17-23
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: All Watched Over Contemplates Arts Relationship to Technology
description: One of the weirder cultural products to emerge from the age of early cybernetics was a 1967 poem by Richard Brautigan titled All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace. It imagined mammals and computers living together in mutually programming harmony, freed from labor and joined back to nature.

title: Movie Listings for July 17-23
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, July 19 to 25, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Dance Listings for July 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Emmy Awards 2015: Game of Thrones and HBO Lead Nominations
description: The fantasy epic Game of Thrones and its home network, HBO, led the field in the nominations for the 67th Primetime Emmy Awards announced Thursday.

title: Dustin Johnson, Weeks After Major Collapse, Leads British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  After smacking his drive on the 13th hole Thursday, Dustin Johnson headed off the tee box and veered right. A smattering of fans was on that side. So, too, was a screened-off portable toilet.

title: The National Journal to End Print Edition
description: The National Journal, the political magazine owned by Atlantic Media, will cease publishing a print edition at the end of the year, the company said Thursday.

title: Cuomo Task Force to Investigate Worker Exploitation in Many Industries
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday announced the creation of a new statewide, multiagency task force dedicated to investigating worker exploitation and abuse across a variety of industries, including restaurants, child care services and carwashes.

title: Suspect Arrested in Attack on Off-Duty New York Police Officer
description: A 21-year-old man suspected of attacking an off-duty New York police officer and stealing her gun has been arrested in Philadelphia, the authorities said.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 17-23
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Convictions Prove Elusive in London Whale Trading Case
description: The case of the London Whale has ended  with a whimper.

title: Restaurant Review: La Chinita Poblana in Irvington
description: The first hint that La Chinita Poblana is not the kitschy kind of Mexican restaurant that used to dominate in Westchester  when you could find Mexican food at all  is the dcor. A deep red ceiling, tasteful lighting and prints of Mexican revolutionaries and Diego Rivera paintings point to a more authentic and flavorful experience than was possible just a few years ago.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Indonesia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Review: Stanley Whitneys Paintings Reinvent the Grid
description: Abstract painting moves in mysterious ways. Sometimes it leaps ahead and challenges us to keep up, as with Malevichs black square of 1915, Jackson Pollocks dripped skeins from the late 1940s, or Frank Stellas shaped canvases and metallic stripes of the early 60s. And sometimes abstract painting seems to stall, its devotees settling for cautiously repeating accepted conventions  monochrome, grids, stripes and so forth.

title: Review: The Stanford Prison Experiment Revisits the Psychology of Power and Abuse
description: Fine ensemble acting brings a notorious psychological study to life in The Stanford Prison Experiment. The research, now 44 years old, may today seem as if it merely confirmed the obvious, but the film, by Kyle Patrick Alvarez, certainly makes you feel the claustrophobic intensity of what went on.

title: Wan Li, Who Helped Chinas Farmers Emerge From Mao Era, Dies at 98
description: HONG KONG  Wan Li, the Communist Party leader who helped end the failed Mao-era policy of collective farming, which had left rural Chinese in desperate poverty, died on Wednesday in Beijing. He was 98.

title: Restaurant Review: Scarpetta Beach in Montauk Offers Meals to Match the View
description: Long Island, surprisingly, has very few waterfront restaurants. Scarcer still are oceanfront spots as opposed to those on canals, bays or the sound. Gurneys Montauk Resort & Seawater Spa has one of the islands most spectacular ocean vistas, but its restaurants, until now, have never offered food that could compete with the views.

title: Complications Cloud Possibility of a Movie Based on Watchman
description: LOS ANGELES  Typically, the outsize attention given a novel like Go Set a Watchman would set off an immediate scramble in Hollywood for the film rights.

title: July 16, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Indonesia, China, Bangladesh and the United States.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Spare Times for Children for July 17-23
description: Rubin Museum of Art Block Party

title: Review: Morgans at Interlaken Inn Embraces the Changing of Seasons
description: Many restaurants brag of a farm to table ethic. Morgans at the Interlaken Inn in Lakeville backs that up by listing on the front of its one-page menu more than a score of area producers on whom it relies for provisions.

title: A Lucha Libre Party Ends Early for the Mens Fashion Crowd
description: At a party celebrating New York Fashion Week: Mens on Wednesday evening, fashion  more specifically, clothing  was forgotten as men stripped off their shirts in the heat of Church Street Boxing Gym, an old-school spot on Park Place where fight posters function as wallpaper and air-conditioners are considered a luxury for the weak of spirit.

title: Spare Times for July 17-23
description: Museums and Sites

title: G.O.P. Is Quiet About Fed Rate Increases, but Democrats Voice Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  As the Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates later this year, Republican critics have dialed down the volume of their complaints, while Democrats are now fretting loudly about the path of monetary policy.

title: Raymond Pettibon, Richard Prince and More Rally in Support of 826NYC
description: The artist Marcel Dzama is a longtime collaborator: He started the Royal Art Lodge collective in college, art-directed a short film with the band Arcade Fire and has since worked with everyone from his mother to Kim Gordon. Now, he will continue the streak: He has curated an online art auction, which goes live on Paddle8 tomorrow, marrying his impressive roster of friends with community action. In support of the nonprofit 826NYC, which offers free creative-writing programs to children, the auction features works from such art-world luminaries as Chris Ofili, Suzan Frecon and Raymond Pettibon. Theres also a piece by the art handler Justin Davis Anderson, who once helped install one of Dzamas shows at David Zwirner Gallery, where an exhibition of the works in the auction will open next week.

title: One Year Later, Remembering Eric Garner
description: Eric Garners death a year ago set off protests against the New York Police Department. A young South African photographer documented Mr. Garners family and their Staten Island community.

title: President Obama Takes On the Prison Crisis
description: On Thursday, for the first time in American history, a president walked into a federal prison. President Obama was there to see for himself a small piece of the damage that the nations decades-long binge of mass incarceration has wrought.

title: Review: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Kicks Off a Summer Series
description: During the summer, chamber music lovers are lured to rustic barns, parks and even a wilderness grotto to hear concerts, while performers enjoy a change of scenery at festivals nationwide. And in New York, listeners have plenty of fun outdoor orchestral events to attend, although musical nuances are often drowned out by noisy picnickers and tinny amplification systems, with humidity and thunderstorms a constant threat.

title: Review: The Look of Silence Confronts Individuals and Ideology of Indonesian Massacre
description: The Look of Silence, a documentary directed by the American filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer and an anonymous Indonesian collaborator, is a painful, profoundly empathetic work of moral reckoning. Like its companion film, The Act of Killing, released in 2013, it examines the mass killings that began in Indonesia in 1965, when at least a million people were slaughtered in the aftermath of a military coup.

title: Movie Review: The Look of Silence
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Look of Silence.

title: Movie Review: Trainwreck
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Trainwreck.

title: One Year Later, Remembering Eric Garner
description: Eric Garners death a year ago set off protests against the New York Police Department. A young South African photographer documented Mr. Garners family and their Staten Island community.

title: Tracker Linked to Hillary Clinton PAC Is Spotted at a Martin OMalley Event
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons supporters have their eye on Martin OMalley.

title: Movie Review: Ant-Man
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Ant-Man.

title: Street Style at New York Fashion Week: Mens
description: The runways outside the runways at the mens spring 2016 shows.

title: Hickey Freeman: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: This Weeks Movies | July 17, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Ant-Man, The Look of Silence and Trainwreck.

title: Beyond Skydiving
description: High-level thrill-seeking.

title: U.S. Proposes New Rules to Protect Streams From Coal Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department on Thursday proposed a new rule aimed at protecting streams from the high level of pollution caused by a technique known as mountaintop removal mining.

title: Robert Geller: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Treasury to Examine Online Lending Industry
description: The Treasury Department has begun a study of online marketplace lenders, as the federal government looks to determine whether regulations are keeping up with the rapidly growing industry.

title: The Best-Seller List 55 Years Ago
description: 55 YEARS AGO

title: Review: Alleluia Follows Partners in Crime, but Not Necessarily in Love
description: The expression amour fou barely begins to describe the unhinged passions that boil in Alleluia, the Belgian director Fabrice Du Welzs reimagining of the 1970 crime classic The Honeymoon Killers. That docudrama was inspired by the murderous real-life exploits of Raymond Fernandez and Martha Beck, lovers who achieved tabloid notoriety as the Lonely Hearts Killers in the late 1940s.

title: Ettore Stratta, Music Producer and Conductor, Dies at 82
description: Ettore Stratta, who produced records by stars like Barbra Streisand and Tony Bennett and conducted symphonic arrangements of everything from bossa nova to the music of Andrew Lloyd Webber, died on July 9 in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Craft Atlantic: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Review: In Lila and Eve, a Grieving Mother Turns Gun-Toting Vigilante
description: The main, and perhaps the only, reason to see the revenge thriller Lila and Eve, a shallow, cut-rate Thelma and Louise, is for the thunderous lead performance of Viola Davis. Her character, Lila, is an aggrieved mother of two sons in an Atlanta suburb who is responding to the drive-by shooting death of the older, the 18-year-old Stephon (Aml Ameen), who was college bound. Whether on the large or small screen, Ms. Davis projects an ominous gravity. Even when smiling, she always means business.

title: Review: In Northern Limit Line, the Koreas Do Battle
description: South Koreans voted with their feet to give Northern Limit Line the box-office edge over Terminator Genisys and Inside Out, but I wouldnt get too excited. This jingoistic war-at-sea movie, redeemed by neither narrative momentum nor fully formed characters, will test the patience of the most ardent military fanatic.

title: Gary Mack, Kennedy Assassination Expert, Dies at 68
description: Gary Mack, a Dallas broadcaster whose fascination with the Kennedy assassination led him to become a widely consulted expert on the event and, eventually, the curator of the Sixth Floor Museum, which is devoted to the assassination, died on Wednesday in Arlington, Tex. He was 68.

title: Polo Ralph Lauren: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Review: In Twinsters, Separated-at-Birth Twins Tell Their Own Story
description: The real-life story told in Twinsters  separated-at-birth twins find each other and reunite  is less unusual than it once was, thanks to the Internet. But the way this particular tale is told has some DIY charm.

title: American Ambassadors' Letter
description: More than 100 former American ambassadors wrote to President Obama, calling the deal a landmark agreement and urging Congress to support it.

title: Brazil Adds to Tally of Corruption Scandals With Investigation of a Former President
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Federal prosecutors in Brazil said Thursday that they were opening a full investigation into claims of influence peddling by Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the former president whose leftist Workers Party is already struggling with a sweeping graft scandal involving some of the countrys most powerful political figures.

title: 2 Convicted in 2013 Fatal Shooting of Brooklyn Boy in a Stroller
description: A man accused of opening fire on a rival in Brooklyn in 2013 and killing the rivals 16-month-old son in his stroller was convicted of second-degree murder on Thursday, according to the Brooklyn district attorneys office.

title: Review: Steak (R)evolution Travels the World to Find the Best Beef
description: In his documentary Steak (R)evolution, Franck Ribire goes in search of the worlds best steak. But this informative foodie film is more than just footage of assorted chefs cooking delicious-looking cuts of meat. The tour encompasses breeders, butchers, grazing practices and genetics. Mr. Ribire uses a Top 10 countdown structure familiar from other searching-for-the-best documentaries, but the rankings are beside the point. This film is all about the meat and the animals it comes from.

title: Review: Ardor Depicts an Argentine Land Grab and a Quest for Vengeance
description: The Argentine director Pablo Fendrik presents Ardor as a machete western  that is, a western transplanted to the thick rain forests of South America  but its plot draws just as much from Tarzan as from Sergio Leone, with a dusting of magical realism.

title: The Vivid Hues of William Diamonds Rooms
description: Mr. Diamond, with his design partner Anthony Baratta, created spaces that married antiques and contemporary pieces; their creations were often featured in home design magazines.

title: William Diamond, Designer of Wildly Colored Interiors, Dies at 63
description: William Diamond, a New York designer known for wildly colored, theatrical interiors that upended scale and proportion to near-hallucinogenic degrees, died on July 9 in Chicago. He was 63.

title: Review: Famous Nathan Tells How Nathan Handwerker Built a Hot Dog Empire
description: Back when Coney Island was Americas playground, Nathan Handwerker was royalty. An immigrant from Poland of little education and lesser means, Handwerker built a hot-dog stand into an eatery that became an institution, then a sensation. No one who was anyone didnt stop by and have a frank at Nathans Famous.

title: Over Objections of Legislature, Alaskas Governor Says He Will Expand Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON  After failing to persuade his Legislature to expand Medicaid, Gov. Bill Walker of Alaska said Thursday that he planned to unilaterally accept the federal funds available to cover more low-income residents under the program.

title: Review: In A Hard Day, Looney Tunes Meets Cops, Corpses and Crime
description: Not long after the panicky protagonist of A Hard Day avoids hitting a dog with his car on a dark highway  only to run over some guy, stuff the guys corpse into the trunk and be comically waylaid at a sobriety checkpoint by some Keystone clowns  you may wonder how long the writer-director, Kim Seong-hun, can keep this Rube Goldberg machine going. By the time the dupe-hero is sliding that cadaver through an air duct at the funeral parlor where his dead mother is laid out, its clear that Mr. Kim is just going to keep the gears greased and happily purring.

title: Iranian Hard-Liners Say Nuclear Accord Crosses Their Red Lines
description: TEHRAN  When Irans supreme leader sent a note to the countrys president, thanking him for bringing the nuclear negotiations with the United States and other world powers to a conclusion, he added an important caveat. The comprehensive plan needs close scrutiny, the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, wrote, adding: Be concerned about possible violations of the commitments in the accord by other parties.

title: Sea Warming Leads to Ban on Fishing in the Arctic
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and four other nations that border the Arctic Ocean pledged on Thursday to prohibit commercial fishing in the international waters of the Arctic until more scientific research could be done on how warming seas and melting ice are affecting fish stocks.

title: Review: For Ian McKellens Mr. Holmes, Retirement Is Afoot
description: Mr. Holmes, a mild and minor bit of revisionist Sherlockiana, imagines the worlds greatest detective in his dotage, retired to a picturesque rural spot on the English coast where he tends to bees and fading memories. Its 1947, and Holmes is in his 90s. Dr. Watson is long gone, and it turns out that the pipe and the deerstalker cap were fictitious embellishments. The keen ratiocinative powers that made Holmes an early hero of modern popular culture are still in evidence, though the cases he has left to solve are of a decidedly intimate, melancholy nature. No spectacular murders or intricate conspiracies: just quiet enigmas of memory and remorse.

title: Putin Rejects U.N. Tribunal for Downed Malaysian Jet
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pushed back forcefully on Thursday against calls for an international tribunal to investigate the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over eastern Ukraine last year, even as other world leaders were demanding accountability for the deaths of the 298 people aboard the plane.

title: Obscured Truths About Yankees and Mets
description: The Yankees have just one more victory than the Mets this season. But the teams are actually not that close as the 2015 campaign resumes Friday after the All-Star break.

title: Snapback Is an Easy Way to Reimpose Iran Penalties
description: UNITED NATIONS  The world powers have promised to keep an eye on Irans nuclear ambitions and renew United Nations sanctions, if deemed necessary, for an additional five years after the initial 10-year agreement comes to a close.

title: The Guardians Divestment Campaign
description: A discussion by journalists on the rights and wrongs of journalism as advocacy at Our Common Future Under Climate Change, a conference in Paris on global warming science and policy.

title: Grimms Lawyers Focus on a Troubled Upbringing in Hopes of Lenient Sentencing
description: When he was running for Congress, Michael G. Grimm often spoke of his working-class youth. He frequently talked about his father, Gerard, a union roofer in Queens, who could hardly read and write. On the day he was sworn in as a representative, he wore his fathers ring. And even as he pleaded guilty in December to tax fraud, Mr. Grimm seemed to be thinking of his father: Michael G  for Gerard  Grimm, he told a federal judge when she asked his name.

title: Frozen Chicken Recalled After Reports of Illnesses
description: Aspen Foods is recalling nearly two million pounds of frozen chicken products after three people in Minnesota became ill with infections from salmonella.

title: Planned Parenthood Leader Apologizes for Video
description: WASHINGTON  The president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Cecile Richards, apologized Thursday for what she called the lack of compassion shown by a staff member who was secretly recorded describing how affiliates provide tissue from aborted fetuses to researchers.

title: Bill Would Save Horse Racing From No. 1 Threat: Itself
description: WASHINGTON  When American Pharoah, the colt with a thunderous gallop, became the first Triple Crown winner in nearly four decades, he couldnt have had better timing.

title: City Comptrollers Office Dispenses Few Answers but Writes Real Checks
description: A few days ago, a New York City official named Scott M. Stringer announced that he had agreed to pay the estate of Eric Garner $5.9 million for violations of his civil rights during an arrest one year ago on Staten Island.

title: $1 Million Price Tag Hinted at in El Chapos Escape
description: MEXICO CITY  Just about the only hard facts to emerge in the wake of the escape of Mexicos most notorious drug baron are that he is gone, and that he used a sophisticated, solidly constructed tunnel to fashion his departure from the tight confines of the nations most secure prison cell.

title: Obama Reacts to Tennessee Shooting
description: The president offered condolences to the families of the victims, and said the governments response would be thorough and prompt.

title: Friends and Family Ask if Policing Has Changed Since Eric Garners Death
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who once reacted to the Eric Garner case by discussing the challenges of raising children of color, said this week that it was time to leave the past behind.

title: ChattanoogaGunman Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez: Life Is Short and Bitter
description: HIXSON, Tenn.  He played whiffle ball in a suburban neighborhood of swim meets and gently sloping lawns. He was a young man who was polite, who sometimes drove too fast, who was arrested on a drunken-driving charge. He was a hardened mixed-martial arts fighter who kept a blog where he mused about submitting to Allah.

title: In Bankruptcy Filings, Maritime Company Says It Settled Labor Case
description: Signal International, a maritime construction company, filed for bankruptcy on Sunday, six months after a jury ruled that it, and other defendants, should pay $15 million in a prominent case involving the labor abuses and trafficking of foreign workers into the United States.

title: Siki Im: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Surprises Abound in the Usually Predictable Gold Cup
description: Sometimes, the early rounds of the Concacaf Gold Cup are a bit of a snooze, as the regions two powerhouse teams, the United States and Mexico, stomp their opponents on the way to the final.

title: 12 Aircraft Targeted by Laser Beams Above New Jersey
description: Eleven commercial airliners and one military aircraft were illuminated with laser lights over the course of 90 minutes as they flew over New Jersey on Wednesday night, according to the Federal Aviation Administration, which is investigating the episodes along with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Life Is Good
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  You might not be familiar with the work of the hip-hop artist NAS, and thats O.K. I think we can all generally agree that if you are 15 years young and you have it together enough to get a crossword puzzle published in The New York Times that, as Mr. NAS opines, Life Is Good.

title: Review: Amazing Grace, the Story of a Slave Traders Moral Awakening
description: The timing is fortunate for Amazing Grace, a Broadway musical about the unusual life story of the man who wrote the lyrics for that classic hymn. President Obama ended his stirring eulogy for the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney, a victim of last months gruesome killings in a South Carolina church, by singing the song, a last-minute inspiration that made for an affecting viral media moment after a year (and more) of disturbing racial violence.

title: Judge Reads Verdicts in Aurora Rampage
description: A judge read the guilty verdicts against James E. Holmes, the gunman who three years ago killed 12 and wounded 70 at a Colorado movie theater.

title: State Senator Offered Law Firm Work if It Hired His Son, Witness Testifies
description: WHITE PLAINS  State Senator Thomas W. Libouss son Matthew was unhappy in his job and needed to make more money, Anthony Mangone recalled, and the senator hoped that he could help.

title: 62 City Schools in Bottom of Rankings Will Be Put in Steward Program
description: The New York State Education Department announced on Thursday that 144 underperforming schools, nearly half of which are in New York City, will enter receivership, a new designation that puts pressure on the de Blasio administration to show improvement at the citys most troubled schools, and to do so quickly.

title: The Rising Activist Voice of Hip-Hop Mogul Russell Simmons Takes Aim at Mayor de Blasio
description: The hip-hop impresario Russell Simmons began Thursday as he begins every day: in meditation, practicing what he has preached through a book, Success Through Stillness, and even an app.

title: Records for Group Backing Mayor Show Payment to an Ex-Obama Strategist
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio started a high-profile campaign this year to tug the Democratic Party to the political left. Turns out one of President Obamas closest confidantes is helping him do it.

title: Strangers on the Street Find a Connection in the Stars
description: Felton Davis feels it deeply, this thing he calls the alienation of the people, the loss of community and conversation.

title: Cuomo and de Blasio Still Keep a Distance
description: There were no hugs, no small chitchat  not even a handshake or a stray glance.

title: Texas: U.S. Will Seek Return of Work Permits
description: Scrambling to comply with an order from an irate federal judge, the Obama administration will dispatch officials to make home visits to collect about 2,000 three-year work permit cards that were issued to undocumented immigrants after the judge halted the program granting them. In his order July 7, the judge, Andrew S. Hanen of United States District Court in Brownsville, Tex., said he was shocked and surprised at the cavalier attitude of the administration about recovering the cards, which were issued through programs President Obama created by executive action. Under the programs, two-year work permits for some young undocumented immigrants were extended to three years. The judge gave the administration until July 31 to collect the cards and reissue them for two years, or he warned he could find the secretary of Homeland Security, Jeh Johnson, in contempt of court.

title: Chattanooga Mosque Where Gunman Worshiped Mourns Marines
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  In the past two or three months, Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez, the man accused of killing four Marines here Thursday, had begun showing up fairly regularly at Friday Prayer at the Islamic Society of Greater Chattanooga, a large mosque and cultural center, said Dr. Azhar S. Sheikh, a founding member of the centers board.

title: John Varvatos: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Montauks Best Fish Taco  Now Made in Manhattan
description: A small slice of Montauk has docked at the corner of Broome and Mulberry in New York. Seamores, the airy new sustainable seafood spot from Michael Chernow (co-founder of the crowd-pleasing Meatball Shop), recalls NoLIta in the early aughts  when unpretentious design and ingredient-driven dishes attracted a hip, laid-back crowd. And the menu, an homage to the eastern ends fish shack roots, waxes nostalgic for the old Montauk.

title: The Happiness Project
description: Walt Disney didnt just build a theme park for childhood fantasy. He created a world we believe in, and a journey to the land of the better self.

title: Shootings in Tennessee
description: A gunman opened fire on a military recruiting station on Thursday, then raced to a second military site where he killed four Marines, prompting a federal domestic terrorism investigation.

title: Samsung Fight Exposes Tension in Asia Over Activist Investors
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Samsung fended off the challenge of a big activist investor on Friday as the founding family tightened its grip over the sprawling South Korean conglomerate.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE REWRITE (2015) Keith Michaels (Hugh Grant, above), a former A-list screenwriter who hasnt had a hit since winning an Oscar in 1999, takes a last-ditch job at Binghamton University in upstate New York, choosing his students  the prettiest women, naturally  by scouring their Facebook profiles instead of their writing samples. Those who pass muster include Karen (Bella Heathcote), whom he immediately beds, and Holly (Marisa Tomei), a single mother. Then he meets his nemesis (Allison Janney), a scowling Jane Austen scholar and head of the college ethics committee. The smart, needling dialogue in the opening scenes sets a high standard that the rest of the movie cant maintain, as the story settles into a formulaic tale about a scoundrels redemption, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this fourth collaboration between Mr. Grant and the director and screenwriter Marc Lawrence. That Mr. Grant can bring Keith back from the edge more or less persuasively is a testament to his ability to convey genuine humility without mawkishness, once he sees the light.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There but for the grace of God. And that, I think, is something that we all have to think about.

title: Corrections: July 17, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: One Year Later, Remembering Eric Garner
description: A year after Eric Garner was killed by a police officer who placed him in a chokehold, a cloud of anger and impatience still hangs over the streets of Tompkinsville, Staten Island.

title: Thoreaus Clutter, and Mine
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. as Egypts Enabler
description: To the Editor:

title: Deterring Prison Escapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to Ta-Nehisi Coates While White
description: Dear Ta-Nehisi Coates,

title: Bernie Sanders and Third Parties
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Stonewall Park
description: To the Editor:

title: The South China Sea, in Court
description: A courtroom in The Hague has become an important new battleground in the multinational struggle over the resource-rich South China Sea. Based on a case brought by the Philippines against China, which claims it has rights over 90 percent of that body of water, the proceedings at the Permanent Court of Arbitration are an attempt to resolve peacefully a dispute that had been playing out in increasingly dangerous confrontations on the high seas.

title: Liberals and Wages
description: Hillary Clinton gave her first big economic speech on Monday, and progressives were by and large gratified. For Mrs. Clintons core message was that the federal government can and should use its influence to push for higher wages.

title: Heritage and Healing
description: Unhappy small towns are all alike  claustrophobic, gossipy, dying. The elderly live away their days in a haze of 1950s nostalgia and Fox News-induced paranoia. The cops harass the young, while the meth lab at the edge of town produces poison for those not clever enough to leave.

title: Why Texans Fear Invasion
description: HOUSTON  A PSYCHIATRIST I knew many years ago suggested to me that a persons irrational behavior in the present was probably not so irrational (to the person) in the past. As time has gone on, this insight has proved pretty useful, helping me develop empathy not just for bad boyfriends and crazy bosses, but for understanding my home state of Texas, which, lets face it, has been known to excel at throw-up-your-hands behavior.

title: The F.D.A.s Medical Device Problem
description: THE Food and Drug Administration has been regulating the approval of medical devices since 1976, but its regulatory oversight has not kept pace with the increasing complexity of this technology. Many high-risk medical devices today are approved on the basis of just one clinical trial (as opposed to new medications, which usually require two trials). And only a small minority of clinical studies of medical devices are randomized, controlled and blinded  the gold standard for reliable evidence (and the benchmark to which studies of drugs are held).

title: Doctor Notes in Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Must Free Jason Rezaian
description: In the year leading up to this weeks nuclear deal with Iran, the cruel and unjustified imprisonment of the Washington Post journalist Jason Rezaian complicated negotiations between world powers and Tehran. It is imperative that Iran set him free immediately and unconditionally. If Iranian leaders want the deal to help the nation shed its international pariah status, they must start taking steps that generate good will. Freeing Mr. Rezaian is an important one.

title: Listen. Pluto Is Trying to Tell Us Something.
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Qigong Master Said to Be Detained in Murder Case
description: Read in Chinese |

title: The Obama Revolution
description: Making peace with Americas old adversaries.

title: 888 Holdings Agrees to Buy Online Gambling Company Bwin.Party
description: The bidding battle for Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment culminated on Friday with the online gambling company 888 Holdings agreeing to acquire its larger rival in a deal worth 893.3 million pounds, or about $1.4 billion.

title: Umbrella House: East Village Co-op Run by Former Squatters
description: Umbrella House has come a long way from the late 1980s, when a handful of squatters broke into what was then an abandoned city-owned tenement house and claimed it as their home. Today, most of the early homesteaders remain and the building has been converted into a co-op that operates like many others, though with a more utopian and collectivist ethos.

title: A Tiny Banks Surreal Trip Through a Fraud Prosecution
description: In the heart of New Yorks Chinatown, a mortgage closing at the Abacus Federal Savings Bank was just about complete. All had gone smoothly: identifications verified, documents signed, checks exchanged. Only one set of papers still required signatures.

title: Can Montanas Smith River Survive a Nearby Mine?
description: In a state lousy with world-class waters  the Yellowstone and the Gallatin, the Madison and the Ruby, the Mighty Mo and Norman Macleans Big Blackfoot River  the Smith River may be the river that Montanans love most.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: July 17
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include an evangelical event in Central Park and a wedding at Columbia University.

title: Stowaways and Crimes Aboard a Scofflaw Ship
description: CHIOS, Greece  The rickety raft made of empty oil drums and a wooden tabletop rolled and pitched with the waves while tied to the side of the Dona Liberta, a 370-foot cargo ship anchored far from land in the Atlantic Ocean off West Africa.

title: Fridays Travel News: California Beach Reopens; Greyhound Goes to Mexico
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Hipaas Use as Code of Silence Often Misinterprets the Law
description: How do people use, misuse or abuse Hipaa, the federal regulations protecting patients confidential health information? Let us count the ways:

title: European Agency Proposes Tougher Medical and Psychological Oversight of Pilots
description: PARIS  Europes top air safety regulator called on Friday for a series of measures aimed at strengthening the medical and psychological oversight of the regions commercial airline pilots, including random drug and alcohol testing of flight crews.

title: New York Today: A Family Still Shaken
description: Good morning on this brilliant Friday.

title: Japan Scraps Olympic Stadium Plan Over $2 Billion Price Tag
description: TOKYO  Three years after Japanese Olympic organizers selected a vast, sleek stadium design by a prominent Iraqi-British architect for the centerpiece venue of the 2020 Summer Games, the government announced on Friday that it would scrap the plan and start over because of spiraling costs.

title: 1915: Germany Would Pay Bribe
description: Germany is quite willing to buy Roumanias neutrality with a slice of Austrias territory. For her military participation on the Germano-Austrian side, Germany is willing to pay a still bigger slice. The difficulty is that Austria does not appreciate Germanys generosity at her expense, and Roumania does not think the generosity sufficiently generous. Even if Austria were disposed to cede any territory, the utmost extent of the cession would be a part of Bukowina.

title: Today in Politics: Organizers Build Up Events in Iowa, and the Candidates Come
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where hardly anyone seems to be in town. President Obama moves on to New York from Oklahoma and nearly every candidate seems to be heading to Iowa for a couple of large party gatherings.

title: The 7.5.15 Issue
description: RE: ARIANNA HUFFINGTON

title: The Dead
description: I love how poems can inscribe in concrete images some figurative notion of the world Ive harbored. Here, it is the notion that the dead dont completely go away, but travel among us, emerging at moments to be seen.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Summer Fridays
description: It seems far out, but the origins of summer Fridays are shrouded in mystery. No one  not even labor-studies professors  seems to agree on when or where they began. (What on earth would I know about it? one Ivy League academic, who studied the history of office culture, emailed in response to a query.) Still, each Memorial Day weekend, it begins anew, a tradition as elegant and fragile as a dragonfly. On Fridays at lunchtime, well-off people in their white shirts dart down from the buildings of Park and Madison Avenues to the tunnels of Penn and Grand Central. The brave go forth to battle the Long Island Expressway, making themselves scarce at noon. (Beat that traffic, Connor and Katelyn! See you at the Sloppy Tuna, Molly and Preston!)

title: Drink Your Vegetables
description: There used to be a health-food store right across the street from the bar where I work. You could jaywalk from one place to the other, and one day I watched a man do exactly that. He stepped inside the bar with a big plastic cup of psychedelically green vegetable juice in hand and decisively ordered a shot of well vodka  and an empty pint glass. You can guess the rest. After he slurped down his alcohol-enhanced kale-spinach-apple-beet special, or whatever it was, he paid for the shot, looked at me and said, Its all about the balance, right?

title: An Italian Job
description: Last fall, when I was out of work and starting to face serious money problems, I discovered a new vegan restaurant near Porta Venezia, where I live in Milan. I thought, Maybe theyre looking for staff, so I sent in my rsum. Id never worked in a restaurant before. It wasnt a great dream of mine. But Ive been cooking since I was 16, when I told my mother I was no longer going to eat meat, fish, eggs or cheese and I had to make meals for myself. I needed a job, any job, to avoid having to go back to Sicily, because that would have been a great defeat.

title: How to Proselytize
description: Your appearance matters, says Mario Dias, who manages the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints training center in So Paulo, Brazil, which each year prepares 3,500 young Mormons from all over the world for one-and-a-half-to-two-year missions in the country. A conservative look suits a serious message (faux-hawks and mullets are explicitly prohibited for Mormon missionaries, as are above-the-knee skirts). Do not be intimidated or judgmental, Dias says. As a door-to-door evangelist, you will see all kinds of people, from drunkards on the road to the richest men youve ever met. Approach them with respect and treat them with love.

title: How Hip-Hop Is Becoming the Oldies
description: Less than a year ago, the Indianapolis radio station WRWM, then known as Indys i94, was the 15th-most-popular station in the Central Indiana market. It played a forgettable mix of Maroon 5, Sam Smith and other staples of what in radio lingo is called hot adult contemporary  the sort of stuff that drivers might alight on for a song or two but rarely add to their presets. For the last six months of 2014, among listeners ages 6 and older, the stations Nielsen ratings hovered around a 2.0 share, meaning roughly 2 percent of radio listeners in the market tuned in.

title: For Indian Weavers in Varanasi, Help for an Endangered Craft
description: It wasnt until I went to Varanasi, India, that the blue and gold silk sari with the intricate flower design that my parents bought me when I got engaged 15 years ago meant something beyond just another gift.

title: In Oklahoma, Efforts to Save House of Last Comanche Chief
description: A torrential storm lashed tiny Cache, Okla. (population 2,906), in late May, flooding homes and forcing residents onto their roofs to await rescue. But the most devastating damage may have been to a house that has stood empty for nearly 60 years.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 6 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its sixth week. To participate, just post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 24 and answer the question What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: British Pilots Have Been Conducting Airstrikes in Syria, Defense Ministry Confirms
description: LONDON  British pilots have been conducting airstrikes in Syria as part of the American-led coalition against Islamic State militants, the Ministry of Defense confirmed on Friday, even though Parliament voted two years ago against military action there.

title: Morning Agenda: Samsung C&T Shareholders Reject Elliotts Activism
description: SAMSUNG C&T SHAREHOLDERS REJECT ELLIOTTS ACTIVISM | A rare test for shareholder activism in Asia failed on Friday with the Lee family of Samsung securing its future leadership in a face-off with a big New York hedge fund. Shareholders in a Samsung Group subsidiary voted for a merger with another Samsung company, clearing the way for a father-to-son transfer of power in Samsungs largest family-owned conglomerate, Choe Sang-Hun and Neil Gough report in DealBook. The approval delivers a crushing defeat to Elliott Associates, the activist hedge fund, which opposed the merger.

title: Germany Votes to Move Ahead With Greek Bailout, but Opposition Grows
description: BERLIN  German lawmakers on Friday approved entering into detailed negotiations for a Greek bailout amid a simmering international debate over providing more debt relief to Athens and intensifying questions about whether Greece would be better off leaving the European common currency.

title: Video Purports to Show Ukraine Rebels After Downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17
description: A year to the day after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down over Ukraine, an Australian news organization released a video purporting to show pro-Russian separatists walking amid the wreckage, expressing increasing dismay as item after item indicates that the aircraft was a passenger jet.

title: Kiev Remembers Malaysia Airlines Victims
description: Members of the Ukrainian Parliament on Friday laid flowers on the steps of the Dutch Embassy to pay respects to those who died in the disaster last year.

title: Video Reviews of Ant-Man, The Look of Silence and Trainwreck
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Ant-Man, The Look of Silence and Trainwreck. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Casey Neistats Beme Is a Social App That Aims to Replace Illusions With Reality
description: Casey Neistat is not as handsome as he appears in his Facebook profile picture. His daily life is not as beautiful as it looks on Instagram. And he is not as clever as his quips make him seem on Twitter.

title: Martin Wheatley, a Top British Financial Regulator, to Depart
description: LONDON  Britain is looking for new leadership to oversee its financial markets.

title: British Open Friday: Dustin Johnson Stays on Top
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The first group at the British Open on Friday began play at 6:32 a.m. under conditions that might best be described as cataclysmic. There was rain. There was wind. There was, occasionally, lightning out over the North Sea.

title: Fire Island Residents to Lose Their Homes to Make Way for a Dune
description: OCEAN BAY PARK, N.Y.  Eddie Micallef, a film director, has spent every summer of his life coming to the four-bedroom oceanfront house his father, an architect, designed on Fire Island. As a child, he would spend the whole summer surfing and playing softball, and he later worked as a camp counselor here. As an adult, he catches the ferry from Bay Shore, on Long Island, on Fridays and enjoys cocktails with friends on his deck in the bayberry-scented breeze.

title: Thoughts While Sitting at the Grand Central Library
description: Dear Diary:

title: Saudi-Backed Forces Said to Wrest Aden, Yemen, From Houthis
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  The exiled Yemeni government said Friday that Saudi-backed fighters had completely liberated the southern city of Aden from the Houthi rebels who had tried for months to bring it under their control.

title: General Electric Reports Rise in Industrial Profit
description: Ever since the financial crisis, General Electric has been steering back to its industrial roots and retreating from finance. The strategy always looked sound, but the question has been whether G.E. could deliver profitable growth going down that path.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: German Government Defends Greek Bailout
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel and Wolfgang Schuble, the finance minister, urged Parliament to pass a motion allowing negotiations on a third bailout for Greece.

title: Eternal Greece
description: Matt OBrien directs us to a Heritage Foundation economist presenting what is portrayed as a startling idea: America could become Greece! And its true  there probably havent been more than a few thousand articles issuing the same warning in the five (5) years since Alan Greenspan published US Debt and the Greek Analogy, with this immortal complaint:

title: Egyptian Forces Kill 6 Protesters During Clashes
description: CAIRO  Security forces killed six antigovernment demonstrators at Islamist protests near Cairo on Friday morning, highlighting continued tensions two years after the military takeover that removed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Taking Manchester to the Global Stage
description: MANCHESTER, England  In the final days of his last season as artistic director of the Manchester International Festival, Alex Poots could not refrain from being an unabashed booster for the city. Manchester is the original modern city, he said firmly at a local hotel here, with his successor, John E. McGrath, sitting a few tables away.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Enniskillen, Northern Ireland

title: How the West Overcounts Its Water Supplies
