title: 1890: The Pope Leaves The Vatican in Broad Daylight
description: The fact that the Pope has driven out of the Vatican in broad daylight and shown himself in the streets of Rome is a political event of no small importance, since it destroys the fiction that he is a prisoner. Apparently His Holiness has decided that he will no longer risk his health in order to comply with the wishes of the party which seeks to make political capital by requiring him to imprison himself. Everybody remembers Artemus Wards story of the prisoner who one day had a happy thought  that of opening the window and walking out. Now that the Pope has had the happy thought of opening the gates of the Vatican and driving through the streets, the Cardinals who have insisted that he was a prisoner will not be pleased to have their legend so completely contradicted, for nothing could show more plainly that, for the present at least, their influence is no longer dominant. The Pope may now be expected to withdraw to Castel Gundolfi for the rest of the hot season, as was in former days the invariable custom of his predecessors.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 19, 1890

That text, which might provide insight into the gunmans motivation, included a link to an Islamic verse saying, Whosoever shows enmity to a friend of Mine, then I have declared war against him.

title: The Anxious Americans
description: AMERICANS are a pretty anxious people. Nearly one in five of us  18 percent  has an anxiety disorder. We spend over $2 billion a year on anti-anxiety medications. College students are often described as more stressed than ever before. There are many explanations for these nerves: a bad job market, less cohesive communities, the constant self-comparison that is social media. In 2002 the World Mental Health Survey found that Americans were the most anxious people in the 14 countries studied, with more clinically significant levels of anxiety than people in Nigeria, Lebanon and Ukraine.

title: The Dangers of Happiness
description: Whenever we talk about happiness we also talk about something else: morality. We may not know what happiness itself signifies, but we do know how it has been evoked historically  to set out a template for a moral life. As we rush to make happiness the ultimate aim both for ourselves and society at large, we might want to recall some of the wonderfully rich and depressingly contradictory history of the concept. This might help us better understand our own time and the moral values we subscribe to today.

title: Iraq: Toll Rises in Market Bombing
description: The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for a bombing in eastern Iraq, and officials on Saturday said that the death toll had risen to 100 people, with 20 more missing. The bomb tore through a marketplace on Friday in Khan Bani Saad, above, a mostly Shiite town in Diyala Province. It also wounded at least 133 people, the police said, and destroyed several buildings. Government troops and Shiite militias months ago wrested back parts of the province from the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or ISIL. In a statement taking responsibility for the blast, ISIS, which has often singled out Shiites as targets, declared that the attack was revenge for what it called a massacre of Sunnis in the town of Hawija farther north. The statement may have been referring to an episode in March, during a battle that eventually drove ISIS from Tikrit. Residents of Hawija reported at the time that dozens of ISIS fighters had been killed by their commanders for trying to flee the battlefield. ISIS, which follows an extremist interpretation of Sunni Islam, views Shiites as apostates and has often targeted Shiite civilians. Its statement declared that it used three tons of explosives to kill and injure more than 180 apostates. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said that ISIS was targeting civilians in revenge for recent government advances.

title: China: 2 Relatives of a Tibetan Monk Who Died in Prison Have Been Arrested
description: The authorities in southwest China have reportedly detained two relatives of a prominent Tibetan monk whose unexplained death in prison set off protests that left dozens injured after it was announced on Monday. According to Students for a Free Tibet, an overseas advocacy group, the police on Friday detained the sister and niece of Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, 65, a widely revered monk and community leader who was serving a life sentence on terrorism and separatism charges. Human rights advocates contend that the allegations against him were politically motivated. He died in a prison near Chengdu, the provincial capital of Sichuan, under circumstances that the authorities have yet to explain. On Thursday, prison officials, brushing aside the pleas of family members and supporters, cremated his body rather than allow them to carry out traditional Buddhist funeral rites. Witnesses say the relatives, Dolkar Lhamo, 52, and her daughter, Nyima Lhamo, 25, were detained in Chengdu on Friday, according to Padma Dolma, campaigns director for Students for a Free Tibet. Dolkar Lhamo and another sister were among nearly 100 Tibetans who staged a sit-in outside the building in Chengdu where Tenzin Delek was thought to have been imprisoned for the 13 years before he died.

title: Protesters Confront Candidates on Race at Netroots Nation Conference
description: PHOENIX  A group of protesters repeatedly confronted Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Gov. description: Elizabeth Ann Buryk and Jonathan Raul Rego were married Saturday evening at the Sea Pines Country Club in Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. Dr. David E. Leininger, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Elizabeth OConnell and Jesse Jardim: An Infatuation, Not an Infestation
description: Elizabeth Bach OConnell, the daughter of Nancy J. Bach and Michael J. OConnell of Hammondsport, N.Y., was married Saturday to Jesse Duncan Jardim, a son of Virginia E. Jardim and Philip M. Jardim of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Lynne S. Sharp, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Garrett Memorial Chapel in Bluff Point, N.Y.; the Right Rev. Gordon T. Charlton, a retired suffragan bishop from the Episcopal Diocese of Texas and a grandfather of the groom, took part.

title: Laura Coxson,Jacob Perlin
description: Laura Ann Coxson and Jacob Philip Perlin were married Saturday evening at Pioneer Works Center for Art and Innovation in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Samuel L. Waymon, a Christian Methodist Episcopal minister, officiated.

title: Alexandra Toney,  Michael Ahern
description: Alexandra Elizabeth Toney and Michael Christopher Ahern were married Friday at the Carltun, an events space in East Meadow, N.Y. The officiant was the Rev. Enid Kessler, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary; Rabbi Stuart Paris participated.

title: Elana Resnick, William Nomikos
description: Elana Faye Resnick and William George Nomikos were married Saturday at the Bear Mountain Inn in Bear Mountain, N.Y. Rabbi Zoe B. Zak officiated.

title: Cally Bralver and Brett Sumpio
description: Caroline Peyton Bralver, a daughter of Belinda J. Bralver and Charles N. Bralver of Westport, Conn., was married Saturday to Matthew Brett Sumpio, a son of Catherine Zappolo Sumpio and Dr. Bauer E. Sumpio of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Linda Simmons performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Meeting House, where she is the minister, in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Christina Kenyon,  Wilhelm Link
description: Christina Anne Kenyon and Wilhelm Link were married Saturday by the Rev. John Graham at Grace Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Corrections: July 19, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: In Suicide Note, South Korea Hacking Expert Denies Domestic Spying
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A hacking specialist at South Koreas National Intelligence Service who was found dead left a suicide note denying that his team spied on South Korean citizens cellphone or other online communications, the police said on Sunday.

title: Hillary Clinton Draws Scrappy Determination From a Tough, Combative Father
description: As a little girl, if Hillary Rodham forgot to screw the cap back on the toothpaste, her father would toss the tube out the bathroom window. Shed scurry around in the snow-covered evergreen bushes outside their suburban Chicago home to find it and return inside to brush her teeth, reminded, once again, of one of Hugh E. Rodhams many rules.

title: After Cancers Calm, a Daughters Emotional Storm
description: Im the only mother I know who is happy to see her daughter cry. Not because she deserves to, but because after everything she has faced, her tears are our first glimpse of emotions that have been missing for a very long time.

title: British Open 2015: As Scores Drop, Paul Dunne, an Amateur, Rises to Top
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  They came to see history, the fans who poured into this seaside town this week, roaming around the course in the rain and cold and wind. They came to see history, and they just might.

title: 1915: Russians Gain Success Against Austro-German Onslaught
description: LONDON  Fighting is in progress along practically the entire Russian front, extending for a thousand miles from the Baltic to the Bukowina. Despite the activity of the enemy in Courland and on the Narew front, the Germans great effort is apparently being made between the Vistula and the Bug, immediately south of the Lublin-Kholm railway, where General von Mackensen has been rapidly accumulating reinforcements during the recent lull in the fighting and now disposes of armies amounting to almost 2,000,000 men.

title: 1940: Italy Sending Mission to Syria to Disband the French
description: ATHENS  Italy, it was learned here tonight [July 19], is making the final arrangements to dispatch a military mission to Syria to arrange there details of the demobilization of the French Army of the Near East, which is under the command of Gen. Eugene Mittelhauser. In some quarters it is thought that the disclosure that Rome is taking this step may prove the signal for some action by the British forces in the eastern Mediterranean calculated to insure that Syria shall not be left in a position to serve as a potential base for enemy operations.

title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Republicans in Arkansas Homecoming
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  A Democrat is not likely to win this state in the 2016 presidential election, not even one with the last name Clinton.

title: Greeks Worry About Bailouts Push for an Economic Overhaul
description: ATHENS  For Greece, its the economic equivalent of the Big Bang.

title: Black Police Applicant Frustrated by Opaque Hiring Process
description: The morning news flickered on the television while Corye Douglas was drinking his first cup of vanilla chai at home in Brooklyn. Then, a bulletin about the New York Police Department caught his ear.

title: Explosions in Gaza Destroy Vehicles of Hamas and Islamic Jihad Officials
description: GAZA  A series of explosions destroyed several vehicles belonging to officials of the militant Islamist groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad on Sunday, the latest in a series of attacks in Gaza attributed to extremists who have aligned themselves with the Islamic State.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) WELCOME TO SWEDEN A second season begins with a romantic flourish as Bruce (Greg Poehler) plans his proposal to Emma (Josephine Bornebusch), despite the lack of a blessing from her parents (Claes Mansson and Lena Olin), who dont believe in marriage. Emma becomes an unwitting victim of an effort to tweak her banks image, devised by its new head of marketing (Neve Campbell). Then, at 8:30, her boss (Magnus Mark) takes credit for her presentation, while Bruce gives Jason Priestley (as himself) a tour. Above, from left, Per Svensson, Mr. Priestley and Mr. Poehler.

title: Ant-Man, a Small Superhero, Does Big Business at the Box Office
description: Marvels quirky Ant-Man over the weekend provided a told-you-so moment for supporters (Marvel can do no wrong) and naysayers (the movie is about  ants), while Amy Schumer and Trainwreck demonstrated the increasing power of female ticket buyers at the box office.

title: A Fading Neighborhood and Art
description: A working cut of the opening moments of Off Track Betty, which was shot on 16-millimeter film.

title: Capturing a Neighborhoods Essence on Film, Before They Both Vanish
description: Clayton Dean Smith uses words like disappearing so much, its almost a refrain.

title: Review: U2 Kicks Off 8 Nights in New York With Depth and Spectacle
description: The theme and title of U2s current arena tour is innocence and experience. Those ideas dont stay perfectly separated in life, nor do they in the bands complicated and forceful show.

title: Who Advises Candidate Trump? (Hint: His Name Is Donald)
description: In what passes for normal inside Donald J. Trumps unorthodox campaign for president, he flew from Arkansas to Iowa on his Trump-emblazoned jet on Friday, arrived the next morning at a candidate forum without any prepared remarks and, wearing a bright red tie that evoked his days on The Apprentice, told the world exactly what he thought about Senator John McCains reputation as a war hero.

title: In China, a Supercity Rises
description: The government has embarked on an ambitious plan to make Beijing the center of a megalopolis of 130 million people.

title: China Molds a Supercity Around Beijing
description: As Chinese officials are developing a megalopolis that will contain more than 130 million people, some suburban residents cope with difficult commutes and shortages of public services.

title: As Beijing Becomes a Supercity, the Rapid Growth Brings Pains
description: YANJIAO, China  Every morning at 5:30, Liu Desheng joins a dozen retirees waiting for the express bus to central Beijing from this small city in Hebei Province. They stand at the front of the line but never board, instead waiting as bus after bus pulls up, each picking up 50 people from the ever-lengthening line behind the retirees.

title: In China, a Supercity Rises
description: The government has embarked on an ambitious plan to make Beijing the center of a northern supercity of 130 million people.

title: David Cameron Wants Britain to Do More Against ISIS
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron hopes to escalate Britains role in the campaign against the Islamic State, and at the same time stem the rise of jihadists at home, according to remarks he made on Sunday and excerpts from a planned speech.

title: Officials Say Driver Was Drunk in Long Island Limousine Crash That Killed Four
description: CUTCHOGUE, N.Y.  They gathered for an annual rite of the summer wedding season in this rural corner of eastern Long Island: the chauffeured wine tasting with close friends. Eight women, all in their mid-20s, from Suffolk County, Scarsdale and Brooklyn, together in celebration on a Saturday afternoon.

title: Review: Sharknado 3, on Syfy, Endangers the East Coast
description: When the original Sharknado ripped through the summer of 2013 on Syfy, many viewers no doubt thought that its climactic scene, the greatest in made-for-TV B-movie history, would never be topped.

title: Dozens of Civilians Killed by Rockets and Airstrikes in Yemen
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Houthi rebel fighters fired rockets toward the southern city of Aden on Sunday, killing at least 43 people in a residential neighborhood, health and military officials said.

title: Full Speed Ahead
description: Japan advances a plan to allow its troops to serve overseas for the first time since the war.

title: A Wizard at Prying Government Secrets From the Government
description: LOS ANGELES  When the reporter Jason Leopold gets ready to take on the United States government, he psychs himself up by listening to the heavy metal bands Slayer and Pantera.

title: David Duvals Declining Career Hits an Emotional Peak at the British Open
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The Old Course was wet on Sunday morning, and so were Ron Levins eyes.

title: Southern Exposure
description: Sorry about blog silence  real life has intruded. And travel over the next few days, so limited blogging.

title: Merkel Calls for Swift Start of Greek Bailout Talks
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Sunday called for the swift start of negotiations on the Greece bailout package, reiterating her insistence that there will be no reduction in Greek debt but saying that other relief measures can be discussed once Greece has been stabilized.

title: Israel Arrests 4 Palestinians in West Bank Shooting
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli authorities have uncovered a network of Hamas militants suspected of involvement in a shooting that killed an Israeli man and wounded three others in the West Bank in June, Israeli security officials said Sunday.

title: Review: Roberto Villanuevas BalaSole, a Kaleidoscope of Human Shapes
description: The dancer Roberto Villanueva is 5 feet 2 inches tall. On Friday at the Ailey Citigroup Theater he shared that detail while introducing the company he founded five years ago, BalaSole. Early in his career his height had hindered his job prospects, he said. He envisioned BalaSole as a home for dancers of all body types, backgrounds and ages.

title: Clint Dempsey Displays His Hungry Mind-Set in U.S.s Rout of Cuba
description: BALTIMORE  Lest anyone still be wondering about Clint Dempseys state of mind on the soccer field these days, his coach and his fellow members of the United States mens national team spent some of their Saturday night wielding similar gastric imagery to characterize his temperament.

title: The Euroskeptic Vindication
description: One theme Ive returned to often in this blog is that far from failing in the crisis, more or less conventional Hicks/Keynes macroeconomics  whether or not you dress it up in New Keynesian algebra  has performed very well. The quiescence of interest rates and inflation despite large budget deficits and huge increases in the monetary base, the strong negative correlation between fiscal austerity and growth, all have been just what someone who knew his or her IS-LM and took it seriously would have predicted. Anti-Keynesians keep making more or less desperate efforts to refute this proposition, usually by taking something I said out of context and pretending that something that happened for one year somewhere or other is contrary to what the Evil One claimed. But the overall shape of events has been very Keynesian, and very much at odds with alternative stories.

title: Kanye West-Steve McQueen Video to Have American Premiere in Los Angeles
description: When Kanye West and Steve McQueen, the video artist and 12 Years a Slave filmmaker, began publicly praising each others work, fans wondered whether the two would collaborate. They have, and the result, an extended or expanded sort of music video, makes its American debut on Saturday at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Called All Day/I Feel Like That, the video will run in a gallery for four days during regular museum hours.

title: Express Bus Service Shows Promise in New York
description: Last week, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled its first express bus line: the 86th Street crosstown, running back and forth between York Avenue on the east side and Broadway on the west. There was a news conference to celebrate, at Columbus Avenue. Polly Trottenberg, the mayors transportation commissioner, hailed modest investments yielding dividends in terms of saved time for long-beleaguered riders, to which Ben Kallos, a city councilman, added that time saved translates into revenue for businesses whose taxes help pay for further transit improvements: a virtuous circle.

title: Review: The Cleveland Orchestra Plays Strauss With Abundant Color
description: The concept of effortless virtuosity when applied to classical musicians can be somewhat misleading. Describing technical skills this way almost suggests that a performance, though polished and precise, might seem a little breezy or lack intensity.

title: Review: Another Hundred People Digs Into Stephen Sondheims Catalog
description: Another Hundred People, a thrilling new revue at the Laurie Beechman Theater, is the most dramatic example I can remember of how a crash course in the songs of Stephen Sondheim can transform entertainers you thought you knew into beings far more complex and sophisticated than you ever suspected. As its stars, KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnar, dug into Mr. Sondheims catalog, it was as though they had suddenly grown up.

title: Review: What Pet Should I Get?, a New Book From Dr. Seuss
description: In Seussland, we are likely to meetThe fuzzy and feathered and furry,They like to wear hats, mittens and socks,And run, fly and jump in a hurry.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 20
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. At the close of the New York cash market Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.02 percent. The six-month rate was 0.11 percent, and the four-week rate was 0.02 percent. The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

title: The Wire Cast Gathers
description: Cast members of HBOs The Wire gathered at the Modell Performing Arts Center at the Lyric in Baltimore on Saturday to reflect upon the recent unrest in the city and pay homage to its residents. The event, Wired Up!, was part of the annual Baltimore arts festival Artscape and featured the cast members Michael K. Williams, Sonja Sohn, Andre Royo and Larry Gilliard Jr. The sold-out event came about thanks to Ms. Sohn and her fellow cast member Maria Broom, who interviewed residents in West Baltimore about their experiences during the protests after the death of the young black man Freddie Gray. They turned the interviews into monologues that were read in tandem by the residents, including single mothers and self-professed gang members, and actors from the show. Dominic West and Wendell Pierce, two of the shows stars, and the director David Simon were not present, but sent video messages.

title: Review: Ruthless!, at St. Lukes, Takes Stage Ambition to the Playground
description: A spiked Shirley Temple of a show, Ruthless! opened 23 years ago with the likes of Natalie Portman and Britney Spears playing its occasionally homicidal ingnue. Those little tykes have grown up. Aside from the occasional topical joke (the Olive Garden, Donald Trump), this musical, revived by its creators, has not.

title: Early Riser
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Theres an old chestnut that American medical school students are taught when it comes to diagnosing illnesses, and I posit that it applies just as much to solving the Monday crossword puzzle. The chestnut goes something like this: When you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras.

title: Chasing Video With Drones, Hobbyists Imperil California Firefighting Efforts
description: LOS ANGELES  The video footage, captured by a tiny drone, makes for dramatic viewing: In one clip on YouTube, an airplane strafes the treetops of a California forest with red fire retardant, which falls like a curtain on the smoky wildfire hidden below; in another, the flames can be seen from above licking angrily at the tree line.

title: Mark Teixeiras Home Run Lifts Yankees Over Mariners
description: Mark Teixeira strode swiftly through the Yankees clubhouse, a white towel around his neck, his sandals squishing. He had the look of a confident man.

title: Retractable Skylight in World Trade Center Oculus Takes Final Form
description: Santiago Calatrava said the roof would open.

title: Greeces Entrepreneurs
description: Greeces economic crisis has taken its toll on businesses in the country, but some entrepreneurs are fighting to build their companies in the midst of it all.

title: Those Who Would Remake Myanmar Find That Words Fail Them
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Its the dawn of democracy in Myanmar. If only the Burmese had their own word for it.

title: Apple Waits as App Developers Study Whos Buying Its Watch
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the months surrounding the much-ballyhooed release of the Apple Watch, Apple managers courted Facebook in the hopes that the social networking giant would make a software application for the new gadget.

title: A Manhattan McDonalds With Many Off-the-Menu Sales
description: Some customers pour beer into clear McCaf plastic cups and drink it right in the open. A man called Shamrock swills straight vodka from a Dasani water bottle at a table near the entrance.

title: Six Killed in New York City Over the Weekend
description: The victims were near home or on their way back. In one case, a man was walking with his stepsister to the subway station; in another, a man was with friends outside his apartment.

title: Surfer Mick Fanning Escapes Shark Attack During Competition Broadcast
description: A surfing competition in South Africa was canceled after the surfer Mick Fanning, a three-time world champion, fought off a shark attack on live television during the programs opening minutes. He escaped the water with another competitor, Julian Wilson, shaken but physically unharmed.

title: Mourners Make First Visit to New Yorks Potters Field
description: The lonely island where New York City buries its unclaimed dead lies off the coast of the Bronx, off-limits to living mourners for so long that it has sometimes seemed like a mirage.

title: U.N. Vote on Iran Nuclear Deal Irks Congress
description: WASHINGTON  During the closed-door talks in Vienna on limiting Irans nuclear program, Secretary of State John Kerry argued that the United Nations Security Council should not vote on lifting sanctions on Iran until Congress had a chance to review the deal.

title: With Yoda as His Guide, Jordan Spieth to a New Level Takes His Game
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland

title: A Light Bulb Goes On, Over the Mall
description: Among the many promises of the Internet of Things  a network of Wi-Fi-connected devices and equipment managed with smartphones  is the automation of everyday life, whether finding a parking space or discovering a discounted blouse at the mall or lighting the streets when day shifts to dusk.

title: Baseball Renews Push for Diversity as Decades of Gains Slip Away
description: Rob Manfred was a high school student in upstate New York in 1975 when Frank Robinson became Major League Baseballs first black manager. Lloyd McClendon was a high school student in Gary, Ind.

title: Laws Hinder Prosecutors in Charging G.M. Employees in Ignition Defect
description: From the factory floor to the corporate suite, employees at General Motors saw indications of a deadly ignition defect and failed to disclose the problem to the government.

title: Senate Committees No Vote Incenses Lawmakers Seeking Auto Safety Reforms
description: WASHINGTON  The push to impose criminal penalties on auto executives who fail to disclose deadly automobile defects hit another roadblock last week when a Senate committee voted down such a proposal.

title: Bill Cosby, in Deposition, Said Assistants Could Choose Not to Sign Confidentiality Agreements
description: Bill Cosby had a chef and a housekeeper, as well as pilots and a chauffeur.

title: Alex Rocco, Who Played Moe Greene in The Godfather, Dies at 79
description: Alex Rocco, the gravelly-voiced actor whose gallery of memorable characters included Moe Greene, the cocky, bespectacled Las Vegas casino owner who made the mistake of talking back to Michael Corleone in The Godfather, died on Saturday at his home in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: A Confederate Generals Final Stand Divides Memphis
description: MEMPHIS  What people see when they look up at the towering statue of Nathan Bedford Forrest in a park near downtown Memphis usually depends on their deepest beliefs, their memories, their loyalties and maybe even their DNA.

title: Windows 10 Signifies Microsofts Shift in Strategy
description: SEATTLE  Next week, when Microsoft releases Windows 10, the latest version of the companys operating system, the software will offer a mix of the familiar and new to the people who run earlier versions of it on more than 1.5 billion computers and other devices.

title: Stephen Ross Hopes to Turn Soccer Friendlies Into a Moneymaking Juggernaut
description: Every summer, soccer fans in the United States pay steep prices to see the worlds best teams compete in preseason exhibitions against other top clubs as well as squads from Major League Soccer. It is more a taste of world soccer than a feast; some stars are allowed to skip the tours, and those who do arrive are routinely pulled by managers wary of injuries.

title: Chattanooga Wears Pride Beside Its Pain After Killings
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  The American flags are everywhere here: fluttering behind big pickup trucks and choppers growling across the freeways, at half-staff at the McDonalds across the street from the bullet-riddled military recruitment center, and planted, in a long, straight line, in the grass near the place where four Marines and a Navy seaman were fatally shot.

title: As U.S. and Cuba Relations Warm, Property Claims Issue Is Revived
description: WASHINGTON  When Amy Rosoffs parents boarded a ferry from Cuba to Key West, Fla., in April 1961, they took only the clothes they could carry and a wedding band and diamond engagement ring, smuggled in a bundle of her brothers cloth diapers that her mother had stained brown with vanilla to deter communist soldiers from searching them.

title: Claudia Alexander, NASA Manager Who Led Jupiter Mission, Dies at 56
description: Claudia Alexander, who played a pioneering role in NASAs Galileo mission to Jupiter and the international Rosetta space-exploration project, died on July 11 in Arcadia, Calif. She was 56.

title: Bicycle Makers Struggle to Swat Down Counterfeits
description: RODEZ, France  When Alberto Contador won the Tour de France in 2010 while riding a bicycle made by Specialized for the first time, Andrew Love was both elated and apprehensive.

title: For G.O.P., Pope Francis Visit to Congress Comes With Tensions
description: WASHINGTON  In the Reading, Ohio, neighborhood where Speaker John A. Boehner grew up, nearly every house had two things on the wall: a crucifix and a photo of the pope. You never ever expected to meet the pope, said Jerry Vanden Eynden, a lifelong friend of Mr. Boehners. In all of our minds, the pope was the closest thing to meeting God in person here on earth.

title: Mets Strand 25 Runners Over 18 Innings, but Bring 2 of Them Home in the Last One
description: ST. LOUIS  Daniel Murphy took a few steps off third base and lingered there, crouching, looking toward home, his hands twitching. Wilmer Flores was up, with two outs in the 10th inning, and their teammates already looked tired, leaning against the dugout railings.

title: Nuns Intensify Fight Over Sale of Convent to Katy Perry
description: LOS ANGELES  Poverty, chastity, obedience  and they are still barring the door to Katy Perry.

title: Greeces Debt Payments, Apple Earnings and Credit Suisse Results
description: After receiving a short-term loan from the European Union last week, Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros ($4.6 billion) due on bonds held by the European Central Bank, as well as 2 billion in overdue payments to the International Monetary Fund. Failure to pay the E.C.B. would have forced the bank to cut off emergency funding for Greek banks, causing them and the Greek economy to collapse. The debt payments represent a step back from the precipice of a eurozone exit for Greece, but the government led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must cope this week with the political turmoil caused by his decision to accept unpleasant conditions set by eurozone creditors in return for financial aid. In a move toward normalcy, Greek banks reopened on Monday. Jack Ewing

title: Finding a Path to Success in the Second Tier of the Tour de France
description: VALENCE, France  The air-conditioning on the bus of the Bretagne-Sch Environnement team died just as the Tour de France, which has been marked by hot weather, began. On Saturday, one of the teams riders was thrown out of the Tour for taking a brief trip in a car. The chances of one of its riders winning the Tour are effectively zero, and the odds of a stage win are slim.

title: Hideki Matsui and His Teammates Know Pinstriped Suits
description: In many ways, the championship game of the Nippon Clubs 40th annual President Cup baseball tournament was no different from a big game in any other Sunday league. Men who might wear coats and ties working as bankers, accountants and engineers during the week put on different uniforms, playing before a few dozen friends and relatives in the shadow of the concrete train trestles on Randalls Island.

title: Lockheed Is Said to Buy Maker of Black Hawk Helicopters
description: Lockheed Martin has agreed to buy Sikorsky, the maker of the Black Hawk helicopters used by the United States military, people with knowledge of the matter saidon Sunday.

title: Poldark Episode 5 Recap: Heady vs. Grim
description: Poldark, Episode 5  Heady, but Grim

title: Stalled Subway Inspires Word Game
description: Dear Diary:

title: Beating the Heat Was the Toughest Part
description: The 15th annual New York City Triathlon began with a swimming phase in the Hudson River, followed by a biking stage on the Henry Hudson Parkway and a run in Central Park.

title: They Couldve Used a Swim at the End, Too
description: Taking off from the Upper West Side of Manhattan, thousands of athletes swam down the Hudson River, cycled along the Henry Hudson Parkway and ran through Central Park as part of the New York City Triathlon on Sunday.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Everywhere You Look, Love Triangles
description: Season 3, Episode 2: Threes a Crowd

title: Russian Town Near Ukraine, Once Quiet, Now Buzzes With Military Activity
description: GOLOVINKA, Russia  The southern Russian steppe in summertime typically offers a soul-lifting panorama of wheat fields and sunflowers, swaying in the breezes, and vast empty spaces. It is Russias big sky country, rural and calm.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Isabel Marant
description: In this series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets  and how they see themselves and the world around them.

title: India Hickss Bahamian Rhapsody
description: From aristocratic roots to a peaceful beachside existence on Harbour Island, the model-turned-designers new lifestyle brand reveals no shortage of inspiration.

title: Andrew Rosenthal on the Republican Race to the Bottom
description: The Timess editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, caught a whiff of another contest brewing among Republican politicians: a contest, Mr. Rosenthal said in a recent opinion blog post, to say the most obviously ridiculous things that pop into their heads.

title: Whats on TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) PACKED IN A TRUNK: THE LOST ART OF EDITH LAKE WILKINSON (2015) As a child in California, Jane Anderson grew up surrounded by vivid portraits and streetscapes created by Ms. Wilkinson, her great-aunt and part of the early 20th-century art scene in Provincetown, Mass., which her mother had retrieved from trunks in the attic of a relatives West Virginia home. Since the 1970s Ms. Anderson (above, with a Wilkinson canvas), who co-wrote the screenplay for HBOs Olive Kitteridge, has worked to get Ms. Wilkinsons work back into the spotlight. She has also tried to uncover why Ms. Wilkinson was committed to a mental asylum in 1924 at 57 by a family lawyer, who drained her savings and objected to her lesbian relationship. Among the reasons for her institutionalization was this: Has numerous unusual ideas.

title: True Detective Recap: Pain Is Inexhaustible
description: Season 2, Episode 5: Other Lives

title: Corrections: July 20, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Summary execution, vigilantism, overzealous defense, call it what you will. This boils down just the same to a case of murder at sea and a question of why its allowed to happen.

title: Beijing Police Detain at Least 4 Over Uniqlo Sex Video
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Hannibal Recap: Face Off
description: Season 3, Episode 7: Digestivo

title: Modern Love Redux: Readers Offer Their Own Honest Thoughts on Marriage
description: Last Thursdays Modern Love column, The Wedding Toast Ill Never Give, an essay that offered a cleareyed perspective on the complexities of marriage, struck a chord with readers. More than 370 responded on nytimes.com/styles and on Facebook with their own stories about marriages, successful and not, and the advice theyve picked up along the way. Highlights below, edited for space.

title: Capturing the Stillness of Surfers in Portraits
description: Surf pictures are traditionally studies in motion  a figure in the spray of a cutback or under the curl of a jewel-toned barrel. But Joni Sternbach, who has spent the last nine years making large-format tintype photographs of surfers on beaches around the globe, is after something different: a kind of ethnographic study in stillness, silvery portraits of a tribe united by a sense of adventure, the love of a sport and a connection to the ocean.

title: Reducing Teenage Births
description: To the Editor:

title: On Writing Outside the Publishing Mainstream
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Realities in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Europes Impossible Dream
description: Theres a bit of a lull in the news from Europe, but the underlying situation is as terrible as ever. Greece is experiencing a slump worse than the Great Depression, and nothing happening now offers hope of recovery. Spain has been hailed as a success story, because its economy is finally growing  but it still has 22 percent unemployment. And there is an arc of stagnation across the continents top: Finland is experiencing a depression comparable to that in southern Europe, and Denmark and the Netherlands are also doing very badly.

title: How Not to Fix the F.D.A.
description: A bill passed by the House and ostensibly designed to streamline the Food and Drug Administration is loaded with bad provisions and may not even be necessary. The Senate should either eliminate or rewrite the flawed provisions before passing its version of the legislation.

title: Every Drug Court Should Allow Methadone Treatment
description: WHEN an old offense caught up with 28-year-old Robert Lepolszki last year, he had a full-time job and had kicked heroin. But Frank Gulotta Jr., the Nassau County judge assigned to his case, forced him to end the only treatment that had ever worked: methadone maintenance. Judge Gulotta said that methadone does not enable a defendant to actually rid him or herself of the addiction. Complete abstinence programs were the only treatments his court allowed. Not long after stopping the medication, Mr. Lepolszki was dead from an overdose.

title: A View of the Recovered City, and Yet ...
description: Closure is a clumsy description for the aftermath of 9/11. But theres a certain sense of completion at ground zero now that the new skyscraper replacing the fallen towers is open to the flow of tourists. They look out, far out, from the observatory that tops 1 World Trade Center and offers 360-degree views of a recovered city and suburbs.

title: Japan Wrestles With Its Pacifism
description: A vote in the Japanese Parliament last week brought Prime Minister Shinzo Abe a step closer to one of his most important national security goals  a law that would give the Japanese armed forces limited powers to engage in foreign combat for the first time since World War II. But the way Mr. Abe engineered the victory has caused great anxiety about whether he intends to honor Japans deep postwar commitment to pacifism.

title: Fannie and Freddie are Back, Bigger and Badder Than Ever
description: AFTER the financial crisis of 2008, there was one thing that almost everyone agreed on. The government-sponsored mortgage giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, had to go. While shareholders and executives reaped the profits from Fannie and Freddie in good times, taxpayers were stuck with the bill in a crisis. President Obama described their dysfunctional business model as Heads we win, tails you lose. But here we are, seven years after the crisis, and nothing has changed.

title: Sandra and Kindra: Suicides or Something Sinister?
description: Although the mantra Black Lives Matter was developed by black women, I often worry that in the collective consciousness it carries with it an implicit masculine association, one that renders subordinate or even invisible the very real and concurrent subjugation and suffering of black women, one that assigns to these women a role of supporter and soother and without enough space or liberty to express and advocate for their own.

title: Is the Doctor In, or Just Online?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aboard a Floating Armory
description: Private maritime security contractors describe their work and living conditions at sea.

title: Murder at Sea: Captured on Video, but Killers Go Free
description: SHARJAH KHALID PORT, United Arab Emirates  The man bobbing in the sea raises his arms in a seeming sign of surrender before he is shot in the head. He floats face down as his blood stains the blue water.

title: Standard Chartered Shakes Up Management Structure
description: LONDON  William T. Winters, the new chief executive of Standard Chartered, is moving quickly to put his stamp on the British bank.

title: Q. and A.: Andrew G. Walder on China Under Mao

title: ZeroZeroZero, by Roberto Saviano
description: Roberto Saviano has written a kind of concordance of cruelty in this cocaine-trafficking epic, minus the alphabetized structure, which would have made it easier to follow. Much of it, sadly, may be true.

title: God and Jetfire, by Amy Seek
description: In an open adoption, the child, the birth families and the prospective adoptive parents all know one another to varying degrees, creating an extended family tree. Amy Seek placed her infant with a family when she was 23, and in God and Jetfire she chronicles her experience as a birth mother from pregnancy until the child, Jonathan, is 12.

title: Supreme Courts Unsigned Rulings Show a Narrow View of Prisoners Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court decided 66 cases in the usual way this last term, after full briefing and oral arguments. It also quietly issued eight other decisions.

title: Taking Stock (for Once), Self-Styled Hoarder Makes Lucrative Deal to Close Bookstore
description: John Scioli never met a book he did not like. They loom over the doorway of the Community Bookstore in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, his home of 30 years, cataracts of white, brown and yellow pages tumbling from the 10-foot ceilings and spilling out onto the corner of Court and Warren Streets.

title: 10 Murals in Brooklyn to Spruce Up Construction Site
description: An 820-foot stretch of a Brooklyn street will soon become a canvas for 10 artists, as a way to ease the effects of a multiyear construction project.

title: High-End Hotels Help Guests Get a Good Nights Sleep
description: Jeremy Jones considers himself a seasoned hotel guest. He travels frequently for his job as a chemical engineer and toured the globe with his wife, Angie  all documented on their travel blog.

title: CF Industries in Merger Talks With Dutch Chemical Maker OCI
description: LONDON  The American fertilizer maker CF Industries said on Monday that it was in preliminary discussions with OCI of the Netherlands about a potential merger involving certain of OCIs businesses.

title: Attack by U.S. Helicopters Kills Afghan Troops, Officials Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In one of the deadliest episodes of its kind in Afghanistan in recent years, American helicopters opened fire on an outpost belonging to the Afghan Army in the eastern province of Logar on Monday, killing at least seven Afghan soldiers and wounding five, officials said.

title: FIFA Sets Vote to Replace Sepp Blatter and Begins Overhaul Campaign
description: FIFA announced Monday that it would select a replacement for its embattled president, Sepp Blatter, in a special election Feb. 26 and that it had initiated a series of changes to try to restore its image after the worst corruption scandal in its history.

title: Mondays Travel News: American Merges Systems; Fare Deals to Europe.
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: La Hora Loca Is Hopscotching Cultures
description: First came the drums, rhythmic and pulsing. Then came the rhinestone-and-sequin-clad dancers, their headdresses practically brushing the ceiling. Nearby were the stilt-walkers, legs stretched to eternity. There were feather boas and sparkly masks, glow sticks and noisemakers, whistles and confetti. It was as if Mardi Gras had come early.

title: Schneider Electric to Take Majority Stake in Aveva
description: LONDON  The British engineering company Aveva Group said on Monday that it would acquire Schneider Electrics industrial software business in a complex deal that would have the French industrial group take a majority stake in the company.

title: Rethinking Exercise as a Source of Immediate Rewards
description: I was going to skip my daily swim the other morning. I had already walked three miles with a friend and taken my dog to the park for his exercise. I was really tired, my back was sore, I had a column to write and lots to do around the house.

title: New York Today: Feeling Hot, Hot, Hot
description: Good morning on this sweltering, sweaty Monday.

title: Stephen Hawking Joins Russian Entrepreneurs Search for Alien Life
description: Extending his idea of philanthropy beyond the Earth and even the human species, Yuri Milner, the Russian Internet entrepreneur and founder of science giveaways like the annual $3 million Fundamental Physics Prizes, announced in London on Monday that he would spend at least $100 million in the next decade to search for signals from alien civilizations.

title: Russias Coming Regime Change
description: Asked about Russias intervention in Ukraine at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum last month, President Vladimir V. Putin spoke bitterly of America and Europe. They have pushed us back to the line beyond which we cant retreat, he said.

title: Today in Politics: Backlash Against Donald Trump Is Far From Unanimous
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where a new embassy is opening and where President Obama and his team continue to try to make their case on the Iran nuclear deal. On the trail, however, Donald J. Trump continues to gather the acclaim of his supporters and the condemnation of just about everyone else.

title: How Medical Is Marijuana?
description: It is becoming easier to get marijuana, legally. In the last 20 years or so, 23 states, as well as the District of Columbia, have passed laws that make it legal to use marijuana for medical treatments. So have some countries, like Austria, Canada, Finland, Germany, Israel and Spain.

title: Uber's Fight for New York City
Morning Agenda: Greek Banks Open
description: GREEK BANKS OPEN | Greek banks opened for the first time in three weeks this morning, The Financial Times reports. Restrictions on international transfers remain but the withdrawal limit of 60 euros per day has been replaced with a weekly limit of 420 euros.

title: As Banks in Greece Reopen, New Sales Taxes Add to Confusion
description: ATHENS  Greek banks opened their doors on Monday for the first time in three weeks. But with strict limits still in place on the flow of money, the battered economy was far from returning to normal.

title: Weapons on the Water, Violence at Sea
description: Brace yourself. This was the subject line of an email I received from a source at Interpol.

title: Living With Sharks: Views from a Dock and a Surfboard
description: Here are two views of living with sharks, from the vantage point of a Montauk, N.Y., marina and a South African surfing competition.

title: Turkey Says Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 30 inSuruc, Near Syria
description: ISTANBUL  A suicide bombing struck a cultural center in a Turkish town near the Syrian border on Monday, killing at least 30 and wounding more than 100 in an attack that Turkeys prime minister suggested had been plotted by the Islamic State.

title: U.S. and Cuba Reopen Long-Closed Embassies
description: HAVANA  After more than a half-century of Cold War estrangement, the United States reopened its six-story embassy in Havana on Monday, and Cuba raised a flag outside its own stately embassy in Washington.

title: Planetary Selfie? A Cosmic Question
description: If he had a lever and a place to stand, he could move the earth, Archimedes once said.

title: Lockheed Martin to Buy Sikorsky Aircraft for $9 Billion
description: Lockheed Martins $9 billion purchase of Sikorsky Aircraft, the helicopter manufacturer, is part of a larger effort at Lockheed to focus more intently on military hardware than on less profitable government services.

title: John McCain Says Donald Trumps Remarks Will Hurt Him Among Veterans
description: Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona whose war record was questioned by Donald J. Trump over the weekend, said on Monday that he does not want an apology but that the billionaire businessman should tell American veterans and their families that he is sorry.

title: Morgan Stanleys Profit Tops Estimates
description: Morgan Stanley reported second-quarter results on Monday that were stronger than expected, as trading revenue and its wealth management business drove a 13 percent gain in net revenue.

title: With Paul Dunne, Under Armour Gets a Grand Slam
description: I know, I know  the British Open is still going on, and the winner will not be declared until later on Monday, when we find out if Jordan Spieth can come from one stroke down to win his third Grand Slam major this year. But one name has already triumphed: the sportswear brand Under Armour.

title: SunEdison to Buy Vivint Solar for About $2.2 Billion
description: SunEdison, a renewable energy company, said on Monday that it and its publicly traded power plant unit, TerraForm Power, would acquire Vivint Solar for about $2.2 billion in cash and securities.

title: U.N. Moves to Lift Iran Sanctions After Nuclear Deal, Setting Up a Clash in Congress
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council on Monday unanimously approved a resolution that creates the basis for international economic sanctions against Iran to be lifted, a move that incited a furious reaction in Israel and potentially sets up an angry showdown in Congress.

title: Undebasing the Dollar
description: Remember when the likes of Paul Ryan accused Ben Bernanke of printing too much money, solemnly intoning that There is nothing more insidious that a country can do to its citizens than debase its currency? A big part of the justification for this fear-mongering was that commodity prices were rising sharply from their 2009 low, which the usual suspects claimed was a harbinger of rising overall inflation.

title: 1940: Nazi Raiders Swarm on Britain
description: LONDON  Nazi raiders swept over the British coasts yesterday [July 20], attacking widely scattered objectives in the English Channel, Scotland, England and Wales. Defense forces succeeded in repelling the forays and brought down twelve German planes, the Air Ministry said. The fiercest battle ensued when German dive bombers descended on a convoy in the Channel and were driven off by planes and warships after a half- hour of fighting. Other combats took place far inland, the Nazis making persistent but reportedly unsuccessful attempts to put anti-aircraft batteries out of action with bombs and machine-gun fire.  New York Herald Tribune, July 21, 1940

title: Times Critics Guide: What to Do This Week
description: Looking to break out of a cultural rut?

title: Exor Sweetens Bid for PartnerReAgain Ahead of Merger Vote
description: LONDON  The back-and-forth battle for the Bermuda reinsurance company PartnerRe continued to rage on Monday.

title: Irish Playwright Brian Friel to Be Celebrated in Annual Festival
description: LONDON  The Irish playwright Brian Friel will be celebrated in a new annual festival that will be held in County Donegal, in Ireland, and in Belfast, in Northern Ireland, the organizers announced on Monday. The Lughnasa International Friel Festival, which will be held from Aug. 20 to 31 this year, will be the first festival to take place on both sides of the border.

title: Art Matters
description: Beginning this week, the Dean and DeLuca co-founder Jack Ceglic exhibits a series of portraits in Amagansett.

title: Greek Banks Reopen With Limited Cash
description: Greeks saw their banks reopen on Monday, though restrictions were still in place on transactions including cash withdrawals.

title: Daily Report: Windows 10 Signifies Microsofts Shift in Strategy
description: Next week, when Microsoft releases Windows 10, the latest version of the companys operating system, the software will offer a mix of the familiar and new to the people who run earlier versions of it on more than 1.5 billion computers and other devices, Nick Wingfield writes.

title: Surfer Recounts Shark Attack
description: A broadcast of a surfing competition captured a sharks attack on the Australian surfer Mick Fanning in South Africa.

title: 1965: Cuban Exiles Had Other Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Richard M. Bissell Jr., theman who ran the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion for the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that the armed Cuban exile brigade might have tried to seize territory inCentral America if it had not been sent to invade Cuba. The suggestion that the CIAmight have lost control of the Cuban exiles if President Kennedy had canceled the invasion, and that the intelligenceagency warned of this possibility, had notbeen made public before. Mr. Bissellspoke out in a lengthy copyrighted interview in the Washington Evening Star. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 21, 1965

title: Paralyzed by Gunfire, but Denied Care
description: Theres no video of the altercation between Monroe Bird III, a 21-year-old sitting in a car with a friend, and Ricky Leroy Stone, 56, a security guard who found them one night in the parking lot of an apartment complex in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Go Set a Watchman Sells More Than 1 Million Copies
description: Harper Lees Go Set a Watchman sold more than 1.1 million copies in North America in its first week on sale, and now has more than 3.3 million copies in print, the publisher, HarperCollins, said Monday.

title: Migrants Journeys Stall in Italy, Near the French Border
description: VENTIMIGLIA, Italy  The train that rumbles along the steep French-Italian coast, shuttling tourists from one picturesque town to another, did not take Abdulhakim Kabeto very far. After it crossed over from Italy, police officers in France stopped him at the first station in the country and returned him to the border.

title: Edible Schoolyards Kate Brashares Relives Her English Childhood Through a Grill
description: For nearly three hours a day, Kate Brashares lives in transit. Thats the length of the commute between her home in Montclair, N.J., and Dumbo, Brooklyn, where she runs the nonprofit organization Edible Schoolyard NYC, an offshoot of an Alice Waters initiative to bring gardens and cooking classes to public schools.

title: Aftermath of Suicide Bombings in Turkey
description: Graphic video shows the aftermath of what officials say were suicide bombings in the Turkish town of Suruc, near the Syrian border, on Monday, which killed at least 28 people.

title: Travel to Cuba: The Latest on Flights, Hotels and Credit Cards
description: Now that the United States has reopened its embassy in Havana, heres what you need to know about traveling to Cuba. Much has changed already since the publication of new regulations for travel to Cuba on Jan. 16, which losened some restrictions on travel for Americans, though some travelers still cannot just hop on a plane and go.

title: Toshiba Inflated Earnings by $1.2 Billion, a Panel of Experts Says
description: As top executives pushed subordinates to meet unachievable financial targets, Toshiba, the Japanese industrial giant, overstated its earnings by more than $1.2 billion over the last seven years, in what is emerging as one of the countrys largest corporate accounting scandals.

title: Long Before His Candidacy, John Kasich Made It to the White House
description: Like the 15 other Republicans running for president, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio  who is expected to announce his candidacy on Tuesday  knows it takes guts, and even a little chutzpah, to make it to the White House. Its a lesson he learned 45 years ago when, as an 18-year-old freshman at Ohio State University, he begged President Richard M. Nixon to let him visit.

title: Numberplay Classic': Zoltar the Fortune-Weighing Robot
description: This week, we offer a classic Numberplay puzzle from our archives. Gary Antonick will return with a new puzzle on July 27.

title: Confederate Flag Down, butBlack South Carolinians See Bigger Fights

Keith McDaniel Sr. sat at his desk last Tuesday morning, he had already moved on to the more substantive challenges facing African-Americans here.

title: New, Healthy and Portable Snack Options for Travelers
description: Air and road travel arent usually conducive to food thats healthy, appetizing and easy to tote; several new portable options can be of some help.

description: The Family Leadership Summit in Ames, Iowa, over the weekend was dominated by discussion of Donald J. Trump, but for attendees of the annual gathering of conservative Christians, the 2016 race for president is about an existential problem facing America.

description: LONDON  In its continuing regulatory standoff with European policy makers, Uber, the ride-booking company, is not backing down.

description: When Gawker posted an article on Thursday night about a married male media executives futile attempt to hire a gay escort, it was hoping to create a scandal.

description: Rachel Dolezal, the former Spokane, Wash., N.A.A.C.P. chief, was ensnared in a national debate about identity and race last month when her parents told reporters that although she claimed to be black she was born Caucasian.

title: Royal Familys Nazi Salute in 1930s Stirs Debate in Britain
description: LONDON  The grainy black-and-white home movie lasts about 17 seconds. It shows a young Princess Elizabeth, the future Queen Elizabeth II, raising her hand in the air in the style of a Nazi salute, an apparent youthful pantomime. The queen mother and Elizabeths uncle, Prince Edward, who would become King Edward VIII, also make the gesture.

title: Donald Trump Continues to Have Strong Support in Iowa
description: Donald J. Trump has caused a big stir by criticizing Senator John McCains war record, but so far his polling strength appears to be intact.

title: Your New Favorite Bar? Inside Your Old Favorite Bar
description: Not long ago, I paid my first visit to the Jack Rose Dining Saloon, a Washington, D.C., establishment where whiskey bottles line the room like wallpaper. I had a couple of rare drams, a nice chat with the bartender, and left satisfied.

title: Judge Postpones Action on Nuns Request in Property Dispute With Katy Perry
description: LOS ANGELES  At a hastily convened hearing here on Monday, Judge James C. Chalfant of the Los Angeles County Superior Court declined to take immediate action on a request by two nuns for a temporary restraining order that would block the archbishop of Los Angeles from controlling their property.

title: Federal Reserve Approves Capital Restraints for Big Banks
description: Nearly eight years after panic on Wall Street tipped the country into a severe recession, federal regulators are still trying to minimize the risks to the overall economy posed by large banks.

title: Alex Guarnaschellis Variation on Summer Corn
description: Ready for a variation on fresh summer corn? Consider Alex Guarnaschellis take on Mexican street food. Its lip-smacking good with drinks in the secluded backyard garden at the Cassa Hotel, home of her restaurant, Butter. And its easily done at home. She swaps out the usual salty cotija cheese for less-forceful ricotta salata. To make it, shuck and briefly boil 6 ears corn, and melt 6 tablespoons unsalted butter. Season 2 tablespoons mayonnaise with 1 teaspoon ancho chile powder (or to taste),  teaspoon Spanish sweet paprika and a spritz of lemon; mix with 4 tablespoons sour cream. Spread  pound crumbled ricotta salata on a plate. Daub the corn with butter and grill until lightly charred. Break each cob in thirds. Brush with the sour cream mixture and roll in cheese. Dust with salt, pepper and chives and serve: Butter, Cassa Hotel, 70 West 45th Street, 212-253-2828, butterrestaurant.com.

title: Driver Charged in Fatal Limousine Crash on Long Island Left Scene, Prosecutor Says
description: The man charged with drunken driving in a weekend crash on Long Island that killed four women traveling in a limousine left the scene, the Suffolk County district attorney said on Monday.

title: Greek Banks Start Long and Uncertain Journey to Recovery
description: FRANKFURT  Reopening the doors of Greek banks on Monday was just the beginning.

title: Transformation
description: Taye Diggs steps out of the straight-laced role hes known for and into drag.

title: Playing Mozarts Piano Pieces as Mozart Did
description: Classical piano pieces by such composers as Beethoven, Mozart and Chopin likely sounded much different when the masters first performed those works than they do today. Pianos themselves have changed considerably  but so, too, has technique.

title: U.S. Defense Secretary Visits Israel to Soothe Ally After Iran Nuclear Deal
description: HUSSEIN LOOKOUT, Israel  The Obama administration opened its Middle East reassurance tour on Monday with the secretary of defense, Ashton B. Carter, promising Israeli officials that the United States would remain vigilant in trying to combat what he called Irans malign influence in the region despite the nuclear deal struck last week between Tehran and six world powers.

title: Embassies Open as Cuba and United States Forge Ties
description: A United States embassy reopened in Havana and a Cuban embassy opened in Washington as the nations formally resumed diplomatic relations on Monday.

title: Viewfinder: As Four
description: Schohaja, a photographer and T contributor, shares her personal snapshots of the once design collective, taken in 2002 and 2003.

title: Zach Johnsons Grand Win Slams Door on Jordan Spieths Bid for History
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  Just before 8 p.m. Monday, Jordan Spieth wove his way through the crowd around the 18th green at the Old Course. The scrum was heavy, and Spieth bumped into a photographers elbow before skipping around a golf official wearing a suit. Finally, he looked up and smiled.

title: Former Chadian President on Trial
description: The former president of Chad, Hissne Habr, was removed from the courtroom, dressed in white, at his trial for crimes against humanity on Monday.

title: New Tomb for Father of Alexander the Great
description: Philip II of Macedonia, the father of Alexander the Great, may be buried in a different tomb than was previously thought.

title: Where to Shop on Londons Redchurch Street
description: With its colorful graffiti art and three- and four-story brick-front buildings, this Shoreditch street is a retail go-to for cutting-edge brands.

title: David Cameron Calls on Muslims in Britain to Help End Extremism
description: LONDON  Calling the battle with Islamist extremism the struggle of our generation, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Monday asserted that British values were to be shared by everyone living there and promised that the government would no longer turn a blind eye on the basis of cultural sensitivities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Facts & Figures: A $153,000 Snakebite
description: A man named Todd Fassler was treated for a rattlesnake bite in early July, according to KGTV San Diego reporter Dan Haggerty, and his medical bill came to more than $153,000.

title: Book Review: Taking on The Vital Question About Life
description: How did rocks, air and water coalesce into the first living creatures on the primordial Earth? Why did complex life like animals and plants arise from a single ancestor only once in the history of our planet?

title: Declaring War on Thumb-Sucking Leaves Battle Scars
description: A few months ago, I left the pediatricians office feeling as if I had failed my children  and myself. With a new baby at home, my husband, Brandon, and I had become decidedly lax about our twin toddlers coping habits. One used a pacifier. The other sucked his thumb.

title: PayPal Closes Up 5% on Nasdaq as It Splits From eBay
description: SAN FRANCISCO  PayPal has returned to the public stock markets for the first time in more than a decade in a rousing start.

title: Rush Limbaugh Rallies Listeners to Donald Trumps Defense
description: The conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh, who has a substantial following among grass-roots Republicans, came to the defense of Donald J. Trump on Monday as prominent leaders in the party stepped up their criticism of Mr. Trumps pointed comments about Senator John McCain.

title: Secure Your Future With Money You Didnt Even Know You Were Spending
description: Over the last five years, Ive spent a lot of time traveling the world to talk to people about money. At least one common theme comes up again and again: anxiety. People are worried about the future and want to know what they can do to prepare themselves for a stable financial life.

title: Obama Hosts Nigerian President
description: President Obama hosted Nigerias recently elected president, Muhammadu Buhari, at the White House on Monday, where the two discussed cooperation between the two countries.

title: Presidential Hopefuls React to Donald Trump
description: Since Donald Trump, a Republican candidate, attacked Senator John McCains war record, both Republican and Democratic candidates have voiced criticism.

title: Tyrese Tops Billboard Chart With Black Rose
description: The film Furious 7, one of the biggest box-office hits of the year, has been dominating the music charts as well for months: The soundtrack album reached No. 1 in April, and Wiz Khalifas mushy rap ballad See You Again, which plays during the closing credits, reigned as the top single for 12 weeks. Now its musical reach has been extended yet again with the new album by Tyrese, one of the films stars.

title: Utahs Grand Staircase Leads Back in Time to Dinosaur Shangri-La
description: KANAB, Utah  On a stormy day in southern Utah last summer, the paleontologist Alan Titus wandered from the roadside, hot, wet and annoyed. A team from California was supposed to assist him in a ground survey of the craggy, buggy badlands of Utahs Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument. But his colleagues had bailed because of the lousy weather.

title: Review: Walter Laqueurs Putinism Dissects a Canny Russian Leader
description: For Christmas in 2013, President Vladimir V. Putin sent three books to every regional governor and other senior officials in Russia. One of them was Our Tasks, by Ivan Ilyin, an early-20th-century Russian philosopher who disdained Western-style democracy and argued for an authoritarian, though not totalitarian, state. In Mr. Ilyins view, the government would not control all aspects of society, but in certain important areas would be dictatorial in the scope of its powers.

title: Ex-Leader of Chad Goes on Trial for Crimes Against Humanity
description: PARIS  Twenty-five years after he was overthrown, Hissne Habr, a former president of Chad, went on trial Monday to face charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes and torture in a special court in Senegal backed by the African Union.

title: Nigerias New President, Hoping to Host Obama, Visits White House Instead
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama kicked off a week of renewed focus on Africa on Monday by welcoming the new president of Nigeria in an Oval Office visit full of praise for his democratic election and his avowed commitment to fighting corruption and the extremist group Boko Haram.

title: N.Y.U. Acquires Editorial Archives of The Nation
description: The Nation, which celebrates its 150th birthday this year, has donated its editorial archives to Tamiment Library at New York University, one of the countrys leading repositories of material dedicated to labor and the left.

title: Review: Run Mary Run Features Rashida Bumbray at SummerStage
description: It was near sundown when Rashida Bumbray and Dance Diaspora Collective performed in Queensbridge Park in Long Island City on Saturday, but they made it feel like Sunday morning. The performers dressed in white, as if for a baptism, and as Ms. Bumbray sang African-American spirituals in call and response with the dozen or so members of the collective, they worked up a glorious noise.

title: New York Prisoners Keys to Escape: Lapsed Rules, Tools and Luck
description: Night after night for months, David Sweat slipped through a hole he had sawed at the back of his cell in the Clinton Correctional Facility in northern New York. He would plumb the catacomb-like tunnels beneath the prison, where he was serving a life sentence for murder, searching for an escape route, confident that the guards would have no idea he was gone because they were asleep. Then he would return to his empty bunk.

title: A Big Broadway Start for Hamilton
description: It wasnt just a visit from President Obama that made Hamilton big news on Broadway last week. Over seven performances in its first week on Broadway, the highly anticipated hip-hop-infused musical about the founding fathers took in a whopping $1,288,436, or 110 percent of its potential gross, at the Richard Rodgers Theater. The show outpaced several other musicals that have been perched comfortably in the list of top-grossing shows on Broadway recently, including Finding Neverland, The King and I and Something Rotten!

title: Obama Picks Michigan Professor for Fed Board
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Monday that he would nominate Kathryn M. Dominguez, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan, to a seat on the Federal Reserves Board of Governors.

title: In Chattanooga, a Young Man in a Downward Spiral
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  The last time family members here saw Mohammod Abdulazeez was last Tuesday, but they did not worry about his absence because they thought he was heading back to the Nashville suburb where he had found steady work. He had even talked about a coming business trip. They dared to hope that he was putting his troubles behind him.

title: Review: At Summergarden, a Steamy Evening of Exploratory Sounds
description: The weather in New York on Sunday evening felt like the summers steamiest and stickiest so far. So, arriving at the Museum of Modern Art for the third program of Summergarden, I assumed that the audience would not be large.

title: Burundi Nears Presidential Election
description: The lead up to the election in Burundi has been marked by scores of deaths, street protests, the silencing of independent media and a failed coup attempt.

title: In Burundi, President Pierre Nkurunzizas Push for Power Is Marked by Bloodshed
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  The rebel fighter lay grievously wounded in the mud along a river in central Burundi.

title: Review: Marc-Andr Hamelin Connects Past and Present in Kaye Playhouse Recital
description: The revelation of the pianist Marc-Andr Hamelins perfectly conceived recital on Sunday evening at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College didnt come in one of the Liszt or Chopin pieces. It was the contemporary work sandwiched between them: Yehudi Wyners Toward the Center, a solo written in 1988 to commemorate the retirement of a longtime teacher at the Yale School of Music.

title: Teammates Crash Is Reminder to Chris Froome That No Lead Is Safe
description: GAP, France  Mondays Tour de France stage was more of an appetizer than a full-blown day in the Alps. But the races leader, Chris Froome, received an uncomfortable warning of the potential dangers that the final days of the race pose to his lead.

title: A Sale of The Financial Times Seems Increasingly Possible
description: Speculation that the British publisher Pearson might sell The Financial Times could soon be stemmed with a deal.

title: Big City Book Clubs Discussion of Open City
description: Thanks to all who participated in tonights discussion Open City. Our live conversation is closed but feel free to leave additional comments. We will soon post our next selection for the Big City Book Club and the time and date of the online chat. Stay tuned.

title: The Wind and Sun Are Bringing the Shine Back to Buffalo
description: BUFFALO  Along a bend in the Buffalo River here, an enormous steel and concrete structure is rising, soon to house one of the countrys largest solar panel factories. Just to the south, in the rotting guts of the old Bethlehem Steel plant in Lackawanna, where a dozen wind turbines already harness the energy blowing off Lake Erie, workers are preparing to install a big new solar array.

title: What My Landlord Learned About Me From Twitter
description: Last July, I sat at my desk in my Toronto apartment and made my case for an American company to hire me. I had never wanted anything as badly as I wanted that job, and when the email finally arrived, I proceeded to lie facedown on my wooden floor, my nose pressed to the cold surface, too overwhelmed to move.

title: TonyMoly Brings Korean Beauty to New York
description: How old you are is a matter of birth date, but how old you feel is a matter of context. If for some reason youre seeking a temporary conversion back to adolescence  and summer is the season to do it  a visit to TonyMoly is the fastest way to get there.

title: IBM Revenue Falls 13% Despite Big Gains in New Fields
description: IBM is advancing rapidly into new fields like data analytics, cloud computing and mobile applications. And while the technology companys second-quarter results showed encouraging progress in those businesses, it was not enough to translate into growth for the company as a whole.

title: Review: Awake and Sing!, a Depression-Era Family Drama
description: The tension around Bessie Bergers dining room table is so close to the boiling point, you can practically see the steam rising. Her son, Ralph, is venting about wasting his life as a stock clerk. His combative sister, Hennie, is mocking their placid dad. So Bessie, a steamroller of a woman and a lifelong enforcer of her own will, does what she needs to do to shut them up. She feigns weakness from emotional upset. In a minute Ill get up from the table, she says. I cant take a bite in my mouth no more.

title: In Facebook Chat, Hillary Clinton Tells of Her Love of Pantsuits, and Jabs Her Rivals
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton dished out some news on her philosophy of financial regulation, proclaimed her love of pantsuits and threw some jabs at her Republican rivals in her inaugural Facebook chat  as a presidential candidate on Monday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cuba and Elsewhere
description: Cuba and More  Pictures of the Day

title: New York Musical Theater Festival Includes Deep Love and Pope!
description: Has your deceased beloved adopted a telltale moniker along the lines of Old Bones? Are his new friends writhing, leaping creatures whose gossamer garments have a certain shroudlike quality? Has he taken to menacing you from beyond the grave?

title: Musicians Festival Style at Pitchfork
description: The musicians who performed at the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago brought their unique styles to the stage.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
description: The Gold Cup and gold-plated exhibitions fill the schedule this week.

title: Iranian General Criticizes U.N. Resolution on Nuclear Deal
description: TEHRAN  The commander of Irans Revolutionary Guards objected on Monday to the United Nations Security Council resolution that is part of the landmark nuclear agreement, asserting it crossed some red lines concerning Iranian defenses.

title: Pitchfork Music Festival Fashion
description: Bright, tropical and fun prints dominated the landscape in Union Park in Chicago during the Pitchfork Music Festival.

title: Randy Johnsons Viewfinder Points to the Hall, and Beyond
description: PHOENIX  Randy Johnson is rolling now, and when this happens, he might as well be back on a mound, dominating major league hitters. The safest response, as it always has been, is to get out of the way and appreciate his artistry.

title: At Home, One Dean and DeLuca Founder Cant Stop Drawing
description: In a lofted studio steps away from his industrial-style East Hampton home, the Dean and DeLuca co-founder Jack Ceglic is constantly drawing people. In the past two months alone, he has used the simple, bright space to complete 143 portraits of people that I meet at dinner parties or socially who I think have something very special about them, he says. They kind of glow, and Im drawn to them. And in return, they come to sit for him. Each subject wades through the tall grass that surrounds the open, single-room building, toward the faint notes of whatever Joseph Haydn symphony is emanating from his workspace at that moment, and enters through a floor-to-ceiling window that swings open like a garage door. This week, 26 of his compositions will be on view in his second solo exhibition, Aura, at ILLE Arts gallery in Amagansett.

title: Disasters, Both Natural and Weather-Related, Displaced 19 Million in 2014
description: GENEVA  Natural disasters forced more than 19 million people from their homes in 2014, mostly the result of typhoons, flooding and other weather-related events that are becoming more intense and more frequent, a leading European aid agency said Monday.

title: When Will Chuck Schumer Weigh In on Iran?
description: Journalists dont usually have to ask Senator Chuck Schumer for his opinions. The New York Democrat, who is the front-runner to become his partys leader in the Senate after Senator Harry Reid retires, has a well-deserved reputation for being all too eager to share, and often overshare, his views on issues large and small.

title: A Polyglot of Styles at the Pitchfork Music Festival
description: The festival, in its 10th year, was dominated by guitar-driven rock on Friday, a mixed bag of styles on Saturday and hip-hop and electronic music on Sunday.

title: Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago Welcomes a Polyglot of Styles
