description: CHICAGO  The closing-night headliner of the Pitchfork Music Festival, which took over Union Park here from Friday afternoon through Sunday night, was Chance the Rapper, as modern an independent music star as there is. Hes 22 and has a million Twitter followers, but has never had a radio hit (or really, any hit) and has sold exactly zero albums. All of his material has been released free (though a bootleg of his once charted). Even so, several thousand fans crowded the park during his set, exuberantly rapping along to every word.

title: Christopher Dodd and Barney Frank Are Welcomed at Watchdog Agency They Helped Create
description: The Dodd-Frank Act on financial regulation turns five on Tuesday, and it remains contentious. But if there is one place the Democratic authors of the legislation will always feel welcome, it is the offices of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the federal watchdog agency created by the law.

title: Chinas Love Affair With Irresistible Korean TV
description: BEIJING  Chinas obsession with a South Korean television show about a 400-year-old Harvard-educated alien who falls in love with an arrogant actress reached such a frenzy last year that online streaming companies here began racing to snap up licensing rights for other South Korean television programs, inflating their prices almost tenfold.

title: What J. W. Andersons Reading, Some of N.Y.s Best Little Black Books and Lin-Manuel Mirandas Twitter
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Salonen Replaces James Levine at the Verbier Festival
description: VERBIER, Switzerland  No one could have been shocked when James Levine announced on July 10 that because of an ear infection, he would have to cancel his trip here, high in the Alps east of Geneva, to open the 22nd season of the Verbier Festival last Friday. This was to have been Mr. Levines return to the festival orchestra, which he helped form in 2000 and directed until 2009, and his first performance outside New York since he resigned as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in 2011, after a long run of cancellations because of physical ailments.

title: 10 Notable Looks From Mens Fashion Week
description: Notable looks from New York Fashion Week: Mens.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: A Bike Tour Through in Madagascar
description: SpiceRoads Cycle Tours is starting a hike-and-bike trip to southern Madagascar that will take in the African island nations geography, plants, animals and culture.

title: Another Reason to Party
description: All hail the cuke.

title: Military Has Security Tightened for Recruiters After Chattanooga Shooting
description: WASHINGTON  The military has ordered recruiting centers and all its other facilities in the United States to increase their security after the shooting rampage last week in Chattanooga, Tenn., that killed four Marines and a Navy petty officer.

title: A Sweet Treat Is a Clever Trick in Gauging Monkeys Health
description: When scientists seek to predict what diseases might break out of the wild and become human pandemics, among the chief suspects are germs circulating in monkeys.

title: July 20, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Cuba, Burundi, Turkey and Egypt.

title: Lindsey Graham and Friends Join to Denounce Iran Deal
description: Surrounded by two of the three amigos  as former Gen. David H. Petraeus called them  Senator Lindsey Graham appeared with Senator John McCain and former Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in New York on Monday to denounce the deal to contain Irans nuclear program.

title: A Machine in the Co-Pilots Seat
description: MANASSAS, Va.  Joel Walker, a test pilot for Aurora Flight Sciences, a maker of autonomous aircraft, flew his small, twin-engine plane through rain squalls here recently, and before it reached 5,000 feet, he pushed a red button on his joystick that transferred control of the plane to his co-pilot.

title: Kerry on Diplomatic Relations With Cuba
description: Secretary of State John Kerry held a news conference with Cubas foreign minister, signifying the re-establishment of relations between the countries.

title: Howard Schatz: A Lifetime of Exploring Vision
description: Howard Schatz spent the first half of his career helping others improve their vision as an ophthalmologist. When he picked up photography, he felt freer to explore things he never saw before.

title: Impressionist and Modern Art Lifts Christies First Half
description: PARIS  Christies reported a surge in half-year worldwide sales of art on Monday to a record 2.9 billion pounds, or $4.5 billion, buoyed by new clients and a strong market for Impressionist and Modern Art, as well as Postwar and Contemporary Art. At the spring sale, an auction record of $179.4 million was set for Pablo Picassos Les Femmes dAlger.

title: Assessing the Legality of Sandra Blands Arrest
description: A video released by Texas officials confirms accounts of a physical confrontation between Ms. Bland and a state trooper. But her arrest and cause of death remain in dispute.

title: British Open: Jordan Spieth Tips His Cap and Will Rue His Three-Putts
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland

title: Capitalist Soul Rises asHo Chi Minh City Sheds Its Past
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  Taking a puff from a hookah and a sip from her beer, Thuy Truong, a 29-year-old tech entrepreneur in a black cocktail dress, pondered the question: What were her thoughts on the 40th anniversary of the fall of Saigon?

title: Owner Seeks to Move Tulsa Shock to Dallas-Fort Worth Area
description: The majority owner of the W.N.B.A.s Tulsa Shock announced on Monday that he intended to move the team to the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: New York Attorney General Accuses Brooklyn Childrens Charity of Fraud
description: Over the years, donors gave millions of dollars to the National Childrens Leukemia Foundation, perhaps motivated by brochures or telemarketing pitches describing the charitys bone marrow registry or its cancer research building.

title: New York Escalates Investigation Into Promontory Financial Group
description: When an executive at one of Wall Streets top consulting firms testified before Congress two years ago, he stressed the importance of independence in reviewing bank misdeeds, declaring, If we merely told our clients what they want to hear, we would lose credibility.

title: Tearful Moment With Merkel Turns Migrant Girl Into a Potent Symbol
description: ROSTOCK, Germany  She stared down Greece and embraced her role as the rules enforcer of the European Union. But one teary-eyed young asylum seeker from the Middle East turned the tables on Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany last week, raising questions about her compassion and focusing attention on Europes central humanitarian dilemma.

title: A&P Files for Bankruptcy and Aims to Sell 120 Stores
description: A&P, a former titan of the grocery industry, has filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in five years and is trying to sell more than 100 of its stores.

title: California Farm District Accused of Diverting Water
description: LOS ANGELES  California water regulators cracked down Monday on a rural irrigation district accused of illegally diverting water in the midst of the states drought emergency, proposing a record $1.5 million fine in what they said would be the first of many penalties like this.

title: Whats Next for Cuba and the U.S.?
description: As a neatly pressed Cuban flag was raised outside Cubas diplomatic mission in Washington on Monday morning, rancorous cries rang out from the crowd gathered outside the stately limestone building.

title: Menendez Says U.S. Charges Violate Independence of Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez told a federal judge on Monday that corruption charges against him should be thrown out because prosecutors trampled on the independence of Congress and unfairly treated campaign donations as crimes.

title: First Data I.P.O. Is Likely to Be One of Years Largest
description: First Data Corporation, the object of one of the last big leveraged buyouts struck before the financial crisis of 2008, is finally coming back to the stock markets.

title: Scott Walker Proposes Shutting Wisconsin Ethics Board
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said on Monday that he wanted to eliminate the states Government Accountability Board, a nonpartisan agency that oversees elections, ethics, campaign finance and lobbying.

title: Mississippi to Investigate Death of a Black Man Who Raised Confederate Flag
description: JACKSON, Miss.  The Mississippi Highway Patrol on Monday was investigating a car wreck that killed an outspoken advocate of the Confederate flag.

title: Planned Parenthood Tells Congress More Videos of Clinics Might Surface
description: WASHINGTON  Planned Parenthood on Monday told congressional investigators that abortion opponents had harassed and unlawfully infiltrated its clinics for years and most likely possessed thousands of hours of surreptitious video recordings that they could deceptively edit and spread for months to come.

title: New Statewide Guidelines Aim to Accommodate and Protect Transgender Students
description: The New York State Education Department on Monday released guidelines on how school districts should accommodate transgender students. Schools should use the pronouns students prefer, for example, and encourage administrators to be receptive of the gender identities of the young people in their charge.

title: Buddy Buie, Producer and Hit-Making Songwriter, Dies at 74
description: Buddy Buie, a songwriter and record producer who helped propel the Classics IV and the Atlanta Rhythm Section to pop prominence with melodic soft-rock hits including Spooky and So Into You, died on Saturday in Dothan, Ala., his hometown. He was 74.

title: Top Chinese Official Is Ousted From Communist Party
description: BEIJING  A top aide to Chinas former president Hu Jintao who will face prosecution on corruption charges has been expelled from the Communist Party and removed from public office, Chinese state news media reported on Monday.

title: Suspicion Falls on the Police After Dozens of Execution-Style Killings in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A spree of killings which has left at least 35 people dead in Manaus, the largest city in the Brazilian Amazon, is raising suspicions that police officers may have organized a death squad to carry out a wave of execution-style killings in retaliation for the recent fatal shooting of a police officer, security officials said.

title: Veterans Groups Take Their Shots at Donald Trump as He Backs Off a Bit on McCain
description: WASHINGTON  Of the many offenses Senator John McCain has committed in the eyes of his most ardent conservative critics  supporting an immigration overhaul, for example, or more recently calling some of them crazies  a poor record on veterans issues is not one that has ever come up.

title: A Test, and Texts, for the Mets With David Wright Out
description: WASHINGTON  In early June, Eric Campbell singled home a run to give the Mets the lead in a game they eventually lost, 7-2, to the Arizona Diamondbacks. It was the type of play easily forgotten over the course of the six-month season. But for Campbell, a nondescript reserve, the hit ended an 0-for-28 slump.

title: Uncertainty on Whether Cosby Revelations Could Hurt Him in Court
description: New revelations about the sexual behavior of Bill Cosby have been greeted as a vindication to many of the women who have accused him of drugging and sexually assaulting them.

title: City Hall, in a Counterattack, Casts Uber as a Corporate Behemoth
description: The most aggressive, ubiquitous broadsides leveled against Mayor Bill de Blasio in recent memory have come not from Republican foes or skeptics of the mayors housing plan, or even the Democratic governor with whom he is engaged in an open feud.

title: When a Brief May Find a Real Friend on the Court
description: In 2013, Time Warner, the large media company, filed a brief urging the United States Supreme Court to rule against the online company Aereo, which was redistributing broadcast channels over the Internet.

title: Iran: Reporters Espionage Trial May Be Nearing End, Editor Says
description: The secretive trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Posts Tehran correspondent, who has been imprisoned for nearly a year, may soon be over, the newspapers executive editor, Martin Baron, said Monday. In a statement, he said the correspondents Iranian lawyer, Leila Ahsan, had been told that after three hearings in Tehran over the past two months, the fourth was likely to be the last, although no date has been set. Mr. Rezaian faces up to 20 years in prison on charges that include espionage. He has asserted his innocence since his arrest last July 22, and Ms. Ahsan has said there is no evidence to support the charges. Mr. Baron, who has denounced the prosecution as ludicrous, said in the statement that it is long past time for the Iranian authorities to bring this process to an end. Mr. Rezaian is one of at least three Americans held in Iran, an issue that has become more pressing to their relatives and supporters since an international deal on the countrys disputed nuclear activities was reached last week, potentially easing the estranged relations between Washington and Tehran. Also on Monday, the Committee to Protect Journalists, a press advocacy group, published a letter  to Sadeq Larijani, the head of Irans judiciary, asking him to ensure that this case is resolved immediately.

title: Finding the Junkie McDonalds and Drug Culture in Manhattan
description: I first went to the McDonalds on Eighth Avenue in late October 2014, to meet a man known as Loosey Tone, because he sold loose Newport cigarettes for 50 cents apiece and his first name was Tony. Loosey, who couldnt read and couldnt write and had a speech impediment from birth, was helping me with an article about his landlord, Yury Baumblit, who was trying to evict him.

title: Harlem Archive Collects Past Stories of Those Who Wrestled With Their Sexuality
description: By the time Nora-Ann Thompson fell in love with a woman, she was 45 years old and had three failed marriages behind her. The daughter of a black pastor in the Bronx, she had grown up in a family and a church that did not talk openly about sexuality, let alone homosexuality.

title: Rush Experienced During a Movie
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Remember yesterday, when I said that the Monday puzzle was the easy one because the clues are really straightforward and you dont have to deal with any brain-twisting bits of wordplay?

title: Robert Spillane, Who Retooled Bostons Schools, Dies at 80
description: Robert R. Spillane, who helped revive Bostons troubled schools as superintendent in the 1980s and went on to become one of the nations leading education innovators as head of a large suburban district outside Washington, died on Saturday in Boston. He was 80.

title: Larry Clarks Archival Kids Photos
description: Archival images from the filming of the movie Kids in 1995.

title: Archdiocese Disputes Ban on It Selling Headstones
description: The Archdiocese of Newark filed a lawsuit on Monday challenging the constitutionality of a recently passed New Jersey law that makes it illegal for the archdiocese to sell headstones and mausoleums at its cemeteries.

title: Failure of One Metal Strut Seemed to Doom SpaceX Falcon 9 Rocket
description: The snapping of a single strip of metal holding a part in place appears to have doomed an unmanned cargo rocket headed to the International Space Station last month, a preliminary investigation has found.

title: New Details Released in Sandra Blands Death in Texas Jail
description: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.  The authorities on Monday offered new details of the final hours of the life of a Chicago-area woman who was found hanged in a jail cell in Texas three days after she was arrested during a traffic stop.

title: Matt Harvey Excels at the Plate, but Thats About It, as the Mets Fall in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Three months ago, Matt Harvey strutted around the Nationals mound here during one of the most important starts of his young career, his first since having Tommy John surgery. He fired fastballs at will, snapped his slider like a whip, struck out Bryce Harper three times and announced to the baseball world that he was back.

title: Following the Sun
description: Beachgoers relaxed on the boardwalk on Monday in Coney Island, Brooklyn, where the temperature reached 94 degrees. It is expected to hit 90 degrees in New York City on Tuesday.

title: A Face-Wash Miracle: Micellar Water
description: In France, women historically trust their local pharmacies to have just the right products for their skin  not to mention a staff knowledgeable enough to help choose those products. But every couple of years, a French drugstore staple finds its way into the American market  uprooting beauty regimens and making a name for itself as a miracle product, every French womans secret, and so on and so forth. The latest, micellar water, lives up to its claim: An all-in-one cleanser, it removes makeup, purifies the skin and tones to boot. You dont even have to wash it off. Simply sweep the face with a soaked cotton ball, and voil. Here, a roundup of the best this side of the Seine.

title: Five Up-and-Coming Norwegian Design Talents to Know Now
description: The Swedes may hog the spotlight when it comes to Scandinavian design in the U.S.; or what most people think of as Scandinavian design, anyway. But the most exciting Nordic products on American shelves right now cant be found at Ikea  theyre arriving here by way of newer, hipper manufacturers like Menu, Muuto and Hay, and theyre increasingly sourced from young designers based in Norway. Take early advantage of the countrys booming design scene with work from these five Oslo-based talents whose work is available stateside.

title: Shooting Suspect Who Escaped From Police Custody in Harlem Is Captured
description: An attempted-murder suspect who escaped from the police in handcuffs last month in Harlem was captured on Monday, the police said.

title: Tall Task in the Bronx
description: A crew of three at Yankee Stadium is responsible for keeping the rooftop banners of the 30 major league teams in their proper order based on the standings.

title: Quaaludes, Referenced in Cosby Deposition, Have Checkered History
description: Bill Cosby stands accused of committing date rape long before drugs like GHB or Rohypnol were widely used for that purpose. Many of Mr. Cosbys accusers believed they had been drugged  but with what? And how?

title: As Burundians Vote in Presidential Election, Many Are Afraid to Pick a Side
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  After months of unrest and a night of explosions and gunfire, Burundians went to the polls on Tuesday in a presidential election whose results are not in doubt but whose consequences could prove deeply destabilizing.

title: Corrections: July 21, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It is sort of like a wedding. Youve spent all this time planning your wedding day, and finally youre getting to see someone walk down the aisle. Now, you have the rest of your life together.

title: For Social Returns, K.K.R. Gives Philippine Vaccination Company a Lift
description: HONG KONG  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm, announced on Tuesday that it had helped a vaccine company in the Philippines get a credit line of $1 million.

title: Howard Schatz: A Lifetime of Exploring Vision
description: Howard Schatz has devoted his life to exploring aspects of vision, first as an ophthalmologist and then beginning in his late 40s as a professional photographer. Soon after picking up photography as a midlife hobby, his doctors eye, focused on precision, transformed into an artists eye, challenging his viewers to interpret what they were actually seeing.

title: Help for Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: David Brookss Letter to Ta-Nehisi Coates About Race
description: To the Editor:

title: The Self-Taught Tradition Among British Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: The Only Realistic Way to Fix Campaign Finance
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  FOR the first time in modern history, the leading issue concerning voters in the upcoming presidential election, according to a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, is that wealthy individuals and corporations will have too much influence over who wins. Five years after the Supreme Court gave corporations and unions the right to spend unlimited amounts in political campaigns, voters have had enough.

title: New Yorks Big Money Loophole
description: Nearly two decades ago, New Yorks Board of Elections quietly created a gigantic loophole in the states campaign finance laws when it decided that limited liability companies were no different from people when it came to donations to candidates. Under state law, corporations are limited to political donations of $5,000 a year. But limited liability companies are allowed to donate $60,800 a year to any statewide candidate, just like individuals.

title: A Senate Bill That Makes Roads and Railroads Less Safe
description: Last month the House passed an appropriations bill that would put bigger trucks with overworked drivers behind the wheel on the nations highways. If that werent irresponsible enough, the Senate is now considering legislation that would allow trucking companies to hire 18-year-old drivers for interstate routes and undermine safety on roads and railroads in numerous other ways.

title: Donald Trump and the Politics of Insult
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Polygamy Next?
description: CHICAGO  NOW that the dust is settling from the Supreme Courts decision in Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognized a right to same-sex marriage, there are new questions. In particular, could the decision presage a constitutional right to plural marriage? If there is no magic power in opposite sexes when it comes to marriage, is there any magic power in the number two?

title: Dustin Yellins Modern Community-Building
description: When Dustin Yellin was 17 he dropped out of high school. The school was filled with jocks and cheerleaders and he clearly didnt fit in. Plus he wasnt intellectually engaged.

title: Block by Block | Yorkville
description: The Upper East Side neighborhood boasts river views and great schools  and will soon get the subway line its been waiting for.

title: Block by Block: Yorkville (Video Series)
description: Yorkville, on Manhattans Upper East Side, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, Block by Block. Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

title: How Music Got Free, by Stephen Witt
description: In 2007, with the record business well into a seemingly bottomless free fall, Doug Morris, the chairman and chief executive of the Universal Music Group, was interviewed by Wired magazine. He insisted it was a misconception that the labels were caught unaware by the digital revolution that had led to compact disc sales plummeting by 50 percent in seven years.

title: The Hirschfeld Century: Portrait of an Artist and His Age
description: When I finished reading The Hirschfeld Century: Portrait of an Artist and His Age, I cried.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (BET) THE PLAYERS AWARDS Jay Pharoah of Saturday Night Live hosts this inaugural ceremony, a collaboration between BET Networks and the National Basketball Players Association, celebrating the best in the N.B.A., as voted on by active players. Categories include most valuable player, best rookie, best defender, clutch performer, global impact player, hardest to guard, best home-court advantage, coach you would want to play for and player you secretly wish were on your team. The nominees include Stephen Curry, Anthony Davis, James Harden, LeBron James and Russell Westbrook. Lil Wayne, DJ Khaled, 2 Chainz, Monica, Kid Ink, Jason Derulo and Fifth Harmony perform.

title: What John Kasich Would Need to Do to Win
description: Mr. Kasichs expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act and his aversion to the culture wars present considerable obstacles in winning over more ideological voters.

title: John Kasich on the Issues
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has announced his candidacy on Tuesday for the Republican presidential nomination. Known as a fiscal conservative during his nine terms in Congress, Mr. Kasich has recently taken more centrist positions, defending spending on social programs and noting his willingness to work with Democrats on immigration. Here are his positions on some important issues.

title: As Shootings Rise in New York, Police Focus on a Small Number of Young Men
description: Trouble began early in the life of Alexander Williams, the son of a city correction officer from Brownsville, Brooklyn. His first arrest came at age 11. When he was 14, a close cousin was stabbed to death with a barbecue fork outside the Williams family home.

title: ISIS Transforming Into Functioning State That Uses Terror as Tool
description: ISTANBUL  The Islamic State uses terror to force obedience and frighten enemies. It has seized territory, destroyed antiquities, slaughtered minorities, forced women into sexual slavery and turned children into killers.

title: John Kasich Enters 2016 Race, Hoping Centrist Appeal Sets Him Apart
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Gov. John R. Kasich, a voluble and blunt-talking maverick who is hoping his upbeat vision for a united America can catapult him to the White House, declared Tuesday that he is running for president, telling a crowd here that he has the experience and the testing  the testing which shapes you and prepares you for the most important job in the world.

title: An Up-and-Down Season at Yankee Stadium, at Least for the Flag Crew
description: Early in the afternoon on many spring, summer and fall days, two men  sometimes three  hike to the top row of the upper deck at Yankee Stadium, where the oxygen begins to thin. They climb a 20-foot ladder and squeeze through a portal in the roof that is no bigger than Brett Gardners strike zone.

title: Scandal Upends Toshibas Lauded Reputation
description: TOKYO  Few companies in Japan have conveyed respectability like Toshiba, the sprawling industrial conglomerate that, to the surprise of many here, has found itself at the center of one of the countrys largest accounting scandals.

title: Tuesdays Travel News: Airbnb Offer in Cuba; Faster Wi-Fi in the Air
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: The Pros and (Considerable) Cons of Budget Bus Travel
description: Tickets for the discount bus company Megabus start at $1, plus some pesky fees. Its routes connect dozens of United States cities from Maine to California (along with more in Canada). Many routes run overnight, meaning you can save on lodging, if youre up for brushing your teeth at highway rest stops.

title: Kids, Then and Now
description: For cultural alarmists of the 1990s Clinton era, the film Kids represented a culmination of fears.

title: Intersection | Lima, Peru
description: Katy Esquivel, whose videos have more than a million subscribers, likes to film among the vivid colonial buildings in a bohemian neighborhood in Lima.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get the briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Fashion Blogger With a Colorful Peruvian Backdrop
description: The Barranco neighborhood in Lima, Peru, where colorful colonial buildings are coated with even more vibrant bougainvillea flowers, offers a bohemian escape from the citys noisy traffic-stalled streets. A lot of artists, writers, singers or any kind of people who like to perform or do creative things live here because the place gets you really inspired, said Katy Esquivel, whose What the Chic video blog has more than a million subscribers. She was recently in the area wearing a matching floral print top and shorts with an orange clutch and a watch that is a family heirloom. Me as a blogger, it is one of my favorite places to film because it complements my outfits, Ms. Esquivel said. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Warburg Pincus to Take Stake in Indian Developer
description: The private equity firm Warburg Pincus is set to make another big move into India by taking a stake in a real estate developer backed by one of the countrys major conglomerates.

title: The Cutting Edge in Provence
description: ARLES, France  The Rencontres dArles festival, convened annually in this Provenal city with its Roman monuments, has been a prominent showcase for international photography since its inception in 1970. With a mix of new work and established favorites, it has become a site for exhibiting and scouting talent, and has included as guest curators top photographers like Raymond Depardon and Nan Goldin.

title: New York Today: Just Add Twinkies
description: Good morning on this brain-melting Tuesday  Day 3 of the heat wave. They say its the last.

title: Irans Next Need: Internal Healing
description: LONDON  Now that we Iranians have begun breaking out of our three-decade antagonism with the West, it is time to initiate a long overdue reconciliation at home. For 35 years now, Iranian people have been categorized as insiders and outsiders by the state. To understand the structure of this division, the key lies in the narrative of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Iran Lawmakers to Wait 80 Days Before Voting on Nuclear Deal
description: TEHRAN  The Iranian Parliament will wait at least 80 days before voting on a nuclear agreement reached last week with world powers, as legislators decided on Tuesday to form a committee to study the accord, state radio reported.

title: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Weighs Using Donald Trump Against His Party
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio is expected to join the ever-growing field for the Republican nomination, a field that, despite its numbers, has been increasingly overshadowed by Donald J. Trump. Such a development, however, suits at least one other candidate just fine.

title: When the Internets Moderators Are Anything But
description: Let us begin with a toast to the unsung hero of the social-media age: the moderator. Slayer of Internet trolls! Extinguisher of flame wars! Bulwark against race hatred and child pornography! The Internet as we know it could not exist without moderators, constantly pruning back the wild undergrowth of human nature that proliferates there. Nearly every major commercial site with user content is policed by human moderators. Some are unpaid volunteers who agree to enforce administrators rules; others are outsourced workers in the Philippines who flag dirty pictures posted to social media, or domestic employees who delete libelous comments. If you want to see what the Internet looks like without moderators  well, Im not even going to tell you where to go, because wed all be raided by the F.B.I. Lets just say its immoderate.

title: Sports Owners Dip Into the Publics Purse, Despite Their Billions in the Bank
description: CLEVELAND  The billionaire owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, Dan Gilbert, is a lucky man. When LeBron James, his transcendent native son, left for Miami, the owner threw an impressive tantrum, going on about cowardly betrayal.

title: Money-Saving Travel Tips for Madrid and Spain
description: Virginia Irurita wants travelers to go to Spain and enjoy a long lunch; make that many long lunches. As the founder of Made for Spain, a custom trip planner in Madrid, she creates itineraries that show travelers the best of her country; savoring a lengthy midday meal as the locals do is one of her top recommendations.

title: Review: Barbarian Days, by William Finnegan, Details a Surfers Pilgrimage
description: Theres an informing moment in Barbarian Days, William Finnegans memoir about his lifelong surfing obsession, when he and a friend are bumming around Australia in the late 1970s, looking for perfect waves. In a junk shop the author discovers a few hundred back issues of The New Yorker, and buys them for a penny apiece. Its a score.

title: How Taye Diggs Is Transforming the Role of Hedwig
description: A sinewy black man with a shaved head, wearing shiny gold ankle boots, sashays runway-style across the pine floorboards of the New 42nd Street Studios, microphone in hand. In addition to the boots, he wears black drop-crotch sweatpants and a gray tank top that soon becomes drenched in sweat. His nails sparkle with dark green glittery polish. Hes still a little wobbly on the platform heels and exaggerates the swing of his hips, but when the choreography calls for a high kick, his leg stretches up almost impossibly above his shoulders. He drops to the floor and rolls his body from head to toe with an impressively liquid suppleness. When he turns, his smile is bashful, modest.

title: Our Secret Auschwitz
description: When I started therapy, I found it hard to speak. Sessions filled up with silences, pregnant pauses, missing words. I couldnt express myself for fear that any divulgence would hurt someone I loved.

title: From a Million Miles Away, a New NASA Blue Marble View of Earth
description: A few days ago, I had the pleasure of taping a segment of this falls season of Star Talk with the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson (and the science-loving comedian Maeve Higgins) beneath the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History. Nothing animated him more in those two hours than discussing the power of images of Earth from space  particularly the iconic earthrise photograph of Dec. 24, 1968. So it wasnt a surprise when, after a hectic Monday, I found the message below in my email in-box  sent from the White House, but penned by Tyson. Its his reflection on the newest Blue Marble photograph of our home planet.

title: De Blasio, at Vatican, Hails Popes Urgency on Climate Change
description: VATICAN CITY  There would be no special welcome from the papal lectern. And when the time came for Pope Francis to greet some of the leaders he had beckoned to this holy city, Mayor Bill de Blasio was not among the select few granted a clasped hand.

title: Morning Agenda: Courting Conflict of Interest
description: COURTING CONFLICT OF INTEREST | Supreme Court justices are allowed to own stock in companies that file briefs in the cases that come before them. But this potential conflict has drawn criticism. Andrew Ross Sorkins DealBook column examines how the system works and why it worries some onlookers.

title: Are There Too Many G.O.P. Candidates?
HP to Power Texas Data Centers With Wind Energy
description: For years, clean energy developers could look to only a small handful of corporations as project partners or customers for their power. Mostly, there was Google, and a few other high-tech companies that worked directly with wind and solar developers to help green their energy use.

title: Dementia Develops Faster in Women Than in Men, Study Suggests
description: Women who develop slight but detectable deficits in memory and mental acuity late in life tend to decline faster than men with mild impairment, researchers reported on Tuesday.

title: Dance This Week: The Blues Project, Lil Buck and Dancenoise
description: You run the risk of being rained on, and the positioning of seats lower than the stage means that you might not see the dancers feet, but if youre a dance lover in New York in late July and early August, you cant bypass Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Even if the festival werent just about the only game in town this time of year, those less-than-ideal viewing conditions would be offset by the price: Its all free. And this years initial dance offerings include some thrilling stuff.

title: Are There Literary Uses for Boredom?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Rivka Galchen and Adam Kirsch discuss whether boring books might serve an interesting purpose.

title: Tangled Passages
description: The period can be a readers best friend. We should use it more often.

title: Stalins Gift to Warsaw, 60 Years On
description: The Palace of Culture and Science, the imposing Soviet-style building dominating Warsaws skyline, is 60 years old this year.

title: Drug Maker Depomed Skeptical of Horzon Pharmas Latest Bid
description: LONDON  The Irish drug maker Horizon Pharma said on Tuesday that it had sweetened its unsolicited offer to acquire Depomed in an all-share deal as it continues to put pressure on the board of its smaller American rival to engage in takeover talks.

title: The Wonder of a Book
description: Dear Diary:

title: Get Ready: Italy Has a Special Fashion Plan for the United States
description: Italy has designs  literally  on America. In what is the clearest statement yet that European fashion now sees the United States as potentially the most lucrative market of the future, the Italian deputy minister for economic development, Carlo Calenda, was at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan on Monday to unveil what he called a special fashion plan  and the 20 million euros, or about $21.7 million, Italy is investing in the initiative.

title: Barclays Names New Mergers Head for Europe, Middle East and Africa
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays on Tuesday named Pier Luigi Colizzi, its banking head in Italy, as the new head of mergers and acquisitions for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: Another Super PAC Raises Funds for Scott Walker
description: A super PAC backing Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has raised about $20 million from some 300 donors, the group announced on Tuesday.

title: Theres a Youth Movement in Golf, and Jordan Spieth Is Leading It
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The bespectacled, white-haired journalist from The Surrey Advertiser, on hand to chronicle his 37th consecutive British Open, cocked his head and asked Jordan Spieth a question that cut through the crosswinds during the tournament as deftly as did one of Spieths crisp iron shots on the Old Course:

title: Jeff Koonss Suggestions for What to See, Read and Do This Summer
description: With exhibitions around the globe, the contemporary artist Jeff Koons has had a travel-filled summer but it hasnt been all work and no play. At the seasons start, he flew off to Bilbao, Spain for the opening of his major retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum there (the same one that originally debuted at the Whitney in New York before then being installed at Pariss Centre Pompidou). After that, he headed straight to his family farm in York, Pennsylvania, as he does this time of year with his wife Justine and the six of his eight children that still live at home. At the property once owned by his grandfather, and which Koons refers to simply as the country, the man known for balloon sculptures and playful, larger-than-life structures carpeted in live, flowering plants (and a handful of risqu oil paintings) passes the warm summer months playing baseball with his offspring, practicing batting and catching skills at night and occasionally watching the Phillies, Nationals and Yankees play.

title: PartnerRe Willing to Negotiate With Exor After Latest Offer
description: LONDON  The Bermuda reinsurer PartnerRe said on Tuesday that it was willing to negotiate with the Italian investment company Exor following its latest sweetened proposal.

title: Daily Report: IBM Revenue Falls, Highlighting Challenges as It Shifts Course
description: IBM is advancing rapidly into new fields like data analytics, cloud computing and mobile applications. And while the technology companys second-quarter results showed encouraging progress in those businesses, it was not enough to translate into growth for the company as a whole, Steve Lohr reports.

title: The First G.O.P. Debate: Whos In, Whos Out and the Role of Chance
description: Our animated charts show how randomness will help determine who makes the cut.

title: Chinese Police Are Said to Seize Ashes of Tibetan Monk Tenzin Delek Rinpoche
description: BEIJING  The Chinese police forcibly seized the ashes of a prominent Tibetan monk whose death in prison this month set off public demonstrations and raised suspicions about his treatment while incarcerated, supporters of the monk said on Tuesday.

title: Gawker and Jezebel Shut Down Briefly Amid Dispute
description: Gawker and Jezebel, the popular online gossip and news sites, temporarily stopped publishing on Monday afternoon amid an internal debate over a controversial post and managements decision to take it down.

title: Readers Turn: Too Soon on Trump?
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Burundis President Speaks Before Vote
description: President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi spoke on Tuesday before casting his vote in the election, in which he is seeking a third term in office, saying it was a crucial day for the country.

title: Inside Jail Where Sandra Bland Died
description: Closed circuit video, released Monday by the Waller County Sheriffs Department in Texas, shows guards and a nurse rushing toward the jail cell of Sandra Bland, 28, who was found dead inside.

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 4 | The Greek Economic Crisis and Why Americans Should Care
description: In Week 4 of our Summer Reading Contest, we were impressed by the many students who contemplated headline news  whether the Pluto flyby or the removal of the Confederate battle flag from the South Carolina State House  and speculated about what it might mean for the future.

title: 1915: Terror Strikes at U.S. Ships
description: LONDON  A new manifestation of terror that the Germans are attempting to establish in the United States appears in recent attempts to destroy or injure vessels of the navy. A cablegram to the Morning Post says a mysterious fire broke out on Monday night on the superdreadnought Oklahoma, which is nearing completion at the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Company, and which is almost ready for her trial trips. Last week fires broke out on the battleships Alabama and New Jersey while in dockyards, one at New York and one at Boston. The Government Secret Service agents are investigating reports of numerous dynamite plots, attempts to blow up bridges and trains carrying munitions, and the placing of bombs on vessels.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 22, 1915

title: Verbatim: Harry Reid Scolds Republicans on Donald Trump
1965:  Greek Protesters Clash With Police
description: ATHENS  A student was killed and scores of persons were injured tonight [July 21] in bloody street fighting between police and thousands of supporters of George Papandreou, ousted as premier a week ago by King Constantine. More than 10,000 rioters clashed with the steel-helmeted, club-swinging police, as the country plunged deeper into the gravest political crisis since the 1947-49 Communist civil war.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1965

title: Before John Kasich Announces, a Campaign Already in Motion
description: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio has been toying with running for president for months. By Tuesday morning, the fake mystery surrounding his candidacy will officially be over. The student union hall at Ohio State University, Mr. Kasichs alma mater, was festooned with Kasich for America banners, volunteers milled about in bright red Kasich for Us T-shirts, and hundreds of eager supporters waited in the hot sun to get inside the hall.

title: Salvaging a Long-Lasting Wood, and New York Citys Past
description: The blue-collar shop floors fall silent, find new life as artists studios, then exchange their 19th-century guts for 21st-century wine cellars, marble bathrooms and private gyms: So goes the story in a city where time does not stand still for long, and where a neighborhoods shifting fortunes can be told through its old warehouses and factories.

title: Five Up-and-Coming Norwegian Design Talents to Know Now
description: The most exciting Nordic products available stateside arent available at Ikea.

title: Marlee Matlin Cast in Broadway Revival of Spring Awakening
description: Marlee Matlin, who won an Oscar for best actress for the 1986 film Children of a Lesser God, has been cast in Deaf Wests upcoming Broadway revival of Spring Awakening.

title: Toshiba C.E.O. Resigns Amid Scandal
description: Toshibas chief executive, Hisao Tanaka, apologized on Tuesday after an investigation found that the company inflated its profits.

title: Fox Debate of Second-Tier Candidates to Be Shortened
description: A forum that Fox News will hold for Republican presidential candidates excluded from its prime-time debate on Aug. 6 is being moved from early afternoon to 5 p.m. and will be truncated to an hour, officials with the cable network confirmed.

title: Rebuke for Crying Child in a Diner Starts a Parenting Debate
description: A Facebook exchange between the owner of a Maine diner and the mother of a screaming young girl brought the wildfire capabilities of social media to a classic  and divergent  debate over parenting in public.

title: History Hints at Strong P.G.A. for Jordan Spieth, and Oddsmakers Agree
description: The hype is not as great as it would be if a Grand Slam were on the line, but anticipation will be high next month to see whether Jordan Spieth can win major No. 3 in the P.G.A. Championship.

title: 1946: The Times Explains the Bagel
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: A Tomato Salad With a Greek Personality
description: My summer tomato salads are sweet, minty and decidedly Greek in nature. Greek because I can never resist throwing in feta, and because Im pretty wild about mint, too.

title: Miley Cyrus to Host MTV Video Music Awards
description: As the Amy Poehler joke roughly goes: if you run afoul of an awards show, they make you host next time. Two years after Miley Cyruss controversial performance of Blurred Lines on MTVs Video Music Awards, the singer will host this years ceremony in Los Angeles on Aug. 30.

title: Shoulder to Shoulder With History
description: Jackie Robinson stealing home. Ali knocking out Liston. These moments bring to mind famous sports photographs. But can you identify some other participants in each photo?

title: Another Dose of Economic Reality for Jeb Bush
description: The Editorial Board recently cautioned Jeb Bush to think twice about advice on the middle class from his presumed economic adviser, Glenn Hubbard.

title: Okiway Opens in Bushwick
description: Okiway Okonomiyaki, the Japanese pancake, meets IHOP at this new bistro owned by Vincent Minchelli of the Parisian restaurant family (notably Le Duc) and Amanda Jenkins, another lover of all things Japanese. The increasingly ubiquitous okonomiyaki, which often relies on a mixture of cabbage and pork with a drizzle of Kewpie mayonnaise, has a global outlook here in the hands of Michael Arrington, who was at Morimoto. The pancake can be had barbecue style, Mexican style and vegan, in addition to more traditional Osaka and Hiroshima varieties.

title: Revisiting Deadwood, a Lawless Prelude to TVs New Golden Age
description: After watching the pilot episode of Deadwood, I got up, lowered the blinds, dimmed the lights and burned through the rest of the DVD in a fugue of wonder and excitement. I didnt leave the series until the next day, staggering limply into the harsh sunlight like Ray Milland in The Lost Weekend.

title: Two Foster Families, Two Biological Brothers, One Play Date
description: The afternoon sun is starting to drop in the sky and childhood tempers are showing early signs of unpredictability. It is time for the play date  which is no ordinary play date, and yet perfectly ordinary  to end.

title: Pitchfork Music Festival Fashion
description: At last weekends Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago, dressing for comfort seemed to be the rule. Here are some looks that stood out from the crowd.

title: John Kasich Announces Presidential Bid
description: Gov. John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, announced at an event in Columbus, Ohio, on Tuesday that he is seeking the Republican presidential nomination for 2016.

title: Lupulo
description: Casual Portuguese from the chef George Mendes.

title: Restaurant Review: Lupulo in Chelsea
description: If George Mendes did not have such a strong grip on the flavors and aromas of Portugal, Lupulo might have slipped away from him. It can be a confusing restaurant at first, its messages mixed, its fairly simple concept fuzzed over with complications. But give the place a chance, and you can find clarity in the smells of garlic and wood smoke that fill the dining room; in the way sweet paprika and cilantro sidle up to each other in olive oil; and in the fresh, firm seafood, the grilled sardines and carabineros, red as a lobster, their heads dripping with juices that are as rich and intense as any sauce. The restaurant may be unfocused, but the cooking isnt.

title: Iran Deal Looms as U.S. Defense Secretary Meets With Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  It was never going to be an easy meeting, but a face-to-face session on Tuesday between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, the first high-level Obama emissary here since the Iran nuclear deal was struck last week, was so fraught with tension that the two balked at even making the obligatory statements at the beginning.

title: Chattanooga Gunman Researched Islamic Martyrdom, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Counterterrorism investigators have uncovered evidence the gunman who killed five service members last week in Chattanooga, Tenn., searched the Internet in the days leading up to the attack for Islamic materials about whether martyrdom would lead to forgiveness for his sins, like drunkenness and financial debt, according to law enforcement officials.

title: ESPN, Already Battling Rising Costs, Faces a Talent Drain
description: In just over two months, ESPN has lost three major personalities  a drain of renowned talent that is unusual in its suddenness.

title: De Blasio Discusses Climate at Vatican
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke on Tuesday in Vatican City at a conference on climate change and praised Pope Francis for the initiative.

title: K.K.R.s Buyout of First Data Has a Chance of Turning a Profit
description: The acquisition of First Data by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts looked to be a $29 billion mistake right after it closed in late 2007.

title: Protecting the Sanctuary
description: Armed guards keep the congregation safe at the Potters House of Denver. In the wake of the Charleston shootings, more churches should follow their example, says Rev. E. Christopher Hill.

title: Erectile Problems Tied to Diabetes
description: Anyone who watches television knows that men with erectile dysfunction can try solving the problem by taking a pill. But they also need to be screened for diabetes, a new study suggests.

title: What Oysters Reveal About Sea Change
description: Mark Bittman braves the elements off the coast of California and learns how researchers are helping local and regional seafood producers monitor the effects of ocean acidification.

title: What Oysters Reveal About Sea Change
description: This is the third in a series of videos about sustainable agriculture and healthy eating. The series was produced in collaboration with the Global Food Initiative at the University of California.

title: Developers Hope to Change the Face of Transit Hub in Jamaica, Queens
description: A major stop on the AirTrain from Kennedy International Airport has long offered a troublesome first impression for travelers visiting New York.

title: Scientists Trace an Ancient DNA Link Between Amazonians and Australasians
description: Some people in the Brazilian Amazon are very distant relations of indigenous Australians, New Guineans and other Australasians, two groups of scientists who conducted detailed genetic analyses reported Tuesday. But the researchers disagree on the source of that ancestry.

title: Classical Playlist: Christiane Karg, Alan Feinberg and More
description: SCENE! Christiane Karg, soprano; Arcangelo; Jonathan Cohen, conductor(Berlin Classics)This sopranos latest recital recording of six concert arias has everything one could wish for. Her refined voice is wonderfully pliable, her sense of text acute. Haydn and Mozart dominate, but theres a welcome push toward repertoire normally associated with a heavier voice in Beethovens Ah! perfido as well as a rarity, Mendelssohns radiant, later stormy Infelice pensier. Add the stylish, often tumultuous playing of Mr. Cohens period orchestra and a charming guest appearance on fortepiano by Malcolm Martineau in Mozarts Chio mi scordi di te? and this disc makes an immediate impression. (David Allen)

title: No Schmear, but Selfies Are Welcomed
description: The artist Hanna Liden, from Stockholm, was unfamiliar with bagels until she moved to New York. Now she has fashioned her own in styrene and polyurethane in an installation sponsored partly by the Art Production Fund. On Monday, two towers of bagels  plain, everything, sesame and pumpernickel  rose at Hudson River Park, seen here, and the Ruth Wittenberg Triangle in the West Village. A single bagel also appears outside the flagship Kiehls store, in the East Village; the company was a backer of the project.

title: Critics of Solitary Confinement Are Buoyed as Obama Embraces Their Cause
description: WASHINGTON  Before he was exonerated of murder and released in 2010, Anthony Graves spent 18 years locked up in a Texas prison, 16 of them all alone in a tiny cell.

title: Nationals Could Use Some Help. Mets Could Use It More.
description: WASHINGTON  As we enter the sultry, endurance-testing days of the long baseball summer, the expansive view beyond the outfield seats at Nationals Park includes several neighborhood cranes, structures on the rise or under rehabilitation.

title: Ischia
description: Tourists soak in the volcanic hot springs of this Italian island, and some cook food in them, too.

title: In Ischia, Italy, Cooking Is Done in the Sand, Not the Stove
description: ISCHIA, Italy  In theory, Ivo Iacono is the modest owner of a tiny wine bar in SantAngelo, the prettiest town on the sunny Mediterranean island of Ischia, which lies a short ferry ride from Naples and within sight of Capri.

title: In Speech to Veterans, Obama Says Iran Deal Is Smarter Path to Take
description: PITTSBURGH  President Obama said Tuesday that opponents of the nuclear deal with Iran were behaving like those who pushed for war with Iraq more than a decade ago, and said the United States should choose diplomacy instead of another rush to armed conflict.

title: Parke & Ronen: Spring 2016 Menswear
description: New York

title: Germanys Top Court Strikes Down Federal Aid for Home Child Care
description: BERLIN  Germanys highest court ruled on Tuesday that it was illegal for the federal government to pay parents who chose to care for their toddlers at home, rather than send them to publicly subsidized day care, striking down a program that was touted by conservatives.

title: In Exchange of Fire, Donald Trump Has Lindsey Grahams Number
description: Senator Lindsey Graham will probably have to change his cellphone number.

title: At Vatican, Mayors Pledge Climate Change Fight
description: VATICAN CITY  About 60 mayors from around the world gathered here on Tuesday and pledged to combat global warming and help the poor deal with its effects, at a conference swiftly organized by the Vatican barely a month after Pope Francis sweeping encyclical on the environment.

title: Denver Churchs Security Efforts Highlight New Reality
description: DENVER  Armed guards, security patrols and surveillance cameras  at the Potters House of Denver, they are just another part of Sunday services, like prayer, psalms and sermons. Much of the security effort is hidden so it does not interfere with worship, but church leaders insist that the military-style protocols are necessary.

title: Security Researchers Find a Way to Hack Cars
description: Some cars can now be hacked.

title: Why It Will Be Hard for Obama to Downsize Prisons
description: The American criminal justice system is primarily run by state and local governments, complicating President Obamas push to reduce the number of inmates.

title: Cellphone Ordinance Puts Berkeley at Forefront of Radiation Debate
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Leave it to Berkeley: This city, which has led the nation in passing all manner of laws favored by the left, has done it again. This time, the city passed a measure  not actually backed by science  requiring cellphone stores to warn customers that the products could be hazardous to their health, presumably by emitting dangerous levels of cancer-causing radiation.

title: Sail Amsterdam 2015 Set for August
description: The nautical festival Sail Amsterdam 2015, from Aug. 19 to 23, will host 43 tall ships, including 13 first-timers from around the world. The free event, held every five years in the Netherlands capital since 1975, begins with the 7.5-mile-long Sail-In parade, which also features four Dutch Marine vessels, marine training ships from 11 countries, and hundreds of historic ships and replicas, all sailing in line along the North Sea Canal from IJmuiden to Amsterdam.

title: Chris Christie, Springsteen Superfan, Puts Bon Jovi Ahead of the Boss
description: Theirs is a tale of two star-crossed New Jerseyans: a rock-and-roll hall-of-famer with a decidedly leftist political bent, and one of his most passionate fans  who is also the states Republican leader.

title: Rand Paul Takes a Match to the Tax Code. And a Wood Chipper. And a Chainsaw.
description: Senator Rand Paul has been trying to reignite his presidential campaign amid all the attention being lathered upon Donald J. Trump.

title: White House Turns to Social Media to Sell the Iran Deal
description: Its the #IranDeal for Dummies, brought to you by the White House.

title: Trial of Ex-Leader of Chad Suspended After He Refuses to Speak
description: PARIS  The long-awaited trial of Hissne Habr, the former strongman of Chad, was suspended on Tuesday  its second day  because Mr. Habr refused to speak and his defense lawyers did not show up.

title: 4 Arrested in Schemes Said to Be Tied to JPMorgan Chase Breach
description: A huge computer attack against JPMorgan Chase last summer may have been more of an attempt to fuel an ongoing pump-and-dump stock scheme rather than an effort to steal financial data from the nations biggest bank.

title: A Four-Bedroom House on a River
description: In the town of Rothesay, the house, built around 1918, is on the market for about $616,000.

title: Obama Says Iran Must Release Detainees
description: Speaking at a Veterans Association event on Tuesday, President Obama said that Iran must release the Americans they have detained.

title: A History of Frances Love Affair With the Bicycle
description: As Tour de France bikers furiously pedal their way to the Champs-lyses for their July 26 finish, this American in Paris contemplates the culture of the bicycle in France. Consider bike-sharing. New Yorkers are latecomers to the phenomenon; Citi Bike began only two years ago. Bike-loving Parisians, by contrast, are old hands. Theyve been getting around town on rent-to-ride two-wheelers since 2007. Their system, called Vlib, now has more than 1,000 stations and about 18,000 bikes.

title: Kevin Sessums Parts Ways With FourTwoNine
description: Kevin Sessums, the former Vanity Fair writer who chronicled his childhood in the memoir Mississippi Sissy and then his battle with sobriety in its follow-up, I Left It on the Mountain, has parted ways with FourTwoNine, the upstart glossy magazine founded by dot429.com, the gay and lesbian professional social network.

title: Funds Challenging Dell Bid Find Shares Arent Really Theirs
description: It turns out that mutual funds may not be that great at keeping track of the stocks they own. The latest evidence comes from a legal battle over the $24.9 billion management-led buyout at Dell.

title: Alexis Tsipras, Greek Prime Minister, Sheds His Identity as a Radical
description: ATHENS  On the eve of his election in January, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece talked with pride about how his leftist Syriza party rejected the mentality of establishment parties and provided space for the diverse views of its members.

title: Justice Department Drops Case Against Barry Bonds
description: After years of court proceedings and investigations, the performance-enhancing-drug case involving Barry Bonds, baseballs home run king, appears to be over.

title: Verbatim: A New Phone for Lindsey Graham, Thanks to Donald Trump
description: This morning, Donald J. Trump read aloud the phone number of Senator Lindsey Graham during a speech in South Carolina and encouraged people to call the senator.

title: Innovation Sputters in Battle Against Climate Change
description: In the race to develop technologies to slow climate change, the world is off track.

title: F.T.C. Accuses LifeLock of Violating Settlement
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday accused LifeLock, an identity theft protection service, of making deceptive claims in its advertising, in violation of an agreement the company made with the agency in 2010.

title: Private Sector Pay Lures F.B.I.s Hacking Experts
description: As attacks on networks and thefts of data grow, federal agents with just a few years of investigations into Internet crime under their belts need not look too hard for work in the private sector.

title: Sandra Bland Was Threatened With Taser, Police Video Shows
description: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.  A dashboard camera video taken by law enforcement officers and released Tuesday showed in excruciating detail how a routine traffic stop led to a shouting match and struggle between a state trooper and a woman, three days before she was found hanging in her jail cell.

title: Court Overturns Some of Rod Blagojevichs Convictions
description: CHICAGO  A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned five of the 18 convictions of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who was found guilty of corruption charges, including a scheme to sell or trade the United States Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama.

title: As a Broadcaster, Greg LeMond Returns to Tour de Frances Embrace
description: GAP, France  Lance Armstrongs reappearance on the fringes of the Tour de France last week was greeted at the race with the sort of enthusiasm usually reserved for bad odors. That is in stark contrast to Greg LeMond, another American Tour winner, who not only received a warm reception when he returned last year, but who is increasingly becoming an institution.

title: Man Charged With Plotting to Kill U.S. Serviceman in Britain
description: LONDON  A 24-year-old man was charged Tuesday with plotting to run over an American serviceman stationed in Britain and then kill him with a knife in an attack echoing the daylight slaughter of a British soldier on a London street two years ago.

title: Apple Profit Up 38%, but iPhone Sales Disappoint Wall Street
description: Even when Apple jumps, investors wonder why the company cant jump a bit higher.

title: Review: White People Looks at a Majority in an Ever More Diverse America
description: White People is a challenging title, and a trailer for the MTV documentary that bears it drew criticism  from conservative pundits last week. The show itself, however, shouldnt upset anyone when it makes its premiere on Wednesday night. Its exploration of how young white people see themselves and their status in an increasingly diverse America is earnest and upbeat, going out of its way to avoid blame or bad feelings.

title: U.A.B. Football Plans to Resume Play as Early as 2017
description: Alabama-Birmingham announced Tuesday that it would revive its football program, which it eliminated in a cost-cutting move late last year, and resume play as early as 2017.

title: On Beauty, by Rick Guidotti
description: A former fashion photographer, Rick Guidotti, has toured the globe taking photos of people with genetic and developmental disorders.

title: The Shadow of Death
description: Christianity was born in the Middle East, but with the rise of ISIS and other extremist movements across the region, its very survival there hangs in the balance.

title: Facebook Loses Appeal on New York Search Warrants
description: A New York state appeals court ruled on Tuesday that Facebook had no legal standing to challenge search warrants on behalf of its customers, a decision that dealt a blow to civil libertarians and social media companies seeking to expand Internet privacy.

title: Listen: Donald Trumps Future
description: Earlier this month, the Timess editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal took a look at some comments made by the presidential candidates Donald Trump, Chris Christie and Ted Cruz. Not only are the crazy things they say crazier than what the average Republican says, he wrote, they really dont have anything at all to say thats worth hearing. This week, he discussed some of those candidates on the Times Insider podcast. He noted that Mr. Trump had seen some fallout from his comments about Mexican immigrants, with Univision and others severing their ties with him. Its possible that Donald Trump will worry about losing business, Mr. Rosenthal said. On the other hand, this is who he is.

title: Obamas Power Africa Project Is Off to a Sputtering Start
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  On a recent Sunday afternoon, Anike Juliet stood outside her Ghoshen Beauty salon in suburban Lokogoma, Nigeria, waiting for the lights to come back on. Inside, a number of customers waited patiently. This was nothing new to them.

title: The Athletics of Others
description: Wrestlers of the Mongolian steppe.

title: Some New York Times Articles to Appear Free on Starbucks App
description: Starbucks and The New York Times Company announced on Tuesday that certain news articles would be made available free to members of the Starbucks loyalty program through the Starbucks mobile app.

title: A $7 Billion Charge at Microsoft Leads to Its Largest Loss Ever
description: SEATTLE  An accounting charge wiped out Microsofts profit for the quarter, leading to its largest loss ever, the company said on Tuesday, making clear the cost of its missteps in the mobile business.

title: Theodore Bikel, Master of Versatility in Songs, Roles and Activism, Dies at 91
description: Theodore Bikel, the multilingual troubadour, character actor and social activist who created the role of Baron von Trapp in the original Broadway production of The Sound of Music and toured for decades as Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: Review: Kinship Stars Cynthia Nixon as a Journalist
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Two of the three characters in Kinship, Carey Perloffs heavy-breathing drama at the Williamstown Theater Festival about a hard-driving newspaper editor who is ambushed by passion, say theyd do pretty much anything to avoid seeing a play. And you have to admit they have a point.

title: What You Get for  $1,200,000
description: Ten bedrooms on the Massachusetts coast, mountain views in California and an Acadian house in Louisiana

title: Yahoo Posts Loss, Despite Rise in Its Display Ad Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoos revenue in the second quarter rose 15 percent, the company said on Tuesday. But it spent heavily to achieve the gains, wiping out all of its profits and then some. Executives also warned that expenses would continue to be high through the rest of the year.

title: Ischia
description: Tourists soak in the volcanic hot springs of this Italian island, and some cook food in them, too.

title: Leader of Qaeda Cell in Syria,Muhsin al-Fadhli, Is Killed in Airstrike, U.S. Says
description: A military drone strike this month killed the leader of a shadowy Qaeda cell in Syria that American officials say has been plotting attacks against the United States and Europe, Pentagon officials said on Tuesday.

title: Ground Rules for Body Shimmer
description: When it comes to summer beauty products, body shimmer is the lovable but gorgeous ditz. It has nothing to do with efficacy or even practicality, but it sure is pretty. Yet even though there are innovative and upscale versions (like the new golden Nuxe shower oil, $15, and the Omorovicza shimmer oil, $80, that Im favoring lately  it has actual gold particles and practically screams yacht party in Hvar), allover shimmer runs the risk of looking tawdry.

title: How to Get Deep V Cleavage Ready
description: The subject here is cleavage: a generous swath of it, dipping way below the bustline and forming a deep V. (Victory over gravity, perhaps?) If social media and recent red carpets are an indication, dcolletage is in vogue. See: social media darlings like Emily Ratajkowski and the D.J. May Kwok flaunting the plunging 70s-era look on Instagram. (One risqu bodysuit, a black lace-up style by Reformation, has been a particular hit.)

title: Theodore Bikel, 1924-2015
description: A look back at the career of a man who is remembered as Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof, among many other roles and who could perform in 21 languages.

title: Reviving a Harry Partch Work With Hubcaps and Wine Bottles
description: Some looked like Picassos wooden sculptures. A few others might have been designed by Rube Goldberg. In fact, the contraptions jumbled backstage at City Center this week were musical instruments  painstaking re-creations of the whimsical, ingenious instruments invented and built by Harry Partch, a truly unusual 20th-century American composer, theorist and tinkerer whose works created a unique soundscape based on a tonal system all his own.

title: Has Obama Made a Difference in Africa?
description: We want to hear from those in Africa on how President Obama has done, and what he should still try to accomplish.

title: Trump Gives Out Grahams Number
description: Donald J. Trump gave out Senator Lindsey Grahams phone number at a campaign event in Bluffton, S.C.

title: Senators Reach Compromise on Increases to Highway Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the low-key conservative majority leader, and Senator Barbara Boxer, a brash liberal Democrat, reached an unlikely compromise Tuesday to increase highway spending over the next three years and set transportation policy through 2022.

title: In Chelsea, Art for Bibliophiles
description: Its summer reading time at three Chelsea galleries: This season, Fredericks & Freiser, Sean Kelly and Paul Kasmin are all exhibiting work that integrates text and image, celebrating the written word and contemporary literature through visual art. At Fredericks & Freiser, the artist Sam Messer has collaborated with the literary luminaries Jonathan Safran Foer and Denis Johnson to produce sculptures, paintings, drawings, prints and a stop-motion animated video called Denis the Pirate. The actor Liev Schreiber narrates the film, while the indie-music mainstays Sarah Neufeld (of the Arcade Fire) and Colin Stetson provide the score. In Atlas of Stress and Anxiety, arrows and scribbled text describe elements of a drawing that looks very much like Safran Foers face in front of a laptop. Theyre humorous and self-deprecating notes; the phrase Semitic giveaway appears frequently.

title: 50 Cent Says Hes Not as Rich as He Seems
description: 50 Cent, the rapper, actor and businessman born Curtis Jackson III, appeared in Manhattan court on Tuesday and said that his public projections of extreme wealth were little more than a fantasy.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Obama Teases Critics of Iran Nuclear Deal (and Jon Stewart) on The Daily Show
description: President Obama is used to playing the straight man when facing Jon Stewarts sarcastic humor on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Makeup That Lasts in the Heat
description: In deep summer, I consider only makeup products that promise long wear. My nonstop schedule (which for working moms or anyone tethered to her email isnt all that unique) means makeup that stays put. Who wants wandering eyeliner at the 3 p.m. meeting? Ive added these four picks to my cosmetics bag.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Turkey and More  Pictures of the Day

title: July 21, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Turkey, Burundi, Israel, and Japan.

title: The Muscle Shoals Sound Finally Gets Its Due
description: Even with its elite musical legacy, Muscle Shoals, Ala., has never quite gotten the same kind of accolades as Detroit or Memphis  that is, until recently.

title: Food Writer Seeks Story and Finds It Buried in the Sand
description: Normally, as a food writer traveling in Europe, theres no shortage of story lines. Going to London? Check out new gastropubs, Indian restaurants, the state of French cuisine. Scandinavia? Easy  its where the worlds leading chefs are gathering to study ancient foods and preservation methods. Paris? Just dig up the trends of the moment, whether a burger or a brilliant new flavor of macaron.

title: A Conversation With Stephen J. Meringoff
description: Mr. Meringoff, 71, is a founder and managing partner of Himmel & Meringoff, which owns and operates about two million square feet of office and retail space in New York City, much of it in the desirable Midtown South area. The companys most recent project involved a conversion at 1460 Broadway.

title: Dr. Seuss Through the Years
description: A closer look at What Pet Should I Get? and other work by Theodor Geisel.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Dr. Seuss What Pet Should I Get?
description: In December 1960, The New Yorker ran a profile of a man whose public appearances attracted crowds that would cause a western television hero to sway in the saddle with envy: Theodor Seuss Geisel, better known as Dr. Seuss, the author of riotous, catchy childrens books like The Cat in the Hat that had lately been flooding the nations bookstores and libraries. In the article, the 56-year-old Dr. Seuss himself revealed his formula  logical insanity  while the president of Random House, Bennett Cerf, was said to have called Geisel the only genius on his list, which included, The New Yorker reminded its readers, William Faulkner.

title: Dr. Seuss Book: Yes, They Found It in a Box
description: After Theodor Seuss Geisel, better known as Dr. Seuss, died in 1991, his widow, Audrey Geisel, decided to renovate their hilltop house in La Jolla, Calif. She and an assistant cleared out his office, donating most of his valuable illustrations and early drafts to the University of California, San Diego, and stashing some doodles and abandoned sketches in a box.

title: Videos Show Baltimore Riots Erupting After Freddie Gray Funeral
description: Newly released surveillance videos show how rioters destroyed property and clashed with the police at a Baltimore intersection after Freddie Grays funeral in April.

title: FIFA Scandal May Touch Unsuspecting Property Renters
description: There is a 2.74-acre estate in Loganville, Ga., that features a curvy swimming pool and an ornate gate at the head of its drive. On a private island in Miami, a high-rise apartment overlooks the water. And in modest sections of that city, eight cookie-cutter rental units sit in sleepy development communities. The properties are owned by some of the worlds highest-ranking soccer officials and sports marketing executives, and they are tied to tainted money, United States authorities say.

title: An Abandoned Factorys Clinton Connection
description: Michael Boreks penchant for old and quiet places took him to a lace factory where generations of immigrants toiled, including Hillary Rodham Clintons grandfather.

title: Obama Orders Flags Lowered for Chattanooga Victims
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday ordered the American flags at the White House and other public buildings to be lowered to half-staff in honor of the five military service members who were killed by a gunman in Chattanooga, Tenn., last week.

title: Donald Trump Is Thanked by Woman Whose Son Was Killed by Illegal Immigrant
description: Donald J. Trump got a shout-out Tuesday during a hearing on Capitol Hill from the mother of a man who was killed by an illegal immigrant in 2010.

title: A Complex Bankruptcy Case, With Baha Mar and a Chinese Contractor, Lands in Delaware
description: It makes perfect sense, of course, that a fight between a Bahamian resort and a Chinese-owned construction company, being litigated in London, would end up in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware.

title: $250. $500,000. Bail Differs Sharply for Drivers in 2 Similar Cases.
description: Death by car and alcohol in combination is more frequent on Long Island than in most of New York, so it is not surprising that the same judge, Rudolph H. Bruer, has had two cases within the last year in his court involving five fatalities on a small, beautiful stretch of Suffolk Countys North Fork.

title: Officers Arrested in 1986 Burning Death of U.S. Student in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A judge on Tuesday ordered the arrest of two former army officers and five former noncommissioned officers accused in the 1986 killing of Rodrigo Rojas, a United States resident, and the serious injury of a young woman. The two were set on fire by members of three military patrols during a protest in Santiago.

title: Bipartisan Debate Falters Over Removal of Confederate Battle Flag From Federal Land
description: WASHINGTON  Almost two weeks after House Republicans called for a bipartisan solution to the fight over the Confederate battle flag on federal property, there has been no visible progress, and the issue has unexpectedly paralyzed spending bills on the House floor.

title: Obama Kenya Trip Sets Off Gay Rights Debate in Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Obama has not even left for his trip to Africa this week, but he is already getting a lot of advice about what he should  or should not  say about gay rights after he lands.

title: Richard Leone, 75, Dies; Port Authority Chairman and Force in N.J. Politics
description: Richard C. Leone, a former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a prominent figure in several Democratic administrations in Trenton, died on Thursday in Hopewell, N.J. He was 75.
