description: The director James Ponsoldt discusses a sequence from his film The End of the Tour, featuring Jesse Eisenberg and Jason Segel and opening July 31.

title: Dance Listings for July 24-30
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Honeybees Show Evidence of Insecticide
description: More than 70 percent of pollen and honey samples collected from foraging bees in Massachusetts contained neonicotinoids, a type of insecticide that has been linked to colony collapse disorder, researchers are reporting. The disorder causes adult bees to abandon their hives in winter.

title: Spare Times for July 24-30
description: Museums and Sites

title: The End of the Tour (With Movie Trailer): James Ponsoldt Narrates a Scene
description: The End of the Tour, directed by James Ponsoldt and in theaters July 31, aims to cinematically capture the process of a journalist interviewing his subject. That journalist is David Lipsky, whose book Although of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself chronicled the time he spent interviewing the author David Foster Wallace while on his book tour for the 1996 novel Infinite Jest.

title: Spare Times for Children for July 24-30
description: Moth Night: Return to the Woods!

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: July 24
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include construction at the World Trade Center Transportation Hub and the anniversary of Eric Garners death.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll on Race Relations in the U.S.
description: Views about race relations and discrimination differ vastly between black and white Americans, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Hold Dim View of Race Relations
description: Seven years ago, in the gauzy afterglow of a stirring election night in Chicago, commentators dared ask whether the United States had finally begun to heal its divisions over race and atone for the original sin of slavery by electing its first black president. It has not. Not even close.

title: Sesac Settles Antitrust Lawsuit Over Royalty Rates
description: The music licensing group Sesac has settled an antitrust lawsuit with the radio industry that will for the first time subject Sesac to arbitration over the royalty rates it charges stations.

title: Senate to Debate 3-Year Delay for Rail Safety System
description: WASHINGTON  Two months after the high-speed derailment of an Amtrak train killed eight people and injured hundreds more in Philadelphia, a Senate transportation bill headed for debate this week calls for a three-year delay of the deadline for installing a rail safety system that experts say would have almost certainly prevented the Pennsylvania accident.

title: The Village, the Base, and Saint John
description: So, over the weekend we were told that our pass the popcorn moment  I mean, our long national nightmare  was over: Donald Trump would implode now that he had dared to question John McCains heroism.

title: Layers of Meaning in Mr. Obamas Kenya Trip
description: There often comes a time in the lives of Americans when they feel drawn to explore their roots, a quest that might take them on a pilgrimage to the old country, whether County Limerick, or Guangzhou, or a West African country from which their ancestors were abducted as slaves.

title: SPQR And All That
description: Its been a rough few weeks, so Ive been taking refuge in the past: I brought Adrian Goldsworthys The Fall of Carthage along on recent travels. And I found it revelatory; it shook some views Ive long held about history.

title: The Essential Obstfeld
description: Olivier Blanchard, who has to have been one of the most influential chief economists ever at the IMF, is retiring; Maury Obstfeld will be his replacement. Intellectually, theres a lot of continuity: one New Keynesian MIT PhD I know very well replaced with another New Keynesian MIT PhD with whom I co-authored a text now in 10th edition. Still, I hope people are interested in Maurys contributions to economics. And it seems to me that there are two papers in particular that are very relevant.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted July 14 to 19 with 1,205 adults throughout the United States.

title: Donald Trump, at Mexican Border, Claims Close Ties to Hispanics
description: LAREDO, Tex.  It was supposed to be the canvas on which Donald J. Trump painted his campaign, this arid stretch of pavement and patches of dirt where Mexico and the United States meet, now mobbed by more than 60 reporters. It was here that he would secure the border, build his impenetrable wall and stop the illegals.

title: Jobless Claims
description: Weekly number of people who have filed for unemployment benefits for the first time.

title: Jordan Authorities Free Uncle of Chattanooga Gunman
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The uncle of the gunman who killed five servicemen last week in Chattanooga, Tenn., was released Thursday after being held since last Friday by Jordanian security services, his lawyer here and a family representative in Tennessee said as American investigators continued to review the mans recent stay in Jordan as part of their search for a motive.

title: Offshore Wind Farm Raises Hopes of U.S. Clean Energy Backers
description: A few miles off the coast of Block Island, part of Rhode Island, a small flotilla has been gathering: crane vessels, tugboats and barges that began this week installing the 1,500-ton foundations of the nations first commercial-scale offshore wind farm.

title: Hillary Clinton Strongly Defends Planned Parenthood and Cites Nuance on Glass-Steagall
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday addressed two hot-button topics in the liberal base of the Democratic Party: abortion rights and Wall Street regulation.

title: No Charges for Officer in Miami Taser Death
description: MIAMI  No charges will be issued against a Miami Beach police officer in connection with the death of an 18-year-old graffiti artist who went into cardiac arrest after he was shocked in the chest by a Taser almost two years ago, prosecutors said on Thursday.

title: Blackstone C.F.O. Is Said to Be Headed to Airbnb
description: Airbnb, the highly valued house rental start-up, is currently in talks with a top executive at the investment firm Blackstone Group, Laurence A. Tosi, to be its chief financial officer, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Owen Chadwick, Eminent Historian of Christianity, Dies at 99
description: The Rev. Owen Chadwick, an educator and prolific historian of Christianity whose works encompassed sweeping narratives, like his two-volume history of the Victorian church, as well as incisive biographies and vivid pictures of rural church life, died on July 17 at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 99.

title: American Pharoah Has a Secure Spot in History, but a Tricky Future
description: It has been a long time since horseplayers could proclaim that all is right in the world and actually mean it. The horses are already running at Del Mar, the track that Bing Crosby built where the turf meets the surf in Southern California. On Friday, John Old Smoke Morrisseys Saratoga Race Course kicks off its 147th summer renewal.

title: The Financial Times Will Be in Good Hands
description: Who is the ideal owner for a prestigious newspaper? First and foremost, it should be someone who respects editorial independence, and who will not interfere in editorial matters. The decision about what to publish has to be made by journalists: It cant be a business decision designed to appease advertisers.

title: Nova Pilbeam, an Early but Brief Star for Hitchcock, Dies at 95
description: Nova Pilbeam, an English actress who was best known for her roles in the Alfred Hitchcock thrillers The Man Who Knew Too Much and Young and Innocent, but who retired from motion pictures in the late 1940s, before she was 30, died on July 17 at her home in London. She was 95.

title: Procedures Faulted in Army Labs Shipment of Anthrax
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon said on Thursday that its initial review of how an Army laboratory sent dozens of samples of live anthrax to facilities across the United States and around the world found that the lab had conducted insufficient testing and irradiation of samples.

title: Rosanne Klass, Writer and Advocate for the Afghan People, Dies at 86
description: Rosanne Klass, a writer and human rights advocate who presciently warned against Soviet aggression in Afghanistan in the 1980s and its potential to unify rebels under the banner of Islam, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

title: Drug Testing Is Coming to E-Sports
description: Lance Armstrong. Alex Rodriguez. Kory Friesen.

title: A Fatal Crash Shows a Safety Problem With Stretch Limousines
description: To travel safely as they toured wineries on the North Fork of Long Island last weekend, eight young women booked a stretch limousine for the afternoon. They could enjoy the wine and spirits without having to worry about driving.

title: 5 Men, 2 Fraud Schemes and a Possible Link to JPMorgan Chase Hacking
description: Last Saturday, Anthony R. Murgio attended a college friends wedding in Atlanta, seemingly without a care in the world.

title: Restaurant Review: Dining at il Laghetto With a View of the Sunset
description: Beautiful Lake Mahopac is still there but the Terrace Club along its shore is no more.

title: Zack Greinke Feasting on Feeble Lineups
description: Zack Greinke has been scratched from his next start, on Friday night against the Mets, so that he can return to Los Angeles to be with his wife, who is about to give birth. Which means the high-powered Mets offense  just joking  will miss out on a chance to put an end to Greinkes streak of 43 2/3 consecutive scoreless innings.

title: Push to Lift Minimum WageIs Now Serious Business
description: It started in New York City as what seemed a quixotic drive confined to fast-food workers. But the movement to raise the hourly minimum wage took root in other parts of the country, and is emerging as a significant, and divisive, element in the presidential campaign.

title: Restaurant Review: Olio in Stamford Offers a Stew of Global Ingredients
description: Olio, on Hope Street in the Springdale section of Stamford, is hard to categorize. Its dcor is Spanish, its chef and co-owner, Steve Costanzo, is Italian, and its menu is New American, with Asian and South American inflections. In a phone conversation with me after my visits, Mr. Costanzo explained that, after a long and diverse culinary career, which included stints at the now defunct restaurants Baang in Greenwich and Splash in Westport, he grew fond of matching flavors and cuisines.

title: Review: In The Art of Abhinaya, Bragha Bessell Dances WithMasterly Range
description: In many classical Indian dance traditions, the dancer is also an actor. A dance can be a kind of dramatic monologue in which the dancer presents a character, or several, and wordlessly tells a story, both narrating and re-enacting a poem. This kind of acting is called abhinaya, and it was the focus of a performance on Wednesday at the theater of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis High School in Manhattan. Titled The Art of Abhinaya, this was the first solo recital in New York of the Bharatanatyam dancer Bragha Bessell, who revealed herself to be a master of the art.

title: Amagansett Farmers Market to Reopen, With an Emphasis on Local
description: For those who have passed the shuttered Amagansett Farmers Market with heavy hearts this summer, there is cause for celebration. The market, which has been closed since late 2014, will reopen Aug. 1.

title: Teenage Brothers Accused of Killing Parents and 3 Siblings in Oklahoma
description: Two teenage brothers were being held on Thursday in the stabbing deaths of their parents and three siblings  ages 12, 7 and 5  in their home in a suburb of Tulsa, Okla., the police said.

title: Restaurant Review: A Caribbean Ambience at Winstons Bar & Grill in East Hampton
description: Winstons Bar & Grill in East Hampton is the opposite of the typical Hamptons restaurant. Instead of offering a cool, airy, summery ambience, Winstons is cozy, cluttered and rustic.

title: Review: Colin Quinn, Full of Nostalgia for Gritty Old New York
description: When I worked at Time Out New York in the late 1990s, visitors to the office were greeted by an ad poster saying: Welcome to New York. Now Get Out.

title: Minor Concessions
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  This will be a brief one today, because a member of my family had surgery this week and I am the caretaker. Please feel free to discuss amongst yourselves.

title: Bratton Says He Wont Lead Police Through a Second de Blasio Term
description: It was the kind of query he could have nimbly batted away. But the New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, dove straight in with a concrete answer when asked if he would stay on the job through Mayor Bill de Blasios second term were he re-elected.

title: Restaurant Review: The Grange in Warwick, True Farm-to-Table
description: The Grange in Warwick, N.Y., which is just over the New Jersey border, is truly a farm-to-table restaurant.

title: Texans on Donald Trumps Border Visit
description: Laredo residents shared their thoughts about a visit to their city by the Republican presidential candidate.

title: The Web-Connected Car Is Cool, Until Hackers Cut Your Brakes
description: WHEN the history of the connected car is written, this week may go down as a pivotal moment for consumers worried about security.

title: Clayton Kershaw Shuts Out Mets
description: Wilmer Flores stood in the batters box in the fourth inning as Clayton Kershaw began his delivery, rocking back, lifting his leg, and pausing before hurling another nasty pitch toward the plate. Flores stood there, his bat on his shoulder, and watched three pitches zip by him for strikes. The third one, a belt-high fastball, caught the outer half of the strike zone, and Flores just stood there, as if in shock.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, July 26 to Aug. 1, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: De Blasio Administration Grapples With How to Frame Uber Deal
description: On Monday, the message from Mayor Bill de Blasio was unequivocal: Uber was growing too fast.

title: Gunman Kills 2 and Himself at Movie Theater in Lafayette, La.
description: LAFAYETTE, La.  Three people died and nine were wounded after a gunman opened fire in a movie theater here on Thursday night, officials said. The gunman was among the dead.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 26 to Aug. 1, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, July 26 to Aug. 1, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: RapperBobby Shmurda Pleads Not Guilty to Promoting Prison Contraband
description: Ackquille Pollard, better known as the Brooklyn rapper Bobby Shmurda, has been accused of having his girlfriend smuggle a knife into the prison where he is being held on gang conspiracy and gun charges, and then lying to a grand jury, prosecutors said.

title: Review: In By the Water, a Search for Calm After the Storm
description: In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, which is when By the Water opens, a blue-collar couple returns to a ravaged home on Staten Island and starts to clean up the mess.

title: Cuomo Says New York City Should Contribute More to M.T.A. Capital Plan
description: For months, local and state officials from Albany to Staten Island have waited for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to weigh in on how to pay for the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys $32 billion capital plan.

title: Jeb Bush Has Lucrative Day in Chris Christies Backyard
description: Jeb Bush went to New Jersey on Thursday and raised more than $500,000 at two events, a huge haul in the home state of one of his rivals, Gov. Chris Christie.

title: Staging The Wreckers Opera at Bard College
description: Leon Botstein, the Zurich-born polymath and president of Bard College, has the bald pate and imperious bearing of an Old World movie director. And he has the rhetorical style to match.

title: Chenjerai Hove, Chronicler of Zimbabwean Struggles, Dies at 59
description: Chenjerai Hove, one of Zimbabwes leading writers, whose poems and novels powerfully evoked the struggles of ordinary village folk before and after independence, died on July 12 in Stavanger, in southwestern Norway. He was 59.

title: Arvid Anderson, New York Citys First Collective Bargaining Chief, Dies at 94
description: Arvid Anderson, a low-key Midwesterner who as New York Citys first director of collective bargaining won the respect of labor and management by calmly and methodically resolving volatile contract disputes, died on July 22 in Minneapolis. He was 94.

title: Urban Explorers Journey Into the Ruins of Long Island
description: Winter had been particularly rough. The sound of sparrows singing, hidden within the vines and bramble, provided the perfect backdrop for exploration.

title: Inquiry Sought in Hillary Clintons Use of Email
description: Update, Aug. 20, 2018: Subsequent developments and later reporting by The Times shed additional light on these events. New details emerged in April 2017 in this Times account of James B. Comeys handling of the Clinton investigation, as well as in Mr. Comeys own book, published in April 2018.

title: Madagascar at the Bruce Museum Displays Rare Flora and Fauna
description: Madagascar is home to thousands of rare species, including a giraffe weevil, of which the males neck is three times as long as the females; the sunset moth, with bright-colored iridescent wings to ward off predators; and the Madagascar periwinkle, a plant whose glossy leaves contain anticancer agents credited with quadrupling the survival rate of those afflicted with childhood leukemia.

title: Review: Karaoke Bacchae Puts a Spin on Euripides
description: Iggy Pop is a rock god, sure. But an almighty god? Well, he is in Karaoke Bacchae, a high-concept, low-comedy riff on The Bacchae, Euripides great fragmented tragedy.

title: House Votes to Cut Funds for Sanctuary Cities
description: The House voted 241 to 179 on Thursday to withhold some federal funding from jurisdictions that shield illegal immigrants from federal immigration officials. Republicans moved to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities after a young woman was killed this month in San Francisco. The authorities say she was shot by an illegal immigrant with a criminal record who had been released by the authorities there. Senate Republicans have introduced similar proposals, but the Judiciary Committee has yet to add them to its schedule for consideration.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Carrie Brownstein
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Carrie Brownstein.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks offerings are in the Manhattan neighborhoods of Chelsea and Kips Bay and in Fiske Terrace, Brooklyn.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom house in Weston, Conn., and a three-bedroom townhouse in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: 2 Men Are Found Dead in Bronx Apartment
description: Two men were found dead in an apartment in the Bronx on Thursday, the police said.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Starz) BIG HERO 6 (2014) Baymax (voiced by Scott Adsit), a giant marshmallow of a robot created as a health care companion, waddles, boings and even flies as he and a 14-year-old robotics prodigy, Hiro (Ryan Potter), above with Baymax, try to save their city, San Fransokyo, from a villainous takeover in this superhero comedy from the Walt Disney Animation Studios. Big Hero 6 is a bright, visually sumptuous 3-D computer-animated feature that gives you a bit of an emotional workout, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. It doesnt have some of the familiar Disney markers: There are no eardrum-busting anthems or warbling critters, and it isnt a fairy tale, exactly, mostly because its about a boy. Its a Disney superhero movie with a story from a Marvel comic book, if one rendered with the wit and texture often associated with Pixar, which I guess makes it a Walt Pixar Marvel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I asked to use his needle and he said, Hey, Ive got hep B and C. And at the time it didnt really matter to me. The desire to get high was just so great.

title: Corrections: July 24, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Chinese Doctors, Under Strain and Threat, Call for Support in Video
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Garifuna Immigrants in New York
description: The Garifuna of Honduras are keenly aware of their history, being descendants of indigenous Caribbean tribes and African slaves who settled Central Americas Caribbean coast. They honor their ancestors, their language and their traditions, even as many of them have settled in the South Bronx in recent decades. There, Linda Arzu found one more reminder of her past: an ankle monitor immigration authorities had her wear after she arrived in this country without proper papers last year.

title: Life After Death, in Phone Contacts and Cyberspace
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Is the Poison His Party Concocted
description: The adults patrolling the playpen of Republican politics are appalled that weve become a society where its O.K. to make fun of veterans, to call anyone who isnt rich a loser, to cast an entire group of newly arrived strivers as rapists and shiftless criminals.

title: Effects of Our Cuba Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Choosing How We Die
description: Pittsburgh  IN 1975 Shirley Dinnerstein, a 64-year-old Massachusetts woman, learned she had Alzheimers disease. Three years later she was in an essentially vegetative state, according to her case records, and a court was deciding whether to honor her previously expressed wish not to be resuscitated if she died. The court ruled in her favor, establishing, for the first time, that patients care choices at the end of life could be officially documented in the medical record without being validated in court.

title: The Lasting Trauma of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: The Minimum-Wage Muddle
description: Once upon a time there was a near consensus among economists that raising the minimum wage was a bad idea. The market is really good at setting prices on things, whether it is apples or labor. If you raise the price on a worker, employers will hire fewer and youll end up hurting the people you meant to help.

title: The M.I.T. Gang
description: Goodbye, Chicago boys. Hello, M.I.T. gang.

title: The Anti-Immigrant Binge in Congress
description: Congress is in danger of taking that most cursed of American political disagreements, the debate over illegal immigration, and dragging it farther toward insanity.

title: Drug Use in Public Places
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Euro to Blame for Europes Woes?
description: To the Editor:

title: British Gambling Firm Ladbrokes to Acquire Bulk of Rival Gala Coral
description: LONDON  Ladbrokes, the British sports betting company, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire the bulk of its rival Gala Coral Group in an all-share deal.

title: Turkey, Anticipating Attack, Strikes 3 ISIS Targets in Syria With Jets
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish fighter jets struck three Islamic State targets in Syria on Friday in an effort to pre-empt a planned attack on Turkey, a senior Turkish government official said.

title: Al Qaedas Chief of Bombing Attacks Died in U.S. Strike, Pentagon Says
description: ERBIL, Iraq  The Qaeda operative in charge of suicide bombings and operations involving explosives was killed in an American airstrike in Afghanistan this month, the Pentagon said Friday.

title: Making More Space in a One-Bedroom Apartment
description: Cant find a decent two-bedroom at a price you can afford? Try searching for a one-bedroom big enough to turn into two.

title: Obama to Push U.S. Trade in Kenya as Chinas Role Grows
description: VOI, Kenya  After spending their days digging in the red-clay earth to build a railroad between Nairobi and the sprawling port city of Mombasa, the Chinese workers here retreat to metal trailers surrounded by barbed wire and armed guards.

title: Ask Well: Catching Up on Lost Sleep
description: Question:

title: Meiji Yasuda to Buy StanCorp Financial for $5 Billion
description: The Meiji Yasuda Life Insurance Company of Japan said on Friday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the StanCorp Financial Group, an American provider of insurance and retirement products, for $5 billion in cash.

title: Fridays Travel News: Zaha Hadids Museum Under the Alps
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: Love in the Hot Season
description: Good morning on this bright Friday.

title: The World According to China
description: Chinas enormous overseas spending has helped it displace the United States and Europe as the leading financial power in large parts of the developing world.

title: Chinas Global Ambitions, Cash and Strings Attached
description: EL CHACO, Ecuador  Where the Andean foothills dip into the Amazon jungle, nearly 1,000 Chinese engineers and workers have been pouring concrete for a dam and a 15-mile underground tunnel. The $2.2 billion project will feed river water to eight giant Chinese turbines designed to produce enough electricity to light more than a third of Ecuador.

title: Seeking a Global Stage
description: China has been important to the world economy for decades, but the country is now wielding its financial heft with the confidence and purpose of a global superpower.

title: Anthem to Buy Cigna Amid Wave of Insurance Mergers
description: Two more of the nations biggest health insurers are moving to merge, raising the possibility of a potential fight with antitrust regulators.

title: Malaysia Suspends 2 Newspapers Covering Scandal at State-Owned Fund
description: HONG KONG  The Malaysian authorities have ordered two newspapers to suspend publishing for three months over their reporting on a financial scandal that has embroiled Prime Minister Najib Razak and other members of the countrys elite, the outlets parent company said Friday.

title: Today in Politics: A Billionaires Deep Pockets Come With a Big Catch
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, whereinspectors general have asked the Justice Department to investigate whether Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive information on a private email account. And while candidates typically approach donors to make their pitch, one billionaire has a single litmus test to earn his support: climate change.

title: The 7.12.15 Issue
description: RE: BOGOT TWINS

title: Boomerang
description: This poem, the first section in a longer sequence titled Songs for the Cold War, recalls the fears and delights of childhood  how often they are mixed. We do not need to have experienced these moments exactly for the images to evoke vivid recollections of time spent with the beloved adults of our childhoods.

title: Charmed
description: One afternoon last April, I stood in the doorway of my daughters room, watching her prepare for a big recital. She was going to perform with her middle-school orchestra in Santa Monica. She packed her violin, rosined her bow, put on a black dress and tamed her wild hair into a bun. There, she said. Im ready. How lovely she looked, how determined. Had I been half as confident as this when I was 11?

title: How to Tell a Joke
description: People should not be able to telegraph where a jokes going, says Hari Kondabolu, a stand-up comic from Queens. The only way to guarantee surprise is to create original material. Street jokes  the kind you read in a book or hear at summer camp and tell with the preface Want to hear a joke?  are almost never funny, Kondabolu says. They also often involve animals, inexplicably. (If you must go that route, ducks make for the funniest animal jokes, according to a global survey done by scientists at the University of Hertfordshire.) His routines playfully take on more serious topics like race and gender.

title: The Singular Mind of Terry Tao
description: This April, as undergraduates strolled along the street outside his modest office on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles, the mathematician Terence Tao mused about the possibility that water could spontaneously explode. A widely used set of equations describes the behavior of fluids like water, but there seems to be nothing in those equations, he told me, that prevents a wayward eddy from suddenly turning in on itself, tightening into an angry gyre, until the density of the energy at its core becomes infinite: a catastrophic singularity. Someone tossing a penny into the fountain by the faculty center or skipping a stone at the Santa Monica beach could apparently set off a chain reaction that would take out Southern California.

title: What Home Means to New Yorks Oldest Old
description: At the Hebrew Home at Riverdale, in the Bronx, Helen Moses, 90, had news.

title: Jimmy Carter and Jacqueline Woodson on Race, Religion and Rights
description: Take two fine memoirists to lunch, and before long they will be trading moments from their childhood when a door opened, as Graham Greene put it, and let the future in.

title: Teaching Social Skills to Improve Grades and Lives
description: In the early 1990s, about 50 kindergarten teachers were asked to rate the social and communication skills of 753 children in their classrooms. It was part of the Fast Track Project, an intervention and study administered in Durham, N.C., Nashville, Seattle and central Pennsylvania. The goals were to understand how children develop healthy social skills, and help them do so.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 7 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its seventh week. To participate, post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on July 31 and answer the question What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: Morning Agenda: Nikkei Buys the Pink Paper
description: NIKKEI BUYS THE PINK PAPER | The Japanese media company Nikkei trounced the German group Axel Springer to buy The Financial Times, Ravi Somaiya, Jonathan Soble and David Jolly report in DealBook. Pearson, its parent company, had been discussing the sale with Financial Times executives for about a year, but there was a last-minute race to close the deal on Thursday, in which Nikkei trumped the competition with a $1.3 billion offer.

title: Algerias Invisible Arab
description: At the core of any conflict lies invisibility. The enemy cannot be seen, at least not if seeing betokens the start of understanding. The other is there, a menacing and ineffaceable presence, but is invisible in his or her human dimensions.

title: Lafayette Police Chief on Shooting
description: The morning after a shooting rampage in a Louisiana movie theater on Thursday, the police confirmed that nine people had been injured and three people, including the gunman, had died.

title: Restaurant Report: R&J Lounge and Supper Club in Oklahoma City
description: When I tugged open the door to R&J Lounge and Supper Club, a midcentury-inspired restaurant, I expected plumes of cigarette smoke to waft into the air. Its a nonsmoking place, but looks like a set from my imagined sequel, Goodfellas Take the Middle West  red and gold flock wallpaper, burgundy Naugahyde booths, a neon sign out front that washes its somewhat seedy location (up an alley next to a tire dealership) in a warm fluorescent glow.

title: Hotel Review: The Andaz Tokyo Toranomon Hills in Tokyo
description: From about 40,000 Japanese yen, $335 at 120 yen to the dollar.

title: Trial of Chinese Rights Campaigners on Subversion Charges Continues
description: BEIJING  The trial of three prominent rights campaigners, including a lawyer, on charges of inciting subversion continued on Friday in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, amid a sweeping crackdown on human rights lawyers that has drawn international condemnation.

title: Clever or Offensive? Taye Diggs Profile Kicks Up Some Dust
description: Context isnt everything, but it matters.

title: 5 Places President Obama Should Visit While in Kenya
description: As President Obama visits Kenya, concerns about security during his two-day stay will limit his movements to the capital, Nairobi. The trip, his first there as president, is a homecoming of sorts for Mr. Obama who visited the African nation and the birthplace of his father in 1987 and again in 2006 as a senator. Given the constraints of presidential security, Mr. Obama wont have much chance to visit a country that has plenty to offer, including Africas second-highest mountain, wildlife reserves and an elephant rescue center.

title: Converse Dares to Introduce the Chuck Taylor II
description: When you have the worlds most successful sneaker, why mess with it?

title: Strange Case in the Emergency Room
description: Dear Diary:

title: Fire Phasers
description: Jeb Bush doesnt just want Americans to work more hours; he also wants to phase out Medicare, or so he told a Koch brothers backed group. What hes talking about, presumably, is a Paul Ryan-type conversion of Medicare into a voucher system.

title: Lafayette Shooting Adds Another Angry Face in the Gunmens Gallery
description: LAFAYETTE, La.  It was about 20 minutes into the 7 p.m. showing of Trainwreck when moviegoers heard a couple of pops, like a sound effect glitch. But when the sounds rang out again it became horribly clear that this was something else entirely.

title: Absolute Beginners: Evoking MGM Spectacle With 80s Video Style
description: Most movies are made of scenes; others are devoted to making the scene. Julien Temples Absolute Beginners is one  a big-budget spectacle that, made in 1986, sought to render four decades of Anglo-American pop culture as a symphonic music video.

title: A Tiny House Fit for the Hamptons
description: With his venture Cocoon9, Christopher Burch  the man behind the now-shuttered clothing brand C. Wonder and the former husband of the fashion designer Tory Burch  hopes to prove that small, prefabricated spaces can be luxurious and perfect for the Hamptons.

title: 1993 Video Reveals a More Impassioned and Direct Hillary Clinton
description: In 1993, with her father on his deathbed, Hillary Rodham Clinton was not yet a two-time presidential candidate. She was not a New York senator or the secretary of state. She was the presidents wife  a first lady who hosted the Easter egg roll and Christmas tree lighting at the White House, in addition to trying to overhaul the health care system.

title: Oliver Sacks: My Periodic Table
description: I LOOK forward eagerly, almost greedily, to the weekly arrival of journals like Nature and Science, and turn at once to articles on the physical sciences  not, as perhaps I should, to articles on biology and medicine. It was the physical sciences that provided my first enchantment as a boy.

title: Donald Trump and the Press: Why Coverage Matters
description: As journalists agonize over how to handle Donald Trumps candidacy  searching for the signs of inevitable collapse after every new controversy  its worth recalling the case of another outsider who briefly led the primary polls: Herman Cain.

title: How Colleges Are Weak
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Daily Report: Amazon Shows Profit for a Change
description: We have reached Peak Amazon, or perhaps Prime Amazon, David Streitfeld reports.

title: Video Reviews of Southpaw, Paper Towns and Phoenix
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Southpaw, Paper Towns and Phoenix. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Chris Christie Makes Big Advertising Splash on Fox News
description: In the race to crack the top 10 threshold that will determine which candidates can be in the first Republican presidential debate Aug. 6 on Fox News, there is more than one approach to getting your poll numbers up.

title: Top FIFA Executive Jrme Valcke Says He Expects to Leave With Sepp Blatter
description: Jrme Valcke, the top deputy to FIFAs president, Sepp Blatter, said on Friday that he expected his career at global soccers governing body to end along with his bosss when a special election for a new leader is held in February.

title: U.S. Letter to Israel on Fraud Schemes
description: The Justice Department asked Israel to arrest three men charged with running a stock manipulation scheme.

title: Dutch Government Hires Bankers for ABN Amro I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley have been hired to help oversee the sale of the Dutch governments stake of the state-owned lender ABN Amro in an initial public offering.

title: Stuff We Liked: Bees, Home Values and Transit Maps
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Readers on Planned Parenthood and Fetal Tissue
description: In addition to discussions of abortion rights, hidden-camera videos targeting Planned Parenthood inspired a debate among readers over the scientific use of fetal tissue.

title: Exploring a Century of Art From Congo
description: PARIS  The art practically leaps off the walls. A striking painting of President Obama, Nelson Mandela and Patrice Lumumba, the Congolese leader who was assassinated in 1961. Luscious black-and-white photographs of 1950s night life in Lopoldville, now Kinshasa. Whimsical watercolors from the 1930s.

title: Limited Too 2, Project Runways Record and R.I.P. Elio Fiorucci
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: 1940: Oxford Refugees Arrive at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  The long-awaited group of children and wives of Oxford University faculty members arrived in New Haven at 8:10 oclock tonight [July 24] to accept the war-time refuge offered by the Yale Faculty Committee for Receiving Oxford and Cambridge University Children, Inc. The ninety-seven children, ranging in age from one month to fifteen years, accompanied by twenty- four mothers, appeared to be intellectually composed and cheerful.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Technology, While Not a Fountain of Youth, Can Make Aging Safer
description: JEAN DICKOW, 78, never wanted the latest whiz-bang technology. But her gadget-friendly daughter, who lives in Norway, was worried that Ms. Dickow would fall in her apartment and no one would know.

title: Its Time to Reconsider Barry Bonds for the Hall of Fame
description: Years ago, we posed a question about a question, wondering how the court of public opinion, along with the guardians of baseball, might have dealt with Barry Bonds had he answered affirmatively when a federal grand jury asked him in December 2003 about his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: National Park Visitors Cant Resist Bison, Despite Warnings
description: Officials at Yellowstone National Park are warning visitors not to fraternize with wildlife after a woman was injured while trying to take a selfie near a bison  but that hasnt stopped some visitors from posting their close encounters on social media.

title: Witnesses Describe Chaos as Lafayette, La., Shooting Unfolded
description: On Thursday, a gunman opened fire in a Lafayette, La., movie theater. Two people were killed and the gunman, described by the authorities as a drifter, took his own life.

title: Hillary Clinton to Back $15 Fast-Food Minimum Wage in New York
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday will use a speech focused on growing the economy to endorse a $15-an-hour minimum wage proposal for fast-food workers recommended by a New York panel, a person briefed on her plans said.

title: How to Snag a Reservation at That Oh-So-Popular Restaurant
description: Its a beautiful Saturday evening and you want to go out to a hot new restaurant, maybe splurge on one of those grand Michelin three-star restaurants in New York.

title: Finding Bernie Sanderss Brooklyn
description: An attic bedroom in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn is a spot that Bernie Sanders, a presidential hopeful, once called home.

title: Bernie Sanderss 100% Brooklyn Roots Are as Unshakable as His Accent
description: Ivor Williams stood on his porch and stared suspiciously at the visitor who was pointing to the attic of his pink and shingled house near Brooklyn College.

title: The Housing Market Still Isnt Rational
description: Home prices have been climbing. They have risen 27 percent nationally since 2012, even more in places like San Francisco. But why worry? If you accept the efficient markets theory  and believe that real estate is an efficient market  then these prices are based on new information, even if you dont know what that information is.

title: Feedback on Supreme Courts Housing-Law Ruling
description: Some mortgage lenders are predicting costly repercussions from last months Supreme Court decision upholding a longstanding legal tool for challenging housing and lending practices that have a discriminatory effect, if not an obvious discriminatory intent.

title: Review: In LOrfeo, Free Spirit and Brave Soul Unite
description: MUNICH  He grounds me. She draws me out of my shell. It speaks to the vibrancy of David Bschs production of Monteverdis LOrfeo at the Bavarian State Opera here that you could describe Orfeo and Euridices relationship with lines that seem lifted from a modern couples wedding vows.

title: An Alligator Tours New York City, Joining Some Famous Fauna
description: A stray alligator roaming the streets of Manhattan has given jaded New Yorkers yet another reason to marvel at their urban jungle and the wild creatures that occasionally roam through it.

title: Miguel Thrives on Dualities in His New Album, Wildheart
description: LOS ANGELES  Something was not right. Wireless microphone in hand, Miguel was circling the floor of Club Nokia here during the soundcheck for a concert to preview his new album, Wildheart. It was one of the warm-up shows before Miguels first headlining tour, where hell be playing much larger clubs like Terminal 5 on August 2nd in New York City.

title: tk
description: tk

title: Americans Are Finally Eating Less
description: After decades of worsening diets and sharp increases in obesity, Americans eating habits have begun changing for the better.

title: Its Hard to Count Calories, Even for Researchers
description: If youve ever tried to use one of those dieting apps, you probably know the pitfalls of the government survey that most researchers use to evaluate Americans eating habits. Its really hard to keep track of what you've eaten.

title: First Black Leader of South Africas Opposition Seeks to Unseat the A.N.C.
description: HARTBEESPOORT, South Africa  ON a chilly Saturday morning, as delegates of South Africas official opposition party streamed into this resort town for a meeting, black people made up about two-thirds of the attendees. White people were there, too, sitting at tables clustered in the middle of a large convention hall, including the relatives of a party veteran, an older white man who was stepping down that day.

title: What I Love | Cara Nicoletti
description: The butcher, baker, blogger and the author of the memoir/cookbook Voracious lives in a two-bedroom rental in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Cara Nicoletti,Butcher, Baker and Author
description: Theres a brand-new white Whirlpool refrigerator in Cara Nicolettis apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Ms. Nicoletti, a butcher, a baker and the creator of the literary food blog Yummy Books, is grateful to her landlord for the appliance. Its predecessor was gross and old and didnt have any shelf space, and Id been asking for a really long time, said Ms. Nicoletti, 29. But she is reserving judgment on the Frigidaire stove, part of the same delivery of kitchen jewelry.

title: One of Two Charges Against Rick Perry Is Dismissed
description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who is seeking the Republican nomination for president, received some good news regarding his legal problems on Friday when an appeals court in his state dropped one of the two felony charges he is facing.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Jerusalem

title: Prison That Held El Chapo Is Replica of One He Broke Out of Earlier
description: MEXICO CITY  Ever since the powerful drug lord known as El Chapo escaped from a maximum-security prison through a mile-long tunnel that opened right into the shower of his cell, Mexico has been wondering how his accomplices got their hands on the blueprints to operate with such pinpoint precision.

title: Popcast: Prince Royce, Pitbull and Multilingual Pop Music
description: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Julianne Escobedo Shepherd discuss international and multilingual pop.

title: For Fresh, Flavorful Fish, Show Some Backbone
description: Despite the skinless-boneless tendencies of some modern home cooks, these long-held truths apply:

title: Chris Brown Leaves the Philippines After Being Grounded for 3 Days
description: Chris Browns pleas on social media have finally been answered: The R&B singer was allowed to leave the Philippines late on Friday, local time, after being grounded there for three days as a result of a fraud complaint.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: What Pet Should I Get?
description: This week, Maria Russo and Alexandra Alter talk about Dr. Seuss; Jill Ciment discusses The Hand That Feeds You; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Popcast: Prince Royce, Pitbull and Multilingual Pop Music
description: Prince Royce, the young Bronx-raised Dominican-American bachata singer, has just made Double Vision, his first non-bachata album, in English; it includes guests like Kid Ink, Snoop Dogg, Tyga and Jennifer Lopez. Pitbull, the slightly older Cuban-American rapper from Miami who has had enormous hits in English (Give Me Everything, Timber, I Know You Want Me) has just made his second Spanish-language album, Dale; it includes singers and rappers from Cuba and the Dominican Republic like Sensato, Osmani Garcia, and Wisin and Yandel.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Buckley vs. Vidal: When Debate Became Bloodsport
description: Before partisan panels, split-screen shoutfests and brash personalities became ubiquitous on cable news, there were two men who despised each other sitting side by side on a drab soundstage, debating politics in prime time during the presidential nominating conventions of 1968. There were Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: What Pet Should I Get?
description: This week, Maria Russo, Alexandra Alter and Jill Ciment.

title: A Startup for Geeks in Gaza
description: Tucked away in a building near the Gaza Strips scarred but glistening Mediterranean coastline is a wall of dreams. On it, dozens of young entrepreneurs have posted their answers to an especially difficult question: What would you do if you werent afraid?

title: Inside the List
description: Not O.K.: Ta-Nehisi Coatess new book, Between the World and Me  an incantatory essay about being black in America, framed as a letter to his teenage son  enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No.1. Like another recent best seller, Claudia Rankines Citizen, the book burns with moral intelligence about the daily humiliations and degradations confronting black people, and refuses the easy consolations of hope and uplift. Early on, Coates addresses his sons despair over the Michael Brown case in Ferguson, Mo. I didnt comfort you, he writes, because I thought it would be wrong to comfort you. I did not tell you that it would be O.K., because I have never believed it would be O.K. What I told you is what your grandparents tried to tell me: that this is your country, that this is your world, that this is your body, and you must find some way to live within the all of it. I tell you now that the question of how one should live within a black body, within a country lost in the Dream, is the question of my life, and the pursuit of this question, I have found, ultimately answers itself. (The dream at issue is of course the American dream, which Coates points out depends on a vision of innocence that willfully ignores the American sins of slavery and institutional racism.) Some commentators have taken Coates to task for emphasizing social and historical frameworks more than personal choice and responsibility, but a recent profile in New York magazine leaves no question where he stands on that debate. Coates noticed the good people on the wrong side of history, the reporter Benjamin Wallace-Wells writes, suggesting that individual virtue was a weak counterweight to the pathologies of states. Had he been alive and had means, he tweeted, I would have owned slaves too.

title: Ted Cruz Attacks Mitch McConnell in Clash Over an Agency
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Cruz, the sometimes-incendiary Texan running for the Republican presidential nomination, took to the Senate floor on Friday to call his partys majority leader a liar in an extraordinary public airing of grievance.

title: Political listy
description: For listy

title: Summer Fiction
description: HOW TO BE A GROWN-UPBy Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus240 pp. Atria, $25.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE WEATHER EXPERIMENT: The Pioneers Who Sought to See the Future, by Peter Moore. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) Unlike many British-centric meteorological histories, Moores evocative account pays homage to American contributions.

title: A Cure for Suicide, by Jesse Ball
description: In Jesse Balls elegant, spellbinding fifth novel, A Cure for Suicide, a man known only as the claimant sits on a chair, which he has recently learned is called chair. He listens as a woman he knows as the examiner tells him how a story works. The examiner has not yet given the claimant a name. The claimant must first learn how to listen to a story and tell a story in turn. It isnt important that you understand what I say, the examiner tells him. It is not very important that you are understood as long as you give the person the happiness of being told a story.

title: An Unfinished Library
description: The Greatest Books Youll Never Read is a new survey of books that are unfinished, unbegun or lost, and today exist as only suggestive fragments or not at all. Despite the title, not all of these works sound particularly great. Take, for example, Karl Marxs Scorpion and Felix, a comic novel he wrote when he was 19 and under the influence of Tristram Shandy. According to the Marx biographer Francis Wheen, its a nonsensical torrent of whimsy and persiflage.

title: Paperback Row
description: PERFIDIA, by James Ellroy. (Vintage, $16.95.) After a Japanese family is murdered in 1940s Los Angeles, a police force with questionable ethics is tasked with solving the case, blurring the lines between criminality and morality. As our reviewer, Dennis Lehane, wrote, The police are not knights, theyre occupiers, and in Perfidia, Ellroy comes closer than ever to making the case that he writes alt-histories not of the Los Angeles police but of the Los Angeles police state.

title: The End of Plenty, by Joel K. Bourne Jr.
description: An 18th-century question matters for 21st-century foodies: Are human beings perfectible? If our species can improve itself, if we can learn to consume less, have fewer children and wean ourselves off meat, the planet might yet flourish. If not, the fear is that well breed and eat ourselves into extinction. Many have addressed this quandary, but Robert Malthuss ideas are the ones Joel Bourne puts at the heart of The End of Plenty, his big book on the global food system.

title: A Hand Reached Down to Guide Me, by David Gates
description: The world of the knowing and frank stories in David Gatess new collection is located north of New York City, ranging roughly from Peekskill to Vermont. The bright, educated, sardonic people who inhabit this world call themselves refugees from New York, dismissing their new locale as Olde Quaintsburgh or the boonies. Full of rueful badinage, like the characters in his novels Jernigan and Preston Falls, they make for witty and cautionary company. A Hand Reached Down to Guide Me is a smart book about smart, articulate people who get in their own way again and again, engaging in episodic festivals of bad decisions and then talking about their plight with arresting candor, in language rife with humor and allusion.

title: The Hand That Feeds You, by A.J. Rich
description: As The Hand That Feeds You opens, Morgan, a 30-year-old graduate student, returns home to her 68-step Williamsburg walk-up to find that her fianc has been mauled to death by her dogs. Its a terrifying scene, relayed with gripping frankness.

title: Christian Krachts Imperium
description: If, while sprawled in a deck chair or on the beach this summer, you crave a book whose tone and emotional landscape mirror your own state of torpor and cosseted relaxation, such a book would not be Imperium. Although this very amusing and bracingly oddball novel by the Swiss writer Christian Kracht does feature several palm-covered islands  not to mention many gallons of coconut oil and copious amounts of undress  calling it a beach read is like calling Psycho maternal.

title: The Loved Ones, by Mary-Beth Hughes
description: Only a flurry. A thin blanket of white, something to take the gray mounds of snow and make them new. So begins Mary-Beth Hughess third book, The Loved Ones. It is 1969, and Jean Devlin is leaving her house on the Jersey Shore in the Valiant wagon she used for errands. The departure is fraught, partly because the fraughtness of departure is one of the books themes, and partly because of the nature of the driveway. Jean made the reverse up the steep curve, then backed into the roadside pull-off where most delivery drivers chickened out and parked. Theyd rather hand carry a refrigerator than make the plunge, but Jean could do it blindfolded.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Exercise Motivation, Sex Research and Pain Relief
description: Take the Quiz

title: Troika of Greek Creditors to Travel to Athens for Debt Talks
description: Less than seven months after Greeces three major creditors were declared unwelcome in Athens, representatives of the troika prepared to travel there to start on-the-ground talks in the coming days about a new multibillion-euro bailout.

title: F.D.A. Wants Food Labels to Quantify Added Sugars
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed on Friday that nutrition labels on packaged foods cite the amount of added sugars they contain as a percentage of the recommended daily calorie intake.

title: Chicagos Plan to Change Pension Benefits Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A judge in Chicago ruled on Friday that a plan to change city workers pensions was unconstitutional. The case is being closely watched for its effect on the citys uncertain finances.

title: A Floor at the Pierre Hotel for $22.9 Million
description: A full-floor aerie on the 29th floor of the Pierre hotel, steps from Central Park and offering white-glove perks like concierge and twice-daily maid services to its co-op residents, sold to the widow of one of the founders of Liberty Travel for $22,900,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Push Within Religions for Gay Marriage Gets Little Attention
description: From the moment the Supreme Court ruled last month in favor of a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, opponents placed the decision in a very specific analytical frame. Here, they contended, was an egregious example of secular culture triumphing over religious values and religious freedom.

title: Leaked Fed Staff Forecast Reflects Gloomier Expectations for U.S. Economy
description: Staff economists at the Federal Reserve are more pessimistic about the nations economic prospects than the senior Fed officials who set monetary policy, according to an internal document the central bank mistakenly put online.

title: Of Dogs, Faith and Imams
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  When I take my dog for a walk on the beach near my house in Karachi, this is how people react: Mothers tell their kids, look, a dog; kids ask me the dogs name and if they can touch him; most grown men either recoil or ask me about the price and the breed. Sometimes when I see someone heading to the neighborhood mosque, I cross to the other side of the street. There is a popular belief among the pious that if they come in contact with a dog, they become unclean. You have to take a ritual bath before you can offer your prayers.

title: The Four Seasons Space Gets a New, Younger Face
description: A bastion of ritualized, old-guard dining in New York City is about to be taken over by three brash young men who were born decades after it opened.

title: 1965: Nudists Get Under Polices Skin
description: SAINT-TROPEZ  The nudists took on the gendarmes at Pamplona Beach near here this weekend and lost. After four antinudist gendarmes in swimming trunks were hooted and booed off the beach by some 300 nudists  men, women and children  last week, the law returned in a speedboat and announced over loudspeakers: Nudists, naturalists, this concerns you.  If the practice of naturalism and nudism is tolerated in certain places on French territory, the penal code formally forbids it in public. This is the last warning.

title: Ted Cruz Accuses Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Lying
description: The Timess Jonathan Weisman reports that Senator Ted Cruz, the sometimes-incendiary Texan running for the Republican presidential nomination, took to the Senate floor Friday to call his partys majority leader a liar in an extraordinary public airing of grievance.

title: Cruz Criticizes McConnell in the Senate
description: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, on Friday accused the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, of repeatedly lying to him and other Republican senators.

title: Evan Wolfson: I Believed We Could Win
description: Evan Wolfson was one of the earliest national proponents of legalizing same-sex marriage, and his group, Freedom to Marry, has helped win cases throughout the country, including in New York in 2011 and in several more states at the ballot box in 2012. I interviewed him after the dust settled following the Supreme Courts decision legalizing same-sex marriage in June.

title: France Clears Final Hurdle to Expand Spying Power
description: PARIS  A law that gives French intelligence services sweeping new spying abilities has cleared a final hurdle after Frances Constitutional Council widely approved the legislation.

title: Fiat Chrysler Issues Recall Over Hacking
description: WASHINGTON  When the call came to officials at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, they knew they had a problem they had never faced but had long feared.

title: When Your Pet Is a Four-Legged Peace Broker
description: I say things to our cat Linda that Im too emotionally constipated to say to my boyfriend: I love you so much. I wish I could take you on the plane with me, Mrs. Scruffins McDandertop. When I get back, we will have many hourlong sessions of adoration and nuzzle-based loving.

title: ESPN Drops Colin Cowherd After Remarks on Dominicans
description: ESPN dropped the radio host Colin Cowherd on Friday, hours after he had clumsily tried to explain comments he made on his show Thursday that seemed to denigrate the intelligence of Dominicans in baseball.

title: Thai Pork Salad
description: Melissa Clark mixes pork tenderloin into a slaw-like cabbage salad.

title: Thai-Inspired Pork Tenderloin Salad
description: Pork tenderloins are the chicken breasts of the porcine world. Lean and quick-cooking, they offer an expanse of mild, uninterrupted flesh without skin, bones or bits of gristle.

title: Review: Kafka on the Shore, a Metaphysical Odyssey Adapted From Murakamis Novel
description: A sudden craving for Kentucky Fried Chicken swept over me at one point during the stage adaptation of the Haruki Murakami novel Kafka on the Shore, being presented through Sunday at the David H. Koch Theater as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. It has been well more than a decade since Ive visited a KFC, but those familiar with Mr. Murakamis playful metaphysical mystery will recall that Colonel Sanders  or rather a spirit taking the form of that corporate icon  is among the strange array of characters in the book.

title: Confederate Memorials as Instruments of Racial Terror
description: The Confederate-flag-waving white supremacist charged with murdering nine African-Americans in a Charleston, S.C., church in June demolished the fiction that the flag was an innocuous symbol of Southern pride. This barbaric act made it impossible for politicians to hide from the fact that the Confederate banner has been a rallying symbol embraced by racists, night riders and white supremacy groups dating back to the 19th century.

title: Times Article on Romes Decay Draws a Surge of New Scrutiny
description: ROME  The subject has filled afternoon television, dominated newspaper headlines, emboldened critics and left many frustrated Romans with the sense that, finally, someone else was noticing.

title: From College Heartbreak to Commitment
description: They crossed the country in a joyous road trip and then quickly separated. Six years later, they realize they belong together.

title: Gabrielle Karol and Benjamin Jacobs: After Years of Breakup Regret, He Wins Back the One
description: Stubble makes an odd accessory on any well-dressed groom. But there was Benjamin Jacobs, debonair in his tuxedo, with enough blond fuzz on his cheeks to look as if he had forgotten to shave.

title: Gap Widening as Top Workers Reap the Raises
description: The same scene plays out in Robert DeMeolas Midtown Manhattan office every few weeks now  not that it ever gets any easier. In walks a director or senior accountant, job offer in hand, threatening to leave for a hedge fund or big bank unless Mr. DeMeola can deliver a raise of 30 percent, sometimes more.

title: Lafayette Police Identify Theater Gunman
description: Jim Craft, the chief of the police department in Lafayette, La., on Friday identified and described the gunman who killed two people, and then himself, in a movie theater on Thursday night.

title: First Draft Archive: Rendezvous at the Border
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate mogul-turned-Republican presidential candidate, traveled to the United States-Mexico border on Thursday, a crowd of gawking reporters in tow, to draw attention to his campaigns focus on immigration. Border visits have become a fixture in modern American politics, from tours by sitting presidents to campaign stops by candidates like Mr. Trump. But they were not always so common. In October 1909, President William Howard Taft became the first sitting U.S. president to visit and then cross the border, when he met with the Mexican president, Porfirio Daz. The trip, which included meetings in El Paso, Tex., and Ciudad Jurez, Mexico, was the first meeting between sitting presidents of the two nations and was only the second international trip by a sitting U.S. president. At some point during their daylong back-and-forth, the two men posed for their formal portrait.

title: On the Death of Sandra Bland and Our Vulnerable Bodies
description: I AM tired of writing about slain black people, particularly when those responsible are police officers, the very people obligated to serve and protect them. I am exhausted. I experience this specific exhaustion with alarming frequency. I am all too aware that I have the luxury of such exhaustion.

title: New Mixed-Income Housing on the Lower East Side
description: For nearly half a century, the view south from the corner of Essex and Delancey Streets has been of vacant parking lots behind chain-link fences, carving a desolate hole in the otherwise vibrant neighborhood. But this month, construction finally began on a $1 billion redevelopment project that will reshape the Lower East Side.

title: Taking Stock of a Hard Drives Files
description: Q. My phones settings tell me how much room my apps, photos and music libraries take up. Is there a similar place on the computer I can look to see how much of my hard drive space is occupied by photos?

title: In Las Vegas, Korean Basketball Leagues Draft Promises Money and Culture Shock
description: LAS VEGAS  Tommy Smith, in his quest to remain employed as a professional basketball player, joined dozens of other free agents in a single-file line this month at Desert Oasis High School, a boxy structure set amid rocks, cactus and molten heat about 10 miles south of this citys shimmering strip of casinos.

title: Go Set a Watchman Shatters the Myths of the White South
description: I grew up in a leafy, upper-middle-class section of Nashville, well stocked with lawyers and businessmen and the occasional Vanderbilt professor. It was lily-white save for a single black doctor, whose residence brought a perverse sense of pride to the moderate white professionals who lived around him  proof, however specious, that we were an integrated community.

title: Rediscovered Pablo Neruda Poems to Be Published
description: Copper Canyon Press will publish a collection of 20 rediscovered poems by the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda.

title: As Chinas Economic Power Increases, Questions Arise
description: HONG KONG  I was waiting for a train in a remote town in southwest China last year when a young man marched up to me and barked out a question: Did I understand and accept that China is a great power?

title: Bill Cunningham | Pop-Out Art
description: In New York City, bursts of color.

title: Burundi President Wins 3rd Term in Election Boycotted by Rivals
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi was declared the winner on Friday of a national election in which nearly every opposition party boycotted the polls.

title: Mets Call Up Michael Conforto and Make a Trade, but Their Bats Stay Dormant
description: Michael Conforto lay on the ground during a weight-training session in Trenton on Fridaymorning, performing hamstring exercises. He was, at that moment, still a minor league player.

title: New Drug Sharply Lowers Cholesterol, but Its Costly
description: Federal regulators on Friday approved the first of a new class of drug that can sharply lower cholesterol levels, offering a new option for millions of Americans suffering from cardiovascular disease, the nations leading killer.

title: When the Cat Comes Back, With Prey
description: Jennifer L. McDonald is an ecologist by profession and a cat person by avocation. Some years ago, Tiggy, her ginger-and-white shorthair, would bring home freshly killed mice and shrews for her consideration.

title: Suddenly Vulnerable Chris Froome Loses Some of His Tour de France Lead
description: LA TOUSSUIRE, France  Just as the Tour de France seemed set for an overall victory by Chris Froome, he suddenly seemed at least a bit vulnerable on Friday.

title: What Makes a Shooter Do It?
description: I RETURNED to my office in Hartford late one afternoon to find a future mass murderer sitting in my chair.

title: A Trip to the Timess Beijing Bureau
description: A time-lapse video gives an accelerated look of a New York Times editors pedicab commute to the new Beijing bureau. Each trip costs 20 yuan, about $3.

title: F.C.C. Approves AT&T-DirecTV Deal
description: Federal regulators have approved AT&Ts $48.5 billion takeover of the satellite company DirecTV, creating a major new force in the communications industry.

title: Nicki Minaj and Meek Mill, Twitters Ethics Police
description: This was a week for rumbles, for striking back at unchallenged wisdom. Sometimes the desire to speak truth to power is so strong it outweighs any backlash that such interjections might cause. Sometimes thats exactly the point.

title: Book Review Podcast: Dr. Seuss What Pet Should I Get?
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Maria Russo reviews Dr. Seuss What Pet Should I Get? Ms. Russo writes:

title: John Sampson, New York State Senator, Is Guilty on Some Federal Charges
description: State Senator John L. Sampson was convicted on Friday of trying to thwart a federal investigation, becoming the latest New York lawmaker to face a prison sentence.

title: Chicago Pension Ruling
description: The ruling by Judge Rita M. Novak of the Cook County Circuit Court on a plan to change city workers pensions.

title: Bail Set for Georgia Man Charged in Manhattan Crash That Killed Bus Driver
description: A state judge set bail on Friday for a Georgia man who prosecutors say rammed a stolen truck into a New York City bus and killed the driver after a night of barhopping, raising the possibility that he might await his murder trial at home rather than at Rikers Island.

title: The Aptly Named Irish Haven Survives in a Changing Brooklyn
description: Blazing summertime glory barely penetrated Irish Havens darkness. The air inside was sudsy  that classic dive-bar tang of decades of beers sloshed around wood paneling and century-old tile floors.

title: Hunger Games Screenwriter Wins Academy Run-Off
description: LOS ANGELES  And the winner is, Billy Ray. Mr. Ray won a run-off election, to join Phil Alden Robinson and Robin Swicord in representing screenwriters on the 51-member governing board of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the organization said on Thursday.

title: I.S.S. Urges Vote Against Merger of PartnerRe and Axis Capital
description: The proposed combination of two reinsurance providers, PartnerRe and Axis Capital Holdings, hit a potentially big stumbling block on Friday, as an influential shareholder advisory firm recommended that investors vote against the deal.

title: Fidelity Seen as Muscling Investors Out of Upside in a Telecom Deal
description: As steward of a $5.2 trillion mutual fund and asset management empire, Fidelity Management and Research promises to treat investors fairly and put their interests first.

title: Junior Seaus Family Will Not Be Allowed to Speak at His Hall of Fame Induction
description: SAN DIEGO  Junior Seaus induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame was always going to be awkward, a chance to celebrate a marquee player known for his bone-crushing career while not dwelling on the injuries that might have precipitated his death.

title: Scaling Back
description: Articles in this series will examine Americans changing eating habits.

title: The Regulatory Hurdles to Health Insurance Mergers
description: Anthem and Cigna are the latest big American health insurers to propose a blockbuster merger. They and their peers need to satisfy many regulators, though, before the deals are approved. Heres a look at the agencies and the deals that officials may be asked to swallow in an already concentrated industry.

title: Review: In The Art of Abhinaya, Bragha Bessell Dances With Masterly Range
description: In many classical Indian dance traditions, the dancer is also an actor. A dance can be a kind of dramatic monologue in which the dancer presents a character, or several, and wordlessly tells a story, both narrating and re-enacting a poem. This kind of acting is called abhinaya, and it was the focus of a performance on Wednesday at the theater of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis High School in Manhattan. Titled The Art of Abhinaya, this was the first solo recital in New York of the Bharatanatyam dancer Bragha Bessell, who revealed herself to be a master of the art.

title: Clinton Responds to Email Accusations
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton responded to new accusations involving the private email account she used when she was secretary of state.

title: Ted Cruz Breaks Vow to Not Criticize Other Republicans
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has made taking the high road a hallmark of his presidential campaign so far, vowing not to get into fights with other Republicans. Apparently Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky is not covered by that policy.

title: Limit on Damages Is Squeezing Victims of Amtrak Wreck
description: Kathryn Varnum had just settled into her seat on the evening Amtrak train from Washington to New York after sending her parents an email. Her husband, Declan MacFarland, seated next to her, handed her an earbud. The couple, who were moving to a new apartment in Brooklyn that day, leaned back and listened to Madonnas Lucky Star.

title: Thailand Charges 72 With Human Trafficking Crimes Ahead of U.S. Report
description: BANGKOK  Prosecutors in Thailand indicted 72 people on Friday, accusing them of involvement in a multinational human trafficking syndicate. The indictments were filed three days before the expected release of an annual State Department report on human trafficking in countries around the world, including Thailand.

title: Review: Eric Comstock and Barbara Fasano Croon at the Metropolitan Room
description: The poet laureates of the early Mad Men era. That apt description of the songwriting team Cy Coleman and Carolyn Leigh was one of many witty observational nuggets tossed out in Eric Comstock and Barbara Fasanos playful show, Shoulder Season, on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The Coleman-Leigh standard When in Rome (I Do as the Romans Do), a mildly risqu celebration of marital infidelity while traveling, served as the prime example of how their songwriting pushed the boundaries of taste back in the late 1950s and early 60s.

title: Inside the New York Times Polling Operation
description: When I told friends and colleagues earlier this year that I would be taking over polling for The Times, the usual reaction was blinking disbelief. Did you say Poland? they asked. Bowling?

title: Pictures of the Day  Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Turkey and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Uber Makes Its Pain New Yorkers Problem
description: In the immediate aftermath of the stock market crash in 1929, amid the suicides, collapsed fortunes and other pervasive miseries, the number of men looking for jobs in New York expanded the ranks of the citys cabdrivers to 30,000. Chaos reigned. There were too many drivers going after too few passengers  fares were slashed, tensions between fleets escalated, violence erupted. Some drivers working 20-hour days could not make enough money to support themselves. As a result, in 1937, the city devised the medallion system to limit the number of vehicle licenses. In the late 1930s, there were just under 12,000 medallions in circulation; more than 75 years later, in a city larger by one million people and benefiting from far greater prosperity, there are only 13,000.

title: When She Says, She Says Goes Viral: A Toddlers Cries in a Diner are Heard Across the Internet
description: When did the recent encounter between two parents with a fussy toddler and a Maine diner owner with a fiery temper get out of control?

title: Review: Delusion of the Fury, With New Partch Instruments
description: The Lincoln Center Festival typically packs all manner of theater, music and dance offerings into a month. Its director, Nigel Redden, has acknowledged the difficulty of figuring out how many performances of each work to present. The festival probably overscheduled the entertaining opening event, Danny Elfmans Music From the Films of Tim Burton, which drew big audiences at the start but sold inconsistently through the eight-performance run.

title: Hulk Hogan Apologizes for Racial Slur, After Losing W.W.E. Contract
description: World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. terminated the contract of Terry Bollea, better known as Hulk Hogan, on Friday, after it was reported that he used a racial slur on videotape.

title: Country Singer Natalie Prasss Festival Style
description: Natalie Prass, a country singer from Richmond, Va., discussed her on-stage style necessities after performing at last weekends Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago.

title: Municipal Bonds Still Considered Safe, Despite Some Ailing Governments
description: Puerto Rico is drowning in $72 billion of debt it admittedly cannot pay back. Several states  Illinois, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Kentucky among them  are facing mounting financial problems of their own, mainly because of pension promises that are not properly funded.

title: Review: Gauthier Dance Reimagines Ballet in 101 Positions
description: BECKET, Mass.  Every so often, the talent scout for Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival, Ella Baff (the festivals artistic and executive director), plucks a company from overseas and brings it to an American audience for the first time. These debuts are a Pillow hallmark, and the latest comes from Gauthier Dance//Dance Company Theaterhaus Stuttgart, from Germany, led by the former Stuttgart Ballet soloist Eric Gauthier.

title: Rick and Morty Returns to Destabilize the Universe
description: Forget The Big Bang Theory. The best physics lesson on television, at least this Sunday night, comes courtesy of Rick and Morty. That brilliantly deranged animated show returns for a second season Sunday on Adult Swim, picking up where it left off: with time stopped.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Arts of Living
description: Three summer parties in New York City, including a conversation about the China exhibit and a delightful conversation with Nicole Kidman.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: 10 Prominent Britons Back the Iran Nuclear Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton Emails Said to Contain Classified Data
