description: WASHINGTON  Government investigators said Friday that they had discovered classified information on the private email account that Hillary Rodham Clinton used while secretary of state, stating unequivocally that those secrets never should have been stored outside of secure government computer systems.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Squares Filing Turns Talk to Dorseys Juggling Skills
description: Maybe Jack Dorsey needs to clone himself.

title: Super Pac Backing Rand Paul Raised Far Less Than Rivals, Report Shows
description: A super PAC set up by allies of Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky raised just over $3 million in the first six months of the year, according to a report filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday  far less than most of the outside groups backing Mr. Pauls rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Cooperstowns Steadiest Hand Isnt a Hall of Famers
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  When Jim Palmer and his wife, Susan, married in 2007, they chose to have the ceremony here, where he was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame. But the maid of honor was not a relative or friend of the brides. Instead, it was Jane Forbes Clark, chairwoman of the Hall of Fame, who staged a celebration at the lodge behind Kingfisher Tower, a miniature castle built on Otsego Lake in the 19th century by Edward Clark, her great-great-grandfather.

title: Political Pictures of the Week
description: Republican White House hopefuls campaign in Iowa and Texas, and the president visits Kenya amid schools, and backpacks, with his name on them.

title: Popes Visit to East Harlem School Highlights Churchs Challenges
description: On a recent Sunday, on park benches amid public housing projects in East Harlem, more than a dozen people sang hymns and joined hands to pray.

title: Bill Cunningham | Pop-Out Art
description: While most New Yorkers adhere to summer black or white clothing, you may see colors like those of macaw parrots, orange and pink, or the dragonfly in the Rockefeller Center Channel Gardens. Hairstyles, many flowing with color, and balloon sculptures also catch the eye.

title: The Arts of Living
description: Vibrant scenes around every corner of the city. Here are some examples: On July 19, The Rubin Museum of Art, which is dedicated to art and culture from art the Himalayas, India, Tibet and neighboring regions, held a street fair on 17th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, free of any commercial touches. It featured tables for children to make crafts, and also a stage for musicians and performers. On July 20: A conversation in front of the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art about the China exhibit as well as a delightful conversation with Nicole Kidman about the costumes she wore in her films and how they helped her make the transformation into the characters she played. And on July 16, the Museum of Modern Art held a reception on the Cullman library terrace, with its spectacular view over the musuems sculpture gardens.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: Egyptians Turn to Facebook to Highlight Decrepit Public Facilities
description: CAIRO  When the prime minister of Egypt visited two Cairo hospitals last month, he said he was shocked by the disorder and decay he encountered. No one else was.

title: July 24, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Turkey, Kenya, China and Italy.

title: Autopsy of Sandra Bland
description: A county prosecutor concluded that Ms. Bland, who died in a jail cell in Waller County, Tex., on July 13, had injuries that were consistent with suicide, not homicide.

title: Sandra Blands Autopsy Details How She Died
description: An autopsy submitted a day after Sandra Bland was found dead in a Texas jail cell on July 13 ruled her death a suicide. The report, released to the public on Friday, disclosed in detail how she died.

title: French Lawmakers Visit Crimea, to the Dismay of Officials Back Home
description: MOSCOW  A group of French lawmakers visited Crimea this week, the first trip by a European delegation since Russia annexed the peninsula last year. They bought T-shirts, snapped photographs and were serenaded by a Russian pop singer.

title: Mondays Travel News: Carnival in China; New Zealand Bike Race
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: NASA Unveils New Pluto Photographs
description: NASA released more photos taken by the New Horizons spacecraft on its flyby of Pluto, showing the dwarf planet in color and at a higher resolution.

title: How Natalie Collette Wood, Program Director of the Bronx Childrens Museum, Spends Her Sundays
description: Even after the new Bronx Childrens Museum opens on the Harlem River in 2017, Natalie Collette Wood, 33, the program director, will continue to share her peripatetic exhibits and mural-making aboard the organizations traveling bus. This is the way we think a 21st-century museum should run, she said. The Bronx is extremely hard to get across from east to west. We are out in the community building relationships. Sunday, then, is prime time to take the museum on the road. But Ms. Wood also schedules time for her own artwork and to relax with her boyfriend, Victor Vildsola, 37, a musician, with whom she lives in the Morrisania section of the borough, along with a new puppy, a Chihuahua mix named Oliver.

title: Indian Energy Institute Replaces Director Accused of Sexual Harassment
description: NEW DELHI  The governing council of a leading energy institute in India is replacing its director general, the former head of a United Nations panel on climate change, who is facing allegations of sexual harassment from an employee.

title: Not Lonely at the Top
description: FOLK wisdom tells us its lonely at the top. This makes intuitive sense: To occupy the sole position atop a hierarchy, to have the sole authority for tough decisions nobody else wants to (or can) make, and to bear the sole responsibility for the consequences of those decisions is, almost by definition, to be alone. Power implies isolation.

title: Daily Show Writer Recalls Heated Dispute With Jon Stewart
description: A former correspondent and writer for Comedy Centrals The Daily Show has disclosed that he and its host, Jon Stewart, engaged in a heated argument about a segment perceived as racially insensitive. In his recounting, the correspondent, Wyatt Cenac, who is black, said Mr. Stewart became defensive and frequently shouted expletives.

title: Chicory Is the Cheshire Cat of Herbs
description: Chicorys flowers are as blue as the summer sky, their casual, untrained beauty heightened by the meager settings in which they grow. One of the best ways to see chicory in New York City is to simply take a drive. The plant seems happiest growing from road medians, cracks in curbs and mangy, un-mowed fields. It grows alongside other beautiful but outcast plants like Queen Annes lace, dandelion and soapwort, and it takes only a wet week or two in July to produce a burst of color that can challenge autumns leaves.

title: Podcasts Stretch Wings Beyond Audio and Go Live, in Festivals
description: Its not quite Lollapalooza  yet  but podcasts are getting the festival treatment.

title: Bookshelf: Gilded-Age Version of Monopoly in New York
description: Xbox, PlayStation and the iPhone may have relegated many board games to the closet at the lake house, but a three-dimensional diversion that officially debuts this week may delight retro New Yorkers.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: The AT&T-DirecTV Merger and the Problem With the Telecoms Industry
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved AT&Ts $48.5 billion acquisition of DirecTV on Friday. And, as expected, the commission imposed conditions on the company that should help telecommunications users in many parts of the country.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on todays top stories.

title: N.F.L. Hires Chief Operating Officer
description: The N.F.L. has hired Tod Leiweke as its new chief operating officer, a position that has been vacant since Commissioner Roger Goodell was promoted to the leagues top spot.

title: Obama Arrives in Kenya, on Personal and Official Journey
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Obama arrived on Friday in Kenya, his fathers home country, for the start of a four-day swing through East Africa, combining a personal journey with a geopolitical mission that reinforces a shared campaign against Islamist extremism while wrestling with tough messages about democracy and gay rights.

title: Transgender Today
description: A series about transgender experiences and the challenges ahead.

title: Small Businesses Await House Action on Frozen Loan Program
description: Demand for government-backed small-business loans is at a record high, but the momentum came to an abrupt halt last week when the agency that guarantees those loans reached its limit for the year and suspended its program.

title: Life Among the Sea Slaves
description: For an investigative project on the violent and unregulated world of fishing in international waters, Adam Dean Ocean managed to document life aboard one such vessel.

title: The Mayor of Ninth Street Offers Incense and Sensibility
description: Nearly every afternoon, year round, Billy Lyles, 73, sets his spiritual table in front of Katinka, a sliver of a shop in the East Village that carries Indian clothes and accessories.

title: The Effects of Obamas Presidency in Africa: Readers Opinions
description: Ahead of President Obamas trip this week to Kenya and Ethiopia, we asked readers in Africa or from there to share their views of his presidency. Readers discussed their expectations for Mr. Obama when he was first elected in 2008, and whether they thought he had helped or failed Africa during his presidency. Some readers also shared their thoughts on what issues Mr. Obama should focus on for the remainder of his term.

title: Citi Bike to Begin Service in Queens and Expand in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Citi Bike, the popular bike-share program in New York City, will be introduced in Queens this summer and expanded in Brooklyn as the service moves to double its size over the next two years.

title: Two Good Reasons to Visit St. George: The National Lighthouse Museum and Sri Lankan Food
description: The romance and isolation of lighthouses, their life-or-death role for tempest-tossed sailors, is illuminated in St. George, Staten Island, just south of the ferry terminal. THE NATIONAL LIGHTHOUSE MUSEUM, in the works since 1998, had a ceremonial unveiling last year and is now open, although its official debut is Aug. 7, the anniversary of a 1789 Congressional act to commission lighthouses, beacons, buoys and public piers. The Founding Fathers did not take action solely for humanitarian purposes.

title: Hillary Clinton Eyes Corporations in Proposals for Economy
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton made a case on Friday for weaning Wall Street from an addiction to profits, calling for a change to capital gains taxes for the highest earners and a string of measures to adjust the balance of power between corporate titans and their employees.

title: Uber Deal Strains Ties for de Blasio and Mark-Viverito
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Melissa Mark-Viverito, the City Council speaker, were the closest of allies, a pair of ideological fellow travelers suddenly installed in two of New Yorks most powerful jobs. Mr. de Blasio lobbied hard for Ms. Mark-Viveritos election as speaker and was widely credited with propelling her to victory.

title: Water Recedes and Anxiety Rises After Hole Opens Near Upstate New York Dam
description: DEPOSIT, N.Y.  It has been a half-century since the waters first rose at Cannonsville Reservoir, engulfing several towns, swaths of farmland and untold family memories under billions of gallons of water, all to slake New York Citys unrelenting thirst.

title: Yasuo Minagawa, a Master Framer for Exacting Artists, Dies at 69
description: Yasuo Minagawa, a framer known for working closely with several generations of exacting New York artists while always pursuing the ideal of a perfect frame, died on July 4 in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Haggling Over a Deadline for Railroad Safety Measures
description: On Thursday, several Democratic senators expressed their objections to a provision, buried deep in a proposed highway funding measure, that would delay for three years the requirement that railroads install safety features that might have prevented Mays terrible Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia.

title: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso Does Tiny Desk
description: By rights, Nick Sanborn and Amelia Meaths venture shouldnt work  it should put its perpetrators in the Hipster Overdose ward at Mount Sinai, for the shoes if nothing else. And it really, really shouldnt appeal to someone like me, sixtysomething wannabe hipster or not.

title: Fighting the Tide of D.W.I. Crashes on Long Island
description: It is a superlative that Suffolk County officials are not bragging about: Every year since at least 2001 the county has recorded more crashes involving alcohol than any other county in New York. Also: More people have died in alcohol-related crashes in Suffolk during that time than anywhere else in the state.

title: Military Cutbacks Make Sense
description: The Armys plan to cut 40,000 troops, as well as 17,000 civilian employees, over the next two years is unsettling many American communities. Congressmen and senators in the affected districts are railing against the reductions and insisting they will fight to reverse them. But the cutbacks are a sensible and necessary move, and they should not come as a surprise since it was Congress that approved big cuts in federal defense spending.

title: U.S. Says Parole of Jonathan Pollard, Spy for Israel, Will Follow Law
description: WASHINGTON  United States officials said on Friday that they would not object to the scheduled parole of Jonathan J. Pollard, an American convicted of spying for Israel, who is eligible to be released in November after serving 30 years.

title: Donald Trumps Wealth and Poll Numbers Complicate News Medias Coverage
description: Since June 16, when Donald J. Trump announced his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, his name has appeared in headlines of major newspapers an average of 22 times a day, according to the database Nexis, nearly three times as often as Jeb Bush, one of the perceived favorites.

title: Next Thing Mets Hit May Be a New Low
description: Sometime during the fifth inning of a game on a soft summer evening at Citi Field, our gaze strayed from our beers and sausages to the radiant green field and then to the scoreboard.

title: Sally Gross, Choreographer of Minimalist Dances, Dies at 81
description: Sally Gross, a leading avant-garde dancer and choreographer whose minimalist works helped propel the postmodern dance movement, died on Monday in Sag Harbor, N.Y. She was 81.

title: Why Greece Should Leave the Eurozone
description: MUNICH  THERE are not many issues on which I agree with my colleagues Paul Krugman and Joseph E. Stiglitz and the former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis. But one of them is the view that an exit from the eurozone would be advisable for Greece.

title: U.S. Fears Data Stolen by Chinese Hacker Could Identify Spies
description: WASHINGTON  American officials are concerned that the Chinese government could use the stolen records of millions of federal workers and contractors to piece together the identities of intelligence officers secretly posted in China over the years.

title: A De Dva Lexiconska
description: Mooska: Cow

title: George Coe, Actor and Director of a Bergman Parody, Dies at 86
description: George Coe, a film, stage and television actor who earned an Oscar nomination for his single picture as a director  the 1968 short feature De Dva: The Dove, a mock-Swedish-inflected sendup of Ingmar Bergman that has endured as a cult favorite  died on July 18 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86.

title: Gold Cup Match Fixed, Panama Official Says
description: CHESTER, Pa.  The disorderly Gold Cup regional soccer tournament grew even more chaotic on Friday as the head of Panamas soccer federation said the countrys controversial semifinal defeat by Mexico had been fixed.

title: Allergan, in Shift From Buying Spree, Considers a Spin-Off
description: Last fall, Actavis completed its biggest acquisition by buying the maker of Botox, Allergan. Now, the pharmaceutical manufacturer is weighing a potential breakup of itself.

title: New Jersey Legislators Propose Law to Protect Nail Salon Workers
description: State lawmakers in New Jersey proposed legislation on Friday intended to protect nail salon workers from unhealthy working conditions and abusive labor practices. The move followed calls for reform in the industry, and the imposition of stricter rules in New York.

title: Kerry Says Israel May Deepen Its Isolation by Opposing Iran Nuclear Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday that the nuclear accord he negotiated with Iran was in Israels interest and that the Israeli governments decision to oppose it could further its isolation.

title: Ingrid Sischy, Doyenne of Art and Fashion, Dies at 63
description: Ingrid Sischy, a writer, editor and cultural critic known for her long, authoritative associations with Interview magazine, The New Yorker and Vanity Fair, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 63.

title: Presidential Candidates Denounce Violence, but Avoid Talk of Policy
description: The morning after the third deadly mass shooting in six weeks, the presidential candidates acted as though they had not seen the news.

title: Elena Delle Donne Emerges as Face of the W.N.B.A.
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  After Elena Delle Donne was selected No. 2 in the 2013 W.N.B.A. draft, people wondered if she would fulfill the lofty expectations that accompanied such a distinction and become a transcendent player for a league continually fighting for recognition in American sports.

title: Ukraine: U.S. Expands Aid to Train Regular Army Troops
description: The United States Army will modestly expand nonlethal military assistance to Ukraine, beginning training this fall for Ukrainian Army personnel in the western part of the country, the Obama administration announced Friday. This training is part of our long-running defense cooperation with Ukraine, and is taking place at the invitation of the Ukraine government, Mark Toner, a spokesman for the State Department, told reporters. In April, about 300 American troops arrived in Ukraine to train Ukrainian national guard troops, who fall under the Interior Ministry. As that mission winds down, the new trainers will arrive to work with Defense Ministry troops near Ukraines border with Poland. The additional training brings the amount of American military assistance to Ukraine to $244 million, Mr. Toner said.

title: Experience Catharsis
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Lets shift the conversation from solving to constructing today. Most of you arent constructors, but the insight might be interesting. Sometimes knowing how the sausage gets made can really turn you off sausage, and if thats you, please feel free to skip to the video. But sometimes, it can really give you a hankering for more sausage. You might even decide that it would be fun to make your own.

title: Bad Commute? Tell Gov. Christie
description: Thousands of hot and angry commuters were stranded for hours on several days this week as they tried to take New Jersey Transit trains between New York and New Jersey. For these understandably irritated people, we have a suggestion: Blame Gov. Chris Christie.

title: Defense Dept. Asks Armed Civilians to Stop Guarding Recruiters
description: The Defense Department on Friday asked armed civilians who have volunteered to guard military recruiting stations across the country in the wake of the mass shooting in Chattanooga, Tenn., to leave their posts.

title: Ending Housing Segregation
description: To the Editor:

title: Christie and the Rail Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: Lost in Lafayette Gunfire, Two With Bright Futures
description: LAFAYETTE, La.  It seems that everybody in Lafayette knows, or knew, someone who was in that theater.

title: Electricity for Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Coal Miners Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Awe at Grand Central Terminal
description: To the Editor:

title: Chris Christie Claims He Will Pursue the Trans-Hudson Tunnel Project as President
description: Several days of severe delays for rail commuters trying to cross the Hudson River this week has been a painful reminder of the deteriorating state of the tunnels that carry the trains and brought renewed attention to a decision made years ago to halt a project that might have helped improve the situation.

title: Alligator Found Crossing a Street in Manhattan Dies
description: A three-foot-long alligator that attained fleeting fame on Thursday night after the police posted a picture of it on Twitter crossing a busy Manhattan street during the evening rush died unexpectedly on Friday, according to a spokeswoman for the Animal Care Centers of NYC.

title: The F.D.A., Medical Technology and the Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: The Harper Lee Go Set a Watchman Fraud
description: Called away on family business, I was afraid Id missed the sweet spot for commentary on the Harper Lee/To Kill a Mockingbird/Go Set a Watchman controversy  that moment right after Watchmans release on July 14 when it was all anybody in literary circles could talk about.

title: Questions Still Swirling Around the Death of Sandra Bland
description: Critics on social media are questioning what happened after the arrest and highlighting inconsistencies on reports released by the Sheriffs Office in Waller County, Tex., where she died.

title: Plutos Atmosphere Is Thinner Than Expected, but Still Looks Hazy
description: Plutos thin air may be falling to the ground.

title: Taking the Slow Boat (and Train) From London to Paris
description: For travelers weary of the oft-crowded Eurostar, the high-speed train from Londons St. Pancras station to Pariss Gare du Nord, there is a breezier and greener route. It consists of two trains and a ferry, a bit of British and French culture, and tasty stops along the way.

title: A Chance for a Contract in Korea From a Casino in Vegas
description: The Korean Basketball League relocates to Las Vegas every July for an invitation-only tryout followed by an import draft for international players.

title: An Opponents Roomy Ballpark Again Cramps the Yankees Style
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Most baseball teams are put together the way a homebuilder constructs a house, making sure that the features fit with the inhabitants.

title: Navigating Bumps and Avoiding Bruises
description: Chris Froomes success on three tricky stages has put him in position to win the Tour de France.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Oxygen) PRIDE & PREJUDICE (2005) Keira Knightley, in an Oscar-nominated role, stars as Elizabeth Bennet in Joe Wrights adaptation of the Jane Austen novel about five sisters whose mother (Brenda Blethyn) is desperate to marry them off to men of means. Rosamund Pike is Jane, Elizabeths older sister and the belle of the ball. But because Ms. Knightley is, in a word, a knockout, the balance has shifted, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Her radiance so suffuses the film that its foolish to imagine Elizabeth would be anyones second choice. Once viewers accept this, the movie gathers you up on its white horse and gallops off into the sunset, he added. In its final minutes it makes you believe in true love, the union of soul mates, happily ever after and all the other stuff a romantic comedy promises but so seldom delivers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He was by himself, he sat by himself, and the first two people he shot were right in front of him.

title: Corrections: July 25, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Turkey Attacks Kurdish Militant Camps in Northern Iraq
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish fighter jets, which on Friday attacked Islamic State targets in Syria, have launched a wave of airstrikes in northern Iraq, targeting camps of the militant Kurdistan Workers Party for the first time in four years, the prime ministers office said Saturday.

title: Passing on Wedding Gifts, Millennials Prefer Cash
description: When it comes to registering for gifts, a generational sea change has developed, with more and more millennial couples asking their guests to consider holding the gravy ladles and shelving the dishes in favor of gifts of a very different sort.

title: In Pakistan, Detainees Are Vanishing in Covert Jails
description: KOHAT, Pakistan  Niaz Bibis son disappeared into the night, whisked away by Pakistani soldiers who accused him of being aTalibanfighter. For 18 anguishing months, she could find no word of his fate. Then she got a phone call.

title: Obama in Kenya: An Upbeat Tone, but Notes of Discord, Too
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The return of the long-lost son, as President Obama is widely seen by Kenyans, had all the elements of a family reunion. They hugged, they caught up, they talked about shared interests, they agreed they should get together more often, and they had their sibling spats.

title: Muffled in the Hamptons, Uber Makes Some Noise
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  It was just past 1 on a Saturday night, and the scene outside the Memory Motel had an air of frenzied desperation. Hedge fund types and N.Y.U. students stumbled out of bars in their white jeans and Tods loafers as barely legal women in crop tops, jean shorts and Gisele sandals flagged down taxi drivers.

title: How Sorry Saved the Family Business
description: The mood was uncharacteristically somber in the conference room of Hincapie Sportswear as George Hincapie prepared to speak at an all-company meeting on Oct. 9, 2012.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from the U.S. Embassy in Havana to the 29th floor of 10 Hudson Yards in Manhattan.

title: Hilary Liftin Ghostwrote a Book for Miley Cyrus and Others. Now Its Her Time.
description: Los Angeles  Even with Instagram and Twitter buttons at their fingertips, many celebrities are still choosing to write a good old-fashioned memoir. Its the write part that can prove troublesome, and thats where people like Hilary Liftin come in.

title: Susan Cain Instigates a Quiet Revolution of Introverts
description: Last month, 50 executives from General Electric gathered on the fourth floor of a SoHo office building for a fireside chat with Susan Cain, the author of the 2012 book Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Cant Stop Talking, which has sold two million copies worldwide.

title: Namibia by Bike and Train
description: A safari from BikeTours.com will offer travelers an opportunity to see Namibias wildlife from two perches: the saddle of a bicycle and a chartered train.

title: The Old Man and the CPI
description: I dont watch financial news, but CNBC was on in the gym, so I was treated to a long ad from Ron Paul, who wants you to buy his video explaining the coming crisis brought on by loose money. And I found myself thinking about the remarkable fact that there really are people who will buy that video.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Review: Can Cities Beat Uber?
description: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Times technology reporters Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac will review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe even a few jokes about the most important developments in the industry. Subscribe to the Bits daily newsletter

title: Uber and the New Liberal Consensus
description: You might not have thought that a taxi service would move onto center stage in our great political debates. But Uber actually is looking like a surprisingly important political issue. Why?

title: Judge Orders Release of Immigrant Children Detained by U.S.
description: A federal judge in California has ruled that the Obama administrations detention of children and their mothers who were caught crossing the border illegally is a serious violation of a longstanding court settlement, and that the families should be released as quickly as possible.

title: The Outlaw Ocean
description: In this series on lawlessness on the high seas, Ian Urbina reveals that crime and violence in international waters often goes unpunished.

title: Evicting a Family of Urban Raccoons
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Australia Arrests Nurse Who Says He Worked With ISIS Under Duress
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A 39-year-old nurse from Melbourne who said he was forced to work with the Islamic State militant group in Syria was arrested upon returning to Australia, the authorities said Saturday.

title: Ruling on Immigrant Children in Detention
description: In a withering critique, a federal court judge in California ruled that the U.S. detention of children and their mothers who crossed the border illegally is a serious violation of a longstanding court settlement.

title: At Sandra Bland Funeral, Mourning a Life Cut Short in Texas
description: LISLE, Ill.  Hundreds of mourners gathered Saturday at the suburban Chicago church that Sandra Bland attended for many of her 28 years, turning out in such numbers that even the overflow viewing room ran out of chairs. From the pulpit, relatives and friends recounted happy memories of Ms. Blands faith and social activism, and restated their belief that her death in a Texas jail was no suicide.

title: President Obama Welcomed in Kenya
description: Mr. Obama hailed the economic development that has transformed Kenya and other parts of Africa over the last decade.

title: Stung in 2008, Hillary Clinton Builds a Formidable Team in Iowa
description: NEWTON, Iowa  Two or three days a week, for up to five hours, Liz Mueller plants herself in a coffee shop called Uncle Nancys.

title: Highlights From Obamas News Conference
description: Barack Obama spoke in Kenya on his first presidential visit to the land of his father.

title: Chris Froome Set to Win Tour de France After Penultimate Stage
description: LALPE DHUEZ, France  In the end, victory came with a slightly more desperate than triumphant tone. But Chris Froome, 30, the British leader of Team Sky, effectively won his second Tour de France on Saturday. All that remains is for him to safely make his way through the largely ceremonial final stage in Paris.

title: United States Gold Cup Performance Culminates With a Whimper
description: CHESTER, Pa.  The United States national soccer team did not want to be here Saturday afternoon, playing a Gold Cup consolation match in a small soccer arena instead of the championship game at a large football stadium.

title: Fiat Chrysler to RecallPickup Trucks With Problematic Airbags
description: At the insistence of federal regulators, Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 843,000 pickup trucks because slamming the door too hard could set off the airbag meant to provide head protection in a side-impact crash, according to a report by the automaker posted Saturday on the regulators website.

title: Variety: A Crunchy Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Todays acrostic is about the first food I learned to prepare for myself. But what I found really fascinating about the quote is what I discovered upon researching the author himself.

title: Aides for Hillary Clinton and Benghazi Committee Dispute Testimony Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Amid renewed controversy surrounding Hillary Rodham Clintons use of private email for government work, a dispute erupted on Saturday over when and how she would publicly testify before the House select committee investigating the 2012 terrorist attacks on the American diplomatic outpost in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Pearson in Talks to Sell Its Stake in the Economist Group
description: Pearson, the British education company, said on Saturday that it was in discussions to sell its 50 percent stake in the Economist Group, the publisher of The Economist.

title: The Rise of Climbing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  IN the summer of 1989, when I was 21 years old, my father and I went rock climbing with a family friend named Peter Mayfield, a professional mountain guide. As we walked through lush meadows and then waded barefoot in the cold Tuolumne River, Peter talked about raising investment capital for an indoor climbing gym.

title: For Ransom, Bitcoin Replaces the Bag of Bills
description: In the old days, criminals liked their ransom payments in briefcases full of unmarked bills.

title: Cuomos Plan to Close M.T.A. Funding Gap Revives Familiar Debate
description: For decades, it has been New Yorks great underground contradiction: The sprawling transit system  the municipal feature perhaps most likely to spawn complaints from city residents about their government  is operated by the state.

title: Bryant Parks Fence Is Removed for Repairs. In Its Place, a Bench.
description: Verdant lungs of Midtown Manhattan. Backyard of the New York Public Library.

title: Mets New Additions Settle In, and Offense Breaks Out
description: Juan Uribe greeted new teammates, laughed with old friends and hugged the former shortstop Nomar Garciaparra, a broadcaster. Uribe lounged comfortably in a chair in the Mets clubhouse and joked in Spanish with Ruben Tejada. He wore a bright red glove and a smile.

title: Spys Release Is Unlikely to Assuage Israel on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: JERUSALEM  The two issues with perhaps the broadest consensus and resonance in Israeli politics are opposition to the Iran nuclear deal and support for the release of Jonathan J. Pollard, the convicted Israeli spy, from a North Carolina prison. Now the two could be tied together, as some in Washington appear to be highlighting Mr. Pollards likely parole in November in hopes of quieting the vigorous campaign by Israel and some of its American supporters against congressional approval of the deal.

title: A Terrorism Case in Britain Ends in Acquittal, but No One Can Say Why
description: LONDON  Ian Cobain, a reporter with The Guardian, is one of very few people who know why a student arrested by armed British police officers in 2013 was finally acquitted this year of terrorism charges.

title: United States Gets Favorable Draw in World Cup Qualifying
description: The first step toward the 2018 World Cup in Russia appears to be a relatively simple one for the United States mens national team.

title: Sandra Bland Death May Lead to Disciplinary Action, Sheriff Says
description: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.  The Texas sheriff whose policies have come under intense criticism in the aftermath of the jail-cell hanging death of Sandra Bland says he is seriously considering disciplinary action against jail staff members for not fulfilling state requirements for mental health training.

title: Obama Administration Targets Trade in African Elephant Ivory
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Obama will forgo the usual tourist safari during his visit here, but his administration on Saturday announced new legal changes intended to help protect endangered wildlife in African nations.

title: Chloe Malle and Graham Albert: Yet Another Fine Romance
description: Chloe Franoise Malle, the daughter of Candice Bergen of New York and the late Louis Malle, the French film director, was married Saturday to Graham McGrath Albert, the son of Gail McGrath Albert and Alan F. Albert of Williamsburg, Va. Mayor Gyl Crayssac of Lugagnac, France, officiated in the town hall there.

title: U.S. Markets Are an Oasis for Buy-and-Hold Investors
description: There has been no shortage of market-moving business and economic news this year. But for the overall American stock market, none of it has really seemed to matter.

title: A Millennial Named Bush
description: THE time-honored way to speak of young people is with horror. Theyre wild, reckless, irresponsible, narcissistic, immoral and hopeless  and always have been.

title: Guns and Mental Illness
description: A selection of articles from New York Times series about weapons and mental health.

title: The Pursuit of Nick Saban: Alabama vs. Texas
description: In December 2012, as Nick Saban was preparing Alabama to face Notre Dame in college footballs national championship game, a University of Texas regent named Wallace Hall received a phone call from a friend.

title: Saudi Forces Agree to Halt in Yemen War
description: SANA, Yemen  Saudi Arabia said Saturday that it would halt its military offensive in Yemen for five days to allow the distribution of humanitarian relief supplies, according to a statement carried by the official Saudi news agency.

title: When Youre Writing a Resignation Letter, Less Is More
An Act That Enabled Acceptance
Helping Patients and Doctors Talk About Death
description: Medicare announced plans this month to reimburse doctors for talking with patients about what treatments they want  and dont want  toward the end of life. This sensible, long-overdue proposal is likely to have a very wide impact. About 80 percent of people who die in the United States each year are covered by Medicare, and Medicare policies are often followed by private insurers, some of which already pay for these advance-planning conversations.

title: How the Euro Turned Into a Trap
description: When they introduced the euro in 1999, European leaders said the common currency would be irreversible and would lead to greater economic and political integration among their countries. That pledge of permanence, long doubted by euro-skeptics, seems ever less credible.

title: Looking Away From Abortion
description: IN an essay in his 1976 collection, Mortal Lessons, the physician Richard Selzer describes a strange suburban scene. People go outside in the morning in his neighborhood, after the garbage trucks have passed, and find a foreignness upon the pavement, a softness underfoot.

title: Greece, the Sacrificial Lamb
description: ATHENS  AS the Greek crisis proceeds to its next stage, Germany, Greece and the triumvirate of the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank and the European Commission (now better known as the troika) have all faced serious criticism. While there is plenty of blame to share, we shouldnt lose sight of what is really going on. Ive been watching this Greek tragedy closely for five years, engaged with those on all sides. Having spent the last week in Athens talking to ordinary citizens, young and old, as well as current and past officials, Ive come to the view that this is about far more than just Greece and the euro.

title: Higher Wages, Great! But How to Enforce?
description: LOS ANGELES  THERES a certain euphoria among minimum-wage workers these days, as local and state governments across the country, most recently in New York, approve plans to substantially raise their pay.

title: The I.R.S. Gives Up on Dark Money
description: The federal government has all but surrendered to the powerful, rich donors whose anonymous contributions threaten to undermine the 2016 elections. The commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John Koskinen, signaled as much on Thursday when he told a House committee that there would be no change in the tax code in 2016 to end its growing abuse by political operatives using nonprofit social welfare institutions to disguise the identities of affluent campaign contributors.

title: We Need Optimists
description: MY wife, Ester, and I had just endured a difficult parent-teacher conference for one of our teenage children. It was a grades issue. The ride home was tense, until Ester broke the silence. Think of it this way, she said. At least we know hes not cheating.

title: Courtney Young
description: Courtney Young, immediate past president and a board member of the American Library Association, travels widely lecturing on the field of library science, which is gaining importance in an era of vast online data. Her day job is head librarian and professor of womens studies at Pennsylvania State University, Greater Allegheny campus, near Pittsburgh.

title: Stephanie Pinto: Investing in Personal Growth
description: Stephanie Pinto, 23, is a fund administrator at the State Street Corporation in Boston.

title: The Millions of Marginalized Americans
description: NOT long ago I had separate chats with two political insiders who offered to fill me in on Jeb Bushs strategy, if he prevails in the primaries, for winning the general election.

title: A Rocky First Review for a Climate Paper Warning of a Stormy Coastal Crisis
description: [ | When the Hansen paper finally passed peer review and was published in March 2016, the elements predicting an imminent rapid rise in sea levels  the aspect of the paper that drew the attention of CNN, CBS and other major media  were largely replaced by projections.]

title: Recapturing Our Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: Save the Elephant
description: Listing the two types of elephants as separate endangered species will save them from being poached into extinction.

title: A Cellar Full of Collateral, by the Bottle or the Case
description: As a restaurateur and wine collector, Nick Gangas knows the special pleasures of pairing a fine Burgundy with a roast chicken or a leg of lamb. Yet recently, he discovered another use for his Burgundy  as loan collateral.

title: David Politis of BetterCloud: Start by Working Beyond Your Rsum
description: This interview with David Politis, chief executive of BetterCloud, a maker of cloud-based software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Diamondbacks Player Has Miguel Cabreras Likeness, if Not Yet His Power
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks had already scouted Yasmany Tomas by the time their chief baseball officer, the Hall of Famer Tony La Russa, first saw him. But when La Russa did, it confirmed to him that his team had spent wisely by investing $68.5 million for six years.

title: Salesforce Makes Strides Toward Gender Equality in Silicon Valley
description: Marc Benioff, the co-founder and chief executive of Salesforce, was riding high a couple of years ago. His cloud software company had weathered the financial crisis, revenue was up, and the stock was at a record high.

title: Orlando City S.C. and New York City F.C. Take Different Paths in M.L.S.
description: For 13 years, there was a steady, archetypical quality to the career of Kak. He was one of those famous mononyms sprinkled throughout global soccer. He played for some of the biggest clubs in Italy, Spain and his home country, Brazil. Each team was steeped in tradition and imposed on players the weight of its own history. Always, he felt a burden of immense expectation.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Move to Disc Brakes, on Trial Basis, Stirs Concern Among Cyclists
description: LALPE DHUEZ, France  For all the high tech in cycling, much in the sport would be familiar to a mechanic a century ago. The tires used by riders at the Tour de France, for example, have their inner tubes sewn into lightweight casings that are then glued onto the wheels.

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 17 to July 23.

title: For Alex Rodriguez, Its Another Big Number
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Alex Rodriguez has joined some exclusive clubs this season. He now finds himself with Willie Mays, Babe Ruth, Henry Aaron and Barry Bonds as the only players to have hit 660 home runs, and he became the 29th player to have 3,000 hits, doing so in striking fashion with a home run.

title: A Back Porch Filled With Stars, as Is the Nearby Hall of Fame
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  When baseballs Hall of Famers reconvene here each year for the induction of new members, the spacious veranda behind the Otesaga Resort Hotel is the equivalent of their town square.

title: Las Vegas Strip Cloaked in Smoke From Hotel Fire
description: A fire broke out at a luxury hotel on the Las Vegas Strip on Saturday, injuring one person and covering the Strip with thick plumes of black smoke, fire officials and witnesses said.

title: Migrants Surge Into Europe Through the Balkans
description: Much of Europe is reeling from the flow of people seeking safety, jobs and a better life.

title: Seeking Sanctuary, More Migrants Confront Land Routes Perils
description: SUBOTICA, Serbia  They call it the jungle, but its really just a tangle of dirt paths through stunted trees near an abandoned brick factory.

title: In Iowa, Donald Trump Takes Aim at Scott Walker, for a Change
description: OSKALOOSA, Iowa  To the list of Republican rivals he has insulted, Donald J. Trump on Saturday added a new name: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, whom he accused of mismanaging his states budget and creating a disaster for its roads, schools and hospitals.

title: No Escape
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Awesome! That was my first thought. I love an original twist on an idea, and Ellen Leuschner and Jeff Chen have hit on an idea that will pull you right in. There you are, sitting in front of your Sunday pastime, and the puzzle pulls you headfirst (hopefully, unless you hold your writing implement or type with your toes) into the New York Times Crossword. Have no fear; Will Shortz will be on the other side to meet you.

title: Black South Carolina Trooper Explains Why He Helped a White Supremacist
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  What the black state trooper saw was a civilian in distress. Yes, this was a white man, attending a white supremacist rally in front of the South Carolina State House. And yes, he was wearing a black T-shirt emblazoned with a swastika.

title: Candidates Caught in Middle as Words Ring Hollow to Activists
description: In the space of a few hours last week, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Jeb Bush showed how their parties two best-funded candidates are grappling with insistent, intensifying demands from activists on the left and the right who are deeply disenchanted with the political establishment.

title: A Dance Maintains Its Hold on New York
description: Since vogueing strutted into the mainstream in the 90s, it has evolved stylistically and demographically, with more women participating and a shift to bolder moves.

title: Israel Is Steadfast in Criticism of Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  In a stern response to Secretary of State John Kerrys recent comments on the Iran nuclear accord, an Israeli official said Saturday that Israel would continue to criticize the agreement and could not be pressured to stop voicing its objections.

title: Migrants Surge Into Europe Through the Balkans
description: Much of Europe is reeling from the flow of people seeking safety, jobs and a better life.

title: Teva Said to Be Close to Buying Generic Drug Unit of Allergan
description: Teva Pharmaceuticals is in advanced talks to buy the generic drug division of Allergan for about $45 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Saturday.

title: Presidential Race Just Started? Not According to the Spending
description: Since late last year, presidential hopefuls have been romancing donors, hiring staff and haunting the diners and senior centers of Manchester and Dubuque.

title: Key & Peele to End After Its Fifth Season
description: Somewhere, we have to assume that President Obamas anger translator is very upset with this decision: the current fifth season of the influential Comedy Central sketch series Key & Peele will be its last, the network said.

title: Alex Rodriguezs Three Home Runs Help Yankees Rally to Stun the Twins
description: MINNEAPOLIS  If you strung together the three home runs that Alex Rodriguez hit Saturday night, they would total more than 1,300 feet  about as long a shot as the Yankees figured to have of winning Saturday nights game.

title: Baseball Union Chief Marvin Miller Awaits His Due
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  At Doubleday Field here on Saturday, the Baseball Hall of Fame honored Curt Flood for challenging the reserve clause in 1970, when he refused to report to the Philadelphia Phillies after being traded to them by the St. Louis Cardinals. He took that challenge against Major League Baseball to the Supreme Court of the United States, but lost. Yet his boldness and selflessness in asserting his rights helped inspire free agency, which became a part of the game a few years later.

title: Holly Shaw, Seth Karpinski
description: Holly Kay Shaw and Seth Peter Karpinski were married Saturday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy in Port Chester, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy Wiggins performed the ceremony.

title: Mary Cowan and Jerrold Lundquist
description: Mary Skoby Cowan and Jerrold Theodore Lundquist were married Saturday. Stephen C. Waluk, the chief clerk of the Rhode Island District Court, in Providence, officiated at Ocean Cliff, a hotel in Newport, R.I.

title: Jessica Pabst and Eric Southern
description: Jessica Marie Pabst and Edward Frederick Southern III are to be married Sunday at the Greenpoint Loft, a warehouse space in Brooklyn. Samuel D. Hunter, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Swagata Biswas and Matthew Regan
description: Swagata Biswas and Matthew David Regan were married Saturday evening at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Capt. Arnold Wonsever, a minister ordained through the Esoteric Interfaith Church, officiated.

title: Margot Weller, Daniel Moccia-Field
description: Margot Claire Weller and Daniel Moccia-Field were married Saturday at Cricket Creek Farm, a dairy farm and cheese producer in Williamstown, Mass. L. Ward Schaefer, a friend of the groom who received permission from Massachusetts to solemnize the wedding, officiated.

title: Sara Ruddock-Harris, Austin Walker
description: Sara Charace Ruddock-Harris, the daughter of Charmaine R. Ruddock of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Austin Guyton Walker, the son of Diane C. S. Walker and Paul G. Walker of Houston. The Rev. Elias OBrien performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Chicago, where he is the pastor.

title: Beverly Rich,  George Ingersoll
description: Beverly Nora Rich and George Morin Ingersoll were married Saturday at the home of the grooms parents in Pasadena, Calif. The officiant was Elizabeth R. Rich, the brides sister who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion;Marion I. Quinones, a sister of the groom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Elisa Olivieri, Alexander Torgovitsky
description: Elisa Marie Olivieri and Alexander Torgovitsky were married Saturday at the Rockefeller Memorial Chapel in Chicago. Jos A. Olivieri, the brides father, who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

title: Sarah Brasell, Brian Donohue
description: Sarah Stevenson Brasell and Brian Michael Donohue were married Saturday at Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains by the Rev. Gawain F. de Leeuw, an Episcopal priest.

title: Jung Mee Park, Everett Schlawin
description: Jung Mee Park and Everett Alden Schlawin were married Monday. Christopher J. Durkin, the clerk of Essex County, N.J., officiated at the Hall of Records in Newark. On Saturday, Carl D. Ferkinhoff, a friend of the couple, led another ceremony at the Big Red Barn, Cornells graduate student center, in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Jessica Harris, Martin Shapiro
description: Jessica Sara Harris, a daughter of Shari S. Harris and I. Ron Harris of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married Saturday to Martin Nathan Shapiro, a son of Dr. Priscilla A. Bresler and Dr. Charles L. Shapiro of New Rochelle, N.Y. Cantor Dana S. Anesi officiated at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Gilbert Smith, Charles Gulas
description: Gilbert Mathew Smith and Charles John Gulas are to be married Sunday at the Randall Gallery, an events space in St. Louis. Marlene Sundheimer, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the Universal Life Church for the occasion, will officiate.

title: Jesse Horwitz and Mark Severs
description: Jesse Scott Horwitz and Mark David Severs were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The officiant was Gillian I. Horwitz, Mr. Horwitzs sister, who became an affiliate of the First Nation Ministry for the occasion.

title: Nicole Perlroth,  Heath Thomson
description: Nicole Perlroth and Heath David Thomson were married Saturday in an outdoor ceremony at the Family Farm, an event space in Woodside, Calif. Daniel Ellenberg, who was ordained by Open Ministry for the occasion, officiated.

title: Chanel Lewis, Andre Donald
description: Chanel Natalya Lewis and Andre Khalid Donald were married Saturday at Woodbury Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Lisa S. Ottley, a supervising judge for Kings County Civil Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Marren, Sean Barry
description: Elizabeth Mary Marren, a daughter of Joan M. Marren and Joseph H. Marren of Harrison, N.Y., was married Saturday to Sean Patrick Barry, the son of Patricia E. Barry of Missoula, Mont., and the late James J. Barry, who lived in Ellenville, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel OReilly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: Sandy Myers, Ames Grawert
description: Sandy Lynn Myers, the daughter of Sarah Myers and Steven A. Myers of Marlboro, N.J., was married Friday evening to Ames Cheney Grawert, the son of Melissa McCarthy Grawert and Bruce A. Grawert of Atlanta. Brian Cook, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at Doolans Shore Club, a hotel and event space in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Erin McNamara,  Henry Blechman
description: Erin Elizabeth McNamara and Henry Chase Blechman were married Friday at the Roundhouse, a hotel in Beacon, N.Y., in an interfaith ceremony officiated jointly by their fathers, Dr. Peter J. Blechman and Mark A. McNamara, who were ordained by the American Fellowship Church.

title: Laura Zanzal, Christopher Ford
description: Laura Ann Zanzal, the daughter of Joanne I. Zanzal and Andrew G. Zanzal of Cheshire, Conn., was married Friday to Christopher Reilly Ford, the son of Patricia A. Oehl of Scituate, Mass., and Christopher M. Ford of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Norman L. Brockett performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Roman Catholic Church in Waterbury, Conn., where he is the pastor.

title: Ashley Harris and Jon Fougner
description: Elizabeth Ashley Harris and Jon Bernhard Fougner were married Saturday at Beaulieu Garden, an event space in Rutherford, Calif. The officiant was Judge Alex Kozinski of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Jessica Wuerth and Marc Vigliotti: Meeting Up Was a Walk in the Park
description: Jessica VanTassel Wuerth and Marc Ralph Vigliotti were married Saturday evening at Eolia Mansion in Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, Conn. The Rev. Kent J. Siladi, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Laura Brace, Devin Rochford
description: Laura Ainsworth Brace, the daughter of Susan R. Brace and Glenn E. Brace of Englefield Green, England, was married Saturday to Devin Sean Rochford, a son of Diane R. Rochford and James M. Rochford of Roswell, Ga. The Rev. Msgr. Lanaux J. Rareshide, the great-uncle of the bride, officiated at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

title: Michelle Schackman and Jonathan Fayer
description: Michelle Kate Schackman and Jonathan Charles Fayer were married Saturday evening at the Crossed Keys Inn in Andover, N.J. Rabbi Gloria J. Milner officiated.

title: Suzanne Schueller,  Daniel Gottlander
description: Suzanne Ernster Schueller, a daughter of Shannon E. Schueller and Dr. Dean R. Schueller of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married Saturday to Daniel Johan Robert Gottlander, the son of Eva Gottlander and Dr. Robert Gottlander of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. James N. Carruthers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Annes Catholic Church on Mackinac Island, Mich.

title: Amanda Janulis, James Turley Jr.
description: Amanda Susan Janulis and James Stanton Turley Jr. were married Saturday at St. Hedwigs Church in Chicago. The Rev. Jacob D. Martin, a Roman Catholic priest and the brides brother, performed the ceremony.

title: Sadie Stein,  Lorin Stein
description: Sadie Olds Stein and Lorin Hollister Stein were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City clerks office, officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 26, 2015
description: Were in uncharted territory. This campaign cycle more than any other, weve seen more pre-announcement activity being paid for through essentially unregulated money.

title: Corrections: July 26, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Using Algorithms to Determine Character
description: Computers arent just doing hard math problems and showing us cat videos. Increasingly, they judge our character.

title: Netflix Refines Its DVD Business, Even as Streaming Unit Booms
description: FREMONT, Calif.  It was just past sunrise on an early-spring morning at Netflixs DVD operations here, where metallic arms whirred in a giant glass box and rolling carts holding millions of DVDs lined the walls. The companys iconic red envelopes buzzed through an assembly line at the other end of the warehouse.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: Boy Scouts Are Poised to End Ban on Gay Leaders
description: The Boy Scouts of America is expected on Monday to end its blanket ban on gay leaders  a turning point for an organization that has been in turmoil over the issue.

title: Aging Infrastructure Plagues Nations Busiest Rail Corridor
description: In Maryland, a century-old rail tunnel needed emergency repairs this winter because of soil erosion from leaks, causing widespread train delays.

title: Review: Cheers, but Modest Impact, for Revisionist Tristan
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  Its the season of re-evaluating well-loved characters we thought we knew. First Atticus Finch, a saintly warrior for racial justice in Harper Lees To Kill a Mockingbird, was revealed as a patronizing bigot in Ms. Lees newly published companion novel, Go Set a Watchman.

title: Obama Delivers Tough-Love Message to End Kenya Trip
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At one point during his weekend in Kenya, President Obama acknowledged the delicate nature of deciding which of his vast array of half cousins and stepaunts should be invited to dinner.

title: Is There Such a Thing as Ethical Cheating?
description: When the news broke recently that hackers had breached Ashley Madison, the dating website that helps married people find out-of-wedlock romance, the Internet responded with a lot of snark and not much sympathy.

title: 1940: Hungary Expects to Get Only Part of Transylvania
description: BUDAPEST  The impression that Soviet aspirations as yet unknown are the reason for this week-ends Salzburg conversations is generally gaining ground here, as well as the feeling that Hungary will not receive the whole of Transylvania in the axis solution of the Danubian question, because of the important problem of erecting an anti-Russian bloc in this area. It is difficult to say how a partial cession of Transylvania would be received here, in view of the propaganda which has been waged for the return of the whole district. An indication of how this might be done gracefully, however, was given this morning in the Pester Lloyd, organ of the Foreign Office. The papers leading editorial resurrected the Hungarian claims for damages caused by the Rumanian Army during its partial occupation of the country in 1919.  New York Herald Tribune, July 27, 1940

title: Assad, in Rare Admission, Says Syrias Army Lacks Manpower
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a striking admission, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said on Sunday that the countrys army faced a manpower shortage and had ceded some areas to insurgents in order to hold onto other regions deemed more important.

title: Obama in Kenya Urges Reform
description: President Obama gave a speech to mostly young Kenyans in Nairobi on Sunday.

title: In Iowa, Chris Christie Gets a Heros Welcome, Pun Intended
description: DES MOINES  Chris Christie has not gotten a lot of Iowa love lately. Hes sunk deep down in polls of the states Republicans, and he attracts only a smattering of reporters  a far cry from the hubbub a year ago when, on frequent Iowa trips, he was treated like a front-runner.

title: 1965: U.S. Cars to Provide More Safety Features
description: NEW YORK  The nations leading auto makers now seem ready to install a number of safety items as mandatory equipment on their 1967 models. The decision to do so has not been taken lightly. Many of the auto makers, including Frederic G. Donner, chairman of General Motors, are known to feel that if we were to force on people things they are not prepared to buy we would face a consumer revolt.

title: Fiat Chrysler Gets Record $105 Million Fine for Safety Issues
description: DETROIT  In their most aggressive crackdown yet on auto safety, federal regulators on Sunday levied a record penalty of $105 million against Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for failing to complete 23 safety recalls covering more than 11 million vehicles.

title: Proposed Raise for Fast-Food Employees Divides Low-Wage Workers
description: Rebecca Cornick cheerfully chopped 120 heads of lettuce, wiped tables and rang up some Baconators, fries and chicken club sandwiches. For most of her customers, it was just another afternoon at a Wendys restaurant in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Not for Ms. Cornick. She was celebrating.

title: A Note on Medicare Costs
description: Medicare is about to turn 50, and while it has brought immense benefits, it has also cost a lot of money. Why? Is it the general rise in health care spending, or some specific government-related inability to limit outlays?

title: Thorstein Veblen in Brooklyn (Trivial)
description: I went to another Celebrate Brooklyn concert in Prospect Park last night, and had a very good time  although the usual close-up seating where you can really see the performers was given over to a throng of standing dancers, and while I may be a wannabe hipster Im not going that far. But anyway, music aside, one thing I enjoy about these events is crowd-watching, which varies a lot by performer. Lucius was a real all-ages, all-subcultures crowd, ranging from enthusiastic teenagers to fairly sedate but equally enthusiastic senior citizens. Sylvan Esso was very hipster  which is fine; de gustibus non whatever.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (E!) I AM CAIT Why did I decide to do a series? Caitlyn Jenner, above, ponders in a trailer for her latest endeavor. Im telling my story. People dont understand looking into the mirror and nothing seems right. Putting on clothes that you just really dont identify with. This is about getting to be who you really are. This new reality series aims to moves beyond the paparazzi photos (Ms. Jenner in Versace! In Diane von Furstenberg!) and public speculation to find out how Ms. Jenner came to be a role model for transgender pride. And while the show, at least initially, seems to focus on her looks  Ms. Jenner quipping about sports bras as she plays tennis; plucking a dress from her closet, only to be told by her stepdaughter Kim Kardashian that her mother, Ms. Jenners ex, has one just like it; and fixing a chip in her baby-blue manicure  Were going to do some good, she promises. Caitlyn Jenner, on screen, maintains the public personality of Bruce Jenner, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. She has the qualities of an excellent decathlete, spokeswoman and even leader, but as a reality star she could take a few lessons in openness and spontaneity from the Kardashians.

title: A Manhattan Project Veteran Had a Unique View of Atomic Bomb Work
description: Benjamin Bederson turned past the page in the diary from long ago, the page he had burned a hole through, and mentioned things he had done since that summer of 1945.

title: At Sandra Blands Funeral, Celebration and Defiance
description: LISLE, Ill.  Funerals are often predictably somber  a cloistering and culminating of grief and pain. Not Sandra Blands funeral. (Everyone called her Sandy, by the way.) Sandys was simultaneously celebratory and defiant.

title: Rain Leads to Crashes in Womens Race on Champs-lyses
description: PARIS  Rain-slicked cobblestones proved treacherous at the second edition of La Course by Le Tour de France on Sunday, a one-day womens race on the iconic Champs-lyses finishing circuit used by the three-week mens event.

title: BAMs Karen Brooks Hopkins Steps Into New Role
description: No sooner has Karen Brooks Hopkins stepped down as the longtime president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music than she is stepping up to something new. The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation plans to announce on Monday the appointment of Ms. Hopkins as senior fellow in residence, a newly created position.

title: Sebastian Vettel Wins the Hungarian Grand Prix
description: BUDAPEST  The Hungarian Grand Prix, held Sunday, was a poignant reminder, in both its underlying tragic backdrop as well as the track action, that sport is all about emotion.

title: Hologram Performance by Chief Keef Is Shut Down by Police
description: A performance by the Chicago rapper Chief Keef  or rather, his likeness, beamed live via hologram from California  was shut down by the police on Saturday night in Hammond, Ind., after warnings from the mayors office that the performer could not appear, even digitally, promoters said on Sunday.

title: The Disappearing Entitlements Crisis
description: A few years back elite policy discourse in the United States was totally dominated by the supposed entitlements crisis. Serious people all assured each other that historys greatest menace was the threat posed by the unstoppable growth of Medicaremedicaidandsocialsecurity, which could only be tamed by dismantling the legacy of the New Deal and the Great Society, while of course cutting top marginal tax rates.

title: Strikes on Kurd Militias Elevate Tensions in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  As Turkish fighter jets pounded Kurdish militia targets in northern Iraq late Friday, the implications of the attack weighed heavily on Turks and Kurds across the border in Turkey, as they faced the prospect of being drawn back into a bloody civil conflict after years of relative peace.

title: Adam Sandlers Pixels Cant Topple Ant-Man at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  American moviegoers to Adam Sandler: Weve moved on.

title: Hannibal Recap: Just When Will Thought He Was Out
description: Season 3, Episode 8: The Great Red Dragon

title: Facebook and Other Tech Giants Expand Internet Access in Africa
description: Nearly two years ago, Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, announced an ambitious effort to connect the worlds poorest people to the Internet.

title: Chris Froome Gives Britain and Africa a Tour de France Win
description: PARIS  The normally deferential Chris Froome, who won his second Tour de France by completing a drizzly and chilly final stage on Sunday, was emphatic about one aspect of his victory during his final news conference before the result was official.

title: Tattoos, Incompetence, and the Heritage Foundation
description: Henry Farrell  who recently said some very interesting things about Very Serious People  writes me about my musings on hipster style, and refers me to a review of a book on codes of the underworld. The book notes that tattoos and such play a role as signals of criminal identity, which work precisely because they make it hard to participate in non-criminal society.

title: Palestinian Youths Clash With Israeli Police in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Masked Palestinian youths clashed with Israeli police in Jerusalems Al Aqsa Mosque compound on Sunday, as Jews marked an annual day of mourning commemorating the destruction of two ancient temples believed to have once stood at the holy site.

title: Republicans Fault Hillary Clinton Over Emails on Talk Shows
description: The 16 Republican presidential hopefuls are competing against one another to score a coveted spot onstage for the first Republican debate next month. But on the Sunday shows, the chatter was all focused on the new developments surrounding Hillary Rodham Clintons emails.

title: British Lord Resigns Posts in Scandal Over Drugs
description: LONDON  Scandals make good headlines, wrote John Sewel, a member of the House of Lords, in a recent blog post about efforts to clean up the image of the British Parliament. On Sunday he featured prominently in those headlines, as he faced a police investigation into allegations that he had taken cocaine with two prostitutes in a London apartment.

title: Crunching Lifes Path
description: LinkedIns new search tools aim to guide members in the selection of a college and a career.

title: Gawkers Future: A Conversation With Nick Denton
description: On July 16, the news and gossip website Gawker, a digital-media pioneer partly responsible for the tone and sensibility of web journalism, published an article that accused a married male media executive of seeking, via text message, to pay for sex with a gay escort. It was swiftly condemned as an unseemly invasion of privacy, and Gawkers founder and chief executive, Nick Denton, decided to remove the article from the site. Two of his editors resigned, accusing Mr. Denton of violating editorial independence.

title: Strong Showings for Donald Trump in Iowa and New Hampshire Polls
description: For now, Donald Trump is here to stay, at least according to two new NBC News/Marist polls released on Sunday.

title: 12 Are Killed in Bombing Outside Hotel in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A vehicle packed with explosives detonated outside a landmark Mogadishu hotel long favored by diplomats and top government officials, killing at least 12 people and wounding many more, witnesses and the authorities said on Sunday.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 27
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Review: In Butcher Holler Here We Come, Tensions Down in the Hole
description: Darkness can be thoroughly disorienting, a fact that the performance collective Aztec Economy uses to advantage in Butcher Holler Here We Come, at the Tank in Midtown. The play, about a fictional mining disaster in West Virginia, is lighted entirely with headlamps worn by the actors, and sometimes it isnt lighted at all.

title: Review: Jane Urquharts The Night Stages, a Novel of Melancholy and Missed Chances
description: The acclaimed Canadian writer Jane Urquhart often works within a particular wistful mood  her stories, whether contemporary or historical, are full of dormant hurts, quietly endured; long separations; sorrows. The Night Stages, her tender, meditative eighth novel, again has this tenor, suggestive of John Banville and Alice McDermott, and again demonstrates both its virtues and its flaws. The books language is often lovely. Its story could be described with equal fairness as stately or static, depending on your sense of how fast a narrative should move. Its coercively melancholy. I suspect that not many people will like it, and also that some will love it.

title: Senate Resurrection of Export-Import Bank Goes to Divided House
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare and fiery weekend session, the Senate voted on Sunday to resurrect the federal Export-Import Bank, handing the Republican Partys most conservative wing a major defeat and setting up a showdown this week with House leaders divided over the moribund export credit agency.

title: 11 Arrested in Nepal in Possible Ritual Killing of Boy
description: KATHMANDU  The police found the boys body on the banks of a river in Kudiya, a farming village near the Indian border. His throat had been slit.

title: Chasing Shadows Offers Another Sleuth With Problems
description: Sometimes British mysteries take us to places we havent been before. Chasing Shadows takes us straight to familiar places, and Im not talking about the seedier parts of England.

title: The New York Musical Theater Festival Features Joy and Purpose
description: The Statue of Liberty should always be played by a transgender woman in a sea-foam-green cape and boxing trunks. Shakespeare should always be a lovesick character in his own plays. All dying Parisian courtesans should declare the greatest thing youll ever learn  and repeatedly change their minds about what that is.

title: Snoop Dogg Arrested in Sweden, Then Freed
description: The rapper Snoop Dogg was arrested in Sweden on Saturday night on suspected drug charges. After playing a concert in Uppsala, Snoop Doggs vehicle was pulled over and he was taken to the police station for a urine test, The Guardian reported. After completing the test he was released without charges. Snoop Dogg profiled the events on his Instagram, posting videos from the back of the police car and inside the station. Sorry about that to all the fans in Sweden, Ill never be in this country, he says in one video.

title: Review: Dancenoise Brings Biting Commentary (and Fake Blood) to the Whitney
description: If only you could stuff the world into a box  a big cardboard box labeled The World  and just carry on around it, dancing naked and painting your nails. Thats one thing that happened on Friday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, in a wickedly funny new concoction from Dancenoise, the inimitable duo Anne Iobst and Lucy Sexton.

title: Cooper Hewitt to Host Pixar Exhibition
description: There was a time when Buzz Lightyear was just two-dimensional. That Toy Story characters prehistory, as a conceptual sketch on a page, will be on display with other gems from Pixar Animation Studios at the exhibition Pixar: The Design of Story, opening on Oct. 8 at Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum. Conceptual drawings from Pixars films  including Wall-E, Brave and more  will be one aspect of the show, which will also feature paintings and sculpture to demonstrate the studios development process. The show will be a blend of blockbuster brand recognition and education. Caroline Baumann, the Cooper Hewitts director, said the exhibition is completely parallel with the museums mission, which is focusing on process and inspiring and educating people with design. Pixars most recent film, Inside Out, was released on June 19. The Cooper Hewitt show opens about a month before the studios next venture, The Good Dinosaur, due on Nov. 25.

title: Tanglewoods Contemporary Music Fest Milks Many Sources
description: TANGLEWOOD, Mass.  Gunther Schuller, a composer, conductor, jazz historian and horn player, had hoped to conduct the premiere of his Magical Trumpets last Thursday at Tanglewood. But the concert, part of the annual Festival of Contemporary Music, instead became a memorial to Mr. Schuller, who died in June at 89.

title: Calling Obama Our Son, Kenyans Nod Knowingly at His Critique
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Shaking off the morning chill, they walked down dirt pathways and past burning piles of trash. It would cost 10 shillings  about a dime  to see the speech, but they wanted to see the man.

title: Kitty Genovese Killing Is Retold in the Film 37
description: Walking her dog through a sun-roasted film set in Queens last Monday, Lois Gillman said she couldnt believe it at first when she heard about the movie being made, just around the corner from her house.

title: Lil Buck and Michelle Dorrance Dance Enliven Lincoln Center Out of Doors
description: Friday and Saturday nights offered, at Damrosch Park as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors series, performances by Dorrance Dance (tap) and Lil Buck (the style called Memphis jookin) that were, in their different ways, phenomenal. But Dorrance Dance left an impression of marvelously developed plenitude, with a program that ideally celebrated and renewed the resources of its genre, whereas Lil Buck looked like an artistically under-realized genius, a dazzling prodigy whose gifts are in danger of turning into point-scoring stunts.

title: Mets Break Zack Greinkes Scoreless Streak in Win Over Dodgers
description: After a game in which they had scored the most runs, tallied the most hits and presumably left the most mouths agape in Citi Fields seven-year history, the Mets returned to the ballpark Sunday morning with a revised and sobered outlook. One run would do, thanks very much.

title: Economic Measures and an Abundance of Earnings News
description: On Tuesday, the Conference Board, an independent business membership and research association, will report on consumer confidence in July. After a surge in June, a mild drop in consumer attitudes was expected by some experts this month in the face of slightly slower hiring, and of anxiety on Wall Street after a plunge in Chinese stocks and economic uncertainty in Europe.

title: A Little of This, A Little of That
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Its funny how your senses come into play even when solving a crossword. You have to pay close attention, but sometimes an entry can trigger a Proustian memory of things past and, for me, its also a reminder that a crossword puzzle is much more than just a square of interconnected words.

title: Lynch Says Death in Police Custody Highlights Fears Among Blacks
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said Sunday that the recent arrest of a black woman in Texas and her death while in police custody were bringing renewed attention to the fear and anger that characterize the relationship of blacks with the police.

title: Yankees Nathan Eovaldi Lends Stability to a Rickety Rotation
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Three relievers rose from the Yankees bullpen bench on Sunday afternoon and began stretching their arms and loosening their legs. There was nothing unusual about that, except that it was in the fourth inning and starting pitcher Nathan Eovaldi was cruising along, having allowed only a run and three singles.

title: Hillary Clinton Unveils Far-Reaching Climate Change Plan
description: DES MOINES  Promising more than a half-billion solar panels by the end of a first term and an ambitious target of clean energy for every home in America in a decade, Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled goals on Sunday evening to reduce the threat of climate change.

title: The A.D.A., 25 Years Later
Calls for Change in Waller County, Tex.
description: After the death of Sandra Bland, talk of racial milestones here gave way to questions about whether the countys checkered history of race relations had set the stage for a tragedy.
