title: Texas Countys Racial Past Is Seen as Prelude to Sandra Blands Death
description: PRAIRIE VIEW, Tex.  When Sandra Bland enrolled in 2005 at Prairie View A&M University, the historically black institution founded here almost 140 years ago, its students were still waging a civil rights war that had ended elsewhere decades before: a legal battle, against white Waller County officials, for the right to vote in the place they lived.

title: Spelman College Terminates Professorship Endowed by Bill Cosby
description: Spelman College has discontinued a professorship endowed by Bill Cosby, a university spokeswoman said.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Park Opening New Vistas
description: On a sultry afternoon recently, Regina Myer, president of the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation, walked past profusions of swamp milkweed, rose mallows and cardinal flowers. Interspersed with lawns, the red and purple flora carpeted a new area of the park, which stretches for 1.3 miles along the East River. Until recently, Pier 6 near Atlantic Avenue had been largely barren. Now it evoked a Vermont meadow in midsummer.

title: China Uses Picking Quarrels Charge to Cast a Wider Net Online
description: DUNHUANG, China  An oil-field worker in this Gobi Desert town posted poetry online memorializing the victims of the Tiananmen Square crackdown. An artist in Shanghai uploaded satirical photographs of his wincing visage superimposed on a portrait of the Chinese president. A civil rights lawyer in Beijing wrote microblog posts criticizing the Communist Partys handling of ethnic tensions.

title: Ads for Podcasts Test the Line Between Story and Sponsor
description: For the last several months, Lisa Chow, a reporter for and co-host of StartUp, a podcast about starting a business, has been interviewing engineers at Ford Motor.

title: ComptrollerSees Financial Power as Tool to Advance Civil Rights
description: Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller, grew animated as he addressed a late spring conference of executives from minority-owned businesses. Voicing exasperation with what he called the homogeneous hue of the financial sector, Mr. Stringer demanded that investment funds hire more women and nonwhite employees, starting with the citys youths.

title: Deregulator of Banks Set to Testify Before House
description: When the House Financial Services Committee examines the sweeping overhaul of financial regulation on its fifth anniversary, legislators will first hear on Tuesday from a former senator with longstanding familiarity with banking regulations.

title: Obamas Visit to Ethiopia Promises Little for Human Rights Activists
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  When a young Ethiopian journalist, Simegnish Mengesha, got the chance to meet with President Obama in May, a comment from a high-ranking American official was on her mind.

title: W.N.B.A. Star Tamika Catchings Nears End of One Career While Preparing for Another
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  The list of people who can relate to what comes next for Tamika Catchings, the only player who has been a W.N.B.A. All-Star 10 times, is short.

title: Bobby Jindal Calls for States to Follow Louisianas Example in Toughening Gun Laws
description: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana called for tougher gun laws in other states on Sunday, breaking his silence on the issue three days after a gunman with a history of mental illness and violence opened fire in a movie theater in the states fourth-largest city.

title: Republicans Alter Script on Abortion, Seeking to Shift Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Perrys voice softens when he talks about the joy he gets from looking at his iPad and seeing that 20-week picture of my first grandbaby. Marco Rubio says ultrasounds of his sons and daughters reinforced how they were children  and they were our children. Rand Paul recalls watching fetuses suck their thumbs. And Chris Christie says the ultrasound of his first daughter changed his views on abortion.

title: Andrea Pirlos Debut and a Scoring Spree Energize City F.C. Fans
description: Andrea Pirlo waved his hands above his head as he shuffled out for pregame warm-ups at Yankee Stadium on Sunday afternoon. The Jay Z song Takeover was growling over the speakers, but the cheers and applause from the fans bubbled up over the music.

title: While Some Republicans Seize Chance to Attack Hillary Clinton, Others Refrain
description: The latest chapter in the continuing story of Hillary Rodham Clintons State Department emails has presented Republican presidential candidates with a new opportunity to attack Mrs. Clinton, traditionally something popular with their partys voters, and some of them lost no time doing it.

title: Donald Trump, a Figure of Contention, Hosting a Golf Major
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland  In the United States, Donald Trump is known as a tycoon, as an outspoken television personality and, now, as a presidential candidate. In Scotland, however, Trump is renowned primarily for his impact on the countrys golf scene  although here, too, he is a figure of contention.

title: Raising Floor for Minimum Wage Pushes Economy Into the Unknown
description: WASHINGTON  The fight for a $15 minimum wage has gained momentum in New York, California and other places around the country in recent months. But as a national strategy to raise incomes at the bottom of the pay scale, it faces major obstacles, both political and economic.

title: Condolences at Grand Central
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pedro Martinezs Hall of Fame Delivery: Moving, With Light Touch
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  In the hour before the Baseball Hall of Fames induction ceremony Sunday, the fever for Pedro Martinez began to grow. Fans of Martinez, mostly for his time as a member of the Boston Red Sox and the Montreal Expos, waved flags of the Dominican Republic and chanted Pe-dro! Pe-dro! with little prompting.

title: Puerto Rico Should Collect Unpaid Taxes, Hedge Fund-Backed Economists Say
description: Economists working for a group of hedge funds and other firms with major investments in Puerto Rican bonds said Sunday night that the government could solve its debt crisis largely by stepping up tax collections and obtaining additional financing over the next two years.

title: Letter to Pope Francis
description: Groups representing gay and transgender people, Catholics, and Hispanics said the church in America is in the midst of a pastoral crisis over gay issues.

title: Howard Rumsey, 97, Dies; Musician Invigorated West Coast Jazz Scene
description: Howard Rumsey, a jazz bassist and entrepreneur who helped popularize the notion of a progressive West Coast jazz scene in the 1950s as leader of the Lighthouse All-Stars, died on July 15 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 97.

title: Help for Mets, Just When They Needed It
description: The scoreboard watching starts now. Juan Uribe said it, anyway, and good teams tend to follow his lead.

title: Police Seek Man Who Escaped, Shoeless, From Harlem Cell
description: Arthur Collins managed to get out of a holding cell in a police station in Harlem last week without any shoes on.

title: Poldark Episode 6 Recap: Tragedy vs. Troublemaking
description: Episode 6

title: City Invalidates Test Scores of Third Graders at Harlem School
description: The results of several dozen standardized tests taken by third graders at a sought-after public elementary school in Harlem have been invalidated amid allegations of testing improprieties by the schools principal, according to city education officials.

title: N.J. Transit Announces More Delays Amid Work
description: Commuters in New Jersey were given one more reason to dread morning rush hour, when New Jersey Transit on Sunday pre-emptively announced residual delays to its Monday morning service, and said that commuters could use their tickets on private bus and ferry services as well as PATH trains.

title: Bobbi Kristina Brown, Daughter of Whitney Houston, Dies at 22
description: Bobbi Kristina Brown, the only child of the pop stars Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown, who set off a media frenzy after she was found unconscious in a bathtub on Jan. 31, died on Sunday. She was 22.

title: Fantasy Sports Website DraftKings Adds $300 Million in New Investment
description: DraftKings, the daily fantasy sports website, was set to announceMonday that it had added $300 million in new investment to sustain its growth, marketing and planned international expansion. Fox Sports, the lead investor, will pay about $150 million for an estimated 11 percent of DraftKings, according to a person briefed on the terms of the transaction.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: For Tessa, a  Nightmare Homecoming
description: Season 3, Episode 3: The Excitement of Release

title: Overcoming Distractions, Mexico Wins Gold Cup Final
description: PHILADELPHIA  The troubled Gold Cup came to a celebratory end for Mexico on Sunday night with a 3-1 victory against Jamaica as the regional tournament sought to shift its focus from scandal to soccer.

title: Peg Lynch, Writer and Star of Early Situation Comedy, Dies at 98
description: Peg Lynch, who wrote and starred in Ethel and Albert, one of televisions earliest situation comedies, died on Friday at her home in Becket, Mass. She was 98.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (Logo) MATT SHEPARD IS A FRIEND OF MINE (2015) Through the memories of family members and friends, Michele Josue traces the life of Mr. Shepard (above with Ms. Josue), the University of Wyoming student whose 1998 murder brought widespread attention to hate crimes against gay people. Before his nationally reported death, hed suffered hateful violence, Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times, citing an awful episode on Mr. Shepards high school trip to Morocco, where he was raped. He added: In lingering over moody night streets and trembling faces, Ms. Josue has brought this film to the verge of becoming a tear-jerker. But, as epitomized in an extraordinary scene with a conflicted priest, its all part of a shared soul-searching that still continues.

title: Hall of Fame Celebrates Four of Baseballs Greatest
description: Craig Biggio, John Smoltz, Randy Johnson and Pedro Martinez were honored at the national pastimes spiritual home in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Modern Love Redux: Readers Thoughts on Gifts, Love and Lying
description: Last Thursdays Modern Love column, Uniting a Mysterious Ring With Its Rightful Owner, inspired over 170 readers to weigh in  on Facebook and nytimes.com/styles about the fraught subject of gift-giving and relationships. When should we feign excitement? When should we just be grateful? Is it shallow to even care? Below are a selection of comments edited for space.

title: There Ought to Be a Law Against Hate
description: OAK CREEK, Wis.  LAST week, the Department of Justice indicted Dylann Roof, the suspect in the shooting deaths of nine people in Charleston, S.C., for hate crimes. Officials said they were bringing this indictment because they were worried that the racial motivation in the case would not be addressed adequately by a trial in a state court.

description: To the Editor:

title: Zombies Against Medicare
description: Medicare turns 50 this week, and it has been a very good half-century. Before the program went into effect, Ronald Reagan warned that it would destroy American freedom; it didnt, as far as anyone can tell. What it did do was provide a huge improvement in financial security for seniors and their families, and in many cases it has literally been a lifesaver as well.

title: Improving Gender Equity in Medical Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Plans: A Chinese Megacity, Pop. 130 Million

title: For Transgender Americans, Legal Battles Over Restrooms
description: Gavin Grimm sat quietly in the audience last November as dozens of parents at a school board meeting in Gloucester County, Va., demanded that he be barred from using the boys restrooms at school. They discussed the transgender boys genitals, expressed concern that he might expose himself and cautioned that being in a mens room would make the teenager vulnerable to rape. One person called him a freak.

title: Dont Just Close Bases at Home, Close Them Overseas
description: WASHINGTON  THERE are signs that Congress may soon approve another series of domestic military base closings, after the Pentagon threatened earlier this month to cut nearly 90,000 jobs instead. For years, the military has been trying to save money with new rounds of Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC), the congressionally mandated process for shuttering underutilized domestic military installations.

title: A Smart Deal to Cut Tariffs on Tech Products
description: More than 50 countries agreed on Friday to eliminate tariffs on a wide range of technology goods like medical devices, navigation equipment and advanced semiconductors in a trade agreement that should benefit American manufacturers, consumers and the global economy.

title: Sea Slaves: The Human Misery That Feeds Pets and Livestock
description: SONGKHLA, Thailand  Lang Longs ordeal began in the back of a truck. After watching his younger siblings go hungry because their familys rice patch in Cambodia could not provide for everyone, he accepted a traffickers offer to travel across the Thai border for a construction job.

title: Life Among the Sea Slaves
description: Although Adam Dean had photographed for The New York Times in Southeast Asia before, he was excited to work with Ian Urbina on part of his investigative series, The Outlaw Ocean. He saw it as an opportunity to dig into a story and spend some time trying to find out what was really going in the violent, unregulated world of fishing boats in international waters.

title: Drugged, Kidnapped and Enslaved
description: In 2011, Asorasak Thamma was kidnapped in Thailand and enslaved on a fishing boat. Interviewed last year, he had not been home since.

title: Turkey and U.S. Plan to Create Syria Safe Zone Free of ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  Turkey and the United States have agreed in general terms on a plan that envisions American warplanes, Syrian insurgents and Turkish forces working together to sweep Islamic State militants from a 60-mile-long strip of northern Syria along the Turkish border, American and Turkish officials say.

title: Inquiry Into Litvinenko Poisoning Is Delayed After Russian Fails to Testify
description: LONDON  The long-running inquiry into the poisoning death in London of a former K.G.B. officer, Alexander V. Litvinenko, hit new delays on Monday over the failure of a key Russian suspect to testify by video link from Moscow.

title: UBS Profit Increases 53% in Second Quarter
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS said on Monday that its profit rose 53 percent in the second quarter, driven by gains in its wealth management business as it had higher inflows from the Asia-Pacific region and ultrahigh-net-worth clients.

title: Gunmen in Indian Army Uniforms Attack Bus and Police Station, Killing 5
description: NEW DELHI  Gunmen dressed in Indian Army uniforms opened fire on a civilian bus and then took over a police station in the northern state of Punjab early on Monday, killing at least five people, the police said, in a region that has been mostly calm since India quelled a Sikh insurgency there two decades ago.

title: Should We Fear the Political Crazies?
description: The melee began, as they often do in politics, with simple umbrage. This performance with our friend out in Phoenix is very hurtful to me, Senator John McCain told Ryan Lizza of The New Yorker. He was referring to a massive rally that Donald Trump held a few days earlier in July to protest illegal immigration. McCain then followed with the kill shot. What he did, he said of Trump, was he fired up the crazies. In the annals of political deprecation, McCains charge of rallying the crazies was not terribly inspired. It was a far cry from, say, Teddy Roosevelts remark that William McKinley has the backbone of a chocolate clair or Winston Churchills description of Clement Attlee, the British prime minister, as a sheep in sheeps clothing. This was not even a Top 5 effort by McCain, who will sometimes refer to reporters as Trotskyites (often with affection) and last year dismissed protesters who interrupted a Senate hearing as lowlife scum (without affection). McCain is not so much a put-down artist as he is gifted at caricaturing entire sectors and viewpoints by way of dismissing them  in this case the border hawks who turned out for Trump.

title: Let Me Tell You, by Shirley Jackson
description: How do we explain to the new, knowing wash-ashores, Brits and Aussies mainly, who have insinuated themselves into the media here, and into popular American culture generally, and to the very young, that there are touchstones and events that define us, that have formed us, that they know nothing about? They dont have the slightest clue, nor do they know Bo Diddley.

title: The Complete Stories, by Clarice Lispector
description: Theres a whiff of madness in the fiction of Clarice Lispector. The Complete Stories of the great Brazilian writer, edited by Benjamin Moser and sensitively translated by Katrina Dodson, is a dangerous book to read quickly or casually because its so consistently delirious. Sentence by sentence, page by page, Lispector is exhilaratingly, arrestingly strange, but her perceptions come so fast, veer so wildly between the mundane and the metaphysical, that after a while you dont know where you are, either in the book or in the world. Coherence, I dont want it anymore, a character in one of her stories thinks. Coherence is mutilation. I want disorder. That character, a 37-year-old woman in melancholy flight from her husband or lover, has this revelation too: It was a lie to say you could only have one thought at a time: She had many thoughts that intersected and were multiple. Especially in the 1970s, in the last decade of Lispectors life, when that story (The Departure of the Train) and two of her best, most challenging novels  gua Viva and The Hour of the Star  were written, she was trying to get all her own intersecting, helplessly multiplying thoughts on the page. She failed, of course, but failed beautifully. Her willed disorder is heroic.

title: Suicide on Campus and the Pressure of Perfection
description: Kathryn DeWitt conquered high school like a gold-medal decathlete. She ran track, represented her school at a statewide girls leadership program and took eight Advanced Placement tests, including one for which she independently prepared, forgoing the class.

title: More Fees Propel Airlines Profits, and Embitter Travelers
description: As a frequent business traveler, Wayne Miller, a distributor for an ethnic foods company, often pays extra to stretch out his legs. When he paid $38 for a window seat with extra legroom on a recent cross-country flight, though, Mr. Miller was upset to find out, when he boarded, that the seat didnt actually have window access.

title: At Least 20 Are Killed in Attack at Afghan Wedding Party
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 20 people were killed at a large wedding party in northern Afghanistan when a group of gunmen opened fire on the gathering, the authorities said Monday.

title: Teva Pharmaceuticals to Buy Allergans Generics Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The mantra bigger is better continues to hold sway in the drug manufacturing industry, as two big pharmaceutical makers struck a $40.5 billion deal  and set the stage for potentially more mergers to come.

title: Snoring Children May Suffer From Sleep Apnea
description: Barrett Treadway, now 3, has never been the best of sleepers, but her sleep grew increasingly worse in the last year and a half. She gets up several times a night, often climbs into her parents bed and creates havoc with their nights.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: ScienceTake | The Very, Very Clean Ant
description: Ants have a remarkable cleaning mechanism for their highly sensitive antennae.

title: How Ants Keep Clean and Safe
description: You will never find a dirty insect, said Alexander Hackmann, a zoologist who studies how ants clean their antennas.

title: Learning to Protect Lives, With Help From Inmates
description: The Canine Performance Sciences Program at Auburn University breeds and trains dogs to use their powerful sense of smell to keep people safe.

title: Puppies Go to Prison to Become Dogs That Save Lives
description: OPELIKA, Ala.  All dressed up in a shiny new red shirt, little Opelika could not stand still in the anteroom of the City Council chambers. And who could blame her? In a few minutes she would meet the mayor of this Alabama city for which she is named. Her meltingly calm mother, Lily, ignored her fidgeting.

title: Chinese Shares Tumble Again
description: HONG KONG  After several weeks of relative calm, tumult returned to Chinas stock markets on Monday, casting doubt on the governments measures to support share prices.

title: New York Today: Planes, Trains and Automobiles
description: Good morning on this hazy Monday.

title: Today in Politics: Drowned Out by Donald Trump, Other Candidates Clamor for Space Onstage
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where, though Congress has work to do before its August recess, its members still found time to fight among themselves. Two other deadlines are around the corner as outside fund-raising groups have to file paperwork, and the candidates await word on whether they have been invited to the debates. Toward that end, those on the brink find themselves competing with a surprise front-runner for attention.

title: Can the Weeknd Turn Himself Into the Biggest Pop Star in the World?
description: The scene backstage last November at the American Music Awards, that annual gathering of pop perennials and idiosyncratic arrivistes, was carnivalesque: Niall and Liam of One Direction toddled about trying to snap a picture with a selfie stick, while Zayn, their bandmate at the time, smoked coolly out of frame; Ne-Yo was there in a leopard-print blazer two sizes too small; Lil Wayne was wandering around, alone, wearing absurd shoes. In the middle of it all, Abel Tesfaye, better known as the Weeknd, remained calm, slow motion to everyone elses warp speed.

title: Dont Be Misled by the New Poll Results for Donald Trump
description: It has been more than a week since Donald Trumps remarks about whether Senator John McCain should be considered a war hero, and many journalists and commentators have reached a conclusion: Mr. Trump has emerged unscathed.

title: 10 Things Id Tell My Former (Medicated) Self
description: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts that began in February, she has chronicled the challenges she has faced from both the drugs and the withdrawal. This is the final installment.

title: Obama Gathers Leaders in Effort to End South Sudan War
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  For President Obama, the birth of South Sudan four years ago was the capstone of his Africa policy. He sent his United Nations ambassador, Susan E. Rice, for the independence celebration, and she took her 13-year-old son to stand in the joyous crowds of the new capital, Juba.

title: Punjab Police Station Attacked
description: Special forces secured the scene in the northern Indian state early on Monday after gunmen dressed as soldiers stormed a police station.

title: Morning Agenda: Teva to Buy Allergan Generic Drug Unit
description: TEVA TO BUY ALLERGAN GENERIC DRUG UNIT | The Israeli drug maker Teva has agreed to buy Allergans generic drug division for $40.5 billion in cash and stock, Chad Bray reports in DealBook. The transaction would create a company with estimated, pro forma revenue of $26 billion in 2016, including about $11 billion in sales outside the United States, Teva said. Under the terms of the deal, Allergan would receive $33.75 billion in cash and shares worth about $6.75 billion, representing an ownership stake of under 10 percent in Teva.

title: American Racism in the White Frame
description: This is the next installment in a series of interviews on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Joe Feagin, a sociologist, and a leading researcher of racism in the United States for more than 40 years. He teaches at Texas A & M University and is the author of more than 60 books, including the forthcoming How Blacks Built America: Labor, Culture, Freedom, and Democracy.

title: Palestinian, 18, Dies While Trying to Evade Israeli Security
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A Palestinian man died after he was shot and appeared to fall from a rooftop in the West Bank while trying to evade arrest by the Israeli security forces on Monday, a police spokesman said. It was the fourth fatal shooting by Israeli forces in the territory this month.

title: Chocolate Factory Announces 10th-Anniversary Season
description: Nine premieres are in store for the 10th-anniversary season of the Chocolate Factory, the Queens-based incubator of experimental performance.

title: The Evidence Supports Artificial Sweeteners Over Sugar
description: In the last few years, Ive watched a continuing battle among my friends about which is worse for you: artificial sweeteners or sugar. Unless you want to forgo all beverages that are sweet, youre going to run into one of these. Rather than rely on anecdote or myth, we can inform this debate with research.

title: For Hissne Habr, a Trial by Refusal
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Surrounded by 10 muscular prison guards, Hissne Habr, his frail body entirely swathed in white, looked smothered in his chair. He was sitting in the front row of the immense courtroom, fingering Muslim prayer beads. His boubou covered all but his eyes, and they were partly hidden by his glasses.

title: Slaves at Sea
description: Men who have fled servitude on fishing boats recount beatings and worse as nets are cast for the catch that will become pet food and livestock feed.

title: Verbatim: Obama Calls Republicans Remarks Sad
description: President Obama, during a news conference in Ethiopia, responding to former Gov. Mike Huckabees suggestion that his Iran policy amounts to marching the Israelis to the door of the oven.

title: McGraw Hill Financial Buys SNL Financial for $2.2 Billion
description: McGraw Hill Financial, the owner of Standard & Poors Ratings Services and S&P Capital IQ, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy the financial data and information provider SNL Financial for $2.2 billion in cash.

title: On I Am Cait, a Wardrobe Tour Reveals Fashions Fixation on Caitlyn Jenner
description: The debut on Sunday night of Caitlyn Jenners new reality TV show, I Am Cait, was full of emotional moments, as well as Kardashians, as you might expect. But tucked away in the family revelations and inspiration was a pretty interesting moment between Kim Kardashian and Ms. Jenner, in, of all places, Ms. Jenners closet.

title: ObamaCriticizes Huckabee, Trump, Cruz and Other Republicans
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  President Obama on Monday lashed out at Republican presidential candidates for making what he called ridiculous claims about his policies and outrageous attacks that crossed the line of political decorum.

title: Farming Had an Earlier Start, a Study Says
description: Farming may have originated 23,000 years ago, thousands of years earlier than previously thought, according to a new study.

title: Fans Highlight Bobbi Kristina Browns Bond With Her Mother
description: In the hours after Bobbi Kristina Brown died on Sunday, fans shared pictures of her with her mother, Whitney Houston, the music superstar whose legacy she had hoped to continue.

title: New Yorks Oldest: Reporters Notebook
description: There is a risk in planning a long-term project focusing on people age 85 and older, like the one Ive been reporting since the beginning of the year. (The second installment ran in Sundays paper.) The lives of the subjects can change very rapidly, and not necessarily for the better. Whenever I pick up the phone to call one of the six subjects of the series, I hope for a healthy voice on the other end. This makes the series a rarity in the news business; Im hoping for no news.

description: Looking for something new to check out this week?

description: The Navy joined the Coast Guard on Monday to look for two teenagers who disappeared off the Florida coast while on a fishing trip. The Coast Guard found their capsized boat over the weekend in a search that has already covered thousands of miles.

title: A Clinton Story Fraught With Inaccuracies: How It Happened and What Next?
description: The story certainly seemed like a blockbuster: A criminal investigation of Hillary Rodham Clinton by the Justice Department was being sought by two federal inspectors general over her email practices while secretary of state.

title: Rats,  Waves, Forced Labor: A Reporters Life on the Lawless Ocean
description: For five weeks last year Adam Dean, a photographer, and I reported on fishing boats in the South China Sea and in Thai, Malaysian and Indonesian port towns for a story about forced labor in the fishing industry.

title: Daily Report: How Algorithms Determine Our Character
description: Its set to be another busy week in technology news. In Silicon Valley, two of the best-known social media companies  Twitter and Facebook  will be reporting their quarterly earnings in the next few days. In Europe, Nokia will be posting its financial results, with plenty of scrutiny over who might emerge as the victorious bidder for the companys mapping business.

title: 1890: Paris Concierge Robbed
description: PARIS  A concierge in the rue Fontaine, who knew the owner of the house but not his wife, was agreeably surprised to receive on Friday last a visit from the latter. The concierge brought out biscuits, fruit and wine. When the lady consented to take something the concierge was astonished at seeing her guest nearly clear the table. And now, said the visitor, Let us talk about business. I suppose you have now received the rents which were in arrears; kindly let me have them. The concierge handed over 262fr. to the lady, who found soon that she had only just time to catch her train. When the owner of the house called yesterday morning, the concierge learnt that she had been the victim of a cruel swindler.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 28, 1890

title: Review: Dialogues of the Carmelites, Under Will Crutchfield, Finds Beauty Anew
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  The conductor Will Crutchfields Bel Canto at Caramoor program has been bringing eager audiences to this festival here in Westchester County each summer for performances of operas from the early 19th century. On Saturday at Caramoors Venetian Theater Mr. Crutchfield turned to a work that couldnt seem further from the era and style of bel canto: Poulencs Dialogues of the Carmelites, performed in the original French. First presented in 1957, this austerely beautiful and wrenching opera, loosely based on a historical event  the guillotining of 16 nuns from the Carmelite convent of Compigne during the French Revolution  owes more to Debussy and Neo-Classical Stravinsky than the bel canto composers of an earlier time.

title: Bostons Bid for Summer Olympics Is Terminated
description: BOSTON  Deep skepticism here about whether taxpayers would be stuck footing the bill for the Olympics has doomed Bostons bid to host the 2024 Summer Games and raised questions about whether any other major American city might be willing to take on the risk.

title: Claustrophobia: More Likely in Women Than Men
description: Q. Are men more likely to be claustrophobic than women?

title: Mike Trouts Numbers Add Up to Greatness at a Tender Age
description: It is not that Mike Trout hit his 30th and 31st home runs Sunday. It is not that the second shot was a grand slam. It is not that the homers helped the Los Angeles Angels to a 13-7 victory over the Texas Rangers and kept them a game ahead of the Houston Astros in the American League West.

title: Mike Huckabee Responds to Obamas Criticism of Oven Comment
description: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas continued his war of words with President Obama on Monday, defending his use of Holocaust imagery to describe the White Houses policy toward Iran.

title: Lessons From the Past on Negotiating with Iran
description: Republicans in Congress have gotten a lot of mileage, and headlines, out of being glibly contemptuous of the Iran nuclear deal.

title: Expanded Richard Wagner Museum Opens in Bayreuth
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  Wagners home here, the stately yet eccentric Villa Wahnfried, has reopened after substantial renovation and new construction as an expanded Richard Wagner Museum.

title: Greece Made Preparations to Exit Euro
description: FRANKFURT  Already struggling with internal conflict, Greeces government is facing new criticism over secret preparations that would have allowed the country to leave the euro if necessary.

title: I Am Cait Premiere Recap: All About Everyone Else
description: As I watched the premiere episode of I Am Cait, it struck me that Caitlyn Jenner was alone. Not alone in the sense of having zero people being around her, because this was a reality show, full of people in front of the camera and many more behind. No, she was alone because none of those people were transgender people.

title: Nicholas Gordon Complaint
description: Bobbi Kristina Browns conservator, Bedelia Hargrove, filed a lawsuit on her behalf against Mr. Gordon, alleging that he physically abused Ms. Brown and misrepresented himself as her husband to embezzle her funds.

title: Key Shift on Malaysia Before Trans-Pacific Partnership Deal
description: WASHINGTON  With the Obama administration pushing to conclude a vast Asian trade pact, the State Department on Monday upgraded its assessment of Malaysias efforts to combat human trafficking, a move that could ease the countrys inclusion in the trade deal.

title: Terence Taos Airport-Inspired Puzzle
description: This weeks puzzle is by Terence Tao, an Australian-born mathematician and current professorat theUniversity of California, Los Angeles. Dr. Taoistruly remarkable. Research mathematicians often see themselves as falling into two categories: technicians  those who can bring rigor, precision and clarity to a solution, and magicians, who open entirely new fields of inquiry. Dr. Tao can do both. Hes a rock star, said Ravi Vakil, a four-time Putnam winner whos known Dr. Tao for years. Brilliant, collaborative, maintains the best blog in mathematics. Im not sure how he does it. The computer science legend Donald Knuth was even more pointed. Terry Tao is the current paradigm in mathematics, he told me recently.

title: An Artist Illustrates a Better Way to Enjoy Certain New York City Spaces
description: Kate Neckel has never been bound by the traditional confines of canvas and paper. The artist has fashioned her signature intricate drawings of cityscapes and stylized figures on everything from the blank walls of the Ace Hotel to the bodies of her friends in the band Honduras. That interaction with her environment  and the people in it  has been at the core of Neckels creative output since she arrived in New York in 2000, fresh from grad school in Baltimore, and found herself in the enviable position of sharing an apartment with the model Angela Lindvall.

title: Montreal Adds Drogba and Red Bulls Sign Shaun Wright-Phillips, the Brother of Their Star Striker
description: Major League Soccers summer of signings continued with the acquisitions of two more big-name players on Monday.

title: Comcast and Discovery Announce Long-Term Distribution Deal
description: Comcast isnt the big bad bully in media land anymore, at least according to the television group Discovery Communications.

title: Dutee Chand, Female Sprinter With High Testosterone Level, Wins Right to Compete
description: The final appeals court for global sports further blurred the line separating male and female athletes on Monday, ruling that a common factor in distinguishing the sexes  the level of natural testosterone in an athletes body  is insufficient to bar some women from competing against females.

title: Tevas Deal for Allergan Unit Allows Graceful Exit From Mylan Fray
description: Teva has found a neat exit from its Mylan mess. Teva, an Israeli pharmaceutical firm, had been locked in a bitter battle to take over Mylan. Now it has agreed to buy the generic business from Allergan for $40.5 billion. The swap makes sense.

title: Controlled by the Troika
description: On managing revenue.

title: Obama Bristles at Republicans Comments
description: In Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Monday, President Obama reacted strongly to Republican presidential candidates remarks, which he said were lacking in political decorum.

title: Taking Matters Into His Own Hands
description: On hacking the finance ministry.

title: Scaling a Plan B
description: Why Mr. Varoufakis saw the need for a contingency plan.

title: The Bomb Helps Return Nukes to the TV Spotlight
description: Somewhere along the line nuclear weapons became the Rodney Dangerfield of global threats. Sure, theres the current kerfuffle over Irans nuclear program, but American schoolchildren arent exactly diving under their desks about it. Al Qaeda and the Islamic State and climate change and hackers are what give us the jitters. Build a bomb shelter in this century and you end up on Doomsday Preppers, coming off as a bit kooky.

title: Ending the Abuse of Laws, Workers and the Environment at Sea
description: How might we better manage the worlds oceans?

title: The Grey
description: Mashama Bailey, a Prune alumna, takes the helm of a new restaurant in a former bus depot in Savannah, Ga.

title: At the Grey in Savannah, History Takes Another Turn
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  A few days before she drove into town to run the kitchen at the Grey, one of the most talked-about new restaurants in the country, Mashama Bailey treated herself to an eating tour of the South.

title: Hillary Clinton Assails Mike Huckabees Remarks on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, on being asked for her reaction to comments by former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, who said the international nuclear deal made with Iran will lead Israelis to the door of the oven.

title: Converting the Drachma at the Drop of a Hat
description: How the economy could switch over to the drachma currency.

title: Tempting Offer Could Mean End of a Brooklyn Longshoremans Bar
description: There are ghosts in here, Amethyst Valentino said, holding up a photo on her cellphone as proof.

title: Private Equity Firms Raise Funds in Brazil Despite Challenges
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The private equity firm Hamilton Lane is raising its second fund of funds here from local investors, seeking 300 million reais, or about $90 million, according to a person with knowledge of its plans.

title: 1915: Belgian Artists Thank U.S.
description: A touching tribute of gratitude has been sent by the inhabitants of Lige to their American benefactors. The American Relief Committee packed foodstuffs for the city in canvas sacks, which were preserved by the recipients. The idea occurred to artists of Lige to ornament these sacks with decorative work and paintings and then to send them back to the United States. Among the artists taking part were MM. Pirenne, Duchteau, Rossenfosse, Marneffe and Neutier.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 28, 1915

title: A New Direction for Andrew McCarthy: A Novel
description: The actor Andrew McCarthy, who is best known for his roles in 1980s hits like Pretty in Pink and St. Elmos Fire, will publish his debut novel, Just Fly Away, with Algonquin Young Readers.

title: Derek Stepan Signs a Long-Term Contract With Rangers
description: In five seasons, center Derek Stepan has developed into a locker-room leader and big-game player for the Rangers. Stepan became a restricted free agent on July 1, and as the Rangers announced deals with their other restricted free agents, the likelihood of a rare arbitration hearing increased.

title: Obama Dances at State Dinner in Kenya
description: The president joined in the traditional Lipala dance made popular by the Kenyan pop group Sauti Sol on Saturday, during a state dinner held in his honor in Nairobi.

title: Varoufakis Tapes: Listen to Excerpts From Greeces Former Finance Minister on the Crisis
description: The Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum recently released an audio recording of a July 16 meeting with Yanis Varoufakis, Greeces recently departed finance minister.

title: Juan Camilo Makes Sure Dyckman Beer Measures Up
description: The first place Juan J. Camilo, the founder of Dyckman Beer Company, attempted to make beer was in the concise (as he puts it) kitchen of his one-bedroom co-op in the South Bronx.

title: The Donald and the Delusional
description: Nate Cohn cautions us not to make too much of the polls supposedly showing the Trump surge continuing, as many  but not all  were taken before the McCain affair. Fair point. But theres enough genuine post-McCain polling to show that Trump hasnt imploded, the way virtually every pundit predicted he would.

title: Lebanese Seethe as Stinking Garbage Piles Grow in Beirut and Beyond
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  On a normal weekend night, the revelers at Floyd the Dog, a bar in one of this citys rowdiest party neighborhoods, spill onto the sidewalk, drinks in hand, to smoke cigarettes in the warm Mediterranean air.

title: African Eggplants Grown in New Jersey
description: Organize a cluster of these African eggplants on your table and you have a centerpiece. But theyre also worthy of the skillet. Typical in Mali, Ivory Coast, Senegal and Guinea, these pumpkin-shaped cuties are now being grown in Vineland, N.J., from seeds imported by Global Bloom, an international produce company.

title: Contingency Plans
description: People are apparently shocked, shocked to learn that Greece did indeed have plans to introduce a parallel currency if necessary. I mean, really: it would have been shocking if there werent contingency plans. Preparing for something you know might happen doesnt show that you want it to happen.

title: Metropolitan Opera Streaming Service Expands to Roku
description: It is a little like having Netflix for Metropolitan Opera performances.

title: Obama, in Ethiopia, Calls Its Government Democratically Elected
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  President Obama twice called the government of Ethiopia democratically elected on Monday as he stood by the countrys prime minister, two months after elections that handed every seat in Parliament to the governing party and its allies.

title: The World Wide Web, the New Frontier in Fraud
description: Welcome to the latest frontier in white-collar crime, where just finding the criminals is often the greatest challenge.

title: Jeb Bush Scolds Mike Huckabee for Holocaust Comment
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Jeb Bush rebuked Mike Huckabee on Monday for invoking the Holocaust in criticizing President Obama over the nuclear agreement with Iran, arguing that Republicans needed to tone down the rhetoric if they hoped to recapture the White House next year.

title: Anoles Going Strong on Hispaniola Millions of Years Later
description: About 15 million to 20 million years ago, anoles were trapped in tree resin on what is now the island of Hispaniola, home to Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

title: Blame Uber for Congestion in Manhattan? Not So Fast
description: Uber is no longer jamming the New York airwaves with commercials explaining that its cars havent jammed the citys streets. And like a traveler trying to hail a taxi to La Guardia Airport at the 4 p.m. shift change, Mayor Bill de Blasio has given up  for now  trying to limit Ubers growth, something he had said was necessary to curb congestion.

title: Future Opens at No. 1
description: The Atlanta rapper Future opened at No. 1 on Billboards album chart this week with his latest release, DS2 (A1/Freebandz/Epic), which racked up the equivalent of 147,000 copies sold, counting both sales and streaming, according to Nielsen. DS2, the third studio album by Future  whose real name is Nayvadius Wilburn  was announced just a week before its release on July 17.

title: Cellular Cheaters Give Rise to Cancer
description: Maybe it was in some warm little pond, Charles Darwin speculated in 1871, that life on Earth began. A few simple chemicals sloshed together and formed complex molecules. These, over great stretches of time, joined in various combinations, eventually giving rise to the first living cell: a self-sustaining bag of chemistry capable of dividing and spawning copies of itself.

title: Obama Discusses Ethiopias Government
description: The president told Ethiopias leaders on Monday that allowing more political freedoms would strengthen democracy in the African nation.

title: Steve Jobs Gets Centerpiece Slot at New York Film Festival
description: Steve Jobs, the biopic starring Michael Fassbender as the Apple co-founder, has already generated a lot of anticipation, and now it has a high-profile festival berth to boot: on Monday, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced that the movie, directed by Danny Boyle from a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin, would be the centerpiece of the New York Film Festival.

title: Mimosa-Flavored Limoncello
description: Bob Fernandez combines grain alcohol, simple syrups and lemons with mimosa flowers to create a uniquely Southern drink.

title: If Pressure and Hovering Dont Help Children Succeed, Why Is It So Hard to Stop?
description: When Julie Scelfo set out to report Campus Suicide and the Pressure of Perfection, she expected to learn that todays college students faced new and different stresses than their forebears. Instead, she found pieces of a familiar story.

title: Verbatim: Yes, Mr. President, You and Donald Trump Do Share Something in Common
description: Zeresenay Alemseged, of the California Academy of Sciences, showing President Obama the bones of Lucy, the human ancestor from 3.2 million years ago found in Ethiopia in 1974. Mr. Obama laughed.

title: The Special Olympics World Games
description: The competition has grown into a global movement for equality, rights and dignity for the worlds most vulnerable population.

title: A Mother-Daughter Connection
description: Photos tell the story of Whitney Houston and Bobbi Kristinas relationship through the years.

title: The Upper East Sides Beachiest Vibes
description: On New Yorks Upper East Side, luxury is often less of a, well, luxury. Its simply whats for sale: Vintage lamps are sold beside Carolina Herrera gowns; Christian Louboutin shoes are a stones throw away from perfect peonies and Diptyque candles. But one newcomer boutique on Madison Avenue, LJ Cross, is serving up a different breed of luxury: one thats a little less precious, and with a seaside sensibility that belies the shops zip code. Its a rare sentiment for the neighborhood  which usually caters to a more buttoned-up sense of style  and comes courtesy of interior designer turned jewelry designer Lisa Jackson.

title: When Cancer Triggers (or Hides) an Eating Disorder
description: As Kathleen Emmets was undergoing cancer treatment in New York over the past few years, her weight began to drop. Even though she was often nauseated and paralyzed by chemotherapy-induced neuropathy, she joked that thinness was the bonus of cancer, and found herself looking in the mirror and admiring her deep and hollow collarbone.

title: A Portrait of Bobbi Kristina and Whitney Houstons Powerful Bond Emerges in Images Online
description: Few expect to salvage testaments to a mothers love from the tabloid slag heap. Yet news of the death of Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year old daughter of Whitney Houston and the singer Bobby Brown, sent some back to the scandal-sheet record  where much of her young life had played out against a train-wreck backdrop of drug and alcohol abuse, marital discord and the unremitting voyeurism of the paparazzi and reality television  and from there a click or two away to something surprising.

title: Review: Kristen Greens Something Must Be Done About Prince Edward County
description: One day in 1951, an African-American high school junior in central Virginia named Barbara Johns forgot her lunch and missed her school bus. When a half-empty bus with white children sped by her an hour later leaving her standing there, Ms. Johns, 16, decided something had to be done about the inferior treatment of black students.

title: Special Olympics Takes On the World
description: LOS ANGELES  If you want to see a world that takes equality seriously, then come to Los Angeles this week, for the Special Olympics World Games, which run through Saturday, at stadiums, ball fields, tracks and pools around the city. Take a seat in the stands and root for your country, or your common humanity.

title: F.B.I. Emphasizes Speed as ISIS Exhorts Individuals to Attack
description: WASHINGTON  In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, 2001, Justice Department officials, concerned that another attack was imminent, swiftly arrested many people, some of whom were only remotely suspected of having ties to terrorism.

title: Civil Rights Timeline
description: Civil Rights Timeline

title: Harlem Principal Said She Forged Test Answers, Education Dept. Says
description: The principal of a popular elementary school in Harlem acknowledged that she forged answers on students state English exams in April because the students had not finished the tests, according to a memorandum released Monday by the New York City Education Department.

title: Five to Follow
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Letters to the Editor
Review: Do No Harm, a Neurosurgeons Tales
description: Published in Britain last year, Dr. Henry Marshs Do No Harm: Stories of Life, Death, and Brain Surgery comes to the United States laden with well-deserved critical praise: The book is as complex, evocative and cannily crafted as any Masterpiece Theater production. Dr. Marsh, 65, is an eminent London neurosurgeon who looks back on a long career, effortlessly layering the technical details of his work with resonant emotional overtones. (Read an excerpt.)

title: Strong Showing for Summer Openings on Broadway
description: Its been a strapping summer for three of the four new shows of the 2015-2016 Broadway season, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers.

title: Fight Against Tropical Diseases Is Framed as Efficient
description: In the battle for the billions of dollars spent fighting global diseases, doctors who tackle neglected tropical diseases have labeled their struggle a best buy.

title: Mac & Cheese Fest in Chicago to Expand This Year
description: There will be more macaroni, more cheese and one more Golden Noodle Award, above, to present at this years Mac & Cheese Fest in Chicago. The event takes place Oct. 24 at the University of Illinois at Chicago Forum.

title: A Mimosa-Flavored Limoncello Recipe, Straight Out of Georgia
description: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of natures seasonal yield.

description: India and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Under the Influence
description: Dan Bejar, of Destroyer and the New Pornographers, shares the authors, filmmakers and others who have shaped his music.

title: La Guardia Airport to Be Overhauled by 2021, Cuomo and Biden Say
description: La Guardia Airport, whose dilapidated terminals and long, unenviable record of traveler delays have made it a target of jokes and complaints for decades, will be completely rebuilt by 2021, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday.

title: CFDAS Fashion Instagrammer of the Year, a Place to Buy Plants and the Magazine Ryan Roche is Reading
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Boston Mayor Wont Commit to Olympic Bid
description: The U.S. Olympic Committee terminated Bostons bid for the 2024 Olympics on Monday, hours after Mayor Martin J. Walsh said he would not commit to a deal that uses taxpayers dollars to pay for them.

title: Bad News for Climate-Change Deniers
description: Republican presidential candidates have generally refused to acknowledge the reality of climate change. New polls and a report issued last week show they arent helping themselves with business or voters.

title: July 27, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from India, Philippines, the West Bank and Lebanon.

title: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, Ex-President Who Pushed a Nuclear India, Dies at 83
description: NEW DELHI  Indias 11th president, A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, whose role in advancing Indias nuclear program made him one of his countrys most beloved figures, died on Monday after collapsing at an event where he was to deliver a lecture. He was 83.

title: Russian Liberal Who Aided Post-Soviet Overhaul Comes Under Attack
description: MOSCOW  Anatoly B. Chubais, one of the best-known architects of Russias post-Soviet economic overhaul, has come under attack from anti-Western hard-liners in the Russian government. The campaign against him appears to be the latest effort by powerful loyalists of President Vladimir V. Putin to cut liberal voices out of Russian public life.

title: Where to Go in Ballston Spa, New York
description: The village has its mineral springs, but also young artisans and entrepreneurs who have decamped here after being priced out of nearby Saratoga Springs.

title: Praluent Looks Cheap to Those With Extreme Cholesterol
description: The newly approved cholesterol-lowering drug, Praluent, is powerful almost beyond belief. It can drive levels of LDL cholesterol, the dangerous kind, into the 20s or even the teens, numbers almost never before seen in adults. In general, it lowers cholesterol by 50 percent to 70 percent, compared with 25 percent to 55 percent with statins.

title: Fetal Tissue From Abortions for Research Is Traded in a Gray Zone
description: Videos released by an anti-abortion group during the last two weeks have drawn attention to a little-known practice: the buying, selling and research use of fetal tissue acquired from abortion clinics.

title: Cities Still in the Running for the 2024 Olympics
description: Now that Bostons bid for the 2024 Summer Games is over, here is a look at the other cities eagerly seeking the Olympics.

title: Cuomo and Biden Unveil La Guardia Plans
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced a plan to completely rebuild La Guardia Airport in New York by 2021.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: Four hundred thirty-three hot air balloons lifted off on Sunday from an air base in Chambley-Bussires, France, to break the previous record for simultaneous hot air balloon flights.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on todays top stories.

title: Review: Nicki Minaj Raps Life Lessons at Barclays Center
description: Promise me that youll never let anyone steal your joy: Sunday night at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Nicki Minaj was convening her faithful, guiding them through whatever storms theyd been weathering.

title: Live and Kicking: Games to Watch This Week
description: Farewell Concacaf Gold Cup, with your dubious penalties and your match-fixing accusations and your huddled masses yearning to avoid corner-flag cup showers. Good riddance. Everyone back to your clubs.

title: Elaine Mayes: In the World and Always Photographing
description: The art world finally catches up with a photography teacher who was always looking, even when a bad break in her personal fortunes uprooted her.

title: Transportation Secretary Seeks Meeting With Cuomo and Christie on Hudson River Rail Tunnels
description: Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx, hoping to spur action on long-stalled plans for new Hudson River rail tunnels, sent a letter on Monday to the governors of New York and New Jersey urging them to meet with him in the next two weeks to map out a strategy for building new crossings.

title: Witness Recalls Afghan Wedding Shootout
description: One of the survivors of a shooting at a wedding party in northern Afghanistan spoke from his hospital bed on Monday, saying the violence stemmed from a dispute between two rival groups of gunmen.

title: Former Mayor Bloomberg Buys London Mansion for $25 Million
description: In the final weeks of her life, the novelist George Eliot retired to a redbrick mansion on Cheyne Walk, a charming road along the Thames in an aristocratic ward of London, where she died in 1880.

title: Google Loosens Ties to Google Plus
description: For many users, Google Plus accounts dont get all that many visits. Now, Google seems to be indicating it, too, will be paying less attention to its social network.

title: Newport Folk Festival Pays Tribute, With a Jolt, to Dylan and Seeger
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  This guitar that Im holding has been on this stage before, Taylor Goldsmith said at Fort Adams State Park during 65 Revisited, the grand finale of the Newport Folk Festival here on Sunday night. He was referring to the Fender Stratocaster played by Bob Dylan in a brief but rattling festival set 50 years ago, which delivered an electric jolt to the acoustic folk faithful, and one of the most fabled and contested moments in rock history.

title: Review: Doug Varones ReComposed, Inspired by Joan Mitchells Swirling Pastels
description: DURHAM, N.C.  When you look at a drawing by the Abstract Expressionist painter Joan Mitchell, what do the aggressive whorls and thickets of line suggest to you? The choreographer Doug Varone sees his own dances. That association  personal but not merely so, as expressed in a program note  is behind his new work, ReComposed, which had its debut at the Durham Performing Arts Center on Friday as part of the American Dance Festival here.

title: At Maccabi Games, Jewish Athletes Vie for Medals While Mindful of Past
description: BERLIN  When Nancy Glickman lights the torch for the 14th European Maccabi Games, being held for the first time in Berlin, she believes that her father, Marty Glickman, would have been proud of the honor  and the irony  of his legacy inspiring hundreds of Jewish athletes competing in the facilities that Hitler triumphantly presided over during the 1936 Olympic Games.

title: The Verbier Festival Revels in Mixing It Up
description: VERBIER, Switzerland  Martin Engstroem, the founder and general director of the Verbier Festival, leaves little to chance. But that little can sometimes loom large.

title: Issues Mount as Negotiators Gather to Wrap Up Trans-Pacific Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON  The top trade negotiators of the United States and 11 other Pacific nations are gathering this week at a luxury resort in Maui for one last push to complete the largest regional trade accord in history, roping together 40 percent of the worlds economic output.

title: Review: The Wreckers, a Tale of Piracy, Love and Betrayal
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  I want women to turn their minds to big and difficult jobs; not just to go on hugging the shore, afraid to put out to sea. Times have changed since 1902 when the composer and womens rights activist Ethel Smyth (1858-1944) wrote these words. But when it comes to the big and difficult job of writing opera, there are still few who follow in Smyths footsteps. To date, her one-act opera Der Wald is the only opera by a female composer the Metropolitan Opera has ever staged.

title: Metropolitan Museum Draws Record Crowds
description: Buoyed by strong international tourism, a spate of well-attended shows and a seven-day-a-week schedule, the Metropolitan Museum of Art drew 6.3 million visitors in the last year, the most since it began tracking these statistics more than 40 years ago.

title: Intersection | Montevideo, Uruguay
description: In a university neighborhood in Montevideo, the Uruguayan model Romina Di Bartolomeo buys second-hand clothes and imagines people wearing them at special moments in the past.

title: Deliveroo, an On-Demand Food Delivery Service, Raises $70 Million
description: For Will Shu, the idea behind his tech start-up grew out of frustration.

title: Manhattan D.A.s Office Appeals Goldman Programmer Case
description: The criminal case against Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer, just will not die.

title: Ex-Police Chief in Westchester County Pleads Guilty to Child Pornography Charge
description: Brian Fanelli was his police agencys computer maven, and in his spare time he taught children at a Roman Catholic church in northern Westchester County how to look out for sexually abusive behavior.

title: Police Identify Man Whose Severed Legs Were Found in New Haven
description: On July 15 in New Haven, a man led the police to a spot along a fence by the State Street train station downtown. There, in the thick foliage, was a pair of severed human legs.

title: Mets Trade for Athletics Tyler Clippard
description: Bobby Parnell stood on the mound at Nationals Park last week, stunned, as he watched the Mets lead slip away against Washington, their division rival. For the Mets, trying to push their way into the playoff race, it was a devastating sight.

title: Goals Diverge and Perils Remain as U.S. and Turkey Take on ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  In agreeing to cooperate to clear Islamic State forces out of a 60-mile-long strip of northern Syria along the Turkish border, the United States and Turkey have taken a major step toward increasing pressure on the militant group and easing their differences on the Syrian conflict.

title: Junior Seaus Family Renews Call for Daughter to Speak at Hall of Fame
description: The family of Junior Seau reiterated its stance Monday that his daughter, Sydney, should speak live and in her own words at her fathers induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame next month.

title: Boy Scouts End Ban on Gay Leaders, Over Protests by Mormon Church
description: The Boy Scouts of America on Monday ended its ban on openly gay adult leaders.

title: Hillary Clinton Lays Out Climate Change Plan
description: DES MOINES  Setting ambitious goals for producing energy from the sun, wind and other renewable sources, Hillary Rodham Clinton seized on an issue Monday that increasingly resonates with Democratic voters and sets up a stark contrast with the Republican presidential field.

title: Muslim Image-Makers, Made in Moscow
description: In Russia, some Muslims want to create a more positive image of Islam. A fashion designer, a public relations adviser and a composer all work toward the same goal.

title: Muslims in Moscow Work to Break a Stereotype
description: MOSCOW  Dozens of women dressed in colorful hijabs and floral dresses gathered under gray skies recently in the garden of a four-star hotel here for a charity fashion bazaar. They tried on styles from local designers and sampled new cosmetics, posing for selfies and dropping sunny filters on the images before posting them to Instagram and Facebook.

title: With New Leader, Changes Could Come to Cup Events
description: The international appeal and dramatic potential of the Davis Cup were on full display during the quarterfinals this month.

title: Turkeys Shift on the Syrian War
description: Late last week, Turkey significantly escalated its involvement in Syrias civil war by carrying out airstrikes against Islamic State targets in Syria and announcing that it would allow American military aircraft targeting the terrorist group to fly sorties out of Turkey.

title: A Letter About Rail Tunnels Under the Hudson River
description: A letter from Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx urging Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York to meet with him to discuss a plan to build new Hudson River rail tunnels.

title: Big Fine for Fiat Chrysler, Then Further Penalties to Set Example for Industry
description: DETROIT  Once Fiat Chrysler Automobiles admitted to widespread violations of vehicle safety laws, regulators decided to get creative in their punishment.

title: Can the Giant Stand on Its Own?
A Letter About Amtraks Gateway Program
description: A letter from transportation officials in New York and New Jersey expressing support for a plan to build new Hudson River rail tunnels.

title: Average Rise on Insurance Seen at 4% in California
description: WASHINGTON  Health insurance rates will rise next year by an average of just 4 percent in California, one of the few states that actively negotiate prices, state officials said Monday.

title: Family of Sandra Bland Seeks Answers With Multiple Inquiries Into Case Underway
description: CHICAGO  On the Friday before she died, Sandra Bland sent a joyful text to her older sister in Illinois, telling her that she had landed a job working with students at her alma mater, Prairie View A&M University, the historically black institution in East Texas where she had played trombone in the marching band and earned a bachelors degree six years ago.

title: Shigeko Kubota, a Creator of Video Sculptures, Dies at 77
description: Shigeko Kubota, who with Nam June Paik, her future husband, was one of the first artists to see the artistic potential of video technology, which she integrated in intensely personal sculptural works, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Bank of Americas Chief is the Captain of a Ship Becalmed
description: Just two weeks ago in a conference call with Wall Street analysts, Bruce Thompson, the chief financial officer of Bank of America, took a victory lap.

title: Lack of Pause in Yemen War Delays Aid
description: AMMAN, Jordan  A pledge by Saudi Arabia to halt its military operations in Yemen failed to stop ferocious fighting across the country on Monday as a humanitarian aid group warned that more than six million people were facing starvation because of the war.

title: A Creature on the Loose Puts Milwaukee Residents on Edge
description: MILWAUKEE  One man saw the creature for only a few bone-chilling seconds, but he remembers that it was big, with heavy brown fur and a long tail, and not in any particular hurry as it walked through his neighborhood in Milwaukee and then disappeared into a thickly wooded ravine.

title: Braves Take Unorthodox Approach to Overhaul
description: ATLANTA  Phil Gosselin was working out at the Atlanta Braves complex near Orlando, Fla., last month, on the rehab trail from an injury to his thumb, when he took a phone call from John Coppolella, the assistant general manager, who told him he had been traded to the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: Problems Plague System to Check Gun Buyers
description: His family called him unstable and violent, so John R. Houser was ordered by a judge to be taken against his will to a mental hospital in 2008. Despite that sign that Mr. Houser was mentally troubled, he passed a background check and was able to legally purchase the gun he used last week to kill two people in a Louisiana movie theater, because that hospital stay was not defined by officials as an involuntary commitment.

title: Hillary Clinton Aim Is to Thwart Quick Buck on Wall Street
description: While Washington and the media were worked up about Hillary Rodham Clintons emails last Friday, most of the nation seemingly missed  or at least largely ignored  what may have been her most important comments yet about how she plans to transform Wall Street and corporate America.

title: Review: Helen Kellers Words and Seven Actors in Three Days to See
description: Helen Keller had a brief stage career. This might sound like a joke. It isnt. In the 1920s, she toured the vaudeville circuit with Annie Sullivan, swanning around in sequined dresses while demonstrating her accomplishments and cracking jokes about drink and politics. A review in The New York Times effused, Helen Keller has conquered again.

title: Todays Soccer Gear: Shorts, Cleats, Shinguards and a GPS Unit
description: Over a 90-minute soccer match, Swedens Zlatan Ibrahimovic makes dozens of feints, false starts, and other fine movements in an attempt to free himself from opposing defenders. Each motion requires Ibrahimovic to accelerate, and then decelerate, his 209-pound frame forward or backward, left or right. Each effort takes a toll on his body that Paul Balsom, the head of performance for the Swedish national team, cannot track.

title: What Jab? Mayor de Blasio and Council Speaker Move Past a Disagreement Over Uber
description: They shared an aside in hushed tones, the mayor bending down to her ear. She wore a blue suit; he wore a bluish tie  a sartorial likeness that made them look as if they were headed to prom.

title: An Outpouring of Support as Two Towns Mourn Lafayette Shooting Victims
description: FRANKLIN, La.  Residents of this tightknit region known for its Cajun music and sugar cane farms came together Monday to say goodbye to two of their own.

title: As the G.O.P. Base Clamors for Confrontation, Candidates Oblige
description: WASHINGTON  For Senator Ted Cruz to call his partys leader, Senator Mitch McConnell, a liar as he did Friday and again Sunday in the Senate was an extraordinary personal attack, but given how much the conservative base of the Republican Party has come to loathe its leaders, it was also good politics for the struggling presidential candidate.

title: House Approves Expansion of S.B.A. Loan Program
description: A popular government-backed small-business lending program, suspended last week after reaching its limit for the year, is on the verge of restarting.

title: South Korea: Government Declares End to MERS Outbreak
description: South Koreaon Tuesdaydeclared ade facto end to an outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome that has infected 186 people, killing 36 as well as scaring away foreign tourists and temporarily shutting down thousands of schools. South Koreas outbreak was the largest outbreak outside Saudi Arabia, where the virus, known asMERS, first emerged in 2012. Since the first South Korean patient tested positive onMay 20, the quick spread of the disease has exposed loopholes in the countrys infection-control abilities: overcrowded emergency rooms, frequent visits to hospitalized patients by relatives and friends, and the governments failure to share information with doctors and the public. It is the view of the medical community and the government that it is O.K. for the people to feel safe, Prime MinisterHwangKyo-ahnsaid Tuesday. The country has reported no newcases in the past two weeks, the maximum incubation period for the virus.

title: Editors Note: Clinton Email Coverage
description: Update, Aug. 20, 2018:  Subsequent developments and later reporting by The Times shed additional light on these events. New details emerged in April 2017 in this Times account of James B. Comeys handling of the Clinton investigation, as well as in Mr. Comeys own book, published in April 2018.

title: Review: King Liz, at the Top of Her Game and Wanting More
description: As portrayed with fierce and compelling focus by Karen Pittman, Liz Rico, the heroine of King Liz, a new play by Fernanda Coppel, is as powerfully smart as she is powerfully sexy. Also just plain powerful, at least in the realm of sports-agenting, where she has nearly reached the pinnacle. Ms. Coppels engrossing if sometimes formulaic drama, at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of Second Stages Uptown summer season, explores the pressures that Liz comes under as an independent black woman in a field generally dominated by  well, not black women, independent or otherwise.

title: In a Hurry
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! Lollapuzzoola 8 is happening on August 8, a Saturday in August. This is the most fun you can have with a sharpened pencil, honest. You can play solo, with a friend, or from home. Get registered by clicking here.

title: Jabbing at Republican Rivals, Jeb Bush Calls for Civility
description: LONGWOOD, Fla.  The first Republican presidential debate is just over a week away, but one could have easily concluded on Monday that Jeb Bush was sounding out themes for a face-off against Hillary RodhamClinton.

title: N.S.A. Will Not Be Allowed to Keep Old Phone Records
description: WASHINGTON  Analysts at the National Security Agency will no longer be permitted to search a database holding five years of Americans domestic calling records after Nov. 29, the Obama administration said on Monday.

title: , Made in Moscow
description: .   ,    ,       Instragram  Facebook.

title: George Washington University Drops Sat and Act Scores for Applicants
description: George Washington University will no longer require most applicants to submit SAT or ACT test scores to be considered for undergraduate admission. The new policy, announced by the school on Monday, makes George Washington one of the largest colleges in the nation to adopt a test-optional policy. The change takes effect on Aug. 1 and will apply to the 2016-17 school year. It was made in response to the recommendations of a university task force formed in 2014 to explore ways to expand higher education opportunities for low-income students. The testing requirement will still apply to applicants who are home-schooled, those who come from high schools that provide only narrative evaluations, college athletes and students applying to a seven-year program for aspiring physicians.

title: Airport Redevelopment Could Mean New Life for a Jet Age Landmark
description: With the addition of two new wings, Eero Saarinens T.W.A. Flight Center at Kennedy Airport  a lyrical landmark in search of an everyday purpose  might finally reopen to the traveling public for the first time since Trans World Airlines went out of business in 2001.

title: Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking Among Hundreds to Urge Ban on Military Robots
description: Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, along with hundreds of artificial intelligence researchers and experts, are calling for a worldwide ban on so-called autonomous weapons, warning that they could set off a revolution in weaponry comparable to gunpowder and nuclear arms.

title: The Authors, Musicians and Broadway Musical That Inspire Dan Bejar
description: The man who makes music as Destroyer has played many parts over his career  a dream lover, a Spanish-language crooner and a New Pornographer. But the Dan Bejar who met T in the back of a Brooklyn bar one evening in early July has shed those guises in favor of something simpler: a guy who wants a cold beer before his flight back to Vancouver. I have a very functional approach to booze, says the 42-year-old musician as he sips his Dogfish Head Pilsner. Which kind of disallows me from becoming a connoisseur.

title: A Spritz of Citrus: 10 Fresh, Summery Scents
description: Whether planning a Mediterranean vacation or just trying to beat the city heat in August, theres something refreshing about trying on a new, lighter perfume this summer. These 10 airy citrus scents are easy to travel with  and will lift your mood long after the dog days are over.

title: Stripe, Digital Payments Start-Up, Raises New Funding and Partners With Visa
description: Stripe is gaining more financial allies to help it take on the digital payments industry.

title: N.E.H. Announces First Public Scholar Grants
description: A biography of One World Trade Center, a study of the cinematic legacy of Casablanca, and a cultural history of the Book of Revelation are among the 36 projects supported by the National Endowment for the Humanities new Public Scholar program, the agency is to announce on Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day: July 28, 2015
description: Best of all, its not a plan, its not a sketch, its not a dream, its not a vision. It is actually happening.

title: A Big-League Presence
description: Haverford College, outside Philadelphia, has become a pipeline to a career in the baseball industry.

title: On His 40th Birthday, Alex Rodriguez Blows It Out With a Swing
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  For all the years that Alex Rodriguez was the Yankees carnival act, a ballplayer who seemed to create as many headlines with his behavior as he did with his bat, who would have figured this?

title: Chinese Markets Uneasy After Huge Sell-Off
description: HONG KONG  Instability continued to roil Chinas stock markets on Tuesday in spite of new pledges of support from the government.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 1:40 A.M. (Showtime2) CITY OF GOD (2003) It was built as a housing project in the 1960s, the salvation of some of Rio de Janeiros impoverished residents. Twenty years later it had become a violent, drug-riddled favela. In this scorching Oscar-nominated drama (starring Alexandre Rodrigues and Alice Braga), Fernando Meirelles and the films co-director, Ktia Lund, use children from the slum to tell the tale of two young men struggling to escape its lethal hold. As the movies frenetic visual rhythms and mood swings synchronize with the zany, adrenaline-fueled impulsiveness of its lost youth on the rampage, you may find yourself getting lost in this teeming netherworld, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. To experience this devastating movie is a little like attending a childrens birthday party that goes wildly out of control. You watch in helpless disbelief as the apple-cheeked revelers turn into little devils gleefully smashing everything in sight.

title: Sanofi to Join Regeneron in Quest to Unleash Immune System on Cancer
description: The French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi will pay at least $1.7 billion to enter a new collaboration with Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, this one aimed at developing drugs that harness the bodys immune system to fight cancer.

title: Editors Note: July 28, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: How Changing Attitudes Went Along With a Drop in Calories
description: Fifteen years ago, in July 2000, a Newsweek cover depicted an overweight boy clutching a giant, melting ice cream cone. Fat for Life? read the headline.

title: Elaine Mayes: In the World and Always Photographing
description: My most enduring memory of my photography teacher Elaine Mayes in the late 1970s was that she was continually making pictures without much concern about the reception the work would get.
