title: The Challenges That Remain After Marriage Equality
description: Its tempting to regard last months Supreme Court ruling legalizing same-sex marriage as the coda of the gay rights movement. The joyous celebrations it prompted around the nation had an air of finality for the broader effort set in motion decades ago by the trailblazers who demanded to be treated with dignity.

title: Americas Obligation to South Sudan
description: There was no way President Obama could travel to East Africa and not make an effort to resolve the tragedy that is South Sudan, though the prospects for a solution are bleak.

title: Todays Exhausted Superkids
description: There are several passages in the new book Overloaded and Underprepared that fill me with sadness for American high school students, the most driven of whom are forever in search of a competitive edge. Some use stimulants like Adderall. Some cheat.

title: For the Mideast, Its Still 1979
description: I started my career as a foreign correspondent in Beirut in 1979. I didnt know it at the time, but 1979 turned out to be one of the great vintage years for foreign news  particularly from the Middle East. It set in motion the most important dynamics still shaping that region today. In fact, its been 1979 for 36 years. And the big question about the Iran nuclear deal reached this month is, Will it ultimately be a break from the history set in motion in 1979, and put the region on a new path, or will it turbocharge 1979 in ways that could shake the whole world?

title: To Fix the Fed, Simplify It
description: PHILADELPHIA  IN 1935, President Franklin D. Roosevelt wanted to fundamentally restructure the Federal Reserve System. The first wave of New Deal reforms had expanded the Feds emergency powers. But in this second wave, Roosevelt sought something more enduring. He didnt want to change the way the Fed operated day to day, but rather who controlled its levers of power.

title: Stop Hiding Police Misconduct in New York
description: A state judge in Manhattan acted in the public interest this month when she ordered the city to release a summary of substantiated misconduct findings against the police officer who used a chokehold against Eric Garner last year during an arrest that led to Mr. Garners death.

title: How Germany Prevailed in the Greek Bailout
description: BERLIN  At the height of crucial negotiations over the latest bailout of Greece this month, Germany circulated a proposal that undercut decades of promises about the march toward deeper European unity: Greece, it said, could be offered a temporary exit from the euro.

title: Helping Chinas Mentally Ill and Their Families
description: Yuyang Liu, who documented the lives of the severely mentally ill and their families in China, has won the Ian Parry scholarship that recognizes young photographers at the beginning of their career. The award is named for the Sunday Times photographer who died at the age of 24 in a 1989 plane explosion while covering the Romanian revolution.

title: Signs of War Crimes Seen in Israeli Hunt for Ambushed Soldier
description: KFAR SABA, Israel  It took Second Lt. Hadar Goldins comrades a few minutes to discover that he was missing after a burst of gunfire on the outskirts of Rafah, in southern Gaza, pierced a painstakingly negotiated truce that was barely an hour old.

title: Barclays Pledges to Accelerate Overhaul as Profit Rises
description: LONDON  Barclays reported improved second-quarter earnings on Wednesday, but its new chairman said the lender would speed up its overhaul, curtail marginal activity and leave its 2015 dividend the same.

title: Beyond Green Eggs and Ham
Rutherford, N.J., Quiet Outpost Beyond the Tunnel
description: Sriram and Hema Sridharan were living in Jersey City and working in Manhattan when they decided they wanted to move to a less crowded place.

title: A Dream Undone
description: On the morning of his wedding, in 1956, Henry Frye realized that he had a few hours to spare before the afternoon ceremony. He was staying at his parents house in Ellerbe, N.C.; the ceremony would take place 75 miles away, in Greensboro, the hometown of his fiance; and the drive wouldnt take long. Frye, who had always been practical, had a practical thought: Now might be a good time to finally register to vote. He was 24 and had just returned from Korea, where he served as an Air Force officer, but he was also a black man in the American South, so he wasnt entirely surprised when his efforts at the registrars office were blocked.

title: The Dying Grass, by William T. Vollmann
description: One alluring aspect of the novel form is that every one is simultaneously too large and too small. When we are writing and reading a novel, it can overwhelm us with feelings and ideas  but no novel, and no author, can ever encompass a real experience; every author must eventually give up and close the book (the manuscript, the file, the trilogy, the series). William T. Vollmann, whose Europe Central won the National Book Award in 2005, is undaunted, though; he has certainly tried as hard as any living writer to convey the grandeur of real experiences, many of them cruel, some of them inspiring.

title: Junior Seaus Family Silenced by a Policy Not Found at Other Halls of Fame
description: When three dead men  an umpire, a team owner and a player  were inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2013, relatives delivered speeches at the enshrinement ceremony in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: The Birds and the Bees as Seen at 15, in The Diary of a Teenage Girl
description: The question that the women behind The Diary of a Teenage Girl had been dreading came during a Q. and A. session at a screening in a Park City, Utah, mall two days after the films triumphant premiere at Sundance.

title: Bloomberg Is No Longer Mayor, but His Schools Agenda Thrives in Albany
description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been out of office for a year and a half, but his influence over New York schools is practically as strong as ever.

title: Facebook Expands in Politics, and Campaigns Find Much to Like
description: WASHINGTON  When Gov. Scott Walker kicked off his presidential bid this month, supporters who visited his website could view photographs of him, peruse his announcement speech and read about the Wisconsin Republicans life and accomplishments.

title: Solvay of Belgium to Buy Rival Cytec Industries for $5.5 Billion
description: LONDON  The Belgian chemical company Solvay said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire its American rival Cytec Industries for $5.5 billion in cash.

title: R.B.S. Sells $2.2 Billion in Shares of Citizens Financial Group
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday that it had sold $2.2 billion in shares of the Citizens Financial Group, an American retail bank, in a larger-than-expected offering as it further reduces its stake in the lender.

title: How Many Times Has Your Personal Information Been Exposed to Hackers?
description: Find out which parts of your identity may have been stolen in major hacking attacks over the last several years.

title: A Way to Get Fit and Also Have Fun
description: Can exercise that is intense also be fun?

title: Wednesdays Travel News: Noma Goes to Sydney; LOT Expands in the United States
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Airlines Give In-Flight Entertainment Options an Update
description: With more in-flight entertainment than ever, the longest flights can often seem short these days. On a recent trip to Hong Kong on Cathay Pacific, for example, I could build a list of video favorites from more than 100 movies, with options ranging from new Oscar nominees like American Sniper and Mr. Turner to classics like Casablanca.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: You Get What You Pay For, Sometimes
description: Housing fees tend to reflect housing quality.

title: New York Today: Ride the Heat Wave
description: Good morning on this sun-baked Wednesday.

title: Migrant Crisis in Calais Worries Cameron
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said his government was working closely with the French authorities to secure the city, where thousands of migrants have tried to enter the Channel Tunnel.

title: Dorms Youll Never See on the Campus Tour
description: Nap pods and gaming arcades. Walk-in closets and private bathrooms. Rooftop pools and maid service.

title: Malik Ishaq, Anti-Shiite Leader in Pakistan, Is Killed Trying to Escape, Authorities Say
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leader of a banned Sunni extremist group that is believed to have killed hundreds of Pakistani Shiites in a series of bombings died in a shootout Wednesday after supporters tried to free him from police custody, the Pakistani authorities said.

title: Laurent Fabius, French Foreign Minister, Visits Iran
description: TEHRAN  The French foreign minister arrived in Tehran on Wednesday, the latest in a string of visits by officials from European countries seeking closer economic and political ties with Iran after the nuclear agreement this month.

title: Lone Star Agrees to Buy Quintain of Britain for $1.1 Billion
description: LONDON  The private equity firm Lone Star Funds has agreed to acquire the British property investment company Quintain Estates and Development for 700 million pounds, or about $1.1 billion, in cash, the companies said on Wednesday.

title: Building a Khan Academy for Health Care
description: Doctors dont like to talk about death, and they often avoid doing so. Most physicians  including me  never studied palliative care in medical school and were rarely trained in how to communicate with patients. By the time I finished residency in 2002, I had to show competency in running Code Blues, inserting arterial lines and performing lumbar punctures, but not a single senior physician had to certify that I could actually talk with patients.

title: Today in Politics: Candidates Court Labor Group, Which May Wait to Reciprocate
description: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where President Obama is back from Africa and will immediately return to pressing Congress to support the nuclear deal with Iran. Several of the Democratic candidates, and Mike Huckabee, will start appearing before a gathering of organized labor, honing their best arguments for why they are deserving of the groups endorsements.

title: Morning Agenda: A Flutter Over Twitters Growth
description: A FLUTTER OVER TWITTERS GROWTH | Most people dont see the point of Twitter, and its becoming a big problem for the company, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times. Twitter executives acknowledged the issue on Tuesday: It has huge name recognition but the vast majority of potential customers do not understand how or why to use the service, stunting its growth. Even regular users are checking the network less than they were before.

title: What Can I Do About a Neighbors Partying Child?
description: I live in a neighborhood of predominately single-family homes in Southern California. On our block, most homes have garages that lead to an alleyway shared by homes on the other side. One neighbor is a single parent with three children, one of them a junior in high school. When they first moved in last summer, this adolescent was using the converted garage as an area for social gatherings. Multiple teenagers parked their cars in the alley, which is expressly forbidden by posted signs, and engaged in underage drinking. The mother was approached and essentially told us that we should talk to her child because she has been ineffective. This summer, although the cars are no longer in the alleyway, the partying has resumed: Our trash can was filled with beer cans this morning so that the parent would not be aware. I think this is an accident waiting to happen. The police have taken reports, but the behavior is unchanged. What would you do? I was so angry this morning, I wanted to dump the evidence on her front porch. NAME WITHHELD

title: The Miracle of Preserves
description: For as long as I can remember, I have had an unfathomably strong affection for pickles and potted meats and jellies and jams. I was thrown into the preserving pond early. I sat as a toddler, I am told, several summers running, in the cool shade of a tidy old trailer in Canaan, Me., playing with snails as the mobile homes fleshy mistress, Louise, taught my mother to select cucumbers and beets and pole beans from a dense trailer-side garden  packing them into heavy glass jars and then gently heating them in a worn tin pot.

title: UPS Agrees to Buy 46 Million Gallons of Renewable Diesel
description: For years, companies that rely heavily on fuel have experimented with substitutes for conventional gasoline and diesel, including natural gas, electricity and biofuels.

title: Taliban Leader Mullah Omar Died in 2013, Afghans Declare
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After months of speculation, Afghan officials announced Wednesday that they were now certain that the Talibans reclusive leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, died in a Pakistani hospital in 2013.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 545  548
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 545  548

title: Obama, on Chinas Turf, Presents U.S. as a Better Partner for Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Without ever quite saying so explicitly, President Obama used his four-day trip to Africa to suggest that the United States offers an alternative to Chinas aggressive courtship of the continent.

title: Carlyle Profit Slips, but Tops Forecasts
description: The Carlyle Groups profit fell in the second quarter, but the private equity behemoth still exceeded expectations, bringing in more cash from the sales of stakes in companies it owns.

title: Court Fight Presents Risks for Tom Brady and N.F.L.
description: On its often twisted six-month journey, the N.F.L.s case against Tom Brady and the New England Patriots has included a coach lecturing the news media on the physics of air pressure, an influential owner lashing out against the league he helps run and a star player denying all charges with a smile.

title: Amateur Video of Cecil the Lion
description: Footage captured as recently as 2012 shows Cecil, the beloved lion who, Zimbabwean officials say, was lured out of a sanctuary and killed by the American hunter Walter J. Palmer.

title: Erdogan Rules Out Peace With Kurds
description: The Turkish president said on Tuesday that it was impossible to continue a two-year-old peace process with Kurdish militants.

title: An Aroma From the Past
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Feds Button on the Economy
description: When it comes to raising or lowering interest rates, what the Fed is really trying to do is balance growth and inflation. But they have a limited set of tools to accomplish their goal.

title: $650,000 Homes in Philadelphia,Florida and Tennessee
description: VERO BEACH, FLA.

title: Who Should Be Allowed to Compete as a Female Athlete?
description: Should the size and shape of a womans breasts be considered factors in whether she is allowed to participate in elite athletic competitions like the Olympic Games? It sounds a bit ridiculous, but since 2011, breast size and shape have helped determine whether a woman may have testosterone levels deemed too high to be allowed to compete with other women.

title: Michael Shannon Rounds Out the Cast of Long Days Journey
description: The Oscar-nominated actor Michael Shannon (Revolutionary Road) will return to Broadway next spring to play James Jr., the elder son of the troubled Tyrone family, in the Roundabout Theaters revival of Eugene ONeills Long Days Journey Into Night, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Shannon will join the previously announced cast of Jessica Lange and Gabriel Byrne as Mary and James Tyrone and John Gallagher Jr. as their younger son, Edmund.

title: Fall for Dance Festival to Have Premieres from Tanowitz and Dorrance Dance
description: Premieres from Pam Tanowitz and Dorrance Dance, as well as performances from principal dancers in some of the worlds best-known ballet companies, are in store for New York City Centers Fall for Dance festival.

title: Daily Report: The Tough Realities of a Twitter Turnaround
description: Jack Dorsey, Twitters interim chief executive, tried to bring some different elements to the social media companys quarterly results on Tuesday, including by live video-streaming the earnings call for the first time through Twitters Periscope app.

title: House Hunting in ... Britain
description: A SIX-BEDROOM FARMHOUSE IN NORTH YORKSHIRE

title: State Growth Versus National Growth
description: It still seems kind of incredible that Jeb Bush is running in large part on claims that Floridas growth during his governorship shows that he knows how to bring prosperity. In effect, hes saying Trust me  I presided over a giant bubble! Ive been pointing this out for a while; Jim Tankersley at the WaPo chimes in with pretty much the same point.

title: Fox Allows All Candidates, No Matter Polling, Into Lower-Tier G.O.P. Debate
description: Fox News has relaxed an important requirement for entry to its forum for the lower-polling candidates that will air before their main debate on Aug. 6.

title: Why December Is Looking Likelier for the Fed to Raise Interest Rates
description: More than seven years ago the Federal Reserve put its benchmark interest rate close to zero, as a way to bolster the economy. But that policy is about to change, perhaps this week.

title: No, Really, How Hot Is It?
description: On a July day north of 90, we decided to find out.

title: The Jane Birkin-Herms Fuss Needs to Be Put in Perspective
description: Jane Birkin appears to be vying with the Kardashians in an attempt to break the Internet. On Tuesday, she released a statement announcing that she had asked Herms to take her name off its famous Birkin crocodile bag. The companys chief executive at the time, Jean-Louis Dumas, named the bag after Ms. Birkin about 30 years ago, and it remains one of its best-sellers: an accessory practically synonymous with the brand.

title: Skirting Comedy Limits in Myanmar
description: MANDALAY, Myanmar  Emerging from behind a tawdry blue curtain in the garage of his three-story home here in Myanmars second-largest city, U Lu Maw made his way onto a makeshift stage to do what he does best: tell jokes.

title: Photos, Photos Everywhere
description: Flash back to the glory days of film photography: 2000. That year, Kodak announced that consumers around the world had taken 80 billion photos, setting a new all-time record. The explosion of digital photography has since rendered such statistics almost quaint. This year, according to the market research firm InfoTrends, global consumers will take more than one trillion digital photos.

title: 2016 Endorsements: How and Why They Matter
description: William Boss Tweed captured the importance of the nominating process when he said that he didnt care who did the electing, as long as he got to do the nominating. The choice of nominee can determine the future course and fortune of a party  such as whether it tilts right or left  and the likelihood of victory. No wonder the political scientist Nelson Polsby described nominating candidates as the central purpose of a political party.

title: Tate Britain Names New Director
description: LONDON  Alex Farquharson has been named the new director of Tate Britain, the countrys leading museum for British art.

title: 1890: Argentine Rebellion Crushed
description: LONDON  The Legation of the Argentine Republic in London received at half past nine oclock the following telegram from the Argentine Ministry of Finance: Buenos Ayres, July 29  10:55 A.M.  TheNational Government surprised by a military conspiracy pitted with the greatest accuracy, has had to face a serious armed struggle. The Government is completely victorious. The mutineers have capitulated. They deposit their arms and deliver up the arsenal and fleet. All rebellious superior officers will be dismissed and absolutely separated from the service. The troops return to their quarters in command of officers loyal to the Government.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 30, 1890

title: Opening of Ceramics Center Coincides With Crafts Revival
description: YORK, England  Perched on a shelf at York Art Gallery is a ceramic figure of a portly middle-aged man holding a magnifying glass. A new work by the ceramicist Peter Meanley, it depicts William Ismay, a librarian from the nearby city of Wakefield who devoted most of his spare time and money to collecting British studio pottery, which has been made by artisanal potters since the early 1900s.

title: Venice Film Festival to Have a Global Flavor
description: PARIS  Amos Gitais Rabin, The Last Day, a drama about the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel; a new film by Luca Guadagnino; a thriller by Atom Egoyan, and the directorial debut of the musician Laurie Anderson are among the 21films in competitionin the 72ndannual Venice Film Festival, the festival announcedon Wednesday.

title: Girls Are Born With Weaker Backbones Than Boys
description: Girls tend to be born with smaller and weaker backbones than boys, a new study has found, a finding that may have implications years down the road.

title: The Anatomy of a Christie Town Hall
description: Like many politicians, Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor, has a formula. Spoiler: It involves jacket tossing and wise words from his mom.

title: Chris Christies Town Hall:  Routine Spiced With Spontaneity
description: NEWPORT, N.H.  A circle of chairs, maybe a campaign sign or two, a stool with a few water bottles and a hand-held microphone.

title: Atlantas High Museum Names New Director: Randall Suffolk
description: The High Museum of Art in Atlanta announced Wednesday that it had selected Randall Suffolk, a longtime museum leader who is credited with transforming the Philbrook Museum of Art in Tulsa, Okla., over the last several years, to be its new director.

title: Criticism of Unvarnished Brings a Strong Times Defense
description: In a week in which The Times has garnered some valid criticism, it also came under heavy attack from the august New York Review of Books. It published a blog post by a former Times reporter, Richard Bernstein, criticizing last springs reporting project, Unvarnished, which vividly laid out the poor working conditions and illegally low pay of nail salon workers in New York.

title: Taxes on Digital Books Are Called Unfair
description: E-books, which according to PricewaterhouseCoopers represent a quarter to a third of consumer book sales in the United States and Britain, have largely failed to catch on outside English-language markets.

title: Bookshelf: Gone to the Beach
description: New picture books take children, animals and a T-Rex on getaways to the shore.

title: The More Scrutiny for Donald Trump, the Testier the Response
description: Is the spotlight finally getting too hot for Donald J. Trump?

title: Britain and France Scramble as Channel Becomes Choke Point in Migration Crisis
description: LONDON  They have reached Europe after often-treacherous journeys, usually across the Mediterranean. They have dodged the authorities as they made their way north toward their ultimate goal, Britain. But now, thousands of illegal migrants, refugees from war and poverty in Africa and the Middle East, find themselves bottled up at one final choke point in northern France: the entrance to the Channel Tunnel.

title: Kids in the Kitchen: Tomato-Watermelon Salad
description: Its not that we havent properly brainwashed our 3-year-old. We have. We do. She will tell you how important it is to make a rainbow on your plate, and she loves pointing out all the colors of her meal, but getting her to actually eat the rainbow these days is another thing.

title: A Harlem Tenement Was Her Neighborhood
description: Sometime in the next year, my childhood home is going to disappear. The building where I was raised, 602 West 132nd Street, is being torn down to make room for Columbia Universitys $6 billion Manhattanville campus expansion.

title: N.B.A. Pick From India Makes Entire Village Feel 7 Feet Tall
description: BALLO KE, India  In this sleepy Punjabi village, no one was surprised to see a seven-foot-tall Sikh farmer striding the narrow lanes toward the local Sikh temple on June 25. The farmer, Balbir Singh Bamrah, is a familiar presence in Ballo Ke, and something of a local curiosity.

title: Craig Robinson on Trading The Office for the Classroom in Mr. Robinson
description: Props to the students who got Craig Robinson  music teacher by day, aspiring comic by night  riled up.

title: Sandorkraut: A Pickle Maker
description: This short documentary profiles the queer farmer and food writer Sandor Katz, whose work in culinary fermentation transformed his relationship with life and death.

title: Charles Smiths Seattle
description: The wine producer selects his favorite places to drink and eat in the Emerald City.

title: Sandorkraut: A Pickle Maker
description: Since the beginning of time, humans have been fermenting our food. Sauerkraut, chocolate, beer, cheese: Because of fermentation these foods not only last longer  they are delicious. But although nearly every region of the world has cultivated its own unique fermentation traditions  and devoted eaters  the practice has all but disappeared from many modern households. This Op-Doc video profiles the man at the forefront of reviving the art of fermentation, a New Yorker turned homesteader named Sandor Katz (or Sandorkraut, as he is often known).

title: Steep Discounts a Boon for Customers, but a Gamble for Start-Ups
description: Jet.com, a well-funded new shopping site, opened to the public last week and celebrated the debut by sending reporters a big box of swag. I got a T-shirt with a company logo, fuzzy socks, stickers and $1,400 in oversize, fake $100 bills.

title: J. K. Rowlings Family History on Who Do You Think You Are?
description: On Sunday on the TLC genealogy show Who Do You Think You Are?, fans of Harry Potter can learn quite a lot about his mother  not Lily Potter, but his real mother, the writer who gave birth to him.

title: Sweden Spots a Russian Submarine, 99 Years Late
description: LONDON  The mystery vessel was found off the Swedish coast last week lying on the sea floor, its hatches closed. Cyrillic letters on the hull suggested it was Russian.

title: Preserving Koreas Kimchi
description: As Chinese kimchi producers enter the Korean market, Koreas national dish has been left with a kind of identity crisis.

title: Lincoln Center Honors Richard Lester With Retrospective
description: Richard Lesters 1968 film, Petulia, aimed dead center at the swinging 60s and hit the bulls-eye in evoking the disoriented historical moment of the Vietnam War, psychedelia and mod fashion, when everything seemed to be unraveling. To the delirious playfulness of his two Beatles musicals, Help! and A Hard Days Night, Mr. Lester added a new layer of grown-up chaos with this story of a divorced, floundering San Francisco surgeon (George C. Scott); a kooky, free-spirited British beauty (Julie Christie); and her abusive husband (Richard Chamberlain), adapted from a novel by Lawrence B. Marcus. With Nicolas Roegs phantasmagoric cinematography and fractured narrative style, which jumps forward and back, this bittersweet movie was way ahead of its time.

title: Uncertain Trade Path for South Koreas Kimchi
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The fate of South Koreas kimchi industry rests on whether China considers it pickled or not.

title: Tsipras Seeks to Avert Party Split as Greeces Creditors Arrive for Talks
description: ATHENS  As representatives of Greeces international creditors started arriving on Wednesday in the Greek capital for a new round of tough negotiations, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said the country would get relief from its huge debt burden as early as November. He also hit out at dissenters within his party, saying that securing a new bailout deal was a priority.

title: Sherie Rene Scott Stars in Whorl Inside a Loop
description: Sherie Rene Scott dazzled in Everyday Rapture, a loosely autobiographical musical based on her Mennonite upbringing that was well-received both on and Off Broadway several years ago. Now, as she did then, Ms. Scott has teamed up with the writer Dick Scanlan to create a show that stems from her experience. This time its the time she spent in prison.

title: Marilynne Robinson and Anne Tyler Among Booker Prize Nominees
description: Five American writers, including Marilynne Robinson, Anne Tyler and the literary agent turned debut novelist Bill Clegg, have been nominated for the Man Booker Prize, one of the most prestigious literary awards.

title: Disabling Video Autoplay on Twitter
New Releases From Bea Miller, Sublime With Rome and DonMonique
description: Bea Miller

title: Taking It Slow, Until She Took Charge
description: They didnt plan for things to turn out this way: both of them well past 50, both living with a parent in the houses they grew up in, never married, no children. Most people dont.

title: Patriots Owner Criticizes N.F.L.
description: Robert K. Kraft, owner of the New England Patriots, said on Wednesday that he had been wrong to believe the N.F.L. would exonerate Tom Brady in the scandal over deflated footballs.

title: Issue Project Room Names New Director
description: Issue Project Room, the avant-garde music and performance presenter, announced Wednesday that it had appointed a new executive director to help guide the renovation of its home in the former Board of Education building on Livingston Street in Brooklyn.

title: The Joyce Ballet Festival Features Indie Choreographers
description: A commission from a company is one way to make ballet; another is to strike out on your own. With its two-week Ballet Festival (formerly Ballet v6.0), the Joyce Theater spotlights independent choreographers, presenting six ensembles for two days each. BalletX, from Philadelphia, and Amy Seiwerts Imagery, from San Francisco, are full-time enterprises; others, like the Ashley Bouder Project, spring up intermittently. But all find ways to produce ballet on their own terms.

title: Purple Haricot Vert, Radish and Purslane Salad With Coconut Yogurt Dressing
description: At The Surf Lodge in Montauk, chef Chris Rendell shares the growing, harvesting and making of a beachside salad.

title: Move Over, Taxidermy: Contemporary Design Gets Lighter and Cleaner
description: The Contour coffee table by the Brooklyn-based design firm Bower is one sexy piece of furniture.

title: Overhauling La Guardia, an Airport With a Historical Name but a Tarnished Image
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has declared that the $4 billion rebuilding planned at La Guardia Airport in Queens will amount to replacing the airport in its entirety.

title: 1959 : Lee Harvey Oswald in Moscow
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: As Homes in West Bank Settlement Are Demolished, Netanyahu Approves More
description: JERUSALEM  After an Israeli court ruled on Wednesday that two apartment blocks in a West Bank settlement had been built illegally and ordered them demolished, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu authorized the immediate construction of 300 more housing units in the same settlement.

title: Spys Wife Applauds Husbands Release
description: Esther Pollard, the wife of Jonathan J. Pollard, an Israeli spy sentenced to life imprisonment in the United States, celebrated on Wednesday the decision to release him.

title: 1940: Rumania Is Given Deadline
description: BUCHAREST  Premier Ion Gigurtu returned here today [July 29] from Salzburg and Rome prepared to face the task of leading Rumania through one of the most difficult and critical periods in the countrys history. Germany has given Rumania until Sept. 15 to settle her territorial difference with Hungary and Bulgaria by direct negotiation, The Associated Press reported from Bucharest. Otherwise, the report said, the Axis powers will step in and impose their own settlement.  New York Herald Tribune, July 30, 1940

title: Review: Judith Bernstein Weaves Feminist Messages
description: Judith Bernsteins art has never taken any prisoners. In the early 1970s, she satirized male domination and its failings with wall-size drawings of round-headed screws. They were rendered in hefty strokes of charcoal that gave them both hair and rotary motion. They were unforgettable images  cartoonish one-liners perhaps, but expressing a fury that many women felt. They became an indelible part of the history of feminist art.

title: India Will Be Most Populous Country Sooner Than Thought, U.N. Says
description: Demographers have known for some time that the number of people in India would surpass the number in China, the two most populous countries in the world. But they did not anticipate that the change would happen so quickly.

title: Hey, Tom Brady, Heres How You Destroy a Cellphone
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell believes Tom Brady had his cellphone destroyed to eliminate evidence of his role in deflategate. Bradys assistant successfully damaged the phone enough to remove the thousands of texts and emails contained within, some of which might have been damaging to Bradys defense.

title: In Yussef El Guindis Plays, Personal and Political Are in Bed Together
description: The Egyptian-American playwright Yussef El Guindi has a lot on his mind these days.

title: Yahoo Offers New Mobile Chat Service Featuring Silent Video
description: Yahoo is quite late to the world of mobile messaging, but youve got to give the company some credit: The new chat service it finally debuted on Wednesday sure is different from the rest of them.

title: U.S. Importers and Greek Suppliers Stymied by Cash Controls
description: Ted Diamantis, an importer of Greek wines who is based in Chicago, has been helping his suppliers stock up on bottles, labels and printing ink. The barrels, though, have him worried.

title: Jail Video of Sandra Bland Aims to Dispel Rumors About Her Death
description: Sandra Bland is shown into a holding cell in a Texas county jail. She throws down bedding and sits. She is let out of the cell to be told details of her bond. And she makes a phone call, gesturing and wiping her eyes.

title: Readers React to News of La Guardia Airports Planned Overhaul
description: An article Tuesday in The New York Times on a proposal announced by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to renovate La Guardia Airport drew more than 400 comments from Times readers.

title: Chris Christies Personality Is Selling Point, but New Hampshire May Not Be Buying
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  He flew to this state immediately after announcing his presidential candidacy and burned nearly a half-million dollars on his initial ad purchase, directed at voters here. He has locked down the former state Republican chairman to lead his New Hampshire campaign. And he has already held more than a dozen town-hall-style events in the state.

title: Nearing Recess, House and Senate Put Off Difficult Battles Until Fall
description: WASHINGTON  Congress will slide toward its August recess this week by doing what every high school student dreams of: putting off the hardest projects until later.

title: University of Cincinnati OfficerIndicted in Shooting Death of Samuel Dubose
description: A University of Cincinnati police officer was indicted Wednesday on a murder charge in what a prosecutor called a senseless, asinine shooting of an unarmed man during a minor traffic stop. Officials say it was the first time such a charge had been leveled against an officer in the county.

title: Turkey Escalates Airstrikes on Kurdish Targets in Northern Iraq
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey stepped up its offensive against Kurdish militias in northern Iraq early Wednesday, pounding targets in six locations from the air, officials said.

title: App Smart | Essentials for Soccer Fans
description: Luckily for new American soccer fans, there is a mature market of apps that keep track of the latest professional soccer scores and news.

title: Video Feature: Putting the Soccer Pitch in the Palm of Your Hand
description: The championship won by the United States womens soccer team in the World Cup this month has made the sport a hot topic. To that end, there is already a big list of apps to help people learn more about soccer and to follow news about the game on their phones.

title: Catching Up With the OBannon Ruling, Soon to Go Into Effect
description: A federal judge issued a groundbreaking decision last summer when she found that the N.C.A.A. broke antitrust laws by preventing universities from sharing broadcast and video-game revenue with top-division football and mens basketball players.

title: A Summer Salad Recipe From the Surf Lodge
description: The fashion photographer and farmer Greg Kessler teams up with New York chefs to trace the trajectory of seasonal food, from its original source to a place on your table. This edition: chef Chris Rendell (the Surf Lodge in Montauk).

title: Albuquerque 911 Dispatcher Who Hung Up on Caller Quits
description: An Albuquerque 911 dispatcher who in June hung up on a teenage girl seeking help after her friend was fatally shot resigned on Tuesday after audio of the incident was released.

title: Nonpayment on Bonds Would Have Consequences for Puerto Rico
description: Debt-ridden Puerto Rico faces its next big test in just a few days, when $58 million in bond payments come due  and already the government is mounting a defense against the possibility that it will not have the cash.

title: Chaka Fattah, Pennsylvania Congressman, Indicted on Charges of Misuse of Funds
description: WASHINGTON  A veteran House member from Philadelphia, one of his staff members, a lobbyist and two others were indicted Wednesday by the federal authorities in connection with bribery schemes and the misuse of hundreds of thousands of dollars in federal, charitable and campaign funds.

title: Looking at van Gogh, 125 Years Later
description: Vincent van Gogh, the most mythologized of Impressionists, died 125 years ago. And he is the focus of two current exhibitions recently reviewed by New York Times critics.

title: Zvi Gotheiner, the Zen Dance Master of New York
description: Even in the depths of summer, when New York theaters close up shop and dance companies go on break or on tour, the ballet teacher Zvi Gotheiner keeps going to work, though he may not call it that. And dancers keep flocking to work with him.

title: September Is Looking Likelier for Feds First Rate Increase
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve remains on track to raise interest rates later this year, and perhaps as soon as its next policy meeting in mid-September, as economic growth continues to meet its expectations.

title: As New York Bakes: Its Late July. This Is What Its Supposed to Be Like.
description: The water was warm, the lifeguards were whistle-happy and the poolside pavement was packed. Beyond the usual irritants, a chunk of concrete had broken off the bottom of Douglas and DeGraw Pool in Brooklyn, which meant swimmers on Wednesday had to navigate a tangle of lane lines designed to protect them from the jagged patch.

title: Jets Return to Work With New and Old Concerns
description: The Jets reported to training camp Wednesday with a new coach, a new old friend at cornerback and the same uncertainty at quarterback. But you knew all that. Here are some facts and figures about the 2015 team that perhaps you did not know.

title: Driven | 2015 Honda Accord Hybrid
description: A family sedan with familiar looks packs a hybrid system quite different from the norm.

title: Video Review: Honda Takes Different Path With the Accord Hybrid
description: THE Honda Accord, now in its ninth generation, is the blue blazer of the automotive world: always in style but never fashion-forward. The conservative design still holds, even though it has been available as a hybrid and plug-in hybrid for the last year and a half.

title: De Blasio Finds a Kindred Spirit in the Mayor of Rome
description: ROME  Shortly after this citys mayor, Ignazio Marino, discovered bullet casings and a dead pigeon at his doorstep, a not-so-subtle message from the local mafia, he received a call from New York.

title: What to Do in Seattle: Tips From the Citys Wine Guru
description: As a four-prop plane drops low above his glistening new winery in Georgetown, the South Seattle neighborhood a mile from downtown and directly adjacent to Boeing Field, Charles Smith raises his voice above the noise. It just landed 300 yards from where were standing! he yells. Smith is Washington States fourth-largest wine producer; among his seven labels and dozens of varietals, a handful have received 100-point ratings from respected sources. But hes best known as the wine guy of the people  dedicated to making accessible and affordable wines  and, increasingly, as a symbol of bohemia in a rapidly gentrifying city.

title: As Medicare and Medicaid Turn 50, Use of Private Health Plans Surges
description: WASHINGTON  As Medicare and Medicaid reach their 50th anniversary on Thursday, the two vast government programs that insure more than one-third of Americans are undergoing a transformation that none of their original architects foresaw: Private health insurance companies are playing a rapidly growing role in both.

title: Cincinnati Prosecutor Discusses Indictment
description: Joe Deters, the Hamilton County prosecutor, said on Wednesday that a grand jury indicted Officer Ray Tensing for murder in the shooting of 43-year-old Samuel DuBose.

title: Congress Should Reauthorize the Export-Import Bank
description: Earlier this year, Tea Party ideologues managed to stop Congress from reauthorizing the Export-Import Bank of the United States, a federal agency that helps American businesses sell their products abroad. Closing down the bank has been an obsession with some conservatives who falsely insist that doing so would curb corporate welfare.

title: Killer of Cecil the Lion Finds Out That He Is a Target Now, of Internet Vigilantism
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn.  Two signs posted on the door of a nondescript dental office here asked passers-by to mourn the death of Cecil, a lion who was lured off his sanctuary and killed during a game hunt this month in Zimbabwe.

title: The Pivotal Scribe of 1980s New York Clubland
description: Looking back at Stephen Sabans legacy in New York.

title: Afghanistans Olympic Bocce Dreams [Updated]
description: Said Samiullah carries alone the weight of Afghanistans Special Olympics bocce tradition. He wears this burden lightly, because he is 15 and confident. And also because the tradition only began in 2012. His coach, Abdul Karim Azizi, saw bocce for the first time at the World Games in Ireland that year and thought, this looks interesting.

title: 2022 Winter Games Vote Down to Two Cities and Some Major Concerns
description: When the International Olympic Committee gathers Friday in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to name a host for the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, it will have a curious choice. Cities closely associated with winter sports, like Oslo and Stockholm, have fallen by the wayside, leaving only two unconventional finalists, both with significant flaws.

title: Former Club Kids Rally Around Stephen Saban, a Scribe of 1980s New York Culture
description: Anita Sarko, a D.J. at epochal nightclubs like the Mudd Club and the Palladium in the 1980s, recalled the time when a pudgy teenage boy spotted her in the West Village and acted as if he had just seen Marilyn Monroe return from the grave.

title: Debris Is Thought to Come From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
description: PARIS  American investigators have concluded that a large object that washed up Wednesday on the shore of Runion, a French island in the Indian Ocean, came from a Boeing 777, making it likely that it was debris from Flight 370, the Malaysia Airlines jetliner that disappeared in March 2014.

title: Five Daily Show Producers to Stay With Show
description: While The Daily Show will undoubtedly be different after Jon Stewart leaves and Trevor Noah takes over, Comedy Central signaled on Wednesday that there will be continuity from one host to the next by announcing that a team of five executive producers who have overseen the show during Mr. Stewarts tenure will stay on with Mr. Noahs incarnation of the program.

title: Video of Officer Shooting Driver in Ohio
description: Ray Tensings body camera captured him shooting Samuel DuBose during a traffic stop. This video has been edited to obscure the moment Mr. DuBose was shot in the head.

title: Rick Perry Challenges Hillary Clinton on Wall Street, and Donald Trump to Pull-Ups
description: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas criticized Hillary Rodham Clintons economic agenda on Wednesday and urged replacing the Dodd-Frank financial regulation bill.

title: In Power and Pathos, Faces Frozen in Time and Bronze at the Getty Museum
description: More than 2,000 years ago, artists of ancient Greece and Rome created sculptural representations of human beings that remain as striking for their anatomical and psychological realism as anything produced by Western artists since. The public does not often get to see many masterpieces of that time and place together, so Power and Pathos: Bronze Sculpture of the Hellenistic World at the J. Paul Getty Museum (and traveling to the National Gallery of Art in December) will be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for comparing and contrasting. The exhibition convenes more than 50 ancient bronzes from the Mediterranean region dating from the fourth century B.C. to the first century A.D. Among them is the famous Terme Boxer from the National Roman Museum, a nearly life-size representation of a muscular, bearded athlete seated in a state of exhaustion, his face bruised and bloody, his head turned to his right as if to ask his coach for advice or to plead with the gods for relief from his barbaric plight. (310-440-7300; getty.edu)

title: De Blasios Warning About the Heat Wave
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York warned about the dangerous effects of both heat and the overuse of electricity on Wednesday; temperatures in the city are expected to rise in coming days.

title: The Propaganda Campaign to Misrepresent Planned Parenthood
description: The Center for Medical Progress, a group apparently created to produce undercover videos targeting Planned Parenthood, released its third such video on Tuesday. The video makes the same allegation as the first two: that Planned Parenthood is engaged in the illegal sale of baby body parts.

title: Mike Huckabee Courts Labor in Rare Appearance by a Republican Candidate
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  Mike Huckabee, the conservative former governor of Arkansas turned presidential candidate, extended a hand to an unlikely audience on Wednesday: the leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the umbrella organization of the labor movement.

title: U.N. Envoy for Syria Seeks to Resume Peace Talks
description: The United Nations special envoy for Syria said Wednesday that he had invited a range of Syrians to participate in what he described as preparatory, separate discussions on how to restart peace talks after more than four years of war.

title: Review: In The Speechwriter, Barton Swaim Shares Tales of Working for Mark Sanford
description: As an unwitting participant in the Americas Craziest Governor contest of 2009, Mark Sanford of South Carolina bestowed many gifts upon the American people, some of them linguistic. There was the phrase hiking the Appalachian Trail, which really meant meeting my lover in Buenos Aires. There was the surreal effluence of words at the news conference following the nonhiking trip, which featured Mr. Sanfords rambling thoughts on his broken heart as well as his theatrical announcement that he had spent the last five days crying in Argentina.

title: Michel Platini Announces Candidacy for FIFA President
description: Michel Platini confirmed on Wednesday that he would run for FIFA president, writing in a letter to the leaders of the organizations member federations that he wanted to give FIFA back the dignity and the position it deserves.

title: Novartis Spinoff Shows Alternative to Big Drug Makers
description: Biotechnology investors can be better than big pharmaceutical companies at valuing and nurturing small drugs. Recognizing this, Novartis is spinning three drugs in development into a new entity backed by British investors. With biotech markets hot, theres room for copycat deals.

title: Top General Gives Pragmatic View of Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  While the nuclear agreement with Iran will not stop it from funding organizations the United States considers to be terrorist groups, the pact reduces the chances of a near-term military conflict between the two countries, the top American military leader, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, told Congresson Wednesday.

title: Official on New Yorkers Terror Arrest
description: William J. Hochul Jr., the United States attorney for the Western District of New York, announced that a man from suburban Buffalo was arrested on charges of trying to support the Islamic State.

title: 36 Hours on Marthas Vineyard
description: Lobster on the deck, sunset on the beach and long nights on the town are all part of Marthas Vineyard island allure.

title: 36 Hours on Marthas Vineyard
description: This summer marks 40 years since Steven Spielbergs Jaws made Marthas Vineyard a household name, setting off the islands inexorable transformation from remote haven of artists and hippies to high-profile haunt of celebrities and presidents. Yes, in summer, dinner and ferry reservations may be difficult to get, and traffic tests tempers. But what hasnt changed is what makes the island so magical: breathtaking natural beauty, rich ethnic heritage, a vibrant cultural scene and an abundance of farms and fisheries that feed a savvy foodie community. One thing you wont find: the popular Monster Shark Tournament, which was discontinued last summer, thanks in part to the shark activist wife, Wendy Benchley, of the Jaws author (and screenwriter), Peter Benchley. But youll still spot more artists, writers and hippies than you can shake a codfish bone at.

title: Hunt for California Girl Leads to a Body, and a Neighbor, 15
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  At the edge of this coastal California town known for its liberal bent and boardwalk amusement park is a cluster of big red barnlike structures that was supposed to be a freewheeling utopia of its own.

title: New Books From Louisa Hall, Christian Kracht, Juan Gabriel Vsquez and Others
description: TALKBy Linda Rosenkrantz215 pages. New York Review Books Classics. $14.95.

title: Review: John Pizzarelli Channels Paul McCartney and Antnio Carlos Jobim
description: John Pizzarelli, Paul McCartney and Antnio Carlos Jobim: now theres a musical dream team. And on Tuesday evening, that triumvirate occupied the stage of Birdland in spirit, if not in the flesh. A small orchestra that included a string quartet and four horns, augmented by three backup singers, completed the picture.

title: Comedy Centrals Review and Its Hapless Critic Return
description: Mainstream television comedies sometimes seem as if they are innovative only within relatively narrow limits. Families in domestic sitcoms are more diverse and more blended these days, but theyre still working the old families-acting-funny formulas. Workplaces in workplace comedies arent all white and male, but theyre still grounded in office dynamics.

title: Facebook Posts Solid Gains, a Feat Eluding Rivals
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Drama may be exciting, but consistency makes for better performance in the stock market.

title: Classical Playlist: Hindemith, Shostakovich and Dutilleux
description: HINDEMITH: The Long Christmas DinnerCamille Zamora, Sara Murphy, Jarrett Ott and other singers; American Symphony Orchestra; Leon Botstein, conductor(Bridge Records)Paul Hindemith rightly saw rich operatic potential in Thornton Wilders one-act play The Long Christmas Dinner, first performed at Yale University Theater in 1931. Wilders delicate, profound work follows the story of an American family over 90 years through periodic visits to Christmas dinners at the household table. Wilder, an astute music lover, readily adapted his play into a libretto for Hindemith, cutting the text considerably and providing some new rhymed lyrics for extended vocal pieces. Though well received, Hindemiths opera, completed in 1961, has become a rarity. The conductor Leon Botstein came to the rescue in 2014 when he conducted a fine cast and the American Symphony Orchestra in a beguiling staged production at Alice Tully Hall. (This fascinating program preceded the opera with a performance of the Wilder play by a strong cast of actors, using the same set.) Bridge Records has now released a live recording of the performance. We hear the highs and lows of the Bayard family discussed over Christmas dinners, starting from the first at the familys new house, when the matriarchal Mother Bayard beams as her son, who runs the family firm, slices turkey alongside his cheerful wife. Cousins come and go; children are born and have children of their own; one son dies in war; a child dies in infancy; an unmarried cousin comes to live; social mores and customs change. Its a special opera, and this performance sounds as good as I remembered it to be. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: India and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Chaka Fattah Denies Any Wrongdoing
description: Representative Chaka Fattah, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was indicted on charges of misuse of funds on Wednesday. Mr. Fattah denied all charges.

title: Youre Disgusting: A Trump Revelation Hiding in Plain Sight
description: Whats left to learn about Donald Trump, a man who has pursued the spotlight in the most relentlessly possible way?

title: July 29, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from India, West Bank, Italy and Egypt.

title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Tribunal for Malaysia Airlines Crash in Ukraine
description: UNITED NATIONS  Infuriating nations that lost citizens in the destruction of a Malaysian jetliner last year over eastern Ukraine, Russia blocked a Security Council resolution on Wednesday that would have created a tribunal to prosecute and punish those found responsible.

title: Donald Trump Calls Lawyer in Breast-Pump Incident a Horrible Person
description: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday called the lawyer who took out a breast pump in front him during a 2011 deposition a vicious, horrible person, even as he acknowledged his angry response to the incident.

title: Man From Buffalo Area Is Charged With Trying to Aid ISIS
description: As law enforcement increasingly focuses on stopping Americans from supporting the Islamic State, a man from the Buffalo area has been arrested and charged with trying to join the terrorist group.

title: Review: Paradise Blue Rekindles Racial Drama in 1949 Detroit
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Her name is Silver, but everything about her says noir: the slinky, hip-swaying gait; the voice  one part molasses, one part bourbon and cigarettes; the electric charge she sends through a room just by walking in.

title: Alexander Wang, Balenciaga and the Dismaying Trend of Leaks
description: Is Alexander Wang leaving Balenciaga? No one will say flat out he isnt. They wont even call it idle gossip. Designers in Paris have reported being approached for Mr. Wangs job.

title: India Executes Yakub Memon, Man Tied to 1993 Mumbai Bombings
description: NEW DELHI  Yakub Memon, the driving spirit behind a series of bombings in Mumbai that killed 257 people in 1993, was hanged early Thursday morning at a prison in central India.

title: So Much Like Humans, Only Better
description: Fashion has been especially quick to seize on the notion that robots are slicker, more perfect versions of ourselves.

title: Seeking a Middle Path in Hong Kong Politics
description: Read in Chinese |

title: 5 New Brands Expertly Reinventing Vintage Denim
description: Thanks to several new companies, old, worn-out jeans suddenly look very fresh.

title: Paradigm Talent Agency Enters Partnership With Windish
description: The Hollywood talent agency Paradigm has deepened its expansion into music through a partnership with the Windish Agency, one the most successful independent shops covering the world of indie rock and electronic music.

title: Treasury Secretarys Letter to Senator Hatch on Puerto Rico
description: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew advocated that Puerto Rico should have the ability to pursue federal bankruptcy procedures in a letter to Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: The Dangers of Partying in a Stretch Limo
description: Serious questions of passenger safety are finally catching up with stretch limousines, the larger than life vehicles popular for celebrating proms, weddings and other gala occasions. Five women burned to death in one two years ago in California, and the state legislature quickly enacted better escape requirements in response. There now must be extra emergency doors and push-out windows in the spacious rear compartments where passengers typically like to party while a hired driver has the wheel.

title: Fashion Finds a More Perfect Model: The Robot
description: In a recent episode of the AMC drama Humans, Toby Hawkins, a randy adolescent, engages in a bit of unseemly groping, reaching for Anita, the humanoid family housekeeper. When she turns him away, he glowers, asking her sourly, Why do you have to be so fit?

title: Prom Math: One Night, Five Prokofiev Concertos
description: LONDON  Flick through the advertisements in the glossy program book for Tuesday nights BBC Proms concert, the 14th one in this years festival at the palatial Royal Albert Hall, and one name stands out.

title: A Contemplative New Track (and Album) from the Brooklyn Indie Rockers Small Black
description: The inspiration for the indie dream-pop band Small Blacks new single, Boys Life, which premieres here, was an overwhelming archival project undertaken by the groups frontman, Josh Kolenik, in 2012: attempting to help clean out an old shed behind his fathers house in Long Island after Hurricane Sandy left it under five feet of water. In the melting boxes and floating Sega Genesis games, I found a slew of images and letters of my parents that Id never seen before  stuff that maybe nobody had seen in 20 to 30 years, Kolenik explains. I didnt know who a lot of the figures in the photos were, or who the letters were to, so I spent a week out there trying to preserve and figure out the story. With no power supply other than a small generator, he laid out nearly 1,000 photos to dry by the fireplace, then took them home to Brooklyn to blow-dry and try to make sense of them. I scanned all of them, bay bottom residue and all, and attempted to solve the mystery that often eludes, even as its right there in front of us: Where did I come from? Who made me?

title: Migrants Try to Walk Into Channel Tunnel
description: On Wednesday, for the third night in a row, migrants in France tried to enter the Eurotunnel illegally in order to get to Britain.

title: Benedict Cumberbatch, a Hamlet Whos One Hot Ticket in London
description: LONDON  Clare Newman was not taking any chances. If Benedict Cumberbatch was going to play Hamlet, she was going to be there.

title: In Atlantas Ever-Shifting Hip-Hop Scene, Future and Migos Keep Innovating
description: On Saturday, the durable Atlanta rap veteran Young Jeezy celebrated the 10th anniversary of his major-label debut album, Lets Get It: Thug Motivation 101, with an extravagant hometown concert. A decade may not seem like a long time to wait before revisiting your signature work, but in Atlanta, the white-hot center of hip-hop innovation for that whole stretch, time moves fast and can blithely leave you in the dust.

title: Hunter Appears in Zimbabwean Court
description: Theo Bronkhorst, a hunt organizer from Zimbabwe, appeared in court on Wednesday, charged with failing to prevent an amateur American hunter from killing the well-known lion Cecil.

title: James Grant of Five Star Is an Enforcer on Screen, if No Longer in Life
description: James Grant strolled through the Walt Whitman Houses in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, recalling his past as a drug dealer while pointing out where he played football and where the police caught him with a Tec-9 pistol after a foot chase. Now, he said, he is planning on acting lessons and a life with fewer burdens than being a leader of the Bloods gang.

title: Strike Back, on Cinemax, Returns to Overwhelm Bad Guys Everywhere
description: Strike Back returns on Friday night for its fourth and final season on Cinemax, and it keeps to the rules its followed through the first three. Every 15 minutes or so theres a loud, long gun battle, and once or twice an episode theres a wholly gratuitous sex scene. Women do a fair bit of the fighting, but the heroes are a pair of white men who trade tender insults while mowing down stunning numbers of third world bad guys.

title: James Gilmore, Ex-Virginia Governor, Files Papers to Run for President
description: And then there were 17.

title: Review: Mostly Mozarts Opening Concert, With a Chopin Encore
description: A graceful performance of Chopin does not normally require an apology. But on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall the pianist Emanuel Ax sounded a little sheepish when he announced that he would play Chopins Waltz No. 2 in A minor (Op. 34) as an encore. After all, this was the opening concert of the Mostly Mozart festival, and it had been planned as a nothing-but-Mozart affair.

title: Helen Gurley Brown Scholars Redefine Cosmo Girl
description: Given an opportunity on a recent Friday to tour a magnificent New York City four-story penthouse apartment sitting atop the Beresford, one of Central Park Wests most famous buildings, a group of 15 teenage girls did what teenage girls do: snapped a bunch of selfies.

title: Review: Benjamin Clementine Releases His Debut Album
description: BENJAMIN CLEMENTINE

title: Alex Olson Mixes Skateboarding and Fashion
description: Age 29

title: Review: Titus Andronicus Releases a Punk Opera
description: TITUS ANDRONICUS

title: Travel Diary
description: In Croatia with the designers of Dioralop.

title: Activists Demonstrate at Portland Bridge
description: As environmental activists floated in kayaks, others hung suspended from the St. Johns Bridge in Portland, Ore., in an effort to stop a Shell Oil arctic icebreaker from leaving for Alaska.

title: No Time Like the Present at Nowadays, in Ridgewood, Queens
description: After six years of giving nomadic parties across Brooklyn (Mister Saturday Night, Mister Sunday), the D.J.s Justin Carter and Eamon Harkin have landed at a permanent, albeit seasonal, outdoor home in Ridgewood, Queens. Last month, the duo opened Nowadays, a combination beer garden, grill and Ping-Pong arena.

title: Millennials Less Likely to Leave the Nest, a Pew Study Finds
description: During the recession near the end of the last decade, many young adults facing a dreadful job market moved in with their parents to save money.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on todays top stories.

title: Living in the Wild
description: Cecil in his natural habitat.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Mr. Fongs Is Chinatowns Unlikely New It Bar
description: In the hottest days of summer, the heat sends funk rising from the neighborhood fish markets, and directly overhead, in plain view, the subways rattle over the Manhattan Bridge every few minutes. Location, location, location, the real estate adage goes. But Mr. Fongs, a new bar at the forlorn corner of Market and Madison Streets in Chinatown, is packed every night, from 10 p.m. until it closes at 4.

title: The Shooting of Samuel DuBose
description: Samuel DuBose was a 43-year-old unarmed black man who was shot in the head and killed by a University of Cincinnati police officer, Ray Tensing, during a traffic stop a few blocks from campus.

title: Hamilton, Based on a Book, Is Becoming One Again
description: Lin-Manuel Mirandas raucous hip-hop musical, Hamilton, sprang from an unlikely source: a dense, 818-page biography of Alexander Hamilton by the historian Ron Chernow. Mr. Miranda picked up the book as vacation reading before a trip to Mexico, and soon after tearing through the first chapter, he had the idea to adapt Hamiltons life story into a musical.

title: A Drug Hits Cycling Before It Hits the Market
description: Recent positive drug tests by two cyclists suggest there is a new, cutting-edge substance making its way to athletes looking for performance-enhancement: FG-4592, an experimental drug that increases production of red blood cells but has not yet been approved for human consumption.

title: Beating the Heat in New York City
description: The temperature climbed into the 90s on Wednesday, sending residents to fountains and pools to seek relief.

title: In China, the Photobook as Art and History
description: An ambitious survey of Chinas rich and diverse history of photobooks represents a turning point in narrowing the comprehension gap between East and West.

title: The Killing of Cecil the Lion
description: To the Editor:

title: Add a Dash of Fall to Your Summer Look
description: Heavy knitwear and furry bits will be trickling into stores any day now, but here are some ways to get a jump on the fall season without gasping for air.

title: Cuomo and Christie Call on U.S. to Share Cost of Hudson Rail Tunnel Project
description: The governors of New York and New Jersey signaled on Wednesday that a deal to build new rail tunnels under the Hudson River would require billions of dollars from the federal government, which has called the plan one of the most important transportation projects in the country.

title: Ferguson Residents Video of Shooting
description: Residents in the Ferguson, Mo., neighborhood where Michael Brown was shot by the police on Aug. 9 have posted video and photos of the aftermath to social media.

title: Ruling That Denied Release of Grand Jury Evidence in Garner Case Is Upheld
description: A New York State appeals court on Wednesday denied the release of evidence presented to a Staten Island grand jury that decided not to indict a New York City police officer after the death of Eric Garner last year.

title: Art in America Sold to ARTnews Owner
description: Two of the most venerable American art publications will now be owned by the same company and will be merged into a single entity online.

title: While Guantnamo Logjam Endures, Some Prisoners Could Be Freed
description: American national security officials concluded more than five years ago that Tariq Ba Odah, a prisoner at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, should be released because he doesnt pose a major risk. Mr. Ba Odah, a Yemeni citizen who has been on a hunger strike since February 2007 and is subject to forced feeding, is emaciated. Fearing that he could starve to death in the near future, his lawyers recently filed a petition challenging his detention.

title: Bernie Sanders Lobbies for A.F.L.-C.I.O. Endorsement
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  Citing his long legislative record and improving performance in opinion polls, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont told leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. gathered here on Wednesday that he was best equipped to advance the rights and benefits of organized labor.

title: New Ebola Cases Decline, but W.H.O. Advises Caution
description: Seven new cases of Ebola were reported in Guinea and Sierra Leone last week, the lowest weekly total in more than a year, the World Health Organization said Wednesday. But it is too soon to tell whether the decline will last, the agency said, noting that during the previous two months, 20 to 30 new cases a week were reported in the two countries. Liberia had no new cases last week, but 33 people potentially exposed to the virus are being monitored and will not be in the clear until Aug. 2. Over all, more than 2,000 people in the region who may have been exposed are still in the 21-day incubation period and are being monitored, so a substantial risk exists that more cases will occur, W.H.O. said. Ebola has killed 11,294 people as of July 26.

title: Van Alexander, Composer of A-Tisket, A-Tasket, Dies at 100
description: Van Alexander, a composer and arranger who adapted a nursery rhyme into A-Tisket, A-Tasket, which became Ella Fitzgeralds breakout hit in 1938, died on July 19 at a hospital near his home in Los Angeles. He was 100.

title: Labours Reckless Left Turn
description: LONDON  IF you think Donald J. Trumps early lead in the race for the Republican presidential nomination is the seasons most spectacular case of unlikely political ascendancy, think again. In Britain, a 66-year-old left-wing member of Parliament named Jeremy Corbyn is close to becoming the leader of the Labour Party.

title: Cerner Wins Bid to Redo Health Data
description: In a closely watched contest, the Defense Department late Wednesday awarded the Cerner Corporation a multibillion-dollar contract to digitize the health records of more than 9.5 million military personnel and beneficiaries.

title: Jules Hirsch, Pioneer in Obesity Studies, Is Dead at 88
description: Jules Hirsch, whose clinical investigations into body weight regulation helped establish the biological underpinnings of obesity  including that a persons weight is in part determined by the bodys own predisposition  died on July 23 in Englewood, N.J. He was 88.

title: Outlook for the Ex-Im Bank Dims as Congress Departs
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect that the Export-Import Bank would soon reopen its credit windows to support foreign sales for American businesses was dashed on Wednesday as Congress prepared to recess until September without reauthorizing the 81-year-old agency, leaving its future more uncertain than ever before.

title: Making Missteps as Tom Brady Scrambles in Suspension Fight
description: For fans of Tom Brady, Part 2 of his fight with the N.F.L. was not much better than Part 1.

title: Henry B. Platt, Scion Who Gave Tiffany Sparkle, Dies at 91
description: Never mind breakfast at Tiffanys. Caviar and champagne were more the style of Henry B. Platt, Tiffanys former chairman, who was the great-great-grandson of the stores founder.

title: Yankees and Cashman Remain Quiet as Trade Deadline Nears
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Fridays nonwaiver trading deadline draws near, teams with championship ambitions  especially in the American League  have been busy adding pieces they hope will be difference makers in October.

title: Dan Fellman, Executive at Warner Bros., to Leave Studio
description: LOS ANGELES  Dan Fellman, one of Hollywoods most experienced movie distribution executives, beginning his studio career in 1964 and recently playing an influential role in the digital transformation of the exhibition business, said on Tuesday that he would leave Warner Bros. at the end of the year.

title: Former University of Virginia Fraternity Members Sue Rolling Stone
description: Three former members of the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity at the University of Virginia filed a lawsuit against Rolling Stone on Wednesday for defamation and infliction of emotional distress, saying the magazines discredited article on a campus gang rape had a devastating effect on their reputations.

title: Will Dana, Rolling Stones Managing Editor, to Depart
description: Will Dana, the managing editor of Rolling Stone, will leave the magazine, just months after a controversial article about a supposed gang rape at the University of Virginia was retracted.

title: Small Price to Pay
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Hands up if you remember reading Louisa May ALCOTTs Little Women for the first time. I can remember being enchanted with the relationship between the March sisters and their Marmee, and crying at their misfortunes.

title: $30 Million Program to Help Low-Income New Yorkers Get Mental Health Care
description: New York is set to begin a $30 million program aimed at providing mental health services to low-income residents with little or no access to care.

title: A Trade Deal Falls Apart and a Mets Player Is Left Shaken
description: On Wednesday night, the Mets finally pulled off a major deal, sending Wilmer Flores and Zack Wheeler to the Milwaukee Brewers in exchange for the highly regarded center fielder Carlos Gomez. Except, it turned out, that they didnt.

title: Two Communities Struggle to Find Common Ground
description: The legal and cultural borders between Riverton, Wyo., and the Indian reservation surrounding the town have defined struggles over property rights, crime and justice, and even the town itself.

title: In Wyoming, Shooting Highlights Divide Between a City and a Reservation
description: RIVERTON, Wyo.  Roy Clyde was sick of the homeless people who linger in this citys parks, urinating in public and drinking bottles of vodka and mouthwash, he told the police. So on a recent afternoon, the police say, he grabbed his handgun, walked into an alcohol detox facility called the Center of Hope and shot two men as they lay on green floor mats, killing one and critically wounding the other.

title: Illuminating the Plight of Endangered Species, at the Empire State Building
description: TRAVIS THRELKEL was standing on the roof of a building on Fifth Avenue and 27th Street looking uptown at his canvas. Its hard to miss: Its the Empire State Building, and on Saturday evening he and his collaborator, the filmmaker and photographer Louie Psihoyos, will project digital light images of endangered species onto the building in an art event meant to draw attention to the creatures plight and possibly provide footage for a coming documentary. Although the men refer to the event as a weapon of mass instruction, Mr. Threlkel explained: Were going to try to create something beautiful. Not bum people out. He added later: Hopefully, this is one big domino. If we can tip it, it would be great.

title: Legionnaires Disease Sickens 31, 2 Fatally, in the South Bronx
description: An outbreak of Legionnaires disease has sickened 31 people in the South Bronx since July 10, two of them fatally, New York City health officials said on Wednesday.

description: A grand jury has found that four officers acted lawfully when they shot and killed an armed man shortly after he robbed an Upper East Side pharmacy in May 2014, the Manhattan district attorneys office said on Wednesday.

The pair behind the Zagreb, Croatia-based clothing label Dioralop recently spent two weeks road-tripping through their home country, stopping in three Adriatic cities on their usual summer loop, Merlic, an architect and print designer, explains amid Bistricics laughter.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 7:45 P.M. (TCM) AFI LIFE ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO STEVE MARTIN Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to Mr. Martin, who on June 4 received the annual life achievement award from the American Film Institute. From a wild and crazy standup comic to one who stands tall among the great figures in this American art form, he is a multilayered creative force bound by neither convention nor caution, said Howard Stringer, chairman of the institutes board. His work is defined by him alone, for he is the author  and a national treasure whose work has stuck with us like an arrow in the head. The evenings lineup begins with Carson on TCM: Steve Martin, an interview from The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson in which Mr. Martin discusses The Jerk. Excerpts from the Film Institute ceremony follow at 8; Father of the Bride (1991), about a doting patriarch who finds his life upended and bank account depleted when his daughter announces that shes getting married, at 9:30; and Pennies From Heaven (1981), in which the dreams of a sheet-music salesman who longs to live in a world like the one depicted in the songs he peddles lead to tragedy, at 1 a.m.

title: Phillies Said to Be Trading Cole Hamels to Rangers
description: When the Philadelphia Phillies signed Cole Hamels to a six-year contract extension, in 2012, they believed he could help extend their long run of success. Instead, after five consecutive division titles, the Phillies collapsed. On Wednesday, they succumbed to their new reality.

title: In China, the Photobook as Art and History

Mr. Lundgren, who relocated there and became fluent in Mandarin, helped Mr. Parr make sense of the many volumes they began to systematically collect. By 2009, Mr. Lundgrens Beijing apartment overflowed with books.

Many are there, he said, because they didnt have the resources to survive those mistakes.

title: The Case for Fetal-Cell Research
description: Boston  WE first acquired the stem cells from the red receptacles of a local hospitals labor and delivery ward, delivered to our lab at the University of Southern California. I would reach into the large medical waste containers and pull out the tree-like branches of the placenta, discarded after a baby had been born. Squeezing the umbilical cord that had so recently been attached to new life, the blood, laden with stem cells, would come dripping out.

title: Advice for New Students From Those Who Know (Older Students)
description: New supplies, new clothes, new start. Freshman year is a chance to redefine yourself, to challenge assumptions, to lay the foundation for the rest of your life. Gee whiz, you say, Im just 18! So we asked for help, from those who have been there, done that. Below are words of wisdom from 25 upperclassmen and recent grads. See the comments section for additional reader submissions.
