title: Making Friends in New Places
description: Freshman year is critical, but not for the reasons most students (and their parents) imagine. American students have the luxury of a long horizon to settle on good classes, select a major and chart a career; theres plenty of time to make academic mistakes and recover from them. But its important to set off on the right foot in one respect: making friends.

title: This Year, Dont Change. Same Beach, Same Sea.
description: There is a line in an old Italian pop song: Per quest anno non cambiare, Stessa spiaggia, stesso mare. This year, dont change. Same beach, same sea. Tim Parks quotes it (and translates it) as he describes the Italian ritual of going to the same beach every summer in his lovely memoir An Italian Education, and I think of it every year as we make the drive to our own same beach, same sea: the resort on Cape Cod where we have gone every year for nearly a decade.

title: The Psychologist Warden
description: A new warden at Cook County Jail in Chicago is looking for ways to treat an influx of mentally ill inmates. Her hiring comes at a time when many public mental health facilities have closed.

title: A Jail Focuses on Mental Health
description: The Cook County Jail, where up to a third of the inmates are mentally ill, has started providing services to help them.

title: What I Learned on Stage
description: MILAN  I HAVE been a journalist for over 30 years, first as a foreign correspondent and then as a columnist. Along the way I have written 15 books, all nonfiction. Last year  dont ask me why  I decided to write a play. I called it La vita  un viaggio, or Life is a journey.

title: Today in Politics: Polls Keep Bolstering a Trump Seemingly Impervious to Scrubbing
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where the Iran nuclear deal has resurrected a debate on oil. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont hosted a nationwide house party, and Donald J. Trumps status as a front-runner has prompted an increased scrutiny that feeds his combative nature, further fueling that status.

title: Jermaine Affonso Cant Escape the Garbage, Either
description: You are the editor in chief of ClickHole, a website The Onion started last year that satirizes web media. The most common way Ive heard people describe their experience with ClickHole is that they both laughed and felt bad about themselves. Is that the mixture of feelings you were hoping to inspire? Yeah. I think, to some degree, all comedy exists to make people laugh and see something deeper. And usually when you look deeper into anything, you feel terrible about it.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Egg Shakers
description: We give babies rattles because babies understand abandon, because theyre not too proud or complicated yet to shake those rattles hard and feel free. Im no baby; Im a man, with two small children of my own. But last fall, I got an egg shaker, and Ive enjoyed putting on records and playing egg shaker along with them ever since. Its an outlet, a release  like air guitar, but with one key difference. I am making noise.

title: Who Runs the Streets of New Orleans?
description: On the morning of Sunday, March 29, Sidney Torres was sipping an espresso in the kitchen of his mansion on the edge of the French Quarter when a jarring notification lit up his iPad and two iPhones. Pimps fighting with drug dealers and johns. Man has gun. Hurry. The message came from a neighbor 10 blocks away, on St. Louis Street, and was sent through a venture Torres started four days earlier: a private police patrol that could be summoned via mobile app. Torres, who made a vast fortune as the founder of SDT Waste & Debris Services, a sanitation company that cleaned up much of New Orleans in the years following Hurricane Katrina, spent $380,000 to fund the enterprise after a crime wave put Quarter residents on edge for the better part of a year. Between November and January, there were more than 60 robberies in the neighborhood, and the crimes became increasingly brazen, including a vicious stabbing and a spate of random beatings. It became a personal issue for Torres on Dec. 17, when his 8,000-square-foot home was burglarized; three weeks later, the bar next door was held up by two masked gunmen. Torress crowdsourcing approach to crime, conceived throughout February and March, was the impulsive byproduct of his belief that the New Orleans Police Department, which has shrunk by around 500 officers since Hurricane Katrina, was no longer able to protect even the neighborhood less than a square mile in size that contained the citys most valuable real estate.

Net income was down to $719 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $791 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Carlos Chvez, Mexican Modernist
description: European musicians are of the worst kind, the composer Carlos Chvez declared in a 1931 letter. Conductors, pianists, violinists, singers and so on are prima donna minded people  they are very important to themselves. We must change the situation, Aaron. In a reply to his close friend, the young Aaron Copland concurred: All you wrote about music in America awoke a responsive echo in my heart. I am through with Europe, Carlos, and I believe as you do, that our salvation must come from ourselves and that we must fight the foreign element in American music.

title: A Champagne Houses United Nations Connection

It will be the first region of its kind on the list of areas of authenticity  which typically includes institutions, cities or structures. And in adopting the region, UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organizations) also acknowledges and protects all the individual historic institutions within the region, like Ruinart, the oldest Champagne house there.

title: Daily Report: Social Media Stocks and Their Unforgiving Investors

On top of that, Facebooks shares fell slightly in after-hours trading after it posted financial results that included a surge in spending and a forecast of slowing revenue growth. Lets see if LinkedIn, which reports earnings on Thursday, also joins this not-so-fun party.

title: 1890: Buenos Ayress Revolution

Naval Attach Attewell, of the Argentine Legation, thinks that with the large force the Government could muster in the interior the conflict could be indefinitely prolonged with the chances against the insurgents of Buenos Ayres.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 31, 1890

But the most enduring of all, the Three Choirs Festival, whose current season opened last Saturday and runs for a week, has been around far longer.

title: On Prince Edward Island, a Seafood-Dining Excursion

The picturesque Gulf of St. Lawrence glistened on a sunny August evening on Prince Edward Island, Canada, and our 6-year-old daughter was running around on the grounds of the resort we were visiting for the afternoon called the Sundance Cottages.

title: For U2, 2 HBO Specials in November
description: U2 is a band that generally likes to go big and, as such, it will receive not one but two substantial HBO specials in November, the cable channel said Thursday.

title: A Little Night Music Brings Dark Magic to the Kaplan Penthouse
description: One of the most popular innovations of the Mostly Mozart festival has been a Little Night Music, the series of late-night, hourlong performances in the Kaplan Penthouse. The success of this venture proves that, in classical music as in many arts, smaller is often better. Audiences have loved the programs, the 10 p.m. starting time, the intimacy (about 230 people sit at small tables) and the city views from the wall-spanning windows, not to mention the free wine.

title: Before Gomez and Flores, Other Baseball Trades That Never Were

title: Northern Ireland Town Embraces Beckett Festival

A piercing whistle seems to propel them into movement and they shuffle and stop until another whistle commands them. Who are they? What are they doing? Why?

title: Airports Get More Friendly for Parents With Young Children
description: Airports are getting a little more child-friendly, at least for parents traveling with babies and toddlers. The Honest Company, a consumer goods brand, recently started installing automated kiosks stocked with essentials for parents who forgot to bring diapers onto their next flight. The eco-friendly line, founded by the actress Jessica Alba in 2012, has set up nine kiosks at several airports and already plans more.

title: Faith No More Brings Reboot to Madison Square Garden
description: Empty rituals, trinkets and fossils, Mike Patton gargles within the first half-minute of Sol Invictus (Reclamation/Ipecac), a rattlingly vital new album by Faith No More. Hes taking aim at religious trappings but maybe also disarming the pomp around, say, a cult-heroic rock band in the midst of an unlikely reunion. Self-inflicted wounds were always part of the bargain for Faith No More, which blazed a trail for alternative metal in the 1980s and 90s, always with a compulsion for subverting expectations. After going their separate ways in 98, the bands members seemed unlikely to find a common cause again.

title: Chicks To Go Serves Chicken and Peruvian Pride in the Rockaways
description: Golden cans of Inca Kola are stacked behind the counter of Chicks To Go, a Peruvian pollera (rotisserie-chicken shop) that opened in March a block from Rockaway Beach. Invented in 1935 in Lima, Peru, the chartreuse-yellow soda  infused with lemon verbena, an herb native to the Andes, and tasting of caramelized Sprite, Bubble Yum and jackfruit  is one of the few in the world to outsell Coca-Cola on its home turf.

title: New Prince Single Released on Spotify
description: In the evolving landscape of streaming music, it can be tricky to keep track of which artists music is available where. Taylor Swift has pulled her songs from Spotify but allowed her latest album, 1989, to be on Apple Music. Lil Waynes newest release is only on Tidal. Neil Young has removed his music altogether.

title: Success Academy Gets $8.5 Million to Add Charter Schools in New York City
description: Success Academy, the fast-growing network of sought-after charter schools, announced on Thursday that it had received an $8.5 million gift to add schools in New York City.

title: Congressman for Family of Iran Prisoner, Amir Hekmati, Backs Nuclear Deal
description: A congressman whose constituents include the family of the longest-held American prisoner in Iran said Thursday that he had decided to vote in favor of the nuclear agreement reached with Iran on July 14.

title: Mullah Muhammad Omar, Enigmatic Leader of Afghan Taliban, Is Dead
description: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the leader of the fundamentalist Afghan Taliban movement, proved to be as enigmatic in death as he had been in life. When the Afghan government announced on Wednesday that he had died more than two years ago in a Pakistani hospital, he had not been seen in public since 2001, not long after the attacks of Sept. 11, carried out by a terrorist group to which he had given safe harbor.

title: Dominican Resort Is a Refuge Twice Abandoned
description: CABARETE, Dominican Republic  Just a few kilometers down the road, in the center of Cabarete, the tourism industry pulses with life: Beachfront restaurants dish up offerings as varied as ceviche and pizza, tourists cart surfboards and sport fanny packs, and combed white sand as clean as crisp bed linen beckons sunbathers.

title: Insider Trading Petition
description: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to review a court ruling that sharply narrowed the definition of insider trading.

title: How to Tax Gordon Gekko
description: The plot of Oliver Stones 1987 movie Wall Street revolves around the betrayal of Bud Fox by his mentor and hero, Gordon Gekko.

title: Review: The End of the Tour Offers a Tale of Two Davids
description: Theres an unhappy paradox about literary biographies, David Foster Wallace observed in The New York Times Book Review in 2004, in reference to Borges: A Life. Readers who pick up such books, drawn by their admiration for a writers work, are likely to find themselves distracted and disappointed by a welter of iffy theories and picayune data. In the case of Borges, Wallace argued, the stories so completely transcend their motive cause that the biographical facts become, in the deepest and most literal way, irrelevant.

title: Google Fights Effort to Apply Right to Be Forgotten Ruling Worldwide
description: Google, the search giant, is gearing up for a fight in France.

title: Inside the Floating Head of Marlon Brando
description: One unusual sequence in the documentary Listen to Me Marlon shows a seemingly low-tech digital version of the actor Marlon Brando quoting Macbeth. His head floats in black space and the image looks three-dimensional yet still raw.

title: 1940: Hungarys Jews Await Curbs
description: BUDAPEST  Hungarys 600,000 Jews are awaiting with mixed feelings of resignation and hope the reconvening of Parliament on Sept. 6, when, according to current reports, the third so-called Jewish law will be introduced. According to one version, the Hungarian legislature will announce the same definition which Germany enacted in its Nuremberg laws. Although there has been no pogrom here comparable to the anti-Jewish actions taken in Germany, it is generally believed that the law restricting Jewish participation in commerce, industry and agriculture to between 6 and 12 percent causes more hardship.  New York Herald Tribune, July 31, 1940

title: A Return to Poland
description: A writer and his sister journey to the childhood homes of their parents, places where once Jews like them could thrive.

title: Abductions Hurt U.S. Bid to Train Anti-ISIS Rebels in Syria
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  A Pentagon program to train moderate Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has been vexed by problems of recruitment, screening, dismissals and desertions that have left only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.

title: A Balloon to Treat Glue Ear, a Common Childhood Problem
description: Millions of children each year develop a buildup of thick fluid in the middle ear that can muffle sound and make them cranky and uncomfortable. Now there is new evidence that a simple do-it-yourself home treatment  which involves inflating a balloon by blowing out through the nose  may help clear the fluid without drugs or surgery.

title: Bolshoi Is Not Renewing Acid Attack Victims Contract
description: MOSCOW  The Bolshoi Theater will not be extending the contract of Sergei Filin, the ballets artistic director who was injured in an acid attack organized by a dancer in January 2013.

title: In Poland, Searching for Jewish Heritage
description: When I was growing up, my mother filled me with visions of her hometown, Otwock in Poland, describing it as a kind of Brigadoon without actually using that American word.

title: Assyrtiko, Now an American Treat
description: I was excited and pleased to offer last months Wine School assignment: assyrtiko from the Greek island of Santorini. The response was mostly enthusiastic, but a few readers were puzzled or even annoyed.

title: Addicted to Your Smartphone? The Company That Made It Would Like You to Think So.
description: Who is making the most noise about smartphone overuse? It seems that it might be smartphone companies themselves.

title: Your Next Lesson:White Bordeaux
description: The first Wine School assignment, back in early 2014, was Bordeaux, reds from the Haut-Mdoc appellation. Now we return to Bordeaux, but to another, more obscure wine: the white Bordeaux of Pessac-Lognan and Graves.

title: Inside the 16th Arrondissement
description: Inside the 16th Arrondissement

title: Dentists and Skin in the Game
description: Wonkblog has a post inspired by the dentist who paid a lot of money to shoot Cecil the lion, asking why he  and dentists in general  make so much money. Interesting stuff; Ive never really thought about the economics of dental care.

title: NBCUniversal Said to Be Near Investing in BuzzFeed and Vox
description: NBCUniversal is poised to make a pair of investments in the digital media start-ups BuzzFeed and Vox, seeking to appeal to younger millennial viewers who are abandoning traditional media, according to executives with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Jacob Fugger and the Renaissance Superrich
description: It is far from clear that Jacob Fugger really was The Richest Man Who Ever Lived, as the title of Greg Steinmetzs new biography claims. That said, he definitely seems to have amassed significantly more money than any of the current crop of multibillionaires.

title: Lawsuit Says Bronx Health Center Turns Away Patients With Physical Disabilities
description: A Bronx health center that serves many poor and minority patients was accused this week of discriminating against another group that often faces barriers to medical care: those with physical disabilities.

title: Support for Bernie Sanders Is Deep but Narrow
description: As many as 100,000 people attended house parties for Bernie Sanders on Wednesday in an extraordinary and perhaps unprecedented early demonstration of grass-roots support.

title: A Wedding for Couple in Hillary Clinton Announcement Video
description: The gay couple featured in Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential announcement video have married, and The Timess Weddings section looks at their relationship.

title: Review: Martial Bliss, a Loving Memoir About a Bookstore for Military Buffs
description: The story Margaretta Barton Colt has to tell in her charming memoir, Martial Bliss  do not misread its title as Marital Bliss  takes place only a few decades ago. But it seems to emerge as if from a time machine.

title: Even a Near Slur Demands an Apology
description: During a PTA meeting, a colleague said, You can chew them down on the price. I had never heard this expression, but another colleague explained to me that it was probably a misuse of the horrible phrase Jew them down. I have a feeling the speaker didnt know this. As president of the PTA, I would like to explain to her what the phrase means. Any thoughts?

title: Importing Both Salamanders and Their Potential Destruction
description: We humans can drive species toward extinction by hunting them or destroying their habitat. But we can also threaten them in a more subtle but no less dangerous way: by making them sick.

title: Lupita Nyongo to Star in Eclipsed at the Public Theater
description: The Academy Award-winning actress Lupita Nyongo (12 Years a Slave) will make her New York stage debut this fall in the Public Theaters production of the war drama Eclipsed, written by the Obie Award-winning playwright Danai Gurira (In the Continuum), the theater announced on Thursday.

title: After Cecil the Lions Killing, U.S. and U.N. Look to Take Action
description: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said on Thursday that it was investigating the circumstances surrounding the killing of Cecil, a lion who is thought to have been lured out of his protected habitat in Zimbabwe this month and killed by Walter J. Palmer, an American dentist and hunter.

title: Wheeling Around a Tranquil Bay
description: A leisurely five-day ride takes in pine forests, fishing hamlets and a preserve, with time to stop for fresh oysters.

title: Review: Ramona, a Puppet Tale About Trains in Love
description: Ramona, a play from Georgias Gabriadze Theater at the Lincoln Center Festival, stars two star-crossed steam locomotives. You could say its about the romance of travel, though here that romance ends in an unusually tearful scene of smelting. In just over an hour, this puppet show, set in the postwar Soviet Union, tackles freedom and duty, love and death, and metallurgy.

title: 1973 | Meet Donald Trump
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter, and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: To Live and Not Die in L.A.: Fear the Walking Dead on AMC
description: LOS ANGELES  Here on the set of the new prequel Fear the Walking Dead, a mother, her son and her boyfriend are crammed together in the cab of a beat-up Ford truck, terrified that somethings not quite right in their city.

title: SunGard Is Said to Be in Sale Talks With Fidelity National Information
description: SunGard may have been planning to return to the public markets, but it may instead be sold to a peer.

title: Ultra-Orthodox Israeli Stabs 6 at a Gay Pride Parade for Second Time, Police Say
description: JERUSALEM  An ultra-Orthodox Jewish man who had recently been released from prison after serving 10 years for stabbing participants in the annual Gay Pride Parade here in 2005 struck again Thursday, stabbing six marchers in this years parade, according to the police.

title: A Jail Focuses on Mental Health
description: The Cook County Jail, where up to a third of the inmates are mentally ill, has started providing services to help them.

title: Robert Kirkman: In Fear the Walking Dead, Dreamers Face the Apocalypse
description: Since 2003, when the first issue of the comic-book series The Walking Dead appeared, zombies have stalked most of the waking hours of Robert Kirkman  though in a good way. The success of the comic Mr. Kirkman helped create has spawned video games, novels and most notably, a hit TV show on AMC. And on August 23, there will be a new addition to the zombie universe when Fear the Walking Dead, a companion series he created with Dave Erickson, makes its debut on AMC.

title: Israel Allows Hunger-Striking Prisoners to Be Force-Fed
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli legislators voted Thursday to allow the force-feeding of hunger-striking prisoners in extreme cases, a move that appeared to be aimed at preventing Palestinian inmates from using fasts to win their release, particularly from indefinite incarceration.

title: Secret to a Long Life
description: Helen Moses, a 90-year-old in the Bronx, says that age should make no difference in life.

title: Whiff of Dot-Com Fever in Delphi Deal
description: Theres a whiff of tech fever emanating from Delphi Automotive.

title: Blue Jays Latest Deal, for David Price, Seems to Amplify the Yankees Silence
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  If there is anybody in the Yankees clubhouse who understands how to navigate the emotional roller coaster that kicks into overdrive as the nonwaiver trading deadline approaches, it is Chase Headley.

title: Senate Passes a Highway Bill, but Only for Three Months
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a stopgap three-month spending bill to finance federal highway and transportation projects until the end of October, leaving some frustrated lawmakers lamenting that important projects will be stalled.

title: Dream Weavers
description: Behind the scenes at Swans Island.

title: Murder Charge for Brooklyn Woman Whose Infant Was Found Dead in a Bag
description: She was adept at hiding her pregnancies. At 14, she went into labor with her first baby before her mother even knew she had conceived a child. A year later, prosecutors say, she secretly gave birth to a second baby, this time in the bathtub of her apartment. That baby has disappeared.

title: Modern Love | A Kiss, Deferred
description: A 12-year-old girls life and love are shattered by the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Water Use in California Down 27% in June, Beating Goal
description: LOS ANGELES  Water use in California dropped by more than 27 percent in June, surpassing the 25 percent statewide cutback ordered by Gov. Jerry Brown in what officials called an encouraging development as this state struggles through one of its worst droughts in history.

title: Donald Trump Appeals for the Sarah Palin Vote
description: Donald J. Trump appears to be making a serious play for the Mama Grizzly vote.

title: Choosing Your Preferred View of a Macs Stacks
description: Q. When I previously clicked on the Downloads folder in my Macs Dock, the files inside would spring out in a vertical column with the newest file at the bottom. Now, when I click on the Downloads folder, it opens in a giant window and blocks half my screen. I must have accidentally changed a setting, but how do I change it back?

title: Whats Your Secret to a Long Life? Tell Us in a Video
description: Note: We are no longer accepting submissions for this project.

title: Every Kind of a Painter Features a Retrospective of Thomas Prichard Rossiter
description: The 19th-century painter Thomas Prichard Rossiter was a prodigy whose fame did not last. As a teenager in New Haven in the 1830s, he set up an acclaimed portrait and landscape studio, but by the 1860s his tableaus of historical and biblical figures and mountainous backdrops were unfashionable, considered stiff and academic.

title: At Historic House Museums, Time for a Face-Lift
description: At historic house museums established by trailblazing women in the late 1800s, the current administrators are rethinking some original design decisions while also paying tribute to the founders preservation efforts with new exhibitions and books.

title: Migrants in Calais Desperately Rush the Channel Tunnel to England, Night After Night
description: CALAIS, France  The sun had barely set when a 23-year-old Eritrean woman who gave her name as Akbrat fell into step with dozens of other men and women and started scaling the fence surrounding the entrance to the French side of the Channel Tunnel.

title: Elizabeth Warrens Crusade to Separate Investment and Commercial Banks
description: For reasons that are mystifying, the idea of separating investment banks from commercial banks  once the law of the land for more than 60 years  is again the rage among certain politicians.

title: Review: De Wain Valentine Show at David Zwirner
description: For sheer physical beauty, few objects in any New York gallery at the moment exceed this exhibitions plastic sculptures, which were made in California by De Wain Valentine in the 1960s and 70s. Associated with the West Coast movements known as Light and Space and Finish Fetish, Mr. Valentine cast his works in variously colored, translucent polyester resins, creating sleek, geometric forms that intimate transcendentalist vibes.

title: Review: Sam Messer Collaborates With Jonathan Safran Foer and Denis Johnson
description: In 1990, the New York painter Sam Messer met a 96-year-old self-taught artist named Jon Serl and became fascinated by his personality and history. Over the next three years, he painted Mr. Serls portrait some 50 times. Mr. Messer did more than paint him: He entered Serls being, and the paintings look that way  like empathetic projections.

title: Review: At SummerStage, Philadanco and TU Dance Produce Fancy Footwork Across Vastness
description: Philadanco isnt too rare a sight in New York, but its usually a welcome one. Formed in 1970 by the esteemed director Joan Myers Brown, this Philadelphia company lit up the stage at Central Park on Wednesday night with a typically accomplished group of dancers. The choreography, sadly, was another story.

title: Rosettas Philae Lander Discovers a Comets Organic Molecules
description: Philae, the little lost lander that the European Space Agency dropped on a comet last November, is still lost.

title: Police on Video: When the Camera Turns
description: Since 2014, videos of incidents between white police officers and minorities have prompted changes in procedures. Here is a look at those videos, which include graphic scenes of violence.

title: Britain Limits Visit by the Chinese Artist Ai Weiwei
description: LONDON  The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei has been denied a normal six-month business visa by the British government, which said on Thursday that Mr. Ai had lied on his application by neglecting to declare that he had been convicted of a crime.

title: U.S. Names New Targets of Sanctions Over Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday identified 26 additional people and institutions that will be subject to economic sanctions as part of an effort to maintain pressure on the Russian government over its support of insurgents fighting in Ukraine.

title: Why Consumers Should Tread Carefully with Samsung Galaxys Price Cut
description: As profits continue to slip for Samsung Electronics, the South Korean manufacturer is resorting to reducing the price of its most popular phone, the Galaxy S6. But all would-be buyers eyeing the price cut should take heed and proceed with caution.

title: James Cohan Gallery Expands to Lower East Side
description: This fall, a former fish market on the Lower East Side will become the third outpost of the James Cohan Gallery, which is expanding beyond its flagship in Chelsea and a satellite in Shanghai. After being in business for 16 years, our roster of artists continues to grow and we want the opportunity for them to exhibit sooner than later, Mr. Cohan said.

title: Looking at How Performers Are Paid for Performance Art
description: On the heels of protesters descending upon the Guggenheim Museum in May, calling for improved conditions for the workers who will build a future branch of the museum in Abu Dhabi, the artists Gerard & Kelly have partnered with the Guggenheim to hammer out fair labor standards for themselves and the other performers in Timelining, part of Storylines: Contemporary Art at the Guggenheim.

title: The Style of Yves Saint Laurent Is Set to Arrive in Seattle
description: As a teenager, Yves Henri Donat Mathieu-Saint-Laurent, born in 1936 in Algeria, was already designing Paper Doll Couture House, replete with miniature accessorized frocks and people-scaled programs on which his sisters, playing clients, would write their clothing selections.

title: Review: Weird Science, a Group Show of Experimental Art
description: WEIRD SCIENCE

title: U.S. Psychologists Urged to Curb Questioning Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The board of the American Psychological Association plans to recommend a tough ethics policy that would prohibit psychologists from involvement in all national security interrogations, potentially creating a new obstacle to the Obamaadministrations efforts to detain and interrogate terrorism suspects outside of the traditional criminal justice system.

title: Hillary Clinton Speaks Favorably About $12 Minimum Wage
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  Fresh off a meeting with national labor leaders, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday spoke favorably about legislation to raise the federal minimum wage to $12 an hour, tacitly dismissing proposals by her two leading Democratic competitors who have called for a bigger increase.

title: Plan by Judge May Allow Pop Star Katy Perry to Rent Convent
description: LOS ANGELES  The entertainer Katy Perry cannot close her proposed deal to buy an eight-acre convent property here anytime soon, but she may be able to rent it.

title: In Indonesia, a Region Where Death Is a Lure
description: Baby Grave, 50 Meter read the hand-carved wooden sign. An arrow pointed into the woods.

title: Bailout Money Goes to Greece, Only to Flow Out Again
description: FRANKFURT  The Greek businessman was nervous as he carried a suitcase stuffed with cash through security at the Athens airport a few months ago. But the distracted and overworked officials waved him through.

title: The Fitness Chain SoulCycle Files for an Initial Public Offering
description: So popular is SoulCycle that customers eagerly arrange their schedules around openings for the weeks classes, with sessions regularly booked up within minutes.

title: A Kiss Deferred by Civil War
In Microsofts Nokia Debacle, a View of an Industrys Feet of Clay
description: Lets call it the $7.5 billion lesson.

title: Review: Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation With Tom Cruise and Plenty of Stunts
description: Watching Tom Cruise hurtle through the latest Mission: Impossible, taking one blow after another, you cant help worrying that he wont be able to keep this action stuff up. It looks so hard! But here he is, the 53-year-old Tom Terrific, holding onto a plane as it takes off, defying sense and gravity, and making you wonder (not for the first time) if he would actually die for our pleasure. By the time hes flailing underwater without an oxygen tank, struggling against violent surges as breath and time run out, you can almost feel the life leaving his body.

title: The Price of Thomas Heatherwicks Imagination
description: A tiny canal bridge in London doesnt just open for boat traffic, it curls up like a caterpillar. A suave redesign of Londons familiar double-decker bus invites passengers to the upper deck with a curving ribbon window that follows a winding staircase. An exposition building in Shanghai is covered in what look like porcupine quills. A pier in the Hudson is reimagined as a miniature island park with an amphitheater nestled within Lilliputian hills.

title: Back to the Future and Zemeckis Get MoMA Retrospective
description: One way to take in all the films that Robert Zemeckis has directed is to hop in your time-traveling DeLorean and skip from year to year as movies like Back to the Future, Who Framed Roger Rabbit and Forrest Gump are released in theaters. Your other option is to wait until the fall, when the Museum of Modern Art will honor this Academy Award-winning filmmaker with a career retrospective that includes his feature motion pictures, as well as television work and student films.

title: Increased Competition Kept Lid on Health Insurance Inflation, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said on Thursday that many consumers were benefiting from increased competition among insurers under the Affordable Care Act.

title: This Weeks Movies | July 31, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Listen to Me Marlon, The End of the Tour and Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation.

title: In Guatemala, Exhuming Children to Make Room for Death
description: Saul Martinez discovered that his homelands mind-numbing violence has led cemetery administrators to clear out the graves of forgotten children to make room for new burials.

title: Movie Review: Listen to Me Marlon
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Listen to Me Marlon.

title: Visiting the Source
description: Martell celebrates 300 years of Cognac.

title: Hans Hofmanns Murals Add a Blast of Color to a Muted Legacy
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  You have to love Hans Hofmann for his exuberant late-blooming paintings, and for his eponymous art school, which formed one of the foundations of Abstract Expressionism. His paintings are, fittingly, usually seen as part of that heroic art movement, even though they replace its existential undercurrents with a stylistic capriciousness that sifts through European modernism with abandon.

title: Letters: Nixons the One
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: At Salzburg Festival, a Story of Sex and Conquest
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Armed combat between nations, brutal clashes of culture, a superpowers ruthless subjugation of a less-developed people  it all comes down to the continuing battle of the sexes.

title: Movie Review: Mission: Impossible
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation.

title: Bernie Sanders Again Links Low Wages With Immigration
description: Senator Bernie Sanders addressed the hot-button topic of immigration for the second day in a row on Thursday, saying at a Hispanic Chamber of Commerce event that lower wages were tethered to an influx of immigrants.

title: More Than Scary
description: This week, Paul Theroux reviews Let Me Tell You, a collection of Shirley Jacksons writings that includes previously unpublished material. Jackson, in publicity speak, is having a moment.

title: Giants Say They Have Not Seen Jason Pierre-Paul Since Accident
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul, who lost his right index finger in a Fourth of July fireworks accident, did not report for the first day of training camp Thursday, and the team co-owner John Mara said the Giants had no information on the condition of Pierre-Paul, their best defensive player.

title: Viewfinder: Joanne Dugan
description: The New York-based photographer Joanne Dugans analog images.

title: Review: Daniel Ulbricht & Stars of American Ballet: A Summer Endeavor
description: BECKET, Mass.  What do principal dancers with New York City Ballet do during their summer breaks? Daniel Ulbricht keeps dancing and convinces his co-workers to join him. Last summer, he brought Ballet 2014/Daniel Ulbricht to Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival. Now hes back, with Daniel Ulbricht & Stars of American Ballet.

title: From Hundreds of Miles Away, Indians Converge to Honor Abdul Kalam
description: RAMESWARAM, India  At the break of dawn, Nimmi Jaan sat down on a patch of red sand near a large tent that had been set up the night before. She was one of the first people there. By afternoon, a line would stretch out behind her, across a sun-scorched field, through a patch of palms, around a bend and out of sight.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Pakistan and More  Pictures of the Day

title: July 30, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, Nepal and India.

title: Puppies in Prison: Reporting the Story of Bomb-Detecting Dogs
description: Travel delays are rarely, if ever, occasions to celebrate.

title: Fashion World Reacts to the Killing of Cecil
description: A number of fashion notables are among the many who have taken to social media to shame Dr. Walter J. Palmer, the American dentist who killed Cecil, the beloved lion, during a hunt in Zimbabwe this month. In particular, the Victorias Secret Angels Candice Swanepoel, who hails from South Africa, and Behati Prinsloo, who is from Namibia, drew attention for the outraged comments they posted to Instagram.

title: Second Police Body Camera Video Released
description: The University of Cincinnati Police released video from an officers body camera that shows the scene moments after Officer Ray Tensing shot and killed Samuel Dubose.

title: Seeing the Power of Political Posters
description: Can a poster change the world? In the 1970s, the German media theorist Hans Magnus Enzensberger criticized young French activists for making traditional letterpress posters during the May 1968 uprisings, rather than broadcasting via the state radio and television stations. The website for Art as Activism: Graphic Art From the Merrill C. Berman Collection at the New-York Historical Society asks a related question in updated form: How did political messages go viral before the Internet?

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on todays top stories.

title: Scouts in Japan
description: An international gathering.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Im Heung-soon Explores the Horrors Women Endure in War
description: May God give me patience, whimpers a chador-clad woman in Reincarnation, the newest video work from the South Korean artist and director Im Heung-soon. She is in wartime Iran, waiting for news of her son, whom she fears may be dead. She starts screaming in Farsi, then ululates at ear-piercing timbre. We see the door behind her: Its been soundproofed.

title: China Blames U.S. Military Actions for Tensions in the South China Sea
description: HONG KONG  A top Chinese official said Thursday that American military drills and surveillance flights in the South China Sea were threatening regional stability, a harsh assessment that seemed likely to heighten tensions between the two countries before several crucial meetings.

title: How a Chinese Billionaire Built Her Fortune
description: Zhou Qunfei is the worlds richest self-made woman. Ms. Zhou, the founder of Lens Technology, owns a $27 million estate in Hong Kong. She jets off to Silicon Valley and Seoul, South Korea, to court executives at Apple and Samsung, her two biggest customers. She has played host to President Xi Jinping of China, when he visited her companys headquarters.

title: The Young Curator Bringing the Lower East Side to the West Coast
description: Before Hannah Hoffman opened her gallery in East Hollywood in 2013, she didnt really know much about the Los Angeles art scene. In fact, she had never been to Los Angeles.

title: A Confusing Look at Folk Art and American Modernism
description: In recent years museums have raised their consciousness on various ethical fronts. A salubrious effect has been that they attend more to histories of collecting  their own and those of other institutions. Just this year, at least three such shows have been staged on the subject, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Discovering Japanese Art: American Collectors and the Met); at the Rubin Museum of Art (Collecting Paradise: Buddhist Art of Kashmir and Its Legacies); and at the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Discovering the Impressionists: Paul Durand-Ruel and the New Painting).

title: Ex-Military Leader in China Is Subject of Graft Inquiry
description: HONG KONG  A former commander of the Peoples Liberation Army was expelled from the Chinese Communist Party and placed under investigation for graft crimes on Thursday, becoming the most senior military figure brought down in President Xi Jinpings campaign against corruption.

title: Theater Listings for July 31-Aug. 6
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for July 31-Aug. 6
Review: In Netflixs Wet Hot American Summer, Back to Camp 14 Years Later as Big, Big Stars
description: If you havent seen the movie Wet Hot American Summer  released in 2001 and featuring a largely unknown cast that would go on to various levels of fame, or at least steady work  you can still enjoy the Netflix series Wet Hot American Summer: First Day of Camp, whose eight episodes go online Friday morning. The shaggy humor is amusing enough, and you can marvel at how the Wet Hot creators, David Wain and Michael Showalter, gathered so much of the original cast. Look, its Bradley Cooper! Wearing that same awful sweater!

title: Wells Fargo to End Some Marketing Ties With Home Builders and Brokers
description: Citing intensifying regulatory uncertainty, Wells Fargo is severing roughly 200 agreements with builders, brokers and other real estate firms that the bank uses to bolster its mortgage business.

Movie Listings for July 31-Aug. 6
Art Listings for July 31-Aug. 6
The DuBose Family: Grieving, but Determined
description: CINCINNATI  Terina DuBose Allen had just gotten out of the shower when she answered the phone. It was her brother Aubrey DuBose.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Mission: Impossible
description: Christopher McQuarrie narrates a sequence from Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation, starring Tom Cruise.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for July 31-Aug. 6
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Debris Alone May Not Solve Mystery of Malaysia Flight 370, Experts Say
description: Though the piece of airplane debris found on a remote Indian Ocean beach may yield the first tangible proof that a Malaysian jetliner that vanished almost 17 months ago crashed into the sea, experts said it may not be much help in solving the vexing mystery of where to find the planes wreckage.

title: A Facebook Project to Beam Data From Drones Is a Step Closer to Flight
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Facebook has moved several steps closer to fulfilling its grand ambition of building an Internet network in the sky, announcing on Thursday that it has built its first unmanned drone and found a way to vastly increase the capacity of the lasers that will eventually beam data between the drone network and the ground.

title: New York Judge Denies Request to Extend Legal Rights to 2 Chimps
description: ALBANY  In a case watched by animal rights activists and courtroom curiosity seekers, a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan on Thursday denied a request to free a pair of chimpanzees, Hercules and Leo, being held at a state university on Long Island.

title: Racetracks Open Their Wallets in Attempt to Attract American Pharoah
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  American Pharoah is undoubtedly the Big Horse. He is the first Triple Crown champion in 37 years and has looked every bit of it in winning seven of eight races in dominant fashion. Racetrack executives swoon at the mere thought of the colt circling their oval before a full house.

title: Vasily Pichul, Director, Dies at 54; Skewered Soviet Life in Little Vera
description: Vasily Pichul, a Soviet reform-era director who, in the 1988 film Little Vera, captured international attention with his comically scorching portrait of a teenage girl navigating a grim society that was then adjusting uneasily to social and political change, died on Sunday in Moscow. He was 54.

title: Spare Times for July 31-Aug. 6
description: Museums and Sites

title: Using DNA to Fight Dog Owners Discourtesy in Brooklyn
description: On a frigid Wednesday evening in January, 40 residents of One Brooklyn Bridge Park, a condominium complex converted from an old printing factory on the Brooklyn Heights waterfront, gathered at Wag Club, a dog grooming and training service on the ground floor, to discuss an issue that had been stirring tensions in the building. Dispersed among the 440 or so apartments are about 175 dogs of varying sizes, breeds and dispositions. As it happened, some of their owners had been behaving badly.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, Aug. 2 to 8, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Spare Times for Children for July 31-Aug. 6
description: Get Up & Go! Family Adventure Race

title: Projecting Change
description: Images of animals that will be featured in the event Projecting Change: The Empire State Building.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 2 to 8, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 2 to 8, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: After Trade Evaporates, So Does the Mets 6-Run Lead
description: Curtis Granderson had just sent a charge through Citi Field, lifting a three-run homer to right field Thursday afternoon in the fifth inning of the Mets game against San Diego, and after he rounded the bases to roaring cheers and made his way through the dugout, high-fiving his teammates, he found Wilmer Flores. Granderson pulled him in for a hug and patted his back, and Flores laid his head on Grandersons shoulder and smiled.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 2 to 8, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation (With Movie Trailer): Christopher McQuarrie Narrates a Scene
description: Mission: Impossible  Rogue Nation, like the other films in this franchise starring Tom Cruise, weaves a handful of complex action set pieces into its narrative. But one with a significant number of moving parts takes place at the Vienna opera house and involves action in the rafters, high above the stage. In this video, and in an interview, the films writer and director, Christopher McQuarrie, discussed elements of the scene.

title: Jets Sheldon Richardson, Already Suspended, Is Accused of Resisting Arrest After a Traffic Stop
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Around 4:45 p.m. Thursday, Jets defensive lineman Sheldon Richardson, already suspended for the first four games of the season for violating the N.F.L.s substance abuse policy, said he had recently told the team that it did not have to worry about his name being in the news again.

title: U.S.-Taliban Fight Goes On, So Guantnamo Detainee Stays, Court Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military may continue to hold a Guantnamo Bay detainee accused of being a Taliban fighter even though President Obama has repeatedly said that the United States war in Afghanistan has ended, a federal judge ruled Thursday.

title: Review: From Israel, The Kindergarten Teacher, a Drama About Poetry and Obsession
description: Can a 5-year-old boy be a literary genius? And if so, how might his precocious gift be nurtured and protected? These are, on the surface, among the main questions posed by The Kindergarten Teacher, a self-assured, remarkably powerful film from the Israeli writer-director Nadav Lapid.

title: A Review of Clean Plate Kitchen in Clinton, Which Feeds Vegans and Meat-Eaters
description: Despite the picturesque spot, near the Raritan River and the historic Red Mill Museum, previous restaurants at 49 Main Street  the current location of the Clean Plate Kitchen  never quite found their culinary grooves.

title: An Iliad, a One-Man Take on Homers Classic, Comes to the Hudson Valley
description: This season the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival in Garrison is featuring The Winters Tale with a cast of 18  a fairly typical number of actors for a Shakespeare play.

title: Fiat Chrysler Profit Increases 69%, Most of It From North America
description: DETROIT  Fiat Chrysler Automobiles on Thursday reported a big gain in second-quarter profits and assured investors that its recent record-setting penalty for safety violations would not slow its earnings momentum.

title: Review: Best of Enemies Recalls Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr.s TV Battles
description: In 1968, as the summer political-convention season approached, ABC News decided to take a gamble. The network seemed permanently stuck in third place, and its news division in particular suffered from the lack of a brand-name on-air authority figure to compete with Chet Huntley and David Brinkley at NBC or Walter Cronkite at CBS. Back in those days, the two leading networks covered the conventions live from beginning to end. (Can you imagine?) Instead of comprehensiveness, ABC went for provocation and at least the illusion of intellectual heft, hiring Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr. to conduct a series of debates during the Republican circus in Miami and the subsequent Democratic debacle in Chicago. Best of Enemies, Robert Gordon and Morgan Nevilles lively new documentary, an accessible assemblage of archival footage and talking-head analysis, mines the Buckley-Vidal skirmishes for nuggets of historical insight.

title: A Brewerys Offerings Stretch From Beer to Yoga
description: After more than 90 minutes, the Saturday morning yoga class at the Captain Lawrence Brewing Company in Elmsford was coming to a close.

title: John Kasich Raises $11.7 Million Through Political Action Committees
description: For a long-shot contender, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio is building an impressive campaign war chest.

title: Review: Counting, a Meditation in Story Shards
description: At one point in Counting, a wistful meditation on the world, its beauties, mysteries and injustices, the independent filmmaker Jem Cohen cuts from a photograph of Soviet cosmonauts to a view out a plane window. There are a number of aerial images scattered throughout the movie, which Mr. Cohen has stitched together from visual fragments that he shot over a period that took him from Coney Island to Moscow. Mr. Cohen, born in 1962, turns out to be another type of space-age traveler, if one whos specifically crossing cinematic time.

title: Relativity Media Files for Bankruptcy Protection, Hoping to Sell Itself
description: LOS ANGELES  Relativity Media, an entertainment mini-conglomerate that outgrew its financial underpinnings after a decade of expansion by its brash founder, Ryan Kavanaugh, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Thursday and put itself up for auction.

title: Problems of Housing Mentally Ill People Spill Into the Street
description: One evening last week, a restaurant owner in Washington Heights and two customers stood chatting on the sidewalk about the changes in the area over the last 25 years. The restaurateur, Peter Walsh, was telling the people, who were coming from a hospital on 168th Street, how much safer the neighborhood had become as he stood in front of his restaurant, Coogans, on Broadway between 168th and 169th Streets.

title: Liberia: Ebola Stalls Birth Registrations
description: The births of more than 70,000 children in Liberia during the Ebola crisis were never recorded, leaving them vulnerable to marginalization as noncitizens, denial of government services, trafficking and illegal adoption, Unicef reported Thursday. The agency said birth registrations in 2014 and so far this year had dropped sharply compared with levels before the Ebola epidemic. Quoting Ministry of Health data, Unicef said the births of only 700 children had been registered between January and May of this year, when many health facilities were overwhelmed or closed. Sheldon Yett, the Unicef representative in Liberia, said the agency was helping the government to register the others. Registration is required to obtain basic health and social services and identity documents. Children who have not been registered at birth officially dont exist, he said in a statement. More than 4,800 people have died in Liberia because of the Ebola crisis, according to the World Health Organization.

title: Review: Two Step Scuffles Around With Petty Criminals
description: A recurrent image of grackles lined up on a wire as if on the lookout haunts Two Step, a creepy indie thriller set in the seedier environs of Austin, Tex. That image reinforces the movies acrid portrait of a scuffling working-class milieu where the lines between legitimate employment and petty crime blur. Several of the characters run scams in addition to holding jobs.

title: A Fight Outside an Uptown Restaurant
description: A surveillance video shows an altercation between Peter Walsh, the co-owner of Coogans restaurant, and a man who approached him outside his restaurant.

title: MSNBC Reshuffles Its Daytime Lineup Ahead of Brian Williamss Debut
description: The cable network MSNBC is getting a long-awaited shake-up to its daytime lineup.

title: Review: In Dark Awakening, a Haunted House and Surfeit of Gore
description: The district attorney of a Southern town, James Thomas (Jason Cook), has a lot on his docket. First he has to put up with an angry court spectator who shoots a leering defendant just declared innocent. Then Jamess mother dies, and he and his wife, Jennifer (Valerie Azlynn), and 7-year-old son, Danny (William Pifer), move into Moms country home, where spectral residents befriend Danny and terrify Jennifer. The local priest (Lance Henriksen) clearly isnt sharing all he knows, and before long James just isnt acting like his old self.

title: Construction Plans for La Guardia Airport Dont Faze Its Neighbors
description: One cannot live any closer to the terminals of La Guardia Airport than the residents of East Elmhurst, Queens. Some homes sit only a few hundred yards away from the control tower, on the opposite side of the Grand Central Parkway. The new $4 billion airport hub envisioned for the site, announced this week by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Vice President Joseph R. Biden, would be even closer.

title: Review: Burgers (and Seafood) at Shad Row in Rocky Hill
description: I have waxed enthusiastic over Spicy Green Bean in Glastonbury, whose funky-cozy-colorful ambience reflects the eclectic flair of its chef-owner, Kathy Denisiewicz. Now the Bean has sprouted a new branch, Shad Row, just across the Connecticut River, that is ably tended by Kathy D, as Ms. Denisiewicz is often called, and her niece, Jenna Cavalieri.

title: Restaurant Review: Tony Cuban Cucina & Cocktails in Freeport Has a Rollicking Setting
description: A Cuban-Italian fusion restaurant seemed like a natural project for married restaurateurs Frank and Elizabeth Minier (he is of Cuban descent; she, of Italian and Colombian heritage) who opened Tony Cuban Cucina & Cocktails in Freeport in May.

title: Mullah Muhammad Omars Life Ends With Little Clarity
description: WASHINGTON  In the winter of 2014, an Afghan with links to top Taliban leaders approached Afghanistans intelligence service with a startling tip: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the secretive leader of the Taliban, had died in a hospital in Karachi, Pakistan.

title: Review: I Am Chris Farley, a Brief Life, Lived for Laughs
description: I Am Chris Farley paints an effusive portrait of its title subject, a man the Saturday Night Live creator Lorne Michaels is shown calling an infuriatingly talented comedian.

title: Banking for Pot Industry Hits a Roadblock
description: Banking regulators just said no to a financial institution that aims to be the first to serve the expanding marijuana industry in Colorado.

title: Spike in Donor Numbers for Clinton Foundation
description: The Clinton Foundation accelerated its fund-raising in the first six months of the year, officials said Thursday, as Hillary Rodham Clinton was gearing up for her presidential run amid a crush of news reports scrutinizing the charitys solicitation of foreign donors.

title: Review: Jennys Wedding, a Lecture on Tolerance
description: Jennys Wedding begins with a christening and ends with a conga line  a finale signaled so clearly that even those in the cheap seats cant miss it. And thats one of the many irritants in this trite, well-intentioned lecture on tolerance: The audience is always several moves ahead of the script.

title: Taking Aim at Planned Parenthood, Conservatives Use Familiar Tactic
description: WASHINGTON  The vow by ardently conservative Republicans to reject any spending bill that does not cut off federal funds for Planned Parenthood is their latest attempt to force through policies by threatening to shut down the government.

title: Review: Emanuel Ax, at the Mostly Mozart Festival, Gives a 19th-Century Lesson
description: In the 19th century, when many homes had a piano and before recorded music was available, composers often disseminated their orchestral works to a wider public via piano transcriptions. Composers also transcribed their predecessors music; Liszt created solo piano arrangements of all the Beethoven symphonies as well as numerous virtuosic opera transcriptions. Many musicians, like Schumann, created duo works and arrangements for the amateur market.

title: Review: In A Lego Brickumentary, Master Builders Working and Playing
description: Youd expect A Lego Brickumentary to be an extended plug for Lego products, and it is certainly that  to an extent. (Lego did not finance the film.) And this nimble, expertly paced family-friendly film by Daniel Junge and Kief Davidson dutifully covers the origins of the Lego company in Billund, Denmark, and its growth into a global toy brand rivaling Mattel and Hasbro. But it delves into other things: how engineers and psychologists have employed the pieces as tools, and the ways in which people have adopted Legos as a medium to realize their creative visions.

title: Marylands Governor Orders Immediate Shuttering of Long-Troubled Baltimore Jail
description: The man who until recently ran the huge, fortresslike city jail in Baltimore impregnated four corrections officers, bought fancy cars and demanded unchallenged loyalty, investigators would later say.

title: Ivan Moravec, Pianist, Dies at 84; His Music Penetrated Iron Curtain
description: Ivan Moravec, a Czech pianist who earned a reputation as one of the greatest interpreters of Chopin largely through recordings that had penetrated the Iron Curtain, died on Monday in Prague. He was 84.

title: Review: Paulo Coelhos Best Story Hopscotches Through an Authors Career
description: Before the Brazilian author Paulo Coelho published his mythic quest of a fable, The Alchemist, he had already written plays, put out a magazine, made hit records with the Brazilian rock star Raul Seixas and became a music executive. So the title of this biopic, Paulo Coelhos Best Story, is apt: His own life might well be his greatest work.

title: Richard D. Bass, Ski Resort Developer Who Climbed Tallest Peaks, Dies at 85
description: Richard D. Bass, an oil and gas scion and Texas rancher who preferred mountain altitudes to oil field flats, building the Snowbird ski resort in the Utah Rockies and scaling the highest peaks all over the world, finally reaching the summit of Mount Everest after three failed attempts, died on Sunday at his home in Dallas. He was 85.

title: Undone Deal Is Astros Gain
description: HOUSTON  Sitting in the dugout at Minute Maid Park in Houston this week, the Astros general manager, Jeff Luhnow, reflected on the way his job had changed. The Astros are making a playoff push, a bit ahead of schedule, after six losing seasons in a row. The team expects to contend for a long time, but that did not lessen Luhnows urgency.

title: Glare of Video Is Shifting Publics View of Police
description: They began as workaday interactions between the police and the public, often involving minor traffic stops in places like Cincinnati; North Charleston, S.C.; and Waller County, Tex. But they swiftly escalated into violent encounters. And all were captured on video.

title: Mike Pyle, Captain of 9-0 Yale Team and Champion Bears in 63, Dies at 76
description: Mike Pyle, the captain of Yales last unbeaten and untied football team and of the 1963 N.F.L. champion Chicago Bears, died at 76 on Wednesday in Highland Park, Ill., after a decade-long battle with dementia, which his family believes may have resulted from the battering he took as an offensive lineman.

title: Attack on Gay Pride Parade Shakes Israels Self-Image as Bastion of Tolerance
description: As the news spread online that an ultra-Orthodox Jewish man had stabbed six people at Jerusalems annual Gay Pride Parade on Thursday, accompanied by terrifying images of the attack, critics of Israel were quick to argue that the rampage undermined the countrys self-image as a bastion of tolerance in the region.

title: Koch Brothers Brave Spotlight to Try to Alter Their Image
description: Once known for grim letters to fellow wealthy Americans warning of socialist apocalypse, Charles G. Koch now promotes research on the link between freedom and everyday happiness. Turn on The Big Bang Theory or Morning Joe, and you are likely to see soft-focus television spots introducing some of the many employees of Koch Industries.

title: Review: In That Sugar Film, a Bitter Truth
description: In That Sugar Film, Damon Gameau, an engaging Australian actor-director who has been off refined sugars for years, shifts his consumption for two months to include 40 teaspoons of sugar a day, the average Aussies intake. And he isnt scarfing candy and soda: Instead, to highlight the hidden sugars in so-called healthy alternatives, he consumes products like low-fat yogurt, juice and cereal.

title: Review: Wild City Follows Two (Very) Good Samaritans in Hong Kong
description: Much has changed in Hong Kong since Ringo Lams classic 1987 undercover thriller, City on Fire, starring Chow Yun-fat, but one scourge of urban life apparently persists: sidewalks and shops plagued by careening car chases. Wild City, Mr. Lams respectable but average return to directing feature films after a recent hiatus, follows an accidental hero, T-Man (Louis Koo), who often laments the evils of cash. But its mayhem, not moralizing, that perks up the story.

title: Texas Troopers Behavior Called Catalyst in Sandra Blands Death
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The head of the Texas state police department faced fierce grilling by lawmakers here Thursdayover the confrontational behavior of a trooper in the arrest of Sandra Bland, who was found hanged in her Waller County jail cell this month, three days after she was taken into custody after a routine traffic stop.

title: Turn Awkward
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  You definitely cant say that this one by James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson wasnt exciting. If you are going to start your weekend with a crossword puzzle, it might as well have SEXY BEAST, GET WEIRD and RUN AMOK in it.

title: Family of Man Killed by Rogue Detectives Settles Suit for $5 Million
description: The last that Israel Greenwalds daughters saw of him was in February 1986. Yael, then 7, had the flu, and her father stayed up all night with her; the next morning, he hugged Michal, 9, when he left her at her bus stop. They never saw him again. The married father of two girls, a diamond dealer and a religious man with no criminal record, simply seemed to disappear.

title: Review: Skepta Returns to the Rugged at Palisades and MoMA PS1
description: Last year, the British grime rapper Skepta released Thats Not Me, a punchy, skittish, electrifying song that went on to become one of his biggest hits. It was also a song that announced a creative rebirth by way of de-accessioning  Skepta had been releasing music for more than a decade, and was a star for years, but to rediscover himself, he had to return to grimes rugged origins.

title: 4 N.J. Transit Conductors Sold Stolen Tickets, Prosecutors Say
description: The four New Jersey Transit conductors collected tickets from their usual passengers in their usual cars, making idle chatter day after day as riders flashed monthly rail passes that can run more than $400.

title: Judge Hears Arguments on an Exxon Settlement
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J.  For months, environmental groups, state lawmakers and others have blasted a proposed $225 million deal to settle a longstanding environmental pollution case between New Jersey and Exxon Mobil Corporation.

title: Stand-Up Comedy Beyond the Brick Wall
description: Everything that Ive done in life thats been remotely successful started out with a joke that I just blurted out, said Brandon Scott Wolf, a stand-up comedian based in Brooklyn. And then I was like, You know what, Im going to do that.

title: Dancing for Geoffrey Holders Birthday and Legacy
description: Geoffrey Holder was, for starters, a dancer. He was also a choreographer, an actor, a painter  the list goes on. With a towering height (6-foot-6) and personality to match, he made his presence known all over New York for over 50 years.

title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art: A Look Back
description: 143 YEARS AGO

title: Bad Day for Dry Cleaning
description: A man tried to protect his clothes as he crossed 26th Street at Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday. Forecasters say Friday will be sunny, with a high in the 90s.

title: Facebook Taking Open-Source Software Ethos to Drones
description: Facebook is developing advanced telecommunications, complete with autonomous laser-firing drones, and it is doing it as if it were a big software project.

title: Families of 2008 Crane Collapse Victims Are Awarded $48 Million
description: One of the longest civil trials in New York City history ended on Thursday when a jury found the owner of a crane company responsible for the deaths of two people killed when a tower crane collapsed in Manhattan seven years ago.

title: Report Reveals New York City Paid $138 Million in Settlements Related to Potholes on Roadways
description: New York City should do a better job of fixing potholes to reduce the amount of money it pays to settle claims involving injuries and damage they cause, which have cost taxpayers $138 million in the past six years, Comptroller Scott M. Stringer said on Thursday.

title: Movie Review: The End of the Tour
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews The End of Tour.

title: U.S. Sets Goal for Faster Supercomputers. Much, Much Faster.
description: President Obama has announced an ambitious plan to build the worlds fastest computer, a machine capable of speeds far beyond technologys current reach, in a bid to enlarge the frontiers of fields including medicine, biology and astronomy.

title: Facing Death With a Shrug in Two Versions of The Killers
description: To read Ernest Hemingways short story The Killers, first published in Scribners magazine in 1927, is to understand why this most mainstream of American writers was once considered a modernist.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Ta-Nehisi Coates
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Ta-Nehisi Coates, national correspondent for the Atlantic and the author of Between The World and Me and The Beautiful Struggle, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

title: Yankees Fall in Ninth Inning, Capping a Day of Frustration
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On a day when the Yankees lost out on acquiring David Price and lost one of their best pitchers, Michael Pineda, to the disabled list, they also suffered a rare letdown from their two nearly infallible relievers.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) FOXCATCHER (2014) Bennett Miller recounts the based-in-truth story of the chemical company heir John E. du Pont (Steve Carell) and his dream of Olympic glory, which leads him to build a training center on his Foxcatcher Farm in Newtown Square, Pa., and lure the gold-medal wrestler Mark Schultz (Channing Tatum, far left, with Mr. Carell) to live and train there. Mark Ruffalo plays Marks brother, Dave, himself a gifted wrestler, who is disinclined to join the crusade. Vanessa Redgrave is Johns disapproving mother, who finds the sport beneath the familys station. Beautifully acted and impeccably mounted, it is light on historical details and heavy on atmosphere, character and chintz, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama, which earned Oscar nominations for Mr. Carell, Mr. Ruffalo and Mr. Miller; its screenwriters, E. Max Frye and Dan Futterman; and Bill Corso and Dennis Liddiard, the men behind Mr. Carells large prosthetic nose. Some of the best scenes in the movie are of the brothers, including an early one in which they train in their old gym, hitting and grasping in a pantomime of aggression and affection, the crowns of their heads touching like the antlers of young stags testing each other, Mr. Scott added. Its rare to see such physical male intimacy on screen, especially among men not bonded by war. And its in the depictions of this intimacy, in its tangle of bodies and desires  the images of John squirming on top of and below other men say more than any of his pitiful speeches  that Foxcatcher rises to the occasion of real tragedy.

title: Corrections: July 31, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Jails were never meant to be mental health hospitals.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: July 31
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include water-gazers at the Battery, high temperature scenes across the city and more summer love.

title: Jewish Arsonists Suspected in West Bank Attack That Killed Palestinian Toddler
description: DUMA, West Bank  Residents of this Palestinian hamlet still awake on a hot summer night heard the screams and rushed to the Dawabsheh home. Outside, Saad, 32, lay writhing on the ground. Nearby, his wife, Riham, 27, was still on fire. Their 4-year-old son, Ahmad, could be heard crying inside the burning house, and his brother, 18-month-old Ali, was already dead.

title: In Guatemala, Exhuming Children to Make Room for Death
description: There is palpable heartbreak in the photos of Saul Martinez. On one level, it is evoked by the subject itself: The bodies of Guatemalan children have been put into mass graves after being removed from burial niches because their parents could not  or forgot  to pay the upkeep fee. But just as sad is the underlying reason: Guatemalas mind-numbingly high levels of violence have created an unceasing demand for new burial spaces.

title: A Nighttime Police Visit in China
description: On the night of July 11, the police in Guangzhou came for the human rights lawyer Ge Wenxiu. They threatened to break down his door.

title: Setting Big Goals, Hillary Clinton Joins the Climate Battle
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has promised a series of initiatives to address the challenge of climate change. The first installment, unveiled this week in Iowa, calls for an aggressive expansion of wind, solar and other carbon-free energy sources so that they provide one-third of Americas electricity by 2027  enough, she says, to power every home in the country.

title: A Port Authority Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Administration Ignores Malaysias Trafficking Record
description: After one year on the State Departments list of countries that are failing to combat modern-day slavery, Malaysia has been upgraded to a higher category. That judgment, part of an annual evaluation of how 188 countries deal with human trafficking, strains credulity, given how little Malaysia has done to address the problem.

title: The Profusion of Airline Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns and the Two Americas
description: The waves of mass shootings continue to roll over the United States like surf on the ship of states prow. Every few weeks now we get hit with a jolt of cold water. We shake and shudder, and then brace ourselves for the next one.

title: Two Cheers for Capitalism
description: We are clearly heading toward another great debate about the nature of capitalism. Contemporary capitalisms critics are becoming both bolder and more intellectually rigorous. Protests and discussions are sprouting up all over the place.

title: The Death of Cecil the Lion
description: The death of Cecil, the black-maned lion killed by an American big-game hunter in Zimbabwe, has unleashed a global storm of Internet indignation. The hunter, Dr. Walter Palmer, a dentist from Minnesota, has been forced into hiding.

title: Chinas Naked Emperors
description: Politicians who preside over economic booms often develop delusions of competence. You can see this domestically: Jeb Bush imagines that he knows the secrets of economic growth because he happened to be governor when Florida was experiencing a giant housing bubble, and he had the good luck to leave office just before it burst. Weve seen it in many countries: I still remember the omniscience and omnipotence ascribed to Japanese bureaucrats in the 1980s, before the long stagnation set in.

title: The G.O.P.s Crowded Stage
description: ANYBODY not running for president?

title: We Invited Donald Trump to Town
description: WHERE did we go wrong?

title: When Nonprofits Funnel Campaign Money
description: To the Editor:

title: On Raising the Minimum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Films Find Their Audience  and Its Huge
description: This is turning out to be a very good season for domestic films in China.

title: BNP Paribass Profit in 2nd Quarter Is Bolstered by Investment Bank Revenue
description: LONDON  BNP Paribas, Frances biggest bank, said on Friday that it swung to a profit in the second quarter because of higher revenue in its investment bank and international financial services business, less than a year after being hit by a huge settlement for doing business with countries that face United States sanctions.

title: Liberty Global Increases Its Stake in British Broadcaster ITV
description: Liberty Global, the international telecommunications operator controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, said on Friday that it had increased its stake in the British broadcaster ITV to almost 10 percent.

title: Big Turnout for Madame Chiang Kai-shek Estate
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Protesters Upset Over Textbook Changes March on Taiwans Education Ministry
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Lloyds Profit Rises Despite $2.2 Billion Provision for Loan Customers
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday that its profit had risen 18 percent in the first half of 2015, but its results were again dragged down by provisions for a contentious loan insurance product that has cost the industry billions of dollars.

title: What China Has Been Building in the South China Sea
description: China has been feverishly piling sand onto reefs in the South China Sea for the past year, creating seven new islets in the region. It is straining geopolitical tensions that were already taut.

title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Announces $25 Million Project to Link 3 Spaces
description: For more than a century, the Brooklyn Academy of Music was just one theater, originally on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights and later replaced, in 1908, by a Beaux-Arts building on Lafayette Avenue in Fort Greene.

title: This Hollywood House Sitter Makes His Own Rules
description: LOS ANGELES  Brian Farrell rarely sleeps at the ramshackle apartment he rents on an uninviting stretch of Sunset Boulevard. Look for him instead in the Hollywood Hills, where residents pay him to slumber in their guest rooms, swim in their pools and rummage through their refrigerators.

title: What China Has Been Building in the South China Sea

description: Good morning on this sun-splashed Friday.

Given what you know about your ever-changing self, and factoring in the breakneck pace of societal change, can you accurately predict what the future world around you will look like and what role youll play in it?

title: For Sympathetic Ear, More Chinese Turn to Smartphone Program
description: She is known as Xiaoice, and millions of young Chinese pick up their smartphones every day to exchange messages with her, drawn to her knowing sense of humor and listening skills. People often turn to her when they have a broken heart, have lost a job or have been feeling down. They often tell her, I love you.

title: Shares in Mainland China End Worst Month in 6 Years
description: SHANGHAI  Stock prices in China fell modestly on Friday, but ended July with their worst monthly decline in six years, despite repeated government efforts to stabilize the market and prop up prices.

title: Nine Apps for Travel With One iPad and More Than One Kid
description: Going on a very long drive with a group of children and a single tablet? Make a folder called SOS and stock it with a few of these apps. Open the folder if things get tense.
