description: A total of four relatives were critically injured and were being transferred to a hospital in Israel, officials said. Jewish extremists are suspected as Hebrew graffiti was found sprayed nearby.

title: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush to Work a Shared Room on a Delicate Issue
description: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the House has gone on summer vacation and the Senate left the nitty-gritty of a highway bill for September. But rivals from across the aisle will share a crowd and address race relations and the Black Lives Matter movement, issues that have stirred anger and presented challenges for the 2016 candidates.

title: The 7.19.15 Issue
description: RE: HILLARY CLINTON

title: Air Mail
description: The first time I heard the term dead letter, I imagined all the missives sent out into the world that had gone unread. Reading this poem, a translation from its original Swedish, I was reminded of that childhood wonder and felt again the heft of so many truths waiting to be known.

title: How to Cure a Cats Anxiety
description: Impulse-control problems, phobias, anxiety, violent outbursts and compulsive disorders are not uncommon in pets. Unfortunately, you cannot put a cat on a couch and say, Tell me about your mother, says ELise Christensen, a veterinary behaviorist with practices in Manhattan and Denver. (Think of us as animal psychiatrists, she says.) Still, you can treat the kind of underlying feline psychological distress that leads to biting, scratching, moping and urinating outside the litter box. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors like Prozac can help, but Christensen advises clients to examine a pets environment before turning to pharmacology. Ask yourself, Are you coming close to meeting this animals natural needs? The answer is almost always no.

title: Taking Questions: Artificial Sweeteners
description: Readers responded in great number to my recent column on artificial sweeteners. Many comments were on the same topics, which Ill address here.

title: A Slack Lifeline for Drowning Homeowners
description: After Lucy Circe became disabled and could no longer work, she applied to Bank of America for a mortgage loan modification on her Vermont home. Over more than two years, starting in 2012, the bank repeatedly requested copies of documents that had already been provided, asked for proof that she was no longer married to a man she did not even know, and made other errors, like asking why Ms. Circe had indicated that she didnt want to keep her property when she had actually told the bank she did.

title: Hotel Review: The Ludlow in New York City
description: From $295.

title: In France, Biking Along Arcachon Bay
description: It was midnight in the French forest off the Gulf of Gascony, and I pedaled along the deserted bike trail, fueled by the fumes of a fabulous bottle of Bordeaux and the memory of a seaside feast: oysters and turbot, overseen by a grandmotherly patronne in a flowered housedress. Far ahead my husbands bike light glimmered through the dense pines. Suddenly he stopped and waited for me. Cherie, cant you go a bit faster? Guy said rather anxiously. Later, I learned that a boar had just crashed through the woods in front of him.

title: Exit Strategy
description: It was nine years ago, when I was 23, that I first tried to leave Afghanistan. I had been working as an interpreter for coalition forces, and I started getting phone calls from the Taliban. They would say, We will find you, and we will kill you. They claimed to know my name and where I was living. I dont know if it was true  when you worked with the Americans, you hid your face to protect yourself  but interpreters had been killed before. I felt I had to try to go to Europe and make a new life there. So I went to a kachakbar, a smuggler, to get me out of the country.

title: Why Republicans Should Worry About Restrictive Voting Laws
description: When The Times released its joint poll with CBS on race last week, its most eye-catching finding was that a majority of Americans have a negative view of race relations, a sharp reversal of expectations following Barack Obamas election in 2008. But deeper in the results was a telling data point relating to the recent proliferation of state laws and policies having to do with access to voting, the topic of the cover story I wrote for this weeks magazine.

title: Morning Agenda: Supreme Court Asked to Review Insider Trading Case

Mr. Bharara persuaded the Justice Department to ask the Supreme Court to review an appellate court ruling that narrowed the definition of insider trading and overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers.

title: Talks for Pacific Trade Deal Stumble
description: LAHAINA, Hawaii  Trade negotiators from the United States and 11 other Pacific nations failed to reach final agreement on Friday, with difficult talks on the largest regional trade agreement ever deadlocking over protections for drug companies and access to agriculture markets on both sides of the Pacific.

description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban leadership announced on Friday that the groups longtime deputy, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, had been appointed its new supreme leader, and that his two deputies were drawn from its hard-line Haqqani wing, according to messages posted on a website associated with the group.

title: Reversing Itself, Britain Grants Ai Weiwei a Six-Month Visa
description: LONDON  After a day of embarrassing criticism over its refusal to grant the dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei a six-month business visa and its assertion that Mr. Ai had lied on his application, the British government reversed itself on Friday and said he would get the visa he wanted.

description: An experimental Ebola vaccine being tested in the West African nation of Guinea during the continuing outbreak of the viral disease has shown promising initial results, according to a report on the clinical trial that was published Friday.

We were standing on the top of Butternut, and it was so cold and windy that we only did one run, she said. I told my husband-to-be that we should go look at houses instead.

Instead of drenching their salads in dressing, they dip in a fork and spear the vegetables. They mostly steer clear of bread and pasta, and limit their daily caloric intake to 1,500. They write down their fitness objectives, and they exercise together three days a week.

title: Daily Report: That Facebook Drone is Ready for Takeoff
description: In about a year and a half  ever since Jeff Bezos, Amazons chief executive, unveiled one  drones for consumer use seem to have proliferated everywhere. Quentin Hardy and Vindu Goel wrote this year about how Facebook is building a V-shaped unmanned vehicle called Aquila to help connect people to the Internet. In China, a drone maker, DJI, has been valued at about $8 billion. New funds are being formed to invest in the flying machines. Even pranksters are using them to cause trouble.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Hillary Rodham Clinton issued a pointed broadside against Jeb Bush on Friday, suggesting his positions as a presidential candidate and his actions as governor of Florida had set back the cause of black Americans.

title: Donald Trumps Instinct for Racially Charged Rhetoric, Before His Presidential Bid
description: Under a dark photograph showing hypodermic needles and drug paraphernalia, the newspaper advertisement warned in dire terms that violent criminals were coming to town. Are these the new neighbors we want? the paid message asked. The St. Regis Mohawk Indian record of criminal activity is well documented.

title: Shooting at Sri Lanka Political Meeting Leaves 1 Dead and 12 Hurt
description: KOTAHENA, Sri Lanka   Sri Lankas parliamentary election campaign took a deadly turn on Friday when unidentified gunmen opened fire into a crowd at a campaign meeting, killing one woman and injuring 12 other people.

title: California Cuts Back on Water, but Troubles Remain
description: Californias urban areas reduced their water use by 27.3 percent in June, beating the 25 percent reduction requirement issued by Gov. Jerry Brown on April 1. However, some communities still arent pulling their weight.

title: No Respite From the Heat for Air-Conditioning Installers
description: HAZLET, N.J.  As Mike Passeggio went about his work this week, the sun did so as well, melting his frozen plastic water bottle as he hauled old ducts and other air-conditioning equipment from the attic of a house here.

title: Hitting All the High Notes in Munich
description: MUNICH  A bunch of hippies partying, then mourning, in a shadowy gray landscape. A stories-high crucifix propped ominously against a wall. A stark black stage outlined in neon white. A gyrating crowd of shirtless cowboys.

title: Dark Memoirs
description: SCREENING ROOMFamily PicturesBy Alan Lightman247 pp. Pantheon, $25.95.

title: A Hanging at Cinder Bottom, by Glenn Taylor
description: As anyone who has ever spent much time there can tell you, West Virginia is a land to its own: home, like every hard-pressed environment, to the best and worst of human instinct and behavior, a beautiful, breathtaking curse of a place.

title: Ronda Rouseys U.F.C. Dominance Evokes a Young Mike Tyson
description: Ronda Rousey spends some of her time posing for magazine covers, filming television ads and movies, sitting for interviews, winning awards and generally continuing a rapid ascent to sports superstardom.

title: Barbara the Slut, by Lauren Holmes
description: In Desert Hearts, a story in Lauren Holmess debut collection, Barbara the Slut, a straight woman tries to pass as gay so she can work at a lesbian sex shop, largely to upset her lawyer father. He pays her a surprise visit at work and accuses her of shallowness: You and your goddamn jokes, Brenda. You think life is so goddamn funny.

title: The Fly Trap, by Fredrik Sjoberg
description: The Fly Trap is the first volume of Fredrik Sjobergs autobiographical trilogy, En Flugsamlares Vag (The Path of a Fly Collector), and the first to be published in English. A hit when it appeared in Sjobergs native Sweden in 2004, the book makes for seductive reading, a quirky and wide-ranging meditation on the deep pleasures of collecting, obsession and the natural world.

title: Stuff We Liked: Mapping Slangs Spread, Suburban Demographics
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: The Richest Man Who Ever Lived, by Greg Steinmetz
description: Jacob Fugger, the Renaissance-era financier, is a familiar name in Germany, but little known in the English-speaking world. The Richest Man Who Ever Lived, by Greg Steinmetz, a journalist turned securities analyst, is an attempt to remedy that. Though it doesnt quite live up to its promise, it provides a serviceable and colorful introduction to one of the most influential businessmen in history.

title: Circling the Sun, by Paula McLain
description: If you were half awake in 2011 (or 2012 or 2013), you couldnt have avoided Paula McLains runaway best seller, The Paris Wife. That fictional autobiography of Ernest Hemingways beleaguered starter wife, Hadley Richardson, unfolds pretty much as the Hemingways marriage does, in Paris in the 1920s. Caught up in the mass hysteria, I too bought a copy. But when I came to this line, after just half a dozen pages, I couldnt go on: I dont want to think and I dont want to feel, either, unless its as simple as this beautiful boys knee inches from mine.

title: The Watchmaker of Filigree Street, byNatasha Pulley
description: When a coincidence or accident alters the course of a life, we call it chance, destiny, a twist of fate. But if you could anticipate these random forces and use them to your own ends, what would you set in motion? And what sort of person might you become?

title: The Bird King
description: Ray Harinarain has been involved in finch singing competitions since emigrating from Guyana in the 1980s. Today, the sport is flourishing in pockets of New York City.

title: The Love She Left Behind, by Amanda Coe
description: Midway through Amanda Coes sly, astringent novel, about a woman who abandons her husband and children for the love of a famous playwright, she observes, in passing, a young graduate student who has designs on the now aging and insufferable geezer: Even at its most enjoyable, sex always made Mia feel she was missing the point of something others deployed to enhance their status by claiming to find it transformational  much like those who trumpeted their love of the theater.

title: Familiar Names Gave Big to Jeb Bush-Aligned Super PAC
description: A super PAC supporting Jeb Bush raised huge contributions from a wide array of Bush family business associates, prominent Republican donors, and former political appointees of his brother and father, according to disclosures submitted to the Federal Election Commission on Friday.

title: Wealth Secrets of the One Percent, by Sam Wilkin
description: From all appearances, Sam Wilkins Wealth Secrets of the One Percent could not be more timely.

title: A Voice From Chinas Uighur Homeland, Reporting From the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  IN December 1994, Shohret Hoshur, then a 29-year-old journalist in a remote corner of the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang, said goodbye to his homeland. After writing two articles in his native Uighur language that incensed the local authorities, he escaped using a false passport he bought for about $600.

title: Inside the List
description: The Waves: As a war reporter and international correspondent for The New Yorker, William Finnegan has long been celebrated for his sober examinations of the worlds hot spots  going back to 1986, all of his books have been editors choice picks in the Book Review, including dispatches from apartheid-era South Africa, civil-war-torn Mozambique and poverty-stricken America. None of those books became best sellers. But his latest, the surfing memoir Barbarian Days, ends Finnegans dry spell at last, landing on the hardcover nonfiction list at No.5. I was kind of nervous about coming out of the closet as a surfer, Finnegan told The National Post in Canada last month. I mean, I was a political reporter and writing a lot of political opinion pieces for The New Yorker, and I had a kind of reluctance to expose this part of my life and have a bunch of people say, What do you know? Youre just a dumb surfer. Once he started, though, he couldnt stop. Its easy for me to write about the act of surfing. I find it endlessly interesting, he said. The trick is to make it interesting to readers who couldnt care less. This columnist might be the kind of reader he means  Im not a surfer, dumb or otherwise, although friends in California once coaxed me onto a board for 20 seconds. But I do kayak, and I recognize the giddy obsession Finnegan brings to his sport. In that sense, Barbarian Days offers the same heedless pleasure as any addiction memoir before the reckoning; it is, as Alice Gregory writes in The New York Review of Books, an utterly convincing study in the joy of treating seriously an unserious thing.

title: Stolen Consumer Data Is a Smaller Problem Than It Seems
description: At Target, 40 million customers had their credit card information exposed to hackers. At JPMorgan Chase, personal details associated with 80 million accounts were leaked. Last month, a hacker gained access to 4.5 million records from the University of California, Los Angeles, health system.

title: Flight or Fright
description: Dont listen to Thomas Wolfe. You can always go home again  if youre prepared to have your beating heart ripped from your chest and stomped on. Sara Paretskys crusading private eye, V.I. (Vic) Warshawski, finds that out in BRUSH BACK (Putnam, $27.95) when she lets a high school boyfriend talk her into returning to the ramshackle neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago where they grew up. Frank Guzzo, a truck driver for a haulage company, is worried about his unstable mother, Stella, a truculent old bat who just got out of prison after doing 25 years for beating her teenage daughter to death. (She was getting those big ideas, way above herself.) But when Vic pays an unannounced visit to Stella, who now claims to have been innocent, this harridan slanders Vics mother and blames the killing on the sleuths beloved cousin and Chicago hockey legend, Boom-Boom Warshawski (who was murdered far too early in this series).

title: Deeper Mideast Aspirations Seen in Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  As he struggles to sell his nuclear deal with Iran to resistant Republicans and Democrats in Congress, President Obama describes it in the narrowest possible terms, as a limited transaction in which Tehran gives up the bomb in return for sanction relief.

title: Paperback Row
description: A MAP OF BETRAYAL, by Ha Jin. (Vintage, $15.95.) In stark contrast to the lurid lives of many other fictional spies, Gary Shang, a Chinese mole inside the C.I.A., navigated ambivalence and modest motivations throughout his long espionage career. As our reviewer, Ben Macintyre, wrote, what emerges is a study of the painful, often humdrum essence of the hidden agent, living a double life but only half a life.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE HAND THAT FEEDS YOU, by A.J. Rich. (Scribner, $26.) Amy Hempel and Jill Ciment based their pseudonymous novel, about a woman who learns her fianc was an impostor, on the experience of their dying friend, Katherine Russell Rich.

title: 1890: Bismarck Speaks His Mind
description: BERLIN  The Post has now published a detailed account of Prince Bismarcks interview with the representative of the Russian journal the Novoe Vremya. It was on a personal subject that the ex-Chancellor expressed himself with the greatest bitterness, on the subject of the proposed monument in his honor. His friends were desirous, he said, of paying to him in his lifetime the honors due for the dead. The Prince declared that he was becoming reconciled to his lot. Everything had been carried out with such attention to legal form that he could not dream of protesting. He took a keen pleasure in his present life as a country nobleman. Harking back to the subject of Socialism, the Prince declared that in his opinion a bloody cataclysm was impending in Germany in the near future and that the later repressive measures were undertaken the bloodier would be its solution.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 1, 1890

title: New Womens History Museum in London Turns Out to be a Jack the Ripper Museum

description: Dock Rocks, a concert to benefit the South Street Seaport Museum that was scheduled for Tuesday, has been canceled.

title: Modern Families and Modern Money Worries
description: WHEN it comes to their families, the rich have a lot in common with the rest of us.

title: 1915: Submarine Sinks the Iberian
description: LONDON  Sixty-one survivors of the Leyland liner Iberian, which after being attacked by shellfire, was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine yesterday afternoon, were landed at a British port to-day. It was then learned that seven of her crew, three of whom were Americans, and one American woman, Miss Mary Wily, of Boston, had been killed by the pirates shellfire. The crew got into the ships boats and rowed about for several hours before being rescued by a British steamer. Two of the crew died on board the rescuing steamer. The Iberian had a gross tonnage of 5,223, and was built at Sunderland in 1900. Only a month ago the Armenian of the same line was torpedoed and sunk off the Scillies. She, too, was shelled as a preliminary, and a number of men were killed, among them being sixteen Americans. Six more Lowestoft trawlers, the Coriander, Fitzgerald, Quest, Athena, Achieve and Strive were torpedoed and sunk by submarines to-day. Nearly all of the crew were saved.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 1, 1915

description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  Fifteen years ago, Bruce Springsteen wrote a dirge about Asbury Park, his adopted musical hometown, called My City of Ruins, in which he lamented the fate of this forlorn seaside resort:

description: ALBANY  Mirroring a national trend toward an acceptance of marijuana, the New York State Health Department on Friday named the five organizations that will be allowed to grow and sell the drug for medical use in the state, including in New York City.

title: Grilled Clams and Mussels
description: Melissa Clark steams clams and mussels on the grill.

title: Smoky, Juicy Mussels and Clams Pop on the Grill
description: By this late in the season, all the usual suspects have probably done time on your grill: the requisite burgers and hot dogs; steaks, chops and loins; vegetables of many colors. Maybe even a slab of tofu or fillet of fish.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Mortgages for Millennials
description: When Jeff and Zizi Patmont, both 30, found a house they could afford in the competitive suburban markets outside San Francisco, they had very little time to make an offer. As first-time home buyers, they needed proof of financing fast. So, like most people of their generation, they turned to the Internet for help.

title: Face Time
description: Four smoky-eye tutorials.

title: Wall Street Now Hates Democrats
description: Over at Vox, Jonathan Allen notes that Hillary Clinton, sometimes derided on the left as doing Wall Streets bidding, is actually getting a lot less Wall Street money than people think. Allen notes that during her husbands administration Clinton was known for her relative antipathy toward financial types, which may be part of the story. But you should also put this in the context of finances hard turn against Democrats in general. In 2004, facing an election whose outcome was uncertain, finance and insurance split its donations almost equally between the parties; in 2012 it gave well over twice as much to Republicans as to Democrats.

title: Designer Alexander Wang to Leave Balenciaga
description: There is another major job opening in fashion. Kering, the French luxury goods conglomerate, announced on Friday that the designer Alexander Wang was leaving the helm of Balenciaga after less than three years by joint decision.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from a swimming pool in Brooklyn to an Indian village celebrating a basketball players success.

title: Industrial Cities of Yore
description: Nicholas Crafts and Alex Klein have a nice piece that tries to measure gains from geographic specialization in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Indeed, it was a great age of industrial localization, so much so that the Twelfth Census (1900) included a monograph on the subject that is still a great source for students of economic history. Not only did it identify and quantify the degree of localization in many industries, but it offered quick origin stories for the main clusters. Thus, heres what it had to say about detached collars and cuffs, almost totally centered in Troy, New York:

title: At the 2022 Winter Olympics, No Snow Is No Problem for the I.O.C.
description: Its a sad day when the International Olympic Committee cannot even clear one of the lowest bars for choosing the host city for the Winter Games: snow.

title: Coast Guard Calls Off Search for Florida Teenagers
description: The Coast Guard suspended its search at sunset on Friday for two missing teenagers who disappeared a week ago during a fishing trip off the coast of Florida, saying that in covering a huge area from Florida to North Carolina, it had done all it could.

title: $50,917,500Penthouse Sets a Time Warner Record
description: The Russian financier Andrey Vavilov sold his full-floor penthouse on the 78th floor of the south tower of the Time Warner Center, which he bought through a separate company six years ago, to a mystery buyer for $50,917,500  a transaction that yielded a tidy profit, though far less than he initially planned, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Love Letters to the Gravity Boss
description: Dan Price, chief of Gravity Payments, raised the annual salary floor for his employees to $70,000. Most responses were positive, but Mr. Price says that even the negative letters were valuable.

title: A Company Copes With Backlash Against the Raise That Roared
description: There are times when Dan Price feels as if he stumbled into the middle of the street with a flag and found himself at the head of a parade.

title: The Continuing Reality of Segregated Schools
description: Soon after her oldest son was killed by a police officer, Michael Browns mother, Lesley McSpadden, emphasized her struggle to ensure her sons education. Do you know how hard it was for me to get him to stay in school and graduate? McSpadden said to a reporter. You know how many black men graduate? Not many.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: Backed by Big Food, the House has passed a bill that prevents states from mandating GMO labels on food packaging. (Whatever happened to Republicans love of states rights?) But it turns out the fight may not be worth the effort: GMO labels dont actually scare people away from buying the product. In some cases they even increase support for genetic modification.

title: In Coastal Maine, a Historic Weaving and Dyeing Process
description: In this new series for T, Abbye Churchill, the editor of the biannual gardening magazine Wilder, meets makers whose primary resource is Mother Nature.

title: Were Making Life Too Hard for Millennials
description: TO some, millennials  those urban-dwelling, ride-sharing indefatigable social networkers  are engaged, upbeat and open to change. To others, they are narcissistic, lazy and self-centered.

title: Popcast: Titus Andronicuss Rock Opera
description: Titus Andronicuss new album, The Most Lamentable Tragedy, is a rock opera, or a punk opera, if you like. It is long and ambitious and detailed and screamy and sentimental, and its story line is an extended metaphor for living with manic depression: highs, lows, dissociative states. Its an achievement.

title: Popcast: Titus Andronicus
description: Ben Ratliff and Joe Coscarelli discuss the New Jersey punk band and their new album.

title: On Location | Princeton, N.J.
description: Andrew Schroeder selected the New York architecture firm Leven Betts to design a modern home for his parents.

title: Bobcat Goldthwait andBarry Crimmins Explore the Past, Darkly, in a New Film
description: In one of his few vintage stand-up sets preserved on YouTube, recorded in 1985, Barry Crimmins looks like a bear that has wandered onstage. He is burly and belligerent, with a feral mustache and a contemptuous glare, his arms folded in an ill-fitting blazer.

title: Sex Never Dies, but a Medicare Option for Older Men Does
description: Men who have trouble achieving an erection dont want the whole world to know, so I agreed to identify the 77-year-old from White Plains only as Mr. J. He and his wife married in 1959, he told me, and when his problems began years ago, he didnt want to relinquish sexual intimacy.

title: Court Grants Stay in OBannon Case
description: An appellate court granted a stay on Friday of a federal judges ruling last year that N.C.A.A. rules preventing athletes from making money from college sports broadcasts and video games violated antitrust law.

title: When Your Teenager Picks the Architect
description: Glenn Schroeder and Janet Wong had spent months searching in vain for a modernist house around Princeton, N.J., in 2007, and were nearly ready to give up. Why not just buy one of the colonial homes that were everywhere, they asked themselves. How bad could that be?

title: HBO: Game of Thrones Will Go For at Least 8 Seasons
description: When it comes to Game of Thrones, HBO will take whatever it can get.

title: How Rick Springfield Scored a Role Opposite Meryl Streep in Ricki and the Flash
description: MALIBU, CALIF.  Jonathan Demme was looking for an actor who could hold his own against Meryl Streep and also play a mean lead guitar. All the music scenes in his new film, Ricki and the Flash, would be recorded live, no overdubs, so the guy had to have some chops. The call went out. Because of Ms. Streeps involvement, just about every actor who had ever noodled around on guitar came out, along with just about every guitarist with a SAG card. Several actors  about half, by Mr. Demmes estimation  ultimately confessed they couldnt actually play. A lot of the professional guitarists couldnt act. And then Rick Springfield walked in.

title: Struggling to Disconnect From Our Digital Lives
description: It is nearly 11:30 p.m., and Im lying in bed, way overtired. I ought to turn out the lights, but instead, my laptop is perched on my stomach.

title: Borrowing Blind
description: Some students will be surprised when their loan payment comes due. Thats because they dont know what or even if theyre borrowing, according to a recent Brookings Institution report.

title: Two Super PACs Backing Hillary Clinton Join Fund-Raising Forces
description: Two super PACs that support Hillary Rodham Clinton have agreed to raise money together, in a show of unity that could make it simpler for donors to give to both.

title: College Tours, for Just $43,500
description: When it comes to finding the perfect college, the skys the limit.

title: Next Stop: Harvardland
description: What do Chinese travelers  Americas fastest-growing tourist segment  want to see on vacation? Elite universities, of course.

title: The Scholarship in Selfies
description: Consider Parmigianinos Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror for what it is: a selfie. Painting a Renaissance masterpiece takes more skill than tapping a camera app, but in the emerging field of selfie studies, they can be part of the same conversation.

title: New Gear for the School Year
description: College nowadays requires so much more than laptops and textbooks. Youll also need smartphones, tablets and webcams. A thousand pieces of tech that ping and ding and distract and amuse you. Or, if youre looking to persuade your parents to pay for all this, its the technology you cant pass the school year without.

title: Liberal Arts, a Lost Cause?
description: Twenty-five years ago, the economist David W. Breneman published a controversial report lamenting a shift away from liberal arts toward practical courses like engineering and business. Now, more and more university students enroll in professional programs, and the small colleges that were the hallmark of a liberal education are increasingly adding market-oriented programs. Some are closing. Sweet Briar, the 114-year-old womens college in Virginia horse country, is one of the latest to run into trouble. Dr. Breneman, who had just finished six years as president of Kalamazoo College when he wrote his paper, went on to be dean of the school of education and a director of the school of public policy at the University of Virginia. After 10 years on Sweet Briars board, he stepped down in June as a new crew took on a rescue mission.

title: Confederate Symbols, Swastikas and Student Sensibilities
description: Symbols  their meaning, history and power to hurt  have been a volatile topic across the country this summer, and college campuses have not escaped the storm.

title: Philippines President Endorses Mar Roxas as Successor
description: MANILA  President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines on Friday endorsed his interior secretary, Mar Roxas, as the presidential candidate most likely to carry on his anticorruption efforts, which have been credited for half a decade of high economic growth.

title: The Fiske Guide to College Histories
description: In updating the annual Fiske Guide to Colleges, published each July, Edward B. Fiske read through all 818 pages, Adelphi to Yale. You need some way to keep your sanity when you do something like this, he admits, and so he jotted down facts about the entries  how they came about and what they stand for  and wrote this quiz for Education Life.

title: Answers to the Fiske Guide to College Histories
description: For questions from the college history quiz, click here.

title: Rivals of ISIS Attack U.S.-Backed Syrian Rebel Group
description: BAGHDAD  A Syrian insurgent group at the heart of the Pentagons effort to fight the Islamic State came under intense attack on Friday from a different hard-line Islamist faction, a serious blow to the Obama administrations plans to create a reliable military force inside Syria.

title: Inside Perdues Operations
description: Now more than half of the chicken Perdue sells can be labeled no antibiotics ever, a first for a major poultry company.

title: Perdue Sharply Cuts Antibiotic Use in Chickens and Jabs at Its Rivals
description: SALISBURY, Md.  The floors are spotless in Hatchery 3 on the sprawling Perdue compound here. Doors have been rehung to open out, and temperature control and ventilation systems have been upgraded, all to minimize the potential for airborne contamination.

title: In We Come as Friends, Hubert Sauper Takes Flight to Survey the Pain Below in Sudan
description: Theres no shortage of jaw-dropping moments in Hubert Saupers new film, We Come as Friends, an illustrated essay on contemporary colonialism. But the most haunting may be a lightning-streaked nighttime visit to a South Sudanese tribal leader. Mr. Sauper brandishes a copy of a contract to confirm a terrible truth, and the leaders moistening eyes and dejected bearing say everything. The old man has signed away hundreds of thousands of acres of land to a Texas firm.

title: Traveling With the President, and Meeting Lucy, in Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Sometimes the president cannot come to the museum, so the museum has to come to the president.

title: Chris Christie Super PAC Raises $11 Million From a Handful of Donors
description: Chris Christie is struggling to make the cut for the first Republican debate, but the New Jersey governor has plenty of friends to help him out.

title: Into the Family Business at Perdue
description: Jim Perdue initially joined his familys business after graduating from Wake Forest University. But less than a year later, he put as much distance as he could between it and himself, moving to the Pacific Northwest.

title: First Seattle Art Fair Opens
description: SEATTLE  The mayor dropped by. So did Paul Allen and several other local billionaires, as one visitor referred to them. When the inaugural Seattle Art Fair opened for business on Thursday, the crowd included titans from the tech world, as well as Starbucks executives and collectors from San Francisco and Vancouver.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: President Obamas welcome in Kenya and Ethiopia, the presidential candidates at fairs and farms, and more attention for Donald J. Trump while he watched womens golf in Scotland.

title: What 300 Years of Cognac Looks Like
description: Martell, one of the oldest Cognac houses, is currently on a birthday bender, throwing parties at the palace of Versailles, inside the Eiffel Tower in Paris, and, as one might imagine, in Cognac where it is headquartered  and theyre not done yet.

title: Clinton Calls For an End to Cuba Embargo
description: Speaking in Miami on Friday, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic presidential candidate, said it was time to end the embargo against Cuba once and for all.

title: Schimmel Center Season to Feature Musical Work About Gay Rights Battle
description: The premiere of Supreme Justice: The Battle for Gay Rights, a work by conductor Gary S. Fagin that focuses on the recent court decision, will be among the highlights of the 2015-2016 season at Pace Universitys Schimmel Center in Lower Manhattan.

title: After Mission: Impossible, Rebecca Fergusons Impossible Calm Amid a Whirlwind Mission
description: Rebecca Ferguson eased into a nappy armchair at the Paramount screening room in Midtown Manhattan last Monday and instantly lowered her voice.

title: No Serious Health Issues for Hillary Clinton, Her Doctor Reports
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign released a letter on Friday from her doctor attesting to Mrs. Clintons good health and fitness to serve as president based on a full medical evaluation.

title: Of Lions and Men: Mourning Samuel DuBose and Cecil the Lion
description: LIKE many others, I was stunned by the story of the Minnesota dentist who hunted and killed a 13-year-old lion, Cecil, in Zimbabwe. It was a brutal, senseless thing.

title: Details Revealed in Relativitys Bankruptcy Case
description: LOS ANGELES  As the multiple filings in Relativity Medias Chapter 11 bankruptcy case surfaced on Thursday, details of the financial crisis that has gripped the entertainment miniconglomerate for months finally became clear.

title: Tiny Birds, Big Drama: Inside the World of the Birdmen of Queens
description: Ray Harinarain cut the lusty Hellcat engine of his Dodge Challenger and gently lifted his birdcage from the front seat.

title: Review: Ill Eat You Last in Hartford Portrays Sue Mengers
description: D-O-O-W-Y-L-L-O-H. The letters march along the hilly landscape visible through the enormous picture window that spans the expensive-looking living room onstage at TheaterWorks in Hartford. Theyre the perfect prologue to the play were about to watch. John Logans one-woman show, Ill Eat You Last: A Chat With Sue Mengers, shows us Hollywood from a singularly skewed point of view, that of an insider still dazzled by the star-spangled myth.

title: Bush and Clinton Speak At Same Event
description: Jeb Bush, a Republican presidential candidate, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Democratic candidate, both appeared at the National Urban League conference on Friday to discuss race and opportunity in America.

title: Number of Viewers Climbs for I Am Cait Debut
description: The number of viewers for the first episode of E!s I Am Cait, the reality series starring Cailtyn Jenner, climbed to 3.9 million, according to Nielsens live-plus-three-days data that accounts for delayed viewing.

title: Amy Schumer, Louis C.K. Among Jon Stewarts Final Daily Show Guests
description: With only four episodes of The Daily Show left to host before he packs up and never has to watch another 24-hour news channel again, Jon Stewart has revealed who his guests will be in three of those final installments. And though Mr. Stewart has sparred capably with politicians, historians, novelists and media figures during his 16-year tenure, his last desk-side visitors will all be fellow comedians.

title: A Letter From Hillary Clintons Doctor
description: In a letter, her doctor says Hillary Rodham Clinton is in excellent health and fit to serve as president.

title: Review: Billy Elliot: The Musical in Patchogue Has Music by Elton John
description: Hope and despair battle for dominance in the riveting Gateway Performing Arts Center production of Billy Elliot in Patchogue. Set during a devastating, yearlong coal miners strike in England that began in 1984, the musical portrays, with gritty rawness and gravity, the poverty, violence and other hardships of the era. The dark moments are balanced by the warm sense of community that pervades a small mining town and, most appealingly, the release and promise of a better life that young Billy Elliot finds after he discovers his talent for ballet.

title: Mysterious $1 Million Donor Helps Bush Super PAC Meet Fund-Raising Goal
description: Millions of dollars landed in the accounts of a super PAC backing Jeb Bush on the final few days of June, according to campaign reports released Friday by the Federal Election Commission, a last-minute deluge that allowed the group to beat its goal of raising $100 million in the first half of the year.

title: Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers Has a New Director
description: Wayne Winborne has a knack for reeling off liner-note trivia from classic 70s jazz albums, and in his 20s he gave serious thought to becoming a professional saxophone player. But he has never sat behind a circulation desk or charged anybody a fine for returning a past-due book.

title: Rebecca Halls Chic Cropped Prada Pants
description: The Star: Rebecca Hall

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Imagining Envy, One of the Seven Deadly Sins
description: Bartholomew Bland, the deputy director of the Hudson River Museum, was enthralled by the challenge of curating a show about the sin of envy. Envy is the subtlest and also the most corrosive of the sins, he said. It is often expressed under the cloak of something else. Envy is the hidden sin. In many ways, its the least visual.

title: Facts & Figures: Did McCain Comments Hurt Donald Trump?
description: Donald Trumps favorability ratings among Republicans took a dip after he said that John McCain was not a war hero. Fifty-one percent of Republicans viewed him favorably last week, down from 59 percent the week before, according to Gallup polls. Among adults of all political persuasions, 31 percent view Mr. Trump favorably.

title: France Will Compensate Russia for Canceling Arms Deal, Kremlin Aide Says
description: MOSCOW  France has agreed to pay Russia compensation for refusing to deliver two helicopter carrier ships after the economic sanctions imposed on Russia last year over its annexation of Crimea disrupted the $1.3 billion deal, according to a Kremlin aide.

title: Supreme Court Review Could Redefine Insider Trading
description: What constitutes insider trading has always been open to interpretation. Now, the Supreme Court is being asked to decide a knotty question: How much of a benefit does the source of confidential information have to receive in order to convict those who trade on it?

title: Alexander Wangs Time at Balenciaga
description: Mr. Wangs stint at the fashion house will likely prove to be a critical juncture in the evolution of both.

title: St. Louis County Biased Against Black Juveniles, Justice Department Finds
description: The Justice Department said Friday that the juvenile justice system in St. Louis County, Mo., treats black youths far more harshly than whites, and deprives all low-income youths accused of crimes  no matter what race  of their basic constitutional rights.

title: For Some Drivers, Video of Sandra Blands Arrest Is All Too Familiar
description: Rocheane Mabatano is a clerical associate at Queens Hospital Center who lives in Rosedale and has never been to Texas. But the jarring sensation of been-there familiarity she felt when she saw the video of Sandra Blands traffic stop was still with her days later.

title: Britain and France Point Fingers as Migrant Crisis Becomes a Political One
description: LONDON  More than 4,500 vehicles are stuck along one of Britains main highways, caught in the chaos over efforts by desperate migrants to make their way through the Channel Tunnel from the French port city of Calais, 31 miles away. Another 4,500 cars and trucks are stuck on the other side of the English Channel.

title: Guesswork in Cashing In Deltas Frequent-Flier Miles
description: For about a quarter-century, frequent-flier miles have represented a kind of magic for many consumers.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Posts on Facebook: After Miscarriages, Were Having a Baby
description: Mark Zuckerberg revealed on Friday  on Facebook, naturally that he and his wife, Priscilla Chan, were expecting their first child, a girl.

title: Philippine President Endorses Successor
description: President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines on Friday endorsed his interior secretary, Mar Roxas, as his successor. Presidential elections will be held in May 2016.

title: Madison Avenue Condo in an Office District
description: In Manhattan, location doesnt mean what it used to, because some buyers seem open to any neighborhood just as long as they can squeeze onto the island.

title: Billy Pierce, White Sox Power Pitcher in the 1950s, Dies at 88
description: Billy Pierce, the Chicago White Sox left-hander with a blazing fastball who became one of baseballs leading pitchers of the 1950s, died on Friday in Palos Heights, Ill., a suburb of Chicago. He was 88.

title: Hillary Clinton Hits Jeb Bush First, and Hard, in Speech on Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Jeb Bush and his aides had envisioned a big, inclusive, high-minded speech about race on Friday in his home state of Florida, a chance to bring his message of colorblind opportunity to a prestigious group of African-American leaders.

title: What Emotions Are (and Arent)
description: OUR senses appear to show us the world the way it truly is, but they are easily deceived. For example, if you listen to a recorded symphony through stereo speakers that are placed exactly right, the orchestra will sound like its inside your head. Obviously that isnt the case.

title: FedEx-TNT Express Deal to Be Investigated in Europe
description: LONDON  European regulators on Friday opened an investigation into the impact on competition of FedExs $4.8 billion deal to acquire TNT Express in the European delivery market.

title: Open the Music Industrys Black Box
description: THIS should be the greatest time for music in history  more of it is being found, made, distributed and listened to than ever before. That people are willing to pay for digital streaming is good news. In Sweden, where it was founded, Spotify saved a record industry that piracy had gutted.

title: The Incubated Babies of the Coney Island Boardwalk
description: Q. I recently saw a television program that mentioned a former sideshow exhibition of incubator babies at Coney Island. True?

title: George W. Bush Painting to Hang in Washingtons Blair House
description: Foreign leaders who stay in Blair House across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House will have some new artwork to study on the wall between meetings  a George W. Bush original.

title: A Social Network App for Those Battling Addiction
description: Is there anything that would make someone want to join a new social network at this point? We already have Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, as well as smaller alternatives like Ello. And the advent of apps like Snapchat has made public blabbing less appealing than engaging in private communication.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: West Bank and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Mets Trade for Yoenis Cespedes as Yankees Stand Pat
description: David Wright was conducting a group interview near his locker on Friday afternoon and the clock over his right shoulder read 3:53, seven minutes from the trade deadline. It was then that a reporter informed him that news was circulating that the Mets had acquired Yoenis Cespedes, the Cuban-born outfielder with the powerful bat and arm and the ability to electrify a crowd.

title: Restaurant Drama in Review (With Jerky)
description: It is a clich that restaurants are the new rock n roll, but at the Four Horsemen, the new Williamsburg wine bar started by James Murphy of the late electronic band LCD Soundsystem, you could get away with the comparison. Like Mr. Murphys band, which powered down in 2011, Four Horsemen is stylishly designed and intelligently loud, with elements that are crunchy and techy. The minimalist dcor  layered cedar wood and painted burlap  muffles the sound to allow conversation amid the vegetable-rich small plates. On Tuesday night, the 37 seats filled up and stayed full. No one seemed to be stalking the rock star partner.

title: Review: In Arena, Walter Dundervill Uses Fabric as a Foil
description: Walter Dundervill has tapped into a new aspect of performance: the art of draping.

title: Inquiry Into Litvinenko Poisoning Ends With a Nugget of Debris
description: LONDON  It provoked years of legal wrangling, diplomatic intrigue and dogged sleuthing by detectives from Scotland Yard seeking clues in abstruse nuclear science.

title: Coffee From a Cart in SoHo
description: With Peddler, Byron Kaplan has established a portable cafe with all the trappings of a more traditional one, minus the laptops.

title: Hillary Clinton, in Miami, Calls for Lifting of Embargo on Cuba
description: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday called for lifting the embargo on Cuba, saying closer relations with the island nation will bring about change and new freedoms.

title: Coffee Connections at Peddler in SoHo
description: On a humid Monday in July, the corner of Houston and Lafayette was typically busy. Tourists and late-afternoon commuters rushed into the subway. Yellow cabs lurched in and out of the gas station, avoiding shoppers carrying bags from Uniqlo and Zara. In the commotion, you easily could have missed the coffee cart with a frayed, slightly cockeyed umbrella, around which the citys motion pooled and slowed to an amble.

title: Review: Two BBC Proms More Modern than Pastoral
description: LONDON  Elgar at the Proms. Say the words, and the mind recalls pomp and circumstance, a sea of Union flags waving to hope, glory and the memory of empire. Think of Holsts The Planets, too, and the strains of Jupiter, later set as the patriotic hymn I vow to thee, my country, wander through the ears.

title: July 31, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from West Bank, United States, La Runion and Malaysia.

title: Review: Dapline! Demonstrates Gesture as Communication and Dance
description: Dapping could be defined as elaborate handshaking, but that would only begin to describe this kind of greeting, developed by and still largely associated with African-American men. Yes, hands clasp and shake, but they also slide and slap and snap. Something between a punch and an embrace, dapping is communication through touch, a dialect direct in its wordlessness but still rich in emotional nuance and gestural beauty  like dance. All of these facets are illuminated by Dapline!, a powerful dance that Renegade Performance Group debuted on Thursday in University Settlements Speyer Hall on the Lower East Side. Choreographed by Andr M. Zachery with the artist LaMont Hamilton, this work for six men has no sound accompaniment but is hardly silent. Skin hits skin. Feet and fists pound the floor.

title: Bill Cunningham | Daytime Goddesses
description: Its hot and humid in New York City, but our sense of style isnt going to be dented one bit. From gold and silver sandals to shimmery dresses, people are still dressed and ready to do business.

title: Enter Sound Man: An Insiders Look at Baseballs Walk-Up Music
description: Mike Castellani put aside his pregame dinner, leaned back and smiled. Dressed in a blue polo shirt and gray jeans and twirling a pair of eyeglasses in his hand, he was as ready as he would ever be for the music to begin.

title: Reactions to Article About Gender Integration in the Marine Corps
description: Earlier this week, The Times asked readers what they thought of Lt. Col. Kate Germanos article arguing parity for men and women who enlist in the Marines Corps, and what could be done to improve gender integration. Colonel Germano, who served at the all-women boot camp in Parris Island in South Carolina, wrote that women face lower expectations for accountability and that high standards should be demanded of all recruits and Marines.

title: Bill Cunningham | Daytime Goddesses
description: Its hot and humid in New York City, but our sense of style isnt going to be dented one bit. From gold and silver sandals to shimmery dresses, people are still dressed and ready to do business.

title: Microsoft Said to Invest Big Sum in Uber
description: Microsoft has agreed to invest in Uber, according to people with knowledge of the matter, as part of a funding round that values the ride-hailing company at around $51 billion.

title: Sunday at Grey Gardens With Liz Lange, Fashion Designer
description: When Liz Langes real estate broker sent her the rental listing for Grey Gardens, the famed East Hampton estate, her eyes nearly popped out. Ms. Lange, a fashion designer who sold her maternity-wear business in 2007 but remains its creative director, had long been captivated by the decaying mansion and its eccentric former residents, Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Edie, who were immortalized in a 1975 documentary and who are also the subjects of a  2006 Broadway musical being revived this month at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor. Ms. Lange was also obsessed with the houses subsequent renovation by the journalists Sally Quinn and Ben Bradlee. Theres history in that house, she said. She rented it, and Ms. Lange, 48, who lives on the Upper East Side, is spending extended weekends at Grey Gardens this summer with her fianc, a lawyer; her children, Gus, 16, and Alice, 14; and their Goldendoodle, Rosie.

title: Music Artists Take On the Business, Calling for Change
description: Musicians are known for speaking out on issues like human rights, politics and the environment. They are less known for speaking out about how the music business itself should operate.

title: Evening Hours | A Splendid Landscape
description: A creative party in the Hamptons, a dinner in white and a night of mostly Mozart.

title: Friday Night Music: Of Monsters and Men, Crystals
description: Iceland has recovered from its crisis, and Of Monsters and Men is out with a new album. These two facts have absolutely nothing to do with each other.

title: Welcome to Your Airbnb
description: OH, my gosh, welcome! So great to meet you! Im Margot. This is my boyfriend, Claudio. Claudio doesnt talk much. He mostly speaks with his body. Were superexcited to have you here for the weekend.

title: What We Learned While Eating Ice Cream
description: Some elephants respond to the rumba, but not the tango and other concise lessons from the past few months.

title: Unpacking and Decoding the World of Animation
description: BUFFALO  Printed as epigraph in many animators handbooks is the quotable Walt Disney: Animation can explain whatever the mind of man can conceive.

title: Amazon Pushes to Deliver More Prime Time
description: Roy Price, the vice president of Amazon Studios, stood onstage before a roomful of television critics in Los Angeles about a year ago and instructed them on how to sign up for the retailers Prime subscription service, which  along with two-day shipping  offered access to its budding lineup of original series.

title: Manhattan Judge Orders Psychiatric Test for Man Accused of Killing His Wealthy Father
description: A judge on Friday ordered a psychiatric examination for a man charged with murdering his wealthy father, a Manhattan hedge fund manager, during an argument over money.

title: Behind the Counter at the Butchers Shop
description: Butchers from around the world ply their trade in New York City. Miguel Winograd, a photographer, captured some of them from inside 16 of the citys meat markets.

title: Portraits of New Yorks Butchers
description: If you go looking for butchers in New York City, as Miguel Winograd, a photographer, did this year, youre likely to discover a new generation drawn to the trade by a love of charcuterie.

title: Super PACs Backing Republicans Rely on a Handful of Donors, According to F.E.C. Filings
description: Underscoring how concentrated political money is dominating the early months of the 2016 primary season, several super PACs backing Republican candidates raised the bulk of their money from only a handful of donors or families, according to Federal Election Commission disclosures filed on Friday.

title: Clintons Report Earnings of $139 Million in Seven Years
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday released her most recent eight years of tax returns, showing that she and former President Bill Clinton earned $139 million in adjusted gross income from 2007 to 2014. She also released a list of paid speeches showing that she had earned nearly $10 million in speaking fees in 2013, the year she left the State Department.

title: New York Area Churches Mark Their Closings
description: The biggest overhaul of the parish structure in the history of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York culminated on Friday.

title: Catholic Church Closings in New York Bring Sadness and Anger
description: At Our Lady of Peace on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Friday, Janice Dooner Lynch, a lifelong member of the congregation, looked out at tearful parishioners who had gathered for the churchs final Mass.

title: Review: Karen Oberlins His Aim Is True, a Tribute to Elvis Costello
description: Karen Oberlins extensively researched, beautifully executed tribute to the music of Elvis Costello answers a question that has been gnawing at me for years: Why have so few of Mr. Costellos songs achieved the status of modern standards? For all this time, I had assumed that his raw, unwelcoming voice, with its strangulated diction, was the reason. Surely, a better-equipped singer could untangle his knotty lyrics and sharpen the melodic profiles of songs that Mr. Costello presented as impassioned downbeat mystery stories.

title: The Man Behind the $10 Million Donation to a Ted Cruz Super PAC
description: Senator Ted Cruzs standing in many national polls may be middling, but Friday brought fresh evidence as to why he should not be underestimated: The Texas Republican is a magnet for big donors.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on todays top stories.

title: Under the Sea
description: Symbiosis at work.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Argentine Businessman Pleads Not Guilty in FIFA Corruption Case
description: Turning over his two passports to federal agents, Alejandro Burzaco, a citizen of Argentina and Italy, pleaded not guilty Friday at an arraignment in United States District Court in Brooklyn to charges that he paid millions in bribes to world soccer officials to secure lucrative media and marketing contracts.

title: Dylann Roof, Suspect in Charleston Killings, Indicates Desire to Plead Guilty
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  At a brief but emotional hearing in federal court here on Friday, Dylann Roof indicated that he wanted to plead guilty to federal charges related to the killing in June of nine members of a storied African-American church.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Conservative Heart
description: This week, Arthur C. Brooks discusses The Conservative Heart; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Susan Southard talks about Nagasaki; readers offer changes to the literary canon; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Trace of the Original Whitney Museum Reappears
description: The downtown Whitney opened itself to public inspection this week. There are only two more days to fully appreciate it, however.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Conservative Heart
description: This week, Arthur C. Brooks and Susan Southard.

title: Founder of Haqqani Network Is Long Dead, Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON  The founder of the Haqqani network, considered to be one of the most violently effective factions of the Taliban, has been dead for nearly a year, a senior member of the group said Friday, days after it emerged that the Afghan insurgencys overall leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, died more than two years ago.

title: Dan Buettners Longevity Feast
description: Can the insights of a longevity specialist be applied to the life of a food-obsessed writer in New York City?

title: Visualizing the Common Core Curriculum
description: A photographer went back to school to complete an assignment: helping people visualize the much-contested educational initiative known as the Common Core.

title: Indian Rapper Calls Out Unilever to a Nicki Minaj Beat
description: Sofia Ashraf, a young female rapper from the Indian state of Tamil Nadu who rose to fame by riffing about social justice while wearing a burqa, released a new single this week about corporate responsibility that draws inspiration from an unlikely source: the risqu Nicki Minaj hit, Anaconda.

title: Threat to Tiny Golden-Cheeked Warbler Is Disputed in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  With a pair of 10-power binoculars, a zoom-lens camera and sensible hiking shoes, Shelia Hargis arrived at a thickly wooded bird sanctuary just a few miles from the rapidly growing Austin suburbs shortly after 7 on a weekday morning.

title: Howard W. Jones Jr., a Pioneer of Reproductive Medicine, Dies at 104
description: Howard W. Jones Jr., a physician who pushed the boundaries of gynecologic surgery, opened the first sex-change clinic in an American hospital and helped achieve the first birth through in vitro fertilization in the United States, died on Friday in Norfolk, Va. He was 104.

title: Key Voting Rights Test Now in Federal Judges Hands
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  A federal trial that may help shape voting rights protections across the country in the 2016 elections and beyond came to a close here Friday, with the Department of Justice and civil rights groups charging that North Carolina deliberately sought to suppress black voting with a new election law, while the state defended its right to set election rules and said it treated all races equally.

title: U.S. Decides to Retaliate Against Chinas Hacking
description: The Obama administration has determined that it must retaliate against China for the theft of the personal information of more than 20 million Americans from the databases of the Office of Personnel Management, but it is still struggling to decide what it can do without prompting an escalating cyberconflict.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Conservative Heart
description: In The New York Times Book Review, N. Gregory Mankiw reviews Arthur C. Brookss The Conservative Heart: How to Build a Fairer, Happier, and More Prosperous America. Mr. Mankiw writes:

title: Yahoo Buys Polyvore, a Site Focused on Shopping
description: Yahoo has once again gotten the urge to go shopping  and this time the Internet company has acquired a social shopping site.
